                               The New York Times

               November 9, 1986, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

AS MIDWEST'S FARMERS FACE DISASTERS, NEW ENGLAND'S 'GET BY'

BYLINE: Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Part 2, Page 51, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 900 words

DATELINE: NORWICH, Vt.


Tilling the rocky soil of New England is not the way to make a fortune.

But for Jake Guest, who farms 30 acres of vegetables along the Connecticut River
in northern Vermont, the year will show a modest profit. Not an easy one and not
a huge one, but a profit nonetheless.

Although Mr. Guest and other New England farmers, who grow a variety of fruits
and vegetables, among them corn, tomatoes and peppers, rarely make the
tremendous profits that their Middle Western counterparts can reap in a good
year, neither do they risk the catastrophic losses that can result from a single
failed wheat or corn crop.

''I work nine months a year, and I collect an income for about five months of
that,'' said Mr. Guest, who lives in a comfortable New England farmhouse with
his wife and two children. Even so, he said, ''We get by.''

Low Indebtedness in Region

New England has not been at the center of American farming since the years after
the Civil War, when the rolling fields of Ohio and the Great Plains of Iowa,
Kansas and Nebraska drew the country's breadbasket west. What stayed behind was
a farm community built not around big cash grain crops but around small dairy
and vegetable farms that serve mainly the region.

The dairy farms have struggled, but the vegetable farms continue to thrive,
serving communities from Portland, Maine, to Washington.

''Financial Characteristics of U.S. Farms,'' an annual publication of the
Department of Agriculture, notes that even with dairy farms included, farmers in
the Northeast have one of the country's lowest rates of indebtedness compared
with assets.

The report also says the value of farm land, which has plummeted in many parts
of the country, especially the northern Middle West, has actually increased in
New England.

'Not Going Broke'

According to Department of Agriculture figures, while more than 60,000 American
farms are technically insolvent, only 2,000 of those are in New England, less
than 2 percent of the 120,000 total farms in the region.

Assessing New England's vegetable farmers, Rob R. Hedberg, the Windsor County,
Vt., county agricultural extension agent for the University of Vermont, said,
''They're not getting rich, but they're not going broke either,''

Agriculture officials point out a number of reasons for the relative success and
stability of the vegetable farmers from the region.

For one thing, New England farmers are close to the urban centers along the
Eastern Seaboard, said Robert Milton, an economic analyst with the Department of
Agriculture. ''That gives them relatively easy access to important markets,'' he
said.

Smaller Parcel, Smaller Risk

The New England vegetable farmer also typically manages a smaller parcel of land
than his Middle Western counterpart. That limits the New Englander's potential
for big profits, but it also hedges against the possibility of a single
devastating season.

And, perhaps most important, the New England vegetable farmers typically take
more than 20 different productsto market in the course of the short growing
season. That, too, both limits and protects the New Englanders. If the price for
tomatoes collapses, the green pepper harvest may compensate. And if both show a
loss, the farmer can always try to make it up in potatoes or pumpkins.

''It helps cushion New England farmers against catastrophe,'' Mr. Milton said.

Because farmers work small pieces of land, they always hover just around the
profit line. They cushion themselves against loss by retailing their crops
themselves rather than relying on middlemen, Mr. Hedberg said.

'A Little of a Lot of Things'

And retailing means stocking a variety of products, not just a single crop, and
keeping up to date on market demands, he added. This helps prevent dramatic
overproduction or underproduction.

''I have a roadside stand, so I have to grow a little of a lot of things,'' Mr.
Guest said, ''I can't just tell people they have to eat broccoli for a month.''

The need to be retailers has made many farmers, especially those newer to the
business, dependent on the farmers' markets in small towns all over New England.
On a busy weekend, the Norwich farmers' market bustles with dozens of local
farmers and hundreds of customers who come from throughout New Hampshire and
Vermont for fresh vegetables.

To be sure, farmers in New England, like farmers everywhere, have their
obstacles. The success of recent years has inevitably drawn more competition to
the area.

Wintertime for Planning

So for Mr. Guest, the long and cold New England winter is a time for some
figuring, to come up with a way to get a little edge on the competition,
planting the lettuce a little earlier, perhaps, or planting an extra patch of
melons.

Still, the edge he seeks is not a matter of survival, and that sets him apart,
this year anyway, from a big chunk of American farmers.

As Mr. Guest surveyed the last of his pumpkin crop, he kicked a few that had
rotted or frozen in the overnight cold. He grumbled at the loss - a prime
jack-o'-lantern can bring $6 at his stand -but found enough healthy ones to fill
his truck.

He loaded them carefully, making sure not to damage the stems, the ''handles''
that separate an acceptable pumpkin from a standout. ''There's a saying around
here: You don't sell the pumpkin, you sell the handle,'' he said, lifting a
hefty one from underneath.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Photo of Jake Guest, a Vermont vegetable farmer (NYT/Tom Fiddaman)

                   Copyright 1986 The New York Times Company


                             502 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                  The State Journal-Register(Springfield, IL)

                           November 11, 1999 Thursday

Bin busters drive prices down ;
 Large corn, bean crops spell more trouble for farmers

BYLINE: CHARLYN FARGO AGRIBUSINESS EDITOR

SECTION: BUSINESS, Pg. 25

LENGTH: 629 words


Farmers in the United States have harvested the third-largest crop on record and
recorded the second-best yield ever, according to the U.S. Department of
Agriculture.

That means they'll have to live with low prices for a while longer.

Season-average corn, soybean and wheat price estimates were a nickel or more
lower after the USDA's annual Crop Production Report was released Wednesday
morning. The corn crop is now estimated at 9.54 billion bushels, up 1 percent
from a month ago, and soybeans at 2.67 billion bushels, down 1 percent.

The November crop report is among the most important for the grain trade, since
it's based on actual figures.

The big crop comes as no surprise to central Illinois elevator operators.

"We built a 250,000-bushel bin this summer; Mechanicsburg (elevator) did the
same," said Jeff Ramsey, who operates Ramsey Grain Co. in Rochester with his
father, Robert. "A lot of elevators expanded in anticipation of the big crop."

Farmers in Sangamon County took out better crops than they originally expected,
given the dry weather.

"But we didn't have giant, bin-busting crops around here," said Ramsey.

Statewide, the official crop report, the first of the season to give actual
harvested numbers, put Illinois' average corn yield at 156 bushels per acre,
five bushels above last year. Production was 1.555 billion bushels, 6 percent
higher than last year.

The Illinois soybean crop yielded 44 bushels per acre, a bushel below the 1998
yield. That puts production at 462.3 million bushels, just below last year's
record 464.2 million bushels.

Nationwide, corn production is forecast at 9.54 billion bushels, down 2 percent
from last year. The nationwide average corn yield is expected to be 134.5
bushels per acre, nearly the same as last year's 134.4 bushels.

Soybean production for the United States is forecast at 2.67 billion bushels,
down 2 percent from last year's record 2.74 billion bushels. The average yield
is expected to be 36.7 bushels per acre, 2.2 bushels below the 1998 yield.

The USDA also made a rare update of the U.S. wheat harvest, lowering it to 2.31
billion bushels.

The bulging stocks contained in the report have pushed crop prices even lower.
By mid-day Wednesday, corn was down 2 cents and soybeans, 8 cents.

"This report will probably make the corn market go even cheaper over the next
few weeks," said John O'Keefe of Bates Commodities in Springfield. "We've still
got the same problem of way too much supply of wheat, corn and beans. How cheap
we have to go, I don't know."

The market isn't likely to turn around unless a major weather problem occurs
elsewhere in the world. South American farmers are currently planting soybeans
and corn, and Australian farmers are tending their wheat crop.

December futures prices are currently $1.98 for corn, $4.62 for soybeans and
$2.50 for wheat.

"I think we could see another 10 to 15 cents taken off corn," Bates said. "It's
depressing. It amounts to farmers needing to ride out the storm."

Dan Zwicker, market analyst for AgriVisor Services, agreed.

"The numbers are all bearish," said Zwicker. "They paint a balance sheet of over
2 billion bushels of corn left over (in carryover stocks) and soybeans with
ending stocks of 395 million bushels. At the end of the day after this report,
there's just nothing there to excite, so the market turns lower."

Farmers face a huge problem with carryover stocks growing the past few years.

Several factors have contributed to the problem - continued high production by
farmers, coupled with loss of demand for crops due to the Asian market crisis
that occurred two years ago.

"I don't see anything happening real soon to change the overall balance sheet,"
Zwicker said.

LOAD-DATE: June 29, 2000

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                        The Othello Outlook (Washington)

                                  June 4, 2015

Dryland roots: WSU Lind station looks back on century of solving farm challenges

BYLINE: The Othello Outlook staff

LENGTH: 649  words


The Washington State University Dryland Research Station will celebrate its
100th anniversary at the annual Lind Field Day Thursday, June 11.

With six faculty and staff, the Lind station is small. But as the driest state
or federal dryland agriculture research facility in the United States -- it
averages 9.52 inches of annual precipitation -- it has made many contributions
to dryland farming in its first century.

Station's roots established

Wheat farming began in the drylands of Washington in the early 1880s. Immigrants
arrived from America's Midwest, northern and central Europe, and Russia --
notably Volga Germans leaving the czar's empire with hopes of better lives in
the United States.

Claiming 160 acres per adult under the Homestead Act, pioneers had much to learn
about farming in the semiarid inland Pacific Northwest. Settlers found little
rain in summer and soil prone to wind erosion.

"Some back-to-back drought years in the early 1900s were particularly tough,"
Bill Schillinger, WSU professor and director of the Lind station, said. "Crops
were poor and zero-visibility dust storms were regularly reported in regional
newspaper accounts."

Farmers and landlords wanted research-based knowledge about how to survive in
such a dry, harsh climate. An agriculture experimental station had been founded
at State College of Washington in Pullman, but the need was clear for research
in areas receiving less than 12 inches of annual precipitation.

When Adams County stepped up, deeding 320 acres to the college, the Lind Dryland
Research Station was launched April 1, 1915.

Research addresses problems

Over the century, WSU researchers have worked with farmers to solve the
challenges of the drylands. Yield numbers tell the story of success.

In 1915, the average winter wheat yield after a year of fallow in Adams County
was 10 bushels per acre. Today, it is 50 bushels. The increase is due to
breeding, machinery, soil and residue management, fertilizer and weed and
disease control practices -- all driven by research.

"This region is truly unique. Farmers plant winter wheat deeper than anywhere
else in the world," Schillinger, whose research program focuses on soil and
residue management, wheat physiology and alternative crops, said. "WSU wheat
breeders developed varieties that can push through five inches of soil to make a
healthy start."

Lind researchers addressed wind erosion with conservation tillage methods that
result in equal or greater grain yields than traditional practices.

"The key is to leave ample year-round residue cover on the soil and do as little
tillage as feasible during fallow periods," Schillinger said.

Reality check

Farmers and Lind researchers have remained staunch allies as they promote
priorities in the field, at WSU and in the legislative capitals of Olympia and
Washington, DC.

"There are wheat varieties that look great at Pullman and pretty good at Dusty,"
Mark

Schoesler, state senator and dryland wheat farmer, said. "But if you bring it to
Lind, and it doesn't die, you probably have a winner. Lind is the real-world
test. It's a reality check."

Attending Lind Field Day has always been part of being a dryland farmer,
Schoesler said.

"We've survived for 100 years with local and state support," he said. "That
we've persevered is a real tribute to the wheat industry and WSU."

Only eruption canceled field day

The Lind Field Day has been held every year since 1916 with one exception: 1980,
following the Mount St. Helens eruption May 18 that covered the area with five
inches of heavy ash.

The 2015 field day will begin at 8:30 a.m. Thursday, June 11, at the station,
781 E. Experiment Station Rd., Lind. Tours, presentations and lunch are
included. Learn more at bit. ly/lACwlDL.

Visit lindstation.wsu.edu/for more information, including downloads of major
publications from research conducted at Lind and in farmers' fields during the
past 100 years.

                                 March 4, 2010

Wisconsin leads the nation in many areas of organic farming

BYLINE: The Blair Press-Taylor staff

LENGTH: 271  words


Rod Nilsestuen, Secretary of the Wisconsin Department of Agriculture, Trade and
Consumer Protection today congratulated the Midwest Organic & Sustainable
Education Service (MOSES) for their hard work and contributions to Wisconsin
agriculture.

MOSES recently drew more than 2,700 attendees to their 21st annual Organic
Farming Conference, which was held in La Crosse on Feb. 25-27. The conference
began with just 90 participants 20 years ago. Wisconsin is now one of the
nation's top states in organic farming.

"Agricultural diversity and the opportunity for farms of all sizes to succeed
are top priorities for Wisconsin," Secretary Rod Nilsestuen said. "I want to
thank MOSES for its continued help in bringing farmers together, valuing the
land and making our state a leader."

Wisconsin is home to 1,222 organic farms, second only to California, and leads
the nation in many categories of organic farming. Wisconsin is number one in
organic cranberry and beef sales and has more organic farms producing dairy,
chicken eggs, corn for grain, and beef cows than any other state.

Sales of organic products account for almost $133 million annually in Wisconsin,
and most of these sales were local, with 56 percent occurring within 100 miles
of the farm.

Organic dairy was the state's leading product. Sixty-four percent of organic
sales, or $85.1 million, was from cows' milk.

Information about the Midwest Organic & Sustainable Education Service is
available at www.mosesorganic.org. Statistical information about organic farming
in Wisconsin is available at: http://www.agcensus.usda.gov/Publi
cations/2007/Online_Highlights/Org anics/.

                           Manila Times (Philippines)

                            August 2, 2008 Saturday

Group pushes organic farming in the city

BYLINE: By Ira Karen Apanay

LENGTH: 273 words


TO promote organic farming in the city, the Organic Producers and Trade
Organization will submit a P70-million project proposal to Agriculture Secretary
Arthur Yap next week.

Pabs Villegas, an officer of the organization, said the project aims to create
jobs and give a source of healthy foods for people in the city.

Villegas said they would tap the idle lands of the University of the Philippines
in Diliman, Quezon City, and the Philippine Army in Fort Bonifacio as possible
places to grow organic vegetables, which will be sold for public consumption.

Villegas said they would conduct seminars, trainings on organic agriculture if
their project pushes through. He said his group is willing to pay a rental fee
for the lands to be used.

Villegas, also president and chief executive of Meganomics Group, is hoping that
the Department of Agriculture will support the project.

"The government must invest in organic foods because there is a big market due
to the deteriorating lifestyle of the people," Villegas said in a press
briefing.

Villegas said they have chosen UP Diliman and the Philippine Army lands because
unlike the FTI compound, the two locations are not choke points.

Data from Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations showed nearly
31 million hectares, or roughly 2 percent of the world's farmland, was farmed
organically in 2005, generating sales of about $24 billion in Europe, the United
States, Canada and Asia in 2006.

In the Philippines alone, there are 30,000 hectares devoted to organic farming.
"Maybe more than [that] because of the indigenous people, who also use organic
farming," Villegas added.

                                  May 27, 2010

Climate Friendly Farming project outlines how to make ag more sustainable

BYLINE: The Times-Journal staff

LENGTH: 541  words


New agricultural practices, technology and strategies could dramatically reduce
the greenhouse gas emissions associated with climate change, increase the amount
of carbon held in the soil and replace products made with fossil fuels with
those made with biomass, according to a report by Washington State University.

WSU's Center for Sustaining Agriculture and Natural Resources, in partnership
with the Paul G Allen Family Foundation, released the "Climate Friendly Farming"
report today to outline the progress of a five-year project aimed at turning
farms from greenhouse gas emitters to carbon sinks. The foundation funded the
"Climate Friendly Farming Project" in 2004 with a $3.75 million grant to CSANR.
The goal was to find ways to reduce greenhouse gas emissions associated with
agriculture, restore carbon to soils and replace fossil fuels with biomass.

"The Climate Friendly Farming project has been successful well beyond our
expectations," said Anson Fatland, senior program officer for science and
technology innovations with the Paul G Allen Family Foundation. "With strong
scientific foundations, the team has addressed greenhouse gas emissions and
carbon sequestration in on-farm settings and made significant advancements in
replacing fossil fuel-derived products with those derived from biomass. The farm
of tomorrow will be more productive, with a smaller environmental footprint,
thanks to the work of this group."

Dan Bernardo, dean of the WSU College of Agricultural, Human, and Natural
Resource Sciences, said the project results to date build a scientific base to
support specific on-farm practices.

"The Climate Friendly Farming Project is an extraordinary interdisciplinary
effort that involved some of the most prominent agricultural researchers at
WSU," he said. "Sound public policy in this arena must be based upon rigorous
scientific analysis. This report provides the most comprehensive assessment to
date of the greenhouse gas emissions from Pacific Northwest agricultural
systems."

Chad Kruger, interim director of CSANR, agreed. He said overcoming obstacles
facing farmers wanting to adopt new practices is the next step.

"Regardless of what happens with climate change and greenhouse gas policy, many
of the management practices and technologies we evaluated can provide win-win
scenarios for farmers and the environment," Kruger said. "Overcoming technical
and economic barriers will enable our farmers to be more sustainable."

The project focused on agriculture's relationship to greenhouse gases in dairy
production, dryland grain farming and irrigated crop farming. The
interdisciplinary team that tackled the issues included soil scientists,
bio-systems engineers and economists from WSU and the U.S. Department of
Agriculture's Agricultural Research Service.

Specifically, the report explores and outlines the benefits of technology such
as anaerobic digestion of dairy manure; conservation tillage to decrease erosion
and other loss of carbon in the soil; managing carbon inputs such as crop
residues, green manures and organic amendments to increase soil carbon; and
improving nitrogen use efficiency to minimize one of the most significant
greenhouse gases.

The report is available at http://csanr.wsu.edu/CFF/.

                             507 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                                The Toronto Star

                  February 12, 1986, Wednesday, FINAL EDITION

U.S. plan seen cutting our farm incomes 10%

BYLINE: By John Spears Toronto Star

SECTION: BUSINESS TODAY; Pg. E1

LENGTH: 1044 words


   Canadian farmers will see their incomes hammered 10 per cent lower during the
next two years because of a U.S. farm policy, says a big U.S. economic
forecasting firm.

A Manitoba agricultural economist says Western Canada's grain growers could
suffer an income drop of up to 20 per cent - with no guarantee that one or two
tough years will turn the farm economy around as the U.S. hopes.

Eastern farmers won't escape either, since prices for corn - Ontario's biggest
crop - will suffer along with western wheat.

Chase Econometrics predicts that during the next two years, Canadian farmers
will see their net profits slashed by 10 per cent from 1985 levels, or 20 per
cent below their returns in 1984.

Hardest hit will be grain prices - the heart of the western farm industry, and
one of Canada's main export commodities.

The source of the problem is the new U.S. Farm Bill proper name , which sets
American farm policy for the next four years.

Under the Farm Bill, the administration of President Ronald Reagan has slashed
the U.S. "loan rate" for grain - and the loan rate supports prices for grains on
all world markets. The loan rate for wheat will drop 27 per cent this year, and
for corn 25 per cent.

U.S. farmers can take out loans and offer their grain as security. If the price
of their grain falls below the loan rate, they simply default on the loan and
the U.S. government, in effect, buys their grain at the loan rate.

Since the U.S. is the world's biggest grain exporter, the loan rate has a
tremendous impact on world prices.

In slashing the loan rate, the U.S. has hoped to make U.S. farmers sell this
year's crop instead of forfeiting it to the government on the loan program.

That will lower prices, which the architects of the farm policy hope will also
help to sell the huge stocks of grain that have built up in the past few years.
(The surplus stocks, tragically, have accumulated at the same time as famine has
devastated parts of Africa.)

But the U.S. protects its own farmers from the lower prices. They will get
substantial subsidies to make up for the drop in prices.

Since Canada sells most of its western wheat and barley on world markets, the
Chase Econometrics study predicts sharply Canadian lower farm incomes along with
the low prices.

Net farm profits will slip to about $3.5 billion this year from the 1985 level
of $3.8 billion, the Chase study says. And the 1985 profit level was already
down 12 per cent from 1984.

The profit figures are referred to in the forecast as realized net income, which
is simply a total of all farm income, minus expenses and depreciation. Inventory
values aren't included.

"I'm not sure whether Canadian farmers or Canada as a whole realize how hard
this is going to hit the Canadian economy," Allen Shiau, who prepared the
forecast, said in an interview yesterday.

While Canadian income slides, Shiau said, lower production costs and domestic
subsidies will push U.S. farm incomes 9 per cent higher in 1986, and nearly 15
per cent higher in 1987.

The most immediate problem for Canadian farmers, and for the federal government,
is how to set the "initial price" for the 1986 western wheat crop.

The Canadian Wheat Board markets most Western Canadian grain, and it tells
farmers before they plant their crop what the initial price will be.

The initial price - usually set at a very conservative level - is what the wheat
board thinks it can get for Canadian grain on the world market, and farmers are
guaranteed the initial price as a minimum. If the wheat board does better than
anticipated, it distributes the surplus as a "final payment."

The Chase study makes the gloomy prediction that the initial price for top
quality western wheat will fall $20 a tonne to $140.

That's just a guess, of course. The initial payment is ultimately set by the
federal government, and the politicians may decide such a sharp price drop is
too drastic.

Daryl Kraft, a professor of agricultural economics at the University of
Manitoba, said he figures the initial price will have to drop a minimum of $10 a
tonne.

And to accurately reflect the probable market price for the 1986 crop, it would
probably have to drop $30 a tonne, or nearly 20 per cent, he said. That's more
or less where the futures market is holding prices for December, 1986, wheat.

Prices that low would hammer western grain growers, Kraft said. The lower price
would come straight off growers' profits, since they can't expect any decrease
in production costs.

They might switch out of wheat and barley, and into oilseeds such as flax or
canola. But that would simply depress the oilseed market.

Grain growers with less than 75 per cent equity in their farms will be in
trouble, Kraft said.

"Many farmers with greater than 25 per cent debt, and whose predominant income
is from cereal grains, won't be able to make all their financial commitments
next year," he said.

If the low prices persist for more than two or three years, those farmers will
start being forced off their land.

The farm bill, of course, foresees only a year or two of low prices, while
surplus stocks are cleared.

But Kraft said it will take more than low grain prices to start moving grain on
world markets.

To clear the stocks, he said, much of it will have to go to developing
countries. If their incomes don't grow, they won't increase purchases even with
low prices.

Low oil prices will have to persist to permit these developing countries to
spend money on food rather than energy.

And the U.S. dollar - the currency in which grains are priced - will have to
stay low.

"That's where I become a little uneasy," said Kraft. "If those other things
don't come about, we could be sitting on these grain surpluses at even lower
prices."

Turning to the Eastern Canadian farm economy, the Chase economists see corn
prices tumbling 17 per cent this year because of the farm bill.

Corn is Ontario's biggest cash crop, so that's bad news for more than 20,000
corn growers.

On the other hand, since corn is used for animal feed, it will lower the cost of
raising livestock.

But Kraft warned against much optimism that lower feed prices will be a great
boon.

LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1999

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Photo Reagan

                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                           February 25, 1978 Saturday

TRADE REPORT   Farm products

BYLINE: CP

LENGTH: 163 words

DATELINE: Ottawa ON


OTTAWA (CP) - Preliminary figures indicate an $800-million trade surplus
 in agricultural products last year, largely because of grain and oilseed
 exports, the federal Agriculture Department says.

Exports earned $4.2-billion in 1977, while $3.4-billion was paid for
 imports. The trade deficit with the United States grew to $1.3-billion
 from $1.25-billion, meaning almost three times as much food and fibre was
 imported from the United States as was exported there.

Agricultural economist Jim Lohoar said the trade deficit with the
 United States could be reduced by increasing production of pork, corn and
 soybeans. However, a great deal of the deficit is composed of fresh
 fruits and vegetables that either can't be grown here or can be grown
 only during the summer months.

Growing numbers of pigs on farms in Canada should help cut the 200
 million pounds of pork brought in from the United States last year. Also,
 increasing corn and soybean production should help the trade figures.

LOAD-DATE: January 11, 2007

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                   The Blair Press (Blair-Taylor, Wisconsin)

                                  July 3, 2014

Record planting of soybeans; milk production

BYLINE: The Blair Press-Taylor staff

LENGTH: 266  words


Brommerich News Service -Soybean growers in the United States planted more than
84 million acres this year, a record-high up 11 percent over 2013, according to
the federal Department of Agriculture.

Growth in soybeans was noted in Wisconsin, Minnesota, Michigan, Nebraska, North
Dakota, South Dakota, New York and Pennsylvania.

National Agricultural Statistics Service (NASS) said 94 percent of planted
soybeans were biotech varieties, a one percent gain since 2013.

Corn acreage was down, estimated at 91.6 million acres, a 4 percent decline, yet
the 5th largest corn crop on record in the past 70 years, NASS said.

Nearly 84 million acres of corn was expected to be harvested for grain.

Grain stocks in storage were estimated at 405 million bushels of soybeans in
June, down 7 percent from a year ago.

Corn stocks in storage were figured at 3.85 billion bushels, up 39 percent from
a year ago. Wheat storage totaled 590 million bushels, down 18 percent.

Milk production in Wisconsin set a record 2.39 billion pounds in May as dairy
farmers across the state milked an estimated 1.27 million cows.

Monthly production per oow averaged 1,880 pounds, another record high for
Wisconsin, but less than national average of 1,976 pounds, NASS reported.'

Production per cow topped 2,000 pounds in May in the states of Arizona,
California, Colorado, Idaho, Michigan, New Mexico, Texas and Washington. New
Mexico led at 2,240 pounds per cow.

California had the most dairy cows in May, some 1.78 million head. Wisconsin
ranked 2nd. The 23-major dairy states combined had 8.55 million dairy cows, up
10,000 head from April.

LOAD-DATE: February 13, 2016

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                             510 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                    BBC Monitoring Asia Pacific - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                             July 24, 2008 Thursday

North Korea TV details global food crisis, emphasizes farming, self-sufficiency

LENGTH: 770 words


In a rare vehicle, Pyongyang television carries a programme detailing the causes
and consequences of the global food crisis and exhorting viewers to attain
"self-sufficiency in food" by concentrating on farming with their "own
strength." This programme is aired on 22 July, the day DPRK media gave extensive
coverage to a single detailed report on the global food crisis.

At 1044 gmt on 22 July, Pyongyang Korean Central Television (KCTV) via Satellite
in Korean carries an approximately 15-minute "intensive programme" entitled "Let
Us Cope With Food Crisis Sweeping Through the World by Concentrating All Our
Efforts on Agriculture." "Intensive programmes" are a very rare vehicle for
Pyongyang television to employ: they were aired only three times prior to this
instance - in September and October 2005 - all ostensibly aimed at giving a
boost to major economic projects or movements.

This particular television programme follows the prominent coverage given by
Pyongyang radio and major press to a single report detailing the global food
crisis on the same day.

This programme emphasizes that the global food crisis is "serious" and explains
the causes - citing the "inhumane biofuel policies of some Western countries,
including the United States" as an example - and the "tragic consequences" of
it. After noting that more and more countries are conducting policies of
attaching importance to farming to tide over the food crisis, the programme
appeals to "all functionaries and workers" to "solve the food problem and the
eating problem with their own strength at all costs by concentrating all their
efforts on farming." The programme reinforces this appeal by saying "there is no
task as urgent and important as solving the people's food problem and eating
problem under the condition where the world is currently experiencing a serious
food crisis" and assuring viewers that the DPRK "can attain self-sufficiency in
food as much as it wants" if it "farms well with its own strength."

The programme is divided into three segments, summarized below:

Interview with KCNA Bureau Director

"People's reporter Han So'k-ch'o'n, Korean Central News Agency [KCNA] bureau
director"; prior to this programme, Han appeared in a television "dialogue" in
April explaining the situation in Iraq

Han's comments begin with an introduction to soaring international food prices,
citing Thai and US white rice prices as examples. Han says a major cause of the
current food crisis is the imbalance between global crop output and consumption,
noting crop consumption in 2007 exceeded output by 23 million tonnes. Han points
to the "sharply increasing number of starving people around the world,"
particularly in Africa and Central America, as a consequence of food shortages.

Maintaining that "there are no prospects for the ongoing food crisis to be
resolved easily due to its serious causes," Han cites biofuel production by "the
United States and various other countries" as a major cause of food shortages.
As an example, Han says the United States used up 80 million tonnes of corn in
2007 to produce ethanol. Han cites climate change and growing populations as
other causes of rising food prices.

Next, Han explains worldwide efforts to curb rising food prices and ensure food
security, citing an emergency UN-led meeting in April, a meeting of world food
consumers in June, and the G-8 summit in July as examples.

Han concludes by noting that more and more countries are now shifting to
policies that attach importance to agriculture and that they are "taking steps
towards food self-sufficiency by developing agriculture in one's own country."

Interview with Agriculture Ministry Official

Ri Pyo'ng-chun, director of a Ministry of Agriculture office"

Noting that "there is nowhere to purchase rice from, nor does anybody want to
give it, because every country in the world is now experiencing a food crisis,"
Ri underscores the importance of "solving the serious food problem with our own
strength" by "decisively increasing" crop output. Ri stresses upholding the
party's "seed revolution policy," planting more high-yield varieties,
introducing advanced farming technology and methods, improving soil fertility by
increasing fertilizer production, stepping up two-crop and three-crop farming,
and minimizing flood damage.

In the last segment, the programme introduces U'njo'ng Cooperative Farm in
So'nch'o'n County as a model farm which has increased crop output and improved
farmers' living standards "every year" by farming "with its own strength" since
1996.

Source: Korean Central Satellite TV, Pyongyang, in Korean 1044 gmt 22 Jul 08

                             511 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                            The Press (Christchurch)

                           August 23, 2000, Wednesday

Meat high on the menu

BYLINE: ROBSON Seth

SECTION: FEATURES; GENERAL; Pg. 9; LAND OF PLENTY NEWS REVIEW

LENGTH: 839 words


Sheep and beef farmers, already reaping the benefits of excellent market
conditions this year, are positioning themselves to cash in on growing world
demand for meat. SETH ROBSON reports.

Mild weather, the low Kiwi dollar, and high demand from key export markets have
spelled good news for sheep and beef farmers over the last 12 months. The group
was earmarked as the big winner in a series of Ministry of Agriculture and
Forestry farm monitoring reports released this month, that Agriculture Minister
Jim Sutton cited as evidence of a return to New Zealand agriculture's boom days.

According to the reports, sheep properties on the downs and plains of the east
coast averaged 125 per cent lambing this season and their 16.5kg lambs were a
full 1kg heavier than the previous year on average.

Sheep and beef farmers saw the surplus rise on average from $ 54,500 in 1998-99
to $ 82,700 in 1999-2000. The surplus is forecast to rise to $ 100,300 in
2000-2001.

Experts such as Meat New Zealand chief executive Neil Taylor are forecasting
more success over the next 12 months.

"Markets in Europe and the US are quite firm and look promising going into the
new season. Production will be marginally down from the boom of this season over
the next 12 months, but is still expected to be high," he says.

The main concerns in the next year will be the weather and fluctuations in the
exchange rate.

The record deluge in Canterbury last weekend would have cost most farmers some
stock losses, but is generally seen as positive because it has staved off the
possibility of another drought.

Meat Industry Association executive director Brian Lynch is also forecasting a
bright future for sheep and beef farmers.

"New Zealand's meat industry is in better heart today than for many a year," he
said. "A benign growing season after two years of awful droughts does wonders
for the bank balance as well as being a welcome boost to morale.

"It is my firm belief that our meat industry is poised to enter a period of
solid progress unparalleled in its 120-year history."

Mr Lynch shrugs off widespread claims about a downturn in world meat
consumption.

With the world population rapidly increasing and forecasts of booming Asian and
South America economies in the coming decades, red meat consumption is likely to
increase, he says.

But in order to take advantage of growing demand, farmers must first grapple
with change.

"The modern consumer in the markets that count most for us has an abundance of
choice and is very choosy," Mr Lynch says.

"To be competitive, New Zealand meats must be attractively packaged, convenient
to handle, and easy to prepare. They must promise to be safe to eat, nutritious,
and tasty, and to provide value for money.

"If our products fail to meet those standards the neighbouring supermarket
cabinet holds plenty of alternative offerings," he says.

Overseas major retailers are becoming increasingly influential and lay down
precise specifications to ensure customers' expectations are met. They are
rarely interested in contracts that cover fewer than 12 months delivery of a
product that is ready for immediate use with minimal preparation.

Mr Lynch says New Zealand farmers and processors must gear the industry towards
meeting those requirements.

Significant progress has already occurred.

As recently as the early 1990s, Britain still took two-thirds of lamb exports
and 80 per cent of that was in carcass form. Today carcass trade is only about
10 per cent of lamb exports with 90 per cent shipped ready to be put into
display cabinets.

Processing is already much more efficient.

In 1990, the average meatwork chain with 55 to 60 workers could process 3200
carcasses a day. A modern plant can handle more than 5000 lamb carcasses a day
with half as many workers.

Today, more than half the workforce in a typical meat plant is employed in
further processing and making sure the final item has maximum added value.

This year, for the first time, the volume of premium chilled product sent abroad
(expected to be about 30,000 tonnes, about 12 per cent of all lamb shipments)
will be larger than the carcass trade. And more than 70 per cent of lamb exports
will go to markets other than Britain.

"Technological innovation will see robotics introduced for packaging, machines
selecting cuts, automatic carton handling, automated cutting, and deboning," Mr
Lynch says.

Gene technology offers obvious benefits for both farmers and consumers but it
will not be easy to resolve the moral and ethical debate surrounding it.

There is also a growing market for organic meat that could be profitable. Mr
Lynch believes New Zealand lamb and beef farmers need to position themselves to
take advantage of both the organic market and advances in gene technology.

--------------------

CAPTION:

Chain reaction: the Sockburn meatworks is a forlorn monument to a bygone
freezing industry being replaced by factories producing value-added,
ready-to-eat products.

LOAD-DATE: August 23, 2000

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                       Copyright 2000 Fairfax New Zealand


                             512 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                              Journal of Commerce

                           August 20, 1987, Thursday

GROWING SEASON BETTER NATIONWIDE

BYLINE: (AP)

SECTION: FRONT, Pg. 1A

LENGTH: 454 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


No year is perfect for all crops across the United States, but neither are
growing conditions entirely bad throughout the country. This year is shaping up
better than many, according to the Agriculture Department.

The big news in the USDA's August crop report last week was the estimated 1987
output of corn, 7.23 billion bushels, down 12 percent from last year's bumper
harvest of 8.25 billion bushels. The smaller crop is due to reduced corn
lantings this year under the government's acreage program.

But soybeans, cotton and other crops also were estimated, based on field surveys
on Aug. 1. Although USDA will issue revisions in September, October and
November, the August report historically has been in the ballpark most years.

For overall year-to-year comparisons, the board uses a crop production index
based on 1977 output, which was rated at 100 percent.

The 1987 production index is 107 percent overall, as of August. Components
include feed grains, 107 percent; hay and forage, 104; food grains, 107; sugar
crops, 112; cotton, 90; tobacco, 67; and oil crops, 112.

As the department's Agricultural Statistics Board explains, using corn as an
example, the Aug. 1 forecast over the last 10 years has been below the final
estimate six times and above it four times.

The average difference between the final corn estimate and the Aug. 1 forecast
has been 421 million bushels in those years, with annual variations ranging from
6 million bushels to 1.062 billion bushels during the decade.

"This does not imply that the Aug. 1 corn forecast this year is likely to
understate or overstate final production," the board said in its report on Aug.
11. "For most crops, the number of years the forecasts have been below or above
the final estimate is about equally distributed."

The index record includes: 1978, 102 percent; 1979, 113 percent; 1980, 101
percent; 1981, 117 percent (a record); 1982, 117 percent; 1983, 88 percent;
1984, 111 percent; 1985, 117 percent; and 1986, 109 percent.

Thus, in three of the last 10 years, total U.S. crop output has been at record
levels, led each time by harvests of feed grains, mostly corn, and food grains,
which include mainly wheat and rice.

In the one below-par year, 1983, drought and government acreage curbs held crop
production to only 88 percent of the 1977 base. Feed grains, for example,
dropped to 67 percent in 1983, while sharp cuts also were shown for sugar,
cotton, tobacco and oil crops, which are mostly soybeans.

The major exception in 1983 was the crop category of food grains. The wheat crop
was harvested before the full impact of the drought was felt, but the dry
weather shriveled corn and many other fall-harvested crops.

LOAD-DATE: January 8, 1997

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                  Copyright 1987 The Journal of Commerce, Inc.


                             513 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                                  Farming Life

                             May 16, 2015 Saturday

Revitalising rural economy is vital: Robson

BYLINE: Richard Halleron

LENGTH: 522  words


RUAS President Billy Robson has highlighted the absolute imperative of retaining
a sustainable farming industry in Northern Ireland.

Speaking at the now customary DARD Breakfast on day two of Balmoral Show he said
that farmers continue to represent the lifeblood of all the rural communities in
the province.

"Every possible step must be taken to create wealth within production
agriculture," he added.

"When farmers are making money, they will spend it. This activity acts as a pump
priming exercise for the rural economy as a whole. Unfortunately, too many of
our rural towns and villages are in a state of economic decline. And the origins
of this problem can be traced back to the fact that the sustainability of our
farming industry is under tremendous threat."

"We need a complete revitalisation of our rural economy. And this must process
must be kick started without delay."

Robson was responding to the speech made by Farm Minister Michelle O'Neill. She
said that the farming sector is facing significant challenges at the present
time but added that her department has a unique and vital role to play in
opening new markets and supporting exports.

O'Neill added that, in the last year, beef and pork exports from Northern
Ireland have gained access to additional markets in the Middle East, India,
Thailand and across Africa.

"I am hopeful that 2015 will prove even more exciting in terms of furthering new
market access across all meat sectors.

"My officials have been working closely with our beef and lamb processors to
make preparations for an eagerly awaited approval inspection by US officials
which I hope will take place later this year."

The Minister also highlighted her recent efforts to open doors for exports in
China.

"I will continue to use every lever available to progress negotiations. I
welcomed the two inspection team audits of our pork processors in April, which
represented a significant milestone in the approval process.  While I am pleased
we already export dairy products and cattle hides to China, I remain focused on
agreeing access for beef and chicken. I look forward to a positive outcome for
our industry."

Turning to the dairy industry, O'Neill said last year's 20% uplift in exports
shows an increased worldwide demand for produce from Northern and added that
further growing dairy exports will hopefully play a part in helping to turn
around the recent decline in milk prices.

US Counsel General Greg Burton also spoke at the breakfast event. He confirmed
that officials in the United States are currently assessing the application made
by the UK to facilitate the export of beef and lamb to that market.

"All decisions made in this regard will be arrived at on a purely scientific
basis," he said.

Commenting on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP),
currently taking place between the United States and the EU, Burton said that a
successful outcome would represent a win:win scenario for farmers in both
regions.

"Fundamentally, nothing will be agreed that can act to undermine the scientific
principles that underpin agriculture in both the United States and Europe," he
said.

                             514 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                               The Deal Pipeline

                            December 5, 2014 Friday

On the Hunt: Alico plants more M&A seeds

BYLINE: Edited by Sarah Pringle

LENGTH: 881 words


Alico Inc.

Alico Inc. (ALCO) plans to  rake in acquisitions to keep fueling growth. The
Fort Myers, Fla.-based agriculture company said Dec. 3 that  it bought citrus
producers Orange-Co LP, Silver Nip Citrus and Gator Grove for approximately $363
million, making it the largest citrus producer in the U.S. CEO Clay Wilson said
via phone that Alico will continue to examine acquisition opportunities, noting
that Arizona, California and Texas have citrus markets. "Anything that has a
return rate profile that citrus has, we're interested in," he said, adding
almonds and pecans are also of interest. Alico also operates cattle ranching,
water management and mining businesses. In November 2013, private investment
firm 734 Agriculture LLC bought a 50.5% stake in Alico for about $138 million.

- Jaewon Kang


UNITED Ohana LLC

United Ohana LLC,a Dallas-based Applebee's franchisee operator, is expected to
pursue more acquisitions after buying the Roy's brand from Outback Steakhouse
owner Bloomin' Brands Inc. (BLMN). Ohana, led by restaurant veteran Sunil
Dharod, announced Nov. 28 an agreement to acquire the Asian and Hawaiian upscale
chain in a deal valued at around $20 million. Industry sources expect United
Ohana to look for more M&A opportunities, but cautioned that it will likely
remain selective in choosing targets that fit its criteria. Dharod considers
himself a turnaround investor and does not want to pay too much out of his
pocket. In 2008, Dharod acquired 37 Applebee's franchises in Texas that were
underperforming.  - Demitri Diakantonis

PolyOne Corp.

Chemical maker PolyOne Corp. (POL) is bulking up via bolt-on acquisitions. The
Cleveland-based company on Dec. 1 purchased the specialty products business of
private equity-backed Accella Performance Materials Inc. for $49 million,
expanding its business in the coatings and additives space. "Our invest-to-grow
integration playbook is one we have historically executed with great success,"
PolyOne CEO Robert M. Patterson said in the announcement. The company has been
labeled a "selective" acquirer by industry watchers. PolyOne's latest major
acquisition was on Oct. 24, 2012, when it bought Clayton, Mo.-based Spartech
Corp., a producer of plastics and packaging for customers in the aerospace,
security, packaging and healthcare sectors, for $393 million. PolyOne, which
trades on the New York Stock Exchange, has a market capitalization of $3.34
billion. For the third quarter ended Sept. 30.

- Tatjana Kulkarni

UnitedHealth Group Inc.

UnitedHealth Group Inc. (UNH) may be fixing for M&A after pricing a $2 billion
credit facility. A Bank of America Merrill Lynch-led syndicate on Dec. 3 priced
a three-part $2.0 billion offering of senior notes by UnitedHealth. Proceeds
have been earmarked for general corporate purposes, including redeeming existing
debt and funding potential acquisitions, the Minnetonka, Minn.-based health
benefits provider said in a securities filing. Equal-sized $750 million tranches
of three and seven year notes are being marketed at T+48 and T+88, respectively,
while a $500 million installment of five-year notes launched at T+73, according
to a source familiar with the offering. All three tenors priced slightly tight
to talk. UnitedHealth said at a Dec. 2 investor conference that it plans to
spend as much as $1.9 billion on growth initiatives or M&A in 2015. It recently
lost out to China's Fosun International Ltd. in its bid to acquire Portuguese
hospital operator Espirito Santo Saude SGPS SA.  - Nils Van Lieu

Diamondback Energy Inc.

As oil and gas companies go shopping for bargains amid lower oil prices,
Diamondback Energy Inc. (FANG) is among those that may become a consolidator of
properties in their operating areas, according to a report Dec.4 from Tudor,
Pickering, Holt & Co. Securities Inc. Diamondback, which has a clean balance
sheet and a low-cost financing vehicle in affiliate Viper Energy Partners LP
(VNOM), would probably look to add assets in the Spanish Trail region in Midland
County in West Texas' Permian Basin, TPH said. Diamondback management told
Sterne Agee Group Inc. analyst Tim Rezvan recently that they are actively
looking at asset packages coming to market, especially from private
equity-backed companies that lack capital to grow and/or an avenue for a
near-term initial public offering.  - Claire Poole

Energy Distribution

Energy Distribution Partners LLC is poised to be a consolidator of retail
propane distribution companies and energy midstream assets, according to Chicago
middle-market investment bank Jordan, Knauff & Co. The Chicago-based energy
company, formed and sponsored in December 2011 by Jordan Knauff, recently worked
with the firm to raise $31.45 million in stage-funded equity commitments from a
combination of family offices, small insurance companies and high-net-worth
individuals. "After closing the initial equity capital raise, EDP has the
patient capital to implement its business plan of acquiring, developing and
managing companies and assets in the petroleum midstream and downstream sectors,
with a focus on retail propane and natural gas liquids ('NGL') midstream assets
such as pipelines, storage facilities and terminals," Jordan Knauff wrote in a
Dec. 2 statement. e_SFlb - S.P.

                             515 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                                 The Messenger

                              May 8, 2014 Thursday

US keen to promote agriculture in Pakistan: Ambassador Olson

SECTION: Vol. VI No. 127

LENGTH: 291  words


United State' Ambassador Richard Olson reaffirmed the long-term US government's
support to farming communities in Pakistan.

"Since the 1950s, the United States has been working to support agriculture in
Pakistan by introducing the orange and helping to double the country' wheat
production. Today, we continue our support because improving crop yields
protecting food sources from disease and boosting milk production will increase
incomes of the farmers which would ultimately strengthen Pakistan's prosperity,
US ambassador said addressing a gathering of government officials, researchers
and farmers during his visit to the National Agriculture Research Center (NARC)
here on Wednesday.

Ambassador Olson said that the US government is committed to help the small
farmers of Pakistan through projects that enhance agricultural productivity.

The introduction of this wheat variety helps protect Pakistan against UG 99 a
dangerous wheat disease in the region that poses a threat to country' farming
community, he claimed.

Olson added that US government has provided new harvesting machine to support
the Wheat Productivity Enhancement Project and also is also providing
specialized training opportunities to Pakistani wheat scientists to fight
against wheat diseases.

While talking on the occasion, Dr Muhammad Imtiaz, Country Liaison Officer for
the International Maize and Wheat Improvement Center, noted that without
disease-resistant varieties of wheat experts estimate that Pakistan's annual
wheat harvest could be reduced by 50 percent if when UG 99 arrives.

"Agriculture contributes 21 percent to the GDP of Pakistan and employs 45
percent of the labor force, making it one of the most significant economic
drivers of Pakistan," Dr Imtiaz said.

LOAD-DATE: May 9, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                          Copyright 2014 The Messenger
                              All Rights Reserved

                                 The Messenger

                             May 8, 2013 Wednesday

US keen to promote agriculture in Pakistan: Ambassador Olson

SECTION: Vol. V No. 127

LENGTH: 291  words


United State' Ambassador Richard Olson reaffirmed the long-term US government's
support to farming communities in Pakistan.

"Since the 1950s, the United States has been working to support agriculture in
Pakistan by introducing the orange and helping to double the country' wheat
production. Today, we continue our support because improving crop yields
protecting food sources from disease and boosting milk production will increase
incomes of the farmers which would ultimately strengthen Pakistan's prosperity,
US ambassador said addressing a gathering of government officials, researchers
and farmers during his visit to the National Agriculture Research Centre (NARC)
here on Wednesday.

                             517 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                             March 17, 2015 Tuesday

Arizona: Family Farms are the Focus of New Agriculture Census Data

LENGTH: 488  words

DATELINE: Phoenix


Department of Agriculture has issued the following news release:

97 Percent of All U.S. Farms are Family-Owned, USDA Reports

WASHINGTON, March 17, 2015 - The U.S. Department of Agriculture's National
Agricultural Statistics Service (NASS) reports that family-owned farms remain
the backbone of the agriculture industry. The latest data come from the Census
of Agriculture farm typology report and help shine light on the question, "What
is a family farm?"

"As we wrap up mining the 6 million data points from the latest Census of
Agriculture, we used typology to further explore the demographics of who is
farming and ranching today," said NASS Statistics Division Director Hubert
Hamer. "What we found is that family-owned businesses, while very diverse, are
at the core of the U.S. agriculture industry. In fact, 97 percent of all U.S.
farms are family-owned."

The 2012 Census of Agriculture Farm Typology report is a special data series
that primarily focuses on the "family farm." By definition, a family farm is any
farm where the majority of the business is owned by the operator and individuals
related to the operator, including through blood, marriage, or adoption. Key
highlights from the report include the following five facts about family farms
in the United States:

Five Facts to Know about Family Farms

1. Food equals family - 97 percent of the 2.1 million farms in the United States
are family-owned operations.

2. Small business matters - 88 percent of all U.S. farms are small family farms.

3. Local connections come in small packages - 58 percent of all direct farm
sales to consumers come from small family farms.

4. Big business matters too - 64 percent of all vegetable sales and 66 percent
of all dairy sales come from the 3 percent of farms that are large or very large
family farms.

5. Farming provides new beginnings - 18 percent of principal operators on family
farms in the U.S. started within the last 10 years.

"Whether small or large - on the East Coast, West Coast, or the Midwest - family
farms produce food and fiber for people all across the U.S. and the world," said
Hamer. "It's due in part to information such as this from the Census of
Agriculture that we can help show the uniqueness and importance of U.S.
agriculture to rural communities, families, and the world."

The 2012 Census of Agriculture Farm Typology report classifies all farms into
unique categories based on three criteria: who owns the operation, whether
farming is the principal operator's primary occupation, and gross cash farm cash
income (GCFI). Small family farms have GCFI less than $350,000; midsize family
farms have GCFI from $350,000 to $999,999; and large family farms have GCFI of
$1 million or more. Small farms are further divided based on whether the
principal operator works primarily on or off the farm.

In case of any query regarding this article or other content needs please
contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

LOAD-DATE: May 7, 2015

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire


              Copyright 2015 Plus Media Solutions Private Limited
                              All Rights Reserved


                             518 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                                 The Japan News

                               May 5, 2014 Monday
                                   S Edition

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. 7; No. 22838

LENGTH: 652 words


This is the second installment of a series on the Trans-Pacific Partnership
negotiations.

Japan imposes a 778 percent tariff on rice, a 360 percent tariff on butter and a
256 percent tariff on barley. Our nation has been protecting domestic farmers by
imposing high tariffs on imported agricultural products.

Now, tariffs on beef and other products are set to be lowered in the future
thanks to a substantive bilateral agreement between Japan and the United States
on the Trans-Pacific Partnership multinational free trade agreement, seen as key
to broader TPP talks.

So, the question is: Will the reduction of tariff rates devastate Japanese
agriculture?

Past efforts toward market liberalization offer an answer.

When imports of U.S. cherries were fully liberalized in 1992, for example, it
was said the move would deal a serious blow to domestic cherry farmers. Now, 22
years after the market liberalization, the total land area allocated for cherry
cultivation in Japan has grown 50 percent, and productivity has increased by 15
percent to 30 percent.

In Yamagata Prefecture, the nation's largest cherry producer, farmers succeeded
in securing premium brand status for their high-grade Sato Nishiki variety by
investing great effort in cultivation, including setting up tents to protect
cherries from rain during the rainy season.

Cherry imports, 90 percent of which come from the United States, peaked in 2001
at about 17,000 tons. Since then imports have dropped precipitously to about
7,400 tons in 2013, due to the popularity of the Sato Nishiki and other
delicious domestic cherries.

Likewise, after imports of beef were liberalized in 1991, domestic farmers
nationwide intensified efforts to develop beef brand names, like well-known Hida
beef, to counter competition from imports with high quality. Many domestic beef
brands fetch premium prices of more than 1,000 yen per 100 grams, successfully
differentiating themselves from cheap imported beef.

Kazunuki Oizumi, a former professor at Miyagi University who specializes in
agricultural economics, said: "The nation's agriculture grew weak because of
government policies focusing on protecting farmers without trying to enhance
their competitiveness. It is flawed thinking to believe that the domestic
farming sector will fall into decline due to agricultural market liberalization
under the TPP agreement."

The government needs to employ an aggressive strategy of drastic agricultural
reform to enhance farming sector competitiveness. However, growing voices are
calling for the government to boost subsidies for pig farmers and others, as
typified by the comments of one Liberal Democratic Party lawmaker backed by
farming and fisheries sectors who said, "We need to secure several trillion yen
for measures against the TPP agreement."

Under the 1993 Uruguay Round trade agreement, the Japanese government was
obliged to carry out a partial opening of its rice market. At that time, the
government spent around 6 trillion yen over eight years to support domestic
agriculture.

But most of the budget went toward building public halls or spa facilities and
other construction projects that did not strengthen the competitiveness of the
nation's agriculture.

Masayoshi Honma, a University of Tokyo professor of agricultural economics,
said, "If the government secures funding for measures to cope with the impact of
the TPP agreement, the funding should be used to expand the scale of farming
tracts, to help farmers improve their sales capacities, and other similar
measures."

Can the government use the TPP as an opportunity to put an end to old-fashioned
agriculture policy, which provides doting protections for small-scale farmers
through subsidies and other measures? Japan is faced today with the urgent task
of revitalizing its domestic farming sector into a growth industry through
measures such as encouraging corporations to enter the agricultural sector.

LOAD-DATE: May 4, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                       Copyright 2014 The Yomiuri Shimbun
                              All Rights Reserved


                             519 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                              The Washington Post

                             March 8, 2001 Thursday
                                 Final Edition

Farming, American-Style;
Uzbekistanis Learn About Western Agriculture

BYLINE: David Snyder, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: MONTGOMERY EXTRA; Pg. T11

LENGTH: 838 words


They came from the wind-blown plains of Central Asia, from the former Soviet
republic of Uzbekistan, to study American farming firsthand. They left Mehrl
Mayne Jr.'s Buckeystown farm with a new appreciation for the relationship
between plowing and publicity, between harvesting and hoopla.

As Mayne held up old clippings from newspaper articles written about his farm,
he advised the Uzbekistanis on the finer points of farming, American-style.

It's part manure and milking, part Madison Avenue.

"When you keep your picture in front of the public, then they know who you are,"
Mayne told his guests, a contingent of economists, agronomists and farmers who
are visiting Maryland farms as part of a $ 250,000 federal grant. "If you want
to be well-known, if you're proud of what you do, you want to keep in front of
them."

Mayne's Christmas tree farm was the last stop in a day-long tour last week of
Frederick County farms for the six Uzbekistanis, and two agriculture experts
from neighboring Kyrgyzstan.

The tour is part of a three-year exchange program organized by the Maryland
Cooperative Extension and paid for by the U.S. State Department as part of a
larger effort initiated by the 1992 Freedom Support Act. That congressional
legislation provided American aid to newly independent nations carved from the
Soviet Union.

For the Uzbekistanis, raised in a Soviet satellite state that gave way in 1991
to political independence and a budding free market, the tour was as much a
primer in capitalism as it was an education in Western farming techniques.

"Right now, people don't give much attention to advertising in Uzbekistan," said
Saidakhror Guliamov, an agronomist at Tashkent State University in Tashkent, the
Uzbekistani capital. "The most important thing for me to learn is the
marketing."

Last week's trip through Frederick County was part of the program's first phase,
a month-long trip for the Uzbekistanis to the United States. It is to be
followed by trips to Uzbekistan by Maryland agriculture experts.

The immediate goal, Guliamov said, is to establish a network of farming experts
for Uzbekistan's farmers similar to such networks in the United States. The
broader goal is greater prosperity in Uzbekistan, a country of about 25 million
people which consistently ranked as one of the poorest areas of the Soviet
Union.

As the country moves toward a free market, the question of how farms are managed
-- and who will manage them -- remains unsettled, said the exchange program's
director, Jim Hanson, assistant director of the Maryland Cooperative Extension.

"A lot of [former Soviet republics] are stuck in the transition of how to
re-privatize land," he said. "In the process, the assets are limited, the
tractors are old, and there's some confusion about state pricing systems -- is
it still a state system or a private one?"

Uzbekistan borders Afghanistan on the north and is also close to Iran. Huge,
state-owned plantations in the country once produced a large portion of the
former Soviet Union's cotton supply. The country was so thoroughly farmed during
Soviet rule, and often over-fertilized, that much of the already arid land is no
longer farmable.

The State Department's Humphrey Fellowships and Institutional Linkages program
awarded $ 6.3 million to universities for exchange programs between American
schools and schools in former Soviet republics, said Jonathan Sebra, a State
Department senior program officer.

"We're hoping that all of [the former Soviet republics] will move towards
democratic systems and market economies," he said. "There are some challenges on
all of them."

In Uzbekistan, some state-owned farms are being rented to farmers to manage for
themselves. As farming moves away from state control, there may be more need for
outreach offices staffed by agriculture experts, Hanson said.

Mayne's tips, then, were eagerly gobbled up by Guliamov and his colleagues.

He introduced them to some of the latest trends in small farming. Aggressive
advertising; distinctive packaging; niche marketing -- for Mayne, survival
tactics in Maryland's increasingly competitive farming environment, where large
corporate farms are out-pricing smaller family-owned farms.

Until 1966, Mayne's father, also named Mehrl, raised dairy cows on their 170
acres south of Buckeystown. As dairy prices fell precipitously, the Mehrls
decided it was time to get out of the milk business and diversify.

Now, Mayne regularly gives tours of his farm to schoolchildren, handing out
coloring books emblazoned with his farm's logo. He also grows pumpkins -- a big
roadside attraction in October -- and Christmas trees. Strawberries are a big
draw, too.

"When you're into pumpkins and Christmas trees, strawberries are going to have
to take a back seat," Mayne told the Uzbekistanis, who formed a semicircle
around him as he straddled a row of strawberry plants. "If you do it right, you
get berries that size," he said, holding out his left hand, index finger and
thumb making a circle: A-OK.

LOAD-DATE: April 2, 2002

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                           October 13, 1983 Thursday

INTERNATIONAL REPORT   U.S. corn production   seen falling by 49%

BYLINE: GAM

LENGTH: 97 words


Corn production in the United States is forecast at 4.26 billion bushels,
 down 3 per cent from the Sept. 1 forecast and 49 per cent below last
 year's record high.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture also forecast soybean production at
 1.52 billion bushels, 1 per cent less than the Sept. 1 forecast and 32 per
 cent below last year.

Cotton production is forecast at 7,550,000 bales, 37 per cent below
 1982 production and 3 per cent below the month-earlier forecast.

Orange production is forecast at almost 223 million boxes, about the
 same as last season, and 26 per cent more than 1981-82.

                                  May 8, 2014

Corn planting so far has been limited across Minnesota

BYLINE: Ivanhoe Times staff

LENGTH: 249  words


ST. PAUL -- Snow and cold temperatures continue to put field work on ice at
farms across Minnesota. In its weekly crop progress report for the state issued
Wednesday, April 23, the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) said it
received reports of limited com planting from southwestern Minnesota from
Monday, April 14- through - Monday, April 21, as well as some planting of oats,
spring wheat and barley.

But other parts of Minnesota are still waiting for suitable conditions to begin
planting. Last week's weather, Sunday, April 28 - through - Saturday, May 3,
farmers were still for conditions to improve so they can get out into their
fields and start planting because it rained last week from Sunday, April 27
-through - Friday, May 2.

From last Sunday, April 27 - through -Wednesday, April 30, the Ivanhoe area had
received only an inch of rain, while other parts of Minnesota received a lot
more rain.

WCCO Radio, Minneapolis reported that a total of 4.2 inches of rain had fallen
in the Minneapolis-St. Paul area in those four days, Sunday, April 27 - through
- Wednesday, April 30.

Only 0.6 days were rated suitable for fieldwork statewide last week. Several
locations reported new record low temperatures on Tuesday, April 15, including
minus 4 in Lake of the Woods County, while Wednesday, April 16, brought
widespread snow and new daily snowfall records to many parts of Minnesota.

Pastures have started to green up in southwestern Minnesota, but not enough to
allow for grazing.

                             522 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                       St. John's Telegram (Newfoundland)

                             August 7, 2005 Sunday

Going organic

BYLINE: Suzuki, David

SECTION: SCIENCE; Pg. A12

LENGTH: 660  words


It might seem like a hip new trend, but various forms of organic agriculture
have been around for some 6,000 years.

Although it practically disappeared in North America during the latter half of
the 20th century, organic farming has taken off recently as consumers and
farmers have both discovered the benefits of a more holistic approach to
agriculture.

Organic farming is rooted in ancient knowledge passed down through generations.
Long before science could tell us why certain farming methods would produce
greater crop yields, organic farmers were learning the hard way what worked and
what didn't - and sharing their knowledge with others.

With the advent of industrial farming and the green revolution, organic farming
was relegated to the status of "quaint" or "old- fashioned" - something
practised by hippies on communes, certainly not by serious farmers.

But while the green revolution initially produced higher crop yields, it also
created new problems, from fertilizer and pesticide runoff to soil erosion and
reduced soil fertility.

Today, new studies are showing that organic agriculture can often match and
sometimes exceed yields from conventional agriculture, while eliminating the
need for pesticides and conserving soil quality.

The Rodale Farming Systems Trial is the longest-running comparison of organic
and conventional farming in the United States.

For 22 years, researchers have been planting crops at the Rodale farm in
Pennsylvania using conventional agriculture, as well as two organic farming
systems - one based on animal manure for fertilizer and the other based on
nitrogen-fixing legumes.

Recently, a review of the trial was published in the journal Bioscience.
Researchers measured the economic feasibility of each farming system, along with
their environmental impacts, energy consumption and other indicators.

They found that for some crops, like corn and soybeans, organic farming systems
produced the same yields as conventional systems, but used 30 per cent less
energy, less water and no pesticides.

In fact, during drought years, corn yields in the organic systems were 30 per
cent higher than those in the conventional system. Researchers say the organic
systems were able to perform better in drought conditions because their soils
contained much larger amounts of carbon and organic matter.

Increased organic matter also led to an increase in the diversity of creatures
in the organic plots, including twice the number of earthworms. In turn,
increased diversity helped reduce damage from insect pests, by introducing more
natural predators.

One might expect the organic systems to have many beneficial environmental
effects, but the researchers also found that the organic systems could be as
profitable or more profitable than conventional systems. Although the organic
systems required more labour (to remove weeds, for example, rather than spraying
them with a herbicide), consumers were willing to pay a premium for organics, so
the profit margins were often better.

Living lessons

The researchers argue that organic technologies such as using off- season crops,
using more extended crop rotations, increasing the amount of organic matter in
the soil and improving natural biodiversity should be more widely adopted.

They conclude: "Some or all of these technologies have the potential to increase
the ecological, energetic and economic sustainability of all agricultural
cropping systems, not only organic systems."

In other words, many organic practices simply make sense, regardless of what
overall agricultural system is used.

Far from being a quaint throwback to an earlier time, organic agriculture is
proving to be a serious contender in modern farming and a more environmentally
sustainable system over the long term.

With consumers expressing a preference for organics, and farmers seeing the
benefits, this is one trend that's likely to stay.

David Suzuki is a scientist, environmentalist and host of The Nature of Things.

LOAD-DATE: August 9, 2005

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper
