                             557 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                 June 20, 1983, Monday, Late City Final Edition

U.S. SEEKS TO CUT FARM EXPORT LOSS

BYLINE: By SETH S. KING, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section D; Page 2, Column 2; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 739 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 19


Farm exports by the United States continue to decline, and so once again
American trade and agriculture officials will hold talks with their European
Economic Community counterparts this week to ask them to stop subsidizing grain
and meat sales.

At the same time, an American trade delegation will resume talks in Moscow on a
new long-term grain trade agreement with the Soviet Union.

And on Friday in Paris, Deputy Agriculture Secretary Richard E.  Lyng will
discuss the growing problems of agricultural trade with officials of the
Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development. Among the 24 members of
the O.E.C.D. are Japan and the Common Market nations, the two largest customers
for United States farm exports, as well as Australia and Canada, two major grain
exporters.

$9 Billion Loss of Trade

Export subsidies by the Common Market countries and by Argentina and Brazil will
cause other nations to lose more than $9 billion in foreign sales this year, of
which the United States will lose $6 billion, the Agriculture Department said
last week.

In retaliation, the United States will allocate more than $4.8 billion this year
to subsidize sales of American grain and cotton to developing countries, to
guarantee export loans to these countries and, in a special instance, for Egypt
to buy American flour at below market rates instead of purchasing it from France
at a subsidized price.

The department said it expects United States' food and cotton sales abroad to
fall for the fourth year in a row in 1983, to 149 million metric tons, the
lowest level since 1979. Last year these sales totaled 158 million tons, and in
1980 they were 162 million tons.

American farmers must export two-thirds of their wheat, half their soybeans and
at least a third of their corn and feed grain crops, or else surpluses rise and
their prices fall.

Recent Record Crops

For the past two years, American farmers have grown record grain crops. This
year, the prospects are excellent for more bumper wheat, corn and soybean crops
despite the Reagan Administration's new programs that have reduced acreage for
these crops by about one third. Grain and cotton supplies in the United States
have moved up to their highest level since the early 1970's.

The increasing use of subsidies by this country's competitors is only one factor
contributing to the foreign trade problem, American trade officials said last
week.

They also attributed the decline to unusually large world supplies of grain. The
Agriculture Department reported this month that world wheat stocks were at
record levels. World supplies of corn were at their highest point in five years.
Although soybean crops in Brazil have been hurt by bad weather, world stocks
were expected to remain high.

Daniel G. Amstutz, recently appointed Under Secretary of Agriculture for
International Affairs, also said that high interest rates, by pushing up the
value of the dollar, are making American commodities more expensive in the world
market.

But most disturbing, he said, was the capture of American markets by Argentina,
Brazil and the Common Market countries, which have been subsidizing exports of
grain and poultry and underselling this country.

Before President Carter curtailed grain shipments to the Soviet Union in 1980,
the United States delivered 70 percent of Russia's grain purchases. This fell to
20 percent last year. Part of this loss was attributed to subsidized exports
from the Common Market and Argentina.

Soviet Discussions

The United States hopes to persuade the Russians to sign another five-year grain
purchase agreement and to increase their annual purchases of American corn and
wheat. Under an agreement that expires in September, they were obligated to buy
between six million and eight million metric tons of these grains annually.

American trade and agriculture officials did not expect any marked progress in
the talks with the Common Market this week in Washington.  But the American
representatives expect some flexibility among the Common Market officials
because of the rapidly rising costs of export subsidies. The Common Market
spends more than 70 percent of its agriculture budget for these subsidies,
American officials said.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1983 The New York Times Company

                                  July 5, 2012

State Fair Announces 2012 Winner

BYLINE: The Glenville Democrat staff

LENGTH: 372  words


The seventh annual Farming Heritage Award will be presented to the Philip
Harmison family - Philip, Juanita, John, Susan, Gregory, Kody and Kory of
Berkeley Springs, WV.

The award is sponsored by the State Fair of West Virginia and the West
VirginiaFarm Bureau and is presented to a worthy family who has demonstrated a
commitment to a rural lifestyle, been involved in their community and served as
role models to others in the state of West Virginia.

Seven generations of the Harmison family have continued the operation of the
650-plus acre farm. The Harmison's primarily raise beef cattle and run 150 brood
cows.

As time permits, family members do custom farm work and provide lime hauling
services. The Harmison family continues the legacy of community service with
memberships in agriculture related associations and community/civic activities.

The Harmison family will participate in the Farming Heritage Award Ceremony held
on Thu., Aug. 16, "Governor's Day", at the 2012 State Fair. Their award will be
presented by State Fair chair Jerry Cook and West Virginia Farm Bureau President
Charles Wilfong.

The Honorable Governor Earl Tomblin and the Honorable Commissioner of
Agriculture Gus R.Douglass will address the group and participate in the awards
ceremony.

Also included in the award package is a day at the fair including overnight
accommodations, free admission, preferred parking, as well as an engraved
Natural Stone Award.

Applicants for the 2012 Farming Heritage Award represented eight counties. They
were competitive and the judges commend these farming families for their
dedication and longevity to the farming industry.

For more information on the Farming Heritage Award as well as information on the
2012 State Fair of West Virginia, please visit www.statefairofwv.com

The 2012 State Fair is themed "Memories that grow...year after year." and is
scheduled Fri., Aug. 10-Sat., Aug., 18, 2012.

The State Fair of West Virginia, with a $13.8 million dollar economic impact on
the state of West Virginia, is a 501 (c) 3 non-profit corporation committed to
the traditions of agriculture, family entertainment and education.

For more information, please visit www.statefairofwv. com, or follow fair events
on Facebook and Twitter.

                     The Press (Christchurch, New Zealand)

                           February 28, 2017 Tuesday

Robots will make farming smarter

BYLINE: TIM CRONSHAW

SECTION: BUSINESS; NATIONAL; Pg. 11

LENGTH: 557 words


More artificial intelligence, cheaper sensors and longer flying drones are only
some of the technological advances that Kiwi farmers can look forward to on
"data- driven" farms over the next 10 years.

Microsoft Research principal researcher Ranveer Chandra has been in New Zealand
for a week offering insights into precision agriculture and advances the United
States technology company is working on to improve farming and food production.

He said Kiwi farmers and their innovations could help lead world farming, but
they would see more advances themselves over the next decade. Farmers faced
doubling food production to feed a growing population by 2050 and this would
require more technological advances world-wide, he said.

" New Zealand is quite advanced as far as technology and agri-practices go and I
think this is where New Zealand can lead the world because there is more work to
be done."

Chandra was a keynote speaker at the eResearch NZ conference in Queenstown
before travelling to Christchurch and Palmerston North to meet with AgResearch
and other leaders and leaving for the United States on Monday.

The Indian-born researcher went to the US 18 years ago to complete post-graduate
studies and has led Microsoft projects including in longer lasting batteries and
TV white space networking. Chandra said using technology to provide more food
for the world was close to his heart as India had much to do to lift its food
production.

Farmers would rely less on intuition before taking actions on their farm as they
gained more data and this was happening in the technological space and would
increase in farming for "precision nutrition", better yields and profits, he
said. Stock nutrition would be customised for every animal based on the
evaluation of data showing, for example, their body condition score, phenotyping
and other genetic research. However, this data had to be affordable for farmers
to increase its uptake.

Data-driven farming required more sensors and unmanned aerial vehicles such as
drones to capture information such as the location of an animal, soil and
ambient temperature, humidity and soil nutrients.

The limitation with drones was that it remained difficult to send large amounts
of data to the cloud, but this would be solved once faster data streaming was
available. A barrier to advancing farm technology was the cost of sensors, he
said.

Research for field crop farms in the US showed precision agriculture improved
yields and returns on investment, but the sensors were expensive with five of
them costing US$8000. Chandra's team found that to shorten rural gaps in
wireless access they could use TV band white spaces - unused VHF and UHF TV
channels - and because of their lower frequency they could increase the distance
of coverage during US and India projects, so farmers could connect to the
internet.

Chandra said artificial intelligence would be more mainstream in farming over
the next 10 years. It would guide farmers with data- driven predictions such as
the best time to sow seeds, apply fertiliser and provide the best nutrition for
livestock.

Weather forecasts would be co- ordinated with available water storage for
irrigating crops and pastures or applying fertiliser to them.

--------------------

A robotic milking system for dairy farms.

Ranveer Chandra

                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                            September 2, 1991 Monday

Ohio deemed a disaster area

BYLINE: GAM

LENGTH: 160 words


This summer's drought in Ohio has led the U.S. Department of Agriculture
to declare 81 of the state's 88 counties federal disaster areas.

Agricultural economists have predicted the drought could cost the
state's corn and soybean farmers alone as much as $220-million (U.S.), a
figure that does not include losses for livestock producers and vegetable
growers.

The disaster designation by Agriculture Secretary Edward Madigan means
eligible farmers may apply for low-interest federal loans. The declaration
actually will apply to all 88 counties because of a rule that allows
farmers in counties contiguous to natural disaster areas to also seek
assistance.

Release of the declaration came as the National Weather Service
classified the drought in parts of the state as extreme, the worst
category on an index used to measure dry spells.

Amounts of rainfall needed to end the drought ranged from 10
centimetres in south-central Ohio to 28 centimetres in the northeast
hills.

                               The New York Times

              October 11, 1980, Saturday, Late City Final Edition

CUT IN GRAIN FORECASTS

BYLINE: By SETH S. KING, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section 2; Page 29, Column 6; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 579 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10


The Agriculture Department has revised its forecast for American and Soviet
grain crops, predicting that yields in both countries would fall below previous
estimates.

The agency estimated that this year's wheat and coarse grain crops in the Soviet
Union would total 205 million metric tons, 5 million less than it estimated last
month. But today's prediction was still higher than the estimate of 190 million
tons made by a Soviet source in Moscow earlier this week.

The Soviet grain estimate was about 26 million tons higher than the crop
harvested in 1979, which was a poor year. But it was 30 million tons less than
planned.

For the United States, the Department's Crop Reporting Board forecast corn
production at 6.47 billion bushels, or 164 million metric tons, 1 percent below
the September forecast and 17 percent lower than the record crop of 7.76 billion
bushels harvested last fall.

Soybean production was expected to total 1.76 billion bushels, or 47.8 million
metric tons, down 4 percent from last month's estimate and more than 23 percent
below last year's record crop, which totaled 2.27 billion bushels.

May Affect Soviet Meat Output

If today's estimate for the Soviet Union is close, the Russians may have even
more difficulty in maintaining meat production than they have been experiencing
and may have to reduce their livestock herds.

Such a Soviet crop shortfall could heighten the pressure on President Carter to
end the curtailment of grain sales to the Russians and allow American farmers to
enjoy another sharp rise in exports.

The decline in American corn and soybean crops was expected to cause a small
increase in grain prices. But Agriculture Department officials said they did not
believe it would affect meat supplies or cause a further increase in food
prices, which are expected to rise at least 10 percent in 1981.

This year's American wheat crop, unlike the corn and soybean crops, was not
affected by the summer's widespread drought. The wheat crop, already harvested,
was now expected to total 2.36 billion bushels, or 64.3 million metric tons of
2,204 pounds each, a slightly higher figure than the 2.35 million bushels
forecast in the September crop production report.

Forecast Draws Questions

During a briefing that followed release of the forecasts on the American and
Soviet crops, J. Dawson Ahalt, chairman of the department's World Food and
Agricutural Outlook Board, was asked why the department's Soviet estimate was
higher than the 190-million-ton figure attributed to the Soviet source and
higher than the 200-million-ton estimate offered by unidentified White House
souces earlier this week.

''We are aware of these other estimates,'' Mr. Ahalt replied. ''But we looked
carefully at all the available information we had and still concluded the Soviet
crops would be about 205 million tons when their harvest is completed.''

American crop forecasters receive frequent reports on Soviet crop conditions
from satellite observations. They also receive reports from American
agricultural attaches in Moscow.

The predicted shortfall in the Russian crop was expected to increase the cost of
Soviet grain imports and make it more difficult for the Russians to buy
additional supplies of corn and wheat from foreign exporters, department sources
said.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1980 The New York Times Company


                             563 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                                The Toronto Star

                            July 2, 1993, Friday, AM

Sugar war could cost Canadian firms $90 million in vanished sales to U.S.

BYLINE: CP

SECTION: BUSINESS TODAY; Pg. C3

LENGTH: 224 words

DATELINE: WINNIPEG


   WINNIPEG (CP) - American trade retaliation against sugar imports would cost
the Canadian sugar industry $90 million in sales annually, an industry official
says.

United States Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy has asked President Bill Clinton
to sign an emergency measure that would effectively end Canadian exports of
refined beet sugar as well as two sugar-containing products, Sandra Marsden,
president of the Canadian Sugar Institute in Toronto, said this week.

"We're just waiting," she said. "There's nothing to indicate it won't happen.
The U.S. industry is facing a serious overproduction problem."

Trade Minister Tom Hockin said such a move would be wrong.

Hockin noted the U.S. exports more sugar and sugar products to Canada than it
imports but also indicated he would be hesitant to employ sanctions against
American sugar exports.

The American government estimated the U.S. had a $230 million trade surplus in
sugar products in 1991, said Marsden.

"Clearly there's no justification for targeting Canada," she said.

The targeted products are refined sugar made from beets grown in Manitoba and
Alberta as well two products high in sugar, powdered drink mixes and gelatin,
she said.

Altogether, the products account for about 100,000 tonnes of sugar or about 10
per cent of Canadian production.

                             564 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                         Telegraph Herald (Dubuque, IA)

                           September 18, 2005 Sunday

Agribusiness Briefs

BYLINE: Telegraph Herald Staff

SECTION: Agriculture; Pg. b8

LENGTH: 355 words


Wisconsin extends comment period

The Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources has extended the comment period on
proposed changes in the state rule that governs manure management by
larger-scale livestock farms.

DNR officials said they are responding to concerns from some agricultural groups
that producers have ample opportunities to learn about and provide feedback
about the proposed rule changes.

Public comments will now be accepted through Oct. 14.

The changes apply primarily to larger-scale operations that have at least 1,000
animal units. That level equals about 700 milking cows, 2,500 hogs and 55,000
turkeys.

Class III milk price dips

The U.S. Department of Agriculture announced the Class III milk price at $13.60
per hundredweight, which is 75 cents lower than July and 44 cents less than
August of last year.

The 2005 Class III average is now $14.15 per hundredweight, down from $15.60 a
year ago, but $3.77 per hundredweight above 2003.

Safety day camp slated

The Jo Daviess County Farm Bureau will host a safety day camp from 9 to 11:30
a.m. on Saturday as a part of National Farm Safety and Health Week.

The camp is for children ages 6 to 12 and will be at the Jo-Carroll Energy
Building in Elizabeth, Ill. Topics to be discussed at the camp include fire,
animal, power tool, chemical and gravity wagon safety. There also will be an
electrical demonstration by Jo-Carroll Energy.

Campers must register with the Jo Daviess County Farm Bureau by Tuesday to
attend the camp. To register, call 815/858-2235.

National Farm Safety and Health Week begins today. The 2005 theme is "harvesting
safety and health."

Crop report: Fields dry

Southwest Wisconsin leads the state in harvest of corn silage and soils
throughout the state remain dry, the latest crop weather report from AG
Statistics Service shows.

More than 60 percent of farmers throughout the state say fields are short of
moisture.

Thirty-five percent of the corn for silage has been harvested in southwest
Wisconsin. One producer in Lafayette County reports his silage yields ran about
27 to 30 tons per acre.

                             565 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                              The Washington Post

                    August 02, 1997, Saturday, Final Edition

Burned Out By Drought; Long Dry Spell Takes Its Toll On County's Growers,
Grazers

Sewell Chan, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: PRINCE WILLIAM EXTRA; Pg. V03

LENGTH: 557 words


Corn leaves in Prince William County have begun to curl, soybeans are being
harvested early, and verdant pastures slowly are turning brown, leaving local
farmers worried about diminishing grain and feedstocks and wilting profits.

With just 1.14 inches of rain measured at National Airport, July was the
fourth-driest month on record, according to Tom Dougherty, a meteorologist at
the National Weather Service in Sterling. The last time the region had so little
rain was July 1966, when the airport recorded just .93 inches of precipitation.

"Corn and soybeans, especially the late-planted corn and the early-planted
soybeans, they've been affected terribly," said Ronald Farino, 64, who raises
beef cattle and the feed needed to sustain them in Nokesville. "The green grass
is just about all gone, the hot weather dried it up so much."

Farino already has begun, literally, to cut his losses -- baling his soybean
plants "because they're not going to make any beans" but still can be made into
fodder.

The dry spell, which meteorologists describe as a moderate drought, has
especially hurt Northern Virginia's crops, most of which are turned into feed
for dairy and beef cattle. In the week that ended Sunday, a quarter of
Virginia's soybean crops, 42 percent of its pasture lands and half of its corn
crops were in poor or very poor condition, according to the U.S. Department of
Agriculture's National Agricultural Statistics Service.

That comes as no surprise to the growers and grazers of western Prince William,
whose only option has been to pray for rain.

As Robert Caton, 71, looked out at the short pasture on his Brentsville farm, he
said the drought will virtually exhaust his hay supply from last winter. An
initial hay harvest already has been collected, but the total crop will be much
reduced from last year.

"As a rule, we usually have a second hay cut in July and August, but we won't
have one this year," said Caton, who raises 70 head of beef cattle.

And as the stocks saved from last winter run down, Caton's worries grow. "I
think I have plenty of hay to take care of my cows all winter, but as far as the
corn is concerned, I know it's cut in half from what it normally would be," he
said.

Although precipitation was low from April to June, below-normal temperatures
then kept evaporation down. But July's heat worsened the situation.

"This month was definitely worse than the others, because you had near
record-low precipitation and very hot temperatures," said David Miskus, a
meteorologist at the weather service's Climate Prediction Center in Camp
Springs, Md.

Sporadic thunderstorms have hit in the last two weeks, but they barely grazed
the county's eastern half and left the western farmlands unquenched.

The dry spell also has county residents clamoring for water. The Prince William
County Service Authority, which sells water to most of the county, in July
showed an 11 percent increase in water sales from the same period last year.

And Manassas had a 9 percent jump in July from water consumption last year, with
10 million gallons consumed daily during the hottest period, said Allen Todd,
the city's director of utilities.

And it might not improve. There is a 55 percent chance of lower-than-normal
precipitation in August, September and October, Miskus said.


LOAD-DATE: August 02, 1997

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Photo, tracy A. woodward, Farmer Ronald Farino, left, and Andy Clemen
walk through a field. "Corn and soybeans . . . they've been affected terribly,"
Farino says.  Clemen, left, and Farino inspect a corn plant on a Nokesville farm
belonging to Clemen's father. The "moderate drought" has hit county farmers
hard.

                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                             May 11, 1983 Wednesday

U.S. wheat output   expected to drop

BYLINE: DJ

LENGTH: 202 words

DATELINE: Washington DC


WASHINGTON  (DJ) - Winter wheat production was forecast at 1.89 billion
 bushels as of May 1, a 10 per cent decline from last year's record high
 production of 2.11 billion bushels, the Agriculture Department says.

The report, which is part of the department's periodic forecast of
 output, illustrates that even with large acreage reductions because of the
 Payment-In-Kind program, high yields will produce another big year.

The department also said corn growers intend to plant 58.8 million
 acres in 1983, down 28 per cent from 81.9 million acres planted in 1982.

Soybean plantings are forecast to be down 9 per cent in 1983 to 65.8
 million acres. Cotton planted area is expected to total 8.13 million
 acres, 28 per cent below the 1982 acreage.

Spring wheat growers expect to plant 11.6 million acres, down 30 per
 cent from last year. Prospective rice plantings are placed at 2.17 million
 acres, down 34 per cent from a year earlier.

The orange crop this season is forecast at 220 million boxes,
 fractionally less than the April 1 forecast and 24 per cent more than the
 1981-82 season.

The Florida frozen concentrated juice yield this season is predicted to
 be 1.47 gallons a box, up from last season's 1.28 gallons a box.

                         Cape Gazette (Lewes, Delaware)

  This content, including derivations, may not be stored or distributed in any
  manner, disseminated, published, broadcast, rewritten or reproduced without
                      express, written consent from STPNS

                                August 16, 2011

Markell signs Young Farmers Bill into law

BYLINE: Cape Gazette staff

LENGTH: 307  words


The outlook for young people interested in careers in farming got a bit brighter
in Delaware when Gov. Jack Markell signed into law a bill that creates the
Delaware Young Farmers Program. Markell signed the law at the Delaware State
Fair, which has been a showcase for Delaware agriculture for more than 90 years.

"Delaware is taking an important step to make sure our agriculture industry is
stronger for generations to come, planting the seed for future careers in
farming," Markell said.

"The young farmer program is unique and special to the state of Delaware - an
investment that will benefit all of Delaware's cit-izens," said Agriculture
Secretary Ed Kee.

The program, an investment provided for in the fiscal year 2012 budget, will
reduce the capital investment for young people looking to set up agribusinesses
and structure an affordable repayment program for them. The land a young firmer
purchases will also be permanently preserved as farmland through the Delaware
AgLands Program.

The current average age of a farmer in Delaware is 57.

"We're building on the best farmland preservation in the country and carving
aglands money for young people to get into farming," said Markell.

Kee pointed out that the Delaware agriculture industry is based on 2,500 farmers
and generates $1.2 billion in sales every year, which expands to $8 billion
worth of economic activity each year for Delaware. The state ranks ninth
nationwide in the percentage of land area devoted to cropland, with 35 percent
of Delaware's land.

"The governor challenged us to come up with legacy ideas, and this was one of
them," said Kee.

Markell was joined by many members of the Delaware General Assembly, who he
thanked for their cooperation and support of the bill.

"This program will hopefully stand the test of time and benefit farmers for
generations to come," he said.

                     The News-Gazette (Champaign, Illinois)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            January 15, 2008 Tuesday

Soybean, sorghum hay production all down, but corn up 26 percent over 2006

BYLINE: Tim Mitchell, The News-Gazette, Champaign-Urbana, Ill.

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 501 words


Jan. 15--The rise of ethanol use and production is being felt in fields across
Illinois, according to figures released over the weekend by the United States
Department of Agriculture.

But some local ag leaders said rising soybean prices and the high price of
nitrogen could mean a rebound for soybean production in 2008.

Apparently, more farmers are making the switch away from soybeans and other
crops to corn, since production of soybeans, sorghum and hay were all down in
Illinois from a year ago.

Brad Schwab, a USDA spokes-man, said corn production totaled 2.284 billion
bushels in Illinois in 2007, a 26 percent jump over a year ago and a record for
the state.

Meanwhile, soybean production dropped dramatically in 2007, by 27 percent to 350
million bushels.

Darrel Good, professor of agriculture and consumer economics at the University
of Illinois, attributes the rise of corn and the fall of soybeans to ethanol.

"I think much of the increased corn production may be traced back to ethanol,"
Good said. "We had some pretty high corn prices last spring, so we planted a lot
more corn here in Illinois and across the United States."

As more ethanol plants are built and as ethanol use rises, Good said, corn used
in the production of ethanol will see accompanying price increases.

Illinois farmers also got good yields this year, according to Schwab. Illinois
farmers produced 175 bushels of corn per acre in 2007, the second-highest yield
ever behind 2006.

"Illinois had some awfully good yields this year, and that added" to the totals,
Good said.

Pesotum farmer Chris Hausman agreed there was more emphasis on corn in 2007.

"That's not necessarily only due to ethanol, but also on the economics of corn
versus soybeans," said Hausman, who serves on the Illinois Farm Bureau board of
directors. "It is more profitable to grow corn rather than soybeans here in East
Central Illinois."

According to Hausman, area farmers traditionally equally divided their land
between corn and soybeans.

"That 50-50 rotation between corn and soybeans is now two-thirds corn and
one-third soybeans," he said. "We're seeing an increased market for corn, while
the bean market is trying to convince farmers to grow one over the other. Right
now more people are in the corn camp."

Champaign County Farm Bureau manager Brad Uken attributes part of corn's rise to
higher worldwide demand for the crop.

"Some of the developing countries are economically getting stronger and thus
have a larger demand for meat," Uken said. "In order to raise more meat, you
need more grain. Thus, more corn is needed overall."

To see more of The News-Gazette, or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.news-gazette.com. Copyright (c) 2008, The News-Gazette,
Champaign-Urbana, Ill. Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services.

847-635-6550, send a fax to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group
Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave., Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                               Right Vision News

                             April 3, 2010 Saturday

Bangladesh: Call for formulate women-friendly agri policy

LENGTH: 545  words

DATELINE: DHAKA


DHAKA, April 03 -- Speakers at a national seminar yesterday urged the government
for formulating a women-friendly agriculture policy in order to ensure
recognition of their contribution to agriculture.

According to our correspondent, they made the call at the seminar on "Women in
Farming:

Position, Perspectives and Experience". Bangladesh Women Scientists Association
organised the seminar at Dhaka University Senate Bhaban in the city.

Vice Chancellor of Dhaka University Professor Dr AAMS Arefin Siddique addressed
the seminar as the chief guest and Chairman of BCSIR Professor Dr SM Imamul
Haque as the special guest.

Professor of Department of Physics of Jahangir Nagar University Professor Dr
Afrozee Yunus spoke as the guest of honor. President of Bangladesh Women
Scientists Association Professor Dr Shahida Rafiq chaired the seminar.

Dr Najira Koreshi delivered the welcome address while Suraiya Khanam gave the
vote of thanks.

The speakers said a woman, either directly or indirectly, gives labour in every
stage of farming. Although the contribution of women to innovation and growth of
agriculture is universal, women farm laborers are yet to be recognised as
farmers, they said.

Even women have no participation in decision-making when a measure is taken up
for extension and development of agriculture, they added.

Mentioning that women have close involvement in marginal farming, they called
for giving recognition to women as farmers and bringing them under farm loan
coverage.

Prof Arefin said development of agriculture is a must for ensuring
socio-economic development of poor people of the country. Recognition to women
should be given as they are making lots of contributions to the growth of
agriculture sector for ages, he said.

Emphasising utilisation of high technology in agriculture, he said about 80 per
cent of the people are engaged in farming, still the country could not attain
self-sufficiency in food.

In the United States, even only two per cent people are involved in farming, but
they can export food items after meeting their domestic demand as they use high
technology, he added.

He urged all concerned to come forward to change the mindset of the people
regarding women.

"The present government is a women-friendly government," he said, adding that
the government has taken initiatives to include women at different fields of
national development process.

The people of the country should also come forward for making the government
efforts successful, he added.

Ten eminent female scientists were given awards for their contribution to their
respective fields.

The awardees are Dr Malika Al Raji (posthumously - founder president of
Bangladesh Women Scientist Association), Begum Rijia Haque (posthumously - home
agriculture management), Professor Mahfuza Khanam (first DUCSU female VP),
Professor Dr Kamrunnesa Begum (physicist), architect Lailun Nahar (urban
planner), Professor ZN Tahmida Begum (first PSC female chairman), Dr Roushan
Jahan Mannan (chemist), Professor Shameem Ara Ahmed (biologist), Momena Begum
(animal feed inventor) and Dr Dilara siddique (physicist). Published by HT
Syndication with permission from Right Vision News. For more information on news
feed please contact Sarabjit Jagirdar at htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

For any query with respect to this article or any other content requirement,
please contact Editor at htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

                             570 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                           Edmonton Journal (Alberta)

                             July 27, 2013 Saturday
                                 Early Edition

Beef farmers fight U.S. label policy; Canada's cattlemen join lawsuit to delay
country-of origin plan

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. D2

LENGTH: 343 words

DATELINE: CALGARY


An organization that represents Canadian beef farmers says it is seeking an
injunction while a court in the U.S. hears its case against country-of-origin
meat labelling.

The Canadian Cattlemen's Association says it is part of a coalition that has
asked the U.S. District Court in Washington to delay the policy to be
implemented in November.

It would require labels on meat products sold in the United States to contain
detailed information about where the products come from.

The lawsuit claims that the rule would violate the U.S.

Constitution and the U.S. Agriculture Marketing Act, and is arbitrary and
capricious.

The coalition that has filed the injunction argues that the policy would cause
"irreparable harm" to the U.S. meat and livestock industry and is not in the
public interest.

The labelling system increases costs and makes it more difficult for U.S.
companies to buy Canadian products.

Plaintiffs in the lawsuit also include the American Association of Meat
Processors, American Meat Institute, Canadian Pork Council, National Cattlemen's
Beef Association, National Pork Producers Council, North American Meat
Association and Southwest Meat Association. A World Trade Organization ruling on
meat labelling found the U.S. system discriminates against foreign livestock.

The U.S. announced earlier this year it wants even more detail on the origins of
beef, pork and chicken sold in grocery stores. Labels would include such
information as "born, raised and slaughtered in the United States" for American
meat. Meat from other countries could carry labels such as "born in Canada,
raised and slaughtered in the United States."

Last month, Ottawa released a list of potential U.S. agricultural products to
which Canada could apply retaliatory tariffs. They include cattle, pigs, beef,
pork, some fruits and vegetables and chocolate.

Agriculture Minister Gerry Ritz said while Canadians could see higher prices as
a result, the U.S. will lose jobs and significant revenue from the tariffs that
may result from U.S. country-of-origin labelling requirements.

                             571 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                                  Farming Life

                           January 6, 2016 Wednesday

Consumer power driving change in US agriculture

LENGTH: 342  words


Farmers markets in the United States are reflecting the strong growth in
consumer demand for naturally produced foods.

These include grass fed beef and dairy products made with milk from non-BST
treated cows. A case in point is the Fiscalini Cheese Company,  based in Modesto
California.

"The business makes a selection of high quality artisan cheeses from a
proportion of the milk produced by its herd of Holstein and Jersey cows,"
explained Fiscalini's  Mike Green.

"These are then sold at farmers' markets throughout the South West United States
.

"There is a growing demand for high quality cheese made from BST-free milk.
This, in turn, reflects the wish of consumers to have their food produced in the
most natural way possible.

"As a company we are striving to deliver an eating sensation which builds on our
commitment to natural production methods. In fact, Fiscalini cheddar performed
tremendously well in a recent international cheese competition, held in London."

Green made these comments while attending a New Year farmers' market held in
Phoenix Arizona. Significantly, all of the beef suppliers there confirmed a
commitment to rearing cattle, using pasture as the main source of feed. Hormonal
implants are not used at any stage of the production process.

Meanwhile, there is increasing evidence that US consumers are becoming more
interested in the long term sustainability of their farming industry as a whole.

Michael Olson, a member of the management team at the Desert Botanical Garden in
Phoenix, told Farming Life that water conservation is the biggest challenge
facing agriculture in the South West United States.

"There is a growing trade-off between the needs of the growing human population
in the south west and the fact that irrigation is the only way of guaranteeing
satisfactory crop yields in this part of the world," he said.

"Members of the public are also telling farmers that they must act to conserve
as much of the natural landscape and desert heritage as possible.

"It's all about working with nature, rather than against it."

                     The Telegraph-Journal (New Brunswick)

                             July 27, 2013 Saturday

Country-of-origin meat labelling opponents file injunction

SECTION: C; Pg. C3

LENGTH: 340 words


CALGARY - An organization that represents Canadian beef farmers says it is
seeking an injunction while a court in the U.S. hears its case against
country-of-origin meat labelling.

The Canadian Cattlemen's Association says it is part of a coalition that has
asked the U.S. District Court in Washington to delay the policy to be
implemented in November.

It would require labels on meat products sold in the United States to contain
detailed information about where the products come from.

The lawsuit claims that the rule would violate the U.S. constitution and the
U.S. Agriculture Marketing Act and is arbitrary and capricious.

The coalition that has filed the injunction argues that the policy would cause
"irreparable harm" to the U.S. meat and livestock industry and is not in the
public interest.

The labelling system increases costs and makes it more difficult for U.S.
companies to buy Canadian products.

Plaintiffs in the lawsuit also include the American Association of Meat
Processors, American Meat Institute, Canadian Pork Council, National Cattlemen's
Beef Association, National Pork Producers Council, North American Meat
Association and Southwest Meat Association.

A World Trade Organization ruling on meat labelling found the American system
discriminates against foreign livestock.

The U.S. announced earlier this year it wants to require even more detail on the
origins of beef, pork and chicken sold in grocery stores.

Labels would include such information as "born, raised and slaughtered in the
United States" for American meat.

Cuts of meat from other countries could carry labels such as "born in Canada,
raised and slaughtered in the United States."

Last month, the Canadian government released a list of potential U.S.
agricultural products to which Canada could apply retaliatory tariffs.

They include cattle, pigs, beef, pork, some fruits and vegetables and chocolate.

Agriculture Minister Gerry Ritz said that while Canadians could see higher
prices as a result, the U.S. will lose jobs and significant revenue from the
tariffs.

                           Winthrop News (Minnesota)

                               September 15, 2010

Farmers on track for record harvest

BYLINE: Winthrop News staff

LENGTH: 201  words


U.S. farmers are on pace to produce the largest corn and soybean crops in
history, according to the Crop Production report released today by the U.S.
Department of Agriculture's National Agricultural Statistics Service (NASS).

Corn production is forecast at 13.4 billion bushels and soybean production at
3.43 billion bushels, both up 2 percent from the previous records set in 2009.
Based on conditions as of August 1, corn yields are expected to average a
record-high 165 bushels per acre, up 0.3 bushel from last year's previous
record. Soybean yields are expected to equal last year's record of 44 bushels
per acre.

Cotton production is expected to jump 52 percent from last year, to 18.5 million
480-pound bales. Average yield is forecast at 837 pounds per harvested acre, up
60 pounds from last year.

The August Crop Production report contains USDA's first survey-based estimates
of yield and production for corn, soybeans and other spring-planted row crops.
Between July 25 and August 6, NASS surveyed approximately 27, 000 producers and
also took objective field measurements in the major crop-producing states. Crop
Production is published monthly and is available online at
http://www.nass.usda.gov.

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

                    August 7, 1993, Saturday, WEEKLY EDITION

U.S. subsidies stay on wheat sold to Mexico

BYLINE: Peter Morton with files from Canadian Press

SECTION: SECTION 1, NEWS; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 325 words

DATELINE: Ottawa, Ont.


The U.S. government will continue to use its export enhancement program to sell
wheat to Mexico despite Canadian protests, U.S. Agriculture Secretary Michael
Espy said Friday.

Canada has launched a complaint under the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement,
claiming U.S. subsidies to Mexico violate a clause in the accord that requires
both countries to take the other's interests into account in third markets.

''Our interest is to make sure we can maintain a presence in markets like
Mexico, where we have seen a reduction in our presence,'' Espy said after talks
with Canadian Agriculture Minister Charlie Mayer.

Mayer said Ottawa has not yet decided whether to refer the matter to a disputes
settlement panel under the free trade agreement.

The export enhancement program, which offers subsidies of $295 a tonne of wheat,
was designed to counter European subsidies on grain sold to other countries but
was not to include the markets supplied by Canada and other grain-growing
nations.

Canadian grain producers last year sold about 500,000 tonnes of wheat to Mexico,
representing 2% of total Canadian grain exports. The U.S. announced it plans to
expand its program to 32 million tonnes this year, including 1.4 million to
Mexico.

On another front, the two ministers agreed to try to resolve the looming dispute
over Canadian sugar exports by narrowing the fight to food products containing
sugar, such as flavored drinks and gelatins.

The two countries had threatened to slap duties on each other's imports.
Canadian sugar beets, from which sugar is refined, get some government subsidies
and can undercut U.S. domestic prices.

Meantime, Prairie oilseed farmers and central Canadian corn and soybean growers
are expecting higher prices because of widespread flooding that has destroyed
crops in parts of the U.S.

In general on the Prairies, plenty of rain this year means yields are expected
to be above average.

                             575 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                 July 4, 1982, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

AND NOW, A GLUT YOU CAN EAT

BYLINE: By SETH S. KING

SECTION: Section 4; Page 4, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 930 words

DATELINE: ANTHONY, Kans.


Among many farmers in the wheat and corn belt who were around in the 1960's - a
time of abundant harvests and plunging incomes - there has in recent weeks been
a clear feeling that history is repeating itself.

Another record wheat crop is pouring into already bulging elevators, and another
bumper corn crop is in prospect. Prices for farmers' grain are slipping
downward. Surpluses are piling up to levels that will hold prices down for
another year at least, experts say, unless summer storms batter the corn and
soybean crops that are not due to be harvested for another two months or so.

All this has added considerably to the worries of the Agriculture Department,
which has been casting about -unsuccessfully so far - for steps it could take to
help the farmers.

''There's no question that we're really concerned,'' said J. Dawson Ahalt,
Deputy Assistant Secretary for Economics. ''The situation is even worse now
because for the past three years world demand for our grain has not been
expanding as fast as our production.''

Even before the winter wheat harvest got under way in early June, there were 1.1
billion bushels left over from 1981, nearly half a full year's supply, including
exports. Corn from last year's crop still in storage totaled a record high 3.85
billion bushels, 39 percent more than last year. Soybeans still in the elevators
were 3 percent less than in June, 1981.

But the Agriculture Department's latest estimate of grain acreage, released
Wednesday, indicated a record area had been planted in soybeans. Corn acreage to
be harvested for grain was down only 1 percent and for all wheat, including the
winter variety now coming in, the acreage was down only 2 percent. New varieties
of wheat are yielding well above past averages and the analysts expect that corn
and soybean farmers, weather permitting, will put on extra fertilizer and bring
in higher per acre yields.

So the Agriculture Department's offer of price support loans and subsidies in
return for reduced plantings was having little or no effect.

To be sure, there are some differences between today and the late 1960's. There
is now a burgeoning farmer-held grain reserve from which wheat and corn growers
who are eligible for loans can get premiums for holding their grain. But now
they are not being paid, as they were in the 1960's, to leave their land idle.

The United States is exporting twice as much grain as it did in the late 1960's.
But in addition to the slowdown in world demand for American grain, there is
more competition this year from Canada, Australia, Argentina and the European
Common Market, all of which have abundant supplies of wheat they can sell, most
of it at lower prices than the United States can offer.

Western analysts are predicting the poorest Russian grain crop since 1975. But
unless a new grain trade agreement that would include minimum purchases of wheat
is signed soon, the Soviets may not buy any more wheat from the United States
this year.

Even though barely 40 percent of wheat and feed grain farmers have reduced their
planting by 15 or 10 percent and are thus eligible for crop loans and subsidies,
the levels to which Congress has raised these are now so far above free market
prices that farm commodity aid was expected to account for between $10 billion
and $11.5 billion in President Reagan's next budget.

But most of all it was the persistent buildup of surpluses and the problem of
what to do with all that grain that was evoking memories of the late 60's.

Louis Drouhard, a farmer who has lived here in Harper County for all of his 76
years, remembers all too well the 1960's, when wheat supplies were so great that
the farmers' price rarely varied above the price support loans set by the
government and most of it was taken over by the Commodity Credit Corporation as
payment for those loans.

Mr. Drouhard said he and his two sons now had the best wheat yields he had ever
seen. ''But there's so much of it already backing up that we think we'll be
lucky to get

$3 a bushel for it by the time the harvest is ended,'' he said. Mr. Drouhard
said he could find nothing in today's farm outlook that was encouraging for
grain growers, though livestock farmers were beginning to make a little profit
after two years of losses.

Even if the rest of the economy picked up this fall, he said, grain supplies
were already so large that there was little chance farmers' crops would bring
them any more money in the next year.  Which would mean, he said, that the
merchants in the small towns of the Middle West, who depend on what they sell to
farmers, were also in for another bleak year.

But there was little indication, in talks with farmers, elevator operators and
merchants in Harper County, that the Administration was being blamed. ''All we
want from the government is a better price for our wheat and lower interest
rates on what we have to buy,'' Mr.  Drouhard said. ''We could take care of
ourselves with that.''

But concern was growing among all grain farmers over the lack of progress toward
a new Soviet grain purchasing agreement. Unless President Reagan imposes another
embargo, the Russians would still be able to buy all the American wheat and corn
they wanted. But they were worried that without that agreement, the Russians may
be looking elsewhere for their wheat.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Illustrations: table of the producers in billions of bushels

                             576 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

               August 8, 1981, Saturday, Late City Final Edition

Commodities;
Corn and Soybeans Off; Wheat and Oats Mixed

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

SECTION: Section 2; Page 41, Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 384 words


Corn and soybean futures prices turned lower and wheat and oats closed mixed
yesterday.  Analysts said early support seemed to stem from a short-term
tightness in grain supplies at the Gulf of Mexico as well as at interior
locations. They said this forced exporters and other commercial interests to bid
higher for corn and soybeans in order to meet their commitments.

Selling at country elevators picked up as farmers sought to take advantage of
the higher prices and this prompted some hedge selling by commercial interests
in the futures market, traders said.

There was some evening of contract positions ahead of the weekend.

Foreign Demand Shows Rise

A United States Agriculture Department report showing increased foreign demand
for wheat also was said to influence some early buying in that trading pit.

Underlying negative factors in the markets were the strong dollar overseas, and
forecasts for beneficial rains this weekend in the Mississippi Delta growing
areas.

On the Chicago Board of Trade, wheat for delivery in September settled at $4.07
a bushel; corn at $3.26 1/2 a bushel; oats at $1.92 1/4 a bushel, and soybeans
at $7.13 bushel.

Precious metals fell, with silver losing as much as 15.1 cents.  The
August-delivery contract was $8.535 a troy ounce and August gold was $396.50 a
troy ounce on the Commodity Exchange Inc. in New York.

Cattle Prices Mixed

On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, cattle prices were mixed amid expectations
for weaker carcass beef prices next week. Live cattle were 0.12 cent lower to
0.08 cent higher with the contract for delivery in August at 51.65 cents a
pound.

Analysts said demand for pork during the week gave some support to the hog and
pork belly futures markets. August-delivery bellies rose to 51.20 cents a pound
and hogs settled at 51.65 cents a pound.

Coffee for September delivery settled at 114.56 cents a pound.  Cocoa futures
were lifted by $50 to $70 as the International Cocoa Organization reported
progress on some operational questions surrounding implementation of the new
international price support agreement. The September contract settled at $2,081
a metric ton.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                            The Times of India (TOI)

                           February 15, 2014 Saturday

Global farm experts to converge on Mohali

SECTION: CHANDIGARH

LENGTH: 307 words


CHANDIGARH: Agriculture experts, plant breeders and farmers from across the
globe will converge on Baba Banda Singh Bahadur War Memorial, Chappar Chirri,
Mohali, for the Progressive Punjab Agriculture Summit that will be held from
February 16 to 19.

Prominent among the participants will be Saskatchewan (Canada) minister of
agriculture Lyle Stewart, who will be accompanied by a powerful delegation of 20
businessmen from the country.

It is expected that hundreds of farmers from Punjab, besides West Bengal,
Chhattisgarh, Rajasthan, Madhya Pradesh, Haryana, Assam, Uttar Pradesh, Himachal
Pradesh, J&K will participate in this mega agri-summit.

"Nearly 92 million out of 138 million land holders in the country have less than
one acre and their condition is pitiable due to the prevailing agrarian crisis.
They are neither farmers nor labourers," said an official of Punjab agriculture
department.

Eminent agriculture experts and delegates from Canada, Pakistan, the UK,
Denmark, the Netherlands, Australia, and the United States will shed light on
how to increase production so that income of such farmers goes up.

The Punjab government has invited all chief ministers, agriculture ministers and
eminent political leaders of national repute cutting across political lines to
participate in it.

As many as 11 technical sessions on various themes -- including challenges to
Punjab agriculture, bio-technology in agriculture, potato seed production,
rearing of small ruminants, commercial dairy farming, agriculture marketing and
risk management, bee-keeping, investment in food and agri processing, besides
panel discussion on farmers' economy with focus on role of Punjab in Indian
agriculture economy, handling and marketing of food grains, farmers indebtedness
and future of farming, among others -- will be held.

                        The Atlanta Journal-Constitution

                       June 15, 2004 Tuesday Home Edition

GLOBAL GEORGIA: Support, stability crucial to farmers

BYLINE: CHUCK COLEY

SOURCE: For the Journal-Constitution

SECTION: Editorial; Pg. 11A; EQUAL TIME

LENGTH: 670 words


I am concerned by the recent rash of negative publicity given to U.S.
agriculture in general and U.S. cotton producers in particular. Invariably,
these criticisms are based on a distorted view of the role of farm programs and
ignore farming's challenges.

It appears that many have lost sight of agriculture's importance to the U.S.
economy. Annually, this country's food and fiber industries employ 25 million
people, produce output valued at $3.5 trillion, and account for 15 percent of
the U.S. gross domestic product.

In rural America, agriculture's importance to local economies is even greater.

In 2002, the United States enacted a new farm bill, which has come under
constant criticism and has even been portrayed as a lavish handout to corporate
farms.

Nothing could be further from the truth. This law provides an important safety
net for production agriculture and does so in a fiscally responsible manner.
Spending under the law is much less than originally projected. The programs in
that legislation help protect farmers from the vagaries of weather and commodity
markets while allowing them to respond to market signals and not distort overall
production and prices.

Why is this stability and safety net so important to farming? America's farmers
face greater risks than the vast majority of businessmen, but without the
corresponding upside reward potential. There are so many factors they cannot
control: a strong dollar, unanticipated oversupply in high production years,
depressed prices and destructive natural events that can wipe out an entire
crop. An effective farm program is essential for providing stability in
production, financing and marketing, and in a broader sense, underpins the
overall rural economy. And a strong rural economy benefits Atlanta and all of
Georgia.

Another overlooked fact is the scope of programs covered by farm legislation.
Overall outlays are quoted without mentioning that the spending also covers
numerous conservation and nutrition programs benefiting all Americans. Also
going without mention are the important insurance programs and the authorization
for national and international food donation programs.

Recent attempts to portray U.S. farm programs as the root of the problems in
world commodity markets are simply wrong --- but that does not keep them from
being repeated as gospel over the Internet and by the news media.

Georgia farmers compete in a global economy, where many of our competitors are
subsidized or their markets are protected from competition. The world
agricultural system is rampant with governmental policies that distort markets
and prices. Few of those governments have policies that are as transparent as
the United States'. The cotton market faces additional pressures caused by heavy
subsidization of synthetic fibers, such as polyester, in many Asian countries.

Efforts are under way to address agricultural programs in the World Trade
Organization. The United States has repeatedly proposed significant agricultural
reforms, but its proposals have been rebuffed by countries that wish to maintain
high levels of protectionism. Our competitors hope that the rash of misguided
criticisms will force the United States to capitulate and not obtain an
equitable international agreement. U.S. agriculture is unanimous in its
determination that a new WTO agreement must address all aspects of subsidies and
market protectionism across all countries and commodities.

It is vital that the United States maintain a stable, predictable and equitable
farm policy. Such policy supports rural America and permits U.S. consumers
continued access to the safest, most affordable and most secure supply of food
and fiber in the world. Discarding effective farm programs would have
detrimental results. The United States cannot afford to unilaterally disarm. I
would hate to see our nation become as dependent on foreign-produced food and
fiber as we are on energy.

Chuck Coley is a cotton farmer in Vienna, Ga.

LOAD-DATE: June 16, 2004

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SERIES: GLOBAL GEORGIA

GRAPHIC: Photo: Chuck Coley
ME: Op-ed column in the third of a five-part special editorial series on the
Peach State in the world economy.

TYPE: Series

                Copyright 2004 The Atlanta Journal-Constitution


                             579 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                             Windsor Star (Ontario)

                           December 30, 2006 Saturday
                                 Final Edition

Level the playing field

BYLINE: Leo Guilbeault, Special to The Windsor Star

SECTION: EDITORIAL/OPINION; Guest column; Pg. A8

LENGTH: 725  words


The Christmas holiday is always a good time to rest and reflect, especially for
farmers who are still wrapping up an unusually long harvest season.

For most people, a challenging year usually ends on a hopeful note, with a
commitment to persevere and take control of the things that can affect their
futures. Unfortunately for farmers, there is little they can control to turn a
bad year into a good one.

Ontario's 25,000 grain and oilseed farmers have been fighting for survival over
the past five years. It's not because of the weather or the environment. It's
not because there isn't enough farm land to grow the beans, corn, wheat, barley
and other commodities Ontarians enjoy every day. In fact, quality and yield have
never been better.

The problem is the rest of the world. Agriculture is the last sector in which
the industrialized world wantonly subsidizes for political gain at home,
especially in the United States. This results in artificially low world prices,
as anyone with a basic grasp of economics can tell you.

That's OK for farmers in those countries -- government support allows them to
earn a living in spite of the market. Not so here in Ontario. Farmers here don't
have the same levels of support, and they can't go to Washington, Brussels or
Paris and tell politicians in those countries to let the real market work the
way it should.

When the economists and bureaucrats look up from their charts, then they will
see the real story: In Ontario, an entire generation of families is pulling out
of the farming business because they can't afford to carry on producing on land
where, in some cases, it costs twice as much to grow the crop than the farmer
will ever receive from a severely skewed world market.

The Canadian Senate's agriculture committee recently released a report,
Understanding Freefall, that stated low farm incomes caused by the subsidy
madness was turning farmers into poverty-stricken second-class citizens.

'SERIOUS PROBLEMS'

"Persistent low farm incomes have created some serious problems for farmers in
many parts of the agricultural sector.... Hardship on the farm is leading to a
situation where farming is seen as a life with few prospects (and) where
depression, crisis and/or debt seriously impact many farm families," the report
said.

In Ontario, about 1,250 growers are dropping out of the farming business every
year, and more than 6,000 grain and oilseed farming households -- the entire
family -- are living on income under $25,000, according to Statistics Canada
data.

Agriculture analysts say it takes a minimum income of $100,000 a year to make
the smallest farm economically viable, but 52 per cent of Ontario farms report
less than that in income. A further 21 per cent of farms have incomes just
slightly above that critical threshold, according to the Institute of Agrifood
Policy Innovation.

The Canadian and Ontario governments have acknowledged this income crisis, but
continue to offer only ad-hoc aid, too little and too late, through the widely
reviled Canadian Agricultural Income Stabilization program.

Besides, farmers don't want handouts. They want a market that works. The grains
and oilseeds sector, which produces nearly $4 billion in Ontario crops annually,
has asked the two levels of government to move away from handouts and toward a
stable and sustainable insurance-based Risk Management Program to replace the
CAIS debacle.

The federal and provincial governments would administer the program, but farmers
would pay into it through premiums. This system would be fair, and would not
result in more spending by government, instead replacing the hodgepodge of aid
programs that no one believes to be effective.

We fear that 2007 is going to be a watershed year for the future of the family
farm if the governments turn its back on the Risk Management Program. We fear
that more farmers will leave the business, and those that remain will go deeper
into debt, into poverty and into despair. We fear the end of the family farm as
we know it.

One thing is for sure: The cycle of the farm income crisis is quickening and
deepening.

Ontario farmers, and Ontarians in general, don't want handouts or subsidies.
They want the stability offered by protection from worldwide farm subsidies.

Leo Guilbeault is an Essex County farmer and chairman of the Ontario Grains and
Oilseeds Safety Net Committee.

LOAD-DATE: December 30, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC:
Photo: Leo Guilbeault

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Business; Column

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                   The Record-Eagle (Traverse City, Michigan)

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                            January 13, 2017 Friday

Agriculture in Brief: 01/14/2017

BYLINE: The Record-Eagle, Traverse City, Mich.

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 545 words


Jan. 13--Michigan crop yields down in 2016

TRAVERSE CITY -- Most Michigan crop yields, except hay and soybeans, were down
in 2016, according to the United States Department of Agriculture National
Agricultural Statistics Service Great Lake Region.

Heavy precipitation and cool temperatures in April and May delayed the start of
the growing season, the office said in a release. Good conditions the rest of
the year, though, brought most crops in on schedule.

The state's average corn yield dropped 5 bushels per acre from 2015, to 157
bushels. High yields in the Thumb area offset below-average yields in the
state's south central area. Silage yield was 19.5 tons per acre, up half a ton
from 2015.

Soybeans set a new yield record in Michigan at 50.5 bushels per acre, 1.5
bushels higher than the record yield in 2015. Nearly the entire crop was ready
for harvest by mid-October.

Sugarbeet yield fell 0.9 tons per acre from 2015's level to 30.8 tons per acre
in 2016. But that figure was the second-highest on record for the state. Early
analysis shows a lower sugar content in this year's beets.

Dry bean production in Michigan totaled 4 million hundredweight, down 28 percent
from 2015. Quality was down somewhat, the NASS said, because of drought
conditions during the growing season.

All hay production totaled 2.36 million tons, 9 percent lower than 2015.

Farm Service Agency Cooperative Agreements announced

WASHINGTON -- The U.S. Department of Agriculture today announced cooperative
agreements with 46 partners to educate producers, including those who have been
historically underserved by USDA programs, about Farm Service Agency programs
that provide financial, disaster or technical support.

Nearly $2.5 million will go to nonprofits and universities to provide training
and access to FSA programs, financial resources and other information.

SBA Economic Injury Disaster Loans available

ATLANTA -- The U.S. Small Business Administration is offering federal Economic
Injury Disaster Loans for some operations affected by a trio of 2016 disasters.
Separate loan programs are available because of excessive rain from April 25
through Oct. 25, drought from May 25 through Oct. 25, and hail and high winds
from July 8 through Sept. 27.

The drought and hail-and-high-wind disaster loans are available to small
businesses, small agricultural cooperatives, small businesses engaged in
aquaculture and private nonprofit organizations in Antrim, Benzie, Grand
Traverse, Kalkaska, Leelanau. The excessive-rain program is not available in
those counties.

The programs are available to eligible farm-related and nonfarm-related entities
that suffered financial losses as a direct result of the drought. With the
exception of aquaculture enterprises, SBA cannot provide disaster loans to
agricultural producers, farmers, or ranchers. Nurseries are eligible to apply
for economic injury disaster loans for losses caused by drought conditions.

Applicants may apply online using the Electronic Loan Application via SBA's
secure website at https://disasterloan.sba.gov/ela. Loan applications must be
returned to SBA by Sept. 11, 2017.

___ (c)2017 The Record-Eagle (Traverse City, Mich.) Visit The Record-Eagle
(Traverse City, Mich.) at record-eagle.com Distributed by Tribune Content
Agency, LLC.

                           Daily Independent (Lagos)

                               December 28, 2015

Osun Signs U.S.$50 Million Agric Investment MOU With U.S. Firm

BYLINE: Gbenga Faturoti

LENGTH: 950 words

DATELINE: Osogbo


Osun State Government has pegged a $50million Agriculture Investment with the
United States of American (USA) Firm for the provision of modern agricultural
Technological Services as an alternative to the dwindling allocation from the
federation account.

The signing of the partnership with US JIL Firm Limited which took place in
Osogbo, Osun State Capital was aimed at given fresh impetus to its agricultural
sector revolution drive in the state.

The MoU covered the development and infrastructural upgrade of a breeding,
fattening and processing of beef cattle ranch and the establishment of
agricultural equipment leasing and hire centres to be managed by JIL farm
Limited.

Speaking shortly after the signing of the agreement, Ogeni Rauf Aregbesola, Osun
State Governor expressed appreciation to the investors for their interest in the
state. He assured them that no contribution will be spared in ensuring that the
venture comes out a success that will become a benchmark for the nation.

Noting that Osun is predominantly an agrarian state, he said the survival of the
state is tied to agriculture.

According to him, "We cannot survive without the success of farmers. What has
been sustaining the state is agriculture. If the farmers succeed, they will
fulfill their civic responsibility and we all will be better for it.

Ogbeni Aregbesola charged the people of the state to embrace agriculture for the
prosperity of the state to be guaranteed in the face of the grim economic
realities confronting the nation.

In his words: "We slumbered because of the oil windfall. All lands in Osun must
now be available for agriculture. Farming is the only way we can work and
progress without stress".

Jerry Cunningham, an experienced American animal husbandry expert and a member
of JIL Farms Limited investment team while speaking thanked the people of the
state for the hands of partnership extended to them.

"We've always wanted to do this and now we've got an opportunity. You're going
to be number one in the country in animal husbandry with the latest technology
we are deploying. We will not let you down. We've got all our equipment on
ground".

Speaking further, Cunningham expressed the keenness of the team to work with
indigenous farmers and transfer best practices in animal husbandry and modern
agricultural technology competences. "We've got talent in Nigeria, but we've got
to manage it. We will train your people to operate the equipment".

Dr Ayoade Akere, leader of the JIL Farms Limited team assured the governor and
people of the state that the investors are poised to impact the host community
greatly while doing business. He said not only that hundreds of people will be
employed; tourism in the host communities will also be improved greatly.

As an offspring of the Osun Beef Chain Development (O-Beef) and Osun Rural
Enterprise And Agricultural Programmes (O-REAP), the proposed ranch will birth
on 1,500 and 476 hectares of land in Ilawo town and Isatmosa farm in Iwo
respectively. It is proposed to have irrigation for all-year-round controlled
grazing for the breeding and development of 2,500 foundation stock breeding
cattle herd which will include the Tuli and Boran species, which are known to be
highly adapted to rainforest areas.

The project will also include the development of a 10,000-head capacity feedlot
centre, the construction of a feed mill for processed grains, a meat processing
plant, and a packing plant for vegetables. A youth training centre, a retreat
centre for trainings and a livestock and farming outgrower scheme will feature
to guarantee the state government's vision of encouraging the transfer of modern
agricultural technology and best practices to indigenous farmers in the state of
Osun. With support from foreign agricultural scientists from the University of
Nebraska, United States of America, JIL farms, would finance, operate and
maintain the agricultural land into ranches and farmland in such a manner as to
maintain the infrastructure and develop additional farmland for production of
livestock and crops.

The project is expected to serve as a catalyst for agricultural development for
the economic benefit of the State and the local communities involved. When
concluded, the project will deliver facilities such as a feedlot centre,
irrigation for dry season farming and processing centers for the products
produced. Others include the development of a plan for local farmers to have
farm areas prepared for them and a training program for the youth in conjunction
with the Government and the College of Agriculture, Osun State University, and
the University of Nebraska.

Also, as a way bridging the identified agricultural technology deficit among
farmers in the state, the partnership has included the establishment of modern
agricultural equipment leasing and hire centres. This will ensure that sound
technological supports are provided to boost the current steady progress being
recorded in the agriculture sector and catapult the cultivation of food crops in
the State.

Under a joint-venture partnership, State Government of Osun will transfer some
of their current equipment service centres to JIL Farms to develop agricultural
equipment leasing and hire centres in the State of Osun on a five-year basis
subject to further renewal. JIL Farms will provide finance and establish the
agricultural equipment leasing centre to provide modern farming equipment,
technologies, and techniques to local farmers on fair and workable terms taking
into the consideration the profitability of the scheme to the farmers. Such
equipment include: Tractors of various types and purposes, processing equipment,
storage facilities, irrigation facilities, among others

                         Telegraph Herald (Dubuque, IA)

                             April 1, 2004 Thursday

U.S. farmers planting record soybean crop; USDA projects 75.4 million acres of
beans will be planted in 2004

BYLINE: JOHN EVERLY

SECTION: Tristate; Pg. a3

LENGTH: 433 words


American farmers will plant a record number of acres of soybeans in 2004,
according to a government report released Wednesday.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture projected soybean acreage will rebound from a
three-year decline to 75.4 million acres, up 3 percent from last year.

The department forecasts farmers also will plant slightly more acres of corn
than last year, at 79 million acres. Wheat acreage, meanwhile, is expected to
fall 4 percent from 2003.

Iowa State University economist Robert Wisner said corn demand could outstrip
supply. Based on trend yields, 79 million acres would produce a 10.17 billion
bushel crop in 2004, but corn use is expected to be 10.2 to 10.3 billion, he
said.

"I think it bodes well for corn prices," agreed University of Illinois grain
marketing specialist Darrel Good. "We need fairly high yields to get a crop to
meet world demand."

Good expected next year's corn prices to average higher than the $$ @2.45 per
bushel the agriculture department projected for this year.

The increase in soybean acres follows a jump in prices. The agriculture
department said soybean prices averaged $$ @9.56 per bushel this month, $$ @3.97
above March 2003 and the highest prices in 15 years.

Iowa farmers will increase corn and soybean acres by 1 percent, the Agriculture
Department said. Illinois corn acreage is projected to be the same as 2004.

Locally, seed companies said growers were not making major changes in purchases.

"In the fall after the low bean yields some people were considering more corn,
but our numbers wouldn't indicate that," said Les Johnson, vice president with
Cornelius Seed Company in Andrew, Iowa.  He said most growers in the company's
eastern Iowa and northwest Illinois service areas are staying with their
corn-soybean crop rotations.

"Overall, you might see a slight rise in the corn acres," Johnson said.

Wisconsin, meanwhile, will lose both corn and soybean acres. The Agriculture
Department said farmers there intended to plant 3 percent fewer acres to corn
and 1 percent fewer acres to soybeans.

"We're similar to years past, but I'd say there's going to be some last-minute
maneuvering," said Brad Biddick, president of Trelay Seed Co. in Livingston,
Wis.

Good expected volatile soybean prices in the weeks ahead as the market grapples
with questions over the South American crop and growing season weather in the
United States.

That does not make farmers' planting decisions any easier. Biddick said there
has been a trend in recent years toward more last-minute decision making.

                         Telegraph Herald (Dubuque, IA)

                            February 22, 2004 Sunday

Cattle inventory in Iowa and Illinois follows national trend

BYLINE: JOHN EVERLY

SECTION: Business; Pg. b1

LENGTH: 217 words


The United States' cattle inventory on Jan. 1, at 94.9 million animals, was down
1 percent compared to a year earlier, according to the U.S. Department of
Agriculture.

The Illinois cattle herd declined by 4 percent, while Iowa cattle numbers were
down 3 percent. Wisconsin cattle numbers were unchanged.

The Agriculture Department reported the cattle herd might not grow anytime soon,
because the U.S. beef cow herd was the smallest since 1991.

At the same time, the 2003 calf crop was 1 percent below 2002.

Milk cow numbers, meanwhile, were the lowest since 1868. Low milk prices and
strong cull cow prices encouraged dairies to reduce the number of milk cows by 2
percent in 2003.

Price history

Retail fresh beef prices rose steadily during the past five years, hitting a
record high in 2003.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture forecasts retail beef prices will average in
the mid-$$ @3.50s per pound in 2004, down 5 percent from the 2003 record, but up
7 percent from 2002.

Retail equivalent value of U.S. beef industry in 2002 was $$ @65 billion. That
grew to approximately $$ @70 billion last year.
