                               The New York Times

               April 13, 1985, Saturday, Late City Final Edition

BLOCK CALLS REVISED BUDGET 'SENSITIVE' TO FARMERS



BYLINE:
By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

SECTION: Section 1; Page 29, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 546 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 12


Agriculture Secretary John R. Block today praised the farm budget compromise
between the White House and the Senate Republican leadership, but he said the
Reagan Administration was not backing away from its effort to restructure and
cut the Government's agriculture programs.

He agreed with the contention that the Administration's original budget
proposal, given the current financial crisis in farming, was too ''severe,'' and
he described the compromise as a ''soft and gentle'' alternative.

The compromise, which is part of the overall budget agreement reached last week,
would reduce projected spending on farm price support and credit programs by
$16.1 billon over three years, as opposed to the $28.8 billion in cuts
originally proposed by President Reagan. But the compromise would save far more
than the $2.2 billion, three- year reduction voted in the Senater Budget
Committee.

Making Farm Cuts 'Gentle'

On price support programs alone, the compromise allows for spending $8 billion
more over three years than the Administration's original plan, Mr. Block said.
The Administration's original proposal to cut farm credit programs has also been
moderated. The compromise, he added, will ''give us more time to do it and more
money to spend to make it more gentle.''

But Mr. Block said the compromise had not changed the Administration's goal of
making agriculture support programs more ''market oriented.''

Mr. Block described the new program at a news conference today as ''sensitive''
and as one showing ''some appreciation of the deteriorating conditions'' in
rural America.

The proposal is still expected to face strong opposition in Congress. Several
Senate Republicans who represent farm states and are up for re-election in 1986
have already said they oppose the farm program cuts. But the Reagan
Administration and the Senate Republican leadership have said they will oppose
major changes in the over all deficit reduction package.

Mr. Block said he has not decided whether he will send a new version of the farm
bill to Congress or just reshape it in negotiations on Capitol Hill.

More Time to Enact Cuts

Mr. Block did not provide details of the changes the compromise would make in
the Administration's original proposal, but he said the reductions in price
support programs would take place over a longer period of time.

In detailing his objectives, Mr. Block said he wanted to move quickly to reduce
the current commodity loan rates, which now effectively set minimum market
prices.

He said he would be willing, therefore, to extend the period in which payments
to wheat, feed grain, cotton and rice producers would be reduced. Under the
current price support program these farmers are paid the difference between the
market price and a ''target'' price set in law.

On farm credit programs, Mr. Block said the compromise would allow the
continuation of direct loans from the Farmers Home Administration to farmers who
cannot qualify for commercial loans. The original plan wanted to substitute loan
gurantees for most of the direct loans.

In addition, Mr. Block said, the crop insurance program and Rural
Electrification Administration programs would be eliminated over eight years
instead of five years.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1985 The New York Times Company

                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                             April 13, 1987 Monday

U.S. REPORT   Prices to farmers unchanged

BYLINE: GAM

LENGTH: 165 words


The prices U.S. farmers got for raw products in March were, on average,
unchanged from the revised February index and also from March, 1986, the
U.S. Agriculture Department says.

Higher prices for lettuce, cotton, cattle and tomatoes were offset by
lower prices for milk, hogs, strawberries, eggs and sweet corn, which held
the preliminary March reading at the revised February average.

Food grains, livestock feed grains and oilseeds showed little change
during the month. Corn and wheat were both down 1 cent a bushel. Soybean
prices were unchanged.

"The all-beef cattle price has continued to increase since January,"
the department said. "Calves were at the highest price level since
November, 1980. Hog prices dropped after showing small gains in February."

Crop prices over all were up 2 per cent from February, but down 9 per
cent from a year earlier, reflecting lower price supports and the huge
stockpiles of key commodities, including corn and wheat, that have been
built up in recent years.

                    Jacksonville Journal-Courier (Illinois)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           August 18, 2010 Wednesday

Oak Tree Organics' Chad Wallace recognized for farming efforts

BYLINE: Greg Olson, Jacksonville Journal-Courier, Ill.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 334 words


Aug. 18--An Ashland-area farmer was named Tuesday as one of the tops in the
state.

Chad Wallace of Oak Tree Organics was presented the R.J. Vollmer Sustainable
Agriculture Farmer Award at the Illinois State Fair.

The award was created in 1991 to recognize farmers who are doing an outstanding
job both on their farm and across the state in promoting sustainable farming
systems, said Mike Rahe of South Jacksonville, manager of the soil conservation
program for the Illinois Department of Agriculture.

"One of the reasons Chad was selected for the award was because of his efforts
in direct marketing, community-supported agriculture and the promotion of local
food systems," Rahe said.

Oak Tree Organics, located near Ashland, is a family owned and operated farm
offering a wide variety of fresh produce, fruits and eggs. The farm has been
providing naturally grown produce to the local farmer's market for six years and
offers weekly deliveries to the Springfield and Jacksonville areas.

Wallace, his wife, Dana, and their three children all work on the farm. Their
older daughter, Amanda, takes care of the books and son Kyle works on the
equipment. Five-year-old Erin has worked on the farm since she was in a
stroller.

Wallace grew up on what is now Oak Tree Organics Farm. When he was a child, the
farm was a conventional corn and soybean operation of several hundred acres but
after Wallace's father retired from farming, he took a different path,
converting 18 acres of the family farm to chemical-free fruit and vegetable
production.

                             587 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                           Edmonton Journal (Alberta)

                     August 13, 2002 Tuesday Final Edition

Drought slashes estimates for U.S. grain harvests

SOURCE: AP

SECTION: Business; Pg. F3

LENGTH: 356 words

DATELINE: Washington

Widespread drought has prompted the U.S. Agriculture Department to slash its
estimated forecasts for grain and soybean production. The conditions could drive
food prices up.

On Monday, federal officials lowered their estimate for corn production by seven
per cent from last year, predicting that nearly 8.89 billion bushels will be
harvested this year. That would be the lowest production since 1995.

The Agriculture Department alsoreduced its forecast for other crops. The agency
said soybean production is expected to be 2.63 billion bushels, down nine per
cent from 2001.

Corn and soybeans are used in hundreds of food products and as feed for hogs,
cattle, chickens and other livestock. Lack of rain has forced some cattle
producers in the U.S. to sell their herds because of lack of feed.

The forecast for all wheat production was reduced to 1.69 billion bushels, 14
per cent less than last year's crop.

Most farm states have been affected.

In Canada, parts of southern Alberta and Saskatchewan are also suffering through
a severe drought and many farmers have had to cull their herds because they
can't find enough forage.

Last week, Ottawa and the country's railways pitched in for a "Hay West"
campaign, offering money and rail cars to move hay from Eastern Canada to
drought-stricken western farmers.

In the United States, conditions are so poor in Nebraska that Gov. Mike Johans
has asked Agriculture Secretary Ann Veneman to declare the entire state a
disaster area so that farmers can obtain federal assistance.

Veneman already has declared Utah an agricultural disaster area. The state has
been affected by drought for four years.

Although several Midwestern states are also dry, rain fell in much of Minnesota
and Iowa in July, allowing most areas in those states to escape the drought.

But conditions have worsened in Kansas as a heat wave continues. State
statistics rate half the state's corn crop as very poor or poor.

Other commodities are also suffering. The U.S. Agriculture Department says
cotton production is expected to be nine per cent lower than last year's crop at
18.4 million bales.

                             588 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                     The Pantagraph (Bloomington, Illinois)

                            April 18, 2007 Wednesday

Reporter recounts farming changes farming changes

BYLINE: By Michelle Koetters;mkoetters@pantagraph.com

SECTION: MONEY; Pg. C1

LENGTH: 452 words


BLOOMINGTON - Orion Samuelson remembers when the United States exported crops to
the former Soviet Union in the summer of 1972.

The country had done some exporting before, but on a smaller scale. That summer,
the price of wheat and other crops skyrocketed.

"Suddenly, we realized there's a market outside our borders," he said.

Samuelson, agribusiness director and radio broadcaster for WGN radio, spoke
about changes in agriculture as the keynote speaker at the Illinois Wesleyan
Associates luncheon Tuesday. About 370 people attended the event, which brought
business and professional leaders together in support of the university, at
IWU's Shirk Center.

Globalization changed agriculture like nothing else, but it's not the only
factor that's left its mark on the industry. Equipment has come a long way,
farmers have dealt with good times and bad, and ethanol production will be a
large part of the future, Samuelson said.

To illustrate how far agriculture has come, Samuelson showed a newspaper
clipping from April 1923 that raved about the revolutionary Moline Universal
Tractor. With this piece of machinery, one man could cultivate two rows at a
time. He could plow five to eight acres in 10 hours and could harvest eight to
10 acres of corn in 10 hours.

Samuelson has since seen a machine that could tackle 32 rows at a time. Farmers
today can work with a lot of corn in a lot less time, he said.

The 79-year-old Samuelson also remembers living without electricity for 14 years
until the day in 1948 that the rural electric cooperative found his dairy farm.
All of a sudden, he could turn on a light with a switch and milk a cow with a
machine.

The latest change in agriculture has been $4 corn and $8 soybeans, largely the
result of increased demand for corn to produce ethanol as fuel. The next step in
the agriculture community will be to find other crops - maybe switchgrass or
miscanthus - that can produce ethanol, Samuelson said.

Samuelson's speech resonated with the agriculture community.

"It was true, historical," said retired farmer Robert Myers of Peoria. "It gives
you the value of agriculture and the people involved in it."

Myers and his wife, Alta, have witnessed similar changes in farming.

"I use to plow corn behind horses. I have operated some of the big machines,"
Robert Myers said.

"We milked cows the old-fashioned way until the electric came with the milking
machine," Alta Myers said.

Also at the event, the Illinois Wesleyan Associates announced they had raised
$640,000 for scholarships to 63 students.

LOAD-DATE: April 18, 2007

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC:

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                         Copyright 2007 The Pantagraph


                             589 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                             The Kalona News (Iowa)

  This content, including derivations, may not be stored or distributed in any
  manner, disseminated, published, broadcast, rewritten or reproduced without
                      express, written consent from STPNS

                               November 12, 2009

U.S. farms growing and more diverse;
FARMING AND YOUR FREEDOM

BYLINE: PETER GRAHAM

LENGTH: 521  words


Many folks still view U.S. agriculture as a plodding, mud-caked monolith, made
up of white males wearing bib overalls and tilling the soil with small tractors.
They have an "American Gothic" view of farming and farmers. Others think of
farming as a gigantic roaring machine pounding out zillions of crops and
livestock per second.

According to the latest Census of Agriculture: Boy, are they wrong!

The actuality of American farming in this first decade of the 21st Century is
that it is not a monolith, and is, in fact, quite diverse. The new census (2007)
shows that U.S. farms have grown by four percent since the 2002 census, and
those farms are more diverse than in 2002, as well.

Ag Secretary Tom Vilsack has called the Census of Agriculture "a valuable tool
that provides the general public with an accurate and comprehensive view of
American Agriculture."

The 2007 Census counted 2,204,792 farms in the U.S., a net increase of 75,810.
Nearly 300,000 new farms have begun operation since 2002. That flies in the face
of perceptions about farming. Most people would say that farms have disappeared
at alarming rates and that farming, per se, is just about a thing of the past.
The new figures sure give the lie to that idea!

Since 2002, excitingly, American farms have become much more demographically
diverse. For instance, the new count shows almost 30 percent more women as
principal farm operators, while Hispanic farmers as a group grew by 10 percent,
and the counts for African-American, Native American, and Asian farmers have
also increased in five years. Drop that pitchfork, Bud!

Farm size has changed, too. The latest census figures show that the trend
continues toward more small farms and more very large farms, while mid-sized
operations continue to wane. In the five-year period, the number of farms with
sales of less than $2,500 increased by 74,000, while the number of farms with
sales of more than $500,000 grew by 46,000.

In fact, the majority of U.S. farms are now in the small category. More than 36
percent are classified as "residential/lifestyle" farms, with sales of less than
$250,000. The operators of these farms mostly have an occupation other than
farming. Another 21 percent, the Census said, are "retirement" farms, with sales
of less than $250,000, and operators who said they are retired.

Diversity rears its head in other ways than just demographics and farm size. The
2007 Census of Agriculture shows that 57 percent of all farmers have Internet
access, up from 50 percent in 2002. And, 58 percent reported that they have
high-speed Internet connections. A farmer in Mid-America can check in with a
farmer in Afghanistan via the Worldwide Web, and exchanges of agricultural and
cultural knowledge can begin to bind the two as never before in history!

If you want to know more about the census of Agriculture, even down to your own
county level, you can get on the aforementioned web and dial up www.agcensus.
usda.gov. When you do, you'll find that the census also covers on-farm energy
generation, community-supported agricultural arrangements, and, oh yes, historic
barns. Have fun.

I'll see ya!

                             590 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

              September 13, 1983, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

CORN CROP PUT AT HALF OF '82 TOTAL

BYLINE: By SETH S. KING

SECTION: Section D; Page 1, Column 6; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 877 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12


The worst drought in nearly 50 years has reduced this year's corn and soybean
crops, the principal livestock feeds, to levels far below the record 1982
harvest, the Agriculture Department's Crop Reporting Board said today. The corn
crop will be one-half less than last year's yield, and soybeans will be
one-third less.

As a result, the department said, increases in retail food prices, especially
for meat, should start to show up this winter.

By comparison, America's wheat crop, most of it ripe before the drought began,
is expected to exceed 2.41 billion bushels, or 65.5 million metric tons. This
would be one of the largest yields in the last five years despite an acreage
reduction of nearly 25 percent under the Federal payment-in-kind program.

Few Quick Price Rises Seen

Despite the prospect of the smallest corn crop since 1970 and the smallest
soybean crop since 1976, Agriculture Secretary John R. Block said there would be
no immediate increase in most retail food prices.

''There will be some price rises down the road a ways,'' Mr. Block said at a
news conference after the Sept. 1 crop production report was released. ''But we
don't expect to see more than 1 to 1 1/2 percent added to the 4 to 5 percent
food inflation rate we were expecting for 1984.''

As of Sept. 1, the Crop Reporting Board announced, it expected a corn crop of
4.39 billion bushels, or 112 million metric tons, to be harvested in October.
This is 16 percent below the Aug. 1 forecast and would be 48 percent less than
the 1982 crop, which was a record 8.4 billion bushels.

Forecast of Other Crops

The board forecast a soybean crop of 1.53 billion bushels, or 41.8 million
metric tons, which would be 33 percent smaller than the record crop in 1982.

The total feed grain crop - consisting of corn, sorghum, oats and barley - is
expected to total 142 million metric tons, down 44 percent from 1982, the Crop
Reporting Board said. A metric ton, which is 1,000 kilograms, equals about 2,205
pounds.

The board forecast the 1983 cotton crop at 7.78 million bales, 35 percent below
last year. This year's production of tobacco is expected to be 1.36 billion
pounds, 31 percent less than last year. The 1983 peanut crop was projected at
2.91 billion pounds, down 15 percent below 1982.

The Crop Reporting Board's prediction on corn and soybeans was virtually the
same as that made last week by Conrad Leslie, a leading private crop forecaster.



Worldwide Grain Outlook

The department projected total world grain production for the 1983-84 season at
1.58 billion metric tons, down 2 percent from last month's forecast and 5
percent less than last year's record 1.68 billion tons.

The department said the grain crop in the Soviet Union, which has had good
growing weather, was expected to reach 191 million metric tons, above last
year's total of 175 million tons but below the Soviet goal of 225 million tons.

More than half of the record 1982 crop in corn and soybeans has already been
used up, with beef, pork and poultry production at high levels during the last
12 months. Nonetheless, the carry-over of these crops at the end of this month
will be large enough to offset the deep cuts in 1983 production caused by the
drought and, in the case of corn, by the reductions in acreage planted under the
payment-in-kind program.

Calculating Total Supply

The Agriculture Department is expecting a Sept. 30 carry-over of about 3.4
billion bushels of corn. When a 1983 crop of 4.4 billion bushels is added to
this, the total supply for the 12 months beginning Oct. 1 should be 7.8 billion
bushels, the sixth largest on record, Mr. Block said.

The department is expecting domestic corn use plus exports to range between 6.8
billion and 7 billion bushels. This would reduce the projected Sept. 30, 1984,
carry-over to less than one billion bushels. A reserve that low could lead to
shortages and high prices in the 1984-85 crop year, especially if bad weather
holds the 1984 corn crop to less than five billion bushels. Farm economists say
there must be at least 700 million bushels in the supply pipeline at all times
or else there might be shortages at some distribution points.

Meeting Export Targets

Mr. Block expressed confidence that there would be no such shortages of corn or
soybeans before the 1984 crop is harvested and that the United States would meet
all of its grain export commitments, including sales to the Soviet Union.

The carry-over of wheat when the harvest begins next June is expected to exceed
1.5 billion bushels, more than half of a normal year's crop.

With much range and pasture destroyed by the drought and with feed grain prices
more than a dollar a bushel higher than last spring, Mr. Block said, many cattle
and hog raisers are forced to reduce their herds.

This will bring larger supplies into the markets throughout the autumn, he said,
and retail meat prices should remain at today's levels or even decline. But by
January, he added, this larger supply will have been consumed and there will not
be as many animals to replace those slaughtered this fall.

''We expect these lower supplies to force meat prices up, beginning next winter,
and probably keep them up for most of next year,'' he said.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                               The New York Times

              October 19, 1983, Wednesday, Late City Final Edition

COMMODITIES Livestock Prices Mixed; Wheat Futures Up a Bit



BYLINE:
By The Associated Press

SECTION: Section D; Page 12, Column 5; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 371 words


Livestock and meat prices were mixed yesterday on the Chicago Mercantile
Exchange as traders awaited a quarterly report from the Agriculture Department
on cattle.

Wheat futures prices advanced slightly, corn was mixed and soybeans fell on the
Chicago Board of Trade.

Activity was light in the cattle pit as traders were squaring their accounts
before the report was released. The report indicated that as of Oct. 1, the
number of cattle being fattened for slaughter in the 13 major beef-producing
states was about 96 percent of the level of a year before. Analysts had expected
a figure slightly higher.



Heavy Marketing Seen

Chuck Levitt, a livestock analyst in Chicago with Shearson/ American Express,
noted that the weights of the cattle indicated that marketing could continue
heavy through the fourth quarter and that a decline is likely next year.

Ideas that hog producers might be able to command higher prices for their hogs
contributed to strength in hog futures yesterday, but those ideas were dashed
after the close of trading when the hog slaughter was estimated at 375,000
animals.

''When you put the whole meat complex together, you're looking at record
supplies for the fourth quarter,'' Mr. Levitt said. ''Unless we get a tremendous
demand for the products, these prices are going to have a tough time being
sustained.''



Pressure on Soybeans

Some of the pressure on soybean and corn prices came from progress being made in
the harvest, said Richard Loewy, a grain analyst in New York with
Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. He noted that a report Monday disclosed that
the corn harvest is 59 percent complete and the soybean harvest is 53 percent
complete.

Wheat prices were higher with support coming from the outlook for strong
exports, Mr. Loewy said. He noted that a weekly report released Monday showed 10
million bushels shipped to the Soviet Union. In addition, more exports are
predicted in the next few weeks.

Traders were also simultaneously buying wheat and selling corn, both for
December delivery, reasoning that wheat prices will advance more than corn in
the future because corn has gained so much relative to wheat since the middle of
the summer, Mr. Loewy said.

                                  Farming Life

                            July 27, 2016 Wednesday

Lamb exports to America closer

LENGTH: 427  words


The mission to get British lamb chops back onto American dinner plates has moved
a step nearer, Farming Minister George Eustice has announced at the National
Sheep Event.

Speaking at the opening of the flagship National Sheep Association (NSA) show in
Malvern, Worcestershire, the Minister of State will confirm the US Department of
Agriculture (USDA) has published proposals for consultation to relax import
restrictions on lamb that could generate an extra £35 million for the UK
economy.

This significant step forward means that British lamb is on track to be
available for US consumers by early 2017.

The move is the latest in ongoing efforts to allow Britain's farmers to start
exporting sheep meat to the United States' 300 million consumers.

A 1,000-page dossier was submitted to the USDA detailing the safety and quality
of British beef and lamb ahead of April's trade talks with US Secretary of
Agriculture Tom Vilsack in Washington.

Speaking at the NSA Sheep Event, Farming Minister George Eustice said: "The US
decision to press ahead with proposals to lift export restrictions on British
lamb is great news for our farmers who are one step closer to gaining access to
the lucrative American market, worth an estimated £35 million a year.

"Our world-leading food and drink industry is a key part of our nation's
economic success and in addition to forging good trade deals with our European
neighbours, we want to secure more export opportunities in the States as well as
with our close friends in the Commonwealth and other countries around the
world."

Defra is now co-ordinating UK farming industry comment for the 60-day
consultation and liaising with relevant US trade associations to gain support
for proposals.

NSA chief executive Phil Stocker said: "Increasing the number of export
destinations for British sheep meat is vital for our industry, ensuring there is
demand for our quality product in as many markets as possible.

"It is very encouraging that the USA is interested in opening its doors. Lamb
sales in the USA have dropped over the years, as a result of a falling domestic
production base, and NSA would like to see British lamb exported and promoted to
boost consumption. It could be a real opportunity for our sector."

NFU livestock board chairman Charles Sercombe said: "Re-opening the US beef and
lamb market to UK imports would be a positive move and an important confidence
building measure for the British livestock sector. The US is potentially a huge
and affluent market that has strong links to the UK as we share history and
language."

                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                              April 8, 2011 Friday

Bigger food crops no match for rising demand;
Reports indicate farmers will have massive yields this year but added production
can barely keep up

BYLINE: PAUL WALDIE

SECTION: REPORT ON BUSINESS: INTERNATIONAL; COMMODITIES; Pg. B8

LENGTH: 633 words


Global food prices fell for the first time in nearly a year last month, but the
reprieve won't last long and prices are already heading back up even as farmers
plant more crops than ever.

The UN Food and Agriculture Organization's Food Price Index fell 2.9 per cent in
March. That was the first monthly decline since last June and it marked a rare
halt to what had been a run of record highs.

The index, which tracks 55 commodities, dropped mainly because prices for most
grains and oilseeds fell in March as a result of turmoil in North Africa and the
earthquake in Japan. Both events raised concerns about the global economy and
food imports in those regions. As a result, prices for food staples such as
corn, soybeans and wheat began falling for the first time since last summer.

By the end of March those prices started turning back up. This week corn hit a
record high of $7.73 (U.S.) a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade, while wheat
and soybeans have jumped as much as 8 per cent in the past few days.

"It is very hard to think that we are out of the woods yet," said FAO senior
economist Abdolreza Abbassian, referring to food prices. "I think it's more
likely [the March index] was just a short-lived break in the increase."

Mr. Abbassian and others have been particularly surprised at how commodity
prices have started climbing even as several recent reports indicate farmers
will grow massive crops this year.

Farmers in the United States are expected to plant some of the largest corn and
soybean corps in history, according to figures released on Thursday by the U.S.
Department of Agriculture. Growers in Brazil and Argentina have also enjoyed
bumper harvests and wheat production is up in China, Russia and the Ukraine.
India is also enjoying strong rice harvests.

And yet, all that added production can barely keep up with demand. On the same
day the USDA predicted farmers will grow near record crops of corn and soybeans,
the agency said inventories of both are plummeting. The excess supply of corn
has dropped 15 per cent in the past year and is at a 15-year low. Soybean
inventories are at record lows and both crops are expected to remain in tight
supply this year. Canola inventories are also down, leaving wheat as one of the
few major grains still in decent supply. But that could change as farmers switch
from wheat to more lucrative crops.

"I think [low inventories are] going to be the supporting factor underpinning
prices all the way up to the harvest," Mr. Abbassian said. "Because there is no
sign of rationing irrespective of prices being so high."

Corn is by far the most important crop grown in the United States and the price
is being driven by three factors: ethanol production, exports to China and
demand from cattle ranchers who use corn in animal feed. All three are showing
no sign of slowing despite record prices. Ethanol is expected to consume up to
40 per cent of the U.S. corn crop, China keeps buying boat loads of corn and
cattle ranchers can afford to pay more for feed because meat prices are pushing
record highs.

"We have very tight stocks in corn," said Jerry Klassen, a Winnipeg-based
commodity analyst at GAP S.A. Grains & Products. He said corn needs to go $9 or
$10 a bushel before demand would be significantly affected. That's the price
where ranchers in particular would start to find other feed alternatives.

Low inventories also mean food prices will be vulnerable to even minor
disruptions such as flooding or droughts, said David Sparling, chair of
Agri-Food Innovation and Regulation at the Richard Ivey School of Business. Mr.
Sparling added that consumers should get used to long-term food inflation. "I
don't think there's any doubt that we are going to be seeing higher prices," he
said. "Everything is aligned."

LOAD-DATE: April 8, 2011

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                           November 13, 2004 Saturday
                          FIVE STAR LATE LIFT EDITION

"It's the year to grow things"

BYLINE: By REPPS HUDSON Of the Post-Dispatch

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. 01

LENGTH: 430 words


* Missouri, Illinois harvest record corn and soybean crops

Illinois and Missouri are among 18 corn- and 12 soybean-producing states
reporting record yields this fall, the Agriculture Department said Friday.

"This is an unusual and amazing crop yield in the United States," said Mark
Schleusener, deputy director of the Illinois Agriculture Statistics Service.
"We're having a record sorghum yield in Illinois. Hay is good. Even apples did
well. It's the year to grow things."

Agriculture experts point to the relatively cool months of July and August,
followed by dry conditions for harvest in September and October, to explain in
part why these two cash commodity crops have performed so well this year.

Missouri soybean production is expected to be 227 million bushels, based on
estimates on Nov. 1, with a record yield of 46 bushels an acre. In Illinois, the
yield is put at 50 bushels an acre, also a record, with a statewide total of
492.5 million bushels.

Nationwide, farmers are expected to harvest a record 3.15 billion bushels of
soybeans, up 28 percent from last year's crop.

This news comes just days after researchers at Louisiana State University
discovered Asian soybean rust in two test plots. This is the first report of the
soybean-harming fungus in the United States.

The rust, if not contained by fungicides when the 2005 crop is growing, could
have devastating consequences for bean farmers. They have until next spring's
growing season to figure out how they will combat possible infestation.

Nationally, the corn crop is forecast at 11.7 billion bushels, up 28 percent
from last year. Missouri farmers are harvesting a record 453 million bushels,
with a record yield of 159 bushels an acre. The previous record, set in 2000,
was 143 bushels an acre.

In Illinois, another record yield is in the making at 180 bushels an acre.
Illinois farmers are bringing in nearly 2.1 billion bushels of corn, nearly 18
percent of the national crop.

The massive crops in both states are straining the infrastructure of local grain
elevators, where farmers sell or store their grain, and the rail distribution
system. In some areas, elevators have had to store corn on the ground or in
structures under temporary cover, which can cause some spoilage of the crop.

Corn in south central Illinois was selling late Friday at $1.78 a bushel, off a
penny; the March corn futures on the Chicago Board of Trade were $2.11, up 2
cents. The spot price for soybeans in central Illinois was $5.25 a bushel, up 6
cents; the March bean futures on the Chicago Board of Trade were $5.30, up
nearly 4 cents.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

              September 1, 1981, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

COMMODITIES;
Corn Prices Strengthen, But Other Grains Drop

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

SECTION: Section D; Page 12, Column 5; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 450 words


Expectations that a Federal grain reserve program will begin soon and reports of
fungus disease afflicting some of the corn crop triggered a late surge in corn
futures prices yesterday. Other grain prices declined on the Chicago Board of
Trade.

''There's been talk of a modest corn blight in southern Illinois, which set off
some strong commercial buying late in the day,'' said Conrad Leslie, grains
analyst with the Leslie Analytical Corporation in Chicago.

Analysts also attributed corn's strength to forecasts of abovenormal rainfall
that could delay harvest of the grain from what one analyst described as already
''soggy soil'' in the grain and soybean growing areas. Corn settled 2 1/2 cents
to 7 cents higher, with the contract for September delivery at $2.94 1/2 a
bushel.

Analysts attributed the decline in wheat futures prices to substantially
larger-than-expected September delivery notices. Wheat settled 3 cents to 1 cent
lower, with the contract for September delivery at $3.85 3/4 a bushel.

After the close of trading yesterday, the United States Department of
Agriculture announced that the Soviet Union had bought an additional 350,000
metric tons of wheat for delivery in 1981-82, the sixth year of a long-term
grain agreement with the United States.

Soybean futures prices settled lower except in the nearest contract month, in
which traders were swayed by forecasts of wet weather in the growing areas
during the next week, analysts said. Soybeans were 3 1/2 cents lower to 3 1/2
cents higher, with the contract for September delivery at $6.65 1/2 a bushel.

Oats futures finished mixed because of light deliveries in the nearest contract
month, analysts said. Oats settled 1 1/4 cents lower to 3 1/2 cents higher in
the nearest contract month, with September at $1.98 3/4 a bushel.

Livestock prices tumbled in what analysts said was a general reaction to a drop
in cash market prices and falling Treasury bill futures prices. Rates in the
money and bond markets rose as much as one-half of a percentage point Monday,
dashing any hope for a quick and sustained decline in interest rates.

Live cattle closed .28 cent to .58 cent lower with the contract for October
delivery at 66.92 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .40 cent to .90 cent lower,
with the September contract at 69.07 cents a pound; hogs were .77 cent to 1.03
cents lower with the October contract at 49.45 cents a pound, and pork bellies
settled 1.12 cents to 1.65 cents lower, with the February contract at 64.45
cents a pound.

                                This Day (Lagos)

                                 March 03, 2016

USAID Trains Two Million Nigerian Households in New Farming Methods

BYLINE: George Okoh

LENGTH: 389 words

DATELINE: Makurdi


The United States Agency for International Development (USAID) has disclosed
that two million Nigerian households are undergoing training on various farming
methods in order to increase productivity in farming and moving small-time
farmers to commercial level farmers.

Speaking at the presentation of a tractor grant to Mbaikyor MPCS Ltd. by
USAID/Market II in Mano, Katsina-Ala Local Government Area, Managing Director of
USAID/Market II, Mr. Harvey Schartup disclosed that the Mbaikyor Multi purpose
cooperative society won the award after competitive assessments.

He said a key strategy of the Market II was to provide grants to farmers, who
are carefully selected with records of good agricultural performances. "We also
look at farmers who consider farming as a business; who demonstrate team work
and who can serve as model to others," he said.

Schartup also stated that the donation to the Mbaikyor society was a clear
indication that mechanised farming is a way of making Nigerian farmers develop
profitable commercial farming activities. "We are providing this tractor not
only to support the cooperatives and their members in furthering their own
production opportunities but also to allow them to develop a commercial tractor
business to service the other farmers in their communities."

Market II is to provide mechanisation and capacity building grants to 29 high-
performing farmer groups across the North, Middle belt and Southern regions of
Nigeria.

In his remarks, the Benue State Commissioner for Agriculture, Mr. James Anbua,
represented by the Benue state Project Manager of Benue Agricultural and Rural
Development Authority (BNARDA) Mr. James Ker said the development of agriculture
cannot be done by government alone, as such the intervention by USAID is a
welcome development that should be emulate by others.

He said the Benue government is ready to cooperate with any organisation to
uplift the lives of the people of the state.

He urged the farmers to make use of the tractor donated to them by USAID.

Earlier in his welcome address, Managing Director of Egalf Venture Limited,
Prof. Lawrence Ega said, as contractors to USAID, the company had been involved
in the project from the beginning, adding that the project was aimed at
improving agricultural productivity, income, nutrition and the livelihood of the
farmers.

                             597 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                      Hamilton Spectator (Ontario, Canada)

                    January 20, 1993 Wednesday Final Edition

Ontario agriculture needs magic product, says OFA chief

SOURCE: THE SPECTATOR

BYLINE: Stories by Agnes Bongers

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. D16

LENGTH: 378 words


ROGER GEORGE is looking for the magic product that will save farmers and
agriculture.

The president of the Ontario Federation of Agriculture figures it's out there.
It's just going to take someone with a lot of imagination and forward thinking
to come up with it -- a new yogurt, a peach product ... something.

Because without a magic product or two, agriculture in Ontario, in Canada, could
fade away into an industry focused on trucking food in from the United States,
he said.

Speaking to the annual meeting of the Fruit and Vegetable Growers' Association
yesterday in Hamilton, Mr. George explained how farming in this province has
stepped into a new era. This is an era of no government bailouts and an
increasingly competitive market created through free-trade agreements with the
United States, Mexico and the rest of the world through the General Agreement on
Tariffs and Trade.

The industry is going to have to scrutinize itself, to determine what it can do
best and stick to it.

And it's going to have to look beyond raw products to processing to come up with
innovative ideas that will keep it viable.

The only handouts that have to be put in place, Mr. George said, are the social
programs required for those farmers who cannot survive in this new climate. And
Mr. George anticipates there will be many of them.

'I recognize there will be casualties,' he said. 'We have to put in place safety
nets for those people.'

Not even farming's sacred cow, supply management, is immune to the trade winds
blowing into Canada, Mr. George said. It's expected that the number of dairy
farmers will drop in coming years, he said, and that chicken farmers will have
to find a way to break down provincial barriers to allow the industry to
survive.

'It's going to take some new thinking,' Mr. George said. For instance, the
Niagara peach crop damaged by hail might be used in processing instead of being
left on the trees to rot, he suggested.

'There are unlimited areas for growth in all sectors if we're willing to take
off the blinders.'

Mr. George urged farmers to lobby the Ontario government to ensure it
understands the importance of the industry.

'It's an inward-looking government that can't see beyond the bricks and mortar
of Toronto.'

                              The Washington Post

                           January 22, 2004 Thursday
                                 Final Edition

Agriculture Department Plans Cattle Identification System

BYLINE: Marc Kaufman, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: A Section; A13

LENGTH: 447 words


The Agriculture Department wants to implement a nationwide cattle identification
system as a way to better track the nation's herd after  the discovery of the
nation's first known case of mad cow disease.

Speaking yesterday before the House Committee on Agriculture, Agriculture
Secretary Ann M. Veneman said  the department has been studying how to organize
a cattle identification system for 18 months and now is looking to speed its
implementation.

"I understand the need to get it done quickly," Veneman said. But she also said
there is ongoing debate about whether there should be one system organized and
perhaps funded by the federal government, or whether the USDA should set
standards that cattle ranchers  and the meat industry can apply in a variety of
ways.

Highlighting the sense of urgency, Veneman said authorities have  been able to
locate only 24 of the 80 cows that came into the United States with the animal
later found to be infected with mad cow disease, or bovine spongiform
encephalopathy.

Federal officials want to find those animals because they came from the same
dairy herd in Alberta, Canada, as the sick cow and may have eaten the same
contaminated food believed to have caused the animal to become infected. With a
national identification system, it would be considerably easier to locate
individual animals.

The USDA reported yesterday that it had found one more of the animals that came
into the United States with the sick cow on a dairy facility in Boardman, Ore.,
near the Washington border. The farm was placed under quarantine.

Veneman said some meat retailers and restaurant chains such as McDonald's have
already begun identification programs of their own. Last fall, she said,
McDonald's began paying a higher price for beef that could be traced back to its
birth herd.

Veneman's comments came in answer to questions from Rep. Collin C. Peterson
(D-Minn.), who said a government-sponsored identification system has been tested
and is being used with about  1 million of the nation's 45 million cattle.
Peterson said the discovery of mad cow disease in Washington state made it
essential to get an identification system into place quickly, and he suggested
that the government require ranchers to use the one it helped develop several
years ago.

At the hearing, Veneman said that American consumers appear to be taking the mad
cow scare in stride, and that "retailers and food service outlets are reporting
virtually no adverse effects on consumer demand." She also said that the price
of cattle is now about 10 to 15 percent lower than before the contaminated
animal was found on Dec. 23, but that prices have been increasing in recent
weeks.

LOAD-DATE: January 22, 2004

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                       Copyright 2004 The Washington Post


                             599 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                 July 20, 1994, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

FUTURES MARKETS;
Corn and Soybeans Tumble On Report of Thriving Crops

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

SECTION: Section D;  Page 15;  Column 1;  Financial Desk

LENGTH: 419 words


Corn and soybean futures prices slumped to their lowest levels in more than a
year yesterday after the Government said the crops were thriving in the warm,
humid Midwest.

The Agriculture Department rated 86 percent of the corn crop and 79 percent of
the soybeans in good-to-excellent condition as of Sunday. The marks were among
the highest for those crops since the department began the rating system in
1985, said Dale Gustafson, grain analyst with Smith Barney Shearson.

Corn for September delivery sank 3 1/2 cents on the Chicago Board of Trade, to
$2.21 3/4 a bushel, and August soybeans dropped 13 1/4 cents, to $5.99 1/4 a
bushel. Both contracts notched intraday lows that were the lowest for an active
contract since June 1993.

September wheat rose 2 1/4 cents, to $3.30 1/4 a bushel, amid concerns about
scab disease, a fungus, in the spring wheat crop. September oats slipped 3/4
cent, to $1.16 1/2 a bushel.

Green coffee beans for September delivery plunged 7.55 cents, to $2.335 a pound
on the New York Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange.

Stephen Platt of Dean Witter said the drop was part of a continuing correction
in coffee prices, which more than doubled to $2.74 a pound from June 24 to July
13 after two severe frosts in Brazil, the largest coffee producer.

Cold Forecast in Brazil

Losses were limited by forecasts for more cold weather in Brazil this weekend,
Mr. Platt said.

Silver and copper futures rose strongly on New York's Commodity Exchange,
reflecting simmering inflation fears and prospects for stronger European and
Chinese demand for copper as those economies pick up steam. Gold followed silver
higher.

August gold rose 90 cents, to $387.10 a troy ounce; September silver rose 7.3
cents, to $5.345 a troy ounce, and September copper rose 3.75 cents, to $1.162 a
pound.

In energy trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, August light sweet crude
oil slipped 5 cents, to $19.46 a barrel, while September deliveries rose 14
cents, to $19.23 a barrel; August heating oil rose 0.64 cent, to 49.48 cents a
gallon; August unleaded gasoline rose 0.28 cent to 54.25 cents a gallon, and
August natural gas rose 1.4 cents, to $1.959 for 1,000 cubic feet.

In livestock trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, August live cattle fell
0.52 cent, to 68.80 cents a pound; August feeder cattle dropped 0.25 cent, to
78.80 cents a pound; August live hogs rose 0.27 cent, to 44.77 cents a pound,
and August frozen pork bellies rose 0.43 cent, to 32.75 cents a pound.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                         Deming Headlight (New Mexico)

                            February 4, 2013 Monday

Sustainable Farming? Really?

BYLINE: By Baxter Black, DVM

SECTION: OPINION

LENGTH: 455 words


Most of the agricultural community watches the pied pipers of "Sustainable
Farming" the same way grandparents watch their grandkids play with toy trains.
We humor them but don't try to explain how real trains work. Many "Sustainable
Farming" proposals are the exact opposite of their name.

"Model T Farming," or "Third World Farming" or "Farming to Feed the Few" would
be more accurate.

As a caveat, I must credit those scientists seeking realistic solutions to
agriculture's booming production capabilities. However, the dream world lead by
Luddites and New Age gurus are proposing a return to farming methods used in the
first half of the 20th century. A time they describe as "not relying on toxic
chemicals, pesticides, synthetic fertilizer and genetically modified foods. A
time when animals moved freely, consumed a natural diet, and were not confined."

I do offer a tip of the hat to hobby farmers with a nice garden, some chickens
or 15 sheep as 4H projects. Their contribution is appreciated, but they realize
very quickly that they can't grow or raise enough to feed their families for a
fortnight, much less 50 of their urban neighbors. Which, of course, is the
elephant in the room.

After World War II the population of our country and our world began to explode!
In the 1970's scientists were increasingly convinced a new "Ice Age" was coming
and "Global Starvation" was imminent. But help was on the way. Monsanto, Dow,
John Deere, Pfizer, Monfort, Pioneer, plus a battalion of academic and privately
funded scientists had seen it coming and were already root-deep into research.
Their objective was to increase production of food and fiber from a decreasing
number of acres (a result of urban encroachment), AND keep it affordable for the
masses.

Look around you, my friends. They did it and saved the world.

In the last 50 years the United States and Canada have not only been able to
keep up with the sky-rocketing global demand for food, we have shared our
research and taught the 3rd World how to feed itself! THAT is what I call
"Sustainable Farming."

Agriculture, Great Grandpa's agriculture, before the advent of pesticides,
chemicals, antibiotics, concentrated feeding and genetically modified seed, was,
and is not "sustainable" by any definition.

I suggest we call the methods that the pied pipers promote, something that more
accurately describes their toy train idyllic vision. For the sake of clarity how
'bout "Subsistence Level Farming."*

*subsistence: syn. (Poverty, Insufficient, Hand to mouth) Roget's Thesaurus.

Baxter Black is a former New Mexico resident who spent his working days
tormenting cows. He now resides in Arizona and spends his free time tormenting
cowboys and the sports. www.baxterblack.com

LOAD-DATE: February 5, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Baxter Black, DVM

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              All Rights Reserved

                                October 13, 2010

Federal grant will allow U of M and partners to study economics of organic farm
transition

BYLINE: Farmers Independent staff

LENGTH: 453  words


Minnesota economists will study the economic costs associated with transitioning
from traditional to organic farming through a new $1.2 million grant from the
U.S. Department of Agriculture.

The four-year project is aimed at gathering data about costs and returns for
farmers making the switch to organic farming, said Robert King, professor of
applied economics at the University of Minnesota and leader of the project. Data
will come from transitioning and recently certified organic farmers who enroll
in the Minnesota State Colleges and Universities Farm Business Management
Education program. The project also will develop print and online educational
materials that will help transitioning farmers make long-term planning
decisions.

U.S. producers are turning to certified organic farming systems as a potential
way to lower input costs, decrease reliance on nonrenewable resources, capture
high-value markets and boost farm income. While organic farming is among the
fastest-growing segments of agriculture, few public studies have been done on
the economic costs and returns for those who make the transition.

"As more and more farmers consider making the transition to organic production,
we're seeing that uncertainty about the costs of transitioning and the return on
those costs is a significant impediment, " King said. "Data about the
experiences and lessons learned from those who have made the transition will
help other farmers decide whether to make this change."

The project will include training on fundamentals of organic transition for the
71 instructors in the state colleges and universities system's Farm Business
Management Education program. The instructors will work closely with about 80
participating farmers over the life of the study to track farm financial
records, offer advice and develop benchmarks for future organic transitions. The
Minnesota Department of Agriculture will help identify and recruit transitioning
farmers to participate in the project and will administer scholarship awards,
which will cover up to 90 percent of the farmers' participation costs.
Individual farm data will be aggregated to ensure confidentiality, then analyzed
and shared locally and nationally through the Center for Farm Financial
Management's FINBIN website, as well as through publications and presentations
developed specifically for this project.

"The farmers who participate will gain a deeper understanding of their own
financial condition during the years of transition, " King said. "Their shared
experiences will also help other farmers developing transition plans, lenders
evaluating business plans and loan applications from transitioning farmers, and
policymakers assessing program needs."

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                            June 8, 1994, Wednesday

Gwinnett Today Enjoyment of exalted onion spreads far and wide

BYLINE: Elliott Brack

SECTION: EXTRA; Section J; Page 2

LENGTH: 478 words


For years now, you've heard us extol the wonders of the mighty Vidalia onion.
Yes, they are delicious. And we have learned that this year's crop, perhaps the
largest and best ever, is also the least expensive in some time.

We asked friends in the Agriculture Department why Vidalias are so cheap this
year.

"The price is improving," Commissioner Tommy Irvin told us, but he could shed no
light on reasons why. However, prices at supermarkets are still relatively low.

Did you know that it was Americans who introduced the onion to part of Japan? We
learned that recently from Tetsuji Banno, president and CEO of OKI telecom, the
big cellular phone maker in Suwanee.

Mr. Banno is from Hokkaido, an island of northern Japan.

"The island of Hokkaido was developed after a sort of civil war in Japan in
1868," he said. "Many of the defeated decided to immigrate to Hokkaido. The new
government was established after Shogunate and it was decided to develop the
island with the help of American advisers and consultants.

"Farming was established that was unique to any other part of the country.
Vegetables and fruits such as potatoes, asparagus, onions, apples and pears were
grown. Cattle and dairy farming was customary. Statistics show that because
dairy products were plentiful, the average body size of Hokkaidoites has been
bigger."

Then Mr. Banno comes to the onion.

"The onion is one of the vegetables passed on by the United States," he said.
"American agricultural experts advised the local farmers on how to grow onions
on this chilly island. In fact, in Japan the onion is distinctive to the island
of Hokkaido. When growing up, any time I was able to mingle in the larger cities
with people from other districts, I was often laughed at because of my diet
preference for onions. We had learned at an early age to use onions in almost
everything that we cooked.

"It was told that the Americans who helped develop Hokkaido were mainly from the
Northwest," he said, "but who knows, some of the people may have come from
Georgia."

Mr. Banno may not realize it, but one of the onion varieties that tries to
compete with Georgia's Vidalia comes from Washington state. It is grown in the
eastern part, near Walla Walla, and in fact is called the Walla Walla onion.
We've never bitten into a Walla Walla, but there have been tasting contests,
which, if we remember correctly, the Vidalia won hands-down.

As we all have our favorite recipes for the wonderful Vidalia, you might be
interested in how Mr. Banno enjoys his onions, drawing on his life in his native
Hokkaido.

"My way to cook the onion is in a frying pan with salt, pepper, margarine and my
secret ingredient - a dash of Japanese sake," he said. "It is delicious!"

Now that's a different ingredient in a recipe for the tasty Vidalia!

In the Georgia vernacular, "How about them onions?"

LOAD-DATE: June 12, 1994

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH941630026

                    Copyright 1994 The Atlanta Constitution

                           Edmonton Journal (Alberta)

                      March 26, 2001 Monday Final Edition

Canada prepares for the worst: Cattle ID system means Canada ahead of U.S.  in
readiness

SOURCE: CP

BYLINE: Scott Edmonds

SECTION: Top Copy; Pg. A3

LENGTH: 554 words

DATELINE: Winnipeg

Thanks to a new cattle identification system, Canada is likely in better shape
than the United States to deal with any outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease, say
officials.

The United States could be three years away from developing such a system, which
uses electronic tags and bar code tags to identify animals.

"They don't have the national infrastructure like we do in Canada to make it
happen as quickly," said Julie Stitt, general manager of the new Canadian Cattle
Identification Agency.

So far, North America appears to have escaped the outbreak which is raging
across Europe, leaving piles of burning animal carcasses in its wake.

If it does hit Canada or the United States, it could immediately put a halt to
exports. Canada exports more than half its beef.

Some Canadian livestock producers are so worried they have banned visitors from
their farms and cancelled trips to Europe.

But if foot-and-mouth does make its way across the Atlantic, the national
identification system, put in place in January, could help officials get a
handle on an outbreak and control it quickly. There was one in place in 1952,
the last time Canada had to battle foot-and-mouth.

That system was scrapped in 1985, but fears of mad-cow disease helped prompt the
industry to reintroduce it.

Stitt said the United States recognizes the need for such a system and has
started to move in a similar direction. The National Cattlemen's Beef
Association has set up a working group to study the concept and the U.S.
Department of Agriculture is trying to drive it along, but it could take three
years to set up a system.

Even though the new tags have been available for only a few months in Canada,
Stitt estimates as many as half the country's calf herd of four million animals
may already have been tagged.

"There's been a huge demand for these tags and that's based on a program that
has soft enforcement now."

As of January, any animal that leaves its herd of origin in Canada is supposed
to have one of the tags. In July, slaughterhouses will start reading the tags.

The Canadian Food Inspection Agency says animal identification is a key to
tracing sick animals to root out an infection such as foot- and-mouth.

"They may have to go back and test and quarantine one herd as opposed to 100
herds," says Stitt.

The system only applies to beef cattle, but Dr. Blaine Thompson of the food
inspection agency says a system is needed for other animals as well.

The sheep industry, for example, has been fighting periodic outbreaks of
scrapie, a killing cousin of mad-cow disease that hits sheep and goats.

In the last year alone more than 4,000 animals have been killed in Quebec and
Manitoba to control the disease, which, unlike the bovine variety, cannot spread
to humans.

The sheep industry is still considering a plan for a national identification
system that would make tracing infected animals easier. Of the 4,000
slaughtered, most were healthy animals killed as a precautionary measure.

Europe has an elaborate animal identification system, and while it may not be
able to keep animal herds disease-free, it does make fighting outbreaks a lot
easier, said Stitt.

"We might think the numbers are high right now that they're having to kill, but
it could be a lot higher without an ID system."

LOAD-DATE: March 27, 2002

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

spectacles like the one above, showing the carcass of a cow being lowered onto a
pyre of slaughtered livestock to be burned in Monkokehampton, England.

                     Belfast News Letter (Northern Ireland)

                            April 12, 2003, Saturday

BRUSSELS NOTEBOOK: PARTIAL-DECOUPLING IS NEW BUZZ WORD

SECTION: FARMING LIFE; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 762 words


There are growing signs that the Commission has accepted the need to alter its
decoupling plans.

Four months after it first put into play the concept of breaking the link
between aid and production a new term, partial decoupling, has emerged in
Brussels.

Inevitably no-one knows exactly what this means. But the one certainty is that
over the next six weeks or so the Commission is determined to secure a deal on
CAP reform.

By giving way on some of the more controversial aspects of decoupling it
believes this will allow it to clinch a deal relatively quickly, possibly even
by the June deadline set when the proposals were published in January.

The Special Committee on Agriculture (SCA), made up of senior member state
agriculture officials based in Brussels, has been debating partial decoupling
for some time.

They met again yesterday, armed with more knowledge of member state positions
from this week's farm council in Luxembourg. As things stand partial decoupling
could range from phasing in the policy over a number of years to implementing it
only for specific commodities or regions.

The betting at the moment is on arable payments being decoupled, with major
concessions on the livestock side.

This would satisfy the United States and others in the World Trade Organisation,
since in the battle over trade distorting subsidies grain is the most
contentious commodity. In an EU context the arable sector accounts for almost
half of CAP spending, so a decoupling deal would put the Commission well on its
way to securing radical change to the CAP over the next five years.

For beef and dairy farmers phased decoupling could be the worst of all options.
This would mean farmers would still have to keep livestock numbers to secure CAP
payments, but they would also have to cope with the market changes decoupling
would bring.

In short like all compromises this could deliver the worst of both options and
would increase rather than reduce red tape.

It would also allow uncertainty and speculation to continue, since farmers would
still have no firm knowledge of how decoupling would work when it was fully in
place.

The other option would be to protect grass based livestock production in key
regions. This could be for specific member states - unlikely - or limited to
less favoured areas.

A decoupled grassland premium could be paid as a per acre payment up to a
maximum stocking density. Such an approach would however create new anomalies
between farmers in the same area, even if a national envelope concept allowed
member state governments maximum flexibility.

The best approach would of course be a simple grassland premium.

Provision exists in the CAP reform rural development proposals for the
Commission to introduce aid for quality food production.

It could use this as a basis to offer higher entitlements for grass based
livestock production. This would also offset the unfair advantage those with
maize silage will enjoy because under CAP reform they will secure a decoupled
arable aid payment.

For Northern Ireland this would be a good deal, and it is one that might
persuade France and Ireland to support decoupling - although the Republic will
ultimately have to accept that it has for years over-produced beef and depended
on export refunds to dispose of it.

This means a reform deal without pain for Ireland will not overcome the problems
the Commission must tackle if the CAP is to be sustainable for the next ten
years.

This is why Ireland is so resolute in its opposition to decoupling, but for the
Commission the key to a deal is delivering thinking on decoupling which would be
acceptable to France.

This all sounds like a sensible way forward for the Commission and member
states. But there is one major problem, and that is the dairy sector.

The plan to base decoupled payments on quota held at 31 March 2004 has created
massive uncertainty, and already farmers are making business decisions on the
basis that the proposals will become reality.

That is however now looking increasingly doubtful. The Commission seems to be
retreating on its dairy plans.

It may even delay implementation until 2007 when the Agenda 2000 reforms will
end if their implementation is brought forward to 2004. This could see
decoupling agreed in principle for the dairy sector, but then put on ice for
three or four years.

This is fresh uncertainty dairy farmers could do without, but it does seem that
by the end of June, one way or the other, the way ahead will be more clear.

LOAD-DATE: April 12, 2003

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUB-TYPE: PAPER

                   Copyright 2003 Century Newspapers Limited

                               The New York Times

                June 12, 1982, Saturday, Late City Final Edition

COMMODITIES;
Grain and Soybeans Rally in Busy Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

SECTION: Section 2; Page 49, Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 465 words


Grain and soybean futures prices posted a broad rally in active trading
yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.  Support in wheat prices came from
anticipation that the Soviet Union will be in the market for American wheat,
spurred by a an Agriculture Department report that the Soviet harvest is
expected to be poor, said Al London, a grain analyst in Chicago with
Conticommodity Services Inc.

The Agriculture Department also forecast a record winter wheat harvest for the
United States, but Mr. London said the report confirmed what traders already
suspected and prices failed to react.

Wheat was 5 cents to 7 1/4 cents higher with July at $3.50 1/4 a bushel; corn
was 1 3/4 cents to 4 1/2 cents higher with July at $2.77 1/2 a bushel; oats were
1/2 cent to 3 3/4 cents higher with July at $1.92 3/4 a bushel, and soybeans
were 13 cents to 15 cents higher with July at $6.45 1/2 a bushel.

Cattle prices were mostly lower and live hog and frozen pork bellies mixed on
the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.  Trading in cattle was light and pressure came
from weaker prices for wholesale cash prices for choice grade beef, said Chuck
Levitt, a livestock analyst in Chicago with Shearson/ American Express. He said
prices for choice beef were driven down this week by cattlemen flooding the
market to take advantage of high prices.

Live hog futures were mixed after a week of unexpectedly high marketings.
Despite the heavy marketings, the contract for July was higher, indicating a
possible tightness of supply, Mr. Levitt said.

He added that traders were beginning to anticipate that the hog and pig
inventory report due to be released June 22 will show reduced inventory.

Frozen pork belly prices were mixed in what Mr. Levitt said was uncertainty
about supplies being put into cold storage. Trade on the cash market was slow.

Live cattle for delivery in June settled 0.32 cent lower at 71.75 cents a pound;
June live hogs settled 0.12 cent lower at 62.10 cents a pound, and July pork
bellies settled 0.83 cent lower at 76.92 cents a pound.

Sugar prices were higher and coffee lower on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa
Exchange in New York.  Sugar prices recovered from recent declines in what was
called a ''corrective'' move by Antoinette Mammaro, a tropical products analyst
in New York with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

Coffee prices moved erratically during the day with trade selling pulling prices
down, she said.  Sugar for delivery in July settled 0.22 cent higher at 7.02
cents a pound; July coffee settled 0.20 cent lower at 138.76 cents a pound.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                     Belfast News Letter (Northern Ireland)

                           January 17, 2004, Saturday

FALL IN US POTATO PRODUCTION

SECTION: FARMING LIFE; Pg. 33

LENGTH: 108 words


WINTER potato production in the United States for 2004 is forecast at 3.84
million cwt, down five per cent from a year ago and nine per cent below 2002.

Figures released by the United States Department of Agriculture show harvested
acreage in the two winter potato States (California and Florida) is estimated at
14,000 acres, down two per cent from 2003, while the average yield is forecast
at 274 cwt per acre, eight cwt below last year.

According to the USDA report, harvest is underway in California's Kern County
and proceeding normally. In Florida, mostly mild, dry fall weather provided good
conditions for crop development.

                       The Creston News Advertiser (Iowa)

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                            January 16, 2015 Friday

Three-State Beef Conference highlights options for the future of Iowa's cattle
herd

BYLINE: Jake Waddingham, The Creston News Advertiser, Iowa

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 838 words


Jan. 16--The recent resurgence in the cattle market prices have revitalized the
beef industry, but left many farmers and experts questioning, is this the right
time to rebuild the nation's herd?

More than 70 area farmers and students attended the Three-State Beef Conference
at Southwestern Community College Tuesday night for three presentations that
covered supplementation strategies, forage systems and financial impacts of
fertility and infertility in the current cattle market.

"It is really remarkable the prices we are seeing," said Dan Hanrahan, who farms
about 120 head of cattle with his parents in Madison County. "This year has
really been a bright spot for us."

The United States Department of Agriculture's highest estimate of income loss
for Iowa corn and soybean farmers is $2.6 billion. Offsetting those losses are
profits that grain producers locked in earlier this year and the improved
profitability of the livestock industry.

Farmers are weighing the option of selling their high-priced heifers or holding
them back to build their operation numbers.

"If we are going out and buying replacement females, we should be buying females
that are elite or at least an upgrade from what we currently have in our
production system," said Patrick Gunn, animal science assistant professor at
Iowa State University.

Tom Frey of Creston Livestock Auction said his numbers have held steady and the
market prices remain high, making replacement costs for the herd higher.

"It is a direct reflection on the low numbers of cattle because of the recent
drought, high corn prices and high grain prices," Frey said. "This is a heavier
swing than normal. It has us down to the lowest number of cows since the 1940s
and 1950s."

Frey added that several farmers plowed up pasture to switch it to row crops to
take advantage of the high commodity prices.

"If the heifer is a dramatic upgrade over what you have in terms of genetic
potential, then maybe that is a pretty easy pill to swallow," Gunn said. "If you
are not making significant upgrades in terms of what they can bring to your
herd, maybe that is a little pricey in this day and age."

Return investment

Calving season is quickly approaching for a majority of area farmers. Then
farmers will have to decide how many cows they will need to replace for the next
year.

Iowa State University is developing a tool online to help farmers compare
raising or buying replacement heifers for their operation. Users can plug in
fields like weight and current market prices so the computer can calculate the
animal's value.

The biggest factor is how long the new heifer is going to stay in the herd and
actively reproduce to turn a profit.

"It is not the end of the world if we have open females as yearlings," Gunn
said. "Once we get a calf out of them and they come up open as two year olds,
that is when we are going to show where it really starts to hurt your pocketbook
if you are stringently calling open cows every year."

Gunn also encouraged farmers to look into tightening their breeding window.

"Those females that conceive in the first 21 days of calving season stick around
longer and make you more money, plain and simple," Gunn said. "Their longevity
is about 1.7 more years than those females that conceive after 43 days of the
breeding season."

But no matter how good the cow is, Gunn said if she dies on the farm, she is
very unlikely to garner any profit. Around 50 percent of the cow's return is
tied up in her salvage value.

Safe practices

Gunn said a lot of farmers have neglected annual tests like the breeding
soundness exam (BSE) for cows to avoid another veterinary charge.

"If you get one more cow pregnant because you do a BSE, it is well worth the
money spent," Gunn said.

Another problem area Gunn highlighted was trichomoniasis in nonvirgin bulls. The
venereal disease can be transmitted during the breeding season and kill the
embryo late in the breeding season.

In order to establish a healthy herd that has a reliable fertility rate, testing
the cows and bulls annually can relieve farmers of open females or complicated
births.

"Some females are not destined to be momma cows," Gunn said. "That is my biggest
concern right now with the market, is that anything with four legs and a vulva
is being inseminated. That doesn't mean it is an upgrade for some people's
breeding plans."

Gunn said the current prices favor farmers trying something new in their
management practices. That way they don't have to take a risk if the prices
decline or if a drought raises input costs.

"We are still looking at pretty close to $2 cattle for the foreseeable future,"
Gunn said. "If a drought hits again, it is going to shake things up considerably
on the annual cost ... but I think in terms of total number of cows, total
number of calves, it is going to be pretty profitable for the next three or four
years."

___ (c)2015 the Creston News Advertiser (Creston, Iowa) Visit the Creston News
Advertiser (Creston, Iowa) at www.crestonnewsadvertiser.com Distributed by
Tribune Content Agency, LLC

                      Northeast Mississippi Daily Journal

                            December 2, 2005, Friday

Mississippi farmers spend more, grow less

BYLINE: By Emily Le Coz

LENGTH: 526 words



Higher fuel and fertilizer costs boosted the expense of farming this year while
hurricanes and dry spells decreased the amount harvested.

In other words, more went in but less came out.

All the state's major row crops experienced lower yields per acre this year than
they did in 2004, according to a report by the United States Department of
Agriculture.

Per-acre cotton yields fell by 16 percent, rice by 5.8, soybeans by 4 and
corn/grain by 2.2.

Northeast Mississippi fared about the same or better than the rest of the state,
said several agricultural experts.

"Those numbers are pretty accurate," said area agronomy agent Charlie Stokes.
"We don't have any rice, and I saw a little cotton that did a bit better than
that. But corn as far as yield per acre came fairly close. As for cotton, a lot
of it got beat out of the bolls from Hurricane Katrina."

Katrina caused a lot of damage to crops elsewhere in the state but only mildly
affected growers here. In the case of soybeans, the heavy rains actually
provided much needed moisture, said Alan Blaine, soybean specialist with the
Mississippi State University Extension Service.

"In Northeast Mississippi, the yield per acre for soybeans is actually higher
than last year," Blaine said. "We hate that the hurricane came through the rest
of the state, but Northeast Mississippi crops benefited."

High winds, flooding

Not all benefited. High winds from the Aug. 29 storm flooded many fields and
blew down tall stalks of corn, contributing in part to the nearly 19 percent
drop in corn production statewide.

But farmers also opted not to plant as much corn this year due to high
fertilizer costs, said Erick Larson, corn and small grains specialist with MSU's
Extension Service.

"We also had a very wet planting season during March and through mid April,
which prohibited farmers from planting corn," he said. "But had it not been for
Hurricane Katrina, our yields per acre would have been extremely close or
exceeded last year's record highs."

Production was also down statewide for all crops except rice, which increased by
6.2 percent. Soybeans dropped by 8.1 and cotton by 10.2.

"We had hot temps and dry weather," said Tom Barber, cotton specialist with the
MSU Extension Service. "That set us back a little bit."

Most experts ranked this year's harvest a 6 or 7 on a scale from 1 to 10, saying
it could have been better but it could have been worse.

But whatever the outcome, Stokes said, all farmers felt a pinch due to higher
costs of petroleum, which is used to make diesel fuels and most fertilizers.

"Fertilizers have gone up, diesel fuel to harvest the crop was astronomical, if
it could be found," he said. "Yeah, it's going to hurt."


-----

To see more of Northeast Mississippi Daily Journal or to subscribe to the
newspaper, go to http://www.djournal.com. Copyright (c) 2005, Northeast
Mississippi Daily Journal, Tupelo, Miss.

reprints@krtinfo.com.
