                             609 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                               Port Lincoln Times

                             June 21, 2012 Thursday

GRAINassist THE monthly United States

SECTION: SPORT; Pg. 21

LENGTH: 433 words


GRAINassist

THE monthly United States Department of Agriculture World Agricultural Supply
and Demand report was released last week, and despite the fall in production
numbers of wheat, the wheat price fell as trade was expecting a bigger cut.

US 11/12 wheat stocks were down 40million bushels, and the projected 12/13
stocks were down 41 million bushels, but still the trade was looking for more so
the news was viewed as bearish, and wheat fell 14 USc/Bu overnight.

Soybeans also fell; 11/12 stocks are now at 175 million bushels after having
fallen a surprising 35 million bushels, and projected 12/13 stocks were back to
140 million bushels, falling five million bushels.

Along with doubts surrounding second crop soybean acre numbers, this fall in
stocks was seen as bullish, and soybeans jumped 10USc/Bu by the end of trade.

Perhaps the biggest shock to trade was US corn stocks remaining unchanged for
both old and new crop.

The increase in corn for ethanol usage was offset by the decrease in exports and
an increase in production.

Another lot of bearish news for corn, which is now trading at 584 USc/Bu, after
spending much time trading on par with wheat.

However weather has caused a large week on week deterioration in US corn crops,
with a fall of 6% (to 66%) of good to excellent crops conditions and this may
not have been factored into the USDA report, having being announced on the same
day.

While the US situation largely dictates the markets and prices that Aussie
farmers receive for their grain, the increased US crop production year on year
could soon be overshadowed on the market by the global production estimates.

Un.favourable weather has hampered much of the globe in each of their different
seasons.

Up until last week, Australia has had a very dry start to their seeding program,
with parts of Victoria still missing out on the rain forecast for this week.

The US has had unusually warm and dry weather, deteriorating the condition of
wheat crops being currently harvested, and having adverse effects on new crop or
lessening potential for second crop in the area.

Russian production estimates are continually being lowered after drought
conditions, and the trade is watching this one very closely, as Russia is known
to undercut the US export market in good harvest years, forcing US and Aussie
prices down.

June, July and August will be volatile months as crops move through vital
maturing stages overseas, and begin to emerge in Australia, with the
unpredictable La Nina weather pattern still holding on tight.

n Submitted by Belinda-Jane Clark GRAINassist Grain Brokers Eyre Peninsula

LOAD-DATE: June 20, 2012

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


             Copyright 2012 Fairfax Media Publications Pty Limited
                              All Rights Reserved


                             610 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                           Palm Beach Post (Florida)

                            January 15, 2010 Friday
                                 FINAL EDITION

COLD DAMAGE TO CROPS MINIMAL

BYLINE: By SUSAN SALISBURY Palm Beach Post Staff Writer

SECTION: LOCAL & BUSINESS; Pg. 6B

LENGTH: 461 words


Freezing temperatures caused bananas to split open in Loxahatchee, browned
thousands of acres of sod and ruined some sweet corn in the Glades, but overall
the prolonged cold snap did not devastate Palm Beach County's farms and
nurseries.

Although almost all the county's 250 farms and 600 nurseries were affected, much
of the damage is believed to be minimal, preliminary assessments indicate,
agricultural extension agents said Thursday.

"Even next week we will still not know the entire ramifications for sugar cane
and citrus. It will be weeks," said Steve Berk, district director of the U.S.
Department of Agriculture's Farm Service Agency in West Palm Beach.

After further evaluations are made, the local agency will make its final reports
and submit them to U.S. Secretary of Agriculture Tom Vilsack. Gov. Charlie Crist
can request a disaster declaration, then it's up to Vilsack to make the
decision.

Palm Beach County produces most of the winter vegetables grown in the United
States. In 2008-09, its veggie crops were valued at $260 million at the farm
level. Sugar cane accounts for the bulk of its 466,000 acres of commercial
agriculture.

Disastrous or not, the conditions the cold brought could become legendary, with
both ice and frost prevalent in the Belle Glade area. The cold snap began Jan.
2, with sub-freezing temperatures occurring Jan. 6-7 and Jan. 10-13.

David Sui, Palm Beach County extension agent for vegetables and tropical fruit,
estimated the sweet corn losses at 30 percent to 40 percent for corn that was
close to maturity. The wind and freezing temperatures combined hurt corn, green
beans, squash, winter melons, cucumbers and similar vegetables.

"Other crops like lettuces, arugula and basil suffered as well, but not as
badly," Sui said, estimating those losses at 20 percent to 30 percent.

Rick Roth, president of Roth Farms east of Belle Glade, said that despite the
low of 25 degrees at his farm Monday, he's encouraged by how the crops look.

"You are going to lose some sugar cane yield, but it will not be a devastating
loss," Roth said.

Ornamental crops such as bedding plants were hit hard in some cases, with as
many as 70,000 young plants ruined at a Loxahatchee nursery, extension agents
said. Sod sales will slow until new growth sprouts and the sod is green again.
The county has about 12,000 acres of sod farms.

Berk said that if a disaster is declared, federal aid programs kick in, but
unlike past programs, eligibility will not be based on how much of an individual
crop is lost. Instead, an individual farm's entire operation, including its
total revenue and production, will be considered.

"With this type of damage, there have been some losses out there, in some case,
substantial losses," Berk said.

~susan_salisbury@pbpost.com

LOAD-DATE: June 4, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                 Copyright 2010 The Palm Beach Newspapers, Inc.
                              All Rights Reserved


                             611 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                                 Ottawa Citizen

                    December 27, 2003 Saturday Final Edition

U.S. tracks source of diseased cow

SOURCE: The Calgary Herald

BYLINE: Gina Teel

SECTION: News; Pg. A1

LENGTH: 747 words

DATELINE: CALGARY

CALGARY -- The birthplace of the dairy heifer with the first confirmed case of
mad cow disease in the United States could be identified in a matter of days,
and Canada is among the possible sources, U.S. Department of Agriculture
officials said yesterday.

However, officials admit "there is a tangled web of different possibilities" as
to where the cow came from.

Ron DeHaven, the department's chief veterinarian, said Canada is on the list
because of the significant cross-border trade in animals prior to the U.S. ban
on such imports May 20, following the detection of a single case of bovine
spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) -- or mad cow disease -- in Alberta.

However, Mr. DeHaven noted the infected animal responsible for bringing the
country's $27-billion cattle industry to a halt could have just as easily been
born in the U.S.

"It's premature to speculate whether the animal might have or might not have
originated from Canada," he said in a conference call with reporters.

This week, the U.S. confirmed its first case of mad cow disease in a Holstein
heifer in Mabton, Washington, after independent tests by world specialists in
England came back positive.

The U.S. is scrambling to locate the birth herd of the slaughtered cow, since it
likely was infected from eating contaminated feed, Mr. DeHaven said. The
investigation focuses on two dairy heifer finishing facilities in Washington
state.

On Tuesday, investigators quarantined the 4,000-head dairy herd which contained
the infected cow and one of her three calves.

A second dairy herd in Sunnyside, Washington, was quarantined yesterday. That
herd contains a young bull calf recently born to the infected Holstein cow. The
third calf died after birth.

Prior to May 20, Canada exported 80,000 registered Holstein heifers annually to
the U.S. -- its largest customer.

Canadian beef industry officials said yesterday the optics of having another
case of the deadly brain wasting disease would deal a huge blow to Canada's
struggling beef industry.

More than 30 countries shut their borders to Canadian beef and cattle on May 20,
costing the beef industry about $1.9 billion in lost exports to date.

"I don't want to wish anybody bad luck, but we'll certainly be better off if the
animal wasn't born here," said Neil Jahnke, president of the Canadian
Cattlemen's Association.

Arno Doerksen, chairman of the Alberta Beef Producers, said this latest bout of
uncertainty couldn't have come at a worse time.

"We're just at the point where we were starting to see some progress with moving
product back into the U.S.," Mr. Doerksen said. "We're back into another round
of uncertainty on how the markets will respond."

But the uncertainty will likely continue for some time, as American officials
were uncertain yesterday if the infected Holstein was even registered.

Most large U.S. dairies don't keep up the registration papers once they purchase
the animals, which makes tracing the slaughtered animal difficult, said John
Iversen, national director of the Alberta Holstein Association.

"I would think at this point that if there was any identification of the animal,
they would know by now," Mr. Iversen said.

Dr. Brian Evans, chief veterinary officer at the Canadian Food Inspection
Agency, said these types of investigations are very dependent on record-keeping.
Accordingly, he said the investigation may take longer than the couple of days
Mr. DeHaven suggested. He added that Canadian vaccination tags are clearly
marked on the back.

"Certainly if there was any indication that the slaughtered animal bore such a
tag, it would have been made clearly early on," Mr. Evans said.

Meanwhile, Canada doesn't plan to broaden its limited ban on some beef imports
from the U.S. But a number of other countries have announced full scale bans of
American beef imports.

Yesterday, Colombia, Argentina, Peru, Venezuela, Uruguay, Nicaragua and Costa
Rica joined Mexico, Brazil and Chile, which had announced similar measures
earlier this week. Egypt, Indonesia, Vietnam and Ukraine also announced measures
yesterday to keep out American beef imports.

Japan, the largest market for U.S. beef, taking $1.3 billion worth of beef and
veal, announced a ban earlier this week. It was followed by South Korea and
Mexico, the second and third largest consumers of U.S. beef by value.

Japan, South Korea and Mexico accounted for the bulk of $2.6 billion U.S. in
beef export sales in 2002.

LOAD-DATE: December 27, 2003

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: News

                      CanWest Global Communications Corp.

                             612 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                        The Telegraph (Alton, Illinios)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                              June 18, 2010 Friday

Rains interrupt fieldwork throughout the state

BYLINE: Maggie Borman, The Telegraph, Alton, Ill.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 303 words


Jun. 18--The spotty rains continued the week of June 7, interrupting fieldwork
in many parts of the state and delaying the last of the soybean planting.

However, producers continued spraying corn and soybeans and bailing hay as
weather permitted, according to the United States Department of Agriculture's
weekly weather and crop report.

Temperatures averaged 73.4 degrees, 2.6 degrees above normal across the state.
Statewide precipitation averaged 1.50 inches, 0.56 inches above normal, with 2.8
days suitable for field work.

Corn emergence is at 98 percent compared to 87 percent last year and 96 percent
for the five-year average. The average corn height of the Illinois corn crop is
well above last year's height and the five-year average, at 28 inches.

At this time last year 71 percent of the soybean crop was in the ground, and
this year, 91 percent of the bean crop was planted, according the Illinois
Agriculture Association news service.  81 percent of the soybean crop has
emerged compared to last year's emergence of 45 percent.

The first cutting of Alfalfa last week was at 77 percent compared to 76 percent
the week before and 59 percent at the same time last year. The second cutting of
alfalfa last week was at 10 percent compared to 5 percent the week before and 8
percent last year.

Red clover saw a 60 percent cutting last week compared to 52 percent the week
before and 45 percent last year.

To see more of The Telegraph or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.thetelegraph.com/. Copyright (c) 2010, The Telegraph, Alton, Ill.

tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call 800-374-7985 or 847-635-6550, send a fax
to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave.,
Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                             613 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                   May 9, 1995, Tuesday, Late Edition - Final

FUTURES MARKETS;
Wheat and Corn Prices Increase As Rain Hurts Spring Planting

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

SECTION: Section D;  Page 20;  Column 1;  Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 395 words


Wheat and corn prices rose strongly yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade as
rain further hampered spring wheat planting in the northern Plains and corn
sowing in the Midwest.

Livestock and soybeans led other commodity prices lower. The Commodity Research
Bureau's index of 21 commodities fell 0.89 point, to 232.62.

Wheat for May delivery rose 5 cents, to $3.575 a bushel.

Unless the weather turns substantially drier soon in the key spring wheat states
of Minnesota and North Dakota, farmers there will have to consider planting
soybeans, sunflowers or canola instead, analysts said.

"They have one and a half to two weeks left before they're going to have to go
ahead and plant something else," said Bill Biedermann, research director for the
futures brokerage firm of Allendale Inc.

The spring wheat crop in the United States was 23 percent planted as of Sunday,
compared with the five-year average of 67 percent for that date, the Agriculture
Department said in a weekly report released after the close of trading
yesterday.

Rainy forecasts threaten further delays for the crop, which is off to its
slowest start since 1979.

Spring wheat, which generally accounts for about one-third of American wheat
production, is a hard variety used mainly for bread. It is normally planted in
early spring and harvested in late summer or early autumn.

Late-planted spring wheat is subject to a double weather threat. If sown later
than May, the plants go through their vulnerable head-forming stage in July and
August, when excessive heat can harm them. The same plants then face a frost
threat as they mature in September and October.

Corn planting was 20 percent complete Sunday, compared with the norm of 43
percent, the Agriculture Department said. May corn rose 2.5 cents, to $2.5225 a
bushel.

Soybeans can be sown on Midwestern acres too wet for timely corn planting. The
prospect of increased soybean production helped push May soybean futures down
4.75 cents yesterday, to $5.5875 a bushel.

Livestock futures fell sharply on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, reflecting
abundant supplies of market-ready cattle and hogs.

Live cattle for June delivery plunged 1.5 cents, the permitted daily limit, to
59.25 cents a pound; May feeder cattle also fell 1.5 cents, to 63.10 cents a
pound, and June live hogs sank 1.17 cents, to 40.05 cents a pound.

LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1995

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1995 The New York Times Company


                             614 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                    The Carroll News (Hillsville, Virginia)

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                           February 23, 2016 Tuesday

Morgan to be sentenced as USDA takes action

BYLINE: Allen Worrell, The Carroll News, Hillsville, Va.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 686 words


Feb. 23--With a federal sentencing hearing still pending against a former
employee of the company, the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) has
filed an administrative action under the Perishable Agricultural Commodities Act
(PACA) against Andrews Farming, Inc. of Hillsville.

According to the USDA, the Hillsville company allegedly failed to make payment
to 11 produce sellers in the amount of $513,226 from December 2014 through June
2015.

"Andrews Farming Inc. will have an opportunity to request a hearing. Should USDA
find that the company committed repeated and flagrant violations, it would be
barred from the produce industry for two years," the USDA said in a press
release dated Feb. 9. "Furthermore, its principals could not be employed by or
affiliated with any PACA licensee for one year and then only with the posting of
a USDA-approved surety bond."

The USDA measure takes place at the same time a former accountant and bookkeeper
of the company, Robert Donald Morgan III, awaits a sentencing hearing on March 2
at 10:30 a.m. in Abingdon before Judge James Jones. According to Brian McGinn,
Public Affairs Specialist with the U.S. Attorney's Office of the Western
District of Virginia, Morgan pled guilty to one count of bank fraud and one
count of willfully failing to collect, account for or pay taxes in September
2015.

At the time charges were filed against Morgan in April of 2015, an article from
The Associated Press stated that an affidavit filed by a U.S. Secret Service
agent claimed Morgan stole more than $66,000 from Andrews Farming Inc., which is
located in the Carroll County Industrial Park in Hillsville.

"The affidavit says Morgan forged the company president's name of business
checks he made out to himself," the 2015 AP article stated. "He also allegedly
deposited a check from the company's insurance carrier into his personal
account."

The investigation of the case was conducted by the United States Secret Service,
the Virginia State Police, the Carroll County Sheriff's Office and the United
States Marshals Service.

Keith Andrews, owner and CEO of Andrews Farming Inc. and its sister company,
ANDCO Logistics, Inc., declined to comment when contacted for this article. Both
companies joined Carroll County officials Oct. 21, 2014 in announcing a plan to
invest more than $5.6 million to expand their agricultural production,
warehousing and distribution operation in Carroll County. The Virginia Economic
Development Partnership worked with Carroll County, the Carroll County
Industrial Development Authority, and Virginia's aCorridor to help secure the
project for Virginia. The Virginia Tobacco Indemnification and Community
Revitalization Commission approved $225,000 in Tobacco Region Opportunity Funds
for the project.

As part of the performance agreement with the Tobacco Commission and the Carroll
County IDA, Andrews Farming and ANDCO Logistics moved their operations to the
Carroll County Industrial Park in Hillsville. According to the agreement, the
space is leased by the Carroll County IDA to Virginia Produce and subleased to
Andrews Farming until April 30, 2018. Carroll County holds collateral, according
to the performance agreement, of $266,494 from the company in the event the
$225,000 Tobacco Commission funds cannot be repaid.

The Agricultural Marketing Service (AMS), PACA Division, regulates fair trading
practices of produce companies operating subject to PACA, which includes buyers,
sellers, commission merchants, dealers, and brokers within the fruit and
vegetable industry. All oversight of actions related to PACA are conducted by
AMS, an agency within USDA. PACA establishes a code of good business conduct for
the produce industry. Under it, all interstate traders in fresh and frozen
fruits and vegetables must be licensed by USDA. USDA is authorized to suspend or
revoke a trader's license for violating the act.

Allen Worrell can be reached at (276) 779-4062 or on Twitter@AWorrellTCN

___ (c)2016 The Carroll News (Hillsville, Va.) Visit The Carroll News
(Hillsville, Va.) at www.thecarrollnews.com Distributed by Tribune Content
Agency, LLC.

LOAD-DATE: February 25, 2016

JOURNAL-CODE: 1HV

                             615 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                          The Business Times Singapore

Are the EPA's GM standards good enough?

                             July 31, 2003 Thursday

Harish Mehta


IT SEEMS that not everything is going the way of Monsanto, the giant US gene
corporation. The company asked the United States Environmental Protection Agency
(EPA) to approve its new pesticide, Bacillus Thuringiensis (Cry3Bb1), and an
accompanying genetically modified (GM) material.

These are intended to control the corn rootworm, a pest that attacks corn crops,
and promises bumper harvests to farmers all over the world. The EPA said in
April that it had completed a thorough study of the pesticide and, in general,
found it was not hazardous. But the same EPA report has raised serious
questions, and asked Monsanto to clarify them. Chiefly, these are: Monsanto has
not provided sufficient data on how the pesticide would affect bird life. The
EPA has asked it to conduct detailed tests on birds, on the pirate bug, a ground
beetle, and a redweed beetle. Further, Monsanto has been asked to conduct tests
to determine the long-range effects on the ecosystem and the soil.

Tests on birds and beetles could be done very quickly but, given the EPA's
caution, the tests on the general ecosystem should take decades. Yet Monsanto's
product is likely to be on the market within months, just as its earlier
products have won approval, thus rendering the entire ecosystem study of mere
academic interest. Monsanto, after all, enjoys the solid backing of the United
States Department of Agriculture (USDA), which participated in major
agricultural studies with the company, both of whom have a solid financial
interest in establishing American domination over world agriculture. Between May
1995 and February 2003, the EPA approved nine GM pesticides for use in the US,
and for export.

What's happening in the US is of global concern because the US produces most of
the GM products. It is a small mercy that the EPA continues raising concerns
over health issues. For instance, the movement of genes from the host plant into
other plants has been a cause for concern. GM cotton is capable of transferring
genes. Known as gene flow, cross-pollination of wildly growing relatives of
cotton can disrupt a local ecosystem by changing the make-up of local plants,
crowding out related species, and changing the local habitat.

Less risk of cross-pollination exists in the US than in tropical countries where
the relatives of most of these crops are found. In the case of GM Bacillus
Thuringiensis (Bt cotton), where the potential for gene flow did exist, the EPA
restricted the planting of this crop in order to reduce the risk. That was a
small victory for those who fear the effects of GM crops. Dr Anne Fairbrother,
an internationally known ecologist, asks: What if those genes escape? Will they
cause unintended ecological effects, or be harmless once outside of the
agricultural system?

In another move, the EPA has banned Bt cotton, which easily passes to Gossypium
Tomentosum, a type of wild cotton growing in Hawaii. The EPA order says: Test
plots or breeding nurseries in Hawaii must be surrounded by 12 border rows of
non-Bt cotton if the plot is less than 10 acres, or 24 border rows if the plot
is over 10 acres, and must not be planted within a quarter-mile of Gossypium
Tomentosum. The idea of fencing off GM crops from others is most welcome.

The EPA has evaluated the danger of gene transfer to the soil, particularly to
bacteria inhabiting the soil, and has found it to be a cause for concern. What
is of even greater worry is that many of these potentially dangerous products
will enter the market even before the EPA has completed its own studies. One
such study into the potential for the GM crops to breed with related crops that
are found near them will be ready by 2005. A second area of study is the
potential environmental effect of GM crops containing insecticidal toxins. These
protein toxins are genetic additions to the plants which have been incorporated
to protect against specific insect pests. Yet another EPA study to measure the
risk of unintended and unexpected adverse impact on organisms and ecosystems
will be ready by 2008.

The EPA regulates GM pesticides under two laws: the Federal Insecticide,
Fungicide and Rodenticide Act (FIFRA), and the Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetics
Act. Before a pesticide can be marketed and used in the US, FIFRA requires that
EPA evaluate the proposed pesticide thoroughly to ensure that the pesticide will
not pose unreasonable risks of harm to human health or the environment. The
question is: Are these risk evaluations good enough for the rest of the world?

Harish Mehta, a writer based in Toronto, contributed this article to BT

SECTION: VIEWS AND OPINIONS; The Bottomline

LENGTH: 769 words

LOAD-DATE: July 30, 2003

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                Copyright 2003 Singapore Press Holdings Limited

Harish Mehta, a writer based in Toronto, contributed this article to BT

                             617 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                          Sunday Times (South Africa)

                                November 3, 2002

Aim is to become a leader in Africa

BYLINE: Eamonn Ryan

SECTION: Economy, Business & Finance; Pg. 16

LENGTH: 772 words


NEW HORIZONS: African growth has paid off, says Louis Wolthers

Aim is to become a leader in Africa

Group wants to acquire cotton and grain businesses throughout continent, writes

AFGRI expects its African operations - comprising cotton farms and gins in
Zambia and Uganda and a grain business in Zambia - to make a sizeable
contribution to group earnings over the next few years.

Afgri managing director Jeff Wright recently outlined the group's intent to
become the leading agri-services group within Africa.

Afgri is on the lookout for new acquisitions throughout the region to expand
itscotton and grain businesses. These will serve as platforms for the expansion
into Africa of other group services, such as financing and scientific
agricultural services.

Afgri Products is the group's main vehicle for expansion into Africa. Through
its subsidiary Clark Cotton, it is involved in commodity trading in Zambia, and
cotton production and ginning in Zambia, Swaziland and Uganda.

Clark Cotton recently acquired a cotton gin in Uganda to serve the East African
and Indian markets, adding to its existing two gins in Zambia.

Nearly one-third of Clark Cotton's earnings are now generated in Zambia and
Uganda, but new acquisitions under consideration in countries such as Malawi
should swell this figure.

The Zambian cotton gins have a combined capacity of 240000 bales (1 bale >
200kg) against Uganda's 120000-bale capacity. The Zambian gins are operating at
full production, with virtually all output destined for South Africa.

Afgri Products managing director Louis Wolthers says the international cotton
market is depressed. "The US offers huge subsidies for cotton production, with
the result that there is a massive surplus and prices are at a 30-year low. SA
cotton producers have halved their production this year and shifted to more
profitable crops such as maize."

The result is a huge shortage of cotton in SA. But there is also a big
opportunity, due largely to the Africa Growth and Opportunity Act (Agoa), which
grants clothing made in Africa duty-free access to the US market, says Trevor
Wilkinson, managing director of Clark Cotton.

"We are able to sell all that we produce, so it is a question of getting our
gins up to full capacity, and acquiring additional capacity where we can."

To benefit from the Act the cotton has to be African, says Wolthers.

Clark Cotton is scouting neighbouring countries for additional gin capacity.
"Wesee potential to expand into Malawi, Mozambique and East Africa," says
Wilkinson. "In fact, we'd consider virtually anywhere in sub-Saharan Africa as
apotential target for expansion."

Clark Cotton supplies about one-third of SA's cotton needs.

International cotton prices have recovered from US40c/lb to about 50c/lb.
Because production costs are measured in local currencies and selling prices in
hard currencies, cotton producers have enjoyed a welcome increase in margins.

"Our growth in Africa has compensated for the drop in SA production," says
Wolthers.

In the past financial year, Afgri Products established a grain handling,
grading, storage, marketing and trading operation in Zambia. The 35000 tons
handled by the Zambian business over the past year represents a small
percentageof the two million tons handled by the SA business, but there is
plenty of scopefor growth in Zambia, says Wolthers.

"We made good profits from the Zambian business over the last year, and we
expect this to grow. The Zambian business is really a smaller version of what
weoffer farmers and millers in SA."

Traditionally, Zambian commercial farmers sold their maize and wheat direct to
millers.

"What we are able to offer both farmers and millers are value-added services
such as financing, storage and trading - services not generally available in
Zambia," says Wolthers.

"We are also starting to target subsistence farmers, most of whom have little
access to financing and the other services we can offer."

Afgri Products plans to expand its grain business into countries such as
Malawi,the Democratic Republic of Congo and Mozambique, and leverage the
infrastructureand market presence of Clark Cotton in Uganda and Zambia.

Afgri Products has already handled large export volumes to countries such as
Zambia, Zimbabwe and Malawi, where widescale food shortages have been reported.

"We have a lot of experience of exporting grain into Africa and we're familiar
with conditions," says Wolthers. "This makes it easier to take the next step,
which is to set up business units within some of these countries."


LOAD-DATE: November 6, 2002

                             618 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                            Waikato Times (Hamilton)

                             July 6, 1999, Tuesday

Better times ahead for farmers: forecasters

SECTION: FARMING Pg. 14

LENGTH: 419 words


Beef cattle and sheep farmers can look forward to better times, economic
forecasters says.

Chris Ward, of the Agriculture and Forestry Ministry's (Maf) policy unit, told
farmers at the Southern North Island Sheep and Beef Cattle Conference in
Palmerston North last that greater involvement of women in farming, community
solidarity, better management through adverse climatic events, better
communication and more labour-saving devices were some of the positive
influences in agriculture.

He said farmers could expect increases in gross farm revenue during the next few
years, an increase in farm cash surpluses, and an increase in expenditure.

Ministry forecaster Rod Forbes said some of the positives for the beef industry
included a falling US beef inventory and rising beef consumption in Japan and
Korea.

But a negative factor was the public's strong preference for poultry.

The contraction of the pig and sheep industries in Britain was positive for
lamb. But the ongoing Russian financial crisis and the uncertainty over the US
tariff would not help the industry.

Agresearch (Ruakura) general manager Warren Parker said farmers needed to change
to stay ahead.

He said that sometimes meant making a complete break, and getting rid of old
ideas.

Change was stressful, and people tended to oppose it for that reason.

Some change was not always successful, but developing strategies for change
helped.

Mr Parker said possible motives for change included increasing competition, more
demanding consumers, and more information.

Tony Rhodes, from Agriculture New Zealand, said some clients felt maintaining
what they were achieving was now not enough.

He said there were people achieving their maximum potential production figures,
and he challenged farmers to try to do likewise. The trick was how to make it
happen.

Mr Rhodes said farmers should clearly define their own and their families' needs
during the next five years, and come up with a realistic assessment of their
potential.

He said they should focus on what was important for them and no one else.

Farming was in a very significant period of change, and 30 per cent of land
titles would change hands at least once in the next five years, Mr Rhodes told
farmers.

"What role do you plan to take as those deals are brokered?"

To realise their potential, they needed to define needs, quantify resources,
identify opportunities and integrate options that worked. -- NZPA

Supplied by New Zealand Press Association

                             619 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                 June 29, 2002 Saturday Five Star Lift Edition

FARMERS ARE PLANTING MORE BIOTECH CROPS

BYLINE: Virginia Baldwin Gilbert Of The Post-Dispatch

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 281 words


The number of U.S. acres planted in corn is up, while the number of acres in
soybeans and cotton declined, according to the Agriculture Department's annual
planting survey. Farmers planted more biotech varieties of all three crops, the
survey found.

Corn is the No. 1 crop in the United States, with 78.9 million acres planted, a
4 percent increase over last year. Farmers chose biotech varieties for 34
percent of the corn acreage, up from 26 percent last year, the survey said.

While total acreage for soybeans is down, to 72.9 million acres from 74.1
million last year, the number of acres planted in biotech soybeans is up, to
nearly 55 million acres, compared to more than 50 million last year.

Wheat farmers increased acreage to 60.1 million, up 1 percent, making it the
third-largest U.S. crop. No biotech wheat is grown commercially.

Cotton acreage is down nearly 9 percent - to 14.4 million acres, from 15.7
million acres. But the percentage of biotech acreage increased to 71 percent of
the total from 69 percent.

"We deduce that farmers continue to see significant value in biotech," said
Kerry Preete, Monsanto Co.'s vice president for U.S. markets.

Monsanto seed or seed with licensed Monsanto traits accounted for the majority
of corn genetically engineered to tolerate herbicide or to resist insects, all
of the herbicide-tolerant soybeans, all of the insect-resistant cotton and
nearly all the herbicide-tolerant cotton, Preete said.

Preete noted that farmers planted more herbicide-tolerant corn, even though it
has not been approved for sale in Europe. The lack of European approval "is not
as significant a barrier as it was projected to be," he said.

                               The New York Times

               March 30, 1985, Saturday, Late City Final Edition

FUTURES/OPTIONS ;
Corn Rises on Report Of Russian Purchases



BYLINE:
By The Associated Press

SECTION: Section 1; Page 39, Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 294 words


Corn and wheat futures prices, supported by a weakened dollar and new Soviet
corn purchases, were mostly higher yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.
Volume was light.

Corn prices were supported by the Agriculture Department's announcement after
trading Thursday that the Soviet Union had purchased 200,000 metric tons of
United States corn. Corn for delivery in May rose yesterday to $2.82, the
contract's high since early December.

At the close, the Agriculture Department announced an additional 500,000 tons of
corn had been sold to the Russians.

Despite the stronger foreign currencies, soybean prices were mostly lower. A
less expensive dollar makes United States farm products more desirable to
foreign buyers.

''There was no news to justify the selloff, but traders tend to even up their
positions prior to a weekend,'' said Susan Hackmann, a grains analyst with
Pershing Futures, concerning the activity in soybeans.

Live cattle prices were mixed to mostly higher while feeder cattle, live hogs
and frozen pork bellies were mostly lower on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

Cash prices influenced the futures, according to Bob Kuhn, a livestock analyst
in Chicago with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.

Live cattle futures were raised by higher cash markets while prices for feeder
cattle, live hogs and frozen pork bellies were above the cash price.

Crude oil and heating oil prices were mostly lower on the New York Mercantile
Exchange.

Warmer than normal weather softened heating oil prices, according to Andrew
Lebow, a petroleum analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers.

The contract for delivery in April went off the board 0.65 cent higher because
of higher cash prices, he said.

Crude oil trading was quiet and choppy, analysts said.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                             621 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                         Telegraph Herald (Dubuque, IA)

                            February 21, 2005 Monday

Cattleman seeks world marketplace; Fears of mad cow disease stifle exports

BYLINE: JOHN EVERLY

SECTION: Opinion; Pg. a3

LENGTH: 574 words

DATELINE: DODGEVILLE, Wis.


The head of a national cattle industry group said Friday the United States needs
to re-enter the world beef export market as soon as possible.

"The quicker we get back to normalcy, that will alleviate part of this (price)
volatility," said Jim McAdams, president of the National Cattlemen's Beef
Association.

Canada Beef

In January, the National Cattlemen's Beef Association sent a team to Canada to
get a firsthand account of Canada's beef production. The key findings include:

* No burdensome backlog of cattle in Canadian feedlots. Prices for cattle older
than 30 months are severely discounted, and there is no market incentive to
manage cattle beyond that age.

* Slaughter capacity increased 22 percent in Canada in 2004.

* The Canadian feed industry appears to be in compliance with its feed ban. The
Canadian government is expected to release a study addressing recent media
reports about animal protein in animal feed.

Source: National Cattlemen's Beef Association, www.beefusa.org

The Texas cattleman spoke about industry issues at the Wisconsin Cattlemen's
Association Winter Conference in Dodgeville. He spent much of the time answering
reporters' questions about how the return of Canadian cattle to the United
States will affect American producers.

Live Canadian cattle imports were banned from the United States after a case of
BSE, or mad cow disease, was discovered in Canada in May 2003.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture announced in December it would allow imports
of live Canadian cattle younger than 30 months beginning March 7. This month,
however, the department delayed allowing import of meat from animals 30 months
of age and older.

While the National Cattlemen's Beef Association urged the department to keep
that ban, McAdams said new research by the group might alleviate some fears.

A National Cattlemen's Beef Association fact-finding team was sent to Canada
last month and unveiled its findings earlier this month.

"The challenge we have now is getting the true facts out to the cattlemen of
this country," McAdams said. "When the people have seen what we have pulled
together in addition to what USDA is saying, I think it adds to the comfort
level."

American and Canadian feed manufacturers are banned from using rendered cattle
in cattle feed. The practice is believed to have contributed to mad cow
outbreaks in Europe during the 1980s and 1990s. The cattlemen's group found the
Canadian feed industry appears to be in compliance with its feed ban.

The team also found Canadian slaughter capacity increased last year, making a
glut of Canadian cattle in the United States less likely.

"I think the overwhelming body of evidence is indicating that the market impact,
from a fundamental standpoint, will not be that great," he said.

Four cases of BSE have been confirmed in Canada. A dairy cow of Canadian origin
was diagnosed with the disease in Washington state in December 2003. Since then,
the United States has been shut out of most export markets, including the
nation's top beef customer, Japan.

"I'm convinced that we're doing everything we can to get that market open,"
McAdams said.

At the same time, he said Mexico appears poised to accept more American beef.

"As we open up more products from Canada they will open up more products from
the United States. Apparently, we're only shipping 50 to 60 percent of what we
were. That's a huge opportunity," McAdams said.

              The Lake Metigoshe Mirror (Bottineau, North Dakota)

                      express, written consent from STPNS

                                 April 9, 2014

USDA sets loan payment rates for commodities

BYLINE: The Lake Metigoshe Mirror staff

LENGTH: 506  words


The U.S. Department of Agriculture's (USDA) Farm Service Agency (FSA) will begin
accepting requests for marketing assistance loans (MALs) and loan deficiency
payments (LDPs) for eligible 2014 commodities. Notice of the authorization is
published in today's Federal Register.

MALs and LDPs for the 2014 crop year become available to eligible producers
beginning with harvest/shearing season and extending through a specific
commodity's final loan availability date.

Sugar commodity loans for 2014 crop will be available to sugar processors
beginning October 1, 2014.

MALs and LDPs provide financing and marketing assistance for wheat, feed grains,
soybeans and other oilseeds, pulse crops, rice, peanuts, cotton, wool, mohair
and honey. MALs provide producers interim financing after harvest to help them
meet cash flow needs without having to sell their commodities when market prices
are typically at harvest-time lows. Allowing farmers to store their products at
harvest facilitates a more orderly marketing of commodities throughout the year.
A producer who is eligible to obtain a loan, but agrees to forgo the loan, may
obtain an LDP if such a payment is available.

Marketing loan provisions and LDPs are not available for sugar and extra-long
staple cotton.

The 2014 Farm Bill also establishes payment limitations per individual or entity
not to exceed $125,000 annually on certain commodities for the following program
benefits: price loss coverage payments, agriculture risk coverage payments,
marketing loan gains (MLGs) and LDPs. These payment limitations do not apply to
MAL loan disbursements. Please consult your local FSA office for details.

Adjusted Gross Income (AGI) provisions were modified by the 2014 Farm Bill,
which states that a producer whose total applicable three-year average AGI
exceeds

$900,000 is not eligible to receive an MLG or LDP.

The 2014 Farm Bill establishes national loan rates for the 2014 crops of wheat,
feed grains, oilseeds, pulse crops, milled rice, peanuts, extra-long staple
cotton, wool, mohair, sugar and honey. The 2014 Farm Bill requires the upland
cotton base quality loan rate to be determined annually according to the
applicable statutory provisions. The 2014 crop loan rates are seen in the
accompanying chart.

County loan rates also are announced for the 2014 crops of wheat, corn, grain
sorghum, barley, oats, soybeans and other oilseeds (sunflower seed, flaxseed,
canola, rapeseed, safflower, mustard seed, crambe and sesame seed); national
milled rice loan rates by class and state rough rice loan rates by class for the
2014 rice crop; and regional loan rates for 2014 pulse crops (dry peas and
lentils). The rates are posted on the FSA website at
www.fsa.usda.gov/price-support.

Later announcements will include peanut loan rates by type, refined beet sugar
loan rates by region, raw cane sugar loan rates by state, and the schedule of
premiums, discounts and other related information.

For more information, please visit a nearby USDA Service Center or FSA's website
www.fsa.usda.gov.

                 Stone County Enterprise (Wiggins, Mississippi)

  This content, including derivations, may not be stored or distributed in any
  manner, disseminated, published, broadcast, rewritten or reproduced without
                      express, written consent from STPNS

                                 July 16, 2014

More acres planted in states major row crops than in 2013

BYLINE: Stone County Enterprise staff

LENGTH: 666  words


Mississippi producers planted more of the state's major row crops than they
planned in March, and the majority of them are in good condition.

Every winter, Mississippi producers estimate how many acres they will plant of
each crop they intend to grow. The U.S. Department of Agriculture tabulates
these in March and issues the planting intentions report. On June 30, USDA
released actual planted acre figures for the state. Mississippi has 2.25 million
acres of soybeans, up 12 percent from 2013 acreage and up 100,000 acres from
March intentions. The state has 400,000 acres of cotton, up 38 percent from 2013
and up 20,000 acres from the earlier estimate. Growers planted 170,000 acres of
rice for 2014, up 36 percent from last year and unchanged from March planting
intentions. Corn was the only major crop to drop acreage from what was expected
in March. The state has 540,000 acres of corn, down 37 percent from 2013 and
down 40,000 acres from March intentions.

Brian Williams, agricultural economist with the Mississippi State University
Extension Service, said most of the state's major crops set yield records over
the last few years with favorable growing conditions. This encouraged producers
to keep acreage high. "I think the record yields along with favorable markets
this spring encouraged producers to plant even more acres of soybeans and cotton
this year," Williams said. "Although prices have come down since planting, it
could still be a very good year for many producers." Williams said those acreage
increases have come at the expense of other crops. "For example, Mississippi
corn acreage was reduced by 40,000 acres from March estimates and hay was
reduced by 110,000 acres," he said. USDA makes planted acreage estimates by
surveying approximately 11,000 parcels of land nationally, each consisting of
about 1 square mile. These producers are asked about planted acres on that
parcel of land, and results are used to calculate total acreage numbers. John
Michael Riley, Extension agricultural economist, said crop rotation is partially
responsible for corn's drop in acreage and soybean's increase. "U.S. producers,
primarily those in the Corn Belt, spent three straight years heavily invested in
corn and devoted a large amount of acres to the crop largely without rotation,"
Riley said. "We saw a small shift away from corn and toward soybeans last year,
but this year f appears to be a more significant shift." While price was the
primary driver of this shift, Riley said the need for rotation played a role in
getting the record number of soybean acres planted.

Mississippi was not the only state to see increases in the major row crops.

"U.S. producers planted 3.35 million more acres of soybeans than was estimated
in the March planting intentions report, and producers in all but two states
increased their soybean acres from March intentions," Williams said. "If the
acreage numbers stand, this year's 84.84 million acres will be the largest U.S.
soybean acreage on record." U.S. wheat and cotton acres were also increased from
March, but corn acres were decreased by 50,000 acres nationally. The increased
acreage nationwide is driving prices down. "The record acres combined with very
positive crop condition reports released each Monday afternoon by the USDA have
taken their toll on soybean markets. Corn prices have also taken a hit, with
December corn losing 55 cents since the report's release, although for different
reasons," Williams said. More corn is stockpiled than previously expected, and
this has contributed to lower prices. Mississippi crops growing on these
increased acreages are overall in very good condition at this point in the
growing season. By July 6, USDA reported that 70 percent of corn, 71 percent of
cotton, 82 percent of rice and 70 percent of soybeans were in good to excellent
condition. Just 25 percent or less of each crop was in fair condition, with the
remaining acres in poor shape. No acres in the state were listed as very poor.

                      The Goldendale Sentinel (Washington)

  This content, including derivations, may not be stored or distributed in any
  manner, disseminated, published, broadcast, rewritten or reproduced without
                      express, written consent from STPNS

                               September 14, 2011

Symposium to present opportunities and challenges in dryland organic agriculture

BYLINE: The Goldendale Sentinel staff

LENGTH: 526  words


In association with the 2011 Washington Tilth Producers Conference, Washington
State University has organized a special, day-long symposium for those
interested in exploring the challenges and opportunities of organic agriculture
in dryland ecosystems. The symposium is slated for Nov. 11 at the Yakima
Convention Center.

The symposium addresses agronomic and economic issues specific to dryland
organic production and brings together speakers and attendees from Washington,
Oregon, Idaho, and Montana. The keynote speaker is Bob Quinn, an organic grain
farmer from Big Sandy, Montana and founder of Kamut International Khorasan
Wheat. Topics covered include building a growers' cooperative; finding new
market channels; the nuts and bolts of organic dryland farming; and how to build
a system that really works. "Agriculture in the Pacific Northwest's drylands is
at a crossroads," said sustainable agriculture researcher Lynne Carpenter-Boggs.
"Dryland farming in our region faces serious threats from erosion and loss of
soil organic matter. Farmers and industry professionals in dryland organic
agriculture want to farm sustainably, but they face unique challenges, including
low rainfall, short growing seasons, and cool evening temperatures that limit
productivity. Organic agriculture can address those concerns, but for these
systems to be economically sustainable, producers need consistent markets for
their products."

A series of speed networking sessions is also scheduled. These sessions will
bring together business professionals who trade or process organic products and
who are looking for producers who will understand the needs of specialty
markets. "We are expecting 80 to 100 producers to attend," said Carpenter-Boggs,
"so business people and producers will have plenty of opportunities to connect
and initiate mutually beneficial business relationships."

Carpenter-Boggs said that, despite the challenges, there is plenty' of good news
to share with growers and business owners. "Organic producers, researchers, and
early adopters are discovering what works in marketing organic crops, weed
management, soil conservation, control of pests and diseases, design of organic
agro-ecosystems, and conversion to organic farming."

"The time is right to develop sustainable agricultural systems for the special
needs of our region," Carpenter-Boggs said. "The conference will focus on
relevant topics using lectures and discussions so that information is
immediately incorporated into planning. This conference will establish a strong
communications network among producers, marketing organizations, processors,
researchers, and extension educators. University and USDA personnel will obtain
valuable input on how research and extension can better serve organic dryland
farmers."

More information on the symposium is available on the CSANR web site at
http://bit.ly/qlDYkW. Registration through the Washington Tilth Producers will
be available in early September. Check http://bit.ly/qKcNpm for more information
on the main Tilth Producers Conference Nov. 12 -13. Business people interested
in speed networking should register at http://bit.lv/roDMim.

                                The Toronto Star

                    January 5, 1988, Tuesday, FINAL EDITION

Farms lose $80 million in free trade Riddell says

BYLINE: By Bob Boughner Special to The Star

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A2

LENGTH: 348 words

DATELINE: RIDGETOWN, Ontario


   RIDGETOWN, Ont. - Ontario's fruit, vegetable and wheat farmers will lose more
than $80 million annually as a result of the Canada-United States free trade
agreement, Ontario Agriculture Minister Jack Riddell says.

"We have simply given away too much and received too little in return," he told
more than 300 southwestern Ontario farmers attending the official opening
yesterday of the 50th annual farmers week program.

Riddell said Ottawa also does not seem to be concerned about the potential
impact of the free trade deal on the giant food processing industry in
southwestern Ontario.

Ontario Premier David Peterson has raised many concerns about the undertaking,
he said, but "unfortunately, they have fallen on deaf ears.

"Prime Minister Mulroney has now signed a document without allowing a full
review of the agreement. And now we're expected to accept everything that's
dealt to us and adjust to a changed economic outlook - one which will alter the
agriculture and food industry for the next 100 years," Riddell said.

The minister said that under the agreement, which will eliminate tariffs over a
10-year period, Ontario's grape and wine industry will also be seriously
jeopardized. And he charged that what Mulroney and his negotiators have failed
to realize is that they're talking about the livelihood of thousands of Ontario
farmers and food processors.

"As it is, farming has been undergoing hard times across Canada. Economic
pressures have forced many farmers into bankruptcy and others into giving up
farming completely," he said.

"Now, with one quick stroke of a pen last Saturday, the federal government is
adding another element to the uncertainty and hardship facing Ontario farmers,"
he added.

Riddell made it clear he is not against an improved trading environment with
Canada's largest trading partner. But he added, "As far as I'm concerned, a
better trading environment should not be built by sacrificing the food
processors of Ontario or, for that matter, our energy future, our auto industry
and our sovereignty as a nation."

LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1999

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Photo Jack Riddell

                  Copyright 1988 Toronto Star Newspapers, Ltd.


                             626 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                             Herald Sun (Australia)

                             March 6, 2014 Thursday
                               HeraldSun Edition

Farmers should not have to defend their way of life

BYLINE: ED GANNON

SECTION: OPED; Pg. 31

LENGTH: 589  words


TWO visitors to our shores in the past week have been spreading the word on
farming. Both have different messages, both come from different angles. Yet both
attempt to do one thing - defend farming.

One was countering the growing view that farming is cruel and unnecessary, the
second that our quest for energy is harming farming.

First to Trent Loos, a livestock farmer from Nebraska, who a few years back
attended a People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals conference where he heard
a movie star declare that all farming must be banned.

That comment has led Mr Loos to travel the world as an "agriculture advocate" to
counter the messages spread by PETA and its misguided disciples. He now hosts a
radio show in the United States with a claimed audience of three million.

The basis of his message is that the rearing, then slaughter, of animals is
merely part of the cycle of life.

"Everything lives, everything dies and death with purpose gives full meaning to
life," he said.

"In agriculture we manage the life, we create the death so we can, in turn,
improve another living thing." It's a commonsense view, which counters the PETA
argument that concentrates solely on the death of an animal, and never on the
benefit it brings.

Unfortunately, it's the simplistic argument of PETA and its ilk that appears to
be winning the day.

Mr Loos bemoaned the fact that despite the range and power of information at our
fingertips nowadays, people have never been more misinformed about farming.

"We live in the information age and you have, on your hip or in your pocket,
access to more information than could have ever been imagined, and yet there is
a greater disconnect with not only food production, but the essentials of life
that everyone relies on," Mr Loos said.

He told of sitting next to a woman drinking a coffee on an aeroplane who said
she consumed only organic food because she didn't like chemicals.

"(I said to her) do you know what caffeine is? It's actually a pesticide that
the coffee plant produces to protect itself from insects," he said.

"And if you do not harvest coffee beans from the coffee plant, the coffee plant
will actually produce enough of this pesticide to kill itself.

"You can't be drinking copious amounts of caffeine and be telling me that
chemicals are bad." The other visitor is John Fenton, a farmer from Wyoming.

He is speaking in Melbourne tonight and Rosedale tomorrow on coal seam gas
fracking.

That is the process of breaking rocks underground to extract the gas trapped
within. It is of concern to many farmers who fear the process could affect
groundwater.

That view is shared by both Premier Denis Napthine and Deputy Premier Peter
Ryan, who have put the issue into the too-hard basket until after the election.

Mr Fenton has 24 gas wells on his property, from which he makes about $2000 each
a year.

Yet he hates them.

Mr Fenton is here to warn farmers to be wary of promises that fracking will
cause negligible environmental damage, if any.

"Yes, we make some money from it, but then came the smell and the odours and
people getting sick. Then the neighbour's water turned black. All the things
they said wouldn't happen were happening," he said.

Interestingly, these men are here as a report shows Australian farmers think
their advocacy groups are ineffective.

It may be time to rethink how farmers defend themselves. Perhaps Australian
farmers need some local champions such as Mr Loos and Mr Fenton to spread the
message that without food and water, we don't have life.ED GANNON IS EDITOR OF
THE WEEKLY TIMES

LOAD-DATE: March 5, 2014

                   The Star Phoenix (Saskatoon, Saskatchewan)

                           February 26, 2008 Tuesday
                                 Final Edition

Ritz's CWB preoccupation ignores farmers' problems

BYLINE: Joan L. Adams, The StarPhoenix

SECTION: FORUM; Pg. A6

LENGTH: 290  words


Agriculture Minister Gerry Ritz forever rants that our barley and wheat
producers are being denied free choice to market their grain.

However, as agriculture columnist Kevin Hursh points out, our producers have the
worst rail service in the world. An Australian grain company representative who
attended the Crop Production Week in Saskatoon said his company moves sugar from
Brazil and pulse crops from remote parts of India with fewer problems than grain
producers do from Western Canada.

Our producers are captive customers of the railways. We have reduced the number
of grain elevators and built large inland terminals -- at great cost to
producers in terms of time, hauling costs and convenience, with not one iota of
service improvements or lower freight rates.

Perhaps Ritz should concentrate less on the Canadian Wheat Board and more on
getting our grain to market. While the minister is investigating this
bottleneck, could he take a look at the price of fertilizer products? The price
of these products, which in many cases originate in Canada, are a lot cheaper in
the United States.

Furthermore, the price our beef producers receive is worse than it was during
the BSE era, while hog producers are losing at least $30 per animal they ship.
These producers always have had free market choice and we can all see when we
get to the meat counter at the stores that the producers are getting royally
screwed.

Our government so far has turned a blind eye and a deaf ear to the problems
facing our producers. Many hog producers who applied for money under a new
federal-provincial program have received word they qualify for little or none.
Soon we will have no one willing to provide Canadian consumers with safe, cheap
food.

Joan L. Adams

Alsask

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                             629 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                           September 17, 1993, Friday

State's interests remain divided over trade deal

BYLINE: By Ernest Holsendolph

SECTION: BUSINESS; Section H; Page 1

LENGTH: 475 words


The North American Free Trade Agreement to open trade among Mexico, Canada and
the United States has proven politically explosive and divisive for the White
House and the Georgia congressional delegation, and has produced strong views in
the state, especially among farming interests.

The peanut farmers, for instance, are loudly fearful that cheap Argentine
peanuts could wind up here through Mexico.

Georgia meat and chicken producers, on the other hand, favor it because a
prosperous Mexico could become a good customer.

"We will have winners and losers," said Agriculture Commissioner Tommy Irvin.
That prospect does not warm a politician's heart.

Irvin visted Mexico City to express personal concerns about some aspects of the
treaty, now pending on Capitol Hill.

Agricultural issues

"I let President Salinas know our concerns, as state commissioners of
agriculture," he said, "especially about the possibility that food treated with
chemicals now banned in the United States could come into the country."

Georgia farmers and others incur expenses conforming with environmental rules -
expenses that some overseas farmers may avoid and therefore be able to sell food
more cheaply here.

Many political lines have been blurred as the NAFTA debate unfolds.

For instance, Democratic Reps. John Lewis and Sanford Bishop, generally
supportive of the administration, oppose the treaty, and Sen. Sam Nunn
conceivably could vote with his President.

Many economic conservatives, like Republican Sen. Phil Gramm of Texas, are
speaking up for the administration on this issue.

Effect on Georgia

But overall, Georgians will be affected far less than many states by the opening
of Mexican borders, according to a paper by Jeffrey Humphreys, a University of
Georgia economist.

"The states that will be affected most significantly are those bordering
Mexico," Humphreys said, "as well as those with large manufacturing bases."

As for Georgia, he wrote:

"Over time, Mexican consumers will have more purchasing power because of NAFTA,
but initially Georgia companies that export basic commodities and capital goods
will benefit more than those that export consumer goods."

Giving credence to vigorous objections by organized labor leaders to NAFTA,
Humphreys said "labor-intensive manufacturing industries that use mostly
low-skilled workers" are especially vulnerable to low-wage competition in
Mexico.

The carpet industry is one area of manufacturing that should do well because it
has invested in new equipment and procedures to become low- cost, and therefore
globally competitive.

Despite the dangers and pitfalls, Georgia's aspirations to become a major-league
exporter around the world lead many politicians to favor liberal trade as
exemplified by NAFTA.

Ernest Holsendolph's column appears every Sunday, Wednesday and Friday.

LOAD-DATE: September 18, 1993

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH932610264

                    Copyright 1993 The Atlanta Constitution

                    Golden Valley News (Beach, North Dakota)

  This content, including derivations, may not be stored or distributed in any
  manner, disseminated, published, broadcast, rewritten or reproduced without
                      express, written consent from STPNS

                                January 17, 2013

Farmers Union: Farmers receive meager share

BYLINE: Golden Valley News staff

LENGTH: 306  words


The National Farmers Union (NFU) has released its latest farmer's share report
based on calculations derived from the monthly agriculture prices report
produced by the U.S. Department of Agriculture's National Agricultural
Statistics Service, and compared to price points of common grocery food items at
a local Washington D.C., Safeway supermarket.

"It's easy to forget the true value of our farmers and ranchers, who in some
cases are only making pennies to the dollar on their goods, while we're at our
local supermarket," said NFU President Roger Johnson. "Our farmer's share report
reflects the true value that our farmers and ranchers are receiving."

North Dakota Farmers Union President Woody Barth added, "These facts clearly
illustrate how little family farmers and ranchers actually receive out of the
food dollar. No one should blame farmers and ranchers for increased costs at the
grocery store."

According to USDA's Economic Research Service, farmers and ranchers only receive
15.8 cents of every food dollar spent by consumers outside the home in the
United States. Additionally, more than 80 cents of every food dollar is spent on
marketing, processing, wholesaling, distribution and retailing.

Among the more startling statistics noted in the December report:

- Dairy farmers received $ 1.81 for one gallon of fat free milk (retail
price:$4.19);

- Wheat farmers netted only 20 cents of the $3.59 retail price of a loaf of
bread; and

- Tomato growers received a mere 53 cents per pound (retail price: $3.28).

The report shows the consumer that prices may increase in the grocery store,
however the farmer is not necessarily receiving extra income, said Johnson. "It
is also a stark reminder that U.S. family farmers and ranchers need certainty
and Congress" inability to pass the 2012 Farm Bill directly will impact their
operations."

                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                           October 26, 2016 Wednesday
                                Ontario Edition

AGRICULTURE;
To feed a growing world, consider what farming isn't

BYLINE: FRANCO VACCARINO

SECTION: REPORT ON BUSINESS; Pg. B4

LENGTH: 651 words


President and vice-chancellor of the University of Guelph, which was awarded
$77-million this fall from the federal government for the Food From Thought
project, intended to find sustainable ways to feed a growing world population

Nine billion: That's roughly how many people are expected to populate the Earth
by midcentury. How will we feed our growing world without compromising the
planet's ecosystems?

The Canadian agricultural sector produces some of the finest crops and livestock
in the world.

Farmers have tried to lessen their environmental impact, but agriculture will
always consume resources.

About 30 per cent of the world's greenhouse gas emissions come from agriculture.
Farming is our largest source of water pollution through runoff of fertilizers
and pesticides. You might say that our agrifood system often bites the land that
feeds us. This week brings government ministers and officials from Canada, the
United States and Mexico to Niagara Falls, Ont., to discuss trade, development
and co-operation under the annual Tri-National Agricultural Accord.

The group will talk about continent-wide issues, but Canada's agricultural
sector has a wider opportunity to help feed the world.

Here are three agrifood opportunities that delegates at this week's meeting
ought to discuss, based on what farming is not.

Agriculture is not just about growing food. Certainly, farmers feed people and
entire cities. But our agricultural sector also drives economies and
communities.

Speaking this month at the Public Policy Forum's growth summit in Ottawa,
Dominic Barton, chair of the Advisory Council on Economic Growth, pointed to
agriculture as one of Canada's strengths.

Ontario alone is a food-processing powerhouse, with about 3,000 businesses in
the sector employing 100,000 people.

Nationally, the agrifood industry employs one in eight Canadians - 2.3 million
people. We are the fifth-largest agricultural exporter in the world. Production
and trade in the farming sector help pay for health, education and other social
services that we all rely on. The agricultural sector also ensures our rural
communities remain viable.

Agriculture isn't just tractors.

In a digital revolution in agriculture, more and more of our farm equipment will
consist of smart, data-driven machines. Robotic milking systems are already at
work in the dairy industry.

Drones and satellites monitor soil moisture to determine irrigation requirements
or optimum planting times. Farmers can use a smartphone app to identify insects
in their fields and predict and control pest infestations.

Imagine self-driving tractors that automatically plant, fertilize and irrigate
crops without wasting seed, nutrients or water.

In his recent talk, Mr. Barton called for Canada to capitalize on computing
power, connectedness and big data. Precision agriculture based on real-time
information technology will help us deliver and manage resources to produce food
and reduce our environmental footprint. Big data is the new farm nutrient.

Agriculture is not just about growing more food. The green revolution of the
mid-20th century was about making more food, especially for famine-threatened
parts of the developing world.

Today, we produce enough food to meet the dietary needs of our world population.
The United Nations estimates that there are about 2,850 dietary calories
available daily for every man, woman and child on the planet.

But we waste almost one-third of the food we make. And what is not wasted is
poorly shared.

It's not just the amount of food we produce that's important.

What will define this century is how we produce and distribute that food. We
need to recognize the contributions of the agricultural sector to our economy
and our way of life. We need to use information technology and big data to farm
smarter. And beyond the Tri-National Agricultural Accord, we need to find better
ways to share food for our growing world.

LOAD-DATE: October 26, 2016

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


 Copyright 2016 The Globe and Mail, a division of CTVglobemedia Publishing Inc.
                              All Rights Reserved

                               Right Vision News

                              May 16, 2014 Friday

Pakistan: U.S supports farmers grow off-season vegetables

LENGTH: 360  words

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD


ISLAMABAD, May 16 -- The United States, through its Agency for International
Development (USAID), showcased the results of Pakistani farmers using new
technology to grow high value off-season vegetables here at its Vegetable Fair
2014. Acting Mission Director for USAID Pakistan Nancy Estes underscored the
U.S. government's commitment to develop Pakistan's agricultural sector: "The
produce we see here today marks the introduction of greenhouse technology in
Pakistan on a large scale. USAID's goal is to help farmers establish 1,200 high
tunnels and to adopt modern farming practices. These initiatives will
significantly transform vegetable farming, increase yields, create more jobs,
and help farmers earn higher incomes," said U.S embassy statement here.

A large number of participants involved in the industry showcased Pakistani
grown fruits and vegetables as well as related products and services at the
fair. Vegetable Fair-2014 also connected farmers with packing specialists,
marketing experts and exporters, helping them integrate into the global economy.
USAID's Agribusiness Project, which organized the fair, works to improve produce
quality and value, increase agriculture productivity, and remove constraints to
agricultural production and marketing. Through the project, USAID also provides
quality high yield seed, toolkits, low and high greenhouse tunnels, and
technical assistance to Pakistani farmers. The tunnels enable farmers to produce
off-season vegetables, greatly increasing land productivity and profitability.
The United States, though USAID, boosts Pakistan's agricultural productivity by
introducing advanced farming technologies, services, and practices; building
irrigation infrastructure; and introducing improved water management practices.
Over the last 18 months, U.S assistance has helped create 9,000 new jobs in
Pakistan's agricultural sector and generate more than $60 million in new
Pakistani agriculture export orders

query with respect to this article or any other content requirement, please
contact Editor at htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

              September 12, 1996, Thursday, FIVE STAR LIFT Edition

HIGHER MILK PRICES PREDICTED

BYLINE: Jerri Stroud Of The Post-Dispatch Staff

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. 1C

LENGTH: 580 words


A gallon of milk could cost more than $ 3 by Christmas, but dairy farmers say
record-high milk prices won't make them rich.

"All the money is going into corn" to feed milk cows, said Ross Hemann, a dairy
farmer from New Douglas, Ill., about 45 miles northeast of the Arch.

High feed prices have prompted dairy farmers like Hemann to cut milk production.
Strong demand helped wholesale milk prices break a 7-year-old record in August.

Milk production is leveling off despite prices that are more than o ffsetting
higher feed costs, said Keith Collins, the U.S. Agriculture Department's chief
economist.

Consumers aren't seeing record prices in the dairy case yet. On Wednesday, a
gallon of plain-label 2 percent milk cost $ 2.69 at the Ladue Crossing Schnucks.
Schnucks brand 2 percent cost $ 2.85 a gallon, and store brand whole milk cost $
2.89.

"We don't believe (the higher farm price) has all been passed through," said
Bill Brooks, who analyzes farm statistics for Mid-America Dairymen Inc., a large
dairy cooperative in Springfield, Mo., that supplies several St. Louis-area
dairies.

Competition among supermarket chains can keep stores from passing along
wholesale price increases quickly. But most stores eventually raise prices
enough to cover a long-term increase in costs.

Brooks says retail prices could go up as much as 20 cents a gallon by the end of
the year. He expects farm prices to rise about 6 cents a gallon between now and
November. Farmers will see their milk checks peak around Christmas, but retail
milk prices may not fall until spring.

"The supply situation is critical all across the United States," said Don
Nicholson, an Agriculture Department official in Tulsa, Okla., who supervises
the milk market area that includes St. Louis. Dairies are shipping milk record
distances to meet extreme shortages in the South and Southeast, he said.

Brooks and other experts see little chance for a quick drop in the prices of
milk or of the grain that farmers feed their livestock. In a report Wednesday,
the Agriculture Department raised its estimate of the corn crop slightly and cut
its forecast for the soybean crop.

With the corn harvest just beginning, the department projects corn production at
8.80 billion bushels, up 19 percent from last year. Illinois farmers expect to
glean 1.4 billion bushels, up 23 percent from last year. The Missouri crop will
more than double to 317 million bushels.

Soybean production will rise 5 percent to 2.27 bushels nationwide. Missouri
farmers expect to harvest 142 million bushels, 9 percent more than last year. In
Illinois, farmers expect to harvest 364.5 million bushels, 2 percent less than
last year.

Both crops are vulnerable to an early frost. Wet weather this spring delayed
planting, and a cooler-than-normal summer has slowed crop development.

Meanwhile, Hemann is trying to stretch his feed supplies three more weeks. By
then, his corn should be ready to harvest.

He's been buying corn since February, when he ran out of the corn he raised last
year. He paid record-high prices this spring, then switched to wheat when he
harvested that crop in mid-summer.

Lately, Hemann has been trying to find farmers who still have some corn stored
on their farms, hoping to save a few pennies a bushel over the prices at local
elevators. Heavy usage and a short crop last year has cut supplies to a 20-year
low.

"You go where you can get it, and you pay the price," Hemann said.
