                             672 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                                The Toronto Star

                     December 31, 1998, Thursday, Edition 1

THE SPOILS OF DEPENDENCY

BYLINE: Joel Baglole

SECTION: BUSINESS

LENGTH: 770 words


Analysis


 Recent U.S. cold snap pinches our northern wallets

 Imports
 Imports of fruit keep on growing


 BUSINESS REPORTER
 Fruits and vegetables have got to be fresh. And in most of
 Canada, freshness requires importing from other countries. Our
 northern climate shortens the annual growing season to six
 months, seven tops, and heavy frost makes growing citrus fruits
 impossible.
 Slightly more than 80 per cent of Canada's fruit and vegetable
 imports come from the United States. The recent cold snap that
 destroyed 50 per cent of California's orange harvest and caused
 citrus fruit prices to double at Canadian retail outlets,
 highlights our country's dependence on the United States. And
 since the North American Free Trade Agreement was signed, our
 dependence on U.S. produce has increased.
 ''We are big-time importers,'' said Maribeth Fitts, a fruit and
 vegetable specialist with the Ontario Ministry of Agriculture,
 Food and Rural Affairs. ''We're particularly dependent on them
 (imports) in the winter months because we can't grow or store
 (fruits and vegetables).''
 In 1997, Canada imported $1 billion worth of fresh vegetables -
 excluding potatoes. Our fresh vegetable imports were more than
 triple the $240 million worth of vegetables Canada exported to
 other countries.
 Statistics on fruit show an even larger difference between
 imports and exports. Last year, Canada exported $102 million in
 fresh fruit while importing $835 million worth of fresh fruit -
 and $663 million of that was citrus fruit.
 Canada imports most of its citrus fruit from the southern United
 States. ''It has to be grown below the frost line, in places like
 southern California and Florida. Even Georgia is too far north to
 grow citrus (fruits),'' Fitts said.
 But Clarence Swanton, chair of the plant agriculture department
 at the University of Guelph, said Canadians aren't the only
 people who suffer when supplies are diminished.
 ''Sure, we suffer,'' he said. ''But no more than the rest of the
 U.S. People in Wisconsin are seeing their fruit prices go up as
 much as in Ontario.''
 Canada may import more fruits and vegetables than it exports, but
 our national horticulture industry is alive and kicking.
 According to Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada, Canada produced
 678,000 tonnes of fruit last year, with an estimated value of
 $440 million, and 19 per cent of the total horticulture sector.
 The main fruit products produced were apples, tender fruits such
 as peaches, pears, cherries, plums and apricots, and berries
 ranging from blueberries to strawberries.
 Also, Canada produced 2.1 million tonnes of vegetables, worth
 $1.1 billion, and 30 per cent of the horticulture sector. The
 main vegetables produced included tomatoes, corn, peas, beans,
 carrots, onions, cabbage and lettuce.
 These stats don't include potatoes, which was Canada's Number 1
 vegetable export to the United States last year, worth $93.9
 million. Our thriving potato industry has produced an interesting
 spin-off: Canada is now the world's second largest exporter of
 processed french fries, after the Netherlands.
 Fitts said advanced technology in cold storage and greenhouses is
 helping farmers extend the life of their horticulture products -
 both fruits and vegetables - during the winter.
 ''Storage techniques allow many farmers to preserve their crops
 and take them to stores every week during the winter months,''
 Fitts said. ''There are apples in cold storage now that will last
 until next June.''
 While Canada's horticulture industry rises and falls with the
 weather, statistics show that imports and exports of fruits and
 vegetables are growing.
 Canada's $1 billion in vegetable imports this year is a third
 more than the $671.7 million imported in 1990. Canada's current
 level of $835 million in imported fruit is substantially larger
 than the $652 million worth of fruit imported in 1990.
 Exports of vegetables, excluding potatoes, are up more than 450
 per cent - from $52.3 million in 1990 to last year's figure of
 $240 million in vegetable exports. Fresh fruit exports have risen
 from $68.7 million in 1990 to $102 million in 1997.
 John Vandenberg, a market development adviser of horticulture at
 Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada, said the North American Free
 Trade Agreement, which has lowered restrictive trade tariffs,
 accounts for the increase in bilateral horticulture trade with
 the United States.



LOAD-DATE: December 31, 1998

LANGUAGE: English

                  Copyright 1998 Toronto Star Newspapers, Ltd.


                             673 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                 June 1, 1994, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

FUTURES MARKETS;
Midwest Dry Spell Causes Rally in Corn and Soybeans

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

SECTION: Section D;  Page 13;  Column 1;  Financial Desk

LENGTH: 450 words


Dry weather in the Midwest touched off a rally in corn and soybean futures
prices yesterday that pulled other commodity prices upward, reviving inflation
fears. Precious metals, coffee, cocoa and crude oil all gained, while livestock
and meat futures ended mixed.

The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities rose 4.54 points, to
235.42. Many financial experts consider the index an early inflation indicator.

A similar broad-based commodities rally collapsed last week when rain fell in
the Midwest, where most of the country's corn and soybeans are grown.

David Rothberg, a commodities analyst at Friedberg Mercantile Group in Toronto,
said the roiling prices signaled an underlying strength in the market.

"This kind of volatility, this kind of itchiness, is typical of a bull market,"
he said.

Little Rainfall in Midwest

Most corn and soybean contracts rose their permitted daily limits on the Chicago
Board of Trade as traders returned from the long weekend to reports of little
rainfall in the Midwest and forecasts for mostly dry weather this week.

After the close of trading, the Agriculture Department reported 79 percent of
the corn crop was in good to excellent condition as of Sunday. Twenty percent
was fair and 1 percent poor.

Soybean planting was 78 percent complete as of Sunday, the Department of
Agriculture said in the weekly report.

Wheat for July delivery rose 9 1/2 cents, to $3.27 1/2 a bushel; July corn rose
the 12-cent limit, to $2.78 3/4 a bushel; July oats rose 4 3/4 cents, to $1.25
1/4 a bushel; July soybeans rose 27 cents, to $7.01 a bushel.

Inflation jitters drove precious metals higher on the Commodity Exchange in New
York. June gold rose $2.40, to $387.10 a troy ounce; July silver climbed 7.5
cents, to $5.55 a troy ounce.

On the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York, unroasted coffee beans for
July delivery surged 4.7 cents, to $1.26 a pound; July cocoa beans rose $52, to
$1,388 a ton.

Crude Oil Prices Rise

Refined products led crude oil higher on the New York Mercantile Exchange as the
June gasoline and heating oil contracts expired in typically volatile fashion.

Crude oil rose 28 cents, to $18.31 a barrel; June heating oil surged 1.33 cents,
to 49.71 cents a gallon; June unleaded gasoline climbed 1.09 cents, to 53.30
cents a gallon; July natural gas rose 7.5 cents, to $1.917 for 1,000 cubic feet.

In livestock trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, June live cattle rose
0.80 cent, to 66.27 cents a pound; August feeder cattle fell 0.65 cent, to 73.95
cents a pound; June live hogs rose 0.08 cent, to 47.60 cents a pound; July
frozen pork bellies fell 0.32 cent, to 41.50 cents a pound.



LOAD-DATE: June 1, 1994

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1994 The New York Times Company


                             674 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                         The Christian Science Monitor

                           February 17, 2015 Tuesday

Organic farming continues to rise across the globe;
2 million of the world's 1.5 billion farmers are now producing organically, with
nearly 80 percent based in developing countries. India boasts the most certified
organic producers, followed by Uganda and Mexico.

BYLINE: Kendra Nordin Staff writer

SECTION: World

LENGTH: 723 words


Across the decades of boom and bust that characterize agricultural history runs
a trend: the rise and recognition of organic farming worldwide.

According to the International Federation of Organic Agricultural Movements
(IFOAM), 2 million of the world's 1.5 billion farmers are now producing
organically, with nearly 80 percent based in developing countries. India boasts
the most certified organic producers, followed by Uganda and Mexico.

Currently 164 nations have certified organic farms, powering an industry worth
$63.9 billion. (In 2000, there were 86 countries with certified farms producing
$15.2 billion.) With this growth come opportunities for farmers to add value to
their products and access expanding markets.

While the 94 million acres of certified organic agricultural land constitutes
less than 1 percent of total global agricultural land, industry analysts call
the growth of organics significant, also noting that the certified numbers fail
to account for the vast numbers of small-scale farmers who use organic methods
by default.

"[There are] probably 500 million small family farms worldwide; most of those
are traditional farmers who farm primarily through organic principles," says
Andre Leu, president of IFOAM.

He adds that 200,000 organic farmers become newly certified each year. "In most
places there is still a dramatic loss [in the numbers] of farmers and ... where
we see growth is in the organic sector."

Farmers today, battling climate swings and plummeting farm incomes, are
essentially faced with four options: leave farming completely, obtain off-farm
income, expand and play the commodity game more efficiently, or find ways to add
value per unit of production, says Joel Gruver, a soil science professor at
Western Illinois University in Macomb.

"Basically, organic farming anywhere in the world - if you are certified - is
the one label that is most clearly defined," says Professor Gruver, the
university's director of organic research. "Each nation has its own rules in how
they define organic, but the general set of rules is very much the same," he
says. Organic methods eschew chemical additives and rely on such practices as
crop rotation to harness ecological processes that promote healthy soils and
fight disease, weeds, and pests.

For consumers, organic farming addresses a range of issues on which many feel
conventional farming falls short: environmental impact, pesticide residues, and
nutritional quality. It addresses concerns about energy consumption and climate
change, and even restores a social connection to the land that many feel
commodity farming has eroded.

In fact, consumer demand is the driving force behind the growth. In 2012 in the
United States and Europe, markets with a healthy appetite for organic goods,
there was a 10 percent year-on-year rise in sales.

"Organic farming is the fastest growing multi-product sector in the world," says
Mr. Leu. "[I]f you go into any store now, organic products are in every section.
Anything from dairy to [prepared foods] to body care products to organic
clothing.... And there is no other sector like that."

Organic farming does draw critics. Some question the consistency of its
accreditation and labeling system. There is debate over whether organics deliver
higher nutritional value, and concern that the certification process is too
costly to allow for financial success. And there is doubt over whether organic
methods can yield enough to feed an ever-growing population. Yet consumer
preference continues to grow.

"[T]here is more demand than supply," says Anna Lappé, author of "Diet for a Hot
Planet." Ms. Lappé also points out that less than 1 percent of agricultural
research funding now goes toward refining proven chemical-free farming methods.

Still, there have been considerable efforts to support organic farmers. A
growing number of nonprofits provide microloans. IFOAM publishes the principles
of organic farming on its website for those who want to practice it but can't
yet afford certification. Countries such as Denmark and Sweden have set goals
for organic agriculture. The US offers small grants and loans.

Commercial investment may gain momentum, too. Nature's Path, an organic cereal
manufacturer, recently bought 5,640 acres of farmland in Canada and northern
Montana in efforts to support organic family farmers there.

LOAD-DATE: February 17, 2015

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


              Copyright 2015 Christian Science Publishing Society
                              All Rights Reserved


                             675 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                           The Philadelphia Inquirer

                             October 1, 2006 Sunday

ACRES APART

BYLINE: Harold Brubaker, Inquirer Staff Writer

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. E01

LENGTH: 1000 words


The thousands of music fans who partied this weekend at the Farm Aid concert in
Camden raised as much as $1 million to promote the preservation of family farms.

When Farm Aid officials talk about "keeping family farmers on the land," they
imply that they are trying to save an endangered species. Yet, the reality is
that 95 percent of U.S. farms - excluding retirement and residential farms - are
owned and operated by families.

In recent years, Farm Aid organizers have added a twist to their mission: a
vision of family farms producing food for local consumers - which advocates call
the "good food movement."

"It began to dawn on us that food and farming were so closely linked that we
couldn't really separate them," Ted Quaday, Farm Aid program director said.

Farm Aid's evolution into an advocate for a direct connection between farmers
and consumers occurred over the last decade as a segment of the American public
became intensely interested in food: how it tastes and how it was produced -
especially with regard to farm animals.

What Farm Aid is reacting to is the 20th century's massive consolidation in
agriculture - which happened in step with other key sectors, such as banking and
energy. That consolidation eliminated more than two-thirds of American farms
since the 1930s as slaughterhouses, food processors and supermarkets grew and
gained economic leverage.

On the consumer side, demand for easier-to-prepare processed foods grew as women
entered the workforce, reducing the amount of time available to prepare meals.

The number of farms in the United States peaked at 6.8 million in the 1930s,
when 21 percent of the workforce was engaged in agriculture and Americans spent
about the same percentage of their disposable income on food.

Now, the United States Department of Agriculture counts 2.1 million farms -
though 10 percent account for 75 percent of production, and less than 2 percent
of Americans work in agriculture. Huge productivity gains that accompanied the
rise of industrial agriculture reduced the portion of income Americans spend on
food to 11.5 percent last year.

Seventy years of consolidation have created huge family-owned and
family-operated farms, such as Sheppard Farms Inc. in Cumberland County, N.J.,
owned by three brothers who employ 250 and raise 1,500 acres of peppers,
cucumbers, tomatoes and other fresh-market vegetables that are sold in
supermarkets locally and all over the country.

Despite the size of Sheppard Farms Inc., which has $8 million in annual sales,
Tom Sheppard does not hesitate when describing the operation. "We are a family
farm," with roots that go back more than 300 years, he said.

At the other end of the farming spectrum, George and Melanie DeVault cultivate
three acres of their 20-acre Pheasant Hill Farm in Lehigh County.

"We try to sell everything we grow as close to where it's grown as possible,"
George DeVault said. The DeVaults used to haul their fruits, vegetables and cut
flowers more than 50 miles to a market in Philadelphia. When a market opened in
Telford, 30 miles closer, they moved there. Now, they sell at a Sunday market in
Emmaus, which is only three miles away.

The DeVaults, who have other income, represent the kind of locally based farming
Farm Aid promotes, in DeVault's words: "producing food for people and selling it
directly so the farmer gets all the income from it."

Mainstream agricultural economists scoff at the idea that such a regional food
system can meet Americans' food needs.

"There's a good reason why we don't produce most of our own food," Jim Dunn of
Pennsylvania State University said. "Part of it is specialization, part of it
has to do with the seasons we have," which impose serious limits on production.

"We do what we're good at, and we let other people do what they are good at," he
said.

Brian Snyder, executive director of the Pennsylvania Association for Sustainable
Agriculture, said local or regional food systems might be the only way to feed
the world in the long run because heavily subsidized conventional agriculture is
input-intensive and damages the environment.

Besides, he said, industrial-farming advocates "ignore the technological
advances that allow for season extension, better utilization of marginal lands,
and intensive farming on a smaller scale."

Snyder's nonprofit in Milheim, Pa., which runs educational programs for farmers
and works to build markets, has received $17,500 in grants from Farm Aid since
2004.

Since 1985, Farm Aid has granted $93,500 in Pennsylvania, Quaday, the program
director, said. Almost half the money went to the nonprofit group FoodRoutes
Network, which promotes local food systems. The group has not made any grants in
New Jersey.

Farm Aid said it had raised more than $29 million since 1985 and had spent 84
percent of it on programs "to build and strengthen family-farm food production."

A big reason for the widespread perception that corporations dominate American
agriculture is the proliferation of production contracts in poultry and pork
production.

Under such contracts - which account for almost all poultry production and 60
percent of hog production - the farmers own the buildings and equipment, but not
the animals. The contractor owns the animals, supplies the feed, decides when
the animals go to market, and pays the farmer to raise them.

Some critics of industrial agriculture said this system took too much control
out of the hands of farmers.

Jim Brubaker, a Union County, Pa., farmer disagreed.

Brubaker and his two sons - with no hired help - farm 600 acres of corn and
soybeans, fatten 6,300 hogs at a time for a contractor that supplies Hatfield
Quality Meats, and produce a million kosher broilers a year.

"I don't consider myself to be a serf or a slave to the integrator," said
Brubaker, who had an independent hog operation until 1993, but switched because
of declining profit. "They can't exist without us. We can't exist without them."

Contact staff writer Harold Brubaker at 215-854-4651 or
hbrubaker@phillynews.com.

LOAD-DATE: October 1, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                  Copyright 2006 Philadelphia Newspapers, LLC
                              All Rights Reserved


                             676 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                           Aberdeen Press and Journal

                               February 28, 2000

End to trade war in sight
 Hopes are pinned on US-Euro talks

SECTION: Farming, Pg.18

LENGTH: 637 words


HOPES are high that a conclusion to the year-long beef trade war between the US
and Europe could be resolved next month.

Officials in Washington DC said the matter was entirely in the hands of the
European Commission, but they were hopeful that agreement could be reached by
the latest March 15 deadline.

Europe outlawed beef imports from the United States last April after it found
cancer-causing hormone residues in American beef imports that the US had
declared to be hormone-free.

The commission has banned the hormones found in the US beef - which had been
used to help cattle convert feed into beef for more than 16 years.

The discovery prompted a war of words between officials on both sides of the
Atlantic and the US, which had previously exported about 10,000tonnes of beef
annually to Europe, imposed import tariffs on various European goods, including
toothpaste and motorbikes, exported to the US.

Punitive

United Kingdom goods have been exempt from the punitive tariffs as the British
Government believes the US hormone-treated beef should have free access to the
European market - even though the hormones are banned in European beef
production.

Talks over the next fortnight between the US Department of Agriculture (USDA)
and European food-safety commissioner David Byrne could bring about an end to
the dispute.

A spokesman at the USDA said that discussions were ongoing.

He expressed US concerns over Europe's continued inability to enforce on its own
member states the rigid drug-testing controls that it was asking of the US.

He added: "We are still concerned that there is a vast black market in
veterinary drugs in the EU.

"We do not have that trouble because we allow our producers to use legal, safe
alternatives."

The spokesman said it appeared a satisfactory conclusion could be agreed in the
short-term, but there were other issues which could take some time to resolve.

Meanwhile, American officials did not expect US beef to hit European shores this
year.

Shayle Shagam, an economist with the USDA World Agricultural Outlook Board, told
the Agricultural Outlook Forum meeting in Arlington, Virginia, that he had built
no European figure into the US beef exports, which were expected to fall in
weight slightly, to 2.3billion pounds, this year.

Beef production in the US is forecast to hit 25.7billion pounds in 2000 - which
is a 3% fall on last year.

Cattle numbers are expected to fall from the record 14million head recorded last
year, and a sharp 8% decline in production is expected towards the end of the
year.

Beef imports are forecast to increase in weight, from 2.9billion pounds to
3billion pounds.

Officials expect New Zealand to increase its market share in the United States.
This move will undoubtedly take import pressure off the UK beef market.

US pig producers have, like those in the UK, been savaged by the collapse in
world pigmeat markets.

Mr Shagam said that there had been a blood-letting among producers in the last
year, with sow numbers in the United States now at their lowest level since
1965.

Farrowings are expected to fall 4% this year, with pigmeat production down in
weight to 18.6billion pounds.

This fall could well benefit United Kingdom producers, who could now see their
exports to the United States increasing from their current 8,000-tonne level.

Broiler

Pig prices in the US are expected to average about GBP 25 per cwt - a near-GBP
10 improvement on prices experienced last year.

Forecasters expect many US pig producers to return to profitability this year.

Wholesale broiler prices in the US are forecast to hit between 35-40p per pound
this year.

The US hopes to increase its market share in Russia, in Hong Kong, in China and
in the Baltic States - all of which are export markets for UK chicken producers.

LOAD-DATE: February 29, 2000

LANGUAGE: English

                   Copyright 2000 Aberdeen Press and Journal


                             677 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                               The Frontier Post

                           November 9, 2013 Saturday

48.6% Pakistan population food insecure: survey

SECTION: Vol. XXVII No. 748

LENGTH: 676  words


Pakistan overnment direly needs to adopt strategic approach to ensure food
security by taking demand, supply and production into account because 48.6%
population of the country is without access to sufficient food, according to a
survey conducted by media.

Food Security means a condition in which all people have access to adequate
nutritious and safe food. As the population of the country has grown to high
level, the food insecurity has been deepening with each passing day. The
availability of natural resources as compared to population need is reducing,
causing food insecurity. FATA has 67.7% food insecure population, Balochistan
61.2%, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa 56.2%. Food insecurity is also on the rise in rural
Sindh and some 63 % of its population (urban and rural) has suffered decline in
real wages and is forced to take cheaper food with less nutrient value.

In Pakistan, large family size is forced to expense 46 % of the family income on
food while the food expenditures in India are 35% and the United States 7%.
Malnutrition is a health problem in Pakistan and plays a substantial role in the
countrys elevated child morbidity and mortality.

There is need to bring agriculture reforms in the county by providing lucrative
crop subsidies, introducing agriculture farming, ending corporate farming and
providing easy loans to farmers. The government also needs to reduce inflation
rate, which is the major factor behind food insecurity. The corporate farming in
the country also adds to food insecurity, poverty and inflation.

Some Gulf countries have purchased lands in Pakistan, particularly in Sindh and
Balochistan as part of corporate farming that would cause water scarcity and
deprive local farming community of their rights.

It will also cause food insecurity in rural areas, putting the livelihood of
poor people at stake. Such kind of land purchasing is land grabbing, so there is
dire need to accelerate efforts against such onslaughts. The UAE has purchased
324,000 hectares of farmland in the Punjab and Sindh provinces of Pakistan in
June 2008. Investors from Abu Dhabi bought about 16,000 hectares of farmland in
Balochistan. Emirates Investment Group and Abraaj Capital are also investing
directly in corporate farming. Such kind of purchasing is a land grabbing which
will deprive local people of land and cause food insecurity.

Agriculture is central to economic growth and development in Pakistan. Being the
dominant sector it contributes 21.4 percent to GDP, employs 45 percent of the
country?s labour force and contributes in the growth of other sectors of the
economy. The healthy expansion in agriculture stimulates domestic demand for
industrial goods and other services and supplying raw material to agro-based
industry notably cotton textile industry which is the largest subsector of
manufacturing sector.

The government under paradigm of the new growth strategy envisioned to enhance
growth in agriculture sector by facilitating agriculture productivity
sustainable environment, increasing competitiveness in agriculture marketing and
trade by providing friendly climate for more investment in the sector. However,
draft tenth 5 years plan also envisages improving the productivity,
profitability competitiveness and environmental sustainability of agriculture.

Balochistan has the highest number of districts with worst conditions for food
security. The 20 districts of Pakistan with worst conditions for food security
include 10 districts from Balochistan, 5 from FATA; 3 from KPK; and 1 from
Gilgit Baltistan (GB) and Sindh each. The number of districts from Balochistan
in this category has doubled since 2003.

Dera Bugti, Musa Khel, Upper Dir, North Waziristan, Kohistan, Muhmmand,
Dalbidin, South Waziristan, Orakzai, and Panjgur are the 10 districts with worst
conditions for food security in Pakistan. Islamabad Capital Territory is the
most food secure district of Pakistan. Among the top twenty districts with best
conditions for food security, besides Islamabad, are 14 districts in Punjab and
5districts in Sindh.

LOAD-DATE: November 9, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                        Copyright 2013 The Frontier Post
                              All Rights Reserved

                               The Frontier Post

                           November 9, 2013 Saturday

48.6% Pakistan population food insecure: survey

SECTION: Vol. XXVII No. 748

LENGTH: 676  words


Pakistan overnment direly needs to adopt strategic approach to ensure food
security by taking demand, supply and production into account because 48.6%
population of the country is without access to sufficient food, according to a
survey conducted by media.

Food Security means a condition in which all people have access to adequate
nutritious and safe food. As the population of the country has grown to high
level, the food insecurity has been deepening with each passing day. The
availability of natural resources as compared to population need is reducing,
causing food insecurity. FATA has 67.7% food insecure population, Balochistan
61.2%, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa 56.2%. Food insecurity is also on the rise in rural
Sindh and some 63 % of its population (urban and rural) has suffered decline in
real wages and is forced to take cheaper food with less nutrient value.

In Pakistan, large family size is forced to expense 46 % of the family income on
food while the food expenditures in India are 35% and the United States 7%.
Malnutrition is a health problem in Pakistan and plays a substantial role in the
countrys elevated child morbidity and mortality.

There is need to bring agriculture reforms in the county by providing lucrative
crop subsidies, introducing agriculture farming, ending corporate farming and
providing easy loans to farmers. The government also needs to reduce inflation
rate, which is the major factor behind food insecurity. The corporate farming in
the country also adds to food insecurity, poverty and inflation.

Some Gulf countries have purchased lands in Pakistan, particularly in Sindh and
Balochistan as part of corporate farming that would cause water scarcity and
deprive local farming community of their rights.

It will also cause food insecurity in rural areas, putting the livelihood of
poor people at stake. Such kind of land purchasing is land grabbing, so there is
dire need to accelerate efforts against such onslaughts. The UAE has purchased
324,000 hectares of farmland in the Punjab and Sindh provinces of Pakistan in
June 2008. Investors from Abu Dhabi bought about 16,000 hectares of farmland in
Balochistan. Emirates Investment Group and Abraaj Capital are also investing
directly in corporate farming. Such kind of purchasing is a land grabbing which
will deprive local people of land and cause food insecurity.

Agriculture is central to economic growth and development in Pakistan. Being the
dominant sector it contributes 21.4 percent to GDP, employs 45 percent of the
country?s labour force and contributes in the growth of other sectors of the
economy. The healthy expansion in agriculture stimulates domestic demand for
industrial goods and other services and supplying raw material to agro-based
industry notably cotton textile industry which is the largest subsector of
manufacturing sector.

The government under paradigm of the new growth strategy envisioned to enhance
growth in agriculture sector by facilitating agriculture productivity
sustainable environment, increasing competitiveness in agriculture marketing and
trade by providing friendly climate for more investment in the sector. However,
draft tenth 5 years plan also envisages improving the productivity,
profitability competitiveness and environmental sustainability of agriculture.

Balochistan has the highest number of districts with worst conditions for food
security. The 20 districts of Pakistan with worst conditions for food security
include 10 districts from Balochistan, 5 from FATA; 3 from KPK; and 1 from
Gilgit Baltistan (GB) and Sindh each. The number of districts from Balochistan
in this category has doubled since 2003.

Dera Bugti, Musa Khel, Upper Dir, North Waziristan, Kohistan, Muhmmand,
Dalbidin, South Waziristan, Orakzai, and Panjgur are the 10 districts with worst
conditions for food security in Pakistan. Islamabad Capital Territory is the
most food secure district of Pakistan. Among the top twenty districts with best
conditions for food security, besides Islamabad, are 14 districts in Punjab and
5districts in Sindh.

                             680 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

             September 29, 1988, Thursday, Late City Final Edition

Growth in Aquaculture

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section D; Page 5, Column 4; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 56 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28


Aquaculture production in the United States, which includes fish farming, has
grown by 20 percent a year since 1980, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday.
Production includes food and non-food fish, shellfish and aquatic plants, the
department's economic research unit said. The report by the agency was the first
in six years.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1988 The New York Times Company


                             681 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                           Aberdeen Press and Journal

                                 April 20, 1999

Taking GM crops out of feed 'not easy task'

BYLINE: By Joe Watson

SECTION: Agriculture: GM crops, Pg.16

LENGTH: 710 words


THE technical boss of one of Scotland's biggest feed firms yesterday said it was
not as easy as some might claim to remove genetically-modified crops from animal
feeds.

Charles Young, technical manager of BOCM Pauls, said there were major problems
sourcing soya and maize free of genetic modification from world markets that
were now predominantly supplied by gene-altered materials.

He also urged at the Scottish Forage Awards a sea-change in the way farmers look
at grass - and to produce more profit from it rather than simply producing more
milk.

Mr Young's comments on biotechnology come as six of Europe's biggest food
retailers, including Marks and Spencer, look at the feasibility of removing
genetically-modified soya and maize from feeds for animals destined for their
shelves.

The study was announced last week by Marks and Spencer, one of the many
retailers in the UK which has removed all genetically-modified foodstuffs from
its shelves.

Mr Young said diets could be formulated for ruminants that could remove soya and
maize.

But in animals, including dairy cattle, that needed a higher nutrient level it
was almost impossible to take the two products out without affecting yield.

He added: "The main problem for feed firms is that in the main exporting country
- the US - there is no legal requirement to segregate product free from genetic
modification and that has to be changed.

"This makes it difficult for us to import product that is guaranteed to be free
of genetic modification. It is not impossible, but it is extremely difficult."

Mr Young said the UK's annual requirement for soya was well in excess of
2million tonnes, but only 100,000tonnes of it could be guaranteed free of
alteration.

He added: "This highlights the gravity of the problem we face. It's an issue for
smaller countries, not just the UK."

More than 70% of the American soya crop will next year be genetically modified.

Mr Young said grass, whether conserved or grazed, would play an even more
important role in profitable milk production in the future.

He urged a change in thinking on grass. Dairy farmers have traditionally just
questioned their current practice to produce more milk from grass.

But this no longer made financial sense if the grass has a knock-on effect on
other aspects of milk production or herd fertility.

Mr Young said: "We need to develop a strategy to maximise profit from grass by
identifying all factors which could potentially influence bottom-line profit.
Areas to be considered are fertiliser management, grazing strategy and dry cow
management at grass."

Mr Young said while farmers tested silage throughout the winter to determine
feeding values, no similar test was done on grass while growing.

It was, however, time for the industry to start analysing samples of fresh grass
so farmers know the nutritional value of the grass their cows are consuming.

This pro-active approach could help cow fertility, particularly in May and June
- the worst two months for conception rate because of surplus protein in grass
at this time.

BOCM Pauls has developed a new test for fresh grass. Mr Young said problems
could be identified by it. Diets could then be developed to help improve
fertility.

Peterhead dairy farmer James Will, of Hallmoss, St Fergus, took first place in
the big bale silage section of the forage awards.

His silage had a dry matter of 25.5%, with a pH of 3.9, an ammonia level of 16
and crude protein at 14.5%. D value was 68, with ME at 10.9 and fermentation in
class 4.

Mr Will has 90 Holstein cows, averaging 8,981litres at 3.25% protein and 3.99%
butterfat.

Second in the big bale section was T S Thomson and Sons, Kirkton Farm,
Cowdenbeath, who farm 363hectares. They milk 80 Holsteins, with an average yield
of 6,500litres at 3.0% protein and 3.95% butterfat.

Their silage contained dry matter of 30.8%, with pH at 4.3. Ammonia was at 9,
with crude protein at 11.4%. D value was at 64, with ME at 10.3. The silage was
in fermentation class 3.

Other winners were:

Big bale - 3 J and C Russell, Eastertown, Biggar.

Clamp silage - 1 Robert Montgomerie, Glenconner Farm, Ochiltree; 2 W and A
Watson, Muir Farm, Mauchline; 3 R Smith and Co, Corwar Outon Farm, Whithorn,
Newton Stewart.

                              The Bismarck Tribune

                           November 25, 1993 Thursday

LENGTH: 423 words


'94 corn crop acreage unchanged WASHINGTON (AP) Ä The 1994 corn acreage
reduction program will be set at zero, meaning more land can be planted to corn
next year than was this year, Secretary of Agriculture Mike Espy has announced.
The adjustment was made because the 1993 corn crop is down 31 percent from last
year and the projected 1993 corn carryover stocks are at the lowest level since
1975. The action was taken partly to help assure feed grain supplies would be
adequate for domestic livestock producers and to have sufficient feed grains for
export in 1994. For 1993, the acreage reduction was 10 percent of the crop
acreage base. The base is the average of the acreage planted for harvest during
the last five years. Agriculture law requires that the secretary announce the
feed grain acreage reduction percentage by Sept. 30. At the time, Espy announced
1994 feed grain ARP percentages of 5 percent for corn and zero percent for grain
sorghum, barley and oats. The secretary is also authorized to make adjustments
in the 1994 program no later than Nov. 15 if the total supply of feed grains
changes significantly after the first announcement. Since the initial
announcement, estimated feed grain supplies for the 1993 corn crop are down
about 8 percent.

New Caledonia free of ag diseases WASHINGTON (AP) Ä The Agriculture Department
has declared the Pacific Island of New Caledonia free of rinderpest and
foot-and-mouth disease. ""This regulatory revision eases restrictions on certain
meat and dairy products exported from New Caledonia to the United States,'' said
Billy G. Johnson, deputy administrator of veterinary services in USDA's Animal
and Plant Health Inspection Service. An island territory of France, New
Caledonia has its own animal health and veterinary program. USDA declared France
free of rinderpest and foot-and-mouth disease on July 23. New Caledonia has
never reported an outbreak of either highly communicable disease of cud-chewing
animals. Under the declaration, USDA will no longer restrict the importation of
milk, milk products and most fresh, chilled and frozen meat products from
ruminants Ä or cud-chewing Ä animals in New Caledonia. Johnson said USDA will
continue to restrict the importation of live swine and fresh, chilled or frozen
pork from the island because of the presence of hog cholera and swine vesicular
disease in France. Certain restrictions also will remain on ruminant meat and
edible products from New Caledonia because of the presence of bovine spongiform
encephalopathy in France.

                         Business Mirror (Philippines)

                           December 15, 2015 Tuesday

When a new generation refuses to farm, who will feed the people?

BYLINE: Alladin S. Diega

LENGTH: 920  words


ASKED how can the youth be made interested with agriculture, he said that career
orientation in schools should include actual visits to modern farms to show the
students that farming is lucrative and it's not all dirtying-yourself-stuff.

Visibility campaign of agriculture for the youth, schools can even include
elective subjects in high schools even in urban areas that discuss agriculture
and farming he also said.

Baranao also said that many of his friends have repeatedly urged him to shift to
another course, like accounting or information technology but firmly explained
that he is decided with farming.

Food. Survival. Healthy living. These are the images that comes to my mind
whenever I hear the word agriculture. Nothing is more important than that, he
added.

In an interview, Felino P. Lansigan, a professor of statistics at the University
of the Philippines Los Banos (UPLB), said that there is really a decline on the
enrollees of agricultural courses, the students are more into computer related
or technology related courses such as IT, computer engineering, adding that this
is because the youth see farming as all hard physical work.

UPLB has a new program, like agro-biotech, still very much related to
agriculture, for the students to realize that there is more to agriculture,
especially now that the move is toward modernization of the agriculture.

He also said that on the average, Filipino farmers are now 57 years of age, and
that there should really be a concerted effort to convince the young people to
engage in food production.

The lack of new generation ready to shoulder the yoke of farming is not unique
to the developing countries of Asia, Africa and Latin America. In the United
States of America, where farmers are generally believed to be better off
compared with their Asian counterparts, farming is also being relegated to a
much older population.

Currently, the average age of the American farmer is 58.3 years, while 30 years
ago, the average age was 50.3 years.

It's a major problem, Lindsey Lusher Shute, representative for the National
Young Farmers Coalition, a US-based organization, said in a statement available
online. Between the last two censuses, there's only an increase of 3,000 young
farmers. Tom Vilsak, the secretary of Agriculture, is calling for 100,000 new
farmers, She added.

According to Shute, the main problem is the very limited financial incentive for
young people to choose farming as a profession. There's just no way enough young
people enter agriculture to replace the number of retiring farmers unless there
is a very clear career path, she said.

The group is calling the US Congress to introduce legislation that would include
farmers to the definition of public service student loan forgiveness which
currently covers teachers, doctors, nurses, and non-profit employees.

If approved, after 10 years of income-driven repayments, the rest of the student
debt is written-off, allowing young farmers to focus on starting their
businesses without the burden of payments.

Asked whether a similar legislation could work in the Philippines, Virginia
Benosa, campaigner for Greenpeace Philippines, said that it might, except that
the US has a wider swaths of farm lands and being archipelago in nature,
agricultural lands are divided into separate islands which are currently
experiencing environmental abuse through a variety of irresponsible practices.

Instead, Greenpeace is calling for the government to make farming more
profitable and sustainable, by encouraging ecological agriculture, Benosa told
BusinessMirror.

The group calls for the government support to the producers, or farmers
themselves and allow them to deal directly with consumers to maximize their
profit she explained.

To maximize food production and yields, the group is also calling for the
minimize use of land for bioenergy as this limits the available land for food
production.

Under its recently launched program #IAmHampaslupa, Greenpeace is encouraging
young Filipinos to engage in food-production business or activities. Now more
than ever, with the challenges brought about by the changing climate, ageing
farmers, nutrition security, disaster response and environmental protection, we
need comprehensive, holistic and responsive plicies on food and agriculture that
can act to the growing needs and concern of Filipinos, she also said.

The group used the derogatory hampaslupa, which literally means hitting the land
or toiling the soil to release it from the historical negative connotation.

The IDC paper concluded that agriculture's lack of appeal to young people
reflects the lack of effective public investment in small holder farming and the
public infrastructure needed to link to markets. This also include constrained
access to land and uncertain access to inputs among young people, including land
fragmentation in many countries in past few decades and social change resulting
from rapid increases in mass education provision but which have often resulted
in a perceived decline in the status of agriculture.

However, the research also found out that agriculture could be made more
appealing to young people, with the right kinds of measures and support, which
include providing the right kinds of training at appropriate levels to reflect
the demands of the job market and broader public investment.

Also, farmers, across all generations, need support for accessing markets and to
improve productivity, including access to inputs and in the use of modern
technologies, the study said.

                             684 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                           Aberdeen Press and Journal

                                  May 22, 2003

Shift In Finishing Sector Forecast With Production Moving South

SECTION: Business; Farm/Food; Beef; Pg. 22

LENGTH: 648 words


Reforms to Europe's Common Agricultural Policy will result in a drop in suckler
cow numbers in Scotland.  But Peter Cook, the much respected head of the rural
business unit at the Scottish Agricultural College, does not believe the fall in
the herd will be as high as many expect.

The biggest change from the CAP shake-up that is likely to be agreed next month
will come in the finishing sector, where a significant shift is being forecast
with production likely to move south to the more intensive arable areas, where
cheap feed is readily available.

Speaking to the Press and Journal, Mr Cook said if the current reform package
goes through unaltered there would be a 10-15 drop in suckler cow numbers in
Scotland to around 480,000 head.

Finishing systems would show big changes, with Scotland, according to the SAC
modelling, becoming predominantly a store cattle production area.

Store calves would then be sold to the intensive arable areas of England, the
Lothians, Borders, Angus and parts of Aberdeenshire.

Mr Cook believed feedlots - commonplace in the United States - could become more
common in the UK if the CAP changes go through as they stand.

The change in the finishing regime has the potential to cause significant
problems for those relying on cattle numbers.

There was on Tuesday a warning from the Meat and Livestock Commission that many
jobs would be lost in the downstream industries, including auction marts, meat
processors, feed firms and other companies dependent on farming.

Mr Cook said: "A lot of cattle will continue to be finished in Scotland, but a
lot less than previously. There may even be a change in the breeding and in the
size of the cattle that are finished.

"That all means a drop in tonnage - and for the Scottish meat sector that is bad
news, particularly for the processors.

"I do not, however, see the calamitous reduction that many are forecasting." The
CAP changes would also hit stock values, with a drop in price expected as a
result of the headage element of subsidy payments being removed.

Feeding too could become cheaper because of lower-priced cereals.

Mr Cook said he was worried about the future of arable farming in Scotland after
the reforms go through.

The removal of the production-based element of subsidies as proposed by CAP
reform could, he claimed, result in a 30 drop in the arable area.

Cereal cropping would shift to those areas most suited to it, while the marginal
areas which have grown arable crops to make best use of subsidies would revert
to grass - a regime that could, Mr Cook conceded, help livestock numbers.

He added: "Where the really big change is in arable area payments. Without these
the marginal arable areas will move out of cropping. Arable farming will
concentrate on the best bits." Mr Cook also tackled the issue of
competitiveness, highlighting again the huge financial differences that still
exist between the top and bottom third in the beef sector.

He added: "The difference is in the value of the calf and the feed costs. That
is what separates the men from the boys in terms of results." Beef farming had
over the last year been among the better sectors in agriculture, Mr Cook said.

While industry average figures pointed to poor performance, Mr Cook said the
best breeders had seen improved results. Finishers were subject again to
fluctuating returns form the marketplace.

He warned of changes ahead, adding that all headage payments would disappear - a
move that could see stock prices reduce.

Mr Cook said return on capital was also essential, highlighting again big
differences between the best and worst performers.

To achieve a 5 return on capital, the best producers needed to generate a
further £25 per acre margin. Those at the bottom end of the scale needing
anything between £50-£60 per acre to match the best performers.

INTERNATIONAL REPORT   Farm bill

BYLINE: GAM

LENGTH: 106 words


The U.S. House of Representatives Agriculture Committee has rejected
 President Ronald Reagan's plans to cut farm subsidies and instead has
 approved a comprehensive commodity bill that far exceeds Mr. Reagan's
 spending plans.

The House bill, according to the Administration, could cost more than
 twice as much as the $7.8-billion (U.S.) the Agriculture Department had
 planned to spend over the next four years on commodity programs. The bill
 sets higher price supports for wheat, corn, and dairy products than the
 Administration had planned, creates a new sugar price support system and
 retains income subsidies for grain and cotton farmers.

Washington to give $125M relief to dairy farmers

SECTION: FINANCIAL POST; Pg. C02, Food Industry

LENGTH: 79 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


WASHINGTON - The U.S. Department of Agriculture said yesterday it will give
dairy producers $125-million U.S. in subsidies. Dairy farmers increased output
last year as demand was robust for cheese, butter and other products, but prices
are likely to sink as low as 12.35 cents (US) a pound this year, down from a low
of 14.25 cents a pound last year. The USDA's Dairy Market Loss Assistance
program will pay producers based on their milk production in 1997 and 1998.

Soviet Grain Output

BYLINE: Reuters

SECTION: Section 2; Page 43, Column 6; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 89 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15


The United States Agriculture Department today estimated Soviet 1981 grain
production at 175 million metric tons, unchanged from its December estimate. In
its monthly report, the department put Soviet wheat production at 88 million
tons, coarse grain production at 77 million and miscellaneous grain production
at 10 million tons, all unchanged from last month.  The department said this
compares with the Soviet target of 236 million tons and is the smallest crop
since 1975.

                          International New York Times

                            January 6, 2015 Tuesday

U.S. gives green light to imports of Irish beef;
Country is first in Europe to meet American safety rules after mad cow scare

BYLINE: DOUGLAS DALBY

SECTION: FINANCE; Pg. 16

LENGTH: 776 words

DATELINE: DUBLIN

ABSTRACT

Ireland has met American safety rules, becoming the first European country to
come off a ban imposed after an outbreak of mad cow disease in the late 1990s.

FULL TEXT

Irish beef will be the first from Europe to be sold in the United States in
almost 16 years, after the lifting of a ban that had stemmed from an outbreak of
mad cow disease in the late 1990s.

The United States agreed to lift the ban last year, and Ireland is the first
European country since then to have met the requirements ensuring its beef was
safe. Although any Irish imports might represent only a tiny fraction of
American meat sales, Ireland might be likely to find a market among buyers
seeking beef raised in pastures and free from artificial growth hormones.

''This U.S. market is a huge prize given its size and the demand we know exists
there for premium grass-fed beef,'' Ireland's agriculture minister, Simon
Coveney, said Monday in an official announcement on Irish national radio. ''We
now have first-mover advantage as a result of being the first E.U. member state
to gain entry. There is also the large Irish-American community, which will be a
key target of our promotional efforts.''

The United States authorities imposed the ban over health fears during an
epidemic across Europe in the late 1990s that led to mass culling of cattle
herds. The formal name for mad cow disease is bovine spongiform encephalopathy,
an affliction that kills cattle by attacking the animals' brains and central
nervous systems. If tainted meat is consumed, the illness is believed to be
capable of causing fatal neurological disorders in humans, mainly through the
incurable variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease.

Beef prices in the United States have risen in recent years as a result of
droughts and higher feed prices. Australia is a leading exporter of beef to the
United States, although most of that meat comes from industrial feed lots - not
the open-pasture beef that many Irish farms produce.

The demand for premium grass-fed, hormone-free beef in the United States,
particularly in the restaurant trade, is growing an estimated 20 percent a year,
Mr. Coveney said. Last year, the United States imported around 4 billion euros,
or about $4.8 billion, worth of such beef from countries like Paraguay and
Uruguay. Mr. Coveney estimates that the market could be worth (EURO)100 million
to the Irish beef industry in 2015.

The weak euro - it was trading in the range of $1.19 on Monday - should also
help Ireland's export drive, Mr. Coveney said.

The approval to begin exports follows an inspection by the American authorities
of Irish beef production systems last July, after the formal lifting of the ban
in March 2014. The Irish government hopes the United States approval might also
open other foreign markets.

''This is the culmination of two years of intensive work to prove our
credentials as a supplier of highest quality premium beef,'' Mr. Coveney said.
The Irish lobbying efforts included playing host to two visits by the United
States secretary of agriculture, Tom Vilsack.

Irish officials are now in a position to authorize individual beef-processing
plants to export to the United States. Mr. Coveney said that his department had
been in talks with interested producers and that the work would intensify so
trade could begin as soon as possible.

Paul Finnerty, chief executive of ABP Food Group, which has farms in Ireland,
Britain and Poland and is Europe's biggest beef processor, said the reopening of
the American market was ''a significant opportunity,'' given the demand in the
United States for grass-fed beef.

''We have been working on the ground in the U.S. over two years now and sense a
real opportunity for our business,'' he said in an email. ''We have been in
negotiations with a number of leading food service and retail players, and we
are expecting to make an announcement very shortly.''

But some farming organizations were more cautious. Patrick Kent, president of
the Irish Cattle and Sheep Farmers' Association, said the news was good only in
theory - unless big buyers proved willing to pay more for beef. ''Farmers will
remain skeptical, given the ruthless downward manipulation of prices by the meat
industry over the past 12 months,'' he said in a statement. ''They are still
waiting to see concrete benefits from previous announcements of new markets.''

Meat Industry Ireland, a trade group representing beef producers, said it
welcomed the announcement. But it cautioned that further clarity was required on
the approval process for producers, predicting that the exports would be a niche
market concentrated on premium meats sold in relatively low volumes.

                     Belfast News Letter (Northern Ireland)

                            March 1, 2003, Saturday

FARM BUSINESS DEVELOPMENT AGENCY URGED

BYLINE: RICHARD HALLORAN

SECTION: FARMING LIFE; Pg. 28

LENGTH: 386 words


ULSTER Farmers' Union president, John Gilliland, has called on Government to set
up a businesses development agency for agriculture, which will have the specific
brief of developing a spirit of innovation within the local farming industry.

"Annual output from the agri-food and ancillary sectors currently amounts to
pounds 2.2 billion," he told Farming Life.

"These industries also account for approximately 10 per cent of Northern
Ireland's working population. And we cannot afford to have this economic basis
eroded, something that is a real possibility given the pressures on our agri
food sectors at the present time."

Mr Gilliland's comments come in the wake of proposals by the World Trade
Organisation (WTO) that would establish the trading conditions for world
agriculture in the next decade.

He is claiming that these are completely imbalanced and would see European
agriculture suffer at the expense of other WTO partners such as the USA and the
Cairns Group.

The UFU president believes that global free trade could serve to erode Northern
Ireland's entire agri-food base.

"There has been outright rejection of the WTO proposals by EU farm leaders,"
stressed the UFU president. The parameters for agreement on agriculture at the
world trade talks are to be agreed by the end of March and this report is a very
bad start to the process.

"The world trade talks process is now accelerating and urgent action is needed
on behalf of local farming families."

He added: "EU Farm Commissioner, Franz Commissioner Fischler, will be
representing Europe at the WTO negotiations. We must ensure that local
agriculture is defended. This establishes the framework for further reforms of
the Common Agricultural Policy and is crucially important to the future of
farming families."

John Gilliland firmly believes that the WTO proposals focus on dismantling EU
support for agriculture. He is also critical of the fact that no recognition is
given to the great strides made by Europe on key issues such as animal welfare
and.

The UFU leader is also quick to highlight the frustrations felt by local farmers
by the way the WTO is targeting EU agriculture while other regions such as the
USA where continuing to underwrite their agricultural industry with little or no
criticism.

                             690 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                           Aberdeen Press and Journal

                                January 16, 1999

Producers could turn to oats as alternative crop

BYLINE: By Joe Watson

SECTION: Agriculture: Arable, Pg.19

LENGTH: 576 words


OATS could yet shake off its Cinderella image - and take a major place in
Scottish cereal production this year.

Severe shortages of spring barley and wheat seed because of last year's dreadful
harvest might yet force farmers to look at oats as an alternative to normal
production.

The oat is among the few crops that has a true health benefit, with the US Food
and Drug Administration recently revealing it helped reduce risks of heart
disease.

Brian Hutchison, managing director of North Eastern Farmers, said: "For
generations our farming forefathers have understood the suitability of the
spring oat crop for the climatic conditions of North Scotland.

"Last year's difficult harvest again proved this fact. Even after a very wet,
cold spring and summer, the spring oat crop yielded very close to the
expectations of most farmers."

NEF is one of the biggest handlers of oats in the country, and has just launched
its 1999 milling oat contract, which offers a contract price based on a premium
above Scottish cereals, with extra for low screenings and high specific weights.
Scottish Quality Cereal members will also get a separate premium.

Mr Hutchison said: "The production of a crop, which receives no subsidies from
Brussels, but is destined for a local, real market, needs to be given due
consideration as a profitable alternative cereal."

There are several key factors to growing oats, including good free draining soil
and the ability to sow early in soil that has adequate phosphate and potash.
Growth regulators have to be used to keep the crop standing and mildew should
not be allowed to be establish itself.

Drummer is the newcomer this year.  It is the highest yielding spring oat on the
SAC recommended list and early maturing, has large grain size, low screenings
and good specific weight. It is to be launched to the grain trade on January 26
by Perryfields, in which NEF and Glencore are the shareholders.

Also available are: Amigo, which has a good yield, high kernel and short stiff
straw; Melys, the most widely grown with a stiff straw and good mildew
resistance; Dula, which has medium maturity, a fairly stiff straw and good
kernel content, but mildew control is essential; Valiant, which despite having
low screening losses, does have a low kernel content and specific weight.

Oats are used in a variety of products, including breakfast cereals, porridge
oats, and biscuits.

Millers used to be commonplace in every parish across the country, but today few
are left. One of the biggest millers is Grampian Oat Products, near Banff, but
among the more traditional is the Aberfeldy Water Mill, which still uses age-old
traditions to make its fine, coarse, medium and pinhead meal.

Its water-driven millstones are currently being re-sharpened in the
time-honoured tradition as it prepares for its annual influx of visitors keen to
see how oats are milled the old-fashioned way.

Director Thomas Rodger, the seventh generation miller in his family, said
upwards of 2tonnes of oats are milled daily by miller George Paxton, and shipped
across the country.

The secret, Mr Rodger claims, to the best meal is in the roasting of the oats.
He said: "We roast them to between 5-6%. That puts the flavour in the meal,
whereas some of the more modern plants are after quantity not quality.

The recent closure of the Montgarrie Mill at Alford had boosted business at
Aberfeldy, where there has been a mill for 450 years.

LOAD-DATE: January 16, 1999

LANGUAGE: English

                   Copyright 1999 Aberdeen Press and Journal


                             691 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                       May 22, 1998, Friday, ALL EDITIONS

CRISIS IN INDONESIA;
Greenspan expects fallout from Asia

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 10A; Pg. 10A

LENGTH: 444 words


Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan said Thursday that economic conditions
in Indonesia and other hard-hit Asian nations have deteriorated in recent weeks,
and the fallout is "only now just being felt" by the U.S. economy.

Greenspan, testifying along with Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin and Agriculture
Secretary Dan Glickman before the House Agriculture Committee, said part of the
progress several nations made early this year in stabilizing their economies has
been reversed.

Until the situation "fully stabilizes, we can't really have confidence" the
Asian problems won't spread further through the world financial system, he said.
Rubin, too, suggested the United States has yet to feel the worst effects of the
crisis as he and Greenspan implored Congress to pass legislation to increase the
borrowing authority of the cash-strapped International Monetary Fund by $ 18
billion.

Should the crises that enveloped the economies of Indonesia, Thailand and South
Korea spread to any other sizable economy, they warned, the agency would not
have the resources to stem the collapse. That could set off a global panic.

"These occurrences are possible, and the consequences to us could be severe,"
Rubin said.

Greenspan and Rubin told the committee the United States can expect soaring
trade deficits and slower growth for the rest of the year in large part because
of collapsing demand for U.S.-made goods in Asia.

"Nearly 40 percent of America's agricultural production is exported, and roughly
40 percent of that export goes to Asia," Rubin said. "That's about $ 23 billion.
Many fishermen in Alaska are suffering because depreciating currencies (of the
Asian nations) have caused their fish to be too expensive for Asian markets. . .
. Corn farmers in the Midwest, livestock producers in the West are all feeling
the effects."

In other developments: World Bank President James Wolfensohn said at a news
conference in Moscow that the international lender will work with "any
democratically elected government" in Indonesia, but he didn't say whether he
considers the new administration of B.J. Habibie democratic. "We'll have to wait
and see what the next 48 hours in Indonesia bring," Wolfensohn said. Overall, "I
think the whole situation is settling down." U.S. and IMF officials said they
would initially judge Indonesia's new government by whether the Cabinet includes
such reformers as Economic Minister Ginandjar Kartasasmita, who has been the
main liaison with the IMF. Habibie is widely distrusted by the IMF, the World
Bank and Washington because he is seen as a beneficiary of the crony capitalism
that hurt Indonesia's economy.

LOAD-DATE: May 23, 1998

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SERIES: Final Today's News

                    Copyright 1998 The Atlanta Constitution


                             692 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                           The Sunday Times (London)

                             August 3 1986, Sunday

American Account: US gets half a loaf

BYLINE: IRWIN STELZER

SECTION: Issue 8452.

LENGTH: 937 words


THE AMERICAN agricultural crisis has reached a point where it is affecting more
than just the country's cosseted farmers. Uncorrected, it may transfer control
of the Senate from the Republicans to the Democrats, place a strain on US-Soviet
relations, increase the trade deficit sufficiently to give a critical boost to
the protectionist lobby and raise the federal budget deficit by enough to bust
the Gramm-Rudman budget targets. That's a lot to claim for one crisis. But it is
no exaggeration.

Agriculture was once thought to be America's most efficient industry. Between
1970 and 1980, employment fell by a third while production of such key crops as
corn and wheat almost doubled. And prices rose. Corn went from dollars 1.33 to
dollars 3.11 per bushel while wheat prices tripled to dollars 3.91 per bushel.
Exports, too, soared - from dollars 7 billion in 1970 to dollars 41 billion in
1980, when US agricultural exports exceeded imports by dollars 24 billion.


America seemed on the verge of becoming the world's breadbasket. But this
prosperity was based on government support which would prove ineffective when
agricultural markets became international.

Government agriculture programmes had three goals: inflate demand for food,
restrict supply and raise prices. Demand for food was increased by
government-supported food stamps, school lunches and other programmes. By 1980,
their total bill exceeded dollars 13 billion.

Supply was restricted by schemes to reduce acreage, with huge sums paid to
farmers willing to withdraw land from production, even though these farmers were
smart enough to keep production high by leaving fallow only the least productive
land, while more intensively farming the rest.

To complete farming's support system, the government set minimum prices and
acted as the buyer of last resort for crops that could not be sold at those
prices.

Unfortunately, those with visions of never-ending American agricultural
prosperity forgot that what works in a closed national market doesn't in a
competitive international one. As the dollar strengthened in the 1980s, American
farm products for export became more expensive.

Producers in Europe and Latin America responded to American-set price floors and
output cuts by expanding their own production. So prices began to fall, just as
farmers were getting the bills for their wildly-expanded debt. For, in response
to the boom of the 1970s and to low interest rates, land prices had been bid up
by farmers running their debt load from dollars 30 billion in 1970 to almost
dollars 100 billion in 1980.

The decline in farm exports was so sharp that America imported more food than it
exported in May of this year, the first time it has been a net agricultural
importer in 16 years. There are several reasons for this decline.

Increases in government price support in 1981 came just as world prices were
declining, making US products uncompetitive in world markets. Moreover, the
decline in the dollar has been confined largely to non-agricultural goods: the
trade-weighted dollar has actually risen against the currencies of wheat
competitors such as Canada, Australia and Argentina.

To stimulate exports, the US government then decided to let prices drop to world
levels, but subsidised farmers to the tune of the difference between government
support prices and world market prices. This will cost about dollars 35 billion
this year, adding more to the federal budget deficit than all of the Pentagon's
cost overruns combined.

More than 80% of these payments, all financed by taxpayers, will go to the
largest farmers - those with assets of over dollars 2m and incomes of dollars
170,000. Never have so few owed so much to so many.

Even this munificence does not satisfy farmers, who are pressing for still more
aid. The Republican Senate leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, is acutely aware that 11
of the 22 Republican seats being contested in November are in farm states. With
the Republican majority now only three, a Democratic sweep of farm votes would
leave President Reagan to face two hostile legislative chambers in his last two
years in office.

So Dole had the Senate pass a bill last week to force the president to offer
subsidies, in the form of grain from overflowing government warehouses, as
bonuses to communist countries buying US farm products. One senator lamely
defended his vote: 'You market grains where the mouths are and the mouths are in
the Soviet Union and China. '

Dole's subsidy is a strange reward to Russia for its violations of its 1983
wheat-purchasing agreement. In 1985 the Russians failed to buy the minimum
amount of wheat they had committed to take. They have announced that alleged
poor quality and high prices relieve them of any obligation to keep to agreed
1986 purchase levels.

The problem, of course, is that declining oil prices have so reduced Russian
hard-currency earnings that the Soviets are hard-pressed to earn the dollars to
pay for American wheat. Reagan, his eye on the bigger issue of ensuring a summit
and some sort of arms control agreement, is reluctant to remind Mr Gorbachev
that his breach of the wheat deal may encourage many senators to assume he will
do the same with any arms control pact.

In the end, the American, Japanese and European governments may see the folly of
consumption-reducing price-support programmes, and substitute more efficient
direct-income supplements to needy farmers. But it is more likely that EEC
butter surpluses and US grain surpluses will end up at subsidised prices on the
tables of Russians.

LOAD-DATE: September 21, 2000

LANGUAGE: English

                    Copyright 1986 Times Newspapers Limited


                             693 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                                The Toronto Star

                    October 22, 1985, Tuesday, FINAL EDITION

Canada probes Europe's beef subsidies

SECTION: BUSINESS TODAY; Pg. D1

LENGTH: 288 words


   Canada has started a probe into subsidized European beef imports, just as
Canadian beef producers seem poised to get their own subsidization plan to
stabilize beef prices.

Revenue Canada said yesterday it will determine whether European beef exports to
Canada are being unfairly subsidized, and hopes to make a decision by January.

The move, which was requested by the Canadian Cattlemen's Association, could
result in a countervailing duty against the European meat.

Ironically, Canadian beef producers may also get some government help of their
own.

Ontario and the federal government are reportedly near agreement on a
"stabilization" plan for beef producers.

Under the plan, beef farmers, provincial governments and the federal government
would contribute equal shares to the stabilization fund. The fund would pay
money to farmers during periods of low beef prices.

Provincial governments would have to cut off their own subsidy programs if they
joined the national plan, however.

Federal Agriculture Minister John Wise has warned that U.S. beef producers could
say that the fund amounts to a subsidy, and erect their own barriers against
Canadian beef or cattle.

The United States has already slapped duties on Canadian live hogs this year
because of a "stabilization" payment made to pork producers by the federal
government.

No duty was imposed on pork exports by the U.S., and there was speculation that
exports of pork might replace the live hogs.

Figures compiled by the Canadian Meat Council, which represents packers, show
that in the nine weeks after the U.S. decision to put a duty on Canadian hogs,
hog exports to the U.S. were down 68 per cent from the same point last year.

LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1999

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                  Copyright 1985 Toronto Star Newspapers, Ltd.


                             694 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                        Manawatu Standard (New Zealand)

                            October 29, 2013 Tuesday

Grass-fed meat promises to revive health benefits

SECTION: NEWS; NATIONAL; Pg. 15

LENGTH: 445 words


Farming and consuming grass-fed red meat might just save the planet.

This form of farming was completely sustainable, nutritional therapist Nora
Gedgaudas told farmers and visitors at the World Angus Forum in Rotorua.

It is also the predominant method of farming livestock in New Zealand.

"Grass-fed meat may just be the most healthy and sustainable food source on
Earth," she said.

Much of the earth's landmass was unsuitable for agriculture, yet it could
support grazing livestock while providing nutritionally dense food, she said.

Grass-fed beef was vastly nutritionally superior to grain-fed beef. It had a
higher omega-3 content and was also loaded with minerals and vitamins,
antioxidants and conjugated linoleic acids, which reduce the risks of cancer,
obesity and diabetics.

This is because the health of the meat is directly related to the health of the
animal.

She questioned whether the feedlot systems used overseas to finish cattle was
the future of food production because many of the nutritional advantages seen in
grass-fed beef were lost.

Gedgaudas is an expert in Paleolithic nutrition and runs a private practice in
the United States.

She is the author of the book, Primal Body, Primal Mind, which looks at diet and
health from an evolutionary point of view.

She argued that humans would lead healthier lives by adapting Paleolithic
principles.

Studies showed that meat and animal fat made up 90 per cent of the diet of early
humans and this form of food played a critical role in the human diet and brain
development, she said. The human genetic expression had not changed
significantly over the past 200,000 years and humans were genetically and
psychologically hunter-gatherers.

Humans were designed to get their protein from animal-sourced foods, which were
of huge nutritional importance.

This changed with the emergence of modern agriculture. Humans had progressively
lost about 10 per cent of brain volume since the adoption of an agricultural
lifestyle about 10,000 years ago, Gedgaudas said.

It also resulted in a change of human diet, where the consumption of high
energy, fat rich foods of animal origin were replaced by less energy-dense and
more health compromising grains, which human were not genetically adapted for.
In modern times, 90 per cent of the world's food supply is provided by 17
species of plants which were entirely new to the human diet, she said.

The No 1 source of calories in the United States diet was fructose corn syrup
and the No 1 source of fat calories was soya bean oil.

"That's not fat, folks, that's frankenfat, so today Western society is
essentially committing carbocide." Fairfax NZ

--------------------

CAPTION:

Nora Gedgaudas

LOAD-DATE: October 29, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
