                             695 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                      Knight-Ridder Tribune Business News

                                August 12, 2006

Drought puts state's crops in bad shape.

BYLINE: John Dobberstein

LENGTH: 651 words



HIGHLIGHT: cotton trade forecasted


Aug. 12--Oklahoma's cotton, sorghum and peanut crops will shrink dramatically
this year, the government predicted Friday, continuing the litany of bad news
for the state's farmers.

Oklahoma's cotton production may drop by 30 percent, with only 250,000 bales
expected at harvest, according to the U.S. Department of Agriculture's July
estimates.

"I hope we make that. We may not," said J.C. Banks, a professor and cotton
specialist for Oklahoma State University's Cooperative Extension service.

Record cotton harvests were recorded in 2004 and 2005 in Oklahoma. Last year's
harvest brought in 358,000 bales and $80 million.

The 2006 cotton crop was battered by searing heat and drought. Some dryland crop
areas in southwestern Oklahoma are seeing the worst drought on record, Banks
said.

On Tuesday, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration rated most of
Oklahoma in the "extreme" or "exceptional" drought category, with less-serious
drought conditions in the northeast and Panhandle regions.

Most cotton fields in eastern Tillman County are in the crop disaster category,
Banks said.

In the state's irrigation district for cotton, surrounding Lake Altus Lugert,
water has been severely rationed and producers may run out in a week or two,
Banks said. Irrigation wells in Harmon County are running dry, and irrigation
has stopped.

"That's really going to hurt our yield," Banks said. "This is a critical time
where we need to fill the cotton boles."

The only cotton in decent shape, Banks said, is in west-central Oklahoma, in
Caddo and Beckham counties, where more irrigation has been possible.

It's not just Oklahoma, Banks said. Georgia, Texas and Alabama combined will
produced 4.1 million fewer bales of cotton than last year. Nationally, the
cotton crop should be 20.4 million bales, down 14 percent from last year's
record 23.9 million bales, the USDA said.

Sorghum production in Oklahoma could fall 20 percent from last year's crop, with
9.8 million bushels expected in 2006. That would be a drop of one-third from
2004's harvest of 14.4 million bushels.

The soybean harvest will also be smaller, with 5.7 million bushels expected this
year -- down nearly 28 percent from 2005. Nationally, soybean production is
forecast at 2.93 billion bushels, down 5 percent.

Oklahoma's peanut crop, already dwindling because of changes in federal
programs, will take another big hit.

The USDA predicts a harvest of 72 million pounds, a 31 percent decrease from
2005 and the lowest amount since 1956. About 24,000 acres will be harvested, the
lowest total since 1930.

Oklahoma's share of the peanut crop is small compared to states like Georgia,
which could harvest 1.4 billion pounds of peanuts this year. But Georgia, Texas,
Alabama and Florida also face big reductions in peanut yields. The national crop
could be one-third smaller this year than in 2005.

The alfalfa hay crop in Oklahoma could be 23 percent smaller in 2006, and
production of all other hay should be down nearly 17 percent.

The corn forecast for Oklahoma is better, with 28.6 million bushels expected --
only 150,000 bushels less than last year.

The outlook has improved for meat. Analysts raised forecasts for beef and
chicken production, as well as price forecasts for cattle, chickens and hogs.

The pace of beef exports has picked up, with strong sales to Canada and Mexico.
Recovery of the Japanese market, closed to the U.S. until recently over fears of
mad cow disease, will occur gradually, analysts said.

The Associated Press contributed to this story.

To see more of the Tulsa World, or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.tulsaworld.com.

Copyright (c) 2006, Tulsa World, Okla.

Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News.

847-635-6550, send a fax to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group
Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave., Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                           February 21, 2015 Saturday

USPTO grants trade mark "CO-ALLIANCE" to Co-Alliance (INDIANA)

LENGTH: 226  words

DATELINE: Alexandria


Co-Alliance (INDIANA), has been granted trademark (4688187) titled as
"CO-ALLIANCE" from the United States Patent and Trademark Office.

Status: Registered

Class/es: IC 035. US 100 101 102. G & S: Cooperative buying club services in the
fields of farming, agriculture, commercial motor fuel, retail propane services,
grain marketing services, livestock, and livestock feed; business services,
namely, combined strategic goods or services sourcing and cooperative purchasing
for others; cooperative advertising and marketing services; administration of
programs to promote economic and business development projects in agricultural
and farming communities; business management consultation in the fields of
farming, agriculture, commercial motor fuel, retail propane services, grain
marketing, livestock and livestock feed production; business management
assistance in the establishment and operation of farms and co-ops; providing
business information to agricultural communities and community-based
organizations; business consultation services in the field of cooperative
business development relating to agriculture and farming. FIRST USE: 20060000.

Filing Date: June 27, 2014

Date of registration: February 17, 2015

First Use in Commerce: 2006

                             697 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                              The Washington Post

                    June 15, 1988, Wednesday, Final Edition

Drought Hurting Crops, USDA Secretary Says;
Lyng Calls Disaster Predictions Premature

BYLINE: Ward Sinclair, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: FIRST SECTION; PAGE A3

LENGTH: 678 words


Extreme heat and lack of rain have devastated crops in some parts of the
country, but Agriculture Secretary Richard E. Lyng told a nervous Senate
committee yesterday that it is too early to predict a weather disaster for
American farmers.

In a meeting with the Senate Agriculture Committee, Lyng said that "very, very
serious drought" has affected production in the northern tier of states and in
isolated pockets in the South and in the eastern Corn Belt.

"It has been disastrous in some places," Lyng said, "but it is a little bit too
soon to say the country is facing a grim disaster."

The dry, hot spring in northern agricultural areas has made grain markets edgy,
sent futures prices inching upward in some cases, caused fears of higher food
costs for consumers and touched off a wave of calls from Capitol Hill for Lyng
to provide federal aid to farmers whose crops may be stricken.

Lyng would not commit the administration to rubber-stamping assistance to
farmers in advance, but he agreed to join a committee task force set up by
Chairman Patrick J. Leahy (D-Vt.) to monitor the weather picture and consider
ways to channel federal help to affected farmers.

Lyng and Norton Strommen, the Agriculture Department's chief meteorologist, said
weather patterns during the next month will be critical to the corn and soybean
crops that predominate in the Midwest. "The Corn Belt is the most reliable
farming area in the world, but here in mid-June it is being threatened," Lyng
said.

Strommen said overnight rains that ended yesterday and the prospect of normal to
above-normal rainfall in the next 10 days could brighten the outlook. But, he
noted, the longer-range forecast through mid-July indicates below-normal
rainfall in the central Corn Belt and northern Rockies, with temperatures above
normal.

"The stress will continue across the central and eastern Corn Belt," he said,
"and corn is the crop coming into its most sensitive period -- the end of June
and July. Soybeans can stand the stress longer . . . . Current crop conditions
show a deterioration [of yield potential] in the last two weeks, but it is not
as great as one might suspect because of the subsoil moisture."

Data distributed by the USDA indicated that 60 percent of the wheat crop in
Montana, North Dakota and Minnesota and 40 percent in South Dakota and Indiana
was rated "poor" or "very poor" because of the weather.

At least 20 percent of the corn in Missouri, Indiana, Ohio and Michigan was
rated "poor" or "very poor," while soybeans in Indiana, Kentucky, Arkansas and
Louisiana had suffered similar damage.

Lyng and Strommen agreed with Sen. Kent Conrad (D-N.D.) that farmers and
livestock producers in North Dakota already have taken a severe hit from the
drought and heat, which Conrad said could cost farmers $ 2.7 billion in lost
federal benefits and lost sales.

"Barley and wheat production will be off 40 percent, even with rain. Pasture
conditions are the worst since 1922. The loss has already been significant . . .
. We are faced with a disaster now," Conrad said.

Lyng, however, refused to promise that the administration would provide extra
aid or guarantee subsidy payments to farmers whose crops fail. "It is the wrong
moment for the administration to be endorsing [legislation]," he said.

The secretary also rejected, for now at least, a proposal that farmers be
allowed to cut hay and graze livestock on land enrolled in the soil conservation
reserve, a program that pays farmers to idle their most erodible land for 10
years.

"If we don't move quickly, we will lose the feed value of those acres. I hope
the department will take a look and open up the reserve on a county by county
basis . . . . We're not plowing it up, it would be used on a one-time basis,"
Sen. Thomas Daschle (D-S.D.) said.

Leahy and Lyng agreed that if the weather situation remains critical, the new
task force could explore the Daschle proposal and others intended to provide
farmers with federal aid.

"The best thing for us to do is pray for rain," Lyng said.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: NATIONAL NEWS

                       Copyright 1988 The Washington Post


                             698 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                              The Washington Post

                    June 15, 1988, Wednesday, Final Edition

Drought Hurting Crops, USDA Secretary Says;
Lyng Calls Disaster Predictions Premature

BYLINE: Ward Sinclair, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: FIRST SECTION; PAGE A3

LENGTH: 678 words

"The best thing for us to do is pray for rain," Lyng said.

                                US Official News

                            December 8, 2015 Tuesday

Washington: Statement from Secretary Tom Vilsack on Updated 2015 U.S. Farm
Income Forecast

LENGTH: 426 words

DATELINE: Lahore



 Washington: United States Department of Agriculture has issued the following
news release:



  "As one growing season comes to an end and another lies on the horizon, USDA
continues to seek out new and innovative ways to expand opportunity for
America's farming families and support markets that will boost farm income.
Roughly one in three American farm products are exported, but there is
significant and as yet untapped opportunity in markets in Asia and Europe. By
the end of the year, I will have met with key leaders in those regions to
promote the benefits of the Trans-Pacific Partnership and further negotiations
on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership, as well as expanded
access in China. Expanded trade will help to drive higher commodity prices,
additional farm income and agribusiness jobs that ultimately generate more cash
flow in rural economies and support local businesses on main street.





 "Thanks to its ability to remain competitive through thick and thin, American
agriculture continues to enjoy some of the strongest years in our nation's
history, supporting and creating good-paying American jobs for millions, and
positioning the United States as a reliable supplier of high-quality goods for
domestic and foreign markets alike. Overall, today's projections provide a
snapshot of a rural America that continues to remain innovative, stable and
resilient in the aftermath of the worst animal disease outbreak in our nation's
history and as the western United States unloosens itself from the grip of
historic drought. For example, today's projections indicate a rise in specialty
crop receipts in 2015, while final farm income for 2014 was revised upward by
$1.9 billion since August and $13.5 billion since February. Today's estimates
also indicate that new 2014 Farm Bill safety net programs are working as
intended and helping producers protect their operations from changes in the
marketplace.



 "Since 2009, USDA, under President Obama, has made historic investments in
rural America and American agriculture. Two-thirds of all rural counties gained
jobs over the past year and the American economy overall has created 8 million
jobs over the past 36 months, the fastest pace since 2000. USDA and the Obama
Administration will continue to stand with America's farming families, small
businesses and rural communities as they build a brighter future for our country
on the land that they love."

                             700 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                     Belfast News Letter (Northern Ireland)

                         September 25, 2002, Wednesday

US BUYS UP $ 30M OF PORK

SECTION: FARMING LIFE; Pg. 7

LENGTH: 167 words


THE United States Government has announced that it is to buy $ 30 million
(pounds 19.5m) worth of ham, pork patties, sausage and minced pork for the
Federal school lunch programme to help pig producers, writes DAVID McCOY.

This purchase is the biggest by the Government since 1998 when it spent $ 50m
(pounds 32.4m) to try to siphon excess supplies from the market.

The United States Department of Agriculture regularly buys smaller amounts of
meats, eggs, fruit and vegetables for the Federal school lunch programme.

This purchase is the equivalent of 50 million pounds of pork products and will
bring the amount spent by the Government buying pork products this year to
almost $ 45m (pounds 29m).

Following the announcement, pig prices increased by 50 cents to $ 1 per pound.

However, futures traders were more cautious, pointing out that this would only
remove a small proportion of the excess pork from the market and, as a result,
October contract prices eased slightly.

LOAD-DATE: September 25, 2002

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUB-TYPE: PAPER

                   Copyright 2002 Century Newspapers Limited


                             701 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                            August 10, 1993, Tuesday

Goat market gets milked Fort Valley State scientists seek better products

BYLINE: By Hollis R. Towns STAFF WRITER

SECTION: STATE NEWS; Section C; Page 8

LENGTH: 601 words


Fort Valley, Ga. - In a remote section of sun-baked pasture just off the main
campus, a team of scientists at Fort Valley State College is attempting to breed
a bigger, meatier, more profitable goat.

"We're interested in producing a more efficient goat that will increase the
bottom line for farmers," said Seyoum Gelaye, director of the Georgia Goat
Research and Extension Center, about 100 miles south of Atlanta. "Goat meat is
leaner and lower in fat than beef, and goat milk is healthier than cow's milk.
The market potential for these products is enormous."

As Americans become more health conscious, scientists at Fort Valley State are
pioneering new ways to breed and raise goats that someday will result in more
products in local grocery stores and more profits for those who raise the
animals.

"We have definitely noticed an increase in the goat farming in Georgia," said
state Agriculture Commissioner Tommy Irvin. "The facility at Fort Valley State
has made a significant contribution to that industry."

Growing number of dairy farms

There were 230 milk goat farms in Georgia in 1987, the most recent year for
which the state Department of Agriculture has figures; those farms had 1,926
goats. No numbers were kept on farms producing goat meat, which is much less
popular.

But officials said the number of farms has grown in the past five years because
there is a growing market for the products. Georgia is home to more people from
countries where goat milk, steaks, barbecue and curried meat are staples.

In gourmet shops around Atlanta, premium goat cheese can cost as much as $ 6 a
pound.

"People are looking for alternatives, especially as the health consciousness
increases in the country," said Denise Wilson, spokeswoman for the American
Dairy Goat Association.

But there are challenges that must be overcome before goat products can compete
with cows. First, animals must be bred that produce more milk, or meat, to make
them cost-efficient.

Bonnie Zink, who farmed dairy goats in Loganville for several years, got out of
the business recently because she could not get enough goat milk for the cheeses
she sold.

"We never came close to meeting the demand we had," she said. "It was very
frustrating."

Education campaign considered

About a dozen scientists, research assistants and animal caretakers working with
a herd of 200 goats are attacking the problems in Fort Valley. The school soon
will start construction on a $ 700,000 research and processing plant for dairy
products including cheeses, yogurt, milk and ice cream.

Scientists are using gene-splicing techniques to breed a goat that will produce
more than a gallon of milk, Dr. Gelaye said. Cows can produce considerably more.

But goat milk has less fat and is more easily digested by the human body, and
the vitamins are more readily usable, said Thomas Terrill, forage scientist at
the goat center. Additionally, goat milk can be consumed by people who are
allergic to cow milk.

Researchers also are trying to trick the animals into breeding more than their
usual once a year. By limiting daylight hours for the animals, they have been
somewhat successful.

Even as researchers try to breed the perfect goat, industry officials and
farmers said they also must educate the public about the animal and erase
long-held myths concerning their eating habits.

And what about that pungent smell most people associate with the animals?

Well, there are certain things science can't control, Dr. Gelaye concedes.

"It comes from the buck during mating season," he said. "And to the doe, it
smells good."

LOAD-DATE: August 12, 1993

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH932240188

GRAPHIC: Facts to chew on -Goat milk is closer to human milk in composition than
that of any domesticated animal. It also is healthier and more digestible.
-Worldwide, more people drink goat milk than cow milk. -Cashmere, the fine
fabric, comes from Angora goats. -Goats were the second animal domesticated,
after the dog. -Goats don't eat tin cans, wires or shoes. In fact, they are
pickier eaters than cows or pigs. -The term "goatee" comes from the whiff of
hair under a goat's chin. -Unless confined, goats will roam 10 to 20 miles a day
out of curiosity. -A dairy goat will produce about a gallon of milk per milking,
compared to about 10 gallons for a cow. Sources: Georgia Goat Research and
Extension Center, American Dairy Goat Association Color photo from C/01: A
better goat? Schauston Miller gets attention from one of the goats at Fort
Valley State College's goat research complex where he runs the day-to-day
operations. A team of scientists is trying to produce a bigger, meatier and, of
course, more profitable goat. The market potential "is enormous," an expert
says. See article, Page C8. /LOUIE FAVORITE / Staff Color Photo: Goats are
driven into milking stations at Fort Valley State College, where scientists are
pioneering new ways to breed and raise the animals. /Photos by LOUIE FAVORITE /
Staff

                             702 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                     The Telegraph-Journal (New Brunswick)

                           January 26, 2017 Thursday

Local farming a solution to global turmoil

SECTION: Pg. A9

LENGTH: 644 words


The day before Donald Trump became the President of the United States, the
provincial agriculture minister, Rick Doucet, announced a policy for the
protection and preservation of farmland in New Brunswick, addressing a priority
issue for this province. Taken together, these two events, though unrelated,
convey a symbolic message about our perceptions of the future.The inauguration
of President Trump ushers in an era of uncertainty. The world order we have
known for decades is crumbling. The principles which have guided our society in
an interdependent world are threatened; divisive forces work to turn us against
each other.

Mass migrations of displaced populations and extreme weather events are
harbingers of change that will alter our lives forever.How do people react when
they are frightened or anxious? They head for home. Remember on 9/11 how anyone
who was away moved heaven and earth to get back? This was an extreme case, but
it illustrates the depth of our need to hunker down where we feel safest. New
crises, as yet poorly defined, lie ahead. Already people from both the west and
the south are buying property in our province. For some, it represents a
potential refuge; for others, it is an investment to take advantage of the
inevitably increasing search for security.New Brunswick holds the key to
stability in this turbulence. People need food. We can grow it. More than ever,
we need to promote and encourage farming and local food production and
consumption.Until recently, New Brunswick has neglected agriculture in favour of
exploitation of more lucrative resources. Happily, this government is shaking
off the traditional stupor and recognizing that farming may in fact be the
foundation of our future ability not only to survive but to thrive. Interest in
our farmland is growing; the Department of Agriculture now has a development
unit dedicated to attracting and retaining new farmers. We have affordable
farmland available. We have immigrants who want to put down roots here; we have
a generation of young people who are attracted to local farming.
Back-to-the-land movements have occurred throughout history. Most recently,
Greeks have been streaming back to their agricultural villages because of high
unemployment in the cities; today in Canada young people are returning to the
land in part because it offers the opportunity for a future with a sustainable
lifestyle and meaningful purpose.Political, economic and social trends favour
the growth of farming in New Brunswick, both the big commercial agricultural
units and the locally-focused production of healthy food. The wave is coming. We
must be prepared.The new policy points out that agricultural land is a finite,
non-renewable resource that cannot be replaced once lost to development. It is
the backbone of all agricultural activities. Clearing new land is expensive; it
takes many years of careful husbandry to bring land to a productive state.
Therefore, existing farmland must be protected from loss due to encroachment and
topsoil stripping, and new land must be brought into development for long-term
agricultural use. Such a policy provides a foundation which protects investment
in farmland from conflicting pressures, and creates opportunities for growth in
both domestic and export markets, as well as value-added products. Equally
important, this policy provides clarity for planners, developers and owners
regarding what is valuable and necessary for a sustainable agricultural land
base.In an unpredictable world, it is reassuring that we recognize the security
offered by our undervalued farmland asset. While New Brunswick may currently be
perceived by others as the country bumpkin of Canada, the future is heading our
way. We should believe it, and be ready.Sue Rickards is a social policy analyst.

                             703 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                      Saint Paul Pioneer Press (Minnesota)

                     September 12, 2003 Friday CITY EDITION

FEDERAL CROP COUNT CRITICIZED
FARMERS, AG EXPERTS SAY FULL IMPACT OF DROUGHT ISN'T TALLIED

BYLINE: LEE EGERSTROMPioneer Press

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. C1

LENGTH: 697 words


Farmers, state agricultural officials and industry analysts said Thursday that
federal projections for this year's corn and soybean harvests are probably too
high because they don't account for the full impact of the Upper Midwest's
prolonged drought.

In its September harvest forecast, the U.S. Department of Agriculture estimated
Thursday that the nationwide corn crop will be only 1 percent less than a year
ago, and the soybean crop will be down by 8 percent from last year. Large
harvests in the eastern half of the United States should offset drought-affected
smaller crops in Minnesota, Wisconsin and Iowa, the USDA said.

But farmers and analysts were quick to discount yield estimates for the Upper
Midwest states, where drought conditions have worsened since Sept. 1 -- when
government field inspectors visited corn, soybean and sugarbeet fields to
prepare their monthly harvest forecast.

"We'll know a lot more for the Oct. 10 (USDA) forecast because the harvest will
be well under way in another three weeks," said Mike Hunst, state statistician
with the Minnesota Agricultural Statistics Service. Hunst said field conditions
have deteriorated since the Sept. 1 survey. Better data will be found later this
month when farmers start harvesting corn and soybeans that are quickly drying in
their fields.

Minnesota Agriculture Commissioner Gene Hugoson, a farmer in Martin County along
the Iowa border, said weather and crop conditions are different in isolated
locales across the state. Some Minnesota farmers may pull in near-normal crops,
he said, while 10 miles away other farmers will see the worst crops of their
careers.

Hugoson said the harvest will fall short of Thursday's forecast, even though not
all farms are as drought-stressed as those in east-central Minnesota, around the
Twin Cities and in parts of southeastern Minnesota. He visited with farmers in
northwestern and west-central Minnesota on Thursday and saw crops ranging from
normal to destroyed, he said.

Based on field surveys of 11 days ago, the USDA offered a Minnesota corn
forecast of more than 989 million bushels, down only about 60 million bushels
from a year ago, with a yield estimated at 151 bushels per acre -- only a six
bushels per acre drop from last year's bountiful harvest. An acre is a measure
of land about the size of a football field.

Minnesota's soybean harvest was forecast at 277.5 million bushels, down from
308.9 million bushels a year ago, and the yield was estimated at 37 bushels per
acre, a drop from an average of 43.5 bushels per acre a year ago.

While drought conditions are widespread across the western half of Wisconsin and
spread eastward in late August and early September, forecasters said they expect
a Wisconsin corn crop to be off only four bushels an acre from a year ago, and a
soybean harvest that should yield 36 bushels an acre, down from 44 bushels
harvested last year.

The stronger-than-expected harvest forecasts in the Upper Midwest come after the
USDA's Farm Service Agency in Minnesota already has certified that there have
been crop losses of at least 30 percent in one or more fall-harvested crops in
49 of Minnesota's 87 counties.

Farmers have started combining dry cornfields in southern Wisconsin counties,
and they aren't finding the 131 bushels an acre that was the statewide average
forecast, said Dan Undersander, an extension agronomist at the University of
Wisconsin.

Peter Georgantones, a commodities trader and analyst with Investment Trading
Service in Bloomington, said the soybean crop has suffered more drought damage
than corn. He said the USDA forecasted yields are higher than private estimates
and what grain traders expect will be harvested this year.

Soybean futures traded at the Chicago Board of Trade soared in Thursday trading,
gaining more than 7 percent on most future months contracts as traders responded
to USDA's forecast of less soybean production. Prices for corn futures traded in
Chicago fell 4 cents to 9 cents per bushel as the government forecasted a larger
corn harvest than traders expected.

Lee Egerstrom can be reached at legerstrom@pioneerpress.com or 651-228-5437.

                             704 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

               November 1, 1981, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

NEW YORK STATE DECLARED FREE OF LEADING LIVESTOCK DISEASE

BYLINE: By HAROLD FABER

SECTION: Section 1; Part 2; Page 64, Column 3; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 572 words


For the first time since records have been kept, state officials say New York is
free of brucellosis, an infectious animal disease that is the leading health
problem in the livestock industry of the United States.

''We are down to zero infection,'' said Dr. Harold E. Nadler, director of the
division of animal industry of the State Department of Agriculture and Markets.

Dr. Nadler said that the last infected herd of cows had been destroyed last year
in St. Lawrence County and that no further cases had been been reported since
then. If the disease-free status continues until the end of the year, New York
will be certified on Jan. 1 as a brucellosis-free state by the United States
Department of Agriculture.

New York is the only state among the four top dairy states in the nation - the
others are Wisconsin, California and Minnesota - to achieve this status, said J.
Roger Barber, the Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets. ''Because of this,
New York dairy cows can be shipped anywhere in the nation and the world without
fear of quarantine,'' he said. ''It is a big advantage to our dairy industry.''

No Known Cure for Disease

Brucellosis, which is a bacterial infection with no known cure, is sometimes
called Bang's disease. It affects dairy and beef animals, causing the premature
birth of calves and a reduction in milk production. Exposure to the disease can
sometimes cause undulant fever in humans, but there are few cases of that
reported.

''Brucellosis is very definitely the No. 1 disease problem for the livestock
industry of the United States,'' said Sidney Moore, a spokesman for the United
States Department of Agriculture in Washington. ''Our objective is to be rid of
the disease by 1987.''

He said that the financial losses to farmers and cattle raisers from the disease
in 1979, the last year for which figures are available, were $44.5 million. He
also said that the costs of eradication and of preventing the spread of the
disease were about $30 million a year for the industry and $118 million a year
for the Federal and state governments.

As of Sept. 31, there were 7,622 beef and dairy herds - of a total of 1.6
million herds - in the United States infected with brucellosis. By far the
largest incidence of the disease was reported in Southern states with large beef
herds. Florida had the highest percentage of cases, with 1,029 of 21,000 herds,
or 4.9 percent, infected.

Jersey Also to Be Certified

Ten states reported no sign of the disease - Alaska, Connecticut, Delaware,
Hawaii, Michigan, New Hampshire, New Jersey, North Dakota, South Carolina and
Vermont - in addition to New York.

In New Jersey, the last infected herd was destroyed on Sept. 28 in Salem County,
according to Dr. Robert Horton of the State Department of Agriculture in
Trenton, thus qualifying the state for listing at the end of the month. If the
zero infection rate continues for a year, New Jersey, too, will be certified as
brucellosis-free, he said.

In Connecticut, the last infected herd was destroyed in July 1980 in Kent. Since
then, according to Dr. George Sturges, the state veterinarian, in Hartford, the
state has been brucellosis-free and expects to be certified as such on Jan. 1,
along with New York.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1981 The New York Times Company

                                Daily Times (PK)

                           January 28, 2015 Wednesday

USDA, American Soybean Association launch handbook

LENGTH: 324  words

DATELINE: KARACHI


KARACHI, Jan. 28 -- United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) and American
Soybean Association officially launched 'Aquaculture Handbook- Fish Farming and
Nutrition in Pakistan'. US and Pakistani scientists jointly wrote the handbook
as part of an ongoing USDA effort to expand farmed-fish yields and farmer
incomes through better fish feeding and management practices. US Consul General
Brian Heath, Sindh Minister for Livestock and Fisheries Jam Khan Shoro,
Fisheries Development Board CEO Faisal Iftikhar, USDA Project Manager Otto
Gonzalez, Aquaculture Handbook Editor Kevin Fitzsimmons and American Soybean
Association Country Director R S N Janjua attended the event.

Coastal and inland fish farming present an opportunity to make seafood available
to more consumers at more reasonable prices, while generating additional income
for Pakistan's farmers, said Heath. The US is helping Pakistani farmers make
better use of water resources, providing an impetus for supply chain
development, and generating demand for fish feed. More important, an increase in
the supply of farmed fish and expands the availability of protein for Pakistan's
young and growing population, he added. Since 2011, USDA's Aquaculture Project
has helped train hundreds of farmers through field demonstrations, seminars, and
one-on-one site visits. U.S. and Pakistani experts have also helped a local feed
manufacturer establish production of high-quality fish feed using
soybean-derived ingredients, providing farmers with a ready supply of feed. USDA
and US for International Development projects increase farmer incomes and
livelihoods by fighting animal and plant diseases, transferring technology,
developing marketing systems, and efficiently utilising water.

respect to this article or any other content requirement, please contact Editor
at htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                             June 8, 1978 Thursday

Sugar prices

BYLINE: GAM

LENGTH: 106 words


U.S. Agriculture Secretary Bob Bergland has announced that government
 sugar price supports will be raised about 8.5 per cent for the 1978 crop
 of sugar beets and sugar cane under a formula required by law.

Mr. Bergland said the preliminary support rate for refined beet sugar
 will be 16.9 cents a pound, up from 15.57 cents in 1977. The support for
 raw cane sugar will be 14.65 cents a pound, up from 13.5 cents.

The supports are preliminary and can be adjusted later. By law, the
 U.S. Department of Agriculture must support sugar prices at no less than
 52.5 per cent of the July parity price for sugar, a formula reflecting
 production costs.

                               The New York Times

                  July 13, 1990, Friday, Late Edition - Final

Crop Outlook Is Mixed

BYLINE: Reuters

SECTION: Section D; Page 6, Column 6; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 95 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 12


Supplies of corn and soybeans appear tight, while wheat supplies are swelling
with a big harvest, the Agriculture Department reported today in its monthly
crop report.

The Government said wheat farmers would produce 2.7 billion bushels, up about
one-third from last year, while it said corn farmers would produce 7.85 billion
bushels and soybean farmers would produce 1.86 billion.

Much of the wheat crop has already been harvested and the Government conducted
field surveys to assess the rest, so that estimate is expected to be close to
the actual crop size.

                          The Capital (Annapolis, MD)

                            March 23, 2013 Saturday

State launches farming TV show

SECTION: B; Pg.12

LENGTH: 125  words


ANNAPOLIS - There's a new farming show coming to Maryland Public Television this
fall.

"The Maryland Farmer" is a half-hour program produced by MPT and the Maryland
Department of the Agriculture.

The 13-episode series will showcase Maryland farmers with the goal of closing
the "understanding gap" between farmers and consumers, according to the
Department of Agriculture.

The TV show is sponsored by a number of pro-farming organizations and charities,
including groups that represent grain farmers, chicken farmers, dairy farmers
and grape growers. The Harford County government also is a sponsor.

The executive producer is Michael English, who also produces MPT's popular
"Outdoors Maryland" show and is a former editor of the Maryland Farmer
newspaper.

                             709 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                                  Farming Life

                           October 21, 2015 Wednesday

TTIP agreement high on agenda at Congress

LENGTH: 507  words


Tomorrow (Thursday) will see farming organisations from across Europe and North
America gather in Templepatrick to assess the possible implications of the
pending Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) agreement.

These discussions will take place under the aegis of the 37th North American -
European Union Agricultural Policy Congress.

This is the first time that the event has been held in Northern Ireland: the
Ulster Farmers' Union is the hosting body.

Union Chief Executive Wesley Aston confirmed that the congress will allow
farming leaders from both sides of the Atlantic to highlight their hopes and
concerns for the envisaged TTIP arrangements.

"Europe is totally committed to opening up new trade agreements with all of the
world's major economies," he said.

"In my opinion TTIP will, almost certainly, become a reality at some stage in
the not too distant future. The EU has recently agreed a comprehensive trade
deal with Canada. So it makes strategic sense for Brussels to look at securing
similar arrangements with the United States."

Aston regards potential US beef imports into Europe as the biggest threat to
Northern Ireland under a TTIP agreement.

"Red meat is at the very heart of the agri economy here in Northern Ireland," he
said.

"And we export the vast bulk of the beef we produce to GB and the rest of
Europe. So it is crucially important that the final TTIP agreement does not harm
the prospects of livestock farmers in this part of the world."

But Aston also confirmed that a trade deal with the United States would present
Northern Ireland's agri food sector with significant exporting opportunities.

"And, obviously, we want to capitalise on these," he stressed.

"Only a very small proportion of the food that we produce is exported to the
United States at the present time and anything that can be done to improve this
situation is a good news story for farmers here in Northern Ireland."

The hosting of the Transatlantic congress coincides with the confirmation that
Canada has reopened its market for imports of European beef from 19 EU member
states.

The Canadian market has been closed to any EU beef, including deboned beef,
since 1996, when Canada introduced import restrictions on meat of ruminants on
the basis of BSE concerns.

The 19 Member States that have now been authorised to resume exports are the
same that had access to the Canadian market before the BSE ban came into force -
they are Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Czech Republic, Denmark, Finland, France,
Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Luxembourg, The Netherlands, Portugal,
Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden and the United Kingdom.

Commenting on this recent development EU Commissioner for Agriculture Phil Hogan
said: "We welcome the decision by the Canadian government to re-open Canada's
market for imports of European beef from 19 EU Member States.

"It will provide a welcome boost to Europe's beef producers and exporters,
particularly as it comes at a time when farmers across the EU are going through
a particularly difficult period."

                             710 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                              May 29, 1989 Monday

Biodynamic agriculture catching on in the U.S.

BYLINE: MARTIN MITTELSTAEDT; GAM

LENGTH: 1612 words

DATELINE: KIMBERTON, Pa.


As health-conscious consumers become more concerned about what's in the
food they eat, organic farming is slowly moving in from the fringes of the
U.S. farm industry. The trend to what is called biodynamic farming could
reshape U.S. agriculture.
 BY  MARTIN MITTELSTAEDT
 Globe and Mail Correspondent
  KIMBERTON, Pa.

In the fields of sprouting vegetables around farmer Kerry Sullivan, an
agricultural revolution is underfoot.

The rich soil of this farm near Philadelphia hasn't had an application
of commercial fertilizers or pesticides in eight years. On a normal market
garden, that would be a recipe for disaster. Weeds would choke the few
sickly plants struggling to overcome insect infestations - or so
conventional wisdom predicts.

Yet this land is flourishing.

Mr. Sullivan, 33, is a pioneer in the movement toward low-input,
sustainable agriculture, what used to be called organic farming . Several
years ago, farming without modern chemicals was the preserve of hippies
and back-to-the-land eccentrics. But today, with consumer concern about
pesticides widespread, a far-reaching reappraisal is under way at the farm
gate.

Mr. Sullivan is a practitioner of biodynamic farming, perhaps the cream
of the alternative agriculture movement. His farming techniques involve
spreading plenty of compost on the land, along with diluted sprays of cow
manure. All chemical pesticides are taboo, and crop rotation is developed
into a fine art.

'I was basically one of those who said, 'Give me a break. I'm not  going to try
this,' ' Mr. Sullivan recollected of his first exposure to  biodynamic farming.
Now he's an avid supporter, saying, 'When I saw the  results, I began to wonder
what was behind it.'     Most U.S. farmers are still wedded to conventional
methods, using large  volumes of synthetic fertilizers and chemicals to control
insects, weeds  and fungi. Probably fewer than 1 per cent are now organic.

But there is a stirring of interest in sustainable agriculture that
didn't exist as recently as three years ago. For instance, the Natural
Organic Farmers Association of New York has 68 farms applying this year to
be certified organic. Last year it was only 36.

'The program has doubled every year. Next year we're looking at 150,'  said
David Stern, an official at the organization.

California Certified Organic Farmers has more than 450 members and the
acreage of its farmers has more than quadrupled since 1985 to 31,000
acres. Other U.S. sustainable agriculture groups report similar increases.

If the trend gains further momentum, it could completely reshape U.S.
farming, the most chemically intensive anywhere. At stake is a $7-billion
(U.S.) annual market for pesticides and an equally large synthetic
fertilizer market.

At the New York produce markets, something of a national trend setter,
many farmers are thinking of switching to organic methods for the first
time.

'This year I've talked to five growers who are looking at it more  seriously.
Some I would have never guessed,' said Tony Mannetta,  assistant director of
Greenmarket, a group that organizes produce markets  at 18 New York locations.

In the past, he said, some farmers had a 'machismo attitude about
chemicals.' But no longer. Among New York's health-conscious food buyers,
an organic label often means higher prices and good demand.

'In the last couple of years, (farmers) have seen the handwriting on  the wall
in terms of what customers want and are willing to take a stab at  it,' Mr.
Mannetta said.

One such farmer is Frank Stiles, who operates a 200-acre fruit and
vegetable operation in southern New Jersey. Most of his produce is
destined for fresh New York markets and he's in the second year of weaning
his farm from chemicals.

'You start to wonder if there is a better way, an easier way' of  farming, he
said of his decision. 'Why do you want to handle this stuff  (pesticides) if you
don't have to?'     Mr. Stiles, 47, farmed conventionally for almost 20 years,
and the  change to new techniques presents difficulties. For instance, it's much
more labor-intensive. He has bought 800 tons of chicken manure and 500  tons of
leaf mulch for fertilizer, an enormous bulk that requires plenty  of work to
apply to the fields.

With soluble fertilizers, 'one person could spread an acre in 10
minutes,' and he worries that if more people catch the sustainable
agriculture bug, the price of chicken manure 'will go out of sight.'
Insects are also a problem. Last year, he spent $4,000 paying laborers to
hand pluck pesky Colorado potato beetles from plants.

With higher labor costs eating into the premium prices organic produce
commands, most farmers adopting sustainable agriculture are not doing so
with hopes of making big money.

Mr. Stern of the Natural Organic Farmers Association said a far-
reaching philosophical change generally accompanies a conversion to
organic farming. These farmers typically adopt attitudes of agricultural
stewardship, viewing the soil, with its countless micro-organisms and
earthworms, as a living system that must be nurtured to produce good-
tasting, healthy crops.

Reverence for nature is in, opposition to it is out.

Organic farmers definitely talk glowingly about dirt. Walter Pedersen
began a winery in 1976 at Himrod, N.Y., converting land that had been
farmed chemically for decades. 'You have to put in a lot of energy
initially, bringing the soil back to life,' he said.

As well, many farmers are beginning to have the same health fears about
exposure to chemicals so common recently among food buyers. 'A lot of
young farmers have buried their moms and dads and have a great deal of
suspicion about chemical use,' said Mr. Stern, who grows vegetables and
blueberries organically at his farm near Rose, N.Y.

The comment was echoed by viticulturist Mr. Pedersen. 'We would never
think of using anything that said on the back to keep it away from
children and wear a rubber suit.'
   In the end, though, economics will probably decide whether sustainable
agriculture remains a backwater or moves further into the mainstream.
Although organic farms have lower pesticide and fertilizer bills, much of
this gain is eaten up by added labor intensity, practitioners say.

At New York greenmarkets, organic produce typically commands a premium
of 25 to 30 per cent, but not everyone is biting the higher prices.

New Jersey farmer Mr. Stiles has found that in some city markets, such
as in front of the World Trade Center near Wall Street, interest among the
investment banking crowd for pricey organic food is low. But a few streets
away, near trendy Greenwich Village, 'They're gung-ho.'
   Concluded Mr. Stiles of his switchover: 'I don't think in the long run
we'll make any more money' compared to traditional methods.

Still, many farmers find organic status confers a competitive edge. Mr.
Pedersen said his winery's potential customers typically imbibe imported
French wines. 'New York City is almost a province of France, rather than
part of the United States,' he said. With this formidable competition,
the organic label allows him to charge premium prices and gain a marketing
advantage over other domestics.

In Kimberton, biodynamic farmer Mr. Sullivan is part of an experiment
in community-supported agriculture that entirely eliminates the vagaries
of selling fresh produce at market. A group of 100 families, each pledging
to pay $320 up front, share equally in the output from his 10-acre garden
plot. Last year, each family received fresh, pesticide-free vegetables
from May to December that would have cost more than $500 at the local
supermarket. Currently, 25 families are on a waiting list to join.

There are about a dozen such food-growing experiments under way in the
United States.

'It's great. There is no marketing to do except for right early in  that you're
trying to get the full membership,' Mr. Sullivan said  recently while harvesting
collard that had survived the mild winter and  was luxuriating in the gentle
spring sunshine.

At next door Seven Stars Farm, also a biodynamic operation, milk from a
herd of 55 purebred Guernsey and Jersey cows is turned into yogurt and
sold at an organic food store on the premises, which doubled its business
last year. The balance is sold at health food stores along the U.S. East
Coast.

Yogurt is simple to make, and allows a farmer to capture some of the
profits built into the modern food processing system, an important point
for economic survival. 'Yogurt is one of those things that we are able to
get making inexpensively,' said 34-year-old farm manager David Griffiths.

Biodynamic techniques, imbued with an almost spiritual hue, are based
on the idea of farms as self-sufficient systems that build and maintain
soil fertility through farm-produced composts. Animals, plants and the
soil are seen in a larger context, and not simply as agribusiness tools.
(In Canada, there are about 30 biodynamic farms, with a cluster in
Quebec's Eastern Townships and another in Southwestern Ontario near Lake
Huron.)
   On its face, sustainable agriculture can be expected to make inroads.
'Ninety-five per cent of it is just good farming practices,' explained
Rod Shouldice, a spokesman for the Biodynamic Farming and Gardening
Association Inc. in Kimberton. Crop rotation, composting and careful
attention to soil fertility have always marked good farming.

Mr. Shouldice spoke confidently of the number of sustainable
practitioners soon reaching a 'critical mass' that will sweep like
wildfire through U.S. fields and orchards, finishing the two-generation
experiment with chemical fertilizers and pesticides.

'The end of chemical agriculture,' Mr. Shouldice predicted, 'is just  around the
corner.'                NEXT: Booming business for natural pesticides.

LOAD-DATE: January 10, 2007

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


 Copyright 1989 The Globe and Mail, a division of CTVglobemedia Publishing Inc.
                              All Rights Reserved


                             711 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                       San Jose Mercury News (California)

                            March 12, 2014 Wednesday

Berkeley urban farming nonprofit poised to grow

BYLINE: By Damin Esper Correspondent

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 645 words


BERKELEY -- Urban Adamah, a nonprofit educational organization promoting urban
farming, has purchased 2.2 acres of land in Berkeley from the United States
Postal Service. The land, on Sixth Street at Harrison, will give the group a
permanent home.

The organization, founded in January 2011, currently farms on one acre of leased
land at San Pablo Avenue and Parker Street.

"Because we're going to have more space on the land, we hope we can grow a wider
variety of vegetables," program associate Zach Friedman said.

The lease for the current farmland runs through the end of the year, so Urban
Adamah probably won't begin farming the new land until then. The new land is
vacant, although Friedman said it was once set aside for housing during World
War II and some foundations are still present.

The land was used to store rail cars as well.

According to Friedman, the post office purchased the land from UC Berkeley in
the 1990s.

The north side boundary is Codornices Creek.

Urban Adamah is beginning its fourth year of operations. Adamah means earth in
Hebrew. Urban Adamah integrates Jewish traditions with sustainable agriculture,
mindfulness and social action. The group's website says its work is inspired by
the core values of ahava (love), hesed (compassion) and tzedek (justice). The
original idea for a farm-based residential leadership program was created in
Falls Village, Conn.

Three-month fellowships are open to young adults ages 21 to 31. The fellows live
in a house together and work the farm. They also receive training in
anti-oppression and social justice. The program typically hosts 12 to 14 fellows
at a time, although with the larger property, that could increase.

The farm also hosts agricultural classes that are open to the community. School
groups visit the farm, and summer camps are open to children entering preschool
up through fifth grade.

During the school year, the farm even hosts Hebrew school.

"We partner with local temples and synagogues," Friedman said. "They send their
Hebrew school students to our farm once a week in the fall and summer. We run
Hebrew school for the kids focused on the natural world."

Urban Adamah also hosts various religious services, including Shabbat services
and a Hanukkah celebration, as well as Havdalah dance parties.

Vegetables grown on the farm are distributed for free at a weekly farm stand on
the property at 11 a.m. each Wednesday. Produce includes kale, collards,
mustards, arugula, chard, tomatoes, cucumbers, squashes, corn, radishes and
turnips. With more land, that could grow to include broccoli and cabbage,
according to Friedman.

Urban Adamah also has fruit trees on its land, as well as a flock of chickens,
some bees and three goats.

Urban farming has become popular in recent years as activists have begun
advocating what they claim is a healthier, more sustainable and local source for
food, rather than from giant agriculture businesses.

Not far from Urban Adamah's future home, activists have been fighting to stop a
planned development on University of California-owned land along San Pablo in
Albany, calling for it to be used for an urban farm. Appeals challenging the
mixed-use development were rejected by the Albany City Council last week.

In Berkeley, the Edible Schoolyard project teaches children about growing food
through hands-on work on an urban farm.

"There's definite similarities with what we do," Friedman said. "We're
passionate about growing food in an urban environment. We'd be thrilled about
more urban farms sprouting up around the Bay Area. We're focused on growing the
community around our farm.

"For thousands of years, there's a strong connection between agriculture and
food and people. We've lost that, especially recently. It's important to me
because I derive a lot of satisfaction from growing my own food, having food
that's fresh and growing closer to the land."

---

LOAD-DATE: March 12, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                           The Aberdeen Times (Idaho)

  This content, including derivations, may not be stored or distributed in any
  manner, disseminated, published, broadcast, rewritten or reproduced without
                      express, written consent from STPNS

                                 March 28, 2012

A farm bill for the future;
Guest Comment

BYLINE: The Aberdeen Times staff

LENGTH: 335  words


House and Senate Agriculture Committees are already holding hearings on writing
a new farm bill. However, past farm bills demonstrate that we must demand more
of Congress; we must demand a farm bill that invests in the future of rural
communities and the next generation of family farmers and ranchers.

On March 19, the National Sustainable Agriculture Coalition and Center for Rural
Affairs released a 2012 Farm Bill policy platform entitled Farming for the
Future, A Sustainable Agriculture Agenda for the 2012 Food and Farm Bill.

It includes proposals to strengthen family farming and ranching, and assist
beginning farmers and ranchers. These policies, if advanced, will help smaller
producers tap into high-value, niche markets; provide access to land and capital
for the next generation of farmers and ranchers; level the playing field by
capping subsidies to mega-farms and invest in real family farmers and ranchers.

The entire platform spans nearly every section of the farm bill and constitutes
a comprehensive approach to reforming federal farm and food policies that will
create jobs and economic growth, drive innovation for farm and food
entrepreneurs, enhance conservation, protect our natural resources and invest in
the future of rural America.

We cannot continue to follow the failed farm policies of the past. Rural America
wants, needs and deserves a better farm bill, one that creates a future for
America's rural places and the people that live there. Farming for the Future
contains a best first step at making reform a reality.

The Center for Rural Affairs was established in 1973 as an unaffiliated
nonprofit corporation under IRS code 501(c)3. The Center for Rural Affairs was
formed by rural Ne-braskans concerned about family farms and rural communities,
and we work to strengthen small businesses, family farms and ranches, and rural
communities.

Crabgrass can grow on bowling balls in airless rooms, and there is no known way
to kill it that does not involve nuclear weapons. Dave Barry

                                The Toronto Star

                    October 1, 1985, Tuesday, FINAL EDITION

Soviet wheat purchases fall short of U.S. pact

BYLINE: REUTER

SECTION: BUSINESS TODAY; Pg. F5

LENGTH: 327 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


   WASHINGTON (Reuter) - For the first time in 10 years, the Soviet Union has
failed to meet its annual minimum wheat purchase requirement under the
U.S.-Soviet grain pact, American agriculture department officials say.

The officials said yesterday the Soviet Union remained 1.1 million tonnes short
of its commitment under the five-year accord signed in 1983 to buy and take
delivery of 4 million tonnes of U.S. wheat in each year ending Sept. 30.

"This is the first time that anything this clear has happened," one U.S.
official said. "They had a reputation as being one of our most reliable buyers."

Bountiful harvests

In a year of bountiful wheat harvests worldwide, the U.S. officials said Soviet
representatives had told them they felt under no obligation to honor the pact
because American wheat prices are higher than those of many other suppliers.

Agriculture department officials acknowledged that Moscow has been able to buy
cheaper wheat from such suppliers as Canada, Argentina, the European Economic
Community and Australia.

"The Soviets are interpreting the (grain) agreement slightly differently than we
are," a U.S. official said.

Under the 1983 agreement, grain will be purchased "at the market price
prevailing for these products at the time of purchase."

U.S. officials said that means prevailing U.S. prices, while Soviet officials
have said it means world prices.

Western experts in the Soviet Union, saying good weather in key areas had
improved the quality of Soviet crops, predicted a better grain harvest and less
need for imports this year.

They said Soviet grain import needs this year would be 37 million tonnes, down
from 55 million in 1984-85.

Fewer suppliers

The Soviet Union has purchased almost four times its corn commitment this year.
There are fewer worldwide suppliers of corn than of wheat.

The United States and the Soviet Union have traded grain under formal agreements
since 1975.

LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1999

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                  Copyright 1985 Toronto Star Newspapers, Ltd.

                            Sidney Herald (Montana)

  This content, including derivations, may not be stored or distributed in any
  manner, disseminated, published, broadcast, rewritten or reproduced without
                      express, written consent from STPNS

                                December 3, 2014

Richey student writes article regarding areas changes

BYLINE: Sidney Herald staff

LENGTH: 536  words


URBAN SPRAWL

Two acres of farmland are lost every minute (Becker). By the time you finish
reading this, eight acres are potentially no longer usable.

Why is farmland being lost? Some of it is due to natural disasters. However,
most of it is lost because of urban sprawl, or the expansion of cities and towns
to accommodate more people. One local example of this is in and around Sidney,
Montana.

Sidney has increased in size, especially within the past five years. This change
can be positive or negative depending on who you are, what you visualize as
being "good" or "bad", or what your occupation is.

Some of the aspects about Sidney expanding are positive. For example, there are
more places to shop and buy groceries; there are also a few more places to eat.
However, these luxuries come with a price for some people. The problem is this:
To where can the town expand? The only logical answer to this question is to on
the farmland that is surrounding the town.

Understandably, it's great real estate to develop because it's flat and already
accessible by roads. On the other hand, town expansion takes land away from a
group of very important people: the farmers.

Farming is a major source of income for many people in Sidney and the
surrounding area. In fact, farming is a major occupation in the state of Montana
itself, with over 29,300 farms and ranches in the state. This being said, it's
ironic how as the population of towns like Sidney increases, the more there is a
demand for food production and agriculture, yet urban expansion takes away from
food production and agriculture. This leaves farmers faced with problems such as
owning enough land to generate revenue to provide for their families and to
provide food for the world.

Luckily, farmers and other people involved with agriculture are improving
farming practices to get better yields from crops and to use less acreage while
doing so. For instance, many farmers use Global Positioning Systems (GPS) to
maximize their efficiency by reducing overlap on fields. Having very little
overlap on fields saves fuel, seed, chemicals, and fertilizer, allowing the
farmer to lower expenses.

Another example of improved farming practices is no-till farming. This also
saves farmers money because it reduces the amount of times they need to travel
over fields. With these practices, farmers can improve their yields on crops,
but urban expansion still poses a threat to farmers by reducing the amount of
acres they can use.

Sidney, along with other towns and cities in Montana and the United States, are
undeniably expanding to accommodate more people. For example, Bozeman, located
in the fastest growing county in Montana, Gallatin County, has increased by
about 25,000 people in 12 years. With this many people coming in, several miles
of road have to be paved through farmland, and hundreds of houses and buildings
need to be built on top of the land that used to earn farmers a living. In the
end, the farmers that produce our food have to sacrifice their land, the land
that they have been farming for generations.

If cities continue to expand, which they will, farmers will someday be left with
only a handful of acres of farmland to feed several billion people.

LOAD-DATE: March 5, 2016

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Education

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: SID

                               All Rights Reserved
                             SmallTownPapers, Inc.
                          Copyright 2014 Sidney Herald


                             715 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                             July 7, 1994, Thursday

THE FLOOD OF '94: SPECIAL REPORT IN BRIEF Acres of corn, peanuts, other crops
underwater

SECTION: STATE NEWS; Section C; Page 6

LENGTH: 614 words


What started out as Georgia's best agricultural summer in years may end up one
of its worst.

"There are thousands of acres of cropland underwater," said state Agriculture
Commissioner Tommy Irvin. "Everyone has been affected in some way."

In Randolph County, as many as 20,000 acres of peanuts were underwater Wednesday
morning, the state said. In Terrell, 15,000 acres of peanuts were underwater,
and 21,000 acres were underwater in Sumter County. Also in Sumter, 19,000 acres
of cotton and 10,000 acres of corn were reported flooded. And catfish farmers in
Middle Georgia have watched their stock washed out of ponds by the storm.

Because of flooded roads, farmers are having difficulty trucking their goods to
market, said Agriculture Department spokeswoman Lisa Ray. Several dairy farmers
have begun dumping milk they have no room to store, and the state's fruit and
vegetable farmers are concerned that produce now on trees and in packing houses
will soon perish.

Trucks carrying produce to Harry's Farmers Market stores in Atlanta were
stranded on I-75 near the Florida border, the company said.

-BIG BITES FOR GAME FISH: Fisheries biologists in the Georgia Wildlife Resources
Division said many game fish and panfish in central and southern regions of the
state will benefit from the flooding conditions because of the great abundance
of nutrients, worms, terrestrial insects and other food.

"Those fish will feed in the flooded woods," said state fisheries biologist Les
Ager of Fort Valley. "It's like being thrown into the midst of a moving grocery
line."

But when the floodwaters begin receding, numerous fish will be trapped in
low-lying areas and big potholes, and some will die, said Ager, regional
fisheries supervisor of the state Wildlife Resources Division.

-POSTAL SERVICE CURTAILED: The U.S. Postal Service, supposedly undeterred by
rain, sleet, snow, or dark of night, has been waylaid by the weather in Middle
Georgia. Floodwaters that have cut off Macon and left some streets as much as 30
feet underwater have curtailed mail processing operations in that city and
limited deliveries in several city ZIP codes. As a result, mail normally
processed in Macon will be processed and held in Atlanta until the roads are
open. Mail destined for Valdosta will be processed in Jacksonville. Currently,
there are more than 60 post offices in South Georgia that have not received
processed mail from Macon as they normally would.

-RAILROAD TRACKS WASHED OUT: Flooding in Georgia, Alabama and the Florida
Panhandle ruptured three major railroad lines stretching from Panama City to
Macon that are owned by the Richmond-based CSX Corp. Railroad workers were
struggling to repair 30 washouts on a major north- south line from Peachtree
City to Manchester in Meriwether County that will close the heavily traveled
track for at least a week, CSX spokesman Jay Westbrook said today.

"It's a very serious situation for us," Westbrook said. Rail operations were
suspended along all three rail lines, affecting the schedule of the Amtrak
Sunset Limited from Los Angeles to Miami.

So far, no bridges have been washed away on the railroad's main line through
Georgia. But Westbrook said 12 bridges along a 20-mile stretch through the
Florida Panhandle are threatened by floodwaters.

In Dothan, Ala., a railroad crew abandoned a locomotive during a flash flood
just minutes before the water lifted it from the track and washed it down an
embankment, Westbrook said.

CSX trains are being rerouted along the East Coast to bypass the floods.

Staff writers Susan Harte, David Kinney, Robin McDonald, Charles Salter and
Susannah Vesey contributed to this article.

LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1994

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH941890118

                    Copyright 1994 The Atlanta Constitution


                             716 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                         Cape Gazette (Lewes, Delaware)

  This content, including derivations, may not be stored or distributed in any
  manner, disseminated, published, broadcast, rewritten or reproduced without
                      express, written consent from STPNS

                                January 17, 2012

Sussex farmers promote local, affordable food;
Online contest offers people free groceries for a year

BYLINE: Cape Gazette staff

LENGTH: 858  words


At Green Acres Farm, a Land O'Lakes operation on Route 9 outside Lewes, the
Hopkins family has been raising dairy cows for four generations and more than
100 years.

Their cows produce 12 million pounds of milk per year. Some of the milk is
processed and used at the Hopkins Farm Creamery, opened in 2008, where residents
and visitors enjoy farm-made ice cream.

Burli Hopkins, head herdsman, said he was asked to participate in Farmers Feed
US, an online agriculture promotion that will select four Mid-Atlantic residents
to win free groceries for a year.

The Mid-Atlantic Dairy Association partnered with Farmers Feed Us and filmed
three farmers in Sussex County. Besides Burli Hopkins of Green Acres Farm, Jay
Baxter of Baxter Farms in Georgetown and Jesse Vanderwende of Walnut Tree Farms
in Bridgeville are also featured. All three Delaware farmers selected for the
promotion are from Sussex County.

"Our consumers are at least two generations removed from agriculture, so it's
important for them to know that the food they eat isn't just from the grocery
store," said Hopkins. "Putting a face with the farm also helps in the local
community because people Want to know their farmers."

An American tradition

Jay Baxter has been raising soybeans on his family's land in Georgetown since
graduating from the University of Delaware in 2002.

Baxter grows soybeans mostly for feeding animals, but he also grows edamame,
popular in many Japanese and Chinese restaurants.

As a member of the Delaware Soybean Board, Baxter said he heard about similar
promotions that were successful in the Mid-west, so he was happy to be featured
in the Mid-Atlantic Farmers Feed US contest.

"While a professional marketing firm put the contest together, it really uses
farmers on a personal level to describe to consumers what farmers really do,"
Baxter said. "We aren't a machine; we are a family."

Baxter said many children believe peanut butter comes from a grocery store, and
chicken comes from McDonald's; he hopes Farmers Feed US helps bridge the gap
between farms and consumers.

"Children need to know that chickens are raised on a farm and that the farm
contributes to the economy," Baxter said. "As farmers, we all are living in the
same environment as the consumers, so we act as stewards of the land and the
environment. This is a great project to help promote that."

Baxter encourages residents to stop by his farm in Georgetown and talk to the
farmers. He said, "We'll answer any questions and love to talk about farming."

Jesse Vanderwende comes from a long line of Vanderwen-des in Bridgeville, where
the family has been raising chickens for generations. He said getting farming
knowledge to the public is why he got involved with Farmers Feed US.

"The bad economy gives people even more incentive to learn about food. People
are thinking more about what they are spending their money on, so I hope they
learn about their local farmers through this program," said Vanderwende. "The
United States has the safest food in the world, so this is a good opportunity
for us to showcase our agriculture."

In online video clips, each farmer talks about farming and why he does it,
adding trivia about the agriculture industry. Besides the three Delaware
farmers, the website features farmers from around the Mid-Atlantic region.

Hopkins said consumers often are concerned about how farm animals are treated
and how waste is managed. He said large news organizations focus on one or two
big farms that cause pollution, but he said Delaware farmers are very conscious
about nutrient management.

"People want to know that the animals are treated well. Here you don't stay in
business if you treat them badly," Hopkins said. "I live in this community as
well. My kids live here and drink this water, so I don't want to corrupt nature
at all. We try to stay ahead of the curve with nutrient management."

Promoting farming nationwide

Laura England of the Mid-Atlantic Dairy Association said, "Programs like Farmers
Feed US provide an opportunity for farmers to connect with consumers, to show
how they produce and grow food on the farm. The videos on the FarmersFeed-US.org
website allow consumers to see this process in action and to learn from the
farmers themselves."

England said the importance of agriculture may be well known in Delaware where
the industry brings in $8 billion annually to the state economy, according to
the University of Delaware, but nationwide, only 2 percent of the population is
involved in agriculture.

"That leaves a big gap between those who produce the food and those who consume
it," England said. Many agriculture organizations, including Mid-Atlantic Dairy
Association, are working to promote agriculture and raise awareness of the
benefits of healthy, nutritious and locally grown food, England said.

"Last year, our organization launched a consumer education campaign called 'Your
Milk Comes from a Good Place.' The goal of the campaign is to con: nect
consumers with dairy farmers and to provide a better understanding of how milk
and dairy foods are produced."

For more information or to enter the Farmers Feed US contest, visit
www.farmersfeedus.org.

LOAD-DATE: February 21, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Farming

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: CPG

                               All Rights Reserved
                             SmallTownPapers, Inc.

                             717 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                              May 9, 2015 Saturday

MARYLAND: Many farm groups back TPA

LENGTH: 410  words

DATELINE: Annapolis


Department of Minority Affairs, The state of Maryland has issued the following
news release:

Many agricultural groups have come out in support of trade promotion authority.

"The U.S. pork industry, U.S. agriculture, indeed the entire U.S. economy needs
TPA, and we need it soon," said Harry Hill, a pork producer and veterinarian
from Cambridge, Iowa, in testimony before the House Agriculture Committee.

Hill said the pork industry exports more pork to the 18 countries with which the
United States has free trade agreements than to the rest of the nations
combined.

Since 1989, the year the United States began using bilateral and regional trade
agreements to open foreign markets, pork exports have increased 1,550 percent in
value and 1,268 percent in volume, Hill said. The United States shipped more
than $6.6 billion of pork to foreign destinations in 2014.

With TPA, once trade negotiators finalize a deal, Congress is able to vote yes
or no on the deal, but they are not allowed to make amendments. Congress has
granted TPA to every president since 1974, with the most recent law approved in
August 2002 and expiring in June 2007.

The key reason TPA is needed, Hill said, is for concluding the Trans-Pacific
Partnership negotiations between the United States and 11 Pacific Rim countries.

Failure to pass TPA, he said, would signal that the United States is turning its
back on the Asia-Pacific region and allow other countries to write the rules for
international trade.

The National Cattlemen's Beef Association issued a statement saying, "As we have
repeatedly stated, trade is critical to the success and future profitability of
our industry and TPA is critical to negotiating future free trade agreements.
Cattlemen urge swift passage of the legislation by the full House and Senate."

The National Milk Producers Federation and the U.S. Dairy Export Council said,
"because world trade has become a major driver of the U.S. dairy farmer income,
we need well-designed free trade agreements to keep expanding our exports."

"American family farmers depend on trade," said Chip Bowling, Maryland farmer
and president of the National Corn Growers Association. "Congress, we are now
depending on you to pass trade promotion authority. Let's remove trade barriers,
expand our access to global markets and ensure farmers get the best possible
trade agreements."

In case of any query regarding this article or other content needs please
contact:
editorial@plusme.com

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
