                                US Official News

                           October 15, 2014 Wednesday

Hawaii: Solomons Agriculture Official Calls For Support Of Family Farming

LENGTH: 285  words

DATELINE: Honolulu


Pacific Islands Development, The State of Hawaii has issued the following news
release:

Permanent Secretary for Agriculture and Livestock has called for greater
national attention to family farming, saying failing to address this results in
a dependency syndrome.

Jimmy Saelea made the statement this morning at the officially launch of the
first ever Agriculture week in Honiara.

The Agriculture Week has brought together stakeholders in the sector, including
local farmers, to showcase their produce and products at the Art Gallery area.

In his address, Mr Saelea said family farming and rural development cannot be
separated as both are predominant forms of agriculture in food production.

"Family Farming and Rural Development cannot be separated since it is the
predominant form of agriculture in the food production sector. When one talks
about rural development, family farming has to be a large component of such
issues and such policies."

The Permanent Secretary adds, the dependency syndrome is corrupting communities
and this can be discouraged if families receive assistance to establish small
holding activities.

"In failing to address family farming in rural areas, the result is the
dependency syndrome that has been corrupting our communities. The system
therefore, must be discouraged, by providing assistance to families to establish
small holder activities, lest we forget the farming family consists of a father,
mother and children. The father must recognise the important contribution the
mother and children provide to family farming activities. Agriculture is
everyone's business."

In case of any query regarding this article or other content needs please
contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

LOAD-DATE: October 16, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire


              Copyright 2014 Plus Media Solutions Private Limited
                              All Rights Reserved


                             720 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                               The New York Times

                           September 29, 2014 Monday
                              Late Edition - Final

U.S.D.A. to Start Program to Support Local and Organic Farming

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

SECTION: Section B; Column 0; Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 554 words


The United States Department of Agriculture plans to announce Monday that it
will spend $52 million to support local and regional food systems like farmers'
markets and food hubs and to spur research on organic farming.

The local food movement has been one of the fastest growing segments of the
business, as consumers seek to know more about where, how and by whom their food
is grown.

But local farmers still struggle to market their food. Distribution systems are
intended to accommodate the needs of large-scale commercial farms and growers.
Grocery stores and restaurants largely rely on big distribution centers and are
only beginning to figure out how to incorporate small batches of produce into
their overall merchandise mixes.

Farmers' markets are proliferating around the country, increasing 76 percent to
8,268 since 2008, according to the Agriculture Department, but they have trouble
marketing themselves. And few consumers are aware of a website the department
created to help them find a farmers market in their area.

''These types of local food systems are the cornerstones of our plans to
revitalize the rural economy,'' Tom Vilsack, the agriculture secretary, said in
a telephone interview. ''If you can connect local produce with markets that are
local, money gets rolled around in the local community more directly compared to
commercial agriculture where products get shipped in large quantities somewhere
else, helping the economy there.''

The $52 million will be the first outlay to local and organic enterprises of the
farm bill signed into law by President Obama in February, which tripled the
amount of money aimed at that sector to $291 million. The organic business,
which has long complained that the Agriculture Department does not support it
financially, will get $125 million over the next five years for research and $50
million for conservation programs.

''It's a really nice bump for us because we've been getting chump change for
research,'' said Mark Kastel, co-founder of the Cornucopia Institute, an organic
research and advocacy group.

Still, Mr. Kastel said that given the growth in the organic business, with about
$35 billion in sales in the United States last year, he wished there was more
money to study organic practices.

The department will also be putting $30 million a year into marketing programs
for farmers markets and promotion of locally grown foods, and has an additional
$70 million available as a block grant to support more research on so-called
specialty crops, or fruits and vegetables.

''These are significant increases over what it was before I became secretary and
certainly over the 2008 bill,'' Mr. Vilsack said, referring to the previous
omnibus farm bill.

He said local food systems were good investments for government. ''Small and
medium-sized operations end up helping to generate more employment than
commercial operations because of their different distribution systems and their
local natures,'' Mr. Vilsack said. ''And food hubs hire about 20 people on
average.''

Mr. Vilsack said there were about 300 food hubs around the country, and he is
eager to see more. These enterprises, like Appalachian Sustainable Development
in Virginia and La Montañita in New Mexico, help small farmers market and
distribute their products and offer a variety of other services.

URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2014/09/29/business/usda-to-start-program-to-support-loca
l-and-organic-farming.html

LOAD-DATE: September 29, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: PHOTO: The Grand Army Plaza farmers' market in Brooklyn. The organic
food business in the United States reached $35 billion last year. (PHOTOGRAPH BY
ANDREA MOHIN/THE NEW YORK TIMES)

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                   Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company


                             721 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                                 Ottawa Citizen

                       June 13, 2003 Friday EARLY Edition

Vanclief stays mum on aid for beef farmers: Cash, not loan guarantees, needed to
keep ranchers afloat, Alberta says

SOURCE: CanWest News Service

BYLINE: Joe Paraskevas

SECTION: News; Pg. A5

LENGTH: 630 words

Agriculture Minister Lyle Vanclief and his provincial and territorial
counterparts will try to agree today on how to bring financial relief to the
country's stricken beef industry, despite differences over how the federal
government should deliver the help.

More than three weeks after the discovery of one case of mad cow disease
provoked the United States to ban Canadian beef imports, the domestic industry
remains at a virtual standstill. Pressure is mounting on the federal government
to help businesses and restart trade.

"We need to have a good discussion on how collectively we maintain the liquidity
of the industry to get us through this situation until we get the borders open,"
Mr. Vanclief said, refusing to promise that an announcement about financial aid
will follow the Vancouver meeting.

But even as some financial help started to arrive and as Canadian officials sent
a letter yesterday urging Washington to partially lift its ban on Canadian beef,
conflicting views about where most of the emergency aid should come from
persisted.

According to leaked reports, the federal cabinet has approved loan guarantees of
up to $10 million for businesses hit by the mad cow scare, but several provinces
will first have to sign on to a risk-management program.

The news of such a plan met with immediate skepticism.

"Farm groups across this country have all said that the safety net program is
not acceptable," said Canadian Alliance agriculture critic Howard Hilstrom.

"The beef industry is being used to force the provinces to sign on to an
agreement that the grain farmers and farmers of other commodities don't want."

The government's risk-management program costs farmers up to $26,000 to join and
doesn't provide enough coverage, Mr. Hilstrom added.

A spokeswoman for Alberta Agriculture Minister Shirley McLellan said farmers and
other workers in Canada's largest beef producing province expect more from Mr.
Vanclief than loan guarantees.

"Loan guarantees are not the answer for this," the spokeswoman said. "What they
need is a cash infusion."

Mr. Vanclief replied by saying the new federal-provincial disaster program
encompasses more than loan guarantees and he insisted he needs the signed
support of provinces representing at least 50 per cent of people who would have
a stake in the risk-management program.

"You have to have the program in place before it can be used and the program is
there to be used if they ask to participate in it," Mr. Vanclief said.

Only Alberta, Newfoundland and Labrador have signed the agreement until now,
though British Columbia is expected to join them at the agriculture ministers
meeting today.

Meanwhile, federal scientists sent a letter to the U.S. Department of
Agriculture on as a formal request to re-open the Canada-U.S. border gradually,
beginning with beef products considered to be of relatively low risk of having
mad cow disease.

"We've agreed that while the border was shut in one step, that the border will
open in stages," said Paul Haddow, executive director of international affairs
for the Canadian Food Inspection Agency.

Low-risk products include veal, muscle meat from cows under 24-months-old, a
"significant portion" of Canada's $3.5-billion beef exports to the U.S., Mr.
Vanclief said.

The American ban on Canadian beef has reportedly cost the industry in this
country $11 million per day.

On a related note, Japanese officials will visit Canada next week to review the
mad cow investigation.

More than $25 million worth of beef products were en route to Pacific Rim
markets when the mad cow scare broke, and those countries immediately closed
their borders to Canadian cattle imports.

Thirty-two other countries have also banned Canadian beef imports.

* * * * * * * * * * DESCRIPTION * * * * * * * * * *

   Titan Machinery Inc., incorporated on December 11, 2007, owns and operates a
network of agricultural and construction equipment stores in the United States
and Europe. The Company has three primary business segments: Agriculture,
Construction and International. Within its operating segments, it engages in
four principal business activities: new and used equipment sales; parts sales;
repair and maintenance services, and equipment rental and other activities. The
agricultural equipment it sells and services includes machinery and attachments
for uses ranging from large-scale farming to home and garden purposes. The
construction equipment it sells and services includes heavy construction and
light industrial machinery for commercial and residential construction, road and
highway construction, and mining operations. It sells new agricultural and
construction equipment manufactured under the CNH Industrial family of brands,
as well as equipment from a range of other manufacturers. It sells parts and
provides in-store and on-site repair and maintenance services. It also rents
equipment and provides ancillary services, such as equipment transportation,
global positioning system (GPS) signal subscriptions, and finance and insurance
products.

Agriculture

   The Company's Agriculture segment sells, services and rents machinery, as
well as related parts and attachments for uses ranging from farming to home and
garden use in North America. This segment also includes ancillary sales and
services related to agricultural activities and products, such as equipment
transportation, GPS signal subscriptions, and finance and insurance products.
Its Agriculture customers vary from small, single machine owners to farming
operations, primarily in the states of Iowa, Minnesota, Nebraska, North Dakota
and South Dakota

   Construction

   The Company's Construction segment sells, services, and rents machinery, and
related parts and attachments, for uses ranging from heavy construction to light
industrial machinery use to customers in North America. This segment also
includes ancillary sales and services related to construction activities, such
as equipment transportation, GPS signal subscriptions, and finance and insurance
products. Its Construction customers include a range of construction
contractors, public utilities, mining and energy companies, municipalities and
maintenance contractors, primarily in the states of Arizona, Colorado, Iowa,
Minnesota, Montana, Nebraska, New Mexico, North Dakota, South Dakota, Wisconsin
and Wyoming.

   International

   The Company's International segment sells, services, and rents machinery, and
related parts and attachments, for uses ranging from large-scale farming and
construction to home and garden use to customers in Eastern Europe. It also
includes export sales of equipment and parts to customers outside of the United
States. Its International customers vary from small, single machine owners to
farming operations, primarily in the European countries of Bulgaria, Romania,
Serbia and Ukraine.

   The Company competes with Deere & Company, Caterpillar, Inc. Agco
Corporation, RDO Equipment Co., Butler Machinery, Ziegler Inc. and Brandt
Holdings Co.

                             723 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                            July 20, 1994, Wednesday

AROUND THE SOUTH BOUNTY FROM THE GULF Off-shore fish farming may feed the hungry

BYLINE: By Gene Tharpe STAFF WRITER

SECTION: NATIONAL NEWS; Section A; Page 3

LENGTH: 613 words


One catch: Only EPA approval is needed to produce tons of finny food in the Gulf
near Mobile, Ala.

When John Ericsson goes fishing, he doesn't waste time with hook and line. He
aims to "farm" millions of pounds of fish in the Gulf of Mexico.

Ericsson, president of Sea Pride Industries, is one government permit away from
approval to build the Sea Trek Ocean Farming System in federal waters 4 miles
south of Fort Morgan, Ala., near Mobile.

At the $ 15 million, octopus-like facility, Ericsson envisions producing 3
million or more pounds of redfish, sea bass or other edible, warm-water fish
annually.

"It's still experimental, but what Sea Pride Industries is attempting to do is
exciting," said Dr. Hank Parker, aquaculture coordinator of the U.S. Department
of Agriculture.

"Sea Trek has a number of unique engineering features that take the concept of
off-shore fish farming further than any ofter operation I know of."

The remaining permit needed to build Sea Trek is difficult to obtain:
Enviromental Protection Agency approval.

But Ericsson feels sure the EPA permit will be issued, though it is still
undergoing review.

"The EPA assures me there should be no problem," he said. "They tell me the
permit is scheduled to be issued in August, to be effective in October."

With the permit, Ericsson expects Sea Trek to begin operations by the fall of
1995, though further financing is needed to build the facility.

Sea Pride Industries, based in Gulf Breeze, Fla., near Pensacola, has about 80
individual investors and plans an initial public offering of stock later this
year.

Sea Trek, partly submerged in 50 feet of water, will consist of a central dome
and work platform above the surface, with six 160-foot-long barrel-like cages
extending out like spokes underwater for raising the fish.

Each 40-foot-diameter barrel, stocked with fingerlings from a shoreside
hatchery, could hold up to 250,000 fish within three compartments that separate
the fish according to size.

The fish will be fed meals of high-protein pellets dozens of times daily.
Depending on variety, each fish will grow to about 4 pounds in 150 to 365 days.

After they reach "meal" size, a water vacuum system will remove the fish from
the barrels onto boats to transfer to shore for cleaning and sale.

Sea Trek, which will be staffed by about 20 workers, will be set on concrete
pilings and is designed to withstand a "100-year hurricane," as required by the
Corps of Engineers before it would issue a construction permit.

Ericsson and Parker said great strides must be made in farming of seafood - both
freshwater and saltwater varieties - to meet the future seafood needs of the
world's burgeoning population.

Parker said the world's population is forecast to reach 8.5 billion by 2025 and
will need 77 million metric tons more seafood than currently caught commercially
or produced by aquaculture.

"Most scientists agree that we are now at the maximum annual commercial catch of
fish worldwide, about 90 million metric tons," Parker said, "which means that
most of the 77 million metric tons will have to come from aquaculture." About 11
million metric tons now are produced worldwide from fish farming, he said.

Ericsson said salmon farming produces sales in the United States of $ 75 million
annually, and he thinks there are several Gulf of Mexico species that could
generate annual sales of $ 50 million or more annually.

"Sea Trek's technology is exciting and its opportunities unlimited, but the
challenges are also enormous and costs extensive," Parker said. "The critical
issue will be the cost of producing the fish in relation to the market price of
the fish."

LOAD-DATE: July 22, 1994

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH942030321

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Sea Trek Ocean Farming System will feature six barrel-like
cages meeting at a central dome and work platform above the surface, with each
cage holding up to 250,000 fish. / Sea Pride Industries

                    Copyright 1994 The Atlanta Constitution


                             724 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                 July 24, 1988, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

Storms Save Some Crops

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1, Page 20, Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 374 words


Besides dousing dozens of forest fires, downpours this past week have saved - at
least temporarily - corn and other vegetable crops around New York State from
''irreparable damage,'' an official of the State Agriculture Department said
yesterday.

In New Jersey, however, where Governor Kean has asked the Federal Government for
disaster drought relief, the rains came too late to provide much relief.

With 1.71 inches of rain on Thursday and .04 inches on Friday combining with
heavy rains early in the week, Central Park received a total for the month of
6.43 inches, according to Bob McElhearn, a meteorologist with the National
Weather Service in Rockefeller Center. Rainfall in July averages 3.77 inches.

The storms, caused by the clash of tropical and arctic air along a stalled
front, have dampened much of New York State.

''It is more than welcome,'' said Dwayne Lipinski, special assistant to the New
York State Commissioner of Agriculture, Donald G. Butcher.

The rain, Mr. Lipinski said, ''was extremely critical to keep us from
experiencing irreparable damage.'' He added, ''Had we not gotten this widespread
rain, we would have been into a really critical situation, particularly with our
corn crop and our processing vegetables - green beans, cabbage and beets.''

In New Jersey, Carol Shipp, a spokeswoman for the Secretary of Agriculture,
Arthur R. Brown, said: ''The rains came pretty late to help a lot of the crops
in this state. There had been a spell of several weeks of dry weather, and a lot
of them went past the point where they could be helped.''

Jersey Seeks Disaster Relief

On Thursday, citing nearly $120 million in crop losses, Mr. Kean asked the
United States Department of Agriculture to declare a drought disaster in New
Jersey.

Agriculture officials in Connecticut could not be reached for comment yesterday.

There have been more than 500 forest fires around the state this year, compared
with 267 all of last year, said Robert H. Bathrick, the director of the lands
and forests division of the New York State Department of Environmental
Conservation. But because of the rain, he said, ''we're sure in a lot better
shape than a week and a half ago. All the fires are out or under control.''

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1988 The New York Times Company


                             725 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                                 Ottawa Citizen

                       May 21, 2002 Tuesday Final Edition

U.S. subsidies put squeeze on Canada's farmers: Damage to Canadian agriculture
estimated at $1.3 billion a year

SOURCE: The Canadian Press

BYLINE: Scott Edmonds

SECTION: Business; Pg. B8

LENGTH: 719 words

DATELINE: WINNIPEG

WINNIPEG -- Canada's farmers and premiers have been looking with dismay and a
tinge of envy at the United States, where agriculture just got a $180-billion
U.S. pre-election birthday present.

But it's a present that has huge implications for farmers and taxpayers
throughout the world, as calls mount for subsidies to help producers in other
countries compete with what the Americans have promised to spend.

"In fairness to the Americans, they're taking care of their own," says Dennis
Jack, chairman of the Ontario Corn Producers' Association.

His group is just one of many calling on the federal government to pony up $1.3
billion a year to deal with what they point out is Agriculture Canada's own
estimate of the annual trade injury to Canadian farmers from foreign subsidies.

The number -- which started at $1.2 billion when first bandied about last year
-- is based on a look at what has happened to world grain and oilseed prices and
production between 1995 and 2000.

In the end, 25 per cent of the decline in prices in the period was ascribed to
the impact of subsidies.

Mr. Jack says Ontario's corn growers see it in simpler terms.

"Our price is established based on Chicago (prices). We can only get what the
U.S. price is, plus the basis or delivery charges to the destination in
Ontario."

When American farmers have only to cover production costs from the sale of their
corn and earn their profit from subsidies, the impact is clear, he suggests.

Corn that could be selling for $5 a bushel is selling for $2, for example.
"Their product flows into our market at their price and then they get that extra
$100 an acre."

President George W. Bush signed the bill into law over the objections of some
members of his own Republican party, who noted it breaks pledges to reduce
subsidies and will also pump up the U.S. deficit.

It's a complete reversal from the 1996 U.S. farm bill, which was to be the
beginning of the end for such hefty support payments. Canada had already slashed
farm supports as part of world talks on reducing such trade-distorting
subsidies.

U.S. resolve evaporated quickly, however, under political pressure when
commodity prices started to slip in 1997, notes Daryl Kraft of the University of
Manitoba, one of Western Canada's best-known agricultural economists.

A variety of programs were put in place. With U.S. elections now looming again,
however, those have been formalized for grains and oilseeds and expanded to
cover other commodities as well in the new U.S. farm bill.

The new legislation even combines the transition measures from the 1996 farm
bill with those subsidies they were intended to replace, says Mr. Kraft.

"Lo and behold, the new farm bill came along and it had the best of both
worlds," Mr. Kraft says wryly.

It has been widely criticized by other countries that have reduced subsidies,
such as Canada and Australia, and ironically even by Europe, where subsidy
levels remain high.

Despite all the political rhetoric about how evil it is, however, the U.S. farm
bill is now a fact of life Canadian farmers must face along with the threat of
drought, disease and other natural disasters.

Most say they are ill-equipped to deal with this new pressure.

The Grain Growers of Canada was the group that first suggested the $1.3-billion
Trade

Injury Compensation Program last year. The western provinces are also pushing
hard for Ottawa to buy into the idea.

They say they cannot afford to compete with the U.S. treasury and point to
federal surpluses in Canada as a source for the money needed to keep Canadian
farmers in business.

What form the new program might take, if it is even agreed to by the federal
government, remains uncertain.

Grain Growers chairman Brian Kriz, who farms near Red Deer, Alta., says unlike
other farm aid programs, this one has to compensate all farmers fairly, big and
small.

But Stewart Wells, president of the National Farmers Union, says if Ottawa isn't
careful it will only speed the departure of smaller farmers from the rural
landscape.

"If the payments are not capped, that tips the balance in favour of larger and
larger farms and that accelerates the loss of farms out of the countryside,"
says Mr. Wells, who farms near Swift Current, Sask.

LOAD-DATE: May 21, 2002

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Business

                      CanWest Global Communications Corp.
                              All Rights Reserved


                             726 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                          China Daily European Edition

                            February 3, 2015 Tuesday

Sow today, reap tomorrow - the future of China's agriculture

SECTION: INDUSTRIES

LENGTH: 347 words


BEIJING - For twelve years in a row, China's "No 1 Central Document" has focused
on agriculture and rural issues.

The "No 1 Central Document" is the first major policy document released each
year. Agriculture is a significant issue in the world's most populous nation,
with problems including low farmer income, pollution and a lack of competitive
agricultural companies.

Efforts have been made to increase farmers' incomes, but the gap between urban
and rural incomes remains. Growth of rural incomes has outpaced that of urban
dwellers since 2010, but nonetheless, Chinese villagers only earn about one
third of city residents.

Without increased government investment in agriculture, tourism and other income
sources for farmers combined with higher value agricultural products, hopes of
reducing the gap will be in vain.

China has to feed about one fifth of world's population from less than 10
percent of the arable land. Environmental protection was never given enough
weight in farming and over-exploitation of farmland must come to an end. Use of
chemicals and fertilizers per hectare in China was once 70 percent higher than
the world average, resulting in more than 40 percent of farmland being degraded.
Protecting farmland is an uphill battle that China must win.

Many farmers in their 50s or 60s till plots of less than half an acre, while
their children work in cities. Those seniors will soon quit farming and about
200 million rural people are expected to move into cities over the coming
decades, so China has to develop large-scale, environmentally friendly farming,
and must do it quickly.

A high percentage of China's population are employed in agriculture, but a short
list of reputable agricultural businesses compares poorly with the United States
and France. Innovation must play a bigger role in farming, and Chinese
agricultural companies with global clout must be fostered.

A list of 32 points related to agriculture, rural areas and farmers was in the
No 1 document released on Sunday, but implementation is the key. You have to sow
today to reap tomorrow.

LOAD-DATE: February 3, 2015

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                   Copyright 2015 China Daily Information Co
                              All Rights Reserved


                             727 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                           Morris Daily Herald, Ill.

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             May 28, 2011 Saturday

City Moms want to know about farming

BYLINE: Jo Ann Hustis, Morris Daily Herald, Ill.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 933 words


May 28--It's not about corn and beans, but about Illinois farmers coming
together to tell the public who they are, Mazon grain producer Donna Jeschke
says.

"We need to interact with our consumers," she told the full house at the Grundy
County Soil and Water Conservation District's quarterly breakfast Wednesday. "We
need to put the focus on healthy land and farm animals, and that we won't sell
food to the public that we wouldn't feed to our own families."

Jeschke, a spokesman with Illinois Farm Families, told of her recent agriculture
trip to Japan and watching customers line up at kiosks in the grocery stores to
see how various cuts of meat are obtained from which animals, the animals'
pedigrees and how they were raised.

Japan obtains a large share of meat produced on farms in the United States.
Japanese grocery stores have informational bulletins within reach of their
customers on meats and other produce, the use of chemicals like herbicides and
pesticides in farming, and various conservation practices.

Research has shown that non-farm consumers in the United States admit they do
not know much about agriculture, and that their actual experience with farmers
and farming is limited.

"Farmers in general are finding out it's more important than ever to tell what's
happening on our farms. City people have different ideas of what we're doing,"
she said of the FOOD research program initiated by a coalition of farm leaders
who represent the five largest Illinois farm groups.

The acronym stands for the Farmers Opening Our Doors movement.

Non-farm consumers are learning about farming and ag practices from various
sources like the media, books, talks shows, social networking sites, and even
their peers.

"From everyone except farmers -- the people who grow and raise their food," she
said.

This lack of communication with farmers has created a lot of misinformation and
assumptions about food. Farmers need to help consumers find answers to their
questions.

The consumers research program was conducted by Morgan & Meyer, and targeted
toward finding what the non-farm "City Mom" wants to know about the meat and
produce available at grocery stores. The research was conducted in Chicago and
St. Louis. The purpose was to help farmers understand what non-farmers want.

"The new economic norm is that Americans want to live as well as they can on
less money," Jeschke said. "The No. 1 concern of the non-farm family is the
health and welfare of their families."

Mothers are probably the most powerful consumers in today's world. They want to
know how their food was grown and raised, and what is in it. They also expect to
get honest answers to their questions and comments.

"The No. 1 place where City Moms get their information about farming is from the
local farmers' markets," she said. "About 40 percent of Illinois consumers said
these markets are their main source of information. Another 37 percent said
their main source of information was from driving by farms and seeing the signs
-- Monsanto, Pioneer, Grainco FS."

These signs actually are just advertising the brand of seed planted in the field
where the sign is placed. They mislead urban families who mistake them for the
names of large corporate farming operations.

"The image the research program found is that urban people respect and
appreciate farmers, and consider them to be honest and a nurturing and caring
group. Sixty-five percent of the focus groups ranked farmers first in the
professions trusted by the public," Jeschke said.

"They consider good farmers to be the ones who operate small traditional grain
and livestock farms. They consider a bad farm as one operated by a large
corporation. We need to talk to non-farmers about corporate farms, and about the
use of pesticides and the like in the farming operation."

The study displayed nearly a dozen agriculture pictures and asked consumers to
chose the one they liked the best and the least.  The winner was that of several
customers at a produce stand in a farmers market. The least liked picture was
that of a western feed lot containing about 300 head of cattle.

Mothers with children under the age of 12 are the most influential in consumer
buying habits, Jeschke noted.

"They're concerned about safety and healthy elements in food," she said.
"Today's consumer values are based on fear and insecurity. They are concerned
about using corn for food instead of ethanol. They trust farmers in general, but
they don't understand the use of products like pesticides."

The non-farm public does not understand the science behind operating a farm.

The Illinois Farm Families program is offering Chicago-area mothers opportunity
to tour farms as Field Moms reporters. IFF will equip the Field Moms with video
cameras, and let them record and share what they see and learn on the farms.

The Field Moms will participate in media interviews, blog about their
experiences, and appear in other publicity avenues. Field Moms will also write
journal and blog entries about their farm tour experience for Twitter and
Facebook.

To be a Field Mom or to follow the Field Moms on line as they tour farms, go to
www.watchusgrow.org. Most tours will leave the Chicago area at 8 a.m. and return
about 6 p.m.

Jeschke was introduced by County SWCD Executive Director Natalie Mahler.

To see more of The Morris Daily Herald, go to http://www.morrisdailyherald.com.

Information Services. For more information about the content services offered by
McClatchy-Tribune Information Services (MCT), visit www.mctinfoservices.com.

                                The Toronto Star

                   February 5, 1987, Thursday, FINAL EDITION

Gotlieb condemns 'myths' of U.S.-Canadian trade

BYLINE: (CP)

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A4

LENGTH: 415 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


   WASHINGTON (CP) - Allan Gotlieb, Canada's ambassador to the United States,
condemned U.S. trading practices yesterday in a toughly worded attack on the
"myths" of Canada-U.S. trade.

Referring to U.S. criticism of subsidized Canadian industries, Gotlieb said the
United States is a major user of subsidies, particularly in the agriculture
field.

"Last year the total cost of programs pumping government money into that sector
exceeded $25 billion," he said in a text of a speech to be given to a
Canada-U.S. trade conference in Los Angeles.

Price supports

"These programs varied from direct deficiency payments to price supports,
combined with quotas, to help insulate your producers from international
competition.

"Government support to your grain and oilseed farmers is some two to four times
greater than the support given to Canadian farmers, depending on the commodity."

Canada and other U.S. trading partners have come under increasing attack in the
United States for alleged unfair subsidization of industries which export their
products into the U.S. market.

Subsidies are a major issue in the current Canada-U.S. negotiations on a
free-trade pact, especially in the wake of recent U.S. moves to penalize imports
of Canadian softwood lumber, fish and hogs.

Gotlieb said that while Canada may make liberal use of grants and subsidies to
support its industries, the United States may be more inclined to use tax breaks
to achieve the same objective.

"But you are not shy about using grants either, and in any event the practical
result may be the same even though the means vary," he said.

"When you cut through the mythology and take a cold, hard look at the facts, it
seems clear to us that the United States is a major user of subsidies."

Biggest partner

Other "myths" Gotlieb tried to dispel in his speech included the popular belief
in the United States that Japan, as opposed to Canada, is the largest U.S.
trading partner; that Canada enjoys an "inordinate" surplus in its trade with
the United States; that Canada has been maintaining its dollar at an artifically
low level, and that only Canada would benefit from a free-trade arrangement.

Gotlieb urged Americans to recognize that when trade in both goods and services
are taken into account, the Canadian surplus was less than $3 billion in the
first nine months of 1986 on total two-way trade of $114 billion.

See related stories on page A1 by Ruimy and Israelson

LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1999

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

                   May 5, 1994, Thursday, DAILY: WEST EDITION

Minister favors end to wheat board monopoly

BYLINE: Ashley Geddes

SECTION: SECTION 1, NEWS; Pg. 43

LENGTH: 323 words

DATELINE: Edmonton, Alta.


Alberta Agriculture Minister Walter Paszkowski has joined a growing chorus of
calls for the removal of the Canadian Wheat Board's monopoly control on export
wheat sales.

Paszkowski, who has begun circulating a report proposing reforms of the grain
marketing system, said allowing farmers the choice of selling wheat and barley
independent of the wheat board could help alleviate the current trade dispute
over Canadian wheat sales in the U.S.

The wheat board monopoly is ''an obstacle in the trade dispute and it certainly
would help,'' said Paszkowski.

The wheat board currently has a monopoly over the buying and selling of Canadian
wheat and barley destined for U.S. markets.

The U.S., angered by a dramatic rise in imports of Canadian grain, has
threatened to impose tariffs on Canada's wheat and barley, citing the wheat
board's monopoly as one irritant.

Paszkowksi said any producer or grain company - including the wheat board -
should be able to buy and deliver supplies in North America.

The report, which suggests the wheat board could maintain sole jurisdiction over
offshore sales, also calls for the elimination of farm transportation subsidies
under the Western Grain Transportation Act.

''The wheat board has to restructure because it has to meet the current needs
and current times,'' said Paszkowski. ''We'd like to see the whole process
become more competitive.''

The Western Canadian Wheat Growers Association and the Western Barley Growers
Association are also demanding an end to the wheat board's monopoly.

But an advisory committee to the wheat board issued a statement this week
denouncing proponents of reducing the board's authority as apologists for a U.S.
foreign policy.

While the committee says only a minority of grain farmers favors eroding the
wheat board's jurisdiction, Paszkowski said a majority of the farmers and farm
groups he's talked to wants reforms.

                               Irish Independent

                             June 24, 2014 Tuesday
                                   Edition 3;
                                National Edition

Irish land tops global price ranking

BYLINE: Ken Whelan

SECTION: FARMING;NEWS; Pg. 22

LENGTH: 1119 words


IRELAND is the dearest place in the world to buy farming land according to a
recent survey by the Financial Times in London.

The global land price survey, shows that the average price of farming land in
Ireland is (EURO)9364/ac.

It is noteworthy that the next most expensive country in the world to buy land
is New Zealand ((EURO)8532/ac) where the agriculture sector is dominated by
dairying.

The next dearest European location to purchase land is Denmark at (EURO)7,934/ac
followed by Britain at (EURO)5,448/ac.

Poland, France, Canada, Brazil, Romania, Hungary, the United States and Canada,
all recorded a price per acre below (EURO)4,000 in the Financial Times survey
while land in Australia is currently changing hands for as low as (EURO)482/ac.

The Financial Times figure for Irish land prices is broadly in line with the
quarterly Irish Land Market Review published this week by Sherry Fitzgerald
auctioneers.

It found that the average price per acre paid for farming land in Ireland in the
last quarter increased by 2.7% to (EURO)9,550. Economists and auctioneers
believe the value placed by landowners and farmers on their land is essentially
historic. However, they also agreed that this has been inflated over the past
couple of years by demand for land ahead of the EU''s abolition of milk quotas
next year. Economist Jim Power told the Farming Independent that the main reason
for high farmland prices in Ireland is down to the low turnover of land in the
country.

"There is a very limited supply of land in Ireland and an incredibly low
turnover of land, which in turn creates a demand that in turn affects the price
of land," he said.

"There is also a 'caste system' ' operating within Irish agriculture with the
dairy farmers at the top, tillage farmers- depending on the weather-in the
middle, with beef and sheep farmers at the bottom. It will always be the case.

"But the post milk quota situation in 2015 is creating a demand for land and
dairy farmers at the moment will buy anything that moves," he said.

"What we are seeing now is an artificially strong demand for land with bank
lending to agriculture centred almost entirely on the dairy sector - at the
expense of the other farming sectors. This is because of the predicted long term
prospects when milk quotas are abolished."

"  Power, however, believes this is a "short term approach to farm
investment'''' which will not be good for the long term viability of Irish
agriculture.

"What happens when dairy margins tighten and these borrowings have to be paid
off?" "  Kildare-based auctioneer Paddy Jordan says he would not disagree with
the findings of the Financial Times'' survey.

Turnover "The low turnover of land in Ireland is mainly the cause of high land
prices'''', he says.

"You must remember the recent statistic about land in Ireland. Apparently land
in France is sold once in every 70 years while land in Ireland is sold only once
in 400 to 500 years.

"I recently sold 108 acres of good tillage land at (EURO)16,500 an acre. That is
above the number you are quoting, but most of the recent transactions would be
within an ass''s roar of the figure,'' '' he says.

New buyers area mixture of dairy farmers who "would buy outside the ditch
anyway'' '' and farmers buying land as a long term investment.

"There are a lot of cash buyers who are interested in land because interest
rates on deposit accounts are so low," says Jordan.

"Many of them are farmers who sold land near towns for huge sums during the
boom. You must remember that not all of them used the boom time money to invest
in AIB and Anglo Irish.

"They still have the money to invest and when you buy land you know the land is
still going to be there tomorrow morning.

"They are getting two bites of the cherry - land which they can farm now and
land which they can use as an investment for the next generation who will have
no memory of the economic crash.

"I suppose it's all a question of supply and demand but you have to remember
there is a lot of good land in Ireland compared to the USA where there is an
awful lot of bad land,'' '' he added.

BORDER REGION SEES THE ONLY DECREASE IN LAND VALUES THE average price of Irish
farmland rose by 2.7pc from (EURO)9,300 to (EURO)9,550 per acre during the first
quarter of the year, according to the Irish Land Market Review just published by
auctioneers Sherry Fitzgerald.

The review is based on actual prices or prices likely to be achieved by Sherry
Fitzgerald''s network of 56 agents nationwide and covers sales of grassland,
prime tillage land, marginal grassland and forestry land.

Land prices in Cork increased by 9pc contributing to a 7.1pc rise in land values
in the south west, where prices increased from (EURO)9,550 to (EURO)10,650/ac
during the quarter.

Land values in the midlands increased by 3.9pc and values in the mid east region
rose by 3.1pc. Both the Dublin and southeast land markets remained stable during
the quarter, but land values in the Border region dropped by 0.7pc. The average
value of grassland increased by 3pc ( (EURO)10,500 to (EURO)10,750/ac) with the
highest values recorded in the Dublin region ((EURO)13,500/ac). Dublin is
followed by the south west where grassland values grew by 7pc to
(EURO)11,700/ac, driven by strong demand and sales in Cork.

Grassland values in the mid east region increased by 6pc to (EURO)11,600/ac, but
the Border region showed a marginal decrease of 1.5pc.

Looking at the overall national picture, grassland values vary from more than
(EURO)15,000/ac in the right locations to as low as (EURO)5,000 in counties like
Leitrim and Roscommon, where demand is weaker.

The average price per acre for tillage land increased by 3.2pc in the first
quarter to (EURO)11,600.

Values in the south west region were up 7.1pc with Cork again the star in the
salesroom. Tillage land prices increased there by 9.3pc.

The value of tillage land in the mid west region grew by 4.8pc during the first
three months of the year with the midlands and mid east markets growing by 4pc
and 4.2pc respectively.

The average value of prime tillage land in Dublin was (EURO)18,000 /ac.

Prices nationally for marginal grassland averaged (EURO)6, 750/ac - a rise of
1.5pc on the previous quarter.

The south west and midlands saw the largest increases (9.2pc) with Longford and
Laois driving the increase in the Midlands.

Mature forestry of 25 years or more is selling at (EURO)3,700/ac - up 2.2pc with
a notable uplift in prices (8.1pc) in the Border region.

While farmers remain the principle buyers in the markets, the authors note that
cash investors and returning emigrants are also prominent. The report also warns
that access to bank finance remains an issue for dairy farmers who are very
active in the market.

                          September 27, 2012 Thursday

US to strengthen farming business in Pakistan

LENGTH: 231 words

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD


ISLAMABAD, Sept. 27 -- Sixty-four specialists from the ministries of agriculture
from Khyber Pukhtunkhwa, Gilgit Baltistan, Azad Jammu and Kashmir (AJK), Sindh,
and Balochistan have completed a 10-day course on modern farm business and
irrigation methods sponsored by the US. The participants will help farmers
increase their profits by approaching farming as a businessfarmers will be able
to identify higher-value crops and access new markets and customers. The US for
International Development (USAID) organised this training session to help
increase profits through better product quality and water management.

At the completion of the training course in Islamabad, USAID Country Director
Jonathan Conly said, "By using modern techniques, Pakistani farmers can capture
new customers and increase their profits. The United States is committed to
helping Pakistan modernise its agriculture sector so that farmers can improve
their livelihoods." After the workshop, an agricultural specialist from AJK
Amina Rafi added "Farming in mountain areas has always been a challenge. I am
glad that this training has provided me with skills to help farmers in AJK
improve their businesses." staff report Published by HT Syndication with

                     Belfast News Letter (Northern Ireland)

                          December 31, 2003, Wednesday

US BSE OUTBREAK 'TRACED TO CANADA'

SECTION: FARMING LIFE; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 384 words


INVESTIGATORS tentatively traced the first US case of "mad cow disease" to
Canada, which could help determine the scope of the outbreak and might even
limit the economic damage to the country's beef industry.

In addition, some calves in a quarantined herd of 400 that included a male
offspring of the sick cow will be destroyed, the US Agriculture Department has
said.

The herd was at a farm in Sunnyside, Washington.

Dr Ron DeHaven, the Agriculture Department's chief veterinarian, said that
Canadian officials provided records indicating the sick Holstein dairy cow was
in a herd of 74 cattle shipped from Alberta, Canada, in August 2001.

"These animals were all dairy cattle and entered the US only about two or
two-and-a-half years ago, so most of them are still likely alive," Mr DeHaven
said.

The sick cow's presence in that herd does not mean all 74 animals are infected,
he said.

Investigators will probably find where the other 73 animals are within a matter
of days.

Finding them will help investigators determine if any other animals are sick and
need to be tested.

In May, Canada found a lone cow with the disease in Alberta but has not been
able to determine the source of infection.

If US and Canadian officials confirm that the sick cow in Washington state came
from Canada, US farmers hope it will save the export market for the beef
industry because the US could keep its disease-free status and continue trade.

The National Cattlemen's Beef Association in Denver said the indication that the
infected cow was from Canada means US trading partners should reopen their
borders to US beef.

The farm organisation said a beef export monitoring programme would allow
importers to separate beef of Canadian origin if they feel additional
precautions are needed.

More than two dozen countries banned US beef this week. The US lost 90% of its
beef export market, industry officials said.

o CANADA has announced its intention to introduce a ban on the use of Meat and
Bone Meal (MBM) in pig feeds.

The ban is one of the measures introduced to control BSE.

While the ban has not yet been ratified in national legislation, six out of the
nine largest pig abattoirs have made it clear that they intend to institute the
change from May 2004..

                      Knight-Ridder Tribune Business News

                                August 12, 2006

Drought puts state's crops in bad shape.

BYLINE: John Dobberstein

LENGTH: 651 words



HIGHLIGHT: cotton trade forecasted


Aug. 12--Oklahoma's cotton, sorghum and peanut crops will shrink dramatically
this year, the government predicted Friday, continuing the litany of bad news
for the state's farmers.

Oklahoma's cotton production may drop by 30 percent, with only 250,000 bales
expected at harvest, according to the U.S. Department of Agriculture's July
estimates.

"I hope we make that. We may not," said J.C. Banks, a professor and cotton
specialist for Oklahoma State University's Cooperative Extension service.

Record cotton harvests were recorded in 2004 and 2005 in Oklahoma. Last year's
harvest brought in 358,000 bales and $80 million.

The 2006 cotton crop was battered by searing heat and drought. Some dryland crop
areas in southwestern Oklahoma are seeing the worst drought on record, Banks
said.

On Tuesday, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration rated most of
Oklahoma in the "extreme" or "exceptional" drought category, with less-serious
drought conditions in the northeast and Panhandle regions.

Most cotton fields in eastern Tillman County are in the crop disaster category,
Banks said.

In the state's irrigation district for cotton, surrounding Lake Altus Lugert,
water has been severely rationed and producers may run out in a week or two,
Banks said. Irrigation wells in Harmon County are running dry, and irrigation
has stopped.

"That's really going to hurt our yield," Banks said. "This is a critical time
where we need to fill the cotton boles."

The only cotton in decent shape, Banks said, is in west-central Oklahoma, in
Caddo and Beckham counties, where more irrigation has been possible.

It's not just Oklahoma, Banks said. Georgia, Texas and Alabama combined will
produced 4.1 million fewer bales of cotton than last year. Nationally, the
cotton crop should be 20.4 million bales, down 14 percent from last year's
record 23.9 million bales, the USDA said.

Sorghum production in Oklahoma could fall 20 percent from last year's crop, with
9.8 million bushels expected in 2006. That would be a drop of one-third from
2004's harvest of 14.4 million bushels.

The soybean harvest will also be smaller, with 5.7 million bushels expected this
year -- down nearly 28 percent from 2005. Nationally, soybean production is
forecast at 2.93 billion bushels, down 5 percent.

Oklahoma's peanut crop, already dwindling because of changes in federal
programs, will take another big hit.

The USDA predicts a harvest of 72 million pounds, a 31 percent decrease from
2005 and the lowest amount since 1956. About 24,000 acres will be harvested, the
lowest total since 1930.

Oklahoma's share of the peanut crop is small compared to states like Georgia,
which could harvest 1.4 billion pounds of peanuts this year. But Georgia, Texas,
Alabama and Florida also face big reductions in peanut yields. The national crop
could be one-third smaller this year than in 2005.

The alfalfa hay crop in Oklahoma could be 23 percent smaller in 2006, and
production of all other hay should be down nearly 17 percent.

The corn forecast for Oklahoma is better, with 28.6 million bushels expected --
only 150,000 bushels less than last year.

The outlook has improved for meat. Analysts raised forecasts for beef and
chicken production, as well as price forecasts for cattle, chickens and hogs.

The pace of beef exports has picked up, with strong sales to Canada and Mexico.
Recovery of the Japanese market, closed to the U.S. until recently over fears of
mad cow disease, will occur gradually, analysts said.

The Associated Press contributed to this story.

To see more of the Tulsa World, or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.tulsaworld.com.

                             734 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                 February 2, 1997, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

Farmers Cultivating Suburban Neighbors

BYLINE: By The New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Page 21; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 800 words

DATELINE: WOODBINE, Md.


As the suburban frontier seeps across the countryside, officials here in Howard
County are trying to convince farmers that their new neighbors are an untapped
market rather than the ushers of doom.

Phil Gottwals, the county's agriculture marketer, wants farmers to see the
purchasing potential of the new residents, in the county of 260,000 people
between Baltimore and Washington.

"It's the best thing that can happen to you, because your market just came
here," Mr. Gottwals recently said of the farmers. Instead of growing soybeans or
hay, which he said took hundreds of acres and a strong commodities market for a
profit, farmers should turn to produce.

Mr. Gottwals, who was hired six months ago as the county's first agriculture
marketer, says that farmers can make more money on much less acreage by growing
tomatoes, peppers, lettuce and a variety of berries as well as less familiar
like Jamaican black beans and lemon grass.

He also encourages them to sell directly to stores, restaurants and individuals
and to start "pick your own" farms.

Mr. Gottwals is preaching a new way of life for farmers, asking those who savor
the isolation of the fields to deal with strangers, handle telephone calls from
desperate restaurants late at night and perhaps even run educational tours.

As Denise Sharp, part owner of a pick-your-own fruit-and-vegetable farm, put it:
"It's like living in a state park. In season you're open seven days a week
usually long hours -- 7 in the morning and until the market closes."

Mr. Gottwals is one of a handful of agriculture marketers on the East Coast
trying to persuade farmers to cultivate local sales rather than depending upon
the whims of the Midwest-dominated commodities market. This trend to what is
known as metropolitan farming on the East Coast is being tracked by Duncan
Hilchey, an agriculture development specialist for Cornell University's farming
alternatives program in the department of rural sociology.

Until six months ago, Howard County had been content with a program in which it
has committed $100 million over the past 19 years to preserve 17,000 acres for
agriculture. Under this plan, the county paid farmers the market value of their
acreage to maintain it for agricultural use for perpetuity, though the land
could be taken out of production. Purchasers of the property have to abide by
the agreement. Money for the program came from a special real estate development
tax.

But the 17,000 acres represent only 40 percent of the agricultural land in the
county, and the preservation plan does not insulate farmers from development
pressures, like those from the county's largest city, Columbia, a planned
community that now has 85,000 residents.

Donna Mennitto, the administrator of the county's agricultural land preservation
program, said the county wants to insure that agriculture becomes more than a
bucolic backdrop to attract high-tech businesses to the county, "Agriculture
preservation just preserves the farmland not the farmer," Ms. Mennitto said.

Residential and business development has contributed to the loss of 3,300 farms
in Maryland over the last 10 years, to 13,700 in 1996. The United States
Department of Agriculture reports that in the same period, New York lost 7,000
of 43,000 farms and Connecticut lost 300 of 4,100 farms. The number of farms in
New Jersey actually rose by 400, to 9,200.

Profits from metropolitan farming can ease the pressures on farmers to turn a
quick profit on the sale of their land to developers. With this type of farming,
growers can operate like business suppliers, Mr. Hilchey said. They can develop
markets, often catering to the culinary tastes of neighboring communities, he
said, either by setting up a farmer's market or allowing neighbors to invest
money for part of the farm's produce. Direct marketing also allows farmers extra
profits for acting as the distributor.

Mr. Gottwals cites the case of Giant Food as an example of how farmers can take
advantage of local markets. Giant, the state's largest supermarket chain,
initiated a program three years ago to find local farmers as suppliers. Since
the program's inception, Giant has gone from working with 11 local farmers to
100 growers, whose fields are not more than 200 miles from a store.

Mr. Gottwals draws inspiration from local pioneers in metropolitan farming.

Farmers since 1963, Fenby Moore and his sister, Lynn, with 250 acres, own one of
the larger farms in Howard County, and they have dedicated their acreage to a
pick-your-own fruit-and-vegetable business.

"You have a tremendous, large community base here with a heightened awareness of
eating properly with more fresh fruits and vegetables and you have great
farmland here," Ms. Moore said. "What could be a better combination?"

LOAD-DATE: February 2, 1997

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1997 The New York Times Company


                             735 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                              Journal of Commerce

                            January 8, 1988, Friday

GUANGDONG OFFICIAL PREDICTS SUGAR SHORTAGE WILL WORSEN

BYLINE: NOEL FLETCHER; Journal of Commerce Special

SECTION: EXPORTS, Pg. 5A

LENGTH: 491 words

DATELINE: BEIJING


The current nationwide sugar shortage may worsen this year, an official from
China's largest sugarcane-producing area says.

Sugar and pork, China's most popular meat, have been rationed for a month in n
effort to stabilize prices and supplies.

Although China is a producer of sugarcane and sugar beets, it already imports -
mainly from Australia, Thailand and Cuba - to meet ever-growing domestic demand.

A new player was the United States, which sold 146,000 tons of raw cane sugar at
a price lower than the world market, prompting charges of dumping by some
others. The U.S. Department of Agriculture insisted it isn't trying to corner
the market.

Ling Botang, deputy governor of southern Guangdong province, says it will begin
to offer subsidies this year to spur cane cultivation after two successive years
of reduced output.

Starting this month, farmers will receive subsidies equivalent to US$ 2.70 a ton
on sugarcane sold to the government, Mr. Ling said. Refineries will get just
under US$ 3 a ton on sales to the government.

Mr. Ling believes Guangdong's sugarcane production for calendar 1987 will come
out at 14.4 million tons. That would be 1.9 million tons less than 1986 and 5.8
million tons below 1985.

A reduction in cultivated land is a primary cause of the shortfall, he said.
Guangdong had 100,000 acres less sown to sugarcane last year than in 1986,
leaving its total cane area at 568,000 acres.

Land for sugar beets and sugarcane also is dwindling in neighboring Fujian
province on the southeastern coast and in northeastern Jilin and Heilongjiang
provinces.

Farmers find producing sugar less profitable than breeding fish and growing
fruit and grain. This is in part a result of the government's shift toward a
market economy, allowing people to grow and sell cash crops.

Mr. Ling attacked the "unreasonable" prices offered for sugarcane to farmers in
Guangdong, saying those payments have remained stable for several years while
costs of production materials have risen.

China maintains state plans for sugar production. As a result, 110 pounds of
sugarcane in Guangdong costs less than the same amount of firewood, he said.
Consequently, farmers are suffering losses and being tempted to other crops.

The Ministry of Finance began offering subsidies last October to encourage sugar
production and ease shortages in non-producing areas.

Under the program - scheduled to end next September - the ministry provides US$
16 for each ton of sugar a refinery sells to the government. The Guangdong
subsidy apparently supplements the allocation from the Ministry of Finance.

Some factories, however, say they are now having problems with losses. They
arise from subsidizing farmers through increased prices for sugarcane and sugar
beets.

China imported 1.2 million metric tons of sugar from Australia and Thailand in
the first nine months of last year, plus unspecified amounts from Cuba.

LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                  Copyright 1988 The Journal of Commerce, Inc.


                             736 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

              September 9, 1982, Thursday, Late City Final Edition

COMMODITIES;
Hogs and Pork Bellies Show a Sharp Increase

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

SECTION: Section D; Page 16, Column 5; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 424 words


Live hogs and frozen pork belly futures prices rallied yesterday on the Chicago
Mercantile Exchange while cattle futures declined.  Live hogs for delivery in
May and July of next year fell by the 2-cent daily limit in early trading but
gained back the losses and settled with 2-cent gains in ''tumultuous'' trading,
said John Ginzel, a livestock analyst in Chicago with Drexel Burnham Lambert
Inc.

Live hogs for delivery in October and frozen pork bellies for delivery in
February settled at new highs.  Cattle prices, meanwhile, were weaker, with
influence coming from lower cash prices for carcass beef, Mr. Ginzel said.  Live
cattle were 0.10 cent to 0.67 cent lower with the contract for delivery in
October at 61.50 cents a pound; feeder cattle were 0.05 cent to 0.70 cent lower
with September at 68.90 cents a pound; live hogs were 0.30 cent lower to 1.28
cents higher with October at 64.75 cents a pound, and frozen pork bellies were
0.50 cent to 2 cents higher with February at 90.75 cents a pound.

Grain and soybean futures prices closed mixed in light trading on the Chicago
Board of Trade.  Most traders were said to be evening up their contract
positions prior to the release after the close of trading of an updated harvest
forecast from the well-known crop forecaster Conrad Leslie of Chicago.

Mr. Leslie predicted that the United States corn harvest would be 8.365 billion
bushels, and the soybean harvest would be 2.332 billion bushels. Both estimates
were slightly higher than the August forecast released by the Department of
Agriculture, which sent grain prices plummeting last month.

In wheat trading yesterday, prices were higher in early trading, with support
said to be coming from increases in demand for exports and concern about the
Australian wheat crop, which is in need of rainfall.

Corn and soybeans for delivery in September fell to new life-ofcontract lows.
Wheat settled 1/4 cent to 1 cent higher with the contract for delivery in
September at $3.30 a bushel; corn was 3/4 cent to 4 1/2 cents lower with the
contract for delivery in September at $2.18 1/2 a bushel; oats were 1 cent lower
to 1 cent higher with September at $1.48 3/4 a bushel, and soybeans were 1 3/4
cent lower to 1 cent higher with September at $5.38 3/4 a bushel.

                          Australian Financial Review

                            June 12, 2013 Wednesday
                                 First Edition

Good prospects for grain but US affects price

BYLINE: Commodities Jake Mitchell

SECTION: MARKET WRAP; Pg. 27

LENGTH: 396 words


It is shaping up as an above-average year for Australian wheat production after
favourable conditions over the past few weeks, but unfortunately for local
farmers the story is similar in the United States. Fears about wet and frosty
American conditions helped to support grain prices in May, but a window of good
weather has allowed farmers to make strong progress in planting wheat and corn.
US corn generally drives global grain prices.

"Some of the worst weather fears out of the US have started to dissipate over
the past few weeks," said Commonwealth Bank of Australia agricultural commodity
strategist Luke Mathews. "We have seen a significant improvement in [the]
corn-planting progress."

The market is looking to the World Agricultural Supply and Demand Estimates
report due out on Wednesday for updated United States Department of Agriculture
production forecasts, and the global grain outlook going forward.

As of last week about 91 per cent of the US corn crop had been planted, which is
slightly behind the five-year average of 95 per cent completion by early June.
CBA has tipped local wheat Â­production in 2013-14 to be just under 25 million
tonnes.

This is an improvement of 2.8 million tonnes year-on-year, and above the
five-year average of 24.5 million tonnes. Most of this crop will be harvested in
November and December.

Desperately needed rainfall across most of Australia's grain belt in May, has
allowed farmers to assume seeding and provided an improved outlook for grain and
oil-seed production.

"Production prospects currently look sound," Mr Mathews said. "The majority of
the crop has been planted and what hasn't been planted looks as though it will
go into the ground under favourable conditions."

Increased Western Australian output is expected to make a strong contribution to
Australian production.

Market Check grain economist Â­Carolina Morison said while US production
significantly affected the prices Australian wheat farmers could attain, local
factors were also important.

Tight wheat stocks from last year's crop are supporting local prices, Ms Morison
said.

"Obviously the offshore market is extremely important for us, but at the moment
we have our conditions also affecting the domestic market," she said.

The top five destinations for AustraÂ­lian wheat are all in Asia, while the US
supplies South America and Europe in a significant capacity.

                             738 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                              The Washington Post

                      April 3, 1983, Sunday, Final Edition

More Farmers Taking the Organic Route

BYLINE: By Ward Sinclair, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: Business & Finance; H1

LENGTH: 782 words


Delmar Akerland worried a long time about the dead songbirds along his fence
rows before he decided to adopt organic farming methods..

Worried about his costs and what he was doing to his land and wildlife, Akerland
finally decided to farm differently. Without much sense of the many problems he
would face he abruptly took his Nebraska farm off its diet of chemical
fertilizers and pesticides in 1967.

It wasn't easy, but in 15 years Akerland's 760-acre spread near Valley, Neb.,
has become a showcase of commercial farming by nonchemical methods. Visitors
from all over the world are drawn to the place by the idea of growing food on a
large scale without the costly fertilizer, pesticide and fuel expenses that
characterize most of contemporary American agriculture.

One reason they seek out Akerland is that the traditional sources of farming
research data and guidance, the U.S. Department of Agriculture and the state
extension services, can't offer much advice on alternative farming.

No one is calling it a groundswell, yet, but economically-pressed farmers are
showing more interest these days in producing food on a large scale in less
expensive, more soil-conserving ways. Akerland's approach is one of those ways.

When the USDA published a report on organic farming in 1980, it received about
40,000 requests for copies. The department's organic specialist handled an
estimated 2,000 individual requests for more information in two years. Half of
the hundreds of farmers who attended Nebraska's alternative-agriculture day last
year were conventional farmers seeking more information.

To fill that information gap, Akerland and other farmers have formed a new
research organization, the first of its kind on a nationwide scale, to
helpothers avoid the trial-and-error method of nonchemical farming.

The executive director of the new Institute for Alternative Agriculture, based
in Greenbelt, Md., is I. Garth Youngberg, who was the USDA's only full-time
organic farming specialist until his job was abolished last year.

That action,, ostensibly for budget reasons, came at a time when Congress and
the administration were at loggerheads over legislation to establish a small
USDA program of research into techniques known variously as organic,
regenerative and alternative farming.

The bill, proposed by Rep. James H. Weaver (D-Ore.), was defeated on the House
floor after the USDA and Republican loyalists complained that the program would
duplicate current research and would be too costly. Weaver and his allies intend
to reintroduce the bill this year.

Last year's flap drew new attention to organic farming and its stepchild
treatment in traditional research channels. Witnesses before Weaver's
subcommittee talked about their inability to get the kind of guidance they need.
They talked about the economies they have achieved, the quality of food they
have produced, the need to do things differently.

Meanwhile, the institute in Greenbelt isn't waiting for help from Congress or
the USDA. With some private and foundation grants as seed money, Youngberg and
the board of directors, which includes Akerland and other organic farmers, are
laying plans to make research grants, publish information and stimulate interest
in farming with as few chemicals as possible.

"Yes, the image has been a problem for organic farmers," Youngberg admits. "We
chose the word 'alternative' deliberately . . . so we could embrace and relate
to the whole agricultural spectrum in the United States.

"We have no intention of being combative," he said. "We hope USDA will see us as
a resource, maybe even work with us, so we can help by communicating to farmers
the things that are relevant to organic or alternative agriculture."

Once the institute gets rolling, Youngberg envisions a team of researchers
working as "an alternative agriculture think tank . . . looking at the
implications of farm policies in this country, the impact and restraints on
organic farmers by today's tax, credit, energy, trade and commodities policies."

The institute also intends to try to dispel the popular image of the organic
farmer as a freakish health-food nut who is trying to check out of the 20th
century.

"Organic farmers today--and we think there are between 20,000 and 30,000 of
them--use traditional rotation techniques, without chemicals, but they are in no
sense old-time farmers. They are very sophisticated, using modern machinery,
different legumes and corn and wheat varieties, different tilling methods,"
Youngberg said. "What they are not getting from USDA are ways of improving these
systems. This is not a nonscientific movement. These farmers want and need
science."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                       Copyright 1983 The Washington Post

                               The New York Times

               April 30, 1986, Wednesday, Late City Final Edition

FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Nuclear Accident News Spurs Farm Products

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

SECTION: Section D; Page 16, Column 5; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 293 words


Speculation that radiation from the Soviet nuclear accident may have damaged
Russian farms sent grain, soybean and livestock prices soaring on United States
futures exchanges.

However, a senior United States Government meteorologist, Norton D. Strommen,
said the wind since the time of the accident on Saturday had mostly been blowing
into the northwest, away from the major winter wheat area. ''At this time,
certainly the plume has had a minimal impact'' on Soviet crops, he said.

Ed Cook, an Agriculture Department economist, said the radioactive plume from
the accident mainly blew over Byelorussia and the Baltic states. This area, he
said, grows mainly rye and spring barley for animal feed, sugar beets, some
spring wheat and animal forage.

It also produces 13 percent of the Soviet Union's milk and 11 to 12 percent of
its meat. Wheat advanced the 20-cent-a-bushel limit allowed for daily trading
and corn was up its 10 cent-a-bushel limit.

Prices broke off those highs, however, when farmers began selling their grain
because of the sharp run-up caused by the Russian scare, Victor Lespinasse, an
analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said.

Most deliveries of live cattle, feeder cattle and live hogs at the Chicago
Mercantile were higher by the 1 1/2-cent-a-pound limit. Frozen pork bellies were
up by their 2-cent-a-pound limit.

Denmark and Poland ship a lot of hams to the United States, Tom O'Hare, an
analyst in New York with Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, said. There are
some reports, he said, that parts of Poland have stopped slaughtering animals
because of the accident. Petroleum futures prices were mostly lower on the New
York Mercantile Exchange.

Precious metals were higher on the Commodity Exchange in New York.

                     Belfast News Letter (Northern Ireland)

                           November 1, 2003, Saturday

LABEL PLAN BIG BLOW FOR UNITED STATES

BYLINE: DAVID MCCOY

SECTION: FARMING LIFE; Pg. 17

LENGTH: 516 words


A NEW cost-benefit analysis of the mandatory country-of-origin labeling (MCOOL)
law released by the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA), fully
supported the view that there was no evidence that it would benefit pork
producers, meat packers, retailers or consumers, said National Pork Producers'
Council (NPPC) president, Jon Caspers.

"This much-anticipated USDA analysis indicates that in the first year alone
following implementation of MCOOL, the covered commodities could see costs of up
to nearly $ 4 billion (pounds 2.36 billion)," said Mr Caspers.

"It is difficult to understand why anyone would support such a costly and
burdensome rule that offers virtually no benefit to the nation's 1.5 million
farmers, firms and retail establishments that it will impact."

The cost-benefit analysis is a US Government system of calculating costs to
businesses whenever new Government regulations are created.

The analysis is designed to measure the desirability of government programs by
weighing both the long-term and short-term benefits of a program against the
long-term and short-term costs of a program.

According to Mr Caspers, the USDA analysis validates producer concerns that
consumers are not willing to pay a price premium for products bearing US origin
labels and, therefore, higher prices will not be generated for pork products
covering the costs of MCOOL.

"If there was a consumer demand for country-of-origin labeling, the market would
have demanded it years ago," he said.

"The lack of participation by any suppliers in other government labeling
programs clearly indicates, however, that consumers simply don't have a strong
preference for the labels."

Mr Caspers says USDA's cost-benefit clearly states that MCOOL does not provide
valid information to give consumers information on food safety.

"This law doesn't impact any of the food safety laws currently in place,
therefore consumers would not be provided with additional food safety
assurances."

In addition, Mr Caspers said MCOOL was a trade protectionist measure and had the
potential to drastically affect international trade.

"Some of the US pork industry's major trading partners have already indicated
that they will file challenges under the World Trade Organization's (WTO) trade
agreements and could retaliate if MCOOL is implemented," he said.

"In today's global marketplace, where pork producers have just come out from
under 18 months of straight losses, we cannot afford to lose even a small
percentage of the exports that provide significant value to the US pork
industry."

l A NEW report points to further infertility worries on pig farms in England and
Wales.

The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs is conducting a survey to
establish if the causes of the current bout of infertility is due to a new
disease syndrome or linked to similar problems which arose in 2002.

Some producers have seen infertility levels above 15 per cent and extreme cases
recorded at 50 per cent.

Twenty herds will now be targeted in this survey.
