                             741 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                            The Press (Christchurch)

                            April 18, 2002, Thursday

Dairy farms' energy use compares well

SECTION: FARMING Pg. 15; FARMING

LENGTH: 307 words


New Zealand dairy farms use less energy than dairy farms overseas, a Ministry of
Agriculture and Forestry commissioned study shows.

This is despite the fact energy use has doubled on New Zealand dairy farms over
the last 20 years.

The study, prepared by the late Dr Colin Wells of the University of Otago, is
based on data from 150 dairy farms, irrigated and non- irrigated, throughout the
country.

MAF director of policy information and regions Alan Walker said the main cause
of increased energy use was the growing use of nitrogen fertilisers, and the
amount of energy needed for their manufacture.

He said, however, that the high power requirement for spray irrigation was
emerging as a potential sustainability issue.

Some dairy farmers are big power users.

The biggest in Canterbury with deep wells have a power requirement equivalent to
a small town, and new power lines have been needed.

Mr Walker said the energy ratio used for comparison is the OER, which is a ratio
of the total primary energy input per kilogram of milksolids to the calorific
energy output of those milksolids.

New Zealand's OER is 0.59 compared to an estimate of 2.8 in the United States,
and 0.67 to 2.4 in Europe.

Mr Walker said individual New Zealand farms, particularly those with pumped
irrigation or high nitrogen applications, may have higher OERs than some
conventional and organic farms in Europe.

He said a positive aspect of the report was that it identified areas where
energy efficiency could be improved.

"Paramount among these is taking opportunities to improve fertiliser management
and, in particular, judicious use of urea because of its high energy content."

He said best water management practices on irrigated farms, especially those
with high- pressure overhead spray systems, could reduce direct energy use.

                     Belfast News Letter (Northern Ireland)

                           February 1, 2003, Saturday

US BEEF FIGURES IMPROVE

SECTION: FARMING LIFE; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 234 words


NEAR-RECORD beef production, a falling cattle inventory, and lower cattle on
feed numbers characterised the United States beef industry in 2002.

Last year, the US produced 12.283 million tonnes of beef, up two per cent
compared with 2001, and the second highest annual production in more than a
decade (the highest was 12.146m tonnes in 2000).

The United States Department of Agriculture expects US beef production to fall
five per cent, to 11.65m tonnes this year, while Steiner Consulting Group is
forecasting a 2.9 per cent fall.

The high production was assisted by the drought-induced turnoff of additional
heifers, which caused a decline in total cattle numbers for the seventh
consecutive year.

As at January 1 this year, the US cattle inventory was 96.4m head, down 0.3 per
cent from the 96.7m in 2002. The US cattle herd is expected to begin rebuilding
this year, providing weather conditions continue to improve.

The strong demand for beef in the US during 2002 buoyed meat prices in spite of
the large beef, pork and poultry supplies. Per capita beef spending reached a
record high in 2002, up (US$ ) 11 (pounds 6.93) to (US$ ) 210 (pounds 132.30)
per capita.

Most analysts are expecting a sharp rise in US meat prices this year, fuelled by
lower beef supplies, a restoration of poultry exports to Russia, high feed grain
costs and a recovery in export demand.

                             743 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

                   October 12, 1995, Thursday, DAILY EDITION

Cropwatchers buy on rumor, and news too

BYLINE: Scott Haggett

SECTION: SECTION 2, INVESTING; Pg. 32, Open Interest

LENGTH: 631 words


Agricultural markets put a new spin on the old adage ''buy on rumor, sell on
news,'' yesterday. Having already bought on rumors U.S. agricultural production
would be severely harmed by recent bad weather, they also bought when the
government agency responsible for forecasting these things confirmed that was
indeed the case.

The latest figures released by the U.S. Department of Agriculture sent traders
into a buying frenzy as they competed for their piece of the shrinking crop.

The excitement began on Tuesday as suspicions grew that the forecast would be
bullish, particularly for corn, the price of which reached a seven-year high.

The market had been expecting the USDA to tell it the corn harvest would be down
by just over 2%. Instead it forecast a drop of 4%. U.S. farmers are expected to
harvest 17.39 million tonnes of corn. One month ago the estimate was 18.55
million tonnes.

The agency said yesterday that the U.S. soybean crop, at 5.99 million tonnes,
would be one-third smaller than September's forecast of 8.99 million tonnes, a
4% reduction when the market expected a drop of less than 1%.

The size of the U.S. wheat crop was also downgraded yesterday. It went to 10.75
million tonnes from last month's anticipated 11.63 million tonnes.

The sheer scale of the reduction, especially in corn and soybeans, was almost
shocking. The markets opened higher in all three commodities following the
morning announcement. Soybeans for November delivery opened US16 cents a bushel
higher than Tuesday's US$6.48 close.

The news that crops would be smaller wasn't exactly a surprise. September
weather in U.S. growing regions was some of the worst on record.

An early frost damaged immature soybean and corn crops in the field. What no one
knew was just how hard that frost hit.

''I don't think anyone expected this,'' said Joe Victor, a grains analyst at
Allendale Inc. in Crystal Lake, Ill.

''The trade missed the reduction in bean end stocks, that's what really got
everyone excited.''

For Victor, the soybean estimates provided a welcome boost for a market that has
been sleepy most of the year.

While corn and wheat contracts surged higher or lower as different estimates hit
the market, the soy complex has been quiet.

The only news that provided any excitement was last month's frost report, which
helped push the price up.

''The bean complex finally got the attention at the (Chicago) Board of Trade,''
he said.

''Every commodity other than beans got a good rally this year. Now there's a bit
of a floor under the bean market too.''

Dave Armstrong, a grains analyst at Chicago Corp., said the number of weather
scares the market endured in the growing season had toughened it into believing
the crop numbers would be better than reported, simply because that was the
pattern for the rest of the year.

''The soybeans number came as a big surprise to me,'' he said.

After the hot weather in August, expectations got pretty low. ''That didn't
affect yields so everyone got cranked up and didn't expect much'' change in
yesterday's numbers.

While the USDA report helped grains and oilseeds markets open sharply higher, it
didn't take long for traders to figure out they had perhaps overshot the mark
and begin selling.

November soybeans hung on to US10.25 cents of their initial gain, closing at
US$6.5925 and nearing the contract-high close of US$6.6375, set during last
month's frost scare.

The December wheat contract got as high as US6 cents above Tuesday's close of
US$4.8375 but dropped over the course of the session to US$4.8275, a US1 cents
fall.

The December corn contract also failed to hold its morning highs but managed a
strong gain nonetheless. It closed up US5 cents at US$3.2275.

TYPE: COLUMN

                       Copyright 1995 Financial Post Ltd.


                             744 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                               The Daily Yomiuri

                            June 11, 1992, Thursday

Ministry Unveils Major Farm Reforms;
ternationally competitive and attractive to young people.

SECTION: Pg. 8

LENGTH: 612 words


The Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries Ministry unveiled a series of
far-reaching reforms Wednesday for Japan's farming industry to make it more

The reforms, outlining what could map out the country's agricultural policies
for the 21st century, emphasize increasing productivity through consolidating
into large-scale agro-businesses and producing market-sensitive agricultural
goods.

As a policy goal, the ministry said it wants the average full-time rice farmer
to tend 10 to 20 hectares by the year 2000, or fields 15 to 30 times larger than
the current average.

Such economies of scale, according to ministry's estimates, should reduce
production costs to 50 to 60 percent of what they are today.

The ministry drew up the proposals as the country continues to come under
political bombardment from abroad--especially the United States--to open its
domestic market to foreign rice, a politically sensitive issue that has kept the
existing ban firmly in place.

The agriculture industry, whose share of gross national product has been
steadily declining, faces its own internal problems--a declining number of
school graduates taking over family farms. There are currently about 3.83
million farming households in Japan, including part-time farmers. In 1990, only
1,800 graduates became farmers.

To rectify the situation, the ministry said it will implement comprehensive
measures to help average farmers earn a life-time income of 200 million yen to
250 million yen by working 1,800 to 2,000 hours annually. The proposed earnings
and work load would be identical to those of non-farming industries.

The ministry will urge that full-time farmers expand production and that
farmers, living in locations where economies of scale are hard to attain, merge
with others in the community or neighboring areas.

If all goes according to plan, the country's overall agriculture industry will
be composed of 350,000 to 400,000 family-based full-time farming households in
the year 2000 and about 40,000 to 50,000 community-wide joint organizations,
according to the ministry's long-term policy target.

Of the two categories, about 150,000 households and 20,000 organizations are
expected to engage mostly in the production of rice, accounting for about 80
percent of the country's total rice production at the turn of the century, the
ministry said.

Overall, the ministry envisions the number of farming households to decline to
between 2.5 million and 3 million by the year 2000.

Industry observers commented that all the policy targets appeared realistic, but
the ministry failed to mention specific steps to realize the goals.

They said the omission of concrete steps reflected the fact that the Uruguay
Round of GATT multilateral trade negotiations were still going on. The talks
hope to make cross-border trade--including that of rice--far less restrictive.

A delay in the negotiations has undoubtedly limited the ministry's policy
options, observers said.

In a related development, Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries Minister Masami
Tanabu told reporters the new proposals are unrelated to the ongoing Uruguay
Round talks.

Sources close to the ministry said it decided in the spring of 1991 to compile a
new series of agricultural reforms over the course of a year on the assumption
the Uruguay Round would have been ended.

Touching on the government's traditional practice of setting rice producers'
prices under the Staple Food Control Law, a ministry report released with the
proposals stated the government should, in the future, take into account
production costs of highly productive rice growers in determining annual prices.

LOAD-DATE: September 21, 1994

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                        Copyright 1992 The Daily Yomiuri


                             745 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                            The Press (Christchurch)

                          December 21, 2000, Thursday

Merger decision expected this week

SECTION: FARMING Pg. 18; FARMING

LENGTH: 425 words


WELLINGTON -- Dairy industry giants New Zealand Dairy Group and Kiwi
Co-operative Dairies are expected to announce any day an agreement to merge.

The announcement will come after years of argument over industry restructuring,
but will coincide with increased pressure from the European Union, as well as
the United States, for New Zealand to change the Dairy Board's status as a
"State trading enterprise".

Industry leaders, including the chairman and chief executive of NZDG, Henry Van
Der Heyden and John Spencer, and their Kiwi counterparts, Greg Gent and Craig
Norgate, met Agriculture Minister Jim Sutton this week.

Mr Sutton declined comment on the talks, but has previously expressed
willingness to make any legislative changes needed for restructuring in line
with the wishes of dairy farmers.

He made his offer nine months ago after the two big companies failed to agree on
a cornerstone merger of their operations, needed before the Dairy Board would be
absorbed into a new national dairy company.

Because that cornerstone was not in place, with Commerce Commission approval, a
clause providing for deregulation of the Dairy Board in dairy legislation
expired on September 1. In a draft decision on the industry's initial
application, the commission had declined the merger because the detriment to
farmers of having only one company to supply had outweighed the benefits of the
deal.

The next application to the commission would need to make a better case for the
advantages to farmers, and the country, of creating a company that would be able
to compete in consolidating international markets.

Farmers have said Dairy Board chairman Graham Fraser has talked of a merger
announcement by Christmas, and Federated Farmers dairy leader Charlie Pedersen
-- who has made similar comments -- has confirmed he expects a decision any
moment.

Farmers have consistently called for a mega-merger of manufacturing companies
with the industry's marketing arm, which the Dairy Board has predicted will
increase export dairy sales from $ 7.7 billion to $ 30 billion by 2010.

The first study suggesting the integration of manufacturing and marketing would
deliver such benefits was done in 1995. It showed that hundreds of millions of
dollars would be saved if the industry used the resources spread around the then
dozen or so manufacturing companies efficiently rather than competitively.

The minimum level of savings has since been estimated at $ 300 million a year.
--NZPA

                             746 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                   July 9, 1995, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER WEST SIDE;
Urbanites Get Back to the Land (Dirty Fingernails Optional)

BYLINE: By SARAH KERSHAW

SECTION: Section 13;  Page 7;  Column 3;  The City Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 583 words


When Jean-Paul Courtens sent the first crops from his upstate farm into
Manhattan, he knew consumers would go crazy for his tomatoes, strawberries,
turnips and peas. But when he started talking about turning New Yorkers into
farmers, people told him he was nuts.

"The city? Those people could never have a relationship with the land," other
farmers told Mr. Courtens, who has been growing fruits and vegetables in
Columbia County since 1987.

Of course, the urbanites did not become typical farmers. They can be seen
gathering the crops in pantyhose and heels, on Roller Blades, while making play
dates, toting the harvest off in crinkled Weber's, Zabar's and D'Agostino
shopping bags.

The harvest takes place every Thursday from June to November, when the 225 New
York City members of Roxbury Farm, a community-supported agriculture project
that started five years ago, pick up their share of the produce in the courtyard
of St. Paul and St. Andrew United Methodist Church on West End Avenue and 86th
Street.

City consumers are more grateful for fresh produce than others who may take it
for granted, said Mr. Courtens, who studied farming in his native Holland. "They
are so psyched about this."

The latest trend in organic farming, community-supported agriculture farms, take
food co-ops a step further: the members actually finance all operations of the
farm.

There are about 470 community-supported farms in the United States and Canada,
the Biodynamic Farming and Gardening Association said, but Roxbury, which is
just outside Hudson in Claverack, is the first mainly supported by New Yorkers.
One other farm from Columbia County, Hawthorne Valley, has a small New York City
membership.

All 450 Roxbury members -- half from the Albany area -- are asked to go to the
farm twice yearly to help plan the budget, review the crops and help make
decisions about managing the 100-acre farm.

Members pay $258 a year per share, which covers produce delivered weekly from
June to November and biweekly from November to February. They are invited, but
not obligated, to work with Mr. Courtens on the land one day a month but they
can help out any time.

Mr. Courtens, 34, moved to New York in 1987 and joined Hawthorne Valley Farm as
a vegetable grower. Three years later, he took over Roxbury, which was owned by
his wife's family.

He is a disciple of Rudolf Steiner, the Austrian scientist and philosopher who
developed a method of farming called biodynamics. It goes beyond organic
farming, aiming for self-sufficiency and environmental harmony. Mr. Courtens
produces his own hay, uses his cows' manure as fertilizer and tries to produce
his own seeds from the crops.

"Anything you bring to the land must act as a medication for the farm," Mr.
Courtens said.

Roxbury Farm has a waiting list for new members. But, as Mr. Courtens noted,
there are plenty of farmers without partners. "It all depends on whether people
are daring enough to go out and find a farmer and make it work out," he said.
   SARAH KERSHAW



A Weekly Harvest

For $258 a year, farm members get a weekly delivery of biodynamic produce June
through November. One recent share included: 12 ounces of salad mix, 8 ounces of
sugar snap peas, 1 head of lettuce, 1 bunch of turnips, 2 bunches of broccoli,
one handful each of sage, lemonbalm, mint and parsley and one box of
strawberries, and a weekly written newsletter by the farmer, Jean-Paul Courtens,
which sometimes includes a recipe.

LOAD-DATE: July 9, 1995

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

(Linda Rosier for The New York Times)

                             747 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                               Delhi News-Record

                            January 5, 2017 Thursday
                                 Final Edition

Dahlia operation niche farming at its finest; Creekside Growers aims to dominate
market

BYLINE: Monte Sonnenberg, Delhi News-Record

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A2

LENGTH: 602  words


Thousands of brides in Canada and the United States can thank Nick and Hilary
VanderHeide of Hartford for making their special day extra beautiful.

In seven short years, the couple has established themselves as one of the top
producers of dahlias in Ontario. By 2020, the owners of Creekside Growers on
Norfolk Road 19 hope to be the largest producers in Canada.

Creekside Growers stole a march on the competition recently when VanderHeide
revolutionized the way he plants his crop. He modified a cultivator so that it
digs a trench, loosens the soil, hills over the tuber root when planted, and
applies driptape irrigation.

By doing all this in one pass, Creekside Growers has greatly reduced its costs
while boosting productivity.

"We save a ton of money on labour," VanderHeide says. "That part of planting and
putting out drip line - I bet it cut our labour costs two-thirds.

"And we have a 20 per cent increase in production due to correct bulb depth and
the accuracy of nutrient and water placement. There is no wasted water and no
wasted fertilizer."

Innovation like this attracts the attention of the Ministry of Agriculture, Food
&; Rural Affairs. For these insights and results, the ministry recently
recognized Creekside Growers with a 2016 Premier's Award for Agri-Food
Innovation Excellence.

Nick and Hilary VanderHeide are proof that you don't need a background in
agriculture to succeed at farming. What counts is a love of the land, a desire
to grow things, a good plan and the smarts to execute it.

For her part, Hilary is a university graduate with a bachelor of education
degree. She grew up on a hobby farm in Niagara-onthe-Lake.

Nick grew up in Sarnia and was running a home renovation business when the
couple decided to try their hand at farming. They acquired a 5.5-acre parcel
near Hartford and haven't looked back.

When Creekside Growers began in 2009, it was just Nick and Hilary. Today, the
couple employ 13 people during peak season and supply dahlias and peonies to a
market area that includes most of eastern Canada and the eastern United States
south to Kentucky.

At the outset, Creekside Growers tried growing many types of flowers. However,
the VanderHeides soon realized that the eclectic approach was too diverse and
required too many different growing techniques and marketing strategies.

They settled on dahlias - which comprise 65 per cent of their operation - and
peonies. They chose these flowers because they do best in moderate climates and
need cold winters.

Dahlias and peonies are premium flowers. They pay well if you grow them
properly. Because they've symbolized bonds of love and friendship since
Victorian times, dahlias are in high demand at weddings and wedding receptions.

Growing dahlias and peonies is not easy. They require a lot of attention.
Dahlias in particular are highly susceptible to insects and must be sprayed
twice a week.

As it stands, Creekside Growers and another grower in Flamborough are the two
largest producers of dahlias in Ontario. Both have a hard time keeping up with
demand.

The industry is expanding. In 2016, Creekside Growers had 18 kilometres of drip
tape. In 2017, this will grow to 30 kilometres.

A Premier's Award at this point will help the VanderHeides secure market share.
Creekside Growers does a lot of business on-line. Flashing a Premier's Award is
a seal of good house-keeping.

"It's nice to have something like this that lends legitimacy to your business,"
VanderHeide said. "Now, we're just not another online store. When you've been
recognized by the Ontario government, that gives you a lot of credibility."
MSonnenberg@postmedia.com

LOAD-DATE: January 5, 2017

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Contributed Photo; In seven short years, Nick and Hilary VanderHeide
have grown their floral operation near Wilsonville into one of Ontario's largest
producers of cut dahlias. With the VanderHeides are their children Lydia,
Elijah, Josiah, and Asher.;

                             748 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                            November 26, 2004 Friday

Farm revenue climbs 6.4 per cent on higher production of crops

BYLINE: CHRISTOPHER DONVILLE, Bloomberg News

SECTION: REPORT ON BUSINESS: CANADIAN; AGRICULTURE; Pg. B4

LENGTH: 298 words


Canadian farm revenue rose 6.4 per cent in the first nine months of 2004 on
higher production of crops including wheat and record subsidies, a government
survey shows.

Farmers and ranchers generated revenue of $26.1-billion, up from $24.5-billion a
year earlier, Statistics Canada said yesterday.

Revenue from field crops rose 13 per cent to $10.7-billion, and revenue from
livestock rose 1.6 per cent to $12.3-billion. Government financial support rose
4.2 per cent to a record $3.1-billion.

Improved crop sales partly reflect increased grain and oilseed harvests in 2003
after two years of drought, Statscan said. Revenue from cattle and calves fell
11 per cent to $3.4-billion, the least since 1995, reflecting the closing of the
U.S. border to Canadian cattle after the discovery of bovine spongiform
encephalopathy, or mad-cow disease, in a cow in Alberta in May, 2003.

"This is still an industry with a big-time revenue squeeze," Al Mussell, senior
research associate at the George Morris Centre, a Guelph, Ont.-based
agricultural think-tank, said before the figures were released.

"With costs rising, farmers are finding there's not enough revenue in the system
to support a reasonable standard of living."

While the United States eased its import ban to allow Canada to ship some beef,
efforts to resume cattle exports stalled after the United States found its own
case of the disease in a Washington state cow born in Alberta. The U.S.
Department of Agriculture is conducting a review that may lead to reopening the
border.

Revenue from hogs rose 21 per cent to a record $3.1-billion because of "robust
exports and strong consumer demand," Statscan said. Farmers exported 6.3 million
hogs in the first nine months, up 25 per cent from the same period in 2003,
Statscan said.

LOAD-DATE: September 18, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                               The New York Times

                            December 1, 2002 Sunday
                              Correction Appended
                              Late Edition - Final

U.S. Farmers Put Down Roots in Brazilian Soil

BYLINE:   By SIMON ROMERO

SECTION: Section 1; Column 1; Foreign Desk; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 960 words

DATELINE: LUIS EDUARDO MAGALHAES, Brazil


More than a century after his ancestors began farming in the Midwestern United
States, Dan Carroll's best hope of bringing his son into the family business is
to buy land in the savannas of Brazil.

Two months ago Mr. Carroll, of Carthage, Ill., bought a soybean farm on the
outskirts of this dusty town of pickup trucks and barbecue restaurants 350 miles
northeast of Brasilia. He joined more than a dozen other Americans who have
recently begun farming here.

"I have no doubt that Brazil is the future of global agriculture and I want my
son to be able to be part of that," Mr. Carroll, 46, said in an interview. "It's
prohibitively expensive for him to buy land in the States right now."

Recent arrivals like Mr. Carroll and his son, John, have brought the number of
American farmers in Brazil to more than 200, including a small Mennonite
community, according to AgBrazil, a company in Columbia, Mo., that brokers
Brazilian land deals.

Their numbers are expected to grow as Brazil's agricultural frontier expands.
The recent decline of Brazil's currency, the real, weakened much of the economy
but added value to export commodities, especially soybeans, in the last two
years.

Brazil's export surge is causing a sharp increase in the soybean crop across the
cerrado, a vast region of grasslands and savannas. Brazil has about four times
as much available farmland as the United States has, largely because of
improvements in soil fertility and the development of soybeans suitable to the
tropics.

The expansion of Brazil's agricultural frontier in the last two years is roughly
equal to Iowa's entire soybean acreage, according to the United States
Department of Agriculture's Brazil report, which was published in November.

"The guys who come down here now are awestruck," said Thomas Shanks, a farmer
from upstate New York who has been growing soybeans and corn in Brazil for the
last four years.

Mr. Shanks said he received phone calls from American farmers nearly every day
who were interested in buying farmland in Brazil.

Most are lured by relatively cheap land. Prices vary but cleared land in western
Bahia, the epicenter of the soybean boom, can be bought for about $700 an acre
compared with $3,850 in Illinois. There are few restrictions on foreign
ownership of land in Brazil.

"It's like getting a chance to open the Midwest to farming again," said Philip
F. Warnken, the president and chief executive of AgBrazil, which conducts tours
to the region each year. Farmers from Zimbabwe, Zambia and Canada have also
taken part in his tours.

Luis Eduardo Magalhaes has grown from a few hundred homes around a gas station
on the side of a highway a decade ago, into a community of about 35,000 people.
Sensing the importance of attracting investment, the town's businesses
spearheaded a movement to break away from the nearby city of Barreiras. They
succeeded two years ago and renamed the town.

"I don't care if they are Americans, Chinese, Africans, Argentines," Oziel
Oliveira, the town's first mayor, said over breakfast at his new two-story home.
"Anyone who wants to come here is welcome.".

He and his wife, Jusmari Oliveira, a state legislator, recently made a trip to
the United States to speak with Americans considering farming around the town.

Luis Eduardo has grown quickly, drawing thousands of migrants to work as
farmhands. Their district of town, made up of exposed cinderblock homes and bars
selling shots of sugar-cane rum, is called Iraq because of the lawlessness
there.

"Rent and just everything else is too expensive now," said Edson Carvalho, a
migrant who moved to Luis Eduardo from a poorer part of the state of Bahia.

Unlike the laborers who live in Iraq, almost everyone who owns a business or
farm descends from European or Japanese immigrants who settled decades ago in
southern Brazil. The first commercial farmers came nearly 20 years ago from the
southern state of Rio Grande do Sul.

Vilson Kublik, the manager of a bustling John Deere dealership here, said the
level of development in Luis Eduardo was good compared with the rest of Brazil.
"If they have a farm vehicle in United States, we'll sell the same one here," he
said.

In addition, American multinationals like Cargill and Bunge operate large
soybean crushing plants here.

Despite similarities with the United States, however, the integration of
American farmers is not without its problems. Few farmers speak fluent
Portuguese, preferring to have bilingual managers, and most Americans live only
part of the year in Brazil.

In addition, while the land may be cheap, transportation costs are not. Although
rail and river projects are under way, most farmers need to send their crops to
ports in trucks that barrel down pockmarked highways or dirt roads.

Still, the sheer availability of land appears to be on the side of farmers in
Brazil, which is larger than the contiguous 48 American states. While it is
second to the United States in soybean production, Brazil's output is growing
faster. It is expected to produce a record 49 million tons of soybeans this
harvest, up 13 percent from last year.

To the surprise of some Americans, the rapid expansion of Brazilian agriculture
is rooted in policies pursued by the United States to encourage meat production
overseas, partly to stimulate American soybean exports. Soybeans, which are high
in protein, are often used to feed chickens and pigs.

American researchers helped Brazil in the 1970's to improve soils in the
cerrado, helping transform what was once considered an inhospitable wasteland
into what are now seemingly endless plains of farms.

That assistance, said Richard A. Levins, professor of applied economics at the
University of Minnesota, has boomeranged, in a "jolt to our king-of-the-hill
mentality."

URL: http://www.nytimes.com

LOAD-DATE: December 1, 2002

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

CORRECTION-DATE: December 8, 2002



CORRECTION: A picture last Sunday with an article about American farmers who are
buying farmland in Brazil, primarily to grow soybeans, was published in error.
It showed corn, which is also being grown increasingly there.

GRAPHIC: Photos: A sign in Bahia state points to Fazenda Texas, an
American-owned farm. Dan Carroll, left, an Illinois farmer who recently bought
land in Brazil, showed his crop to Philip F. Warnken, the president of
AgBrazil.; Thomas Shanks, from upstate New York, checks young soybean plants on
his 9,855-acre farm in the western part of Bahia state in Brazil. "The guys who

                          Greybull Standard (Wyoming)

  This content, including derivations, may not be stored or distributed in any

                      express, written consent from STPNS

                                  May 8, 2014

Wyoming one of six states with growing farm numbers

BYLINE: Greybull Standard staff

LENGTH: 305  words


The U.S. Department of Agriculture's National Agricultural Statistics

Service (NASS) on Friday released the final 2012 Census of Agriculture results
sharing a wide-range of information about what agricultural products were raised
in the United States in 2012, and where, how and by whom they were grown. The
data, which is reported at the national, state and county level, will help
farmers, ranchers, local officials, agribusiness and others make decisions for
the future.

"The 2012 Census of Agriculture provides a wide range of demographic, economic,
land, and crop and livestock production information as well as first time or
expanded data," said Rhonda Brandt, Wyoming State Statistician. "Many of these
data about Wyoming and our counties are only collected and reported as part of
the every-five-year census."

The 2012 Census of Agriculture data show the following key trends for Wyoming.

Wyoming was one of only six states in the entire United States to increase in
both number of farms, 11,736 farms, and land in farms, 30.4 million acres
between 2007 to 2012.

The largest increases in the number of farms occurred in Laramie, Campbell, and
Sheridan Counties.

At 52%, cattle ranches were the largest type of farm in Wyoming, but there were
also 51 farms that grew potatoes, 43 fruit orchards, and 15 berry farms in 2012.

In 2012, 768 Wyoming farms had renewable energy systems producing energy on
their farms, of which solar panels and wind turbines were the most prevalent.

Fremont County had the largest number of farms selling their goods directly to
consumers for human consumption, with 101 farms selling $596,000 worth of crop
and livestock products in 2012.

Albany, Campbell, Carbon, Johnson and Teton Counties had 80 percent or more of
farms with Internet access, with DSL and satellite being the most prevalent
services.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                               The New York Times

               June 10, 1987, Wednesday, Late City Final Edition

Winter Wheat Crop Up

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section D; Page 10, Column 6; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 112 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 9


The Agriculture Department said today that 1987 winter wheat production was
estimated at 1.58 billion bushels, up 4 percent from last year's harvest of 1.52
billion bushels, and 2 percent more than forecast a month ago. The average
yield, based on indications as of June 1, was estimated at 40.6 bushels per
acre, compared with last year's 35.2 bushels per harvested acre, and 39.9
bushels indicated in May. Farmers are expected to harvest about 38.9 million
acres this year, down 10 percent from 43.2 million acres in 1986. Winter wheat
is planted in the fall and harvested the following summer. It makes up about
three-fourths of the total American wheat production.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                             752 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                                The Toronto Star

                      April 4, 1988, Monday, FINAL EDITION

Mid-East holy war financial God-send to U.S. agriculture

BYLINE: By Juan Miguel Pedraza Agweek Magazine

SECTION: BUSINESS TODAY; Pg. D4

LENGTH: 484 words


   War is good business for agriculture.

Take the Gulf War. Iraq, a California-sized country of 16 million people, has
been at war with neighboring Iran for eight years.

The religious conflict has so far cost the two Islamic countries more than $200
billion (U.S.) in weaponry, fuel and manpower. But the two are spending
increasing sums on imported food.

Iran has banned U.S. food imports since 1982, but they're getting what they need
from Canada, Australia and Argentina.

Meanwhile, Iraq has become one of the hottest new markets for U.S.-grown
commodities. So hot that soon it may be spending $1 billion (U.S.) or more
annually on imports of U.S. food.

That's at least 3 per cent of all U.S. farm exports, going to just one country
with a tiny fraction of 1 per cent of the world's population.

When Iran's Ayatollah Khomeini and Iraqi strongman Sadam Hussein began trading
blows in 1981, Iraq was flush with oil money. By 1985, the war had drained its
cash reserves from $35 billion (U.S.) to about $2 billion, while its foreign
debt had swelled to $50 billion (U.S.).

"The war is an expensive, foolish venture and it was long ago time to cut it
out," said John Parker, a U.S. department of agriculture Middle East expert.
"But you've got two non-economic people - the Ayatollah, a religion man, in
Iran, and Sadam Hussein, a military professional in Iraq - running the show."

The U.S. department of agriculture handed several billion dollars in short- and
medium-term credits to Iraq. The U.S. further sweetened Iraq's taste for
American commodities by offering it stuff extra cheap through the Export
Enhancement Program (EEP).

Iraq's war-fueled food demand has been a sweet deal for just about every sector
of U.S. farming. For example:

* Rice growers are happy because Iraq now imports about 25 million bushels
annually, or 20 per cent of all American rice exports. That's worth about $125
million (U.S.).

* The USDA has sold Iraq some 6,000 head of dairy cattle, purchased at full
price from U.S. farmers.

* As for wheat, from less than $20 million in sales in 1982, annual U.S. wheat
and wheat flour exports - including a lot of EEP deals - to Iraq are now running
at more than a million metric tons, worth $150 million (U.S.).

It looks as if everybody - from missile-makers to wheat farmers - gets a slice
of Iraq's war-fueled action.

Without a steady supply of U.S.-subsidized food, Iraqi public support for the
war - already weakened by years of endless battles - might soon wither. Iran's
populace might soon shun the war if America's competitors weren't supplying them
with bread.

But Sadam Hussein, abetted by USDA's generous subsidies and easy credit, keeps
his countrymen's stomachs full. The Ayatollah seems to get what he wants, too,
despite his general hatred of Western culture, philosophy and economics.

LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1999

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: photo Sadam Hussein

                  Copyright 1988 Toronto Star Newspapers, Ltd.

                                  Farming Life

                              July 31, 2016 Sunday

Lamb exports to America closer

LENGTH: 290  words


The mission to get British lamb chops back onto American dinner plates has moved
a step nearer, Farming Minister George Eustice announced at the National Sheep
Event on Wednesday, 27 July 2016.

Speaking at the opening of the flagship National Sheep Association (NSA) show in
Malvern, Worcestershire, the Minister of State confirmed the US Department of
Agriculture (USDA) has published proposals for consultation to relax import
restrictions on lamb that could generate an extra £35million for the UK economy.
This significant step forward means that British lamb is on track to be
available for US consumers by early 2017.

The move is the latest in ongoing efforts to allow Britain's farmers to start
exporting sheep meat to the United States' 300 million consumers.

A 1,000-page dossier was submitted to the USDA detailing the safety and quality
of British beef and lamb ahead of April's trade talks with US Secretary of
Agriculture Tom Vilsack in Washington.

Speaking at the NSA Sheep Event, Farming Minister George Eustice said: "The US
decision to press ahead with proposals to lift export restrictions on British
lamb is great news for our farmers who are one step closer to gaining access to
the lucrative American market, worth an estimated £35 million a year.

"Our world-leading food and drink industry is a key part of our nation's
economic success and in addition to forging good trade deals with our European
neighbours, we want to secure more export opportunities in the States as well as
with our close friends in the Commonwealth and other countries around the
world."

Defra is now co-ordinating UK farming industry comment for the 60-day
consultation and liaising with relevant US trade associations to gain support
for proposals.

                          Business Day (South Africa)

                                February 6, 1999

FARMERS TO PLOUGH THROUGH INTERNET

BYLINE: Louise Cook

SECTION: National; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 340 words


FARMING organisations backed by information technology companies like IBM are in
a drive to get all the countrys 50000 farmers onto the internet and fitted out
with proper electronic technology by next year.

National Maize Producers Organisation GM Giel van Zyl said about 80% of maize
farmers had to replace their computers as the equipment was not suitable .

At present only about half of SAs commercial farmers had computers, some of
which needed replacement, Van Zyl said.

SA Agricultural Union president Chris du Toit warned that farmers without the
right information technology would drop out of farming in the next century.

The farming unions have been forced to follow a top-down approach to make their
members aware of the importance of this aspect.

IBM manager Jaco van Vuuren said the farming sector was taking longer than other
small businesses to get fitted out.

IBM was working in co-operation with other USbased companies to get farmers and
farm-related business like co-operatives geared up for information handling in
the next century.

It is vital that farmers are able to communicate with their co-operatives daily.
Market and price information have become key to a farms profitability.

Van Zyl said this year there was a marked increase in the number of IT companies
exhibiting at the maize producers agricultural show in Bothaville last month.

Van Zyl said a special information technology show to inform farmers and
agri-businesses of the latest products, was under consideration.

IBM said farmers would rely increasingly on electronic technology for financial
management, market information and buying and selling stock.

A company spokesman said that, like in the US, the local farm sector needed an
internet network to act a as a platform for the procurement and purchasing .

Such a system would fast-forward the sector from the farmer down the
value-adding production chain.

Provincial agricultural unions were also setting up websites to communicate with
members.

LOAD-DATE: July 6, 1999

LANGUAGE: English

                             755 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                           August 28, 1991, Wednesday

NATION IN BRIEF; Smith case judge's refusal to step down to be appealed

SECTION: NATIONAL NEWS; SECTION A; PAGE 04

LENGTH: 697 words


Prosecutors said today they will appeal a judge's refusal to remove herself from
William Kennedy Smith's rape case. The office of State Attorney David Bludworth
issued a one-sentence statement after Palm Beach (Fla.) Circuit Judge Mary Lupo
denied the prosecution motion Tuesday in a one-sentence order.

The appeal to the 4th District Court of Appeals is expected to be filed later
this week. Prosecutors had charged that Judge Lupo had shown bias in her rulings
and her facial expressions and had conflicts in the case because her family is
friends with the family of another prosecutor in the case.

Mr. Smith's attorneys had argued that the request had no legal basis and was an
attempt at "judge-shopping." Mr. Smith, 30, goes on trial Jan. 13 on charges he
raped a 30-year-old Jupiter, Fla., woman March 30 at the Kennedy family's Palm
Beach estate.

OHIO TO GET DISASTER AID DUE TO DROUGHT: This summer's drought in Ohio has led
the U.S. Department of Agriculture to declare 81 of the state's 88 counties
federal disaster areas. Agricultural economists have predicted the drought could
cost the state's corn and soybean farmers alone as much as $ 220 million, a
figure that does not include losses for livestock producers and vegetable
growers. The disaster designation by Agriculture Secretary Edward Madigan means
eligible farmers may apply for low-interest federal loans. The declaration
actually will apply to all 88 counties because of a rule that allows farmers in
counties contiguous to natural disaster areas to also seek assistance.

JAILING OF FORMER IRA MEMBER UPHELD: A former Irish Republican Army member
remains in jail today after a federal appeals court refused to free the man who
has been locked up in this country for eight years while he fights deportation
to England. A panel of the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled 2-1 Tuesday
that Joseph Doherty's rights were not violated by the lengthy detention.
Doherty, 36, was convicted of killing a British army officer in Northern Ireland
in 1980. He escaped from prison the following year and was arrested in New York
in 1983. He has asked to be released on bail while he seeks political asylum in
the United States. Judges Roger J. Miner and George C. Pratt said Doherty's
eight-year detention is a "proper exercise of discretion" by the U.S. attorney
general.

PAMELA SMART APPEAL REJECTED: A judge Tuesday denied three of four motions in
high school instructor Pamela Smart's attempt to get a new trial on charges she
coaxed her teenage lover and his friends into killing her husband. Rockingham
County, N.H., Superior Court Judge Douglas Gray did not rule on a fourth motion,
which claims intense media coverage of her trial tainted the jury that convicted
her. A ruling on the fourth motion is pending. Smart, 24, was convicted in March
of coaxing William Flynn and two of his friends into killing her husband.

DRUGS FOUND IN DEAD REPORTER'S BODY: A reporter who said he was investigating a
possible government plot had traces of a painkiller and an anti-depressant in
his blood when he died with his wrists slashed, West Virginia authorities said
Tuesday. Dr. James Frost, an assistant state medical examiner, said his
examination of the body of Joseph D. Casolaro, 44, of Fairfax, Va., revealed
nothing to change his mind from his earlier finding that Mr. Casolaro's death
was consistent with suicide. Mr. Casolaro's body was found Aug. 10 in a bathtub
in a hotel in Martinsburg with both wrists slashed several times.

GOVERNOR A CANTALOUPE SUPPORTER: Colorado Gov. Roy Romer nibbled a cantaloupe
Tuesday in a T-shirt emblazoned with a slice of the fruit to help calm a
salmonella scare that has devastated the market. Cantaloupe growers in
California, Texas and elsewhere have watched sales plummet since the Centers for
Disease Control in Atlanta said Aug. 15 that more than 400 people in 23 states
and Canada became ill this summer, apparently from eating cantaloupes. "I grew
up eating Rocky Ford cantaloupe," Mr. Romer said as he ate part of a melon from
that growing region in southeast Colorado.

Compiled from wire reports

LOAD-DATE: February 10, 1992

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

Low-level radioactive water was spilled Tuesday when a reactor coolant pump in a
container too tall for an underpass was knocked from a truck onto Interstate 64.

                      Business and Financial Times (Ghana)

                              May 29, 2016 Sunday

AYNAT encourages youth to venture into agric

LENGTH: 539  words


Source: Ekow Essabra-Mensah | B&FT Online | Ghana

The African Youth Network for Agricultural Transformation (AYNAT) has held a
youth policy dialogue aimed at encouraging the youth to see agriculture as a
life-long occupation.

The forum brought together more than 70 participants to empower them to go into
agribusiness, and was on the theme 'Implementing Ghana's Youth Policy on
Agriculture, defining a Pragmatic Approach'. It was organised with financial
support from the Africa Lead of the United States Agency for International
Development (USAID).

AYNAT is a network made up of young people trained by Africa Lead II at its
champions for change leadership in agriculture workshop. It is devoted to
ensuring that a proportion of the African population arms itself with skills and
knowledge to make significant contributions and champion the transformation of
Ghanaian and African agriculture, through capacity building, policy advocacy and
research.

Dr. Ahmed Yakubu Alhassan, a Deputy Minister of Food and Agriculture, speaking
at the event explained that agriculture is the most important instrument for
government and has the greatest potential for solving youth unemployment.

He said it was in this direction that government initiated and institutionalised
the Youth in Agriculture Programme (YAP) to help create more jobs for the youth.

"Government will continue to urge the youth to take up Agriculture at a high
entrepreneurial level to improve their income."

Dr. Alhassan said between 2009 and 2012, YAP provided support for about 250,000
youth in Block Farming, Aquaculture and other forms of skills, with emphasis on
maize, rice and vegetable farming.

He indicated that under YAP, up to 500 youth have been engaged in fish-farming
in the Volta River within the Volta and Eastern Regions.

He said the Programme had a challenge with recouping project funds from
beneficiary farmers, which had rendered the programme dormant in subsequent
years -- though training and other support are still being offered to young
farmers.

He said the challenges are clear indications that the public purse alone cannot
create jobs for all Ghanaians; adding that positioning Agriculture well will
create more jobs for the youth.

He said government will have to partner with the private sector to create more
job opportunities for youth in agriculture; adding that existing viable
incubator farms are being identified by government, so that they will serve as
training centres for youth in agriculture, he said.

Mr. Edem F. Azagloe, the President of AYNAT, said his organisation was devoted
to making sure that a proportion of Africa's youth population armed itself with
skills and knowledge to make significant contributions and champion the
transformation of Ghanaian and African agriculture through capacity building,
policy advocacy and research.

He said AYNAT's objective is to build and strengthen the capacities of youth in
agriculture to scale-up food security.  He lauded Africa Lead and USAID for
their continued support for AYNAT.

He urged government to continue putting in place policies and programmes that
empower the youth to go into agriculture.

                              Daily The Pak Banker

                             May 15, 2014 Thursday

U.S supports farmers grow off-season vegetables

LENGTH: 324  words

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD


The United States, through its Agency for International Development (USAID),
showcased the results of Pakistani farmers using new technology to grow high
value off-season vegetables here at its Vegetable Fair 2014. Acting Mission
Director for USAID Pakistan Nancy Estes underscored the U.S. government's
commitment to develop Pakistan's agricultural sector: "The produce we see here
today marks the introduction of greenhouse technology in Pakistan on a large
scale. USAID's goal is to help farmers establish 1,200 high tunnels and to adopt
modern farming practices.

These initiatives will significantly transform vegetable farming, increase
yields, create more jobs, and help farmers earn higher incomes," said U.S
embassy statement here. A large number of participants involved in the industry
showcased Pakistani grown fruits and vegetables as well as related products and
services at the fair. Vegetable Fair-2014 also connected farmers with packing
specialists, marketing experts and exporters, helping them integrate into the
global economy. USAID's Agribusiness Project, which organized the fair, works to
improve produce quality and value, increase agriculture productivity, and remove
constraints to agricultural production and marketing. Through the project, USAID
also provides quality high yield seed, toolkits, low and high greenhouse
tunnels, and technical assistance to Pakistani farmers. The tunnels enable
farmers to produce off-season vegetables, greatly increasing land productivity
and profitability. The United States, though USAID, boosts Pakistan's
agricultural productivity by introducing advanced farming technologies,
services, and practices; building irrigation infrastructure; and introducing
improved water management practices. Over the last 18 months, U.S assistance has
helped create 9,000 new jobs in Pakistan's agricultural sector and generate more
than $60 million in new Pakistani agriculture export orders.

                             758 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                 The State Journal- Register (Springfield, IL)

                           November 2, 2011 Wednesday

150th anniversary of USDA to kick off in Springfield Wednesday

BYLINE: Tim Landis

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 648 words


Abraham Lincoln's ties to Springfield brought the city a presidential museum in
2005, a yearlong bicentennial celebration in 2009 and the ongoing celebration of
his role in the Civil War this year.

Now comes 2012 and the 150th anniversary of Lincoln's creation of the U.S.
Department of Agriculture.

Secretary of Agriculture Tom Vilsack will kick off the national commemoration at
the Old State Capitol today by unveiling a website - www.usda.gov/usda150 -
outlining the agency's history and Lincoln's role in its creation in 1862. The
website goes live during the 10 a.m. event.

The ceremony in the Old Capitol Hall of Representatives is the first of what is
planned as a yearlong celebration around the country in 2012.

"You have to remember this took place during the Civil War," Vilsack said in a
phone interview on Tuesday.

Lincoln "understood and appreciated that one of the advantages to uniting the
states was the capacity of the country to have extraordinary agricultural
production," said Vilsack. "It also was a way of preparing for the end of the
Civil War. He knew we would have the southern states coming back in, and those
were primarily agricultural."

Lincoln not a fan of farming

The Abraham Lincoln Presidential Library and Museum will put an exhibit of
Lincoln agricultural artifacts on display for today's events at the Old Capitol,
said spokesman Dave Blanchette.

Included are an 1860 letter from Lincoln to his cousin John Hanks about breaking
the central Illinois prairie with an ox team in 1830, the original printing of
an 1859 speech on the importance of agriculture and research, and the first USDA
report, issued in 1862 by the first secretary, Isaac Newton.

Lincoln's name is embossed on the report. The collection was on display at the
presidential museum for a year ending in the summer of 2010, but will be brought
out again only for today's 150th anniversary kickoff.

"We display these for a while and then give them a rest from the elements," said
Blanchette. "This is a special occasion."

While Lincoln's self-taught rural background is part of his lore, Blanchette
said history shows the 16th president wasn't particularly fond of the manual
labor that characterized 19th century farming.

"He was a champion of modernizing farming," said Blanchette. "He never did like
farming and felt farming should be made as easy and productive as possible. It
was part of the reason behind the creation of USDA."

Free mail

According to an agency history, the USDA was part of the Department of the
Interior when Lincoln signed legislation creating the department on May 15,
1862.

The commissioner of agriculture was granted an annual salary of $3,000 and was
allowed to hire a chief clerk at $2,000 a year.

Commissioner duties included an annual report to Congress on agriculture,
collection of data on farming techniques, overseeing agricultural research and
administration of agricultural programs to benefit farming.

There was one other perk: "And said commissioner may send and receive through
the mails, free of charge, all communications and other matter pertaining to the
business of his department not exceeding in weight thirty-two ounces."

Vilsack said dozens of events will be held nationwide as part of the 2012
commemoration, but he considers it appropriate to start in Lincoln's hometown.

"When you think about it, the country then (in Lincoln's time) was heavily
agricultural. People principally lived in rural areas," said Vilsack. "Now, less
than 1 percent of the population produces the food and fiber and fuel for this
country."

Tim Landis can be reached at 788-1536.

Want to go?

What: United States Secretary of Agricultural Tom Vilsack will unveil a website
and plans for a yearlong commemoration in 2012 of Abraham Lincoln's creation of
the agency.

When: 10 a.m. today.

Where: Old State Capitol. A collection of Lincoln agricultural artifacts also
will be on display.

LOAD-DATE: November 3, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                   Copyright 2011 The State Journal- Register
                              All Rights Reserved

                             Ukrainian News Agency

                         December 10, 2015 6:30 AM EST

U.S. Department Of Agriculture Retains Forecast Of Grain Harvest In Ukraine At
59.8 Million Tons In 2015

LENGTH: 100  words


The United States Department of Agriculture has retained the forecast of
Ukraine's cereals harvest in 2015 at 59.825 million tons, reads December issue
of USDA's World Agricultural Supply and Demand Estimates, Ukrainian News Agency
reports.

The USDA retained the forecast of wheat harvest in Ukraine at 27 million tons,
and the forecast of feed grain production at 32.825 million tons.

As Ukrainian News earlier reported, in November, the United States Department of
Agriculture has revised the forecast of Ukraine's cereals harvest in 2015
downwards by 3.2% or 1.95 million tons to 59.825 million tons.

                             Ukrainian News Agency

                         November 10, 2015 6:30 AM EST

U.S. Department Of Agriculture Revises Forecast Of Grain Harvest In Ukraine
Downwards By 3.2% To 59.8 Million Tons In 2015

LENGTH: 100  words


The United States Department of Agriculture has revised the forecast of
Ukraine's cereals harvest in 2015 downwards by 3.2% or 1.95 million tons to
59.825 million tons, reads November issue of USDA's World Agricultural Supply
and Demand Estimates.

The USDA retained the forecast of wheat harvest in Ukraine at 27 million tons,
and downgraded the forecast of feed grain production by 5.6% or 1.95 million to
32.825 million tons.

As Ukrainian News earlier reported, in October the United States Department of
Agriculture revised Ukraine's harvest of grain crops in 2015 downwards by 2.4%
to 61.8 million tons.

                             761 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                     The Leader-Post (Regina, Saskatchewan)

                            January 16, 2006 Monday
                                 Final Edition

Parties take farming seriously

BYLINE: Angela Hall, Leader-Post

SECTION: BUSINESS & AGRICULTURE; Pg. B5

LENGTH: 1095  words


Weak prices for crops, poor quality grain, devastating frosts and flooding --
Saskatchewan farmers have had a tough row to hoe since the last federal election
just 18 months ago.

The United States resumed imports of young cattle from Canada last summer,
improving the outlook for livestock producers after a more than two-year border
closure blamed on the discovery of mad cow disease. But most grain and oilseed
farmers continued to struggle as costs rose dramatically and returns for some
crops dwindled to levels not seen in years.

"In rural Saskatchewan ... my gosh, it's tough out there," said Neal Hardy,
president of the Saskatchewan Association of Rural Municipalities. "There's no
cash flow left. They've used up all the reserves."

Farm issues are getting attention in this federal election campaign, and Hardy
says it's about time. Party leaders even spoke about agriculture issues in their
final English language debate, a pleasant surprise to some lobby groups.

"I think that speaks first of all to how hard farmers have worked to give
agriculture a higher profile," said Bob Friesen, a Manitoba farmer and president
of the Canadian Federation of Agriculture.

"I'm hoping this means there is stronger recognition of the importance of
agriculture, and also stronger recognition that the crisis agriculture is
currently in is due to factors that farmers have no control over."

The Conservatives say if elected to government they would continue with the
Liberals' $755 million in emergency assistance for grains and oilseed farmers
announced in November, of which about $290 million is expected to come to
Saskatchewan.

The three major parties have all acknowledged problems with farmers' main safety
net program, known as the Canadian Agricultural Income Stabilization program, or
CAIS.

The Liberals conceded CAIS is not working, and say the program will be reviewed.

"We're prepared to put more money in but we want it to flow much more quickly,"
said Prime Minister Paul Martin during the Jan. 9 debate.

Gary Anderson, a Bethune-area producer running for the Liberals in
Regina-Lumsden-Lake Centre, said Liberals understand there is a crisis both
"economically and socially" in agriculture.

"We certainly do recognize that we do have to have funding over and above the
safety nets. Our record to date is about $1.5 billion in the last two years
each, over and above the safety net, which far outreaches what the Conservative
party has promised to date."

The Conservatives pledge to scrap CAIS outright, and replace it with separate
farm income stabilization and disaster relief programs, along with an additional
$500 million in annual funding. They say the new income program will be simpler
and more responsive.

"We've been aware of the problems (with CAIS) but it doesn't seem that they've
been fixed," said Cypress Hills-Grasslands Conservative MP David Anderson. "The
majority of farmers are still telling me it's just not fitting their farm
situation."

The NDP platform includes an overhaul of CAIS, and an end to the
"one-size-fits-all" approach.

"We need real income stabilization now," said NDP Leader Jack Layton. "We're
proposing a billion dollars for the grains and oilseeds sector and it's got to
happen now because they (farmers) don't know if they can put anything into the
ground."

No matter which party forms government, farmers must have a say in what happens
with farm-support programs, said Ken McBride, president of the Agricultural
Producers Association of Saskatchewan.

"We should be the major planners, have direct access to ensuring the next
program is a little more satisfactory than the one we're operating under right
now."

The parties' platforms reveal a significant divide on the Canadian Wheat Board,
the agency responsible for marketing all wheat and barley grown by western
farmers. The board's monopoly, or "single-desk" selling, has long been a
divisive issue among farmers, with some advocating they should be able to market
their wheat outside the board.

The Conservatives are the only party to say it would make the Canadian Wheat
Board (CWB) voluntary.

Ken Ritter, the Saskatchewan farmer who is chairman of the CWB's board of
directors, is adamant that the "voluntary" scenario could not occur. "You either
have a single-desk marketing system or you have an open-market system," said
Ritter.

The Conservatives' Anderson disagrees.

"We just think that it's important to give Western Canadian farmers the same
opportunities that other farmers have," he said.

Farm groups that staunchly support the board say the loss of its monopoly would
be like the loss of the Crow rate, which used to subsidize the cost of getting
Prairie grain to port.

"It's $300 million a year out of western Canadian farmers' pockets if they're
able to do that, and it would be the second-biggest blow that western Canadian
farmers have taken over the last 10 years," said Stewart Wells, president of the
National Farmers Union.

The greatest similarity among the three major parties' agricultural platforms
may be the support of developing ethanol and biodiesel, which uses crops such as
wheat and canola.

The Liberal and Conservative platforms include plans to mandate a five-per-cent
renewable fuels content in gasoline and diesel by 2010.

Regina-Qu'Appelle NDP candidate Lorne Nystrom said New Democrats are suggesting
there be a mandated 10 per cent blend by 2010.

Lionel LaBaelle, president of the Saskatchewan Ethanol Development Council,
called the announcements "tremendous" news, but added the benefit to farmers
depend on how plans are rolled out.

In the U.S., many ethanol plants have farmer/community ownership.

"We're very hopeful that -- when whatever party is in power -- when they roll
out their strategy that they will acknowledge the preferential bias for those
types of ownership models because we think they're really important to the rural
economy and rural renewal."

Other key pledges from the three parties include:

n Conservatives promise to seek better access for Canadian agricultural products
in foreign markets, and to create a green-cover program to help protect Prairie
farmers and compensate them in the event of severe flooding.

n A Liberal commitment to review farm policy drawing on the well-received report
by Liberal MP Wayne Easter called Empowering Farmers in the Marketplace, and to
raise the lifetime capital gains exemption to $750,000 from $500,000 for farmers
and fishers.

n New Democrats will work to ensure farmers have the right to save and reuse
seed and work to develop producer-run co-operatives to ensure fairer price
competition.

LOAD-DATE: January 16, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

since the last federal election just 18 months ago.

                               The New York Times

                           January 11, 2001 Thursday
                              Late Edition - Final

Two Named to New German Agency in Shuffle Over Beef Disease

BYLINE:  By ROGER COHEN

SECTION: Section A; Column 1; Foreign Desk; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 564 words

DATELINE: BERLIN, Jan. 10


Chancellor Gerhard Schroder created a new super-ministry for food, agriculture
and consumer protection today and handed it to the environmentalist Greens,
signaling a back-to-nature approach to combating mad cow disease that is certain
to alarm the powerful European farm lobby.

By naming Renate Kunast, 45, a Berlin lawyer with no experience in farming to
head a ministry with such sweeping powers, Mr. Schroder has gambled that any
loss of support among farmers will be more than compensated by support from
ecologically conscious Germans alarmed by the discovery of mad cow disease.

"It is high time that we changed the course of agriculture," Mr. Schroder said
at a hastily called news conference. "We want food safety through appropriate
methods that are good for the environment."

Despite Mr. Schroder's bold declarations, the fact is his government is in some
disarray after the resignation on Tuesday of his health and agriculture
ministers, who took the blame for the government's chaotic response to the
discovery in Germany of 10 cases of bovine spongiform encephalopathy -- commonly
known as mad cow disease.

The reality is also that west European farming is overwhelmingly dominated by
large-scale, industrialized farming, heavily subsidized by the European Union,
and any attempt to revert to smaller, more humane and organic forms of
agriculture would amount to an expensive revolution that most farmers would
resist.

Mr. Schroder appeared to recognize the difficulties by warning that a wholesale
move to biologically friendly farming could not provide "enough healthy food at
affordable prices," but Ms. Kunast, the co-leader of the Greens, said she was
determined to steer agriculture "back to nature."

The outbreak of mad cow disease has heightened already strong concerns among
European consumers about how "natural" or "organic" their food is. This mood has
set the continent on a collision course with the United States over genetically
modified corn and other foodstuffs, a conflict likely to intensify.

"Europeans do not want genetically modified food -- period," said Foreign
Minister Joschka Fischer, of the Greens. "It does not matter what research
shows, they just do not want it and that has to be respected."

No cases of a deadly nervous condition in humans -- new variant
Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease -- that has been linked to mad cow disease have been
discovered so far in Germany. That has not prevented near-hysteria among
consumers. Beef sales have plunged, as elsewhere in Europe, and prices for
poultry and fish have risen.

Mr. Schroder also named Ulla Schmidt, a teacher and deputy leader of the Social
Democratic parliamentary group, to become the new health minister. Ms. Schmidt,
51, gained respect in parliament last year for her strong defense of the
government's proposed pension reforms.

The disease among cattle is believed to result from the use of animal products
in feed. Germany long held that its cattle were not susceptible because such
forms of feed were not used. The recently discovered cases are blamed on tainted
grain.

It is unclear how quickly Mr. Schroder's government can recover from the damage
done by its slow response to the disease and by the departure of four ministers
in the past three months. What seems certain is that the next few months will be
volatile after the generally smooth sailing the chancellor enjoyed last year.

URL: http://www.nytimes.com

LOAD-DATE: January 11, 2001

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

agriculture minister and Ulla Schmidt, of the Social Democrats, health minister.
(Associated Press); (Agence France-Presse)

                          Kenly News (North Carolina)

  This content, including derivations, may not be stored or distributed in any
  manner, disseminated, published, broadcast, rewritten or reproduced without
                      express, written consent from STPNS

                                August 13, 2014

Agriculture has a huge impact on our local economy;
For What Its Worth

BYLINE: Kenly News staff

LENGTH: 526  words


Welcome to our annual salute to farming and agricultural edition of the News.

Why do we publish such a salute each year? Because farming and agriculture are
still the leading industries in our communities.

We think we should take stock of what our farming and agricultural economics
are. And, it's something for which everyone should be proud.

We enjoy this time of year as we ride throughout country-side to see the
tobacco, cotton, soy beans and corn growing.

But there's more happening that just this We have a feature in today's paper
about our local grocery stores buying fresh produce from local growers. It can't
get any fresher than that And then there's the agricultural economy that many
may overlook. We have vast amounts of timber growing in our county. We have one
of the strongest nursery programs around with large and small operators
throughout our area.

Many of us also may take beef, pork and poultry production for granted, but if
you'll look around that also is a large part of our economy.

According to Agricultural Extension Service, nearly 20 percent of the jobs in
North Carolina are agriculturally related. We believe it's much higher in our
local area, when we see acres and acres of crops.

While it's true that farmers are becoming more mechanized and larger, we also
have to realize that as the population grows and the number of farmers decrease
it takes more production to keep pace with those who consume their products.

There's the old saying that we should never complain about food with our mouth
full. And that's true.

We here in the county, the state and our nation are blessed to have an abundance
of food and other agricultural products that the rest of the world envies.

We mentioned briefly last week about one of the articles on this week's front
page about banana peppers being harvested locally and sold to Mount Olive Pickle
Company.

It's interesting to follow the operation from the field to the grocery store.

Another article we have in the paper this week is the well-known Wellons family
of Johnston County who are harvesting their tobacco by hand because they believe
it's better to do it that way.

Also in the paper today we have a great story on a local slaughter house where
beef is being processed.

And, we could have had many other articles about the fabulous agricultural
practices that are going on just down the road from where all of us live.

So, it is-with great pleasure that we present our salute to farming and
agriculture in this week's edition.

Please note the many advertisers in this issue who have a direct interest in
agriculture.

Many of them have stepped forward to thank and salute area farming interests
with us. In fact, we wouldn't be able to present such a salute without the
partnership with these companies who greatly appreciate what the farming
community does for all of us.

We appreciate those companies as well as those who are part of the great
economic impact that agriculture has in our area.

Rick Stewart is editor and publisher of Kenly News and Pine Level News and
president of Johnstonian News, Inc., publisher of The Selma News. Reach him at
919-284-2295 or at rstew-art@kenlynewsx com.

                             764 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                          The Hutchinson News (Kansas)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            November 2, 2014 Sunday

Foreign landowners must report farming transactions

BYLINE: The Hutchinson News, Kan.

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 298 words


Nov. 02--Aaron Fall, county executive director of the Reno County Farm Service
Agency, reminds foreign investors who buy, sell or hold a direct or indirect
interest in agricultural lands in the United States that they are required under
the Agricultural Foreign Investment Disclosure Act to report their holdings and
transactions to the U.S. Secretary of Agriculture.

The Secretary of Agriculture has delegated the responsibility for collecting
this information to the Farm Service Agency.

According to Fall, foreigner investors buying or selling land must report such
transactions within 90 days of the date of the sale.

Failure to file an accurate or timely report can result in a penalty with fines
up to 25 percent of the fair market value of the agricultural land.

Fall said the act requires reports to be filed by:

--Individuals who are not U.S. citizens or citizens of the Northern Mariana
Islands or the Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands;

--Individuals who are not lawfully admitted to the United States for permanent
residence or who are not paroled into the United States under the Immigration
and Nationality Act;

--Any organization created under the laws of a foreign government or which has
located its principal place of business outside the United States;

--Any U.S. organization in which a significant interest of substantial control
is directly or indirectly held by foreign individuals, organizations, or
governments, and;

--Any foreign governments.

Farm Service Agency form FSA-153 is used to report land holdings and
transactions. The completed form must be returned to the FSA county office where
the land is located.

(Hutchinson, Kan.) at www.hutchnews.com Distributed by MCT Information Services

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

            February 17, 1990, SATURDAY, ILLINOIS FIVE STAR Edition

ILLINOIS FARMER TO HEAD U.S. PANEL

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 6A

LENGTH: 227 words


WASHINGTON: An Illinois farmer and livestock industry leader was named Friday as
head of the Packers and Stockyards Administration.  Agriculture Secretary
Clayton Yeutter said he had chosen Virgil M.  Rosendale, of Augusta, Ill., to
head the administration. The Agriculture Department agency handles fair-trade
regulatory programs designed to protect consumers and members of the livestock
and poultry industries from unfair, deceptive or monopolistic business
practices.  Rosendale has managed a 2,000-acre grain and livestock farm. He is
past president of the National Pork Producers Council, former chairman of the
National Livestock Meat Board and was the first president of the National Pork
Board in 1986-89.  Yeutter said that Rosendale, whose salary will be $81,400 a
year, ''brings to the job 30 years' experience running a successful livestock
operation, and a wealth of leadership experience within the livestock
industry.''
