                             766 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                      The News-Herald of Willoughby, Ohio

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             May 25, 2011 Wednesday

Wet weather continues to wash away farming activity

BYLINE: Jeffrey L. Frischkorn, The News-Herald, Willoughby, Ohio

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 503 words


May 25--With summer coming, the state's farmers are running out of time to start
planting.

The near-continuous string of wet days in May has greatly delayed the planting
of nearly all crops. Only fruit trees appear to be on schedule for blooming and
development.

Statistic compiled weekly by the U.S. Department of Agriculture with cooperation
from the Ohio Department of Agriculture point to just how bad it is.

Fully, 83 percent of farm fields are reportedly experiencing a surplus in
topsoil moisture and only 14 percent are rated "adequate." None are said to be
either "short" or "very short."

Last week less than one day was judged suitable for farming field work, the
report said.

"This is about as bad as I've ever seen, especially in Northeast Ohio, which
seems to be hit the hardest," said Les Ober, agent with the Ohio State
University Extension in Geauga County. "This is a real circus this year, and you
don't see one like it for 20 or 30 years."

The latest weekly crop weather report also indicates that farmers have planted
only 11 percent of the state's corn crop. Last year at this time, the figure was
87 percent with the five-year average being 80 percent.

The corn that farmers have managed to put in largely has yet to emerge -- only 2
percent compared with the 72 percent last year at this time and 58 percent for
the five-year average.

Similarly, the state's soybean planting is way behind schedule -- 4 percent thus
far, compared with the 48 percent last year and the 54 percent for the long-term
average.

The first cutting of alfalfa hay has likewise slowed, as has the planting of
oats and potatoes and the harvesting of strawberries.

Only apples and peaches in full bloom are near their point seen last year and
for their five-year average. Ober also said that this is a pivotal week and will
determine whether farmers have to purchase crop insurance.

"I look for a lot of farmers to file for it, though there will be some who will
still plant corn because they have grain contracts and it would be expensive for
them to get out of it," Ober said.

"And if a farmer has borrowed money from a bank, he has to have crop insurance."

After June 1, yields on corn drops dramatically.

Even so, Ober said don't look for many farmers to switch to planting soybeans
instead of corn.

The reason being is if a farmer files an insurance claim for the loss of corn,
he cannot plant another summer crop like soybeans, Ober said.

"What the ultimate impact will be we just don't know yet and will be determined
by the states where farmers were able to get their corn planted," Ober added.

"I think you're going to see a lot of idle farm land this year, especially in
Northeast Ohio."

To see more of The News-Herald or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.news-herald.com/. Copyright (c) 2011, The News-Herald, Willoughby,
Ohio Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For more information
about the content services offered by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services
(MCT), visit www.mctinfoservices.com.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                             767 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                             May 25, 2002 Saturday
                                National Edition

Farmers want $1.3-billion to match U.S.;
That's the minimum needed to compete;
with new subsidies, Prairie politicians say

BYLINE: KRISTA FOSS

SECTION: NATIONAL NEWS; Pg. A8

LENGTH: 539 words


A $1.3-billion compensation package is the "minimum" needed to cushion Canadian
farmers from the new agricultural subsidies promised to their U.S. competitors,
according to Prairie politicians and farm groups who met with federal cabinet
ministers in Saskatoon yesterday.

Trade Minister Pierre Pettigrew, Agriculture Minister Lyle Vanclief and House
Leader Ralph Goodale talked with the premiers of Manitoba and Saskatchewan,
Alberta's Deputy Premier and various farm groups that have been pushing for the
"trade injury" compensation in response to the recently passed U.S. Farm Bill.

Federal Finance Minister Paul Martin joined the morning meeting by conference
call.

But after the three-hour discussion, the federal ministers could give only vague
hints of how the federal government will help Canadian producers compete with
U.S. farmers slated to receive $190-billion (U.S.) in direct farm income
supports over the next decade on top of existing agricultural programs.

"We are looking at everything," Mr. Vanclief told reporters, adding that the
federal government would consider "building on" the $3.8-billion it currently
spends on agricultural programs.

Saskatchewan Premier Lorne Calvert, whose breadbasket province has been hobbled
by drought conditions and depressed prices for grains and oilseeds, said
yesterday the U.S. subsidies need an immediate response.

He called the $1.3-billion compensation suggested by farm groups the "minimum"
necessary because it was calculated without taking into account the impact of
the U.S. subsidies for growers of peas, beans and lentils, crops that many
Prairie farmers now produce.

The dollar figure comes from an Agriculture Canada report that calculated that
international subsidy programs for grains and oilseeds cost Canadian grain
farmers more than $1-billion last year - before the new U.S. income supports
were introduced.

The new U.S. subsidy package increases overall farm spending south of the border
by 77 per cent by hiking subsidy rates or increasing payments for everybody from
grain growers to dairy farmers and those raising peanuts, cotton and peas.

The United States is also instituting a country-of-origin labelling system for
meat exports, which is tantamount to a Buy America program, and is a serious
threat to Canadian livestock producers who count on U.S. markets.

"We're very concerned about it . . . we already have cases where the U.S.
processors don't want to continue signing long-term contracts with exporters
because of the country-of-origin labelling issue," said Bob Friesen, president
of the Canadian Federation of Agriculture, an umbrella group representing
200,000 farm families.

But rather than cutting a compensation cheque for Canadian farmers yesterday,
the federal cabinet ministers at the meeting were satisfied to "to listen, to
understand and to establish solid foundations," according to Mr. Goodale, the
federal minister responsible for the Canadian Wheat Board.

And Mr. Vanclief reminded the provinces "that agriculture is a shared
jurisdiction," suggesting that provincial governments also will be expected to
ante up money to protect Canadian farms.

The Prairie politicians were clearly looking for something more concrete.

                   The Vancouver Province (British Columbia)

                       April 9, 2001 Monday Final Edition

I say tomato, you say unfair trade practice

SOURCE: Canadian Press

SECTION: News; Pg. A14

LENGTH: 152 words

DATELINE: TORONTO

TORONTO -- Canadian tomato producers are angered by a U.S. call for duties on
Canadian greenhouse tomatoes.

"The trade action by these growers is very unfortunate," said Kevin Doran,
vice-president of BC Hot House Foods Inc., a member of the Canadian Tomato
Alliance.

Canadian growers say U.S. greenhouse-tomato producers have filed a petition with
the U.S. Department of Commerce to impose the duties.

"We always understood under [free trade] that both countries have free access to
the other's markets," Doran said. "These highly politicized trade actions must
stop."

Said Denton Hoffman, general manager of the Ontario Greenhouse Vegetable
Growers: "Canadian growers are not dumping their products into the U.S. market,
nor are they injuring the U.S. greenhouse or field tomato producers."

Hoffman said the issue could have been resolved with the help of the Canadian
and U.S. governments.

                            The Daily Star (Lebanon)

                           September 22, 2008 Monday

World Vision, USAID tout aid for local organic agriculture

BYLINE: Daily Star Staff

LENGTH: 377 words


World Vision and the United States Agency for International Development (USAID)
celebrated on Friday the achievements of a three-year project that helped
hundreds of Lebanon's farmers by growing organic agriculture in Lebanon. "We are
proud for having created, and not just enhanced, the organic agriculture sector
in Lebanon.

BEIRUT: World Vision and the United States Agency for International Development
(USAID) celebrated on Friday the achievements of a three-year project that
helped hundreds of Lebanon's farmers by growing organic agriculture in Lebanon.
"We are proud for having created, and not just enhanced, the organic agriculture
sector in Lebanon, which has positive impact on the environment, the economy and
the health of the consumer," said project manager Nabil Maalouf.

More than 4,500 people benefited directly from the Sustainable Agri-Business
Initiative for Lebanon project, 800 of whom are farmers from Bint Jbeil, East
Sidon, Marjayoun, the Bekaa Valley, North Lebanon and Beirut. The project
focused on developing BioCo-op Lubnan, a national organic agriculture farming
cooperative.

USAID provided $7.8 million funding over three years to identify and develop
specialized organic agriculture practices; provide state-of-the-art processing,
packaging and storage facilities throughout Lebanon; and put in place the
marketing and other services needed to bring Lebanese organic farm products to
market.

Through the SABIL project, Lebanese farmers were able to earn organic
certifications and sell their produce at higher prices than conventional produce
under the local brand name Campagnia. Some organic Lebanese products have also
been exported to Europe and the Gulf.

"The journey of the organic farming sector under the program was not easy, yet
despite the many challenging times, what was achieved in Lebanon by the program
and its partners in the past five years has taken other countries at least a
decade," said USAID official Christine Sayegh.

World Vision and USAID worked with several Lebanese partners to implement the
project, including the Litani River Authority, the Lebanese Agriculture Research
Institute, the Gebran National Committee, and the Holy Spirit University
Kaslik's faculty of agricultural sciences. - The Daily Star

                             National Post (Canada)

                     June 15, 2001 Friday NATIONAL EDITIONS

Bumper harvest bad news for wheat prices

SECTION: FINANCIAL POST INVESTING; Pg. D02, Commodities

LENGTH: 498 words

DATELINE: CHICAGO


CHICAGO - Wheat fell to a three-month low yesterday on signs that farmers in the
United States are making quick work of this year's winter wheat harvest, adding
to grain stockpiles at a time of weak overseas demand.

About 70% of the crop in Oklahoma, the No. 2 winter wheat-growing state, has
been harvested, analysts said. U.S. wheat exports are 17% behind last year's
pace, and buyers with overseas clients are reducing the prices they are offering
farmers, according to the U.S. Department of Agriculture.

'The harvest is in full swing, so there's no sense of urgency to acquire
supplies,' said Tom O'Dell, a grain buyer in Kansas City, Kans., for Cenex
Harvest States Cooperatives, the No. 2 farmer-owned group in the United States.

In other markets, cattle prices fell to a three-week low and crude oil was
little changed. The Bridge-Commodity Research Bureau index rose 0.08 to 211.62,
and the energy-weighted Goldman Sachs commodity index fell 0.05 to 221.39.

Wheat for July delivery fell US2.75 cents, or 1%, to US$2.5925 a bushel on the
Chicago Board of Trade, the lowest closing price since April 2. Wheat has fallen
2.9% this month, and it is little changed from a year ago.

Cattle prices fell to a three-week low on signs of weakening U.S. demand for
beef.

Grocers have stockpiled meat for Father's Day on Sunday and Independence Day on
July 4, when consumers often buy steaks and hamburger meat for outdoor grilling.
With retailers well stocked for the summer, wholesale beef prices have fallen to
their lowest level in seven weeks.

Cattle for August delivery fell US0.45 cents, or 0.6%, to US73.1 cents a pound
on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, their lowest closing price since May 23.
Prices still are about 7% higher than a year ago.

Crude oil was little changed on expectations that supplies lost because of a
halt in exports from Iraq will be made up by other members of the Organization
of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

Crude oil for July delivery rose US20 cents to US$29.04 a barrel on the New York
Mercantile Exchange.

Prices are 12% lower than a year ago and near the middle of the range they've
traded in for the past month.

                             771 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                August 23, 1987, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

Farming Without Chemicals: Age-Old Technologies Becoming State of Art

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1, Page 18, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1410 words

DATELINE: ST. PAUL, Aug. 20


From the ridge overlooking fields his family has tilled for 120 years, Ken
Tschumper surveys the lush crops of alfalfa and corn he raised this summer
without pesticides or chemical fertilizers.

When he stopped using chemicals six years ago on his 230-acre dairy farm,
neighbors ridiculed Mr. Tschumper's inexpensive system of spreading manure and
rotating crops to nourish his soil and repel insects, weeds and diseases.
Earlier this year, though, the 37-year-old farmer from La Crescent, 140 miles
south of here, added $20,000 to his savings account. Some of his critics,
meanwhile, filed for bankruptcy.

''When you don't use chemicals, you become a much better observer -you're
constantly evaluating conditions,'' said Mr. Tschumper. ''It verges on the
artistic.''

Catnip to Ward Off Insects

Farming without chemicals, once considered a fringe movement, impractical and
idealistic, has gained ground, moving closer to the mainstream of American
agriculture.

Major growers in Iowa now plant rye after the corn harvest. During the winter,
when the rye decomposes, natural weed-killing substances result, protecting the
fields in the spring and making the use of chemical herbicides unnecessary. In
California, some farmers plant catnip between rows of vegetables to drive away
destructive insects.

The accelerating pace of the transition has surprised university researchers and
officials at the Department of Agriculture. Until the mid-1980's, farming with
little or no chemicals was considered practical only for small farmers and
hobbyists who could more easily rotate crops and spend time working the land.

Now large commercial farmers are seeking alternatives to a chemical technology
that on the one hand is costing billions of dollars each year and on the other
yields health risks, environmental contamination and huge surpluses that drive
prices down. If the movement spreads further, experts say, it could have
important consequences for the farm economy, the environment and the health of
farmers, consumers and rural residents.

''The concept of these alternative practices is that we can work our soil, use
our water, and not use it up or ruin it,'' said George S. Dunlop, Assistant
Secretary of Agriculture for Natural Resources and the Environment. ''The fact
of the matter is that agriculture policy has been adverse to sustaining the
quality of our resources. Our farm policy has encouraged an emphasis on getting
the maximum number of bushels per acre that is conceivably possible. We got away
from natural cropping systems. We need to change that emphasis.''

No Consensus on Name

The Department of Agriculture estimates that 30,000 of the nation's 2.1 million
farmers are raising crops without chemicals or are close to eliminating their
use. Other experts believe the number ranges from 50,000 to 100,000. Nearly
everybody agrees that the number is growing rapidly.

But agreement on what the movement should be called has not yet been reached. In
the East, farmers call the techniques ''regenerative,'' a term coined by
scientists and executives at the Rodale Research Center, an influential private
institute in Pennsylvania. Farmers in California and the Midwest refer to the
practices as ''sustainable.'' The Department of Agriculture calls the system
''low-input'' farming. And many farmers in the Northeast and Northwest call the
practices ''organic.''

The first three terms are meant to describe farm practices that depend on the
dynamic biological interrelationships in nature to achieve the same results as
chemical pesticides and fertilizers. The intent is to maintain the purity and
availability of renewable resources, like soil and water. If done correctly,
advocates say, farmers should also see production costs drop and profits rise.

But labeling the practices as organic has lost favor. ''That word turned people
off,'' said Dr. John Luna, an entomologist at the Virginia Polytechnic Institute
in Blacksburg. ''There was a connotation that the people who pushed organic
agriculture were anti-pesticide, anti-mainstream agriculture and represented an
extreme position. The new terminology has allowed us to redefine what we're
doing, and get rid of a lot of negative baggage that was blocking commercial
farmers from participating.''

The Agriculture Department, which once disdained the practices, opened a center
in Memphis last month, complete with a toll-free telephone line, to provide
technical information on sustainable agriculture to farmers and scientists. The
agency is also openly encouraging its scientists to develop alternatives to
chemicals.

Congress and States Respond

Congress, which approved a program two years ago to establish a network of
demonstration research farms around the country, is now weighing a proposal to
spend $15 million on the system.

And many states are responding. In the last 15 months new programs to transfer
sustainable agriculture techniques to farmers have been established in
California, Iowa, Nebraska and Wisconsin.

In June, Gov. Rudy Perpich of Minnesota, a Democrat, signed a law establishing
the nation's first chair for studying sustainable farm practices at the
University of Minnesota. Agricultural universities in 16 other states maintain
research programs in sustainable farming.

''This kind of research could eventually bring about the healthiest agriculture
in the world,'' said Senator Patrick J. Leahy, a Vermont Democrat who is
chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee.

Based on Age-Old Technologies

In essence, sustainable techniques cut costs by replacing chemicals with labor
and imagination. Some of the practices are based on age-old farm technologies
that lost favor when pesticides and fertilizers became widely available. Mr.
Tschumper, for instance, discovered that two carefully timed applications of
manure, in the spring and fall, provided most of the nutrition his soil needed.

He also developed rotation schemes to fight weeds and bugs. After harvesting
corn, he plants oats which grow thick and tall, crowding out weeds. He follows
oats with alfalfa, a legume, which adds nitrogen to the soil. By the time he
plants corn again on the same land 2 to 5 years later, the soil is rich with
nutrients.

Mr. Tschumper says he can produce a bushel of corn for 40 cents, one-fifth the
cost of chemical farmers, and his alfalfa harvests average six tons per acre, 50
percent better than the state average.

Other sustainable techniques are ingenious. Gary Ruehling, an organic vegetable
and melon grower from Weaver, a cross-roads town 40 miles north of Mr.
Tschumper's farm, plants orange marigolds among his green peppers. The flowers
attract pollinating insects, and produce a natural substance that repels harmful
insects.

Mr. Ruehling learned to plant eggplant, which beetles prefer, next to potatoes.
Likewise, he's learned that onions and garlic are valuable insect repellants.
''You learn from other farmers and you experiment all the time'' said Mr.
Ruehling, 31, who sells his produce to restaurants in the region and from a
stand on the road in front of his farm.

Large Growers Falling in Step

Farmers say the movement toward a system of food production based on biology
instead of chemistry got started in the early 1970's. Small fruit and vegetable
growers, who receive premium prices in urban markets, still outnumber any other
group farming without chemicals.

But farmers in Minnesota and elsewhere are producing organic beef, chicken and
pork by feeding them chemical-free rations and eliminating the use of
antibiotics and other toxic drugs that promote growth.

Some of the nation's largest growers in the Midwest, North Dakota and Montana,
are also taking advantage of a growing market in Europe for grain produced
without chemicals. These farmers are selling soybeans for $8 a bushel and wheat
for $4.50 a bushel, prices that are double those for crops grown with
conventional techniques.

''Instead of turning on the spray guns at the first sight of a weed or insect,
we need to base our farm production on a better understanding of the complex
interactions in nature,'' said Terry Gips, executive director of the
International Alliance for Sustainable Agriculture, a policy and education
organization in Minneapolis that represents farm and consumer groups around the
world. ''By thinking harder we can design even better systems to reduce our
chemical dependency in farming.''

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

farm in La Crescent, Minn. (NYT/Keith Schneider)

* * * * * * * * * * DESCRIPTION * * * * * * * * * *

   YaSheng Group, incorporated on January 12, 2004, is a holding company that
operates and conducts its business operations in the People's Republic of China.
The Company is a producer of specialty agriculture-based products, specializing
in developing the agriculture industry by cultivating, processing, marketing and
distributing a range of food and agro-byproducts. Its product portfolio includes
perishables and processed foods sold in volume, repackaged into units, or sold
directly to consumers in local markets. It produces main staples for animal
feed, fertilizers and agro-industry products, such as edible oils, or
bio-construction materials. The Company also operates a concrete plant in Baiyin
City, Gansu Province, China.

   The Company harvests its crops through its farming operations and from
collective farm operators. As of December 31, 2015, the Company's product
offerings included over 30 agriculture products under six areas, which include
field crops: cotton, corn, barley, wheat, flaxseed and alfalfa; vegetables:
onion, potato, beet and pea; fruit: apple, pear and apricot; specialty crops:
hops, wolfberry, cumin, hemp and liquorices root; seeds: black melon seeds,
sunflower seeds, corn seed, hemp seed and flax seed, and poultry: eggs. The
Company also produces additional fresh fruits and vegetables.

   As of December 31, 2015, the Company sold its products through a sales and
distribution network covering 19 provinces and over 121 cities in China. As of
December 29, 2015, the Company had approximately 238 distributors and 41 direct
clients. It sells its products to food processors, as well as processed within
the Company and then resold to supermarkets or other distributors, or further
processed into retail food products. The Company sells its fresh products within
Gansu province, as well as nationally to food processors and distributors, or
directly to the supermarkets. Its products are also sold as feed for livestock,
ingredients for Chinese traditional medicines, as well as other ingredients in
the food industry.

   The Company competes with China National Cereals, Oil and Foodstuffs
Corporation, and China Grains and Oils Group.

                             773 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                            The Independent (London)

                              May 9, 2005, Monday

ANALYSIS: HOW CHEMICALS ALTERED BALANCE BETWEEN FARMING AND NATURAL WORLD

BYLINE: MICHAEL MCCARTHY ENVIRONMENT EDITOR

SECTION: First Edition; NEWS; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 375 words


One overwhelming cause is behind the dramatic decline of so much of British
flora: intensive farming.

Britain is such a small country that it cannot afford separate areas for
wildlife and agriculture, as to some extent is possible in the United States;
here, farming and wildlife have to coexist side by side.

They coexisted successfully, if now and then uneasily, for thousands of years.
Farmers might sometimes be annoyed at the 'weeds' in their cornfields, but could
never quite eradicate all the poppies, cornflowers and corn marigolds " so the
summer fields were vibrant with scarlet, blue and yellow flashes in amongst the
corn.

However, the chemical-based agriculture that started to emerge 40 to 50 years
ago dramatically altered the balance between farming and the natural world.
Potent herbicides allowed farmers to get rid of many of the unwanted plants in
their arable fields, and their populations tumbled; sights such as a field of
poppies, familiar to most people in Britain over the age of 50, simply
disappeared.

It was not just in the arable fields, either, that wild flowers started
vanishing: the grassland pastures where sheep and cattle fed also held rich
communities of plant life, and they too have been badly affected. Here, the
cause was not pesticides, but fertilisers. The proposition that adding
fertiliser to a field causes flowers to disappear may seem counter- intuitive to
non-botanists, but it is sadly true. What happens is that for a few species "
and usually only the target grass "there is enormous benefit and vigorous extra
growth, but this is so strong that it out-competes everything else. Other plants
cannot survive.

Agricultural chemicals have been the main problem, but not the only one. Man has
made many direct assaults on the landscape: sensitive habitats with specialised
flora such as chalk grassland or lowland heath have gone under the plough or
under concrete. The change in farming practices has also contributed, such as
the shift from haymaking to silage and the destruction of hedges.

The fields still look green when you go for your country walk; but often, green
is all they look, and the wonderful pattern of colour they once exhibited is no
longer to be seen.

LOAD-DATE: May 9, 2005

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                      Copyright 2005 Independent Print Ltd


                             774 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                            The Press (Christchurch)

                             May 9, 2002, Thursday

'A' for talk, 'F' for action

BYLINE: KEENE Howard

SECTION: FARMING Pg. 18; Farming

LENGTH: 383 words


Agriculture Minister Jim Sutton has strongly criticised the United States,
saying it owes the world an explanation over its proposed Farm Bill which will
increase subsidies.

"The United States has always got an 'A' for rhetoric about trade
liberalisation, but at the moment it would be lucky to get an 'F' for effort,"
said Mr Sutton.

He said it was ludicrous that the United States farm industry, which was modern,
technologically competent, and productive, received about 30 per cent of its
annual net income from subsidies.

The Farm Bill, expected to be signed into law by President Bush within two
weeks, boosts funding for subsidies and a range of environmental programmes by $

 US73 billion ($ 160 billion).

Of interest to New Zealand is the creation of new subsidies for wool, mohair,
and honey, as well as a new dairy-price programme.

The bill reverses shifts towards free trade in the American farming sector.

Mr Sutton said the increased subsidies for American farmers would have an impact
on the prices New Zealand farmers would receive for their products.

"This is difficult for New Zealand to accept. We've worked with the United
States to promote trade in agriculture. We have heard very fine speeches. This
bill just flies in the face of that."

He said if the bill was passed it would inevitably lead to the US breaching its
World Trade Organisation commitments.

Mr Sutton will visit Washington later this month.

Any decision on action would depend on his discussion with American officials,
and talks with other affected nations, he said.

The bill makes country- of-origin labelling compulsory for meat, and that has
upset Meat New Zealand chief executive Neil Taylor.

He said the move was intended to suggest to US consumers that US beef was safer
than imported beef.

"Of course New Zealand beef and lamb more than match US product in terms of
safety and quality, but we're dealing with consumer perceptions here which are
notoriously quick to shift."

Mr Taylor said that last week some US farmers struck out at New Zealand beef,
alleging it was less safe than US beef. This was a bid to fight fast-food giant
McDonald's in its testing of New Zealand and Australian beef in some US
restaurants.

--------------------

CAPTION:

Jim Sutton

                                December 8, 2010

Montana Farm Bureau comments in support of Roundup Ready beets

BYLINE: Sidney Herald staff

LENGTH: 373  words


The Montana Farm Bureau Federation has submitted comments to the U.S. Department
of Agriculture on USDA Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS)
published draft Environmental Assessment. This assessment provides an analysis
of any environmental impacts, associated with actions the agency is considering
for Roundup Ready sugar beets.

"Montana Farm Bureau members support Roundup Ready technology due to the fact
that Montana is a large sugar beet-producing state, and Roundup Ready Technology
has been proven safe," said farm bureau executive vice president Jake Cummins in
the comments. "Additionally, markets have proven that consumers are more than
willing to purchase sugar processed from Roundup Ready sugar beets."

Planted on 1.2 million acres in the United States annually and supplying half of
our nation's sugar, sugar beets are an important crop. The value of sugar beet
crops is critically important to rural communities and their economies. Biotech
sugar beets planted on 95 percent of all sugar beet acreage have allowed growers
to control weeds - one of their greatest challenges - in a more environmentally
sustainable way

Don Steinbeisser Jr., a Richland County Farm Bureau board member and sugar beet
grower, is a fan of Roundup Ready sugar beets. "First, by using the Roundup
Ready method of farming, we use reduced tillage, meaning greatly reduced soil
erosion. Secondly, we don't have to make as many passes in the field applying
chemical, so the soil doesn't get compacted. Third, we now only need to use one
chemical instead of four or five," Steinbeisser noted. "Roundup is a very
environmentally friendly product. We haven't seen any resistance trouble."

Steinbeisser said that from a producer viewpoint, the Roundup Ready method has a
very big plus - beets won't be killed by chemicals. "It's common that you'll
kill about 10 percent of your beet crop using conventional farming chemicals,"
Steinbeisser said. "By using Roundup Ready beets, that's no longer a problem."

Even though this technology has been proven safe, environmental activists filed
a lawsuit to stop the use of Roundup Ready sugar beets.

"There is less erosion, reduced chemical use, less soil compaction and a better
yield," Steinbeisser said.

                              Journal of Commerce

                             March 30, 1998, Monday

Canada, US chicken farmers are not birds of a feather;
Marketing differences separate the two

BYLINE: BY COURTNEY TOWER

SECTION: WORLD TRADE; Pg. 3A

LENGTH: 455 words

DATELINE: OTTAWA


They were chicken farmers together, but worlds apart - Don Allen, contract
grower from Arkansas, and his Canadian poultry counterparts.

""You have a completely different perspective of the poultry world than I have
as a contract grower,'' he said, wishing that his world would change.

Aspects of the Canadian poultry world that look so solid and stable to Mr. Allen
are bound to become crucial trade issues, with the United States on one side and
Canada on the other, in forthcoming renewed world trade negotiations.

Mr. Allen, treasurer of the U.S. National Contract Poultry Growers Association,
contrasted the differences in agriculture practices between the United States
and Canada in a recent address to the Chicken Farmers of Canada, which
represents the 2,800 comparatively small poultry farmers.

He portrayed the U.S. system as mainly a contract-farmer industry, with farmers
almost in bondage to giant agribusiness companies like Tyson's, ConAgra or
Cargill.

""They own the birds, own the feed, and pay an average 4.5 cents a pound, when
they paid 3.5 cents in 1977,'' he said. Contract farmers must agree to detailed
instructions as to how they shall operate, and must buy and install whatever new
device or piece of equipment that takes the major company's fancy, he said.

The U.S. chicken industry oscillates between boom and bust, with overproduction
encouraged by the major companies, Mr. Allen said. New entrants were coming in
all the time, depressing prices to the farmer and ruining many with the
unpredictable swings that occurred.

Mr. Allen's association is behind a bill working its way through the House of
Representatives. The bill would bring more control over the large integrated
companies. The bill, H.R. 2738, would bring mediation to disputes between
companies and growers. It would set up a body accredited by the secretary of
agriculture that would bargain with the companies of behalf of the growers.

The Canadian industry is largely one of family firms, reasonably profitable and
stable. Production and prices are controlled under a national system of
bargaining between processors and farmers through their provincial marketing
boards.

A report by Statistics Canada puts poultry and egg growers, and dairy farmers,
at the top of the farm heap for return on investment, with the exception of
tobacco farmers, a minuscule segment. The feather and dairy industries are the
only ones in Canada to practice nationally operated systems of production and
price-setting, known as supply management.

Opponents say these features, and the practice of setting differing domestic and
export prices and paying the farmer one blended price, are violations of market
enterprise.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                                  May 7, 2014

Alliger named FFA Star Over Iowa (Production);
Klingson and Kehoe capture 1st place...

BYLINE: Dayton Review staff

LENGTH: 634  words


The 86th State FFA Leadership Conference was held April 28 and 29, 2014 on the
campus of Iowa State University. Over 5,200 members, advisors and guest were
present.

Local FFA president Austin Promes served as the chapter's official voting
delegate during the business session. Meals from the Heartland

Thanks to the Iowa FFA Association's partnership with Meals from the Heartland,
an initiative of the Iowa Food and Family Project, Iowa Soybean Association,
GROWMARK, and the Iowa FFA Foundation more than 1,600 FFA members packaged over
250,000 rice-soy meals to help families in Iowa and abroad. Six local members
assisted in this activity this year.

The 2014 Stars Over Iowa Winners were announced on Tuesday afternoon. A Star
Over Iowa was selected in each of the four different areas: Agricultural
Placement, Agriscience, Agribusiness, and Agricultural Production. Iowa Star in
Production Agriculture

Alex Alliger, the son of Larry and Jill Alliger, of the Prairie Valley/SWG FFA
Chapter at Gowrie was selected as the Iowa Star in Production Agriculture. His
agricultural education instructor and FFA advisor is Mr. Steven Kehoe. During
the past four years, Alliger has developed skills with corn, soybeans, swine,
and cattle production. Alliger began by recording his placement hours on his
family's diversified farming operation, and he also finished out 250 market
hogs. Since that time, his SAE program has grown to finish over 1,000 market
hogs and assisted his family in keeping records with their cattle, corn and
soybean operation. Alliger is currently a freshman at Des Moines Area Community
College and plans to earn a degree in the Agricultural Business program. Iowa
FFA Degrees

The Iowa FFA Degree is the highest degree that can be bestowed upon a FFA member
by the Iowa FFA Association each year. Only 5% of the FFA members in iowa
receive the degree. Each Iowa FFA Degree recipient receives a certificate and
the golden State FFA Charm pin, which is made possible with support from DuPont
Pioneer through the Iowa FFA Foundation. Receiving their Iowa FFA Degree this
year was Alex Alliger, Gowrie; Curt Castenson, Harcourt; Alexis Hanson, Gowrie;
Taylor Nelson, Otho; and Clayton Taylor, Lohrville. Proficiency Awards

Logan Klingson the son of Mark and Kim Klingson and Trey Kehoe, the son of
Patrick and Christi Kehoe were state winners in the agricultural proficiency
award area. Logan Klingson earned first place gold in Agricultural Mechanics
(repair and maintenance). Trey Kehoe placed first in the area of Diversified
Horticulture.

Josh Carlson (Jim and Jennifer Carlson) was runner-up in forage production.
Clayton Taylor (Clark and Jennifer Taylor) was runner-up in grain production.
Tristan Petersen (Shad and Barb Petersen) placed second in Wildlife Management.

Other members whose applications advanced to state were: Branden Fiala, Moorland
- Ag. Processing - Silver rating; Austin Promes, Gowrie-Agri-cultural Services-
Silver rating; Bailey Wal-rod, Moorland-Beef Production-Silver rating; Alex
Alliger, Gowrie-Diversified Ag. Production-Gold rating; Alexis Hanson,
Gowrie-Beef Production Placement-Silver rating; Bryce Scott, Pilot
Mound-Diversified Livestock Production-Silver rating; Allie Berg, Somers-Sheep
Production-Silver rating; Curt Castenson, Harcourt-Turf Grass Mgt.-Gold rating;
Cadie Schmadeke, Callender, Vegetable Production-Silver rating.

Bryce Scott, the son of Rob and Lorna Scott was the North Central Districts
candidate for the United Boone FFA Alumni Rising Star Award He was honored
Tuesday afternoon for his efforts. Scott was also a member of the FFA Band.

The chapter earned a gold rating in the National Chapter Award program placing
23rd overall. The chapter was also recognized in donating over $1,000.00 to the
Iowa FFA Foundation's Ambassador Program.

                                US Official News

                            December 8, 2015 Tuesday

Washington: Camelina 'Partnered' with Soybeans for Food and Fuel Benefits

LENGTH: 370 words

DATELINE: Lahore



 Washington: United States Department of Agriculture Research Service has issued
the following news release:



 Once considered a weed, camelina is gaining popularity in some parts of the
country as a soil-protecting winter cover crop. Additionally, its seed contains
high-quality oil for use in cooking and as biodiesel, offering a renewable
alternative to imported petroleum.





 U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) scientists have been on the forefront of
studies to make camelina and other novel oilseed crops more profitable for
farmers to grow, easier for industry to process, and better performing as
finished biofuels and other products. At the Soil Management Research Unit,
operated in Morris, Minnesota, by USDA's Agricultural Research Service (ARS),
scientists are evaluating the outcome of integrating camelina, canola,
pennycress and other oilseeds with plantings of traditional Midwestern crops,
such as corn and soybeans.



 In a recent study published in the April issue of Agronomy Journal, ARS
scientists Russ Gesch and Jane Johnson examined the seasonal water use of double
cropping and relay cropping-strategies that overlap the growth of winter
camelina and soybean. Highlights of their findings are:



     Under natural rainfall conditions, relay cropping (in which the soybean
crop is seeded between rows of growing camelina plants) used less water than
double cropping (in which soybean seed is sown right after a camelina harvest,
around mid to late June) and produced higher soybean yields.



     Relay-cropped soybean yields were lower than those of full-season soybean
crops; however, the total oil yield from the relay system (camelina plus soy)
was 50 percent greater than the full-season soybean-only crop.



     Net economic returns of relay cropping were competitive with those of
full-season soybean, while adding the benefits of a cover crop.



 According to the researchers, the study demonstrates a sustainable way to grow
crops for both food and fuel on the same parcel of land, which could potentially
offer farmers a dual source of income in a single season.

contact:

 editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

                            The Daily Yomiuri(Tokyo)

                              May 15, 2007 Tuesday

ECONOMIC FORUM;
Agriculture needs reform;
Farming lobby stumbling block when negotiating FTAs, EPAs

BYLINE: Yoshikuni Sugiyama, Yomiuri

SECTION: Pg. 4

LENGTH: 920 words


What must be done to facilitate progress on the country's negotiations for
sealing free trade agreements and economic partnership agreements, as this
country has been alarmingly lagging behind the global trend of formulating FTAs
and EPAs?

The largest stumbling block for this country to negotiate free trade pacts with
the nation's trade partners is without doubt the agricultural industry.

Now, no time should be wasted in addressing the task of farm reform.

An expert study panel of the government's key policymaking body, the Council on
Economic and Fiscal Policy, chaired by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, has put forth
an interim report calling for a radical reform package of the country's farm
sector.

Although the government made bids to reform the ailing farm industry many times
in the past, they all went round in circles, getting nowhere.

A proposal in the interim report by the panel for globalization reforms of the
national economy points out the need for making the nation's agriculture strong
enough to withstand the impact of a liberalized farm market, by means of
grouping small farming lots into large-scale operations.

Farm reform must be enforced without delay and the government should incorporate
the reform blueprint into the forthcoming Basic Policies for Economic and Fiscal
Management and Structural Reform for 2007 that the Cabinet will approve in June.

South Korea struck a deal in April concluding an FTA with the United States.

Commenting on the Washington-Seoul FTA, the interim report expresses strong
concern noting that Japan, in the event of being left behind, would be "in
danger of finding ourselves in a situation seriously disadvantageous in the
international market."

Regarding the need for an FTA or EPA between Japan and the United States, the
report proposes that joint industrial-academic-government studies be started on
the matter promptly on a bilateral basis.

Japan's negotiations on FTAs and EPAs have so far focused on countries in Asia.

Japan's pacts with Singapore and Malaysia are already in effect, while those
with the Philippines and Thailand have been signed.

None of these countries, however, is a major exporter of agricultural produce,
and the issue of liberalizing farm trade was not a major subject of negotiations
with them.

If this country begins negotiating with the United States on an FTA or EPA, the
problem of farm trade liberalization will certainly be the highest on the
agenda.

It also is certain that Japan's domestic agricultural organizations will react
strongly to the negotiations, intensely opposing the idea of liberalizing farm
trade with the United States.

The more reluctant the government is to begin trade negotiations with the United
States because of the opposition from farm lobbies, the more losses the Japanese
economy as a whole will be bound to suffer.

The interim report makes reference to various reform plans to boost the
international competitiveness of Japan's agriculture.

It calls for plots of farmland that are left idle to be grouped for effective
utilization in a way conducive to fostering enterprises that operate larger
fields.

Abandoned farmland stood at 386,000 hectares throughout the country in 2005,
accounting for as much as 10 percent of the nation's entire arable land. The
acreage of the deserted fields is equivalent to the whole of Shiga Prefecture.

To ensure effective use of the abandoned farmland, the report says no
restrictions should be imposed in principle on types of management of farming
enterprises, while also noting that regulations governing the transfer of
farmland ownership should be lifted.

In addition, the report specifically recommends that the maximum period for
renting farmland, currently set at 20 years under the Civil Code, be extended to
enable farmland borrowers to engage in agricultural business in a stable manner.

It also notes each prefectural government, including the administrations of
Tokyo and Hokkaido, should establish an independent organization comprising farm
business operators and experts, with the aim of encouraging adequate use of
farmland and expansion of the scale of farming operations.

The Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries Ministry, for its part, has presented
its report to the Council on Economic and Fiscal Policy. The report, titled
"Desirable Agricultural Policies in an Age of Globalization," shows what the
ministry favors in dealing with the issues of FTAs and EPAs.

While stressing the need to reform the nation's domestic agriculture, the
ministry in the report reiterates its posture opposed to "rushing the process of
farm trade liberalization." The report says the ministry has remained resolved
to "defend domestic farm interests as long as they are deemed as deserving of
being protected."

"Sufficient attention should be paid to the impact on domestic agriculture in
the event of farm trade liberalization," the report says.

Indications, therefore, are that the liberalization proposals by the expert
study panel would meet strong objections from farm lobbies.

For a country that has received a great deal of benefit from trade
liberalization since the end of World War II, there can be no doubt that efforts
for expediting FTA and EPA negotiations will be beneficial to the national
interest from a long-range point of view.

Prime Minister Abe should be determined to give full play to his leadership to
have the proposals by the expert study panel adopted and enforced as government
policy without fail.

Sugiyama is economic news editor of The Yomiuri Shimbun.

LOAD-DATE: May 14, 2007

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                           Hobart Mercury (Australia)

                            January 6, 2004 Tuesday

Our beef on menu as US suffers

SECTION: FINANCE; Pg. 19

LENGTH: 243 words


THE mad cow disease scare affecting the United States has sparked significant
interest in Australian grain-fed cattle, our second-largest beef producer said
yesterday.

Australian Agricultural Company chief executive Peter Holmes a Court said the
level of contact from Asian clients was up markedly over the past few weeks.

"No doubt we have had an increase in direct inquiries and indirect inquiries
through Australian processors who send to Asia," Mr Holmes a Court said.

The US Department of Agriculture said late last week another cattle herd in
Washington state was under quarantine.

This brings to three the number placed under a state hold order since the first
case of mad cow disease was announced in the US on December 23.

The outbreak in the US of bovine spongiform encephalopathy, better known as mad
cow disease, has led to several countries banning US beef imports.

Australia's livestock industry hopes the US mad cow outbreak will boost local
beef exports.

AACo, which has 19 cattle stations in Queensland and the Northern Territory
covering some 6.5 million hectares, has two feedlots where cattle are grain fed.

It also produces Wagyu, a tender Japanese style of beef with a distinctive
taste, which it sells directly into Asia.

AACo said it had entered agreements to buy the Carrum Station, in central
Queensland, and approximately 58,000 cattle for about $50 million.

AACo shares closed up 4c at $1.26.

                             781 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                               The New York Times

                              May 27, 2003 Tuesday
                              Late Edition - Final

Canada's Problem -- and America's

BYLINE:  By Michael K. Hansen;  Michael K. Hansen is a senior research associate
at Consumers Union.

SECTION: Section A; Column 1; Editorial Desk; Pg. 25

LENGTH: 692 words

DATELINE: YONKERS


The discovery of a case of mad cow disease in Canada underlines the need for
American officials to exercise much greater vigilance to prevent the emergence
of this fatal brain-wasting disease in the United States. Live cattle, beef
products and animal feed move relatively freely between the United States and
Canada; last year the United States imported one billion pounds of beef from
Canada. Unfortunately, the federal government's defenses are full of gaps.

Mad cow disease is one of several similar fatal brain diseases known as
transmissible spongiform encephalopathies. They are so named because of their
main effect: the infected brain eventually becomes riddled with spongelike
holes. The disease is believed to be caused by a mutant protein that, when
eaten, travels through the body to the brain. The effect on the victim is always
the same: mental deterioration and death.

There have been 100 confirmed deaths in Britain from the human form of mad cow
disease, which is thought to be caused by eating tainted beef, and the number is
rising. So far the United States has been lucky. But to prevent an outbreak, a
number of steps need to be taken immediately.

First, we need to screen more cattle for the disease. Last year, the United
States Department of Agriculture tested only 19,990 cows believed to be at risk
for mad cow disease, out of a population of about 96 million. This sample is far
too small to detect a problem that might be small but growing. The department
should mandate the use of rapid tests, currently used in Europe, which have
allowed testing of all cattle above a certain age at slaughter. Last year
European regulators tested more than 10 million cattle for mad cow disease, out
of a total population of some 40 million.

The Food and Drug Administration should also ban the feeding of all animal
remains to food animals. At factory farms and feed lots, cattle, hogs and
chickens eat a relatively high-protein diet, and much of this protein comes from
the rendered remains of other cattle, hogs or chickens.

The European Union, for example, does not allow animal remains to be fed to any
food animal. (In Britain, cows are believed to have been infected by eating
sheep with scrapie, which is a form of transmissible spongiform encephalopathy.)
But under the F.D.A.'s current rules, cattle remains can still be fed to other
animals, such as pigs and chickens, whose remains can then be fed back to cows.
Even the remains of an animal known to carry a form of mad cow disease could go
into rendered feed, under F.D.A. rules.

More than just meat is at risk. Materials from some of the most potentially
infectious parts of a cow, including brains, eyes and spleen, sometimes end up
in dietary supplements. This fact, along with recent deaths associated with use
of the dietary supplement ephedra, underlines the need for Congress to require
dietary supplements to prove their safety before being marketed.

Despite all these efforts, an outbreak could still occur. If it does, we might
not know for some time if Americans were becoming infected with a mad-cow-like
disease at an increased rate -- because it is not one of the diseases doctors
and hospitals must report to the Centers for Disease Control. It should be made
a mandatory reportable disease.

While the government considers what it can do, what should consumers do? The
size of the risk is unknown, so it's hard to say. However, some foods are
clearly more risky than others.

Since the most infectious material is to be found in the brains of cows,
consumers could simply avoid them. Some processed beef products, like many
sausages and hot dogs, are produced using machines that scour a cow carcass for
all available meat. Since they may contain central nervous system tissue, some
people may want to avoid them as well. A steak, or hamburger that the butcher
grinds in front of you, carries the least risk. Consumers may also want to
consider organic or grass-fed beef, since these cows are not fed any animal
proteins.

The bottom line is that the government should act now to protect the food
supply. Delay will only allow any potential problem to get worse.

URL: http://www.nytimes.com

LOAD-DATE: May 27, 2003

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Op-Ed

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                   Copyright 2003 The New York Times Company


                             782 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                             July 19, 1983 Tuesday

Bumper crops   create tension

BYLINE: REUT

LENGTH: 576 words

DATELINE: Washington DC


WASHINGTON  (Reuter) - A third consecutive year of bumper grain harvests
 world-wide is heightening tensions between major grain exporting countries
 and causing some to rethink their farm policies.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture recently forecast 1983 world grain
 output at more than 1.6 billion metric tons, only 2 per cent below last
 year's record crop.

Frustrated by declines in the U.S. share of the market, the U.S. Rice
 Millers Association and the National Soybean Processors Association have
 asked the Government for relief from other countries' export subsidies.

The United States and the European Economic Community have scheduled
 six more months of talks about farm subsidies and export market shares
 after an initial six months of discussion yielded virtually nothing.

Howard Hjort, a private economist and former U.S. assistant secretary
 of agriculture, said the trade disputes are really only the symptoms. Too
 much grain and not enough demand are the real problems, he said.

The USDA reduced its forecast of world coarse grain trade in the crop
 year ending next June by 1.2 million tons to 94.2 million tons, mostly
 because of improved crop prospects.

Although the Australian wheat crop is barely in the ground, early
 forecasts put it at more than 17 million tons, almost double last year's
 drought-reduced harvest.

The world market for wheat is further tightened by record wheat and
 rice crops forecast in China, normally a large wheat importer.

The Soviet Union, also a large importer in recent years, is expecting a
 rebound from three consecutive poor harvests.

The USDA has lowered its July forecast of the Soviet Union's 1983-84
 grain imports to 30 million tons, almost 17 per cent below its June
 forecast and well below an estimated 46 million tons two years earlier.

Prospects in Brazil are for a good soybean harvest, which could double
 this year's exports.

EEC grain output is expected to fall slightly, but officials said
 exports will remain stable as stocks remain high.

In the United States, huge stocks will keep exportable supplies large
 despite an acreage decline owing to a new government program called
 "payment in kind," under which farmers are paid in grain for leaving land
 idle.

The cost of supporting farm prices in the face of reduced demand has
 caused the United States and the EEC to re-evaluate farm policies.

Agriculture Secretary John Block has met farm and agricultural business
 leaders to discuss reforms that would not take effect until 1985. The EEC
 Commission is also considering plans for unprecedented cuts in farm
 subsidies.

But U.S. agricultural economists said the only real cure for the global
 grain market is a sustained and worldwide economic recovery.

Mr. Hjort said there is no question the demand potential is there, but
 many countries are too hard-pressed for cash to buy what they need.

Mexico, for example, has asked the United States for a $500-million
 advance in agricultural credit guarantees to buy farm products.

By the end of May, Mexico had already exhausted the $1.2-billion
 authorized for farm purchases in the 1983 financial year.

The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization reported in mid-
 June abnormal food shortages prevailed in 16 countries, mostly in Africa.

Asked why the United States cuts production while people are starving,
 Mr. Block has responded that storage and distribution problems make it
 virtually impossible to get much more food to the poor than is already
 being distributed.

LOAD-DATE: January 24, 2007

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


 Copyright 1983 The Globe and Mail, a division of CTVglobemedia Publishing Inc.
                              All Rights Reserved


                             783 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



               South Burnett Times and Rural Weekly (Queensland)

                               December 13, 2013

Attitudes to Aussie farms must change;
Importance of Australian farming being revitalised

SECTION: Pg. 21

LENGTH: 633  words



HIGHLIGHT: Valuable skills: Critics will soon eat humble pie


FOLLOWING the GrainCorps comedy and the analysis of the United States purchaser,
the prospect of Australian participation in an Asian Food Bowl has been
revitalised by Agriculture Minister Barnaby Joyce.

Farming is a fizzer in many commercial circles in the land down under, but
agriculture is very real and ironically many people do eat.

The status of the Australian Dairy Industry is an illustration of Australian
economic enigma.

One hundred years ago in 1913 the South Burnett Co-operative Dairy industry was
established in Murgon with a solid body of farmers.

Deemed to be non- competitive with its co-operative status, the dairy
association was governmentally abolished.

The economic excellence of that era prevails today and regional Australia is a
capital city outcast. The Asian ascendancy might see a change in the Australian
agricultural attitude.

Brekkie meet

FOUR kangaroos have breakfast every morning at "Castra" Murgon and enjoy every
bite of it.

The Murgon Rotary Club met at "Castra" on Wednesday evening and discussed the
success of the recent Music Muster.

Rotarian Pat Donohue, recently returned from a fortnight in the United States,
reported on the Stars and Stripes.

Rotarian Babu Singh of Fiji origin, now resident in Murgon and associated with
Cherbourg, greeted two visitors from New Zealand, Nick Taitusi and Willie Hume.

The Murgon Rotary Club in its 58th year is continuing its community
consolidation in the South Burnett town.

KEITH Goodchild was president of the Murgon Rotary Club in 1993-94 and is now
resident in Canberra with wife, Cleo, who is a regular correspondent with Mrs
Kath Braithwaite in Murgon.

Cleo's grandmother, Mrs Martha Angel, is sentimentally recognised as the "Mother
of Murgon." Before banks, Mrs Angel's credit kept the farming community in
business from 1907 onwards.

In a recent letter from Canberra, Cleo wrote "A trip to the Canberra Aboriginal
Centre and I was able to speak to a few interested teenagers about Cherbourg and
a few "Aunties".

Son-in-law Peter, a recently retired officer in the Royal Australian Air Force,
has been asked to return to the RAAF to work on an exciting new plane. So now
"he has donned the uniform again".

Bruce and Jenny Bishop recently visited Keith and Cleo in Canberra.

Speaker named

AS AUSTRALIA Day approaches it's timely to refer to the Murgon celebration of
the event at the Queensland Dairy and Heritage Museum.

Guest speaker this year is Brett Heading, grandson of Sir James Heading and
chairman of solicitors, McCullough and Robertson, Brisbane.

Brett's business interests also include Clovelly Vineyards, Moffatdale. The
Heading family is synonymous with the foundation of Murgon and district and this
is significant in the choice of guest Australia Day speaker for 2014.

Murgon has been heading in the right direction since 1903 and in its 111th year
Brett Heading is a very appropriate choice as guest speaker on Australia Day.

Chairman of the Queensland Dairy and Heritage Museum Committee, Richard O'Neill
is very pleased with the visitation attendance during 2013.

Up, up and away

FOR the best part of a century Qantas has been flying Australia, 93 years in
fact. A 1920 origin in Winton, Queensland, saw the flying kangaroo leap into
international travel.

From biplane to jet Qantas has been a world leader in a period where sentimental
history has to withstand business bombardment.

Qantas was in its early teens when Smithy landed the Southern Cross at
Angelfield, Murgon. Aircraft were still learning to fly.

In 2013 heritage is a sentimental component of aircraft travel and the Kangaroos
in Rugby League have a better chance of survival than Qantas.

With 32,000 employees Shorten has a formidable stake in a Qantas survival. For
93 years Qantas has flown effectively with all its planes securely airborne.

                        The Pueblo Chieftain (Colorado)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            September 9, 2007 Sunday

Area expert will help rebuild Iraq's ag sector: Walsenburg extension agent will
work for Foreign Agricultural Service.

BYLINE: Tammy Alhadef, The Pueblo Chieftain, Colo.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 433 words


Sep. 9--WALSENBURG -- A lifelong love of adventure and a desire to make a
difference in the world has led one Colorado State University county extension
agent to set out on a path for one of the world's most dangerous regions.

Huerfano County extension agent Jim Conley will pack his bags and head to Iraq
in October as a member of the United States Department of Agriculture's Foreign
Agricultural Service. Serving as an agricultural adviser for one year, Conley,
55, will be part of a 75-member provincial reconstruction team commissioned to
rebuild an Iraqi province somewhere north of Baghdad.

"I've heard we're headed to Kirkuk, but you just never know," he said.

Taking with him 5 years of extension experience and three agricultural degrees,
Conley said his job would be to help the province redevelop its agricultural
economy with cotton and small grain crops.

Iraq, he said, has always had a strong agricultural heritage.

"Between the Tigris and the Euphrates rivers, that's where farming started," he
said.

Unfortunately, agriculture in the region has been decimated by war. Even before
that, Conley said, food production was "down the tubes" with Saddam Hussein
diverting resources away from farming.

According the USDA Web site, FAS is working closely with other government
agencies to rebuild the agricultural infrastructure of the war-torn country and
ensure food security for its people. The agency sent its first agricultural
advisors to Iraq in 2006.

Conley heard about the program through a friend, who also was accepted into the
program. Conley said he got on the Internet to find out more and decided to
apply.

"I noticed that they were looking for USDA employees who had experience as
extension agents and I thought I'd go for it," he said. Even though he wasn't a
USDA employee, they made an exception.

Conley said he's proud to serve.

"I think it will really be a personally enriching experience for me, that
opportunity to make a small difference," he said. "Living on the edge, living
and working under those conditions. Anything I could do here at home, I think it
could be a hundred-fold over there."

ON THE NET

Foreign Agricultural Service http://www.fas.usda.gov.

http://www.chieftain.com. Copyright (c) 2007, The Pueblo Chieftain, Colo.

                         Cape Gazette (Lewes, Delaware)

                                December 8, 2015

King Crop Insurance hosts senate staffers

BYLINE: Cape Gazette staff

LENGTH: 322  words


King Crop Insurance in Georgetown hosted staffers from the U.S. Senate
Agriculture Committee recently. James Glueck, senior policy advisor, and Wayne
Stoskopf, professional staff, from Sen. Pat Roberts' office and Kyle Varner,
policy analyst from Sen. Debbie Stabenow's office visited King Crop Insurance to
learn more about the agent's role in administering the crop insurance program to
farmers on Delmarva.

The 2014 Farm Bill strengthened crop insurance and added provisions to help
beginning farmers. The staffers wanted some direct feedback about the impact of
the farm bill changes on farming in the Delmarva region. Delaware and Maryland
agriculture industries each contribute over $1.5 billion to their state's
economies. The day started with a visit to Evans Farms in Bridgeville. Kevin
Evans is a third-generation farmer producing grain crops and variety of
vegetables. He and his wife Katey run a produce stand on the farm and recently
launched the Frozen Farmer featuring ice cream and sorbet frozen treats. Evans
gave the staffers an overview of his farming operation and how he uses crop
insurance as a part of his risk management plan. Farm and crop insurance
programs are constantly being targeted by budget cutters on Capitol Hill. The
farming community wants the committee to know that limiting or reducing premium
subsidies could have negative effects on the financial condition of farms and on
crop insurance program participation. To limit or cap large farming operation
participation would drive premium costs higher. All three farmers represented
were concerned with the delay in the passing and the complexity of the Farm
Bill. There were no objections to eliminating the direct payment program, the
countercyclical program, or the Average Crop Revenue Election program. However,
the complexity of the programs and the fact the farmer was committing to the
selections for the life of the bill was objectionable.

                             786 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                           Pittsburgh Tribune Review

                            December 5, 2004 Sunday

Let's stop subsidizing farmers

BYLINE: Sara F. Cooper

LENGTH: 538 words


GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass. -- When Secretary of Agriculture-designate Mike Johanns
takes office, his first order of business should be pushing for an end to
America's drastically distorted farm subsidy programs.

Eliminating U.S. farm subsidies would dramatically reduce government spending,
end a program that mostly benefits corporate interests and the wealthy,
strengthen U.S. agriculture, give us needed leverage in international trade
negotiations, and allow the United States to extricate itself from the
embarrassing practice of undermining its own foreign-aid program.

The U.S. made $17 billion in direct government payments to farmers and ranchers
in 2003 -- 32 percent of net farm income. Additional billions came in indirect
assistance, delivered via subsidized loans and insurance, loan guarantees and
tax breaks.

If the farm lobby's argument that such largesse is necessary to preserve the
family farm ever applied, it doesn't now. About 40 percent of all farms receive
government payments. The bulk, however, go to larger farms. While just 7 percent
of all U.S. farms have sales of $250,000 or more, this 7 percent receive almost
half of all government payments.

Eligibility for farm subsidies is determined by crop, not by income or poverty
standards. Growers of corn, wheat, cotton, soybeans and rice receive more than
90 percent of subsidies. Growers of the other 400 domestic crops receive
nothing.

Because crop rather than need determines eligibility, billionaires such as Ted
Turner and corporate behemoths such as Georgia Pacific and Cargill are
subsidized. The struggling little guy usually receives nothing.

Farm subsidies are a barrier to trade, putting the United States at a
disadvantage in negotiations for increased market access in other countries.
Countries are less than eager to remove trade barriers when the United States
won't remove its own.

Subsidies also undermine U.S. efforts to help developing economies. On the one
hand, the United States annually provides billions of dollars in foreign aid to
developing countries. At the same time, U.S. farm subsidies prevent farmers in
those countries from effectively competing in, or with, the U.S. market.

U.S. farmers claim that since their European counterparts receive subsidies,
they need them to compete. Yet New Zealand's prosperous agricultural sector --
which at one time was also addicted to subsidies -- shows this is untrue. New
Zealand farm subsidies are the lowest in the world; its agricultural sector is
growing at a faster pace than the overall economy.

New Zealand did away with most farm subsidies in 1984. It's farmers no longer
make decisions based on government handouts. They regrouped and reorganized.
They cut spending. They found ways to increase the market value of their crops
or switched crops altogether.

New Zealand lost less than 1 percent of its farming businesses. Family farming,
not corporate farming, expanded. New Zealand agriculture was not destroyed; it
changed to meet the demands of the market and thrived.

New Zealand has proved it's possible to eliminate farm subsidies. It's time for
the United States to prove it again.

Sara F. Cooper is a visiting fellow at the American Institute for Economic
Research.

LOAD-DATE: December 5, 2004

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                Copyright 2004 Tribune Review Publishing Company
                              All Rights Reserved

                       St. Paul Pioneer Press (Minnesota)

                            March 29, 2012 Thursday

Largest U.S. corn planting since the 1930s expected

BYLINE: By Tom Webb twebb@pioneerpress.com

SECTION: BREAKING; Business

LENGTH: 571 words


Nothing like $6-a-bushel corn to get farmers' attention.

U.S. farmers expect to plant the greatest corn acreage in 75 years, the U.S.
Department of Agriculture reported Friday, March. 30, as growers rush to cash in
on high prices and seek to rebuild dwindling supplies.

"Minnesota farmers, and all grain farmers in the United States, have had a
couple of good years, and this points the way to another good year," said Edward
Usset, a grain marketing specialist at the University of Minnesota.

The world would welcome a huge crop. Corn supplies are already heading to their
second-tightest on record, which would contribute to rising food prices, stress
for grain users and hardship in poor nations around the globe.

But demand for other crops is tight, too. That tightrope came into sharper focus
Friday when the USDA issued a pair of much-watched grain reports.

The first report showed that farmers expect to plant 95.9 million acres of corn
this spring, 4 percent more than last year. In Minnesota, corn acreage would be
up 7 percent to 8.7 million acres, a record.

But the second report showed that grain stockpiles were even tighter than
expected. That jolted the grain exchanges.

Corn prices rose the 40-cent maximum trading limit in Chicago, due to the second
report, while soybean and wheat prices leapt 46 and 48 cents, respectively,
because the plantings report showed so much farmland going into corn.

"It sure ignited things," Usset said.

The USDA issues its Prospective Plantings report each March, giving the first
official look at what farmers nationwide intend to grow.

U.S. soybean acres are projected at 73.9 million acres, down 1 percent from last
year. In Minnesota, planned soybean acres will fall 3 percent, to 6.9 million
acres. That is fewer acres than the grain trade expected, and Darin Newsom,
senior analyst with Telvent DTN, warned of potential volatility.

"That's a market that could really explode at this point because of a lack of
acres and reduced production in South America and continued strength of Chinese
demand," Newsom said.

U.S. wheat acres are expected to rise by 3 percent, farmers told the USDA, which
should ease rising prices. Except that acreage of high-protein spring wheat -
the type widely grown in the northern plains - is expected to fall 3 percent. In
Minnesota, spring wheat acres are expected to fall 10 percent.

That news lit up the Minneapolis Grain Exchange, where spring wheat soared 48.75
cents a bushel for the May contract Friday, closing at $8.375.

The USDA said the amount of U.S. corn acreage will be the highest since 1937.
Doug Hartwig, state director of the USDA-NASS Minnesota field office, dug up
some figures from that very different era.

The corn yield in 1937 was about 29 bushels an acre. This year, the USDA expects
164 bushels of corn an acre. The soybean yield? There wasn't any - harvesting
soybeans was almost unknown.

In 1937 the corn crop was commonly used right on the farm, to feed the chickens
and other farm animals that nearly all Minnesota farm families had back then.

"It was more about them producing their own food - grown on the farm, eaten on
the farm, and they marketed the excess," Hartwig said.

Back in 1940, Minnesota farmers sold $105 million worth of crops. Today,
Minnesota farmers' bounty goes around the world. In 2011, the value of
Minnesota's crops topped $10 billion.

Tom Webb can be reached at 651-228-5428. Follow him attwitter.com/TomWebbMN .

LOAD-DATE: March 31, 2012

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                            August 12, 2000 Saturday

Corn falls to one-year low on U.S. forecast

BYLINE: Bloomberg News

SECTION: REPORT ON BUSINESS: MONEY & MARKETS; Pg. B21

LENGTH: 389 words


Corn fell to a one-year low yesterday after the U.S. government forecast a
record harvest, while soybeans rose on concern that plants still could be
damaged by dry weather this month, trimming a crop also forecast to be the
biggest ever.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture pegged this fall's corn crop at 10.4 billion
bushels and the soybean crop at 2.99 billion bushels. Arid weather forecast for
the U.S. Midwest could hurt soybean plants as pods fill with beans, while corn
has matured enough to withstand the heat, traders said.

"You can expect your corn crop to get bigger," Dick Loewy, president of
AgResource Co. said at a Chicago Board of Trade news conference. "The jury is
still out on soybeans."

In other markets, cotton rose on concern that dry weather could reduce the size
of those crops. Cattle prices also gained.

Corn for December delivery fell 1.2 per cent on the Chicago Board of Trade. It
was the lowest closing price since July 13, 1999.

Soybeans for November delivery rose 1.1 per cent on the CBOT. It was the highest
closing price since July 27. Prices are down 21 per cent from a 17-month high
reached on May 3.

Cotton rose close to a 32-month high after the government said the U.S. crop
will be smaller than previously expected because of drought in the U.S.
Southwest. Farmers will harvest 19.16 million bales this year, down 0.7 per cent
from its estimate in July.

Cattle prices rose more than 1 per cent on expectations for increased overseas
demand for U.S. beef, after Argentina temporarily suspended exports to the
United States because animals there were exposed to an infectious disease.

Argentina, the world's seventh-largest beef exporter, halted shipments to the
United States after some of its cattle were exposed to Paraguayan cattle with
signs of foot-and-mouth disease. If the export ban is extended to other
countries, beef sales by the United States, the No. 2 exporter after Australia,
could rise.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture also suspended imports of beef from
Argentina, where health officials ordered the slaughter of 3,000 head of cattle.

"Right now we're not willing to speculate on what would be needed for the ban to
be lifted," said Anna Cherry, a spokeswoman for the USDA's Animal and Plant
Health Inspection Service in Washington. "We're at the fact-finding stage."
