                             817 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                               The Deal Pipeline

                           December 13, 2012 Thursday

GrainCorp rejects sweetened Archer bid

BYLINE: by Paul Whitfield

LENGTH: 425 words


Australia's GrainCorp Ltd. on Thursday, Dec. 13, rejected a A$2.78 billion
($2.93 billion) offer from leading shareholder Archer Daniels Midland Co.,
declaring the improved bid too low.  "The increase in the proposed price has not
changed the board's view that ADM's proposal materially undervalues GrainCorp,"
the target said. "GrainCorp's board will be constructive in any dealings in
relation to proposals that have the potential to be in the best interests of
shareholders."  Decatur, Ill.-based Archer Daniels made a nonbinding bid of
A$12.20 per share for GrainCorp on Dec. 3, not including a A$0.35 dividend that
would be paid prior to the deal closing. The offer marked an improvement on a
A$11.75 per share bid that GrainCorp. dismissed on Nov. 15.   Archer Daniels has
amassed a 19.9% stake in GrainCorp, taking a 14.9% holding prior to making its
initial offer. The stake may initially have deterred potential rival suitors
including Bunge Ltd., Cargill Inc. and Louis Dreyfus Holdings BV but could now
facilitate other offers after Archer Daniels raised the prospect of selling up.

"We intend to consider all our options with respect to GrainCorp and our 19.9%
shareholding," spokeswoman Jackie Anderson said in a Thursday statement. "Our
proposal offered more certainty, greater value and immediate realization of
potential future value for GrainCorp shareholders than GrainCorp's standalone
plan."  Archer Daniels' bid valued GrainCorp at about 8.7 times earnings. That
is less than comparable deals this year, which have been pitched at more than
9.5 times earnings.   Analysts suggested a bid of between A$13 and A$14 could
win over GrainCorp's board and secure one of the last midsized targets in a
grain-handling sector that has been reshaped by consolidation over the past
year. Glencore International plc this month won final approval for its C$6
billion ($6 billion) takeover of Canada's Viterra Inc., while Japan's Marubeni
Corp. is still waiting to finalize its $5.6 billion takeover of the U.S.'s No. 3
grain-handling company, Gavilon LLC.  GrainCorp is the biggest grain handler on
Australia's east coast, where it handles about 75% of all grain production, and
about 35% of Eastern Australia's grain exports.    GrainCorp is taking advice
from Credit Suisse Group and Greenhill & Co. LLC. It tapped Gilbert + Tobin for
legal counsel.  Shares in GrainCorp closed Thursday on the Australian exchange
at A$12.30, down less than 1% on their previous close. The stock has gained 60%
in the past year.

DEAL SIZE

                             818 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                                The Toronto Star

                     July 23, 1996, Tuesday, METRO EDITION

Alberta challenges wheat board domination

BYLINE: CP

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. B2

LENGTH: 255 words

DATELINE: EDMONTON


   EDMONTON (CP) - The Alberta government has filed a legal challenge to the
Canadian Wheat Board's domination of the Canadian grain industry and intends to
set up a program to help farmers sell their own crops.

The challenge was filed in the Federal Court of Canada yesterday.

"It's very unfair as far as producers are concerned," said Alberta Agriculture
Minister Walter Paszkowski. "We feel we have to find a way for farmers to
maximize their returns."

Farmers on the Prairies currently must sell their wheat and barley through the
board, although a recent report on the federal agency's future suggested a
compromise for barley sales.

The province is also asking an Alberta court to provide a legal opinion on
whether the province can help farmers bypass the embattled wheat board.

Paszkowski hopes the government will be able to buy grain from farmers by early
next year, truck it across the United States border for them and then sell it
back on the other side.

"The Canadian Wheat Board Act does not specify that the act applies to any
government," Paszkowski said. "On this basis the government of Alberta feels it
could export grain without a (wheat board) licence."

Many Prairie farmers have been charged in the last year with illegally trucking
grain across the border where they say they can earn about $2,500 more per load
than what the wheat board pays.

One farmer is now in jail awaiting a court appearance.

Alberta farmers rejected the wheat board in a plebiscite late last year.

LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1999

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                  Copyright 1996 Toronto Star Newspapers, Ltd.


                             819 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

             February 19, 1992, Wednesday, DAILY: NATIONAL EDITION

Chicago wheat futures drop on rejection of foreign bids

BYLINE: Farm Market News

SECTION: SECTION 2, INVESTMENT AND FINANCE; Pg. 18, FARM COMMODITIES

LENGTH: 362 words

DATELINE: Winnipeg, Man.


Wheat futures nosedived on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday, closing US10
1/4 cents to US15 1/2 cents a bushel lower. The actively traded May contract
finished at US$4.08 1/2, down US15 1/2 cents.

The declines were stimulated in part by reports that the U.S. Agriculture
Department had rejected bids by Egypt and Sri Lanka for subsidized U.S. wheat.

Canada's planned protest of the U.S. Agriculture Department's targetting of the
Philippines for 1.2 million tonnes of subsidized U.S. wheat also encouraged
selling interest.

Losses in deferred wheat prices, however, were offset in part by talk the U.S.
winter wheat crop has been left vulnerable to freeze damage.

Historically low supplies of wheat in the U.S. and the potential for another
round of export credits to the Commonwealth of Independent States also limited
declines in the wheat pit.

Slack farmer deliveries combined with a pickup in export demand from Asian
sources to drive CBOT soybean futures US1 3/4 cents to US5 1/2 cents a bushel
higher. The featured May contract settled at US$5.82 1/2, up US5 1/2 cents.

However, the gains in soybeans were offset by the sharp selloff in wheat and the
current favorable growing conditions for the soybean crop in Brazil.

Strong demand from Japanese interests as well as the gains in CBOT soybeans
propelled canola futures at the Winnipeg Commodity Exchange $1.50 to $2.50 a
tonne higher. The most sought June contract closed at $281.60, up $2.50.

The reluctance of prairie farmers to deliver canola to the elevator system also
fuelled the rally.

Profit-taking and a pickup in farmer deliveries generated the selling that took
WCE rye futures $1 to $2.20 lower. The featured May contract ended at $120.80,
down $1.70.

Weakness in the cash market along with news that U.S. retailers have been
featuring pork products and not beef pushed live and feeder cattle futures at
the Chicago Mercantile Exchange lower.

CME live cattle closed US20 cents to US50 cents a hundredweight lower, with
featured April down US50 cents at US$76.80. Feeders ended US23 cents to US73
cents lower, with April down 52 cents at US$77.20.




LOAD-DATE: November 6, 1997

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: NEWS

                       Copyright 1992 Financial Post Ltd.


                             820 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

              January 30, 1982, Saturday, Late City Final Edition

YEAR'S FALL IN FARM PRICES ENDS

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section 2; Page 29, Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 560 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29


After months of steady decline, prices paid to farmers for raw products rose an
estimated 1.6 percent in January, the first time in more than a year that the
index has risen, the Agriculture Department reported today.

Despite the gain in the index, to 130 from a revised 128 in December, prices
remained 9.7 percent below a year ago, officials said. The sag in farm prices
has put heavy pressure on farmers' income prospects for 1982. But it has also
moderated retail food price increases.

In an effort to strengthen farm prices, Agriculture Secretary John R. Block said
today that far mers who wanted to remain eligible for wheat, corn, rice and
cotton subsidies must reduce plantings this year by 10 pe rcent or 15 percent.
Surpluses in these commodities havehelped to dep ress prices. (Page 37).

The latest figures from the Agriculture Department's Crop Reporting Board
confirmed that the index of prices paid to farmers did not rise in any month in
1981, the first time that had happened since 1933.  The index held steady in
four months but dropped in eight, including a revised decline of 1.5 percent in
December. The last previous gain was that of seven-tenths of 1 percent in
December 1980.

Final figures for December also showed that the parity ratio averaged 61 percent
in 1981, the lowest full-year reading since the 58 percent posted in 1932, in
the depths of the Depression. At 100 percent, the indicator would mean,
theoretically, that farmers had the same buying power they had had in 1910-14.

The preliminary January parity ratio was 56 percent, down from a revised 57
percent in December.  Huge harvests and resulting food surpluses, high interest
rates and continued inflation have bitten deeply into the farm economy.  Lower
grain prices, coupled with the failure of the livestock sector to rebound, have
contributed to the squeeze.

While farm income was declining, the index of prices that farmers pay to meet
expenses rose 2 percent from December, and was 4.1 percent above a year earlier.

In January, officials said, the increase in income was caused mainly by higher
prices for hogs, lettuce, cattle, broilers and tomatoes. But lower prices were
reported for strawberries, wheat, eggs, apples and cotton.

According to the preliminary figures, which are based mostly on mid-month
averages, prices of meat animals rose 3.7 percent from December but still
averaged 7.3 percent below a year ago. Poultry and eggs rose 2.7 percent, but
trailed levels a year earlier by 6.6 percent.

Rise in Vegetable Prices

The vegetable price index rose 14 percent from December, reflecting sharp
increases for lettuce and tomatoes. Lower prices for asparagus, carrots and
green peppers helped offset the gains for the other items. Vegetable prices over
all were 19 percent above a year ago.

Department economists predicted that retail food prices would rise about 7
percent in 1982, compared with a 7.9 percent gain in 1981, which was the
smallest annual increase since 1977.

The January index of 130 reflects a 1977 base price average used for comparison.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Illustrations: graph of farm prices from 8 80 through 1 82

                   Copyright 1982 The New York Times Company


                             821 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

               April 1, 1981, Wednesday, Late City Final Edition

PRICES PAID FARMERS DOWN 1.9% IN MARCH

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section D; Page 13, Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 382 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 31


The prices that farmers receive for their raw products dropped 1.9 percent in
March from February, the fourth consecutive monthly decline, but still were an
average of 10 percent higher than those of a year ago, the Agriculture
Department said today. Officials said that lower prices for hogs, cattle,
soybeans, wheat, cotton and corn led the decline.

Prices were higher for oranges, onions, potatoes, tomatoes, lettuce and snap
beans, the department's Crop Reporting Board said.  Prices that farmers pay to
meet expenses rose seven-tenths of 1 percent from February and were an average
of 9.4 percent higher than those of a year ago. Prices were higher chiefly for
family living items, fuels, fertilizers, farm chemicals and farm equipment, the
report said.

According to the preliminary March figures - which are based mostly on midmonth
averages - prices of meat animals as a group dropped 3.2 percent from February.
The index was 6.5 percent below that of a year earlier.

Soybeans and Cottonseed Off

The March price index for oil-bearing crops - which include soybeans and
cottonseed - declined 4.4 percent from February but still was 28 percent higher
than index figures a year ago.

But vegetable prices at the farm rose 4.3 percent from a month earlier, with
higher prices for onions, tomatoes and lettuce accounting for most of it, the
report said. Prices for sweet corn, asparagus and carrots dropped. The overall
index was up 53 percent compared with March figures a year ago.

Fruit prices over all rose 12 percent from February, with oranges, strawberries,
pears and grapefruit accounting for most of the increase.

Department economists continued to predict that retail food prices would go up
an average of 10 to 15 percent this year, compared with an 8.6 percent increase
in 1980, the smallest one-year gain since 1977.

Measuring specific prices, the report said that cattle averaged $57.40 per 100
pounds, compared with $58.70 in February and $64.30 in March 1980; wheat
averaged $3.93 a bushel, compared with $4.17 in February and $3.64 a year ago,
and eggs were 60.8 cents a dozen, compared with 62.6 cents in February and 55
cents a year ago.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1981 The New York Times Company


                             822 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                         Telegraph Herald (Dubuque, IA)

                             April 24, 2005 Sunday

Harkin: Use technology to ensure feed quality; Durbin also expresses concern
about protection from mad cow disease

BYLINE: JOHN EVERLY

SECTION: Agriculture; Pg. b4

LENGTH: 745 words


The federal government is doing a better job of protecting us from mad cow
disease, but there is room for improvement, according to a Government
Accountability Office investigation.

Sens. Tom Harkin, D-Iowa, and Richard Durbin, D-Ill., requested the
investigation of the Food and Drug Administration's enforcement of its
ruminant-to-ruminant feed ban. The GAO report, released in February, found that
the FDA could not say how many plants were actually in compliance with feed ban
rules and lacked testing procedures to detect prohibited material in animal
feed.

Feeding protein material from one ruminant to another is believed to be the
major route by which BSE, commonly known as mad cow disease, is transmitted
among animals.

"The FDA ruminant-to-ruminant feed ban is the linchpin of the U.S. strategy for
preventing the spread of BSE to U.S. cattle herds," Harkin said. "Yet the GAO
found substantial shortcomings in enforcing the ban, including failure to
monitor feed plants adequately and to test animal feed for prohibited ruminant
byproducts. Common sense tells us the best way to measure compliance is to
sample feed to make sure it does not contain ruminant byproducts. Despite what
the FDA asserts, technology is available for testing feed to detect ruminant
byproducts. The FDA should use this technology."

Durbin said: "The U.S. food supply is still the safest in the world, but we must
take the steps necessary to keep it that way. This GAO report is one more link
in a long chain of evidence that the threat of BSE is not being taken seriously
enough."

The ruminant byproducts feed ban has been in place since 1997. The FDA requires
feed companies handling both prohibited ruminant byproducts and ruminant feed to
keep these materials separate.

Harkin said the GAO report shoots holes in the FDA's claim of 99 percent
compliance with the ban because only a fraction of feed plants are inspected.
The FDA does not count actual violations of the feed rules if the plants
involved are later found in compliance, Harkin said.

The GAO also noted that because feed plants are not required to register with
the FDA, not all plants that make animal feed and are subject to FDA inspection
have even been identified or inspected.

It should be noted, though, that there are other safeguards against BSE. While
the FDA looks at feed, the U.S. Department of Agriculture has safeguards on the
other end of the production chain. Since the program's inception on June 1,
2004, the department has tested more than 322,000 suspect cattle for BSE, with
no animals testing positive. The lone BSE case in the United States was
discovered in a dairy cow of Canadian origin in December 2003.

A copy of the GAO report is available at www.gao.gov.

The United States is losing farmers. Farming takes enormous amounts of capital,
which is exposed to a sizable amount of risk. Profit margins continue to shrink,
requiring more land and more production per farm to sustain a farming business.
For many young people, farming does not look like a promising career choice.

To turn this trend around, the Churches' Center for Land and People, based in
Sinsinawa, Wis., is working to link prospective farmers with placement in
startup farming enterprises. The center is helping recruit religious properties
and communities to place new and transitioning farmers on the land.

The center produced a 25-minute documentary called "CRAFTing Farmers for People
and the Land," to promote new farmer training and placement efforts in Illinois
and Wisconsin.

"Our goal in this effort is to transition young farmers and growers into types
of farming that respect life - their life, all life," said Tony Ends, Churches'
Center for Land and People director. "We want to do this through support of
churches, communities and congregations."

The Churches' Center for Land and People partners with the CSA Learning Center
in Caledonia, Ill., to train aspiring farmers in environmentally friendly
sustainable farming practices. Some interns in the program have never been on a
farm before. Others with farm backgrounds want to return to farming but not
through the conventional bulk commercial production.

For more information, contact Tony Ends at the Churches' Center for Land and
People, 608/748-4411, ext. 805, or 608/897-4288.

Everly, a Telegraph Herald reporter, was farm director of Dubuque radio station
KDTH for nearly 10 years. His e-mail address is jeverly@wcinet.com.

LOAD-DATE: April 24, 2005

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                  Copyright 2005 Woodward Communications, Inc.


                             823 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                         Cold Spring Record (Minnesota)

  This content, including derivations, may not be stored or distributed in any
  manner, disseminated, published, broadcast, rewritten or reproduced without
                      express, written consent from STPNS

                               September 10, 2013

This Business Of Farming

BYLINE: Cold Spring Record staff

LENGTH: 480  words


USDA says 2013 will go down as a great year for farmers and their incomes will
be at record levels.

Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack says the record income provides further
evidence that agriculture has "worked hard to recover from an historic drought
and other disasters" and the report is a "further sign of the positive momentum
they have achieved over the past five years."

Much of their optimism is based on healthy balance sheets for most farmers, who
have put a lot of effort into becoming more efficient and financially viable.
Farm sector assets, debt, and equity are all forecast to increase in 2013 and
according to USDA chief economist Joe Glauber, "increases in farm asset values
are expected to continue to exceed increases in farm debt, netting a record high
for farm equity."

Again this year, we saw farmers paying cash for land and equipment rather than
borrowing from the bank, continuing the trend Glauber is referring to, as asset
values outpace increases in farm debt.

As for the lower corn and soybean prices, Glauber says they will be offset
"because big gains in chicken and milk sales will power a five percent increase
in the value of livestock, dairy and poultry production this year." Milk export
sales alone are expected to be up 17% with combined livestock sales up 5%.

Not to take away from such an optimistic forecast, but I wonder if it might be
too early in the game to be forecasting the second highest inflation-adjusted
income since 1973. Especially when farmers are faced with record high production
expenses, sharply lower commodity prices along with crops that are looking rough
and way behind in development.

What makes farmers question the report is the assumption that USDA has a good
handle on the size of this year's crops. The agency hasn't had the best record
in pegging crop size and last year they took a lot of heat for over estimating
the corn crop in its August report which was followed by several downward
adjustments as actual yields started coming in. USDA's Statistics Division
blamed the hot dry weather at the end of summer for the need for adjustments.
Much the same situation we are facing this year.

Unlike early season reports, that are based on statistical models, the August
report uses actual farmer input, which in a normal year would add accuracy to
the report. But with crops running so far behind, even the farmer has trouble
putting a number on their potential yields and the quality of the crop this
year.

While it's good to know the ag economy is doing well, it may be a bit premature
to be declaring 2013 as a year of record income for farmers when the combine
hasn't even left the shed. That, and the fact no-one knows when the first frost
is going to hit which will be the real "game changer."

...just say (Your thoughts? email me at: jussayn@live.com) (c) Copyright 2013
Strom Communications All rights reserved.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                         Tasmanian Country (Australia)

                            February 1, 2013 Friday
                                  1 - Edition

US visitors put Tassie farms on map

BYLINE: ROGER HANSON

SECTION: Pg. 4

LENGTH: 451 words


TASMANIA is becoming a haven for visiting American agricultural tours.

Specialist agricultural technical tour operator Quadrant Australia is bringing a
study group of 24 American farmers to Tasmania next week.

The farmers are from throughout the United States and will look at some of the
diverse range of farming operations here.

The visit follows hard on the heels of a study group led by Dr Paul Read, who
brought nine students from the University of Nebraska's Institute of Agriculture
and Natural Resources on a tour of vineyards and horticultural enterprises.

Well-known rural identity and Tasmanian Country columnist John Rich will manage
the tour to Tasmania for Quadrant Australia.

Mr Rich has been closely involved with Tasmanian agriculture for more than 30
years.

In this time he has led and developed rural study tours within Australia and
overseas.

In addition to inbound groups, Quadrant Australia is planning more than 25
outbound tours this year covering a wide and interesting range of agricultural
activities and destinations.

Mr Rich said group study tours like the latest one provides US farmers,
producers and other industry stakeholders the opportunity to gain an
understanding of both the farming industry and lifestyle in regional Australia.

The American contingent will arrive in Devonport on Monday evening.

The group is travelling under the Farm Progress banner, which operates four of
the United States' agricultural industry's largest annual events, including the
Farm Progress Show, the country's largest outdoor farm show, which attracts more
than 100,000 people.

The Farm Progress Group also publishes 23 regional and national farming and
cropping publications and owns a broadcast network, Farm Progress America.

One of its broadcasters, influential US agricultural journalist Max Armstrong,
who has hosted his own radio and television shows for more than 30 years, is
leading the tour.

``His broadcasts are heard by millions of farmers and consumers through a
network of 165 radio stations,'' Mr Rich said.

``This will be a great opportunity to profile Tasmania to a huge audience.''

Mr Rich said the group would travel from Devonport to Gunns Plains on Tuesday
for a visit to local farms under the guidance of Colin Wing, then experience the
attractions of Wing's Wildlife Park, before going to Launceston late in the
afternoon.

``On Wednesday morning we will be visiting Woolmers Estate at Longford to learn
about some of the early settlement history,'' Mr Rich added.

``And in the afternoon will visit Roderic O'Connor's historic 17,200ha
Connorville Station, at Cressy.''

On Thursday the group heads to Hobart to inspect Houston's Farm at Richmond and
look at production of leafy salads.

                             825 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                     The Press (Christchurch, New Zealand)

                            June 9, 2004, Wednesday

Farming boom predicted

BYLINE: MORGAN Jon

SECTION: BUSINESS Pg. 2; BUSINESS DAY; C

LENGTH: 405 words


The Agriculture Ministry is forecasting a farming boom -- but only if the
Treasury's guess of a falling exchange rate is right.

Ministry economists say the value of all agriculture exports will rise a massive
20 per cent during the next three years, mainly because of Treasury's "working
assumption" that the kiwi dollar will fall against the United States currency.

But in case the Treasury has it wrong, the ministry has included for the first
time two other predictions -- based on higher or lower exchange rates -- in its
annual situation and outlook report.

"You can't forecast what the exchange rate will be. Their guess is as good as
anyone's," said senior policy analyst Tony Wharton when asked if treasury had
the ministry's full confidence. The ministry wanted to give people "a bit more
of an understanding" of the likely levels farm export prices could go between
and had decided to poll seven other economic institutions and add their picks to
the mix.

The top four's average of a kiwi dollar worth US54c and the bottom four's US59c
were then used to give alternative forecasts, though the ministry kept with
Treasury's pick of US55c for its main report. The same exercise was applied to
four other currencies.

The ministry's "baseline" forecast of a $ 20.2 billion return from pastoral
agriculture, horticulture and forestry exports by the year ending June 2007 will
return farming to the boom year of 2002 when the kiwi stayed below US45c.

The largest contributors to this will be dairy, up 25% to $ 7.59b, and forestry,
up 41% to $ 3.89b, both benefiting from rising prices at the same time as they
are producing bigger volumes of milk and lumber.

Wool's export value is projected to rise 4% on higher prices, while
horticulture's worth is expected to leap by about 30%, mainly driven by a 300%
increase in the amount of wine being exported.

Meat exports should firm 1%, as higher prices for lamb and beef are offset by
lower beef volumes.

Within sectors the outlook for prices is variable. Dairy produce is projected to
generally rise, with the exception of butter, and so are prices for venison,
velvet, apples and wine. However, beef, lamb, wool and kiwifruit prices are
projected to fall in 2004-05 and then recover. Milksolids prices are expected to
fall to 2005-06 then recover.

Production is expected to rise over the next three years, expect for beef,
velvet and venison.

                         Telegraph Herald (Dubuque, IA)

                               May 1, 2005 Sunday

Agriculture Briefs

BYLINE: Telegraph Herald Staff

SECTION: Agriculture; Pg. b8

LENGTH: 475 words

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, Iowa


Goat weigh-in slated in Delaware County

The 2005 Delaware County 4-H and FFA goat weigh-in will be held from 9 to 11
a.m. Saturday in the Sheep Barn at the Delaware County Fairgrounds.  All market
goat entries in the 2005 Delaware County Fair Meat Goat Show must be weighed in
and ear-tagged at this site.

There is a $1 fee for each animal. Exhibitors are asked to bring correct change.

For more information on the market goat weigh-in, contact the Delaware County
Extension office at 563/927-4201.

Apprenticeships offered on several Iowa farms

Practical Farmers of Iowa will offer summer apprenticeships on several Iowa
farms through the "Learning the Farmer Way" program.

Students may apply to work on these farms and learn a wide variety of farming
and marketing skills. The operations range from grain and livestock farms to
vegetable and community-supported agriculture farms.

Applicants should contact apprenticeship coordinator Kamyar Enshayan at
319/273-7575.

Foremost Farms giving patronage refunds

BARABOO, Wis. - Foremost Farms USA recently issued $23.9 million in 2005
patronage refunds.

Strong dairy markets in 2004 combined with the business decisions of prior years
helped steer the cooperative to a strong financial performance, the company
said.

The cooperative operates 20 manufacturing facilities and one milk transfer
station for its 3,600 dairy farmer-members in Wisconsin, Minnesota, Iowa,
Illinois, Indiana, Michigan and Ohio. Foremost Farms employed 1,487 people as of
Dec. 31.

Candidates sought

ELKADER, Iowa - The Clayton County Dairy Promotion Committee is seeking
candidates for the Clayton County Dairy Princess, Little Miss Squirt, and Junior
Dairyman contests. Deadline is May 10. Judging will be held at 8 p.m. May 31 at
Herbster Hall, Peace United Church of Christ, Elkader.

For more information, call the Clayton County Extension Office in Elkader at
563/245-1451.

Crowning of the 2005 Dairy Princess, Little Miss Squirt and Junior Dairyman will
be held in conjunction with the Clayton County Dairy Banquet on June 3 at
Johnson's Reception Hall in Elkader.

Judging video available

"Oral Reasons for the 2004 Hoard's Dairyman Cow Judging Contest" is a resource
for coaches of 4-H youth dairy judging teams, high school vo-ag instructors, or
youth looking to enhance their oral reasons skill levels.

The 18-minute video features six University of Wisconsin-Madison dairy judging
students giving sample reasons based on classes from the 2004 Hoard's Dairyman
Cow Judging Contest.

The videos are $30 per copy. Tapes can be ordered from UW-Madison Extension
through e-mail at tjhalbach@wisc.edu. Indicate if additional picture sheets are
needed when placing an order. The tape also is on deposit and available through
the Cooperative Extension Media Collection at 800/353-3514.

                             827 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                              Journal of Commerce

                          September 7, 1989, Thursday

US MEAT EXPORTERS EYE PACIFIC RIM

BYLINE: PAULA L. GREEN; Journal of Commerce Staff

SECTION: EXPORTS, Pg. 4A

LENGTH: 298 words


U.S. exporters of red meat are targeting markets throughout the Pacific Rim with
the help of a $ 9 million grant from the U.S. Department of Agriculture.

The U.S. Meat Export Federation program is using almost 40 percent of the funds
to try to expand the Japanese market for beef, pork and lamb products and about
25 percent to target markets in the China-Pacific region, from South Korea to
Singapore, said Philip Seng, the federation's senior vice president of
nternational programs.

The federation is one of about 50 associations that will receive funds through
the Targeted Export Assistance program, which is run by the department's foreign
agriculture service.

The $ 200 million appropriation for the 1990 fiscal year is the last in the
five-year program, which was authorized under the 1985 Farm Bill. The program
was designed to help commodity producers that were facing unfair trade practices
in foreign countries, a department official said.

This year, for example, the American Soybean Association will receive $ 11.5
million and the California Walnut Commission $ 8 million.

Mr. Seng said U.S. meat exporters want to be ready when Japan's meat market
opens up in 1991. "Right now the market is very controlled," he said. ''As
quotas are lifted and the distribution system is simplified, we want to expand."

U.S. red-meat producers ship about $ 1 billion worth of their output, or 70
percent of their exports, to Japan each year, he said. Before the European
Community banned imports of meats treated with hormones, the 12 EC nations
imported about $ 250 million worth of beef, pork and lamb products, he said.

The Denver-based federation represents a broad range of players in the meat
industry, from cattle feeders to members of the packing industry.

                            The Press (Christchurch)

                             July 26, 1999, Monday

Envoy role for farm chief

BYLINE: BAILEY Malcolm  POLSON Alistair

SECTION: NEWS; National; Pg. 2; NEWS

LENGTH: 306 words


WELLINGTON -- Outgoing Federated Farmers president Malcolm Bailey has been
appointed as a "roving ambassador" for New Zealand agriculture.

Prime Minister Jenny Shipley announced the appointment at the Federated Farmers
annual conference in New Plymouth yesterday when Mr Bailey stepped down after a
three-year term.

Mrs Shipley said Mr Bailey had been appointed as a Special Trade Envoy for New
Zealand with ambassadorial status.

"His role will be to promote and defend New Zealand's agricultural trading
interests in such key organisational export markets as the European Union, the
United States and Japan," she said.

Mr Bailey would meet overseas farmers and farm groups, attend conferences and
speak to the international media.

"His role will be vital in engaging groups such as the US sheep farmers and
European farming lobbies on the benefits of free and fair trade in agricultural
products," Mrs Shipley said.

"Mr Bailey is widely respected as someone capable of promoting agricultural
trade.

"He is able to speak from experience about the benefits of the New Zealand
approach to non- subsidisation of agriculture and to reflect the view of the New
Zealand farmer overseas."

Wanganui sheep and beef farmer Alistair Polson was elected the new president of
Federated Farmers.

Mr Polson had been a vice- president for the past four years and is the
federation's spokesman on ACC, health and safety, animal welfare and education.

The 43-year-old Massey University graduate will follow in the footsteps of his
grandfather, Sir William Polson, who is a past president.

His vice-presidential associate for the past four years, Tom Lambie, a South
Canterbury dairy farmer, was re-elected for another term. --NZPA

--------------------

CAPTION:

Malcolm Bailey

                             829 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                        Western Morning News (Plymouth)

                                 April 28, 1999

Supplement: Farming

SECTION: Supplement: Farming

LENGTH: 409 words


The Beef Wars are heating up after a recommendation by the European Union's
Commission College to ban all imports of United States beef from June 15. This
follows the discovery of residues of banned growth hormones in 258 samples of
supposedly hormone-free beef. The Standing Veterinary Committee will consider
the proposals this week. From May 13, the EU ban is "illegal" under World Trade
Organisation rules, but the test results are part of the EU's scientific report
designed to vindicate its continuing ban. The full reports will be published
later this year. Commission officials suggest the poor controls over
"hormone-free" beef will strengthen the EU's argument for the ban to remain. The
US has agreed to investigate the problem.

- The European Commission is drawing up plans to force member states to increase
surveillance on BSE in sheep and goats, and to implement scrapie eradication
schemes. The Scientific Steering Committee might revive the SRM regulations that
farm ministers failed to agree last year.

- MEPs will have more say in future CAP spending. They will be able to amend
spending on the rural development regulation measures, including early
retirement schemes, afforestation and agri -environment schemes. The RDR budget
will be agreed annually.

- Farm Commissioner Franz Fischler has admitted that the Berlin agreement on CAP
reform has increased the risk of agricultural surpluses and undermined the
European position in the next round of WTO talks.

- There is widespread disagreement over whether quotas should end in 2006 or be
extended to 2008, as part of the dairy sector reforms. The London Club (Sweden,
Italy, Denmark and UK) still favours ending quotas after 2006, while other
member states argue for an extension. Calls for a mid-term review for the dairy
sector in 2003 are backed by the London Club, the German presidency and the
Netherlands.

- The OECD Agricultural Outlook report predicts a slow recovery for world market
prices for most commodities as the economies in the Far East and Latin America
recover. However, it warns that the CAP reforms will not help EU countries to
trade freely on world markets.

- The Swiss federal environment agency has refused two applications for testing
GMOs in Switzerland, although imports of GM products will not be affected. In
America Cargill and two other maize exporters have decided to avoid GM maize
varieties that have not been approved in the EU.

                            Waikato Times (Hamilton)

                             July 14, 1998, Tuesday

Women swap views

SECTION: FARMING Pg. 14

LENGTH: 155 words


Cambridge dairy farmers Hilary Webber and Willy Geck were among 1200 rural women
from 50 countries at the second international conference on women in agriculture
in Washington DC last week.

Hosted by the US Agriculture Department and sponsored by President Bill
Clinton's agency for women, the conference explored free trade and marketing
issues and rural networks. Presenters included US Agriculture Secretary Dan
Glickman.

Mrs Webber, a New Zealand Dairy Group director, said only a Wrightson travel
sponsorship had made it possible to present to the conference evidence on the
dairy product tariffs New Zealand pays to the US Government and on other trade
barriers. She said the sponsorship also meant she could meet Australian rural
women's networks.

These groups encouraged women in agriculture to realise their potential and to
support other women who want to be part of decision-making beyond the farm gate.

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

                   December 2, 1992, Wednesday, DAILY EDITION

U.S. crop glut to force increase in subsidies

BYLINE: Financial Post news services

SECTION: SECTION 1, NEWS; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 388 words

DATELINE: Washington, DC


The U.S., which last month threatened a trade war to get Europe to pledge to
trim its farm subsidies, will spend more on subsidies next year to offset a
price-depressing crop glut, officials said yesterday.

At their annual outlook conference, Agriculture Department officials also
forecast ''fairly strong'' U.S. agricultural exports of US$41.5 billion in 1993
and a third year of modest increases in grocery prices.

''If we look out to 1993, crop and livestock producers are gearing up again for
large production,'' said James Donald, chairman of the department's World
Agricultural Outlook Board.

Donald did not suggest a figure for U.S. farm subsidies, but the department has
estimated the farm program will cost US$13.1 billion in fiscal 1993, compared
with US$10.56 billion in fiscal 1992, which ended Sept. 30.

In late November, U.S. and EC officials settled two key trade disputes. The
agreements call for less EC land to be devoted to oilseed production and for
both sides to seek a world trade pact that will reduce the use of export
subsidies and trade-distorting subsidies to farmers.

Agriculture Secretary Edward Madigan said the U.S. will be just as stubborn in
world trade negotiations in seeking access to rice markets in Japan as it was in
its dealings with the European Community.

''This is very important to us,'' Madigan said at a news conference following a
speech in which he lauded exports and free trade as building stones of U.S. farm
prosperity.

Farm output is up 5% this year from 1991, including a record 9.3 billion-bushel
corn crop.

The U.S. announcement came against a backdrop of continuing protests by French
farmers to European farm trade concessions.

About 50,000 demonstrators gathered around a bonfire in Strasbourg's Place de
Bordeaux yesterday to rally for a six-kilometre march in one of the largest ever
pan-European labor demonstrations.

Every EC member state was represented, as were several outside the community,
including Switzerland, Austria and South Korea. Japanese rice farmers, looking
jet-lagged, protested against attempts to open their protected market.

By far the biggest non-French presence was an 8,000-strong delegation of German
farmers, some of whom clashed with police in a failed attempt to storm the
European Parliament.

GRAPHIC:  Photo: French farmers surround a bonfire at the start of a mass rally
protesting the U.S.-EC trade accord. Thousands of farmers from across Europe and
as far away as Japan marched yesterday in Strasbourg, France, the seat of the
European Parliament.

                        The Othello Outlook (Washington)

  This content, including derivations, may not be stored or distributed in any
  manner, disseminated, published, broadcast, rewritten or reproduced without
                      express, written consent from STPNS

                               February 27, 2014

Preserving farmland may have consequences for taxpayers

BYLINE: The Othello Outlook staff

LENGTH: 775  words


OLYMPIA - A, proposed change to a law aimed at preserving farmland and open
space could result in higher taxes for some Washington property owners.

House Bill 2306 would expand a tax classification on land actively used for
agriculture, timber production or undeveloped open space. While property tax is
generally assessed on the market value of a parcel, the state's Open Space
Taxation Act allows land to be taxed at a lower rate based on its current use,
such as farming,

Under the current law, if a farming operation is 20 acres or more, the parcels
'.must be contiguous in order to be eligible for the lower tax classification.

The bill proposes to take out the "contiguous" stipulation, opening up this tax
classification to farms that have multiple parcels totaling 20 acres or more but
aren't necessarily touching each other.

"It's the preservation of farmland ... that is my ultimate goal," Rep. Kristine
Lytton, D-Anacortes, the bill's primary sponsor, said at a Jan. 21 hearing
before the House Finance Committee.

Allen Rozema, executive director of Skagitonians to Preserve Farmland, said the
bill could help preserve farmland and open space that is not currently, eligible
for the lower tax rate.

"This is an innovative and unique approach to keeping agriculture viable in
Washington state," he said. "This approach and similar approaches need to
continue to be pursued by the Legislature. It helps to elevate the preservation
of farming to the same level as our state's other critical resources."

Farming is an essential part of Washington's economy. The Washington Department
of Agriculture valued Washington's agricultural production in 2012 at $9.89
billion, exceeding 2011 figures by 6 percent and setting a new record.

Lytton said the bill is aimed at preserving farms with small, non-contiguous
parcels.

In Washington, the average farm size decreased by about 12.5 percent from 2003
to 2012, but the number of farms has increased by about 7 percent in the same
time period, according to a report from the United States Department of
Agriculture. The number of small farms is still increasing, Rozema said.

It's hard to know how much of a tax shift could result from allowing more
parcels to qualify for the lower tax rate, as there's no. estimate of exactly
how much land could be eligible, Yakima County Assessor Dave Cook said.

Some county assessors are concerned that extending the current-use tax rate to
more land could mean higher tax bills for other property owners.

Each county collects a specific amount of property-tax revenue, with the total
amount spread across all taxable properties.

When some properties are assessed at a lower rate, the other properties in the
taxing district must make up the difference. Depending on how much property is
eligible to be assessed at the lower agricultural rate, the increase in property
taxes paid by others in the district could be significant.

Cook said the legislation could result in a $70 million loss of assessed
property value in Yakima County because more farmland would be assessed at its
current use rather than market value. Property owners with a decrease in
assessed property value will likely pay less in taxes, a difference that would
have to be made up by other taxpayers in the county.

"The tax-shift implications are significant when you go on a statewide basis,"
Cook said.

Before the finance committee voted on a proposed substitute bill Feb. 6, Rep.
Terry Nealey, R-Dayton, suggested the Legislature conduct a study to assess the
impact of such a change and the possible tax shift.

The bill not only addresses the size of farming parcels but also other scenarios
common to farming operations.

In one particular case, for example, a farmer may grow grain to feed livestock
they sell. The land used to grow the feed is not directly generating income if
the grain is not being sold. Therefore, under current state law, that parcel of
land used to grow the feed would not qualify for the tax reduction. This bill
would change that.

The substitute bill, which was adopted by the finance committee Feb. 6 by a vote
of 10 to 3, further clarifies specific language in the original bill. It states
individual parcels that have been combined to qualify for this tax
classification do not have to individually generate income as long as the whole
farming operation does.

The substitute bill further outlines that if a parcel of at least five acres is
leased to a farmer and that farmer has other land that qualifies for the lower
tax rate, the leased land would also be eligible.

An application process would still be required for land to be considered for the
current-use tax classification.

                    Farmers Independent (Bagley, Minnesota)

  This content, including derivations, may not be stored or distributed in any

                      express, written consent from STPNS

                                  July 4, 2012

The national search for the faces of farming and ranching is on!;
U.S. Farmers & Ranchers Alliance Kicks Off Nationwide Search to Find Top
Ambassadors of Agriculture

BYLINE: Farmers Independent staff

LENGTH: 536  words


LOS ANGELES - When it comes to today's agriculture, there are many examples of
great farmers and ranchers all over the country doing wonderful things to bring
food to the table for those around the world. But few of those farmers and
ranchers are recognizable by consumers, mainstream media and influencers. In
fact, the pictures and perceptions of farmers and ranchers often do not match
reality.

USFRA wants to change that. USFRA announced it is looking for the "Faces of
Farming and Ranching" to help put a real face on agriculture and shine a light
on the heart, personalities and values that are behind today's food.

"USFRA has started a movementtobringmore farmers and ranchers together to answer
people's questions about how their food is grown and raised," said Bob Stallman,
chairman of USFRA and president of the American Farm Bureau Federation. "Many
voices are leading conversations about food - and often leaving the people who
grow and raise our food out. We need to find the best people to be part of these
conversations and represent the real farmers and ranchers of America."

USFRA is looking for standout fanners and! ranchers who are proud of what they
do, eager to share their stories of continuous improvement with others and who
are actively involved today in sharing those stories. Farmers and ranchers who
raise a variety of foods differently, at differing scale and in all areas of the
country are encouraged to apply, as it is important to show American agriculture
and all of its diversity.

Entries will be accepted through Sept. 8, at www.FoodDialogues.com. Ten to 15
finalists will be announced at the November2012FoodDialogues event in New York
City. This national announcement will open a public online voting period where
visitors can vote for their favorite candidates. Those votes will be factored
into the decision to determine "The Faces of Farming and Ranching."

Winners will be announced in early January 2013 based on votes and the
recommendation of a panel of judges.

The public will get to know the USFRA "Faces" winners through national media
interviews, advertising and public appearances. For their time, they will
receive a $10,000 stipend as well as a $5,000 donation to their preferred
agriculture-related or local charity in their name.

"We want America to see the real faces of farming and ranching," said Stallman.
"This is an excellent way for those within agriculture to step up and showcase
to the country what these hard-working farmers and ranchers are really all
about."

Entrants will be required to submit an online application and include a home
video of less than three minutes that describes themselves and their farm or
ranch. More details are available at www.FoodDialogues. com.

U.S. Farmers & Ranchers Alliance (USFRA) is a newly formed alliance consisting
of a wide range of prominent farmer and rancher led organizations and
agricultural partners. This marks the first time agricultural groups at the
national, regional and state levels have collaborated to lead the dialogue and
answer Americans' questions about how we raise our food - while being stewards
of the environment, responsibly caring for our animals and maintaining strong
businesses and communities.

LOAD-DATE: October 27, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Agriculture

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: FRM

                             SmallTownPapers, Inc.

                             834 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

                     October 9, 1992, Friday, DAILY EDITION

Corn futures hit lows ahead of crop report

BYLINE: Farm Market News

SECTION: SECTION 2, INVESTMENT AND FINANCE; Pg. 18, Farm Commodities

LENGTH: 359 words

DATELINE: Winnipeg, Man.


Corn futures hit new contract lows on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday on
concerns that a U.S. Agriculture Department report would show 1992 U.S.
production at its highest level since 1985.

Expectations for an increase in the 1992 U.S. soybean crop also kept those
futures on the defensive throughout the session.

After the close, the department reported U.S. 1992 corn production would total
8.938 billion bushels while U.S. soybean output would be 2.108 billion bushels.

Floor traders' initial reaction was that CBOT corn futures would open unchanged
to US1 cents lower today while soybeans would open US1 cents to US2 cents a
bushel higher.

At yesterday's close, CBOT corn futures ranged US1 1/4 cents to US1 3/4 cents
lower with most-traded December settling at US$2.09, down US1 3/4 cents. CBOT
soybeans ranged US 1/2 cents higher to US 3/4 cents lower. Most-active November
ended at US$5.30, down US 3/4 cents.

CBOT wheat futures finished US1 cents to US3 1/4 cents a bushel lower with
featured December settling at US$3.40, down US3 1/4 cents.

Further delays in a commodity breakdown for US$500 million in U.S. export
credits for Russia weighed on wheat futures with additional selling prompted by
continued speculation that China bought one million tonnes of Canadian wheat
rather than U.S. wheat. The U.S. Agriculture Department's report was considered
neutral to friendly for CBOT wheat futures.

Meanwhile, a pickup in exporter demand and smaller crop prospects helped oilseed
futures at the Winnipeg Commodity Exchange post good gains yesterday.

At the close, WCE canola ranged $2.30 to $3 a tonne higher. Most-sought-after
November finished at $297.30, up $3. WCE flaxseed ended $3.10 to $4.50 higher
with most-traded December settling at $264.50, up $3.70.

A pickup in U.S. consumer demand helped live hog and pork belly futures at the
Chicago Mercantile Exchange close higher. CME live hogs closed US25 cents to
US65 cents a hundredweight higher with most-active December up US52 cents at
US$43.72. CME pork bellies ended up to US65 cents higher. Featured February was
up US65 cents at US$39.52.

                             835 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                           September 27, 2016 Tuesday

Monsanto to Make 41.6 Million Investment in Developing System to Help
Agriculture Quantify Greenhouse Gas Reductions

LENGTH: 593  words

DATELINE: New York



 Jackson: Growing Mississippi has issued the following news release:



  The U.S. Department of Agriculture - Natural Resources Conservation Service
(USDA-NRCS) recently awarded the National Corn Growers Association (NCGA) and
its Soil Health Partnership (SHP) a $1 million Conservation Innovation Grant
(CIG) to help farmers better understand and adopt farming practices that help
reduce climate change impacts.





 Monsanto announced today it also intends to make an additional investment of
$1.6 million in this collaborative effort to help provide expertise, tools and
needed resources to further develop a system that will help verify and quantify
greenhouse gas reductions from carbon smart farming practices.



 USDA's CIG program fosters innovation in conservation tools and strategies to
improve things like on-farm energy and fertilizer use as well as market-based
strategies to improve water quality or mitigate climate change.



 "Climate change is a global challenge facing the entire planet and agriculture
has the opportunity to be a huge part of the solution. We're honored to be
partnering with NCGA and the SHP on this grant from USDA-NRCS. Together, we can
bring focus and resources to help identify ways that modern agriculture helps
drive sustainability," said Brett Begemann, Monsanto President and Chief
Operating Officer. "We look forward to continued collaboration with farmers and
forward-thinking industry partners who are leading the way in making greenhouse
gas reduction a reality on the farm."



 Monsanto, in conjunction with the CIG project partners (NCGA, AgSolver, Applied
GeoSolutions, DNDC-ART, Climate Smart Group and CropGrowers) will develop a
framework that draws on existing greenhouse gas modeling science, emerging
verification technologies (satellite data), and proven precision business
planning methods to drive adoption of conservation practices and validate that
farmers are helping achieve greenhouse gas reductions.



 "To significantly scale up greenhouse gas mitigation practices, a sustainable
agriculture systems approach is needed that is simpler and more cost-effective
for the farmer," said Michael Lohuis, Ph.D., Monsanto's Director of Ag
Environmental Strategy. "The system being developed will help remove barriers to
confirming adoption of best practices and to quantify the benefits these
innovative farm practices can have to air, soil and water quality."



 Monsanto is committed to sharing key learnings with farmers around the world to
scale up adoption of carbon neutral agriculture practices. The company is
working closely with farmers on sustainable agriculture systems and has pledged
to make its own operations carbon neutral by 2021.



 As part of that commitment, last month the company released a scientific report
titled, "Charting a Path to Carbon Neutral Agriculture: Mitigation Potential for
Crop Based Strategies," which examines the potential for reducing GHG emissions
through agriculture in the United States. The report shows that adoption of
innovative production practices such as cover crops, conservation tillage,
precision nutrient management and data science could potentially result in the
reduction of more than 100 million metric tons of carbon dioxide-equivalent
emissions in the United States alone.



 For more resources and information on Monsanto's climate change efforts and
collaborations, see the company's 2015 sustainability report, Growing Better
Together.



 In case of any query regarding this article or other content needs please
contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

                             836 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

               October 6, 1987, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

Russian Agricultural Official Arriving for U.S. Farm Tour

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 14, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 518 words

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Oct. 5


Viktor P. Nikonov, a rising star in the ruling Soviet Politburo and the man in
charge of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's drive to rejuvenate Soviet agriculture, will
arrive in the United States on Tuesday for a week of farm tours and superpower
diplomacy.

While Mr. Nikonov's visit is primarily a chance to study the American way of
farming, Western diplomats say he is also scheduled to meet President Reagan,
and he is assumed to be taking soundings in Congress and among the public at
large for a Gorbachev trip to the United States later this year.

He is the first Politburo member other than Foreign Minister Eduard A.
Shevardnadze to visit the United States since Mr. Gorbachev assumed power in
March, 1985.

A Rapid Rise

Mr. Nikonov, a barrel-chested, 58-year-old agronomist generally considered a
Gorbachev protege, has risen in the last three months from relative obscurity to
become one of the higher-profile members of the Politburo.

The attention reflects the enormous stake Mr. Gorbachev has placed on farming as
the first testing ground for far-reaching changes planned for the Soviet
economy. It is expected that the next meeting of the Soviet Communist Party's
Centraol Committee will take up agricultural questions.

His American trip, at the invitation of Representative Kika de la Garza,
Democrat of Texas, the chairman of the House Agriculture Committee, is to begin
in Washington. Mr. Nikonov is officially the head of a delegation from the
Supreme Soviet, the nominal Soviet legislature. He is scheduled to meet
President Reagan, Secretary of State George P. Shultz, Congressional leaders and
agriculture officials.

The details of the summit meeting are to be worked out later this month when Mr.
Shultz visits Moscow. Since the November 1985 summit meeting, the Soviet Union
has been on the record as saying there should be reciprocal visits to each
nation's capital, starting with Washington. But a year ago, Mr. Gorbachev
proposed a preliminary meeting in Iceland, rather than in Washington, and Mr.
Reagan agreed.

U.S. Stand on Talks

Since then, American officials have said there would not be another summit
conference except in the United States. But the Soviet side publicly has still
not said that Mr. Gorbachev would come to the United States.

Mr. Nikonov's main task is apparently to see what American farming and marketing
methods can be emulated to advance the modest success achieved here in the last
two years.

Stops during his eight-day visit include farms in Iowa, a new supermarket near
Washington, commodities markets in Chicago, an agriculture exhibit at the Epcot
Center in Florida, and the Agriculture Department's research center in
Beltsville, Md.

Mr. Nikonov is regarded by Western analysts not as a leading innovator, but as
an enthusiastic promoter of the Gorbachev program.

When he was promoted to full voting membership in the Politburo at a party
leadership meeting in June, most Western analysts identified him as a Gorbachev
ally, although a few suggest that his real sponsor is the more conservative No.
2 official, Yegor K. Ligachev.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1987 The New York Times Company


                             837 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                  The State Journal-Register (Springfield, IL)

                           November 12, 2005 Saturday

Outbreak in Brazil shows utility of ID program

SECTION: MARKETPLACE; Pg. 11

LENGTH: 773 words


This may be the biggest reason to participate in the voluntary animal
identification program, administered through the Illinois Department of
Agriculture.

Ten new cases of foot-and-mouth disease have been confirmed in cattle in
Brazil's Mato Grosso do Sul state. The outbreak was discovered in early October,
and cases of the disease stand at 21 throughout the country, according to
Brazil's Ministry of Agriculture. The new cases were in Japora, south of
Eldorado and closer to the border with Paraguay. They are within a 25-kilometer
exclusion zone west of the Parana River that was created to prevent spread of
the disease after an outbreak in Eldorado.

Brazil's herd, estimated at 190 million cattle, is the largest commercial herd
in the world, according to Successful Farming's Web site, Agriculture Online.
The South American nation was the world's largest exporter of beef in 2004, with
exports valued at $2.5 billion.

The disease outbreak is in the country's largest beef-producing region, at the
extreme southern tip of Mato Grosso do Sul. The state's estimated 25 million
cattle account for about half of Brazil's beef exports.

As of Nov. 1, about 2,000 head of cattle had been killed in Mato Grosso do Sul
in trying to control the disease. Combined exports of beef, chicken and pork
from the country have dropped about 30 percent since the initial outbreak was
confirmed, according to Agriculture Online.

Brazil's Ministry of Agriculture has said it plans to double its investment in
controlling foot-and-mouth disease, to $24 million. The plan includes
vaccinating the nation's entire cattle herd.

If foot-and-mouth disease were to come to the United States, the animal
identification program would be invaluable in finding and tracking herds.

"It would definitely help," said Cimeron Frost, director of industry programs
with the Illinois Beef Association. "Foot-and-mouth is spread so easily. When
you look at the history of the foot-and-mouth epidemic in England a few years
ago, when they were tracking it, they found that a lot of sheep were spreading
it. The sheep were going through sale barns. Because foot-and-mouth is so easily
transmitted through the air, the sheep, even though they were just together for
a short time, were spreading it."

One of the goals of Illinois' animal ID program will be to track animals within
48 hours.

"We'll be able to track them forward as well as backward very quickly," Frost
said.

For the voluntary program to work, producers need to sign up.

Frost is concerned about the Brazilian outbreaks because travel restrictions
haven't been imposed.

"A lot of people are worried now," Frost said. "When foot-and-mouth spread
rapidly through Europe, we had very heavy restrictions in place. That's because
people can carry it in the respiratory system or on their clothes. Presently, we
don't have the same things in place as we did when the outbreak occurred in
Europe. I hope anyone coming from Brazil is talked to by officials, asking them
what part of Brazil they've visited. But I don't know that's happening. It is
scary."

Foot-and-mouth disease has been diagnosed in 34 countries during the past 18
months. The latest outbreaks have occurred in Great Britain, Northern Ireland,
Argentina and France. The only continents currently free of the disease are
North America, Australia and Antarctica.

Foot-and-mouth disease is caused by a fast-spreading virus, and all
cloven-footed animals are susceptible. Nearly all of the animals in an exposed
herd will become ill, and young animals may die from the disease. Animals
susceptible to the disease include cattle, bison, llamas, domestic and wild
swine, sheep, goats, captive and wild deer and elk.

Foot-and-mouth disease can be transmitted in a variety of ways, the most common
being direct contact with an infected animal.

Once infected, animals become "virus factories," capable of spreading high
numbers of viral particles to other animals and into the environment. Infected
swine, in particular, can release millions of viral particles when they exhale.
The virus can become airborne and can be breathed in by nearby susceptible
animals.

People who have been around infected animals can carry the virus in their nasal
passages for as long as 28 hours. While the disease is not considered to be a
threat to humans, it's possible for a person to spread the virus to susceptible
animals.

The virus also can be carried in raw meat, animal products or milk. An outbreak
in South Africa occurred when waste food containing raw meat scraps was
collected from international ships and fed to swine.

LOAD-DATE: November 16, 2005

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: COLUMN. LOCAL

                   Copyright 2005 The State Journal-Register


                             838 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                       The Financial Express (Bangladesh)

                           January 26, 2017 Thursday

Govt finalises action plan to boost mango exports

LENGTH: 554 words

DATELINE: Bangladesh


Bangladesh, Jan. 26 -- The government has finalised an action plan for boosting
mango production and exports considering its huge potential, officials said.

The main objective of the action plan is to ensure safe mango production, free
from pest attack, proper preservation, packaging, marketing and bringing farmers
under contract farming.

The action plan will have some mechanisms that will help regain confidence in
European buyers, who had curtailed 500 tonnes of mango import from Bangladesh
during the last season due to non-compliance issues.

The country exported about 800 tonnes of mangos mainly to the European markets
in 2015. But the amount fell to 300 tonnes in 2016 for non-compliance issues.

The department of agriculture extension (DAE) will go for contract farming with
farmers in 15 districts during the upcoming mango season.

Last year, the contract farming was done in Satkhira, Natore, Rajshahi, Pabna
and Meherpur districts.

Exports of mango to different countries could be made through contract farming
as an exporter has to make contract with mango growers with the
government-prescribed forms that contain rules. After signing of the forms, the
DAE could assist the farmers in smooth export of mango.

Bangladesh exports vegetables and fruits to different countries including the
European Union (EU) and the United States (US) worth about Tk 10 billion where
mango shares less than five per cent of the total amount, according to the
exporters.

"We have sent an action plan to the ministry of agriculture for mango growers,
traders and exporters. We hope it will come into effect shortly," a high
official of DAE, who is involved in the process of making the action plan, told
the FE.

He said the proposed action plan/guidelines will suggest good practices for
mango production giving priority to health and hygiene. Besides, it will help
mango growers in going for scientific production.

The official of the DAE said the new action plan has been finalised following a
demand of the ministry of commerce (MoC) and stakeholders.

Mangos produced in the country are sweet and of good quality, which has
considerable demand across the world.

Bangladesh is the seventh largest mango-producing country in the world with
around one million tonne of production annually.

The mango traders/ exporters suggested the government make the action plan
simple and less complicated in order to boost vegetables and fruit exports.

They pleaded for easy bank loan for farmers so that they could establish mango
processing plants.

They also suggested fixing mango harvesting time-frame and setting up mango
preservation plants in some selected areas.

"The action plan should be simple and business friendly so that export of mango
could be increased," SM Jahangir Hossain, director of the Federation of
Bangladesh Chambers of Commerce and Industry (FBCCI), told the FE.

DCCI President Abul Kasem Khan suggested the adoption of safe mango harvesting
and mango marketing practices.

He said the DCCI will form a research and development platform soon to conduct
research on the potential sectors of the country.

talhabinhabib@yahoo.com

contact Editor at htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

                             839 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                                 The Advertiser

                            December 2, 1988 Friday

Chemicals 'vital' to world food stocks

BYLINE: JIM MCCARTER

LENGTH: 255 words


The chemicals revolution in agriculture had generated a lot of consumer
misconceptions about the use of chemicals on food crops, agro-chemicals expert
Dr Earl Spurrier said in Adelaide yesterday.

Washington-based Dr Spurrier, vice-president for State affairs of the National
Agricultural Chemicals Association in the United States, was the keynote speaker
at a national workshop on herbicide use in vegetable crops held this week by the
Department of Agriculture.

"People see that some food grains like wheat are in world surplus and so they
ask 'why do we need all these chemicals to increase food production'," he said.

But the fact was that food production could not be maintained without chemicals.

"There is a strong movement in the US to go back to sustainable organic farming
," Dr Spurrier said.

"That sort of farming was okay 40 or 50 years ago. Then, the world's population
was two to three billion. Right now it's about five billion people.

"By the year 2000 it will be six billion, rising to an estimated eight billion
by 2020.

"Where is the food for these people going to come from? We can't go back to the
old ways and reduce food production by half when we are seeing our population
doubling.

"And right now, where are the people who will pull up all the weeds? Weeding by
hand and hoe can cost $1500 a hectare in a crop like onions, compared to $100 to
$125 a hectare using a herbicide."

Dr Spurrier said most proponents of organic farming had never grown food
themselves.

LOAD-DATE: September 20, 2003

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: photo: dr earl spurrier; Dr Spurrier in Adelaide yesterday.

                             840 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



             The Morgan Messenger (Berkely Springs, West Virginia)

  This content, including derivations, may not be stored or distributed in any
  manner, disseminated, published, broadcast, rewritten or reproduced without
                      express, written consent from STPNS

                                August 26, 2015

Veterans and Warriors to Agriculture program growing in West Virginia

BYLINE: The Morgan Messenger staff

LENGTH: 427  words


A message from West Virginia Department of Veterans assistance secretary Rick
Thompson During his State of the State address this January, Governor Tomblin
highlighted the West Virginia's Veterans and Warriors to Agriculture program.
This partnership between the West Virginia Department of Agriculture and the
West Virginia Department of Veterans Assistance (WVDVA) is giving service men
and women the training opportunities they need to succeed when they return home
from serving our country. Specifically designed to assist veterans interested in
farming, the program offers a number of training and support opportunities as
well as resources to connect these "veterans and their products with local
retailers.

Currently, participants receive mentorship with their farming endeavors as well
as assistance with applying for state and federal grants. They are given access
to a variety of publications that offer advice and guidance on everything from
home vegetable gardens to orchards and herbal farming. Even individuals who do
not own their own land can participate, as the program makes state-owned
properties available for lease at reduced rates. "Classes are offered in farming
berries, fruit trees, vegetables and herbs, as well as in bee-keeping.

The bee-keeping classes have been especially popular and the benefits of
increasing West Virginia's honeybee population reach beyond the veteran farmers
themselves. Bees play an essential role in pollinating and fertilizing numerous
crops, so their presence can help other parts of a farm to thrive. Consuming
locally harvested honey is thought to have medicinal value as well and, of
course, consumers have the satisfaction of knowing their honey purchase supports
a West Virginia producer.

We are excited about this program because it is helping our veterans supplement
their income through small business ownership and it's growing the agri-business
industry in West Virginia. Veterans also are. finding therapeutic value in
working the land and being part of a community of veteran farmers, and we are
equally excited about this benefit of the program.

Veterans and Warriors to Agriculture is a shining example of what we can
accomplish by working across agency lines to benefit those who have served our
country. My hope is that the program's success will inspire other government
bodies, businesses and organizations to consider ways they can give back to our
veteran community.

Those who are interested in learning more about Warriors to Agriculture should
go to www.wvagriculture.org or call 1-800-WV4-VETS.

LOAD-DATE: June 26, 2016

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Community

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                             841 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                  Lake Region Times (Madison Lake, Minnesota)

  This content, including derivations, may not be stored or distributed in any
  manner, disseminated, published, broadcast, rewritten or reproduced without
                      express, written consent from STPNS

                                October 13, 2010

USDA Forecasts Record-High Soybean Crop

BYLINE: Lake Region Times staff

LENGTH: 238  words


On the heels of a warm growing season, U.S. soybean production is forecast at a
record-high level, according to the Crop Production report, released on October
8th, by the U.S. Department of Agriculture's National Agricultural Statistics
Service (NASS).

Soybean production remains on target for a record-high year and is forecast at
3.41 billion bushels, up 1 percent from the previous record, set in 2009.
Soybean yield is expected to average 44.4 bushels per acre, up 0.4 bushels from
2009. If realized this will be the highest yield on record. Soybean growers are
expected to harvest a record-high 76.8 million acres, down 1 percent from the
September estimate, but up 0.6 percent from last year's acreage.

Corn production is forecast at 12.7 billion bushels, down 3.4 percent from last
year's record. Based on Oct. 1 conditions, corn yield is expected to average
155.8 bushels per acre, down 8.9 bushels from 2009. If realized, this will be
the third highest yield on record. Growers are expected to harvest 81.3 million
acres, up 0.3 percent from the September forecast.

According to the USDA, NASS, Minnesota Field Office, Corn silage harvest was
nearly complete at 97 percent, compared to 78 percent last year and 90 percent
average. Dry beans were 85 percent harvested, potatoes were 76 percent
harvested, sunflowers were 22 percent harvested, and sugarbeets were 34 percent
harvested, all ahead of their respective averages.

LOAD-DATE: August 3, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Agriculture

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: LKR

                             SmallTownPapers, Inc.

                             842 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                            October 28, 2016 Friday

Washington: Lawmakers Push Feds to Clarify Conflicting Rules on Growing and
Selling Hemp

LENGTH: 571 words

DATELINE: New York



 Washington: Office of the Senator Rand Paul has issued the following news
release:



 After new guidance created widespread confusion about when and where farmers
can grow, research, and sell industrial hemp in the United States, U.S. Senators
Rand Paul, R-Ky., Ron Wyden, D-Ore., and Representatives Earl Blumenauer,
D-Ore., Jared Polis, D-Colo., Thomas Massie, R-Ky., and 14 other members of
Congress today pushed three federal agencies to clarify parts of the guidance
that conflict with current laws.





 In August, the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA), along with the Drug
Enforcement Administration (DEA) and the Food and Drug Administration (FDA),
issued a "statement of principles" to inform the public about industrial hemp
grown in the United States. However, the announcement has created confusion for
state agriculture departments and universities working to establish pilot
programs to study the cultivation and potential commercial uses for industrial
hemp.



 In addition to establishing a new definition of industrial hemp, the guidance
could also have a limiting effect on sales and transportation of products made
from hemp in states conducting pilot projects across the country. Currently,
federal law prohibits American farmers from growing industrial hemp for
commercial profit, but retail sales of products made with hemp are legal, and
make up a $570 million industry annually.



 The 2014 Farm Bill allowed state agriculture departments and universities to
conduct industrial hemp research pilot programs in states that have authorized
the growing and production of industrial hemp, including Kentucky, Oregon,
Colorado, and twenty five other states.



 "We are writing to comment on the recent progress the Administration has made
with regards to industrial hemp and to urge further action to ensure that this
important industry can thrive," the members wrote in a letter to the USDA, DEA,
and FDA.



 "Industrial hemp research and farming have opened doors for students, farmers,
and small businesses in our states. At our universities, students and
researchers are experiencing new learning opportunities, such as researching
hemp for fuel, food, and clothing."



 Paul, Wyden, and Sen. Jeff Merkley, D-Ore., introduced the Industrial Hemp
Farming Act last year to lift the federal ban on domestic farming of industrial
hemp. The bill would remove hemp from the Schedule I controlled substance list
under the Controlled Substances Act of 1970, and would define it as a non-drug
so long as it contains less than 0.3 percent tetrahydrocannabinol (THC). The
bill now has 14 other bipartisan co-sponsors. Massie introduced the House
version of the Industrial Hemp Farming Act, which now has 74 cosponsors,
including Blumenauer and Polis.



 The letter was signed by Sens. Paul, Wyden, Merkley, Steve Daines, R-Mont., and
Representatives Massie, Blumenauer, Polis, Suzanne Bonamici, D-Ore., Kevin
Cramer, R-N.D., Peter DeFazio, D-Ore., Suzan DelBene, D-Wash., Barbara Lee,
D-Calif., Eleanor Homes Norton, D-D.C., Mark Pocan, D-Wis., Dana Rohrabacher,
R-Calif., Kurt Schrader, D-Ore., John Yarmuth, D-Ky., Ryan Zinke, R-Mont., and
Sam Farr, D-Calif.



 Industrial hemp is used throughout the world in thousands of products,
including paper, fabrics, lotions, canvas, rope, and construction material.



 In case of any query regarding this article or other content needs please
contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

LOAD-DATE: October 29, 2016

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire


              Copyright 2016 Plus Media Solutions Private Limited
                              All Rights Reserved
