                             844 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                              Dayton Review (Iowa)

  This content, including derivations, may not be stored or distributed in any
  manner, disseminated, published, broadcast, rewritten or reproduced without
                      express, written consent from STPNS

                                 March 17, 2010

Nations largest organic farming conference continues to grow

BYLINE: Dayton Review staff

LENGTH: 225  words


The nation's largest organic farming conference, hosted by the Midwest Organic
and Sustainable Education Service (MOSES) had approximately 2,700 organic
farmers and agriculture professionals attend this year's Organic Farming
Conference (OFC) from all over the United States, as well as Armenia, Thailand,
Austria, Canada, South Korea and Germany.

Held in La Crosse, Wis., Feb. 25-27, the OFC featured a record 65 organic
farming workshops and 150 exhibitors. "We're pleased this conference continues
to grow in size and scope of subjects addressed," said MOSES Executive Director
Faye Jones.

Some additional highlights from the conference include:

MOSES Farmer of the Year Award Presented Thursday night to John, Jane and Janaki
Fisher-Merritt, who own and coperate Food Farm, an organic vegetable farm near
Wirenshall, MN.

Updated USDA Organic Pasture Rules were released February 17, so understanding
the rules and how they affect new and veteran organic farmers was a popular
discussion topic throughout the conference. Jim Riddle explained some of the
main changes at the press conference on Friday afternoon.

Keynote presenters on Friday and Saturday at the general session were Chuck
Hassebrook, Executive Director of the Center of Rural Affairs and Dr. Margaret
Mellon director of the Food and Environment Program at the Union of Concerned
Scientists.

                             845 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                           Aberdeen Press and Journal

                                February 9, 1999

Mark of distinction for home-produced pork

SECTION: Farming, Pg.14

LENGTH: 554 words


SCOTTISH Agriculture Minister Lord Sewel took the covers off a GBP 2.5million
initiative to give British pig farmers a much-needed boost yesterday.

The minister launched the new Scottish Pig Mark at Central Scotland butchers J
Patrick and Sons, Camelon.

The logo, part of the new British Quality Standard Mark for pigmeat from the
Meat and Livestock Commission, is seen as being highly important in stressing
the welfare and husbandry qualities of the pigs reared in the Scottish industry
- and in encouraging consumers to buy more home-produced pork, ham and bacon.

But while the MLC promotional gurus are looking for increased sales of
home-produced pork, the commission's economists are warning that pork imports
will increase this year and that UK pigmeat exports will fall.

World pig prices have collapsed in recent months because of global oversupply,
the strong pound and cheap imports from nations, including many in Europe, that
do not have the same high welfare standards as those imposed on the UK industry.

Lord Sewel said the mark provided a clear identity for home-produced pigmeat. He
said: "Consumers can be confident that pork with this mark is traceable, of the
highest quality, and comes from farm -assured stock reared to high welfare
standards."

"It is clearly identified as quality farm-assured and reared to the highest
welfare standards in Europe. What we have seen in the industry is a response to
welfare standards which are now dependent on consumer backing. It is time that
the consumers who demanded all these standards back the industry."

Oversupply

Responding to questions on aid schemes to pig farmers in the US and Canada, the
minister made it clear that he was stridently opposed to any similar initiatives
by fellow European nations.

He added: "Basically the reason for the problems in the pig sector lie with a
major global oversupply. Therefore we have to make sure that we supply the
market with the best pigs. The UK most definitely does that."

Sow numbers have fallen by an estimated 11% in the UK, but it is believed the
decrease may be more marked in Scotland, with sows falling back from 75,000 to
about 55,000.

David Whiteford, the chairman of the Scottish Pig Industry Initiative, added the
launch endorsed everything the pig industry had been saying in recent months on
the quality of British pigmeat. He called on a better synergy across the
industry.

Mr Whiteford said: "There are opportunities for further price increases on the
back of our very high quality. We must grasp the mettle and persuade the
processing and catering sectors that there is a huge gap in the industry.

"We must stop them filling this with imported pig meat. It's all about making
better use of the entire pig. Everyone wants the loins, but there is a gap in
the middle. We have to tell them that the rest of our pigs are totally assured."

Mr Patrick said his customers were increasingly concerned about where their meat
came from.

Alistair Donaldson, the MLC's Scottish general manager, said:" Given the current
crisis facing the industry, these initiatives have major significance. We now
have a mark which properly differentiates the Scottish product and the
opportunity to quickly bring it to the consumers attention."

nLord Sewel, left, with butcher Robert Patrick yesterday

LOAD-DATE: February 10, 1999

LANGUAGE: English

                   Copyright 1999 Aberdeen Press and Journal


                             846 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                            February 17, 1989 Friday

WORTH REPEATING

BYLINE: JOHN RAYMOND; GAM

LENGTH: 823 words


BY  JOHN RAYMOND
    Grain farming is fundamentally important to the Canadian economy (and)
Canadian society as a whole should share in its risks. But farmers
themselves should be responsible for handling those risks. Our goal must
be to put the farmer back in control of farming.
   - Judith Maxwell
                          Sharing the risks
Economic Council of Canada president Judith Maxwell , addressing the
Canadian Agricultural Outlook Conference in Ottawa:
   In constant dollars, the long-term trend in wheat prices has been
downward since 1926. (While) the Economic Council recognizes that, sooner
or later, there is likely to be an upswing in prices, we see no
developments on the international scene that would turn the improvement
into a long-term trend.

Canada has an advantage in grain production, but we face volatile
markets and falling prices, in real terms, over the long term. How do we
manage these risks? How do we ensure that Canadian farmers earn an
adequate return?

In considering these questions, the council has noted the traumatic
impact of the stresses of recent years. We are witnessing a social crisis
on the Prairies and also an individual crisis for many farmers.

One negative legacy of these years is a major burden of farm debt.
Another is a retreat from sound financing principles in our major
stabilization programs. In moving to control the crisis, we undermined the
incentives which are the roots of good farm management. At the same time,
we have provided implicit guarantees of future bailouts. None of this
provides the basis for a constructive or predictable agricultural policy.
. .

The Economic Council's view is that the government has two ways to go
in dealing with this situation. The first is to repair the existing safety
net of stabilization programs. If the United States, Europe and Japan do
not make progress toward freer trade, this is what we would recommend.

Option two puts forward a completely new approach (and depends on)
progress toward trade liberalization over the next few years. In this
proposal, governments and farmers would share the risks over the ups and
downs of price cycles. This would be done through programs that would
stabilize incomes. Farm income insurance would replace crop insurance, and
farmers would be encouraged to set up self-managed income stabilization
accounts in good times (with) their deposits being matched by governments,
up to a certain limit.

The net result would be an agricultural safety net based on . . .
insurance, not welfare. And, over time, it would be self-financing, except
in the most disastrous years.

Speaking of farming

The once-lowly potato has come a long way. According to Agriculture  Canada,
customers who are 'looking for something more' can now buy  potatoes that come
in a veritable kaleidoscope of colors - white, yellow,  red and purple.

The designer spuds, which bear names like Yukon Gold, Purple Chief and
Red Pontiac, are aimed at making gourmets take a second look at a
vegetable that has traditionally been considered dull.

Dull! How could anyone fail to be excited by the Caribe - that's Cah-
REE-Bay - described as coming with purple skin and white flesh?

Agriculture Canada says there will never be 'the perfect potato,' but
there are still lots of ways we can breed improvements.

Anyone for polka dots?

This time get it right

From Nuala Beck & Associates:     There is a growing body of opinion that the
United States has pursued  the wrong restructuring strategy. While its trading
partners in Asia and  Europe opted for technological restructuring, North
America made the bad  choice of opting for financial restructuring. The reason
why this was such  an enormous strategic misdirection is that it has largely
capitalized on  existing value, which is not the same as creating value.

This critical difference is essential to grasp, insofar as North
America's approach to restructuring is about to be radically redefined and
replaced by a definition of adding value that focuses to an almost
frightening extent on technological restructuring. The simple production
differences that exist between most North American firms and everybody
else suggests that it will become increasingly difficult to maintain this
divergent strategy path.

Consider just a few of the following differences, which are correctable
via technological restructuring but which no amount of financial
restructuring can remedy:
 . The average time from order to shipment in North America is five to six
months. In Japan it is one to two months.
 . Quality defects average 8 to 10 per cent in North America, compared
with less than 1 per cent in Japan.
 . North America's annual investment per worker is only $2,600 (U.S.),
while in Japan it exceeds $6,500 per worker.

What these simple statistics suggest is that North America has an
expensive game of catch-up ahead.

What causes concern is the ability of numerous corporations to support
incremental investment on their debt-burdened balance sheets.

LOAD-DATE: January 10, 2007

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                             847 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                    The Orange County Register (California)

                           November 6, 2003 Thursday

County farmer named state agriculture chief;
A.G. Kawamura is chosen by Gov.-elect Schwarzenegger to run low-profile but
powerful department.

BYLINE: By JOHN GITTELSOHN , The Orange County Register

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 586 words


Gov.-elect Arnold Schwarzenegger named a third-generation strawberry farmer from
Newport Beach as his secretary of food and agriculture on Wednesday.

A.G. Kawamura, a 47-year-old Republican, will head a department that usually
makes few headlines while overseeing one of the state's largest industries.

Kawamura's family business, Orange County Produce, cultivates about 500 acres of
beans and strawberries in Irvine and assists distribution for farmers in San
Bernardino and San Diego counties, and Mexico.

``I like the honesty of it,'' Kawamura said of farming. ``I like working with a
product you don't have to apologize for.''

While the soft-spoken, ponytailed UC Berkeley graduate espouses the virtues of
small farming, he also has represented the interests of agribusiness as former
president and current board member of the Western Growers Association.

``Most agriculture in California is family business,'' Kawamura said. ``Some of
it's very big, but it's not traded on the New York Stock Exchange.''

The Irvine-headquartered industry group has lobbied against raising the minimum
wage and mandatory arbitration for farmworkers.

It has also worked with the United Farm Workers on federal laws that would allow
undocumented immigrants to legalize their status in the United States.

With 88,000 farms and ranches, California agriculture is a nearly $28 billion-
a-year industry that generates $100 billion in related economic activity.

The Food and Agriculture Department oversees food safety, animal health, food
labeling and quality standards, marketing, county fairs and expositions, and the
control of pests such as the Mediterranean fruit fly.

Like other state agencies, the department faces budget cuts. One example: plans
call for the closure by January at least 11 of the 16 inspection stations near
border entry points.

As president of Western Growers in the mid-1990s, Kawamura launched a program to
plant gardens at schools, called ``Growing with Children,'' which aims to teach
kids about food production and nutrition.

``We want to put people in touch with fundamentals,'' he said Wednesday. ``I'm
very interested in seeing California agriculture have a new renaissance.''

That renaissance means educating the public about the value of farming -- the
need for water, land and locally-grown food -- which is losing ground to urban
sprawl, increasing regulation and rising costs, Kawamura said. ``As an urban
agriculturist, the pressures to continue business are very tough,'' he said.
``Maybe as a result of that, I've tried to be involved in the industry and where
it's going.''

Like other Japanese-Americans in California, Kawamura's grandparents and parents
spent much of World War II in internment camps. The family history gave Kawamura
sympathy for the struggles of migrant farmworkers and also helped him relate to
Schwarzenegger, an immigrant from Austria.

``They're an example of how you can be from an immigrant family and, with hard
work and discipline, move mountains,'' Kawamura said.

He began working on the family farm as a boy growing up in Newport Beach, where
he graduated from Newport Harbor High School.

``He always had a green thumb,'' said his brother, Matt Kawamura, 43, who will
assume control of the family business while A.G., which stands for Arthur Gen,
moves to Sacramento with his wife, Dianne.

Not all of Kawamura's enterprises went well. His father gave him a beekeeping
business that he sold after a couple years.

``I had enough stings,'' he said.

(714) 796-7969

or jgittels@ocregister.com

LOAD-DATE: November 15, 2003

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Honest work: A.G. Kawamura, whose family business cultivates about 500
acres, hopes for an agricultural renaissance.

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Story

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                     Copyright 2003 Orange County Register


                             848 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

              September 18, 1981, Friday, Late City Final Edition

SENATE DEFEATS MOVE TO END SUGAR SUBSIDIES

BYLINE: By SETH S. KING, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 21, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 736 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17


The old coalition of farm state senators regrouped today as the Senate rejected
a consumer-backed amendment that would have prohibited price supports for sugar.

After that vote, the Senate defeated by a vote of 53 to 42 an amendment to
eliminate Federal support for tobacco fa rmers as it continued work on the
Agriculture Committee's comprehensive four-yearfarm bill.

The bill includes a proposal that would have the effect of guaranteeing American
farmers at least 18 cents a pound for their sugar. The current free market price
for sugar is about 15 cents a pound.

Later tonight, the Senate also turned back, by a vote of 54 to 40, an attempt by
Senator Gordon J. Humphrey, Republican of New Hampshire, to lower the loan
guarantee rate to 16.5 cents a pound.

In the aftermath of votes earlier this week to trim both the dairy and peanut
price-support programs, the farm coalition was reestablished today after
Agriculture Committee leaders repeatedly warned farm state senators that further
disunity could endanger chances of passing any farm legislation this fall that
President Reagan would accept.

Senator Dan Quayle, Republican of Indiana, whose amendment to kill the sugar
price-support program was defeated by a vote of 61 to 33, said later that
committee leaders had spent ''some anxious hours'' pleading with farm state
senators to join in killing his measure.

Impact on Coalition Seen

Mr. Quayle said that many of those who were persuaded to change their minds on
his amendment were ''still shaken'' by what happened on milk and peanut support
plans.

When farm state senators split among themselves and began voting against one
another's favorite commodity protection proposals, the Reagan Administration
pushed through a milk program amendment that lowered price support levels to 70
percent of parity with no annual adjustments for inflation, a measure the
powerful dairy lobby had fought bitterly.

Then, yesterday, the peanut program pushed by Senator Jesse C.  Helms, the North
Carolina Republican who heads the Agriculture Committee, barely escaped defeat,
and a substitute measure that the committee did not want was approved.

Senator J. James Exon, Democrat of Nebraska, said today in debate on the sugar
loan amendment that the farm coalition crumbled Monday after the Administration
forced the Agriculture Committee to reduce many of the support loan levels and
subsidy rates on grains and milk that the committee had wanted.

''That original committee bill was only about $1 billion over what the
Administration now says it will accept,'' Senator Exon said.  ''We could have
gotten that money within the budget from someplace else, like defense. But the
Administration divided us. If we do not come together to defeat this sugar
amendment, it will be the final nail in the farm bill's coffin.''

Tobacco Subsidy Amendment

Senator Mark O. Hatfield, Republican of Oregon, introduced the amendment on
tobacco subsidies, saying that since 1938 the Government has been participating
in the tobacco program while spending millions on health programs to combat the
adverse effects of smoking.

This was the first year that Congress has had to enact legislation with costs
within the limits of its budget resolution. This, plus the threat by President
Reagan to veto any bills coming in over these limits, has been a decisive factor
in defeating the once-invincible dairy and peanut lobbies.

There has been no sugar price-support program since 1978.  The Administration
originally opposed resuming the sugar supports, preferring to protect the
domestic price through tariffs on imported sugar, which makes up about half of
this country's annual consumption. But in exchange for votes of sugar state
Democrats, Mr. Reagan agreed to withdraw this opposition.

Defeat of the Quayle amendment cleared the way for passage of a section in the
committee bill that will re-establish sugar loans.  This will enable American
sugar producers to borrow from the Treasury at 18 cents a pound for sugar that
they do not choose to sell on the open market.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1981 The New York Times Company


                             849 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                            October 28, 2016 Friday

Washington: Lawmakers Push Feds to Clarify Conflicting Rules on Growing and
Selling Hemp

LENGTH: 570 words

DATELINE: New York



 Washington: Office of the Senator Ron Wyden has issued the following news
release:



 After new guidance created widespread confusion about when and where farmers
can grow, research and sell industrial hemp in the United States, U.S. Senators
Ron Wyden, D-Ore., Rand Paul, R-Ky., and Representatives Earl Blumenauer,
D-Ore., Jared Polis, D-Colo., Thomas Massie, R-Ky., and 14 other members of
Congress today pushed three federal agencies to clarify parts of the guidance
that conflict with current laws.





 In August, the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA), along with the Drug
Enforcement Administration (DEA) and the Food and Drug Administration (FDA),
issued a "statement of principles" to inform the public about industrial hemp
grown in the United States. However, the announcement has created confusion for
state agriculture departments and universities working to establish pilot
programs to study the cultivation and potential commercial uses for industrial
hemp.



 In addition to establishing a new definition of industrial hemp, the guidance
could also have a limiting effect on sales and transportation of products made
from hemp in states conducting pilot projects across the country. Currently,
federal law prohibits American farmers from growing industrial hemp for
commercial profit, but retail sales of products made with hemp are legal, and
make up a $570 million industry annually.



 The 2014 Farm Bill allowed state agriculture departments and universities to
conduct industrial hemp research pilot programs in states that have authorized
the growing and production of industrial hemp, including Oregon, Kentucky,
Colorado, and twenty five other states.



 "We are writing to comment on the recent progress the Administration has made
with regards to industrial hemp and to urge further action to ensure that this
important industry can thrive," the members wrote in a letter to the USDA, DEA
and FDA.



 "Industrial hemp research and farming have opened doors for students, farmers,
and small businesses in our states. At our universities, students and
researchers are experiencing new learning opportunities, such as researching
hemp for fuel, food, and clothing."



 Wyden, Paul, and Sen. Jeff Merkley, D-Ore., introduced the Industrial Hemp
Farming Act last year to lift the federal ban on domestic farming of industrial
hemp. The bill would remove hemp from the Schedule I controlled substance list
under the Controlled Substances Act of 1970, and would define it as a non-drug
so long as it contains less than 0.3 percent tetrahydrocannabinol (THC). The
bill now has 14 other bipartisan co-sponsors. Massie introduced the House
version of the Industrial Hemp Farming Act, which now has 74 cosponsors,
including Blumenauer and Polis.



 The letter was signed by Sens. Wyden, Paul, Merkley, Steve Daines, R-Mont., and
Representatives Massie, Blumenauer, Polis, Suzanne Bonamici, D-Ore., Kevin
Cramer, R-N.D., Peter DeFazio, D-Ore., Suzan DelBene, D-Wash., Barbara Lee,
D-Calif., Eleanor Homes Norton, D-D.C., Mark Pocan, D-Wis., Dana Rohrabacher,
R-Calif., Kurt Schrader, D-Ore., John Yarmuth, D-Ky., Ryan Zinke, R-Mont., and
Sam Farr, D-Calif.



 Industrial hemp is used throughout the world in thousands of products,
including paper, fabrics, lotions, canvas, rope, and construction material.



 In case of any query regarding this article or other content needs please
contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

LOAD-DATE: October 29, 2016

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire


              Copyright 2016 Plus Media Solutions Private Limited

                             851 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                              The Bismarck Tribune

                             July 30, 2013 Tuesday

Canadian beef farmers fight U.S. meat label rules

SECTION: WIRE; Pg. B3

LENGTH: 381 words


CALGARY, Alberta (AP) - An organization that represents Canadian beef farmers
said it is seeking an in-junction while a court in the U.S. hears its case
against country-of-origin meat labeling.

The Canadian Cattlemen's Association said it is part of a coalition that has
asked the U.S. District Court in Washington to delay the policy to be
implemented in November.

The policy would require labels on meat products sold in the United States to
contain detailed information about where the products come from.

The lawsuit claims that the rule would violate the U.S. Agriculture Marketing
Act and is arbitrary.

The coalition that filed the injunction argues the policy would cause
irreparable harm to the U.S. meat and livestock industry by increasing costs and
making it more difficult for U.S. companies to buy Canadian products.

Plaintiffs in the lawsuit also include the American Association of Meat
Processors, American Meat Institute, Canadian Pork Council, National Cattlemen's
Beef Association, National Pork Producers Council, North American Meat
Association and Southwest Meat Association.

In 2009, the U.S. issued the requirement that retail outlets put country of
origin labels on meat and other products in an effort to give U.S. consumers
more information about their food.

A World Trade Organization ruling on meat labeling found the U.S. system
discriminates against foreign livestock.

The U.S. announced earlier this year that it wants to require even more detail
on the origins of beef, pork and chicken sold in grocery stores.

Labels would include such information as "born, raised and slaughtered in the
United States." Cuts of meat from other countries could carry labels such as
"born in Canada, raised and slaughtered in the United States."

The Canadian Pork Council estimates the existing labeling rule has already cost
Canada about $97 million (CA$1 billion) annually in beef and pork exports.

Last month, the Canadian government released a list of potential U.S.
agricultural products to which Canada could apply retaliatory tariffs. They
include cattle, pigs, beef, pork, some fruits and vegetables and chocolate.

Agriculture Minister Gerry Ritz said that while Canadians could see higher
prices as a result, the U.S. will lose jobs and significant revenue from the
tariffs.

LOAD-DATE: August 1, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


       Copyright 2013 The Bismarck Tribune, a division of Lee Enterprises
                              All Rights Reserved


                             852 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

                 May 2, 1991, Thursday, DAILY: NATIONAL EDITION

Grain farmers blast U.S. over trade deal

BYLINE: Canadian Press

SECTION: SECTION 1, NEWS; Pg. 5

LENGTH: 504 words

DATELINE: Ottawa, Ont.


The U.S. has been violating a key agricultural provision in the free trade
agreement and Canada shouldn't open its borders to American grain until it
stops, the three Prairie wheat pools charged yesterday.

''Canada must not put its agriculture industry in jeopardy in order to live up
to the Canada-U.S. trade agreement when the U.S. is openly violating the same
agreement,'' says Leroy Larsen, acting chairman of Prairie Pools Inc.

The agreement says Canada must open its border to U.S. wheat and barley when the
subsidy levels for grain in both countries become equal.

Many in the grain trade think that has already happened under the subsidy
calculation formula in the agreement. Officials say preliminary figures have
been done by both countries and now are being studied.

They are expected to be announced this month.

Finance Minister Don Mazankowski said last month, when he was still agriculture
minister, that he wasn't happy about opening the border if the subsidies were
even because of a statistical fluke.

The figures for 1988 and 1989 are expected to be close because of a drought in
Canada which reduced the size of the crop and made Canadian subsidy levels
appear high.

Mazankowski said Canada has been forced into higher subsidies because of the
grain subsidies the U.S. has made available under its export enhancement
program.

He said Canadian officials will be closely scrutinizing the subsidy
calculations.

U.S. officials were not immediately available for comment.

Once the border is opened, Canada will only be able to require end-use
certificates to control where U.S. grain is shipped in Canada. The certificates
show where the grain is headed.

The pools said the U.S. has violated the agreement by targeting traditional
Canadian export markets with its subsidy program.

Larsen said that Ottawa should consider the U.S. export program in the subsidy
calculation.

The government should also get assurances from Washington that when the border
is opened, the U.S. won't use subsidies on any grain shipped to Canada.

Larsen said farmers need the government's backing in this dispute.

''The Prairie grain and oilseed industry is in the midst of a very serious
financial crisis, one that was caused by the unfair trading practices of other
countries.

''We have been told that the Canadian government does not have the financial
resources to compensate our producers fully for the effects of these trading
practices.

''Therefore the government must take action at the root of the problem - in
trade. It's time for our government to take a strong position against unfair
trading actions and that includes the U.S. violations of the (trade
agreement).''

Mazankowski sent several protests about grain subsidies to Washington. But the
government has refused to challenge the U.S. under a section of the agreement
that requires each country to take into account the interests of the other in
the use of export subsidies on overseas sales.




LOAD-DATE: November 6, 1997

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: NEWS

                       Copyright 1991 Financial Post Ltd.

                   The Record-Eagle (Traverse City, Michigan)

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                             April 15, 2016 Friday

Agriculture in Brief: 04/16/2016

BYLINE: The Record-Eagle, Traverse City, Mich.

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 291 words


April 15--Producer grant workshop

TRAVERSE CITY -- The United States Department of Agriculture will partner with
the Northwest Michigan Small Business Development Center and the Michigan State
University Product Center to offer a workshop on its Value Added Producer Grant
program. The program helps agricultural producers enter into activities that
would generate new products, create and expand marketing opportunities and
increase producer income.

The workshop will help producers learn if the grant program is the right tool
for their farming operation and how local partners can assist with their
application. It will be held on April 26 from 1:30 to 3:30 p.m. in the large
conference room at the Traverse City Michigan Works Center, 1209 South Garfield
Ave. There is no charge or registration required to attend the workshop. Contact
the SBDC at 231-922-3780 or at sbdc@networksnorthwest.org for more information.

Food system economic assessment

TRAVERSE CITY -- The Northwest Michigan Food and Farming Network will host a
study session on April 20 from 10:30 a.m. to noon in the Cherry Capital Foods
Board Room, 1610 Barlow Street. Sharron May will present the results of the
network's "Lakes to Land Regional Initiative: Farm and Food System Assessment."

Guests and a board of panelists will be able to discuss the case study, which
received the Michigan Association of Planning 2015 award for Excellence in
Planning and Economic Development. The event is open to the public, and no
registration is required. Contact Carol Danly at foodandfarmingnetwork@gmail.com
for more information.

(Traverse City, Mich.) at record-eagle.com Distributed by Tribune Content
Agency, LLC.

                        The Atlanta Journal-Constitution

                      March 22, 2002 Friday, Home Edition

Report: U.S. relies heavily on illegal workers;
Half on farm, 25% in home, 10% in eateries

BYLINE: JULIA MALONE

SOURCE: Cox Washington Bureau

SECTION: News; Pg. 6A

LENGTH: 514 words


Washington --- Nearly half of America's farm workers, 25 percent of household
workers and 10 percent of restaurant employees are illegal immigrants, according
to a new study about America's undocumented foreign population.

The report, produced for the privately financed Pew Hispanic Center, was timed
for release as President Bush meets today with Mexican President Vicente Fox to
discuss border and migration issues.

Although a major amnesty plan is not on the agenda, officials continue to
discuss a possible increase in permits to allow more temporary workers from
Mexico.

The Pew research indicates that the majority of the 7.8 million illegal
residents in the United States come from Mexico. It also found that close to 4
percent of the urban workforce is illegal.

These undocumented workers tend to be clustered in low-wage service and labor
jobs, including garment-making, meatpacking and agricultural work, the study
found. They also make up 6 percent of construction laborers and almost 5 percent
of all manufacturing workers.

Philip Martin, one of the researchers and an economist at the University of
California, Davis, estimated that 47 percent of the 2.5 million farm workers are
in the United States illegally. Large farms that employ contract labor tend to
have more illegals than smaller farms. Fruit and vegetable growers tend to hire
illegal help more often than livestock farmers do, he said.

Martin said the supply of cheap, illegal labor has been plentiful during the
past 20 years. He noted, however, that the agriculture industry also could find
ways to substitute for those workers, if the flow were reduced.

"There are alternative ways to get any kind of work done," Davis said. The wine
industry relies on machines for three-fourths of its harvest, and other
commodities, including Georgia's Vidalia onion industry, could follow that lead,
he said.

The Pew study's statistical portrait of the illegal workforce drew conflicting
conclusions from groups that monitor immigration.

"What we've seen in the last decade is that entire low-wage sectors of the
economy are dependent on immigrant workers," said Frank Sharry, executive
director of the National Immigration Forum, an immigrant advocacy group.

"To us, it cries out for a comprehensive solution," said Sharry, whose group has
called for a process for legalizing immigrants already here and allowing more to
come with the government's per- mission.

Steven Camarota, research director for the Center for Immigration Studies, which
favors a reduction in immigration, said the Pew report left out important
consequences of the influx of undocumented workers.

"Does the modern Amer- ican economy need a lot of high school dropouts?"
Camarota asked, referring to the illegal population, which tends to have low
education and low skill levels.

"The fiscal outcome of illegal immigration is overwhelmingly negative," he said,
adding that this group costs more in social services than do other residents.
"The reverse is true for [immigrants] with college degrees," he said.

LOAD-DATE: March 22, 2002

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                Copyright 2002 The Atlanta Journal-Constitution

                       The Harrodsburg Herald (Kentucky)

                                October 25, 2012

UK Makes Ag Upgrades

BYLINE: The Harrodsburg Herald staff

LENGTH: 340  words


In the past year, the University of Kentucky Research and Education Center in
Princeton has made substantial technology upgrades to the center's equipment to
help further its research mission.

These upgrades include an improved farm record keeping system and precision
agriculture instruments on a sprayer, a tractor, a combine and an all-terrain
vehicle.

The sprayer was purchased through funds from the Kentucky Corn Growers'
Association, Kentucky Soybean Board and the Kentucky Agricultural Development
Fund. The other equipment upgrades were funded through the center.

"We are extremely appreciative of the support we received from the Kentucky Corn
Growers Association, the Kentucky Soybean Promotion Board and the Kentucky
Agricultural Development Board, and the confidence these important stakeholders
have placed in us," said Richard Coffey, the center's director. "This is a great
example of how cooperation between the UK College of Agriculture and our
stakeholders can help meet the needs of our clientele."

UK College of Agriculture researchers have conducted studies in the past using
various precision agriculture technologies at the center, but this year is the
first time the new technologies are available to every researcher who has plots
on the research farm and research plots on Western Kentucky producers' farms.

"The biggest way I can see this helping with research is our researchers can
more precisely repeat an experiment," said Joe Williams, the center's farm
superintendent. "In the past, we were able to accurately replicate a long-term
study within inches; now it will be within centimeters."

Researchers and farm staff now have real-time, online access to the farm's
records, including field history, which will help them resolve land use issues.
In addition, researchers can see when farm personnel make nutrient and chemical
applications throughout the growing season, as well as how their research plots
yielded at harvest.

Additional benefits include lower fuel costs and time saved applying chemicals
and nutrients.

LOAD-DATE: March 22, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                                October 11, 2012

UK Makes Ag Upgrades

BYLINE: The Harrodsburg Herald staff

LENGTH: 340  words


In the past year, the University of Kentucky Research and Education Center in
Princeton has made substantial technology upgrades to the center's equipment to
help further its research mission.

agriculture instruments on a sprayer, a tractor, a combine and an all-terrain
vehicle.

Association, Kentucky Soybean Board and the Kentucky Agricultural Development
Fund. The other equipment upgrades were funded through the center.

Growers Association, the Kentucky Soybean Promotion Board and the Kentucky
Agricultural Development Board, and the confidence these important stakeholders

applications throughout the growing season, as well as how their research plots
yielded at harvest.

Additional benefits include lower fuel costs and time saved applying chemicals
and nutrients.

                        Gazeta Mercantil Online (Brazil)

                          January 14, 1998, Wednesday

Grain prices rise after publishing of USDA reports_

SECTION: Agribusiness

LENGTH: 142 words

DATELINE: 01/14/98


Yesterday, the Chicago Board of Trade reacted to reports from the US Department
of Agriculture (USDA), about grain supply, demand and production. The decrease
in US stocks provoked a significant high of 4.5% on corn contracts for May
delivery, fixed at $108.76 per ton, closing at the upward limit.

Wheat for May delivery was traded at $125.48 per ton, registering a high of 3.9%
due to the reduction of the planting area of winter wheat.

The price of soybean for March delivery increased 1%, to $247.02 per ton, due to
an increase in US domestic consumption. According to the USDA, world grain
production in the 1997/98 harvest should reach 1.88 billion tons, a 0.4%
increase over forecasts from last December's survey, due to an increase in
soybean crops in Brazil, corn crops in Argentina and wheat in Australia. (Gazeta
Mercantil)

LOAD-DATE: January 18, 1998

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

LANGUAGE-SPOKEN: PORTUGUESE

                             858 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

                    November 8, 1991, Friday, DAILY EDITION

Soybean, corn fall on fear of higher U.S. crop figures

BYLINE: Farm Market News

SECTION: SECTION 2, INVESTMENT AND FINANCE; Pg. 33, FARM COMMODITIES

LENGTH: 369 words

DATELINE: Winnipeg, Man.


     Fears that the U.S. Agriculture Department will increase its
 1991 U.S. soybean and corn crop estimate next Tuesday spurred selling yesterday
at the Chicago Board of Trade that took those commodities lower.

CBOT soybeans settled US2 cents to US3 3/4 cents a bushel lower with the most
active month, January, ending at US$5.57, down US3 1/4 cents.

Corn at the CBOT meanwhile finished US1 cents to US1 1/2 cents lower with
featured March down US1 1/2 cents at US$2.54.

News that highly respected private crop forecaster Sparks Commodities raised its
corn and soybean production estimates fuelled the speculation Washington would
raise its estimates.

SOVIET CREDIT

Mixed ideas about a New York Times report that a US$1-billion (C$1.13-billion)
credit package to the Soviet Union might be announced next week accounted for
some of the downward movement in CBOT wheat. This would be much less than the
US$2.5 billion being sought by the Soviets.

Wheat futures at the CBOT ranged US3 1/2 cents to US7 cents lower with
most-active December closing at US$3.50 1/4, down US7 cents a bushel.

Additional pressure in the wheat pit stemmed from news that France has been
aggressively pursuing wheat sales to the Soviet Union.

Canola futures on the Winnipeg Commodity Exchange managed to close 40 cents to
$1.80 a tonne lower based on declines in the CBOT soybean pit. Featured January
ended down 40 cents at $265.70.

Canola prices were taken off their lows at the close by a late spurt of exporter
buying.

The continued lack of farmer selling to the prairie elevator system helped prop
up WCE wheat futures. Those values ended 20 cents to 50 cents a tonne higher
with most-active March settling at $98.80, up 50 cents.

BIG HOGS

Larger-than-expected hog marketings Wednesday and a belief that yesterday's run
would also be high encouraged the selling that took Chicago Mercantile Exchange
live hog and pork belly prices down.

CME live hogs closed US10 cents to US30 cents a hundredweight lower with
featured April settling at US$39.80, down US30 cents. CME pork bellies ended
US28 cents to US50 cents lower, with March finishing at US$40.27, down US48
cents.

                          The Sun (Mount Vernon, Iowa)

  This content, including derivations, may not be stored or distributed in any
  manner, disseminated, published, broadcast, rewritten or reproduced without
                      express, written consent from STPNS

                               September 30, 2010

Francis Thicke, candidate for Iowa ag secretary, brings his vision for future to
Mount Vernon;
Living in Iowa

BYLINE: Dan Brawner

LENGTH: 539  words


Frands Thicke (pronounced THICKEE), of Fairfield, currently running for Iowa
secretary of agriculture, spoke at a small fund-raiser Saturday at David
Osterberg's house in Mount Vernon. Thicke explained his practical approach to
agriculture, quoting Allen Nation, editor of the Stockman Grass Farmer: "It is
the nature of cows to move about and the nature of grass to stand in one place.
But with confinement animal production, we have turned it backwards and made the
cows stand in one place and made the grass move to the cows."

Thicke, who holds a Ph.D. in soil science and worked for the U.S. Department of
Agriculture in Washington, D.C., doesn't sound much like a politician, although
he intends to be one. And he doesn't exactly sound like a farmer either,
although he has been a full-time dairy farmer for 27 years. With an
undergraduate degree in philosophy and music, Thicke isn't the sort of
agribusiness talking head who usually ends up as ag secretary. He's more of a
visionary.

"What exactly does the secretary of agriculture do?" asked somebody in the
audience, as if to suggest that if the position were eliminated altogether,
maybe nobodv would even notice.

Laura Krouse, local conservationist and owner of Abbe Hills Farm, spoke up: "In
the past, all the agriculture secretary did was regulate. The job is wide open.
They could have ideas and promote ideas."

Which is exactly what Mr. Thicke is all about. He argued that the agriculture
secretary has real work to do that is vital to Iowa and to the nation. Rather
than spout generalities and campaign rhetoric, Thicke offered up practical
solutions to pressing problems. He explained that farming today is dependent on
cheap fossil fuel. As oil production declines, the increasing cost of fuel,
fertilizer and pesticides will force food prices up dramatically and send
farmers scurrying for alternatives. He pointed out that whereas corn ethanol
generates 67 percent more energy than it uses to produce, switchgrass (a
perennial native crop) generates 540 percent more energy than it uses. Thicke
proposed the use of "mobile processing" plants that would move from farm to
farm, producing fuel to run the farm from perennial grasses grown right there.
"This would keep money in the pockets of the farmers," he said, adding, "Farmers
are the only ones who sell wholesale and buy retail."

As Thicke spoke of the loss of half of Iowa's topsoil, the need for sustainable
farming and how crucial Iowa is to the nation's food production, it became clear
that it might not matter so much who becomes Iowa's next governor or even who
gets on the Supreme Court. The really important job for the near future is
agriculture secretary. Taking a playful swipe at Bill Northey, the current
secretary, Thicke said, "I don't want to be the secretary of Egg-Recallture."

At the reception after Mr. Thicke's talk we gathered around a table laden with
sumptuous foods, all produced locally. There were vegetables from Abbe Hills
Farm, Sutliff Cider, Ann Booth's famous shortbread, and homemade apple turnovers
made from local, organic apples. It kind of made you proud to be from Iowa. It
also made me hope that 50 years from now, Iowans can still gather around a
home-grown feast like this one.

LOAD-DATE: July 5, 2011

                               The New York Times

              September 1, 1984, Saturday, Late City Final Edition

FUTURES/OPTIONS ;
Grain and Soybeans Mostly Down in Price



BYLINE:
By The Associated Press

SECTION: Section 1; Page 39, Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 356 words


Grain and soybean futures prices were mostly lower yesterday on the Chicago
Board of Trade, as private forecasters began projecting much- needed rainfall in
parts of the Corn Belt.

The soybean crops need rain for good development, and the forecast for rainfall
encouraged selling as it would increase the size of the crop.

Forecasts were not unanimous in predicting rain, said Richard Loewy, senior
grain and oil seed analyst in New York with Prudential-Bache Securities, but
because of the three-day weekend, traders were more inclined to sell than buy.

Corn for delivery in September was lower, and Mr. Loewy said some of the selling
was coming from commercial concerns that operate grain elevators. He said the
recent hot weather could cause the corn to mature earlier than normal, and put
new supplies on the market.

Some sales of corn to the Soviet Union and wheat to China were announced
Thursday by the Agriculture Department.

But sales of wheat to China may fail to meet projections, Mr. Loewy said.
Noting that the Chinese wheat crop is excellent, he said the Chinese might use
the existing disagreement over United States textile agreements to withdraw from
their deal to purchase a minimum amount of United States wheat.

Livestock and meat prices were mixed in quiet trading on the Chicago Mercantile
Exchange.

Traders throughout the livestock markets were reluctant to open new positions
before the three-day weekend, said Robert Holbert, a livestock analyst in
Champaign, Ill., with Conticommodity Services Inc.

He said cattle traders were waiting to see how beef sales go over the holiday
weekend. Movement of cattle from feed lots this week was heavy, Mr. Holbert
said.

Hog traders are awaiting further market indications as well, as the first full
week in September generally sets the tone for fall business, Mr. Holbert said.

The market is also waiting to see the United States Department of Agriculture's
report Sept. 20, on hog and pig inventories. A key figure in the report will be
the farrowing intentions for the December through February period, Mr. Holbert
said. Pork bellies advanced slightly.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1984 The New York Times Company


                             861 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                 December 8, 1991, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

Cuttings;
Now, for Politically Correct Tomatoes: All Hail the Hairy Vetch

BYLINE: By Anne Raver

SECTION: Section 1; Part 2; Page 85; Column 1; Style Desk; Pastimes Page

LENGTH: 1028 words


When the United States Department of Agriculture starts mulching its tomato
patch with a plant called hairy vetch instead of plastic, something is up:
Organic gardening has gone mainstream.

More than a year ago, after a number of meetings with commercial vegetable
growers and horticultural scientists, Dr. Aref A. Abdul-Baki, a plant
physiologist for the Department of Agriculture in Beltsville, Md., decided to
conduct a test with hairy vetch, a nitrogen-fixing legume that has long been
used as an organic means to enrich and hold the soil.

Dr. Abdul-Baki saw it as an ancient solution to a modern problem. For three
decades tomato growers have used plastic to suppress weeds and to warm the soil
in the spring, resulting in early, heavy yields. But plastic costs money -- to
buy and to apply. It's made from oil, a limited resource. It fills up dwindling
landfill space because it's not biodegradable.

Dr. Abdul-Baki kept hearing these concerns as well as worries that nitrogen
fertilizers and herbicides were entering the ground water. And farmers said
their customers were clamoring for organic vegetables.

Enter, hairy vetch.

This green plant, named for its bushy foliage, is a member of the legume family.
Like the edible pea, its roots attract bacteria that can take nitrogen out of
the air trapped in soil and turn it into a form the plant can absorb. When used
as a mulch, this nitrogen-fixing plant has many advantages, scientists have
found.

It keeps the soil cool under midsummer sun, when beds mulched with plastic can
grow too hot. Its thick mat suppresses weeds. And when the vetch is cut and
decomposes, all that nitrogen is slurped up by any tomato seedlings growing in
its midst.

Hairy vetch also seems to discourage a tomato enemy, the loathsome Colorado
potato beetle, which may be confused by the hairy vetch's smell.

So long, plastic. So long, synthetic nitrogen. So long, herbicides and
pesticides. Hello, organic tomatoes.

The use of mulch to control weeds, pests and insects is an age-old practice. But
it waned during America's love affair with petroleum products.

"The 50's were the years when the polymer chemists made a lot of synthetics out
of petroleum," Dr. Abdul-Baki said. "And we had all these pesticides and sprays
that let us produce attractive, healthy plants. And developing plant varieties
that were insect- and disease-resistant wasn't a high priority."

But as the history of DDT showed, heavy pesticide use actually encourages the
selective breeding of the most resistant insects. "Without realizing it, we were
engaged in a breeding program against mankind," Dr. Abdul-Baki said.

Scientists are trying to develop varieties that are biologically resistant to
insects and disease, but that takes time. Meanwhile, using a plant like hairy
vetch can help produce a healthier, less expensive tomato and not pollute the
environment.

About 40 percent of Florida's vegetable cropland is covered with plastic, Dr.
Abdul-Baki says. "And the total amount of plastic used in the world for
vegetable production could circle the earth about 41 times," he said. "It has a
tremendous pollution factor because it's not fully degradable. It's a mess, and
the environmentalists do not like it."

In the test, scientists planted the hairy vetch seed in September 1990. The
legume developed a hearty root system and grew a good 12 inches before cold
weather slowed growth to a minimum. When temperatures warmed up in March and
April, it took off again.

By April 29, the hairy vetch in Beltsville was up to Dr. Abdul-Baki's chest --
about four feet tall. That day, it was mowed to one inch high.

On May 1, the tomato seedlings were planted right into the middle of the hairy
vetch. No tilling, no turning, no disturbing the soil.

"We have designed a mower that runs over the vetch, chops it up and dumps it
right in position," Dr. Abdul-Baki said. "Then we drill a three-inch hole and
stick the seedling in."

At first the seedlings were difficult to see in the thick green mulch. But a
month later, the tomato plants were 25 inches high. And by harvest time, plants
grown in the vetch mulch yielded 45 tons an acre. Plots with no mulch at all
averaged 19 tons an acre; plastic-mulched plots, 35 tons an acre.

So the vetch had won, thumbs up. And the boisterous beds needed little
fertilizer, fewer herbicides and pesticides and less water.

"That thick mat is like a blanket," Dr. Abdul-Baki said. "It reduces evaporation
from the soil, so it saves water." It also kept the plants cool. "The soil
surface was about 35 degrees lower in the middle of the day than under plastic
mulch," he said.

Beds mulched with hairy vetch had hardly any Colorado potato beetles. Beds
mulched with plastic were heavily infested.

"Our entomologist speculated that the beetle may be attracted by the tomato
smell," Dr. Abdul-Baki said. "When the vetch is cut, its smell dilutes the fumes
from the tomato plant and may confuse the insect."

Growing hairy vetch with tomatoes may also cut down on disease. It is a form of
crop rotation, which farmers have practiced since the beginnings of civilization
in Mesopotamia. But in Beltsville, where the hairy vetch research continues,
scientists are speeding up the process -- by planting tomatoes right in the
hairy vetch. In September, they pulled up the old tomato plants and then
reseeded the untilled fields with more hairy vetch.

"The more you dig, the more you disturb the soil," said Dr. Abdul-Baki, standing
in his field of hairy vetch. "Most of the organic material is near the surface,
and by tilling, you're dumping it down and bringing up the poorer soil. The more
you leave it alone, the better off you are."

Adventurous gardeners who live in areas where temperatures are still hovering
around 40 degrees Fahrenheit may want to plant hairy vetch now for next year.
That temperature range is what it takes for the seed to germinate and roots to
grow. Gardeners in colder climates should wait until early spring. "We haven't
tried this, but there's no reason why it wouldn't work," Dr. Abdul-Baki said.

To locate seed, call your local extension agent or a farm supply store.

LOAD-DATE: December 8, 1991

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Photos: A test using hairy vetch as mulch, left, averaged 45 tons of
tomatoes an acre. Where no mulch was used, right, the yield was 19 tons an acre.
With plastic mulch, it was 35 tons an acre. Dr. Aref Abdul-Baki prefers thick
hairy vetch to plastic mulch. (United States Department of Agriculture)

                   Copyright 1991 The New York Times Company


                             862 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                         Telegraph Herald (Dubuque, IA)

                            November 21, 2004 Sunday

Record crops just part of noteworthy November; Agency approves use of fungicides
to fight Asian Soybean Rust

BYLINE: JOHN EVERLY

SECTION: Agriculture; Pg. b7

LENGTH: 836 words


November has been a month of revelations for agriculture.

We learned on Nov. 12 that farmers will harvest the biggest corn and soybean
crops on record. Not just records, but records by far. Tri-state area farmers
reported excellent yields.

Agriculture officials planned a defense against Asian Soybean Rust after the
fungus was discovered in a Louisiana soybean field Nov. 10. Last week, the
Environmental Protection Agency announced its emergency approval of fungicides
to combat the disease.

Goodbye, Ann Veneman. The secretary of agriculture tendered her resignation to
President Bush last week, ending four years at the helm of the U.S. Department
of Agriculture marked by natural disasters, a mad cow disease scare, market
highs and lows and controversy.

Around here, she might be remembered as the agriculture secretary who preserved
the pork checkoff after a majority of pork producers defeated the program in a
September 2000 referendum.

*

Some good news for dairy producers - the ag department raised its milk price
forecasts for 2004-05 from last month because of stronger demand for milkfat.
The all-milk price is forecast at $13.75 to $14.45 per hundredweight for
2004-05.

Meanwhile, the ag department predicts dairy farm net cash income will average
$112,900 this year, up from $69,300 last year and the 1998-2000 average of
$84,900.

Remember, these are national averages, and actual net cash income among
individual farms will vary greatly. Overall, net farm income is expected to grow
by more than 10 percent this year, to a record $73.7 billion, up 24.5 percent
from 2003.

*

A dairy industry self-help program is claiming some of the credit for
stabilizing milk supplies and prices.

Cooperatives Working Together is now in its second year. Participating producers
fund the program through a voluntary 5-cent assessment on each 100 pounds of
milk they market. The money raised is used to fund a dairy product export
assistance program and a herd retirement program to reduce milk production.
Cooperatives Working Together is administered by the National Milk Producers
Federation.

In the latest round of bids accepted during October, about 715 bids representing
around 2 billion pounds of milk volume are under review.

"Our goal with this second go-round is to remove 870 million pounds of milk,"
said National Milk spokesman Chris Galen.

Galen said successful bidders likely will be notified this month. The number of
bids offered increased from the first round.

"We have had greater participation in the second year from upper Midwest
cooperatives," Galen said.

In the project's first year, 299 bids were accepted to remove 608 million pounds
of milk from the market. CWT officials estimate their program gave milk prices a
59 cent per hundredweight boost between October 2003 and September 2004.

Walt Wosje, CWT's chief operating officer, said the program was just one factor
contributing to the market rebound, though.

"This past winter and spring, we saw what was akin to a perfect storm of factors
pulling together to raise milk prices from their record lows. Between CWT's
activities, the Canadian border being closed, and increased milk demand, milk
prices really rebounded quickly," Wosje said.

"Unfortunately, that illustrates our concern about the market's volatility. CWT
activities, like this herd retirement and our export assistance program, are
meant to not only strengthen milk prices but also stabilize them. We can't
simply depend on market factors. Our increased targets this year reflect our
understanding that we won't necessarily have all the other factors working with
us this time."

Participation in CWT is open to all cooperatives and to independent dairy
farmers not affiliated with a cooperative.  More information on the program is
available online at cwt.coop.

*

As we give thanks for our many blessings this week, the Archdiocesan Pastoral
Center in Dubuque reminds us to consider our rural neighbors who are
experiencing extreme economic hardship.

The center will again conduct its "Rural Christmas Outreach" project through the
Rural Life Office in cooperation with Catholic Charities. The project helps fill
in the gaps not covered by the many other civic organizations and agencies
serving the needs of people. Rural Outreach recipients are those folks who
cannot meet their basic needs and who might easily go unnoticed or be ineligible
under other existing programs.

Funds will be collected through Dec. 8.

Those who do not qualify for other existing programs can apply for assistance by
writing to Rural Christmas Outreach, Archdiocesan Pastoral Center, P.O. Box 479,
Dubuque, Iowa 52004-0479. Include your full name and address. Also include the
number of adults and children with all their ages.

Monetary contributions may be sent to the same address.

Everly, a Telegraph Herald reporter, was farm director of Dubuque radio station
KDTH for nearly 10 years. His e-mail address is jeverly@wcinet.com.

LOAD-DATE: November 21, 2004

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                  Copyright 2004 Woodward Communications, Inc.


                             863 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                     March 2, 1996, Saturday, ALL EDITIONS

SCIENCE WATCH;
ARCHAEOLOGY, ENVIRONMENT & MEDICINE;
Sowing hybrid oats

BYLINE: Compiled by Mike Toner

SECTION: SCIENCE; Pg. 01E

LENGTH: 401 words


They're not your father's Cheerios. To combat the spread of an airborne fungus
called crown rust, which annually destroys $ 30 million worth of oats in the
United States, scientists have added something new to the country's amber waves
of grain - a cross between corn and oats.

Researchers at the U.S. Department of Agriculture say the corn-oat hybrids,
which look like oats, carry up to eight corn genes that confer resistance to
crown rust. In time, they hope to infuse hybrid oats with more of corn's
admirable traits, including heat tolerance, better grain composition, and
increased productivity.

Although the corn-oat hybrids are the widest combination of crop species yet
produced that are known to be fertile, they aren't the only mixed grain to
emerge from the laboratory. British researchers have recently managed to cross
wheat and corn to produce a hybrid wheat.

Making viol less vile

Generations of fiddle players, it seems, knew what they were talking about. In a
word, grandpa was right. The older the instrument, the sweeter the sound.

Researchers at South Bank University in London have been fiddling around in the
laboratory themselves and their tests of spruce wood, commonly used as the
sounding membrane in stringed instruments, show that exposure to high humidities
and continuous vibration increased the wood's stiffness, and reduced the damping
coefficient, a change that is thought to improve sound quality.

"Although for the best care of a musical instrument, both high and low
humidities should be avoided," the researchers say, "the results suggest that at
intermediate or high humidities, the sound quality may be improved by regular
playing."

Satellite to be visible

The satellite that broke free from space shuttle Columbia will be visible next
week in Atlanta and across the country.

The satellite and its dangling 12-mile cord can be seen by the naked eye just
before sunrise as it travels through the sky from the West Coast to the East.

"It should be an absolutely awesome sight because the 20 kilometers of tether,
assuming that it's all strung out, will be definitel visible," astronaut Jeffrey
Hoffman said from Columbia. Observers will "actually see a line moving through
the sky."

NASA says the satellite will be visible in Atlanta at 6: 15 a.m. Friday, and
5:30 a.m. March 9. Each sighting will last from one to three minutes/

LOAD-DATE: July 17, 1996

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC:  Illustration: Man playing violin / Paige Braddock / Staff

                    Copyright 1996 The Atlanta Constitution


                             864 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                 March 2, 1996, Saturday, CONSTITUTION EDITION

SCIENCE WATCH;
ARCHAEOLOGY, ENVIRONMENT & MEDICINE;
Sowing hybrid oats

BYLINE: Compiled by Mike Toner

SECTION: SCIENCE; Pg. 01E

LENGTH: 401 words


They're not your father's Cheerios. To combat the spread of an airborne fungus
called crown rust, which annually destroys $ 30 million worth of oats in the
United States, scientists have added something new to the country's amber waves
of grain - a cross between corn and oats.

Researchers at the U.S. Department of Agriculture say the corn-oat hybrids,

Although the corn-oat hybrids are the widest combination of crop species yet
produced that are known to be fertile, they aren't the only mixed grain to
emerge from the laboratory. British researchers have recently managed to cross

Making viol less vile

Generations of fiddle players, it seems, knew what they were talking about. In a
