                             865 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                                The Toronto Star

                   November 24, 1992, Tuesday, FINAL EDITION

Trade deal protests heating up in France

BYLINE: REUTERS NEW AGENCY

SECTION: BUSINESS TODAY; Pg. D1

LENGTH: 466 words


French opposition to a European Community farm- trade deal with the United
States heated up yesterday with the government calling for more talks and
farmers turning their wrath on yet another symbol of U.S. culture, Coca-Cola.

About 300 farmers burned tires and wood in front of a Coca-Cola factory in the
south Paris suburb of Grigny yesterday, in the latest of a growing wave of
protests targeting U.S. interests. French farmers are gearing up for massive
countrywide demonstrations later this week to pressure the government to veto
the agreement.

France's largest farming group also called on farmers across Europe to converge
next Monday on the eastern French city of Strasbourg, the seat of the European
Parliament, to show solidarity, the Associated Press reported.

German farmers will be there in large numbers, farming group officials said. The
German government has urged France not to torpedo the accord in order to avoid a
transatlantic trade war.

French grain farmers joined in a rising chorus of calls for the government to
exercise its veto and scrap the U.S.-EC accord, which cuts exports of subsidized
European crops and limits exports of oilseeds.

Over the weekend, farmers picketed branches of the McDonald's hamburger chain,
prompting the company to say it sold only French agricultural produce in France.

French agriculture minister Jean-Pierre Soisson said his government will ask for
a special meeting of EC foreign and farm ministers, probably next week, to
discuss the U.S.-EC agreement.

France, a major farm producer and subsidizer, vehemently opposes the accord,
which was reached Friday and would slash EC oilseed production and subsidized
food exports.

Britain, current president of the EC, said it has not yet received the request
for a special meeting. Like other EC nations, however, Britain has welcomed the
deal as a move to jumpstart a wider world trade pact being negotiated by GATT.

Underlying that optimism, the chief of the Geneva-based General Agreement on
Tariffs and Trade, Arthur Dunkel, summoned negotiators yesterday to relaunch the
long-running Uruguay Round of trade talks.

Dunkel called for a meeting Thursday of the trade negotiations committee, the
panel steering talks to free up trade in sectors from agriculture to banking.

"This should lead to a package of results acceptable, and of benefit, to all the
participants," he said.

But French Prime Minister Pierre Beregovoy insisted Sunday his country would not
accept the farm deal and for the first time, said it might use its right of veto
in the EC as a last resort.

The government would first seek parliamentary support for its tough stance,
however, and request the solidarity of its EC partners in demanding what he
called a fairer deal for farmers.


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1992

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: PHOTO: Pierre Beregovoy

                  Copyright 1992 Toronto Star Newspapers, Ltd.


                             866 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

               November 21, 1991, Thursday, Late Edition - Final

Why We Might Regret Grain Generosity

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 273 words


To the Editor:
 For some time, voices have been raised in the United States favoring massive
food aid to the Soviet Union, most notably the voice of Agriculture Secretary
Edward R. Madigan. True, Mr. Madigan's voice has been muted lately. But he has a
large constituency in favor of massive shipments of wheat, corn and soy beans.
The legislation for such is already in existence.

To explain: America's largess of grain can be given to any country of the
President's choosing at negotiated interest rates, with as long as three years
to pay, under the Commodity Credit Corporation Act.

Under this act, President Nixon enabled Soviet grain buyers to wipe out our
emergency wheat reserves in the single month of July 1972. A sharp increase in
United States food prices followed this grain-on-credit move.

Such dollar-denominated credits are guaranteed by the Commodity Credit
Corporation, which gets its funds from the Agriculture Department's annual
budget of more than $40 billion, financed by the Treasury. The recipient country
may be careful never to default on the loans. But the loans are continuously
additive to the Federal budget deficit, at least from one accounting year to the
next.

The Soviet Union is the largest importer of corn from the United States. Because
of unusual drought conditions in the corn-producing areas of the Midwest, the
United States corn harvest this year may be low. A massive offtake of corn and
other food grains and feed grains at this time, as under President Nixon in
1972, may cause a sharp increase in food prices at home.

BEVERLY KITCHING
Springfield, Ill., Nov. 5, 1991

LOAD-DATE: November 21, 1991

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Drawing

TYPE: Letter

                   Copyright 1991 The New York Times Company


                             867 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

                     August 2, 1988, Tuesday, DAILY EDITION

Farmers face seed shortages, price hikes

BYLINE: Reuters

SECTION: SECTION 1, NEWS; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 467 words

DATELINE: Washington,DC


  The drought in the U.S. heartland this summer not only dealt a devastating
blow to the 1988 grain harvest, but will be felt next year when farmers buy seed
for 1989 crops.

Farmers anxious to plant more crops next year to make up for this season's
drought-reduced output will face tighter and more expensive supplies of
commercial seed and a shortage of the high-yielding varieties, U.S. seed
industry sources say.

And a reduction in the supply and quality of U.S. seeds could impact on soybean
growers in Italy and grain sorghum producers in Venezuela as well as corn
growers in Iowa.

''The seed supply will be tight at the acreage levels we had this year and if
the acreage increases very much, it could be very tight,'' Bill Schapaugh,
executive vice-president of the American Seed Trade Association, said.

''In any event, there will be inadequate supplies of the preferred hybrids and
this could possibly affect crop yields,'' Schapaugh said.

U.S. farmers spent more than US$3.5 billion this past year to plant almost 6
million tons of commercial seed, ranging from the major field crops of corn,
wheat and soybeans to grass and alfalfa seeds for pastures and conservation
land.

While the U.S. seed industry is a huge business domestically, the U.S. has also
long been the world's largest exporter of seed. Next year's seed exports are
projected to be a record US$400 million.

More than 100 countries regularly import U.S. seeds every year. Canada, Italy,
France, Japan and Mexico are among the biggest buyers.

But the biggest impact of the anticipated seed shortfall will fall on U.S.
farmers, who for the first time in several years, are likely to significantly
expand crop acreage in the next planting season.

Because of higher crop prices and less acreage restrictions in U.S. federal farm
programs, private analysts have estimated that U.S. farmers could increase wheat
plantings by 9 million to 12 million acres, corn plantings by 6 million to 8
million acres and soybean plantings by more than 2 million acres.

About half the U.S. wheat acreage is planted with commercial seed and about 70%
of the nation's soybean acreage is started with store-bought seed. Virtually all
of the corn planted in the U.S. is now planted with commercial seed corn
hybrids.

The use of corn hybrids, a cross between two different types of corn varieties,
has soared since World War II and has caused a tripling of U.S. corn yields in
that time period.

But this year's seed-corn hybrid yields will be down sharply in some areas,
industry officials said.

To offset the short U.S. supply and meet the projected increased demand for seed
next year, major U.S. seed producers are planning large increases in winter
production of seed corn and other grains.




LOAD-DATE: December 9, 1997

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: NEWS

                       Copyright 1988 Financial Post Ltd.


                             868 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                     Deseret Morning News (Salt Lake City)

                            October 27, 2013 Sunday

Utah farmers, ranchers want immigration reforms to meet labor needs

BYLINE: Marjorie Cortez Deseret News

LENGTH: 1137 words


PARK CITY ? Lino Aquino makes it look easy. Riding horseback, he and seven dogs
make quick work of moving 1,200 sheep down a gentle slope in Summit County. As
the dogs gather the stragglers, Aquino waits on a hillside. "If you're just
patient and take your time, the sheep calm down and he can put them where he
wants them.

The sheep get used to him," said Brian Bitner, whose family runs about 6,000
head of sheep in Utah, Idaho and Montana. Aquino, who is Peruvian, has worked
for the Bitners on a series of three-year contracts since 1999. He has entered
the United States on H-2A visas, which permit him to stay in the country up to
three years to herd sheep. The permits must be renewed annually. "He's a good
guy. He knows what he's doing," Bitner said. But training herders takes time.
Although most come from rural Peru, some have not ridden horses or worked with
herding dogs, Bitner said. Some don't know how to drive, so it is a challenge to
prepare them to haul water to the sheep wintering on the west desert. "If one
guy can teach another, then you end up OK," Bitner said. The sheep industry has
exemptions to the H-2A visa that are not available to other livestock producers,
dairy operators and growers. Those industries must abide to the strict limits of
the farm worker visa, which is intended to provide a workforce for temporary,
seasonal work. Workers who enter the country under that program can work for one
employer doing one type of work. Typically, a worker may remain in the country
for 10 months but is supposed to return to his or her native country. That
arrangement doesn't suit the labor needs of the dairy industry, says Brad
Bateman, whose family dairy farm in Utah County milks 6,800 cows three times a
day. Dairy farming is neither seasonal nor temporary, which is something Bateman
said he hopes Congress will acknowledge in the immigration reform debate in
Washington, D.C. "The thing we have to keep in mind as we talk about this issue
and look at it, it's not about cheap labor. It's about labor ? period. It's
about getting a workforce, Bateman said during a recent farm tour offered by the
Utah Farm Bureau. Whether it's harvesting fruit, herding sheep or working in
processing plants, most agriculture jobs in the United States are not filled by
Americans. Yet federal law requires producers to advertise to domestic workers
first, although they rarely last long on the job. "I think the record we have
had is one worked all day once," said Robert McMullin, a Payson fruit farmer who
grows sweet cherries, peaches, apples, nectarines and pluots. When growers like
McMullin cannot assemble enough workers, crops go to waste in the fields. This
summer, it was the sweet cherries. A shortage of farm laborers also affects
consumers, says Randy Parker, CEO of the Utah Farm Bureau. All segments of
agriculture need a productive, efficient workforce that meets their labor need
throughout the production cycle, he said. "All of those things play into
abundance, quality and cost for the American consumer," Parker said. McMullin
said he would like Congress to change immigration laws to give workers and
producers more flexibility. "We would really like to have a program that is
easier and more user-friendly for us ? something that would be more flexible and
allows us to trade (workers) with the dairy guys, with the floral guys," he
said. "We'd like to not only be able to use them in the field. We'd like to use
them in the processing plant." The exemptions granted the sheep industry under
the H-2A program make it the envy of other agriculture industries "because it
works," says Larry Williams, attorney for the Western Range Association. While
many agriculture industries would benefit from changes to the farm visa program,
it is important that sheep ranchers not lose ground in the process. "We have a
very small part of the industry under the H-2A program. We're a little concerned
about gross caps because of the size of our industry and the needs that we have.
We might just get run over," Williams said. Now that the government shutdown has
ended, Parker said he hopes Congress will once again focus on immigration
reform. He and other business interests in the state are lobbying members of
Utah's congressional delegation about immigration reforms they need. ?Our
standpoint is, let?s just get something done that makes sense. If we have to
tweak it as we go forward, let?s do that," he said. From a national perspective,
the American Farm Bureau Federation wants comprehensive immigration reform to
include ?an adjustment of status for experienced but unauthorized agricultural
workers who currently reside in the United States,? according to a position
paper published in September. This would include an obligation to work in
agriculture for a set number of years. Once that requirement is met, workers
could seek permanent legal status. The federation also seeks an uncapped
agricultural worker visa program that will ?ensure agriculture?s future legal
workforce? and give workers and producers alike more flexibility. Sheep ranchers
like Bitner agree that other industries would benefit from more flexibility, but
he notes there are costs associated with maintaining a workforce. Bitner
provides his herders room and board as required under current H-2A regulations.
The herders live in campers among the sheep they tend and they send their
grocery lists to Bitner via iPhones. Aquino has solar power to light his camper,
propane to heat it, and depending upon where the camper is parked and the
antenna is aimed, he can watch television to help break up the monotony and
loneliness. He keeps in touch with friends and family via Facebook and other
social networks. The toughest aspect of the job is Utah's harsh weather, Aquino
said. "The winter is a little cold. It's a little hard." While he's separated
from his family for three-year stints, herding has enabled him to purchase a
home for his family in Peru and pay college tuition for his eldest son, who is
studying administration and marketing, Aquino said. "(The herders) do pretty
amazingly well. I've never had one smoke, and most of them don't drink. They're
good, honest, pretty decent people," Bitner said. Parker agrees. "The reality is
they?re not jobs Americans are willing to do. Let?s give them the help they need
to provide the service they?re willing to do, and quite honestly, they do a
pretty darned good job at it," he said. The Utah Compact, which urges treating
immigrants with humanity and dignity, provides a good framework for the debate
on the national level, Parker said. "Let?s get that done on a national basis
because it is the federal government?s obligation and responsibility to do it,"
he said, "so let?s get it done. Let?s quit playing around.? Email:
marjorie@deseretnews.com

LOAD-DATE: October 28, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                 Copyright 2013 The Deseret News Publishing Co.


                             869 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                            Waikato Times (Hamilton)

                          September 3, 1997, Wednesday

Bigger but fewer farmers ahead in US dairy scene

BYLINE: FOX Andrea

SECTION: FARMING Pg. 24

LENGTH: 260 words


US dairy farms, some already with 15,000 cows, will get bigger but there will be
fewer of them in 10 years, say US Agriculture Department economists.

Milk production and yields in the US will also increase, says economics branch
chief Terry Crawford in Washington.

The US is the world's biggest milk producer with 68 billion kilograms a year.

Mr Crawford does not share the view of some of his department's colleagues that
New Zealand and Australia will be world dairy market leaders in the future.

The US would overtake them as cow nutrition, genetics and farm management
improved and farmers decided if they were in the business of dairy or feed
production, he said.

US dairying yield was improving by up to 2 per cent a year, he said.

Urban encroachment into dairy farming areas and environmental pressure on
farmers were forcing many to sell and move into undeveloped dairying areas where
their money could buy two or more farms.

US farmers did not need much land for dairy feedlot farming but a dry climate
was essential for year-round calving, he said.

In desert areas such as Roswell, in New Mexico, a farmer could set up a 65ha
dairy operation for under $ US5 million including 2000 cows at $ US2500 each. To
do the same in traditional dairying areas like Wisconsin or Minnesota, would
cost $ US10 million and up.

Midwest areas such as South Dakota, Nebraska and Kansas, were recruiting dairy
farmers with promises of tax breaks and other incentives, he said. Dairy farmers
injected a lot of money into local economies.

LOAD-DATE: September 8, 1997

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                  Copyright 1997 Fairfax New Zealand Newspaper


                             870 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                              The Bismarck Tribune

                             March 7, 2013 Thursday

North Dakota's economic model has changed

SECTION: OPINION; Pg. A8

LENGTH: 421 words


Explaining what North Dakota is to people who do not live here has become more
and more difficult. A recent Sunday Tribune story addressed the mingling of
nuclear missile silos with oil rigs and wells in the western half of the state.
Another story talked about the top-to-bottom maintenance of the nation's only
coal gasification plant.

Construction of the first refinery to be built in the United States in the last
several decades will begin in Dickinson this spring. A recent report from the
federal Agriculture Department put the value of crops produced in the state at
$11 billion last year.

North Dakota's economic model has changed - for the better.

By a combination of intention, hard work and luck, the state has diversified its
economic profile.

For much of North Dakota's history, dry-land wheat farming defined the state. It
fed a dependency on the railroad, a cyclic wheat market, weather and the federal
government. It finely honed conservative political and economic thinking of many
of the state's citizens.

Farming remains key to the state's well-being. It represents the largest slice
in the state economic pie. And although wheat remains key to farm operations,
the state has become a bonanza of specialty crops well beyond sugar beets, corn
and other small grains.

It ships cattle to Kazakhstan, a former Soviet Union member state.

Value-added agriculture has become a part of the state's economic vocabulary.

"We're doing a better job at farming now than we every did before in history,"
Dan Wogsland, executive director of the North Dakota Grain Growers Association,
told the Tribune.

Oil and gas represent a big piece of the pie. Production taxes make up an
estimated 20 percent of the state government revenue.

In those lean years, Bismarck-Mandan's economy grew by 1 or 2 percent,. Now it's
picked up the pace, hitting as much as 3 percent annually, according to
Bismarck-Mandan Chamber of Commerce President Kelvin Hullet.

It has been a long climb to this high point.

Through the terms of four governors - George Sinner, Ed Schafer, John Hoeven
and, now Jack Dalrymple - the state has pushed and pulled at policies supporting
growth, entreprenuership, research, economic development and jobs creation.

It has been a sometimes frustrating, hit-and-miss strategy; however, the people
of North Dakota have kept working to stem the flow of outward-bound young people
by creating jobs and new business and industry.

It's an effort that justified the headline on the Tribune's Sunday Money story:
"North Dakota is strong."

LOAD-DATE: March 7, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


       Copyright 2013 The Bismarck Tribune, a division of Lee Enterprises
                              All Rights Reserved


                             871 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                     The Press (Christchurch, New Zealand)

                          February 28, 2004, Saturday

Popular Canty farm adviser

BYLINE: CREAN Mike  EARL Leonard

SECTION: FEATURES; GENERAL; Pg. 15; MAIN LIVES OBITUARIES; D

LENGTH: 586 words


Len Earl didn't miss a Christchurch Show or New Zealand Cup meeting at Riccarton
for 75 years. It wasn't just that he enjoyed them -- he saw them as essential
for meeting and mixing with clients.

When the 89-year-old agricultural adviser and seed company manager died in
Christchurch this month, many former clients recalled the farming and business
advice and financial backing he had given them and his dry sense of humour.

The descendant of a gold prospector who came from the Victorian fields to the
West Coast, Earl was born in Timaru to a Makikihi farming family. The family
moved to Christchurch when he was 10, and he attended St Bede's College from
1928 to 1932.

Earl worked on the Makikihi farm before completing a diploma in agriculture at
Lincoln College. There he was one of a close group of live-in students who ran
the college farm to pay for their keep.

Graduating in 1935, he worked on a remote farm in the Marlborough Sounds,
accessible only by sea, before returning to Lincoln as a foundation student on
the new Valuation and Farm Management course.

Armed with his second diploma, Earl joined the Department of Agriculture at
Palmerston North as a farm adviser. He married Janet Howell in 1941, and they
had four children.

During World War 2, Earl tried to enlist with the navy and air force but was
turned down on health grounds. The Department of Agriculture appealed for him to
be exempt from military service so he could do essential work. This involved, at
first, supervising flax growing in South Canterbury for the manufacture of ropes
for the war effort.

He was then transferred to Auckland and put in charge of vegetable growing near
Pukekohe for supplies to United States forces in the Pacific. Near the end of
the war he moved to the department's head office at Wellington and then to
Timaru.

After the war, Earl opened and headed a new office for the department at
Waimate. For several years he gave weekly radio talks on farming topics, until a
throat operation damaged his voice.

In 1948 he was asked by family connections to take over the Timaru grain and
seeds firm of James Meehan and Sons, which Earl's grandfather had founded in
1913. He managed the company until he sold it and retired in 1981.

Earl showed an astute grasp of business and finance, and the company prospered.
He guided many farmers in technical and financial issues and traded on world
futures markets. He helped many young farmers make a start, backing his shrewd
judgment of their mettle rather than being influenced by "who they were".

He was a canny investor and became a part-owner and director of a Mount Somers
clay company supplying Auckland potteries.

The Earls moved to Christchurch in 1993. Len Earl was a fervent Catholic who
enjoyed the Church's traditions and history. He kept abreast of current affairs
and held strong views -- although he was a quiet man who seldom engaged in
argument.

The loving and trustworthy husband and father experienced seven generations of
his family from his great-grandmother to his own great- grandchildren.

Along with flowers on Len Earl's coffin was an arrangement of vegetables and
wheat stalks, reflecting his lifelong interest in cropping. --Mike Crean

Leonard (Len) Earl; born Timaru, October 14, 1914; died Christchurch, February
10, 2004. Survived by his wife Janet, sons Peter and Frank, daughters Margaret
and Mary Anne, nine grandchildren and two great- grandchildren.

--------------------

CAPTION:

Len Earl

LOAD-DATE: February 29, 2004

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                       Copyright 2004 Fairfax New Zealand

                   The Vancouver Province (British Columbia)

                     August 16, 2001 Thursday Final Edition

U.S. subsidies have growers in sour mood

SOURCE: News Services

SECTION: News; B.C. News; Pg. A21

LENGTH: 108 words

DATELINE: KELOWNA

KELOWNA -- Okanagan apple growers meet in Summerland on Monday to hammer out an
industry-saving strategy.

Orchardists, foundering after five years of bad crops and plunging prices, want
to reach a consensus before approaching Agriculture Minister John van Dongen.

Part of the problem is a subsidy war with the U.S. and Europe. American apple
growers received $100 million in direct subsidies in June and expect to get
another $150 million.

"Americans have increased their subsidies by 700 per cent since they signed the
World Trade Agreement in 1996 saying they'll reduce subsidies to farmers," said
Rutland grower Leo Touw.

                             873 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

               August 13, 1981, Thursday, Late City Final Edition

BUSINESS DIGEST;
THURSDAY, AUGUST 13, 1981;
The Economy

SECTION: Section D; Page 1, Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 735 words


A two-day logjam in trans-Atlantic air travel cleared up swiftly after Canadian
air traffic controllers called off a boycott of United States flights. In
return, Ottawa promised to take part in an inquiry into the controllers'
contention that the strike by American controllers had created safety hazards.
(Page A1.) Airline executives and many pilots say that flights during the
strike, carried on under a contingency flight plan developed by the F.A.A. last
year, are as safe as in normal times. (A1.)

Retail sales rose 1.3 percent in July, the Commerce Department reported.
Although it was the second consecutive large monthly increase, economists did
not see it as a sign of economic resurgence. Murray L. Weidenbaum, chairman of
the President's Council of Economic Advisers, acknowledged in a radio interview
that the nation might be in its second recession in two years. (D1.)

The Agriculture Department forecast the second-largest corn crop in history, a
record wheat crop and a bumper soybean crop. It also foresaw another sharp drop
in Soviet grain production, which could mean more large imports from the United
States. (D2.)

Companies

G.M. will cooperate with Isuzu and Suzuki in building and selling ''mini-cars''
smaller than the Chevrolet Chevette. The three companies hope to gain a
competetive edge in the growing world market for small, fuel-efficient cars with
an engine displacement of 1,000 cubic centimeters or less. G.M. will buy 5
percent of Suzuki's stock, and Suzuki and Isuzu will each buy blocks of the
other's stock. G.M.  already owns 34.2 percent of Isuzu. (D1.)

I.B.M., in a marked change of direction, entered the personal computer market.
Its new desk-top model for use in homes, schools and businesses is expected to
pose a stiff challenge to Apple and Tandy, the leaders in the fast-growing
field. (D1.)

Cablevision, one of few remaining privately held cable companies, won the Boston
cable franchise over Warner-Amex Cable Communications. Cablevision plans to
provide subscribers in the 240,000-home franchise with 52 basic channels for
just $2 a month.  (D1.)

Four companies violated antitrust law by making sure they charged identical
prices for a gasoline additive, an F.T.C. judge ruled. He said the companies -
Ethyl, Du Pont, PPG Industries andNalco Chemical - had used press releases to
alert one another to price changes. He found no price-fixing conspiracy,
however. (D5.)

Bechtel will join Morrison-Knudsen International in a $1.5 billion, 10-year
effort to exploit a copper-and-gold bonanza in the jungles of Papua New Guinea.
(D5.)

Energy

A debate over whether to allow the export of Alaskan oil to Japan is again under
way in Congress and the White House. Backers argue that exporting Alaskan oil,
now prohibited, could lead to cheaper oil for some Americans and substantial tax
benefits for the Government.  Critics balk at possibly giving oil companies big
new profits. (D1.)

The Administration has rejected a World Bank proposal to set up a special
affiliate for expanded lending for energy projects in developing countries. But
even without the affiliate, officials at the bank said, disbursements for energy
projects have been rising.  (D15.)

Markets

The stock market was mixed in active trading, with some airline issues posting
the best gains. The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 4.09 points at
945.21. (D8.) Interest rates rose, ending a three-day rally that lifted prices
and cut yields substantially after last week's heavy Treasury financing. (D11.)
The dollar fell in hectic trading, then recouped most of its losses. Gold prices
climbed to $420 an ounce on the Comex, then fell back to $404 at the close.
(D12.) Grain and soybean futures prices were mixed. (D12.)

Today's Columns

Multiple-beam antennas that can receive signals from more than one satellite at
once are ready for marketing, some manufacturers believe. The new generation of
antennas will be needed, they say, to accommodate the increasing number of
domestic satellites. Technology. (D2.)

A geographical approach to the search for stock opportunities is suggested by
one investment expert. He concentrates on identifying growth companies in the
Great Lakes region. Market Place. (D8.)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1981 The New York Times Company

                              Journal of Commerce

                           February 20, 1987, Friday

3RD ERA OF US FARMING?

BYLINE: (AP)

SECTION: COMMODITIES, Pg. 12A

LENGTH: 530 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


A third era of U.S. Agriculture may be in the works and a new form of rugged
individualism might be one of its ideals, according to a report in the American
Land Forum conservation magazine.

Charles E. Little says in his article that Agriculture I lasted through the
early part of this century and included the great movement of people westward
cross the plains and mountains, an agriculture of settlement and subsistence.

"This was the agriculture of those who got on the land first, for whom to
succeed was simply to survive," he said.

In Agriculture II, which Mr. Little said began in the early 1930s with the
Roosevelt administration's Agriculture Adjustment Act and carried on by
succeeding programs, government prices supports and other benefits helped boost
yields and reduce the number of farms required to feed a nation.

"The subsidies entrained by the AAA, together with the advances in mechanized
and chemical agriculture on larger and larger farms, have created a farm economy
so financially attenuated that it cannot adjust downward, as it is now
necessary, without such dire results that the impacts, like those of the steel
industry, reverberate throughout the whole of society," he said.

Mr. Little added: "Agriculture II is oversimplified and therefore vulnerable. It
lacks the strength of diversity. It has outlived its time and the limits of its
resources as surely as did Agriculture I."

The current state of U.S. agriculture, he said, is in as deep an economic
depression as any since the Dust Bowl era of the 1930s.

Mr. Little, an advocate of conservation tillage methods to help save soil and
water, noted the experiences of individual farmers in Alabama, Washington,
Indiana and Maryland who have used mechanical inventiveness and perserverance to
cope with today's hardships. In farming the land wisely and carefully, they are
surviving.

If the first two phases of agriculture were marked by extremes, Mr. Little said,
perhaps some new form - Agriculture III - may be rising from the old elements.

Mr. Little said "some elements of that more ideal future" might include:

* A return to scientific inquiry by farmers themselves, as opposed to reliance
on advisers. Farmers should write articles in scholarly journals.

* The rewarding of professionalsim in agriculture rather than a reward structure
based on acreage, horsepower or chemicals. And there should be a lower capital
requirement for entry into farming.

* An improved social status for farming. The United States has never gone in for
a peasantry. The farmer-proprietor is not a hayseed, but a middle-class
statesman, as they were called in England, a person of culture, learning and
community responsibility.

* Ultimately, economic stability and independence, of the kind that can be
expected in other professions.

"Dentists, for example, spend a great deal of time getting educated, locating a
practice, buying equipment and setting up shop," Mr. Little said. ''They do this
in the expectation of success. Some fail, of course, but they are not supposed
to. They do not receive a subsidy for not practicing. In the end, should farming
be any different?"

LOAD-DATE: January 8, 1997

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                  Copyright 1987 The Journal of Commerce, Inc.

                                 July 16, 2014

Lyon county family to be honored at Iowa State Fair

BYLINE: LeRoy Independent staff

LENGTH: 381  words


The Van Regenmorter family of Inwood will be recognized as one of six recipients
of The Way We Live Award at the 2014 Iowa State Fair. The family will be honored
in an award ceremony on Sunday, August 10, at 10:30 a.m. on the Christensen
Farms Stage I the Paul R. Knapp Animal Learning Center. "Nothing Compares" to
the Iowa State Fair, set for August 7-17.

The Way We Live Award recognizes Iowa families for their hard work and love of
farming. The families each exemplify dedication to animal agriculture and strong
farm values. Each entrant was asked to submit a short essay describing how the
occupation of farming and living on a farm has shaped their lives. Six families
were chosen out of 38 entries from a variety of commodities and areas in Iowa.

Chad and Jody Van Regenmorter and their two daughters, Rebecca, 16, and Emily,
13, farm approximately 1,800 acres of corn, soybeans and oats, and manage a
160-sow farrow operation.The farm has been in their family for three generations
beginning in the 1950s when Chad's grandfather began raising poultry. Chad's
father and brother also work on the family farm or at the family-owned service
station.

Active in their community, Chad and Jody have been members of Farm Bureau, the
Corn Growers Association and the Pork Producers Association as well as several
church groups. They have served in many leadership positions on numerous county
and state boards and are active advocates of educational advancements of
agriculture. When their daughters are away from the farm, Rebecca and Emily both
attend West Lyon Community Schools and are active in 4-H. Rebecca also serves on
the county council and participates in FFA. They will both show hogs at this
year's county fair.

The Van Regenmorter family (pictured above, photo courtesy of the Iowa State
Fair) will receive a prize package including $250 cash, Fair tickets, free
parking and recognition in the Paul R. Knapp Animal Learning Center during the
Fair. The Way-We Live Award is sponsored by WHO News Radio 1040 and Tractor
Supply Company. "Nothing Compares" to the 2014 Iowa State Fair, August 7-17. The
Fairgrounds are located at East 30th and East University Avenue, just 10 minutes
east of downtown Des Moines. For more information, call 800/545-FAIR or visit
iowastatefair.org.

                                US Official News

                           December 17, 2016 Saturday

Delaware poultry farmer named 2016 Nuffield International Farming Scholar

LENGTH: 476  words

DATELINE: New York



  Dover: Delaware Department of Transport has issued the following news release



 Dover-area poultry farmer Georgie Cartanza is the first United States recipient
of a Nuffield International Scholarship, one of 90 farmers from around the world
to participate in the global agricultural scholarship program.





 Cartanza, who recently began work as poultry extension specialist with the
University of Delaware, will be spending 16 weeks overseas studying farming
technology and production efficiencies.



 She will travel to China, Brazil, Canada, Israel, the United Kingdom, France,
Italy and The Netherlands, learning about topics including production needs,
extreme climates, consumer demands, food safety and organic poultry transitions.




 "There have been many advances in farming and technology over the last 20
years, but we still face challenges to maintain profitability and
sustainability," Cartanza said. "It is critical that we understand new
technology and that it's applied properly. It can be financially devastating for
a farmer to make an investment and not see a return. I want to learn how farmers
in other countries have solved some of these challenges and share that knowledge
with others."



 The Nuffield International Scholarship, supported locally by the Delaware
Department of Agriculture and MidAtlantic Farm Credit, provides participants
with a unique opportunity to research a specific issue in other parts of the
world.



 Past participants have been from the United Kingdom, Australia, Canada, New
Zealand, Ireland, France and The Netherlands. Cartanza is the first from the
United States.



 "It's great to have the first American hail from Delaware for this prestigious
program," said Delaware Secretary of Agriculture Ed Kee. "Georgie Cartanza will
do us all proud with her research and exploration of these issues."



 Kee has assisted with the development of a Nuffield program in the United
States since 2014, and will become president of the Nuffield USA board upon his
retirement in January, an unpaid volunteer position.



 Cartanza has worked with poultry for more than 20 years, including time with
Mountaire and Perdue. She has raised poultry on her farm near Dover for the last
10 years, and has raised organic chickens since April 2015. She began her new
position as UD poultry extension agent on December 1, and will continue to farm.




 Nuffield Scholars participate in a week-long conference in March in Brazil and
then spend six or seven weeks traveling internationally with other scholars,
known as the Global Focus Program. The scholars will visit Washington, D.C., New
York, Brazil, Mexico, Ireland, France and New Zealand. Participants then spend
seven or eight weeks on their individual research projects.

contact:  editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

                                 The Messenger

                           January 30, 2014 Thursday

Pakistan can benefit from Canadian experience in agriculture: Greg Giokas

SECTION: Vol. VI No. 29

LENGTH: 760  words


Canadian High Commissioner to Pakistan Greg Giokas, said Pakistan is
agricultural super power in many ways but the yield is very low.

Pakistan has a lot of natural resources including vast agricultural and mineral
base. However, it needs structural reforms that is, in education, skill
development and taxation, he said.

The Canadian High Commissioner was addressing the members of English Speaking
Union of Pakistan here.

He said that Pakistan is considered as a middle income country and Canada wants
to see it peaceful, prosperous and progressive.

He said: "Under WTO, we must focus on developing its competency through
trainings and skill development of the manpower especially in agriculture. We
would have to improve our quality , yield and certification of our produce".

He noted that Pakistan government needs due consultations with agriculturists ,
businessmen and other stakeholders including the donor agencies to come with
practical policies for developing and putting agriculture sector on  modern line
assuring high yield for the benefit of the country and its large farming
community.

It needs a comprehensive agriculture policy and its true implementation.

Pakistani businessmen should invest in various sectors mainly in agriculture and
in the associated businesses for the improvement of these sectors along with
making their profits. Investment in agriculture generates more employment than
other sectors.

He underlined the need for women empowerment in Pakistan as they had a great
contribution here in agriculture and dairy farming.

Canadian High Commissioner said that his country has focused on tariff regime.
It had initiated tariff reforms leading to preferential tariffs since 2010 which
will be completed in 2015.

He shared his country's experiences regarding opening of economy and trade
especially with its neighbouring countries.

He informed that majority of Canadian people showed strong negative reaction and
became a controversial issue when Canada signed free trade agreement (FTA) with
United States. However, the result came totally different. It helped generate a
great economic activity in Canada and now we have also huge trade with US.

He  advocated that Pakistan should open its economy particularly for the
neighbours.

" We should find deficiencies and fundamentally review our structural policies
to benefit from the emerging changes on global economic scenario ,"

He suggested that Pakistan should not hesitate in going forward with the Most
Favoured Nation status to India as this would be in the interest of both the
people. The regional trade is being focused in the world and it has proved very
beneficial for all the trading partners.

He said agricultural sector is the most protected sector under WTO. Pakistan has
great potential in agriculture , dairy farming and poultry which can be used for
the development of the farming communities.

" We want to share our experiences to support Pakistan's agriculture," he said
adding that his country had agriculture exports of dollars 47 billion which is
expected to reach dollars fifty billion\ soon. All this because of reducing
subsidies , rationalization of tariffs and research and development ,
involvement of businessmen and consultations with the stakeholders in this
sector besides providing a level playing field to our agriculturists", he said.

Canada exported 14million tonnes of canola last year, he informed.

The Canadian diplomat said he had discussions with Pakistan Government
functionaries especially on agriculture trade between the two countries. That,
the response from Pakistan Government was very positive.

He said Pakistan is agricultural super power in many ways but the yield is very
low. Pakistan should also focus on the development of quality seeds and
genetically modified products. You people should have a seed policy.

" It is not possible to feed 18 million through naturally grown crops. Diversity
is needed," he remarked.

He acknowledged that good research has been done in Pakistan under Pakistan's
Agriculture Coalition Programme.

He noted that it is very positive that in Pakistan a chain of fast foods was
growing very fast which would help promote its agriculture.    He said trade
between Canada and Pakistan has been fluctuating.

It was dollars 700million last year and is in favour of his country.

Canada has trade with India up to $6billion and with China it was $70 billion.

Earlier, President English Speaking Union in Pakistan Aziz Memon spoke of the
economic issues of Pakistan especially of trade and sought Canadian support in
different sectors.

                         Telegraph Herald (Dubuque, IA)

                           November 16, 2004 Tuesday

Farmers 'real happy' with bumper crops; Yields are high for corn, soybeans

BYLINE: JOHN EVERLY

SECTION: National/World; Pg. a3

LENGTH: 422 words


Farmers are harvesting bumper crops this fall, with reports of unprecedented
yields.

Dick Kleis, who farms near Zwingle, Iowa, had a good harvest. His early season
corn yielded 206 to 237 bushels per acre, well above the statewide average.

"We are real happy," he said.

Criss Davis, who farms near Shullsburg, Wis., reported corn yields in the 200
bushel per acre range.

"This has been a phenomenal year," he said. "We had twice the bean yield we had
last year, and the corn crop is just fantastic. So we do have something to be
thankful for in the tri-state area. With the prices that we have, it's good we
have some good yields to take to market."

Prices have weakened as this year's large corn and soybean crops come to market.
A government report released Friday indicated that corn and soybean production
will break all previous records.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture estimates that this year's corn crop will be
11.6 billion bushels, up from 10.1 billion bushels in 2003. Yields also hit a
record, averaging 160 bushels per acre and well above last year's record of 142
bushels per acre.

With the exception of Wisconsin, yields in the Corn Belt states are forecast at
record highs.

In Iowa, yields and production were up dramatically from 2003. At 183 bushels
per acre, Iowa topped last year's 157 bushels. Total production climbed 16
percent, to an estimated 2.25 billion bushels.

The Illinois corn crop, at just more than 2 billion bushels, was up 13 percent
from last year. The average yield was up 16 bushels from 2003, to 180 bushels
per acre.

Wisconsin is expected to produce 374 million bushels of corn, an increase from
last year's 368 million. Yields there improved seven bushels against 2003, at
136 bushels per acre.

Total corn use in the United States from 2004-05 is projected at a record 11
billion bushels, up from an expected 10 billion bushels used in 2003-04. Prices
are expected to range from $1.70 to $2.10 per bushel, compared with $2.42 in
2003-04.

American soybean production is forecast at a record 3.15 billion bushels, up 22
percent from 2003's drought-stunted crop. Yields are expected to average a
record high 42.6 bushels per acre, up 8.7 bushels from last year.

Soybean consumption, meanwhile, is forecast to grow about 10 percent from last
year. Producers need strong market demand at home and abroad, said Davis, who is
chairman of the United Soybean Board.

"Clearly we have a window of opportunity in a lot of the world to move
soybeans," Davis said.

                               The New York Times

                June 1, 1988, Wednesday, Late City Final Edition

Prices Paid to Farmers Increased 3.1% in May

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section D; Page 2, Column 5; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 330 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 31


Farmers received 3.1 percent more for their raw products in May than in April,
and 4.7 percent more than in May 1987, the Agriculture Department said today.

''Higher prices for hogs, oranges, soybeans and broilers were partially offset
by lower prices for tomatoes, onions, milk and upland cotton,'' the agency's
Agricultural Statistics Board said in its preliminary report.

Farm commodity prices in May averaged 134 percent of a 1977 base used for
comparison, according to the preliminary figures. The index was 128 a year ago.


Cattle at Post-1979 High

Hog prices reached their highest levels since October, on average, while cattle
brought the highest prices since May 1979. Soybeans posted the largest month-to
month increase in more than four years, 58 cents a bushel, and broilers were up
5.5 cents a pound from April.

According to Agriculture Department economists, farmers' net cash income set a
record of about $57 billion in 1987. This year's net - the difference between
cash receipts and cash expenses - may be in the $50 billion to $55 billion
range.

Consumer food prices are expected to rise 2 percent to 4 percent this year,
compared with a 4.2 percent average increase in 1987.

The preliminary May figures, based mainly on mid-month averages, showed
livestock and poultry prices up 2.7 percent from both April and the previous
May.

Lower Milk and Egg Prices

''Higher prices for hogs, broilers and beef cattle more than offset lower prices
for milk, eggs and calves,'' the Agriculture Department said.

Overall crop prices were up 4.5 percent from April and 7.4 percent from a year
ago.

The price index for oil-bearing crops, which consist mainly of soybeans, was up
7.4 percent from the previous month and 26 percent from May 1987.

Prices paid to commercial vegetable growers decreased 12 percent from April and
11 percent from last year. The department attributed most of the change to lower
prices for tomatoes, onions and sweet corn.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Graph of farm prices from Dec. '86-May '88 (source: Agriculture Dept.)

                      Post-Bulletin (Rochester, Minnesota)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           December 2, 2009 Wednesday

Farmers make headway on harvesting their corn

BYLINE: Mike Klein, Post-Bulletin, Rochester, Minn.

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 370 words


Dec. 2--Rainfall and even snow in parts of Minnesota slowed the pace of harvest
last week, but Minnesota's corn harvest is 78 percent complete.

For the week ending Sunday, producers harvested 12 percent of the corn crop,
compared to 23 percent the week before, according to the United States
Department of Agriculture's weekly crop report for Minnesota.

"They've had some good days to wrap things up or get close to finished," said
Lisa Behnken, University of Minnesota Extension crop specialist in the Rochester
area. "There are a lot of bushels out there, and storage space is getting
tight."

The average moisture of corn being harvested was 21 percent, which is 4 points
above the five-year average. Because of that, more drying time has been needed.

Meanwhile, sunflower producers harvested 10 percent of the crop during the week,
bringing statewide progress to 85 percent complete. Also, the soybean crop is
largely harvested.

The week had mild temperatures for late November.

Usually most of the corn is in by now. A cool, wet spring delayed planting this
year.

While some farmers have completed the harvest, others are not completely done,
Behnken said.

A lot of grain is going through the process because of the late harvest, and
much of it is wet and needs to be dried, she said. That's caused equipment
breakdowns and delays.

"There have been instances where elevators had to shut down for a day to take
care of drying, Behnken said. "If they're shut down and there's no place to haul
corn, you're shut down, too."

On the plus side, the mild weather has allowed farmers to till and fertilize
their fields in preparation for next spring's planting, she said. Last year, the
cold and snow came much earlier, cutting down on fall tillage.

Statewide, farmers had 5.2 days suitable for fieldwork last week.

To see more of the Post-Bulletin, or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.postbulletin.com. Copyright (c) 2009, Post-Bulletin, Rochester, Minn.

                                 Ottawa Citizen

                    January 17, 2004 Saturday Final Edition

'No reason' for U.S. beef ban: Speller: Talks end without timeline for border to
reopen to cattle

SOURCE: The Ottawa Citizen

BYLINE: Sheldon Alberts

SECTION: News; Pg. A3

LENGTH: 578 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON -- Agriculture Minister Bob Speller said yesterday there is no longer
any valid reason for the United States to maintain its ban on Canadian beef
exports to the county.

During meetings in Washington, D.C., Mr. Speller told his U.S. counterpart,
Agriculture Secretary Ann Veneman, that the ongoing border closures were
damaging efforts by both Canada and the U.S. to get bans lifted in other
international markets.

"There is absolutely no reason why the border shouldn't be open," Mr. Speller
said in an interview with CanWest News Service.

"We have farmers and farm families that are suffering. Our guys have been locked
out since last May."'

Ms. Veneman refused to give Mr. Speller a timeline for the re-opening of the
border, but the U.S. and Canada did announce an incremental step towards ending
export bans in both countries.

Ms. Veneman and Mr. Speller will name a team of senior officials to intensify
talks aimed at see cross-border cattle shipments resume.

The panel of officials, which will include representatives from Mexico, will
"co-ordinate the ongoing interagency efforts toward a resumption of exports
based on a harmonized framework."

The U.S. banned live cattle exports from Canada last May following the discovery
of a case of mad-cow disease,

or bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE), in a single animal from an Alberta
ranch.

Canada, in turn, announced a partial ban on U.S. beef after the discovery of a
single case of mad-cow disease in an animal in Washington state last month.

U.S. plans to lift the ban on Canadian live cattle under 30 months of age were
put on hold after it was discovered the Washington state cow had been imported
from from an Alberta dairy farm in 2001.

The two nations are now struggling to settle on standardized regulations for
feed safety and animal inspections that would meet international demands.

Both Mr. Speller and Ms. Veneman acknowledged the difficulty Canada and the U.S.
face in convincing international trading partners that North American beef is
safe when there are existing bans within the continent itself.

"This is what I argued today in our meetings. I said we need to co-ordinate our
response to this," Mr. Speller said.

"That is why we appointed a high-level group, to do exactly that."

A period of public comment on proposed U.S. rules that would allow the
resumption of Canadian exports ended Jan. 5. But Mr. Speller said the U.S. wants
more time to "allow further ideas from people" because of the Canadian link to
the U.S. mad-cow case.

"I got assurances (from Ms. Veneman) that the period of time would not be long
and she would make a decision as expediently as she can."

Ms. Veneman said "the issue of trade is very complex" and said the U.S. and
Canada need "better international guidance" of BSE safety standards before the
the borders would re-open.

Canada wants the U.S. to agree to a broader ban on animal feed that includes
specified risk materials -- like brain and spinal cord matter. The two nations
prohibited the feeding of ruminant products to cattle in 1997, but the ban does
not extend to other animals.

Little progress was made on the issue in yesterday's meetings because Ms.
Veneman's department does not regulate animal feed in the U.S.

The U.S. beef industry has lost up to $30 million U.S. a day since the discovery
of BSE in Washington. Canada has lost at least $1.9 billion Cdn since its mad
cow case was reported May 20.

LOAD-DATE: January 17, 2004

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                             882 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                August 16, 1982, Monday, Late City Final Edition

Commodities;
Soviet Able To Dictate Grain Price

BYLINE: By H.J. Maidenberg

SECTION: Section D; Page 5, Column 5; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 818 words


Just as large debtors often end up giving terms to their bankers, the
grain-deficient Soviet Union last week found itself in a position to dictate the
prices that corn, wheat and soybean producers in the United States will receive
for their crops.

This came about after the Department of Agriculture made a forecast Wednesday of
record grain and soybean crops this season. The news, not wholly unexpected in
the commodity markets, unfolded as farmers were burdened by large unsold
surpluses from past harvests.

The record crops were projected after the Soviet leaders - potentially the
biggest customers for American grain and oilseeds - conceded that they faced
their fourth dismal harvests in a row but still showed little interest in
signing a long-term sales contract.

''The Soviet leaders are being coy and are letting us swing in the air while our
farm prices crash under the pressure of surpluses that we haven't seen in 30
years,'' said John A. Schnittker, head of a large Washington agribusiness
consulting firm bearing his name. ''And if they do sign any agreement, it
probably will be for only a year after the current one expires this Sept. 30.''
President Reagan has said the United States would agree to only a one-year deal,
but many farm analysts consider that as only a bargaining position.

Mr. Schnittker predicted that, as bad as the American farmer's plight has been,
it will be much worse in the 1983-84 crop year because of the soaring inventory
of unsold grains and soybeans. Even if the next crops are average or below
average in size, the surpluses will prevent prices from rising next season, Mr.
Schnittker said, unless the Soviet Union, China or India increase purchases
substantially.

But, barring some unforeseen worldwide agriculture catastrophe, such purchases
are considered highly unlikely, he continued, noting: ''We have become residual
suppliers to the Soviets since President Carter imposed an embargo on exports to
them following their military intervention in Afghanistan in December 1979. When
President Reagan lifted the embargo in the spring of 1981, the Soviets had
already turned to Argentina for large amounts of grain and soybeans and to
Brazil for bean oil and meal under five-year contracts.''

More recently, the Canadian Government granted the Soviet Union $1 billion in
credit, which should enable Moscow to buy about a third of that country's wheat
and barley crops this season.

Mr. Schnittker observed that in 1981 the Soviet Union said it produced grain
crops totaling 175 million metric tons, although some experts put the figure at
155 million. ''In any case, they imported 46 million tons, of which 14 million
came from this country,'' he said. ''Now the Soviet leaders speak of a crop of
170 million tons, but with some belt tightening and some adjustments in
livestock rations, we think they will need to import 40 million tons this
season.''

Mr. Schnittker said the Reagan's Administration's ''confused farm policy has
been aimed primarily at curbing production.'' Last January, for example, the
Administration announced a program under which farmers would have to idle 15
percent of wheat acreage and 10 percent of corn acreage to be eligible for
various Federal subsidy programs.

Farmers were allowed to base their reductions on the maximum acreage ever sown
on their land. Still, only 40 percent of the wheat farmers complied; the rate
among corn growers was half that. The general theory among farm analysts was
that most farmers had expected greatly increased sales to Moscow this season.

Richard A. Loewy, grain and oilseeds analyst at Bache Halsey Stuart Shields
Inc., held that the mounting surpluses, poor export outlook and low level of
compliance with the land set-aside program could be expected to put further
pressure on prices. He made the comments during an interview after Friday's
market close.

''Despite the fact that the markets took the crop projections in stride this
week, we expect to see $2 corn, the current $3.30 floor in wheat broken and
soybeans dropped to its loan level of $5.02,'' Mr. Loewy said, pointing out:
''Corn and wheat prices are currently below the levels that farmers can get
under the loan program. Because grain prices tend to stabilize soybeans, this
could also cause a free fall in beans.''

Last Friday in Chicago, spot September corn futures closed at $2.27 1/4 a
bushel, down 14 3/4 cents on the week. The spot September wheat contract slipped
3 cents, to $3.40 1/2, and the spot August soybean futures plunged 27 1/2 cents,
to $5.64 1/2 a bushel. Each one-cent move in grains and soybeans represents $50
for each contract of 5,000 bushels.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                          The Duncan Banner (Oklahoma)

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                              July 22, 2016 Friday

OFB speaks to locals about SQ 777

BYLINE: Linda Provost, The Duncan Banner, Okla.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 607 words


July 22--A representative from the Oklahoma Farm Bureau spoke to the Duncan Noon
Lions Club about why the OFB was in favor of State Question 777 passing in
November.

Mark Yates, Director of Field Operations for Public Policy, said he was not only
representing OFB but also a group called Oklahoma Farmers Care, a collation of
many of the agriculture groups in Oklahoma.

"I get asked all the time, 'The right to farm? I don't get it, don't we have the
right to farm today? So why is this necessary?'" he said. "Farmers and ranchers
are asking for a Constitutional guarantee to do what they do today. What we have
in place today in Oklahoma -- the farming and ranching practices that are
employed today, the technologies that are being used today and all the
regulations that go along with it -- we are asking to keep it that way. Allow us
to operate how we operate today into the future."

While there have been no regulations against current farm practices, many people
are thinking ahead.

"This is a proactive approach -- it is based on what we are seeing around the
nation and what is happening in agriculture," Yates said. "There are groups
around our nation that are really putting restraints and attacking agriculture
and trying to pull production methods off the table."

Yates gave an example about an egg production bill passed in California backed
by the Humane Society of the United States (HSUS)

"HSUS -- which is not to be confused with your local Humane Society or animal
shelter -- Humane Society of the United States is a national organization for
animal rights activism," he said.

In 2008 in California, a bill was passed changing the allowable sizes of chicken
cages. Yates said when farmers could not pay for the upgrade, they reduced the
number of chickens in the cages to comply with the size changes.

"What we saw after this went into effect was that egg production dropped
dramatically around 50 percent,"  he said, "and the price of eggs immediately
shot up."

While California tried to make up for the loss, Yates said bills like that were
not helpful to the producers.

"We in agriculture call it 'feel good legislation.' It's not based on research,
science and fact, it's just 'we don't feel good' about a production method," he
said. "The farming and ranching practices we use today in Oklahoma and across
the nation are researched by The Noble Foundation, Oklahoma State University,
Texas A&M, Prude, and what we are asking is, 'Look, until proven otherwise, let
the research, science and facts put out there keep (farmers) using these
(methods).'"

Yates said one of the main oppositions against the SQ777 revolves around people
arguing the measure "empowers corporate farming," and that land will be bought
up by large scale producers and overseas buyers.

"Oklahoma Farm Bureau membership is a little over 95,000. They're not corporate
farmers, they are family owned and operated," he said. "They do not want more
competition coming to our state, 98 percent of all the farms and ranches owned
in Oklahoma are family owned and operated and we want to keep it that way. This
does not empower or give corporations more power to come in and take (over)."

Yates also said it was not a deregulation of agriculture.

"It is not a deregulation of agriculture and more regulation can be imposed in
the future," he said. "Future legislation and future regulation upon agriculture
needs to be in the best interest of Oklahoma and not 'feel good legislation'
just based on emotion and feelings."

Okla.) at www.duncanbanner.com Distributed by Tribune Content Agency, LLC.

                                  Daily Times

                            January 31, 2014 Friday

Pakistan can benefit from Canadian experience in agriculture'

BYLINE:  Staff Report

SECTION: Vol. XIII No. 29

LENGTH: 755  words


Canadian High Commissioner to Pakistan Greg Giokas said Pakistan is an
agricultural super power in many ways but the yield is very low.

Pakistan has a lot of natural resources including vast agricultural and mineral
base. However, it needs structural reforms that is, in education, skill
development and taxation, he said.

The Canadian high commissioner was addressing the members of English Speaking
Union in Pakistan.

He said that Pakistan is considered as a middle-income country and Canada wants
to see it peaceful, prosperous and progressive.

He said, "Under WTO, we must focus on developing its competency through
trainings and skill development of the manpower especially in agriculture. We
would have to improve our quality, yield and certification of our produce."

He noted that Pakistan government needs due consultations with agriculturists,
businessmen and other stakeholders including the donor agencies to come with
practical policies for developing and putting agriculture sector on modern line
assuring high yield for the benefit of the country and its large farming
community.

It needs a comprehensive agriculture policy and its true implementation.

Pakistani businessmen should invest in various sectors mainly in agriculture and
in the associated businesses for the improvement of these sectors along with
making their profits. Investment in agriculture generates more employment than
other sectors.

He underlined the need for women empowerment in Pakistan as they had a great
contribution here in agriculture and dairy farming.

The Canadian high commissioner said that his country has focused on tariff
regime. It had initiated tariff reforms leading to preferential tariffs since
2010, which will be completed in 2015.

He shared his country's experiences regarding opening of economy and trade
especially with its neighbouring countries.

He informed that majority of Canadian people showed strong negative reaction and
became a controversial issue when Canada signed Free Trade Agreement with United
States. However, the result came totally different. It helped generate a great
economic activity in Canada and now we have also huge trade with US.

He advocated that Pakistan should open its economy particularly for the
neighbours.

"We should find deficiencies and fundamentally review our structural policies to
benefit from the emerging changes on global economic scenario," he said.

He suggested that Pakistan should not hesitate in going forward with the Most
Favoured Nation status to India as this would be in the interest of both the
people. The regional trade is being focused in the world and it has proved very
beneficial for all the trading partners.

He said agricultural sector is the most protected sector under WTO. Pakistan has
great potential in agriculture, dairy farming and poultry, which can be used for
the development of the farming communities.

"We want to share our experiences to support Pakistan's agriculture," he said
adding that his country had agriculture exports of $47 billion which is expected
to reach $50 billion soon.

All this because of reducing subsidies, rationalization of tariffs and research
and development, involvement of businessmen and consultations with the
stakeholders in this sector besides providing a level playing field to our
agriculturists," he said.

Canada exported 14 million tonnes of cannula last year, he informed.

The Canadian diplomat said he had discussions with Pakistan government
functionaries especially on agriculture trade between the two countries. That,
the response from Pakistan government was very positive.

He said Pakistan is agricultural super power in many ways but the yield is very
low. Pakistan should also focus on the development of quality seeds and
genetically modified products. You people should have a seed policy.

"It is not possible to feed 18 million through naturally grown crops. Diversity
is needed," he remarked.

He acknowledged that good research has been done in Pakistan under Pakistan's
Agriculture Coalition Programme.

He noted that it is very positive that in Pakistan a chain of fast foods was
growing very fast which would help promote its agriculture.

He said trade between Canada and Pakistan has been fluctuating. It was $700
million last year and is in favour of his country. Canada has trade with India
up to $6 billion and with China it was $70 billion.

Earlier, English Speaking Union in Pakistan President Aziz Memon spoke of the
economic issues of Pakistan especially of trade and sought Canadian support in
different sectors.

                               September 16, 2010

Farmers on track for record harvest

BYLINE: Lafayette Nicollet Ledger staff

LENGTH: 201  words


U.S. farmers are on pace to produce the largest corn and soybean crops in
history, according to the Crop Production report released today by the U.S.
Department of Agriculture's National Agricultural Statistics Service (NASS).

Corn production is forecast at 13.4 billion bushels and soybean production at
3.43 billion bushels, both up 2 percent from the previous records set in 2009.
Based on conditions as of August 1, corn yields are expected to average a
record-high 165 bushels per acre, up 0.3 bushel from last year's previous
record. Soybean yields are expected to equal last year's record of 44 bushels
per acre.

Cotton production is expected to jump 52 percent from last year, to 18.5 million
480-pound bales. Average yield is forecast at 837 pounds per harvested acre, up
60 pounds from last year.

The August Crop Production report contains USDA's first survey-based estimates
of yield and production for corn, soybeans and other spring-planted row crops.
Between July 25 and August 6, NASS surveyed approximately 27, 000 producers and
also took objective field measurements in the major crop-producing states. Crop
Production is published monthly and is available online at
http://www.nass.usda.gov.

                             The Kalona News (Iowa)

  This content, including derivations, may not be stored or distributed in any
  manner, disseminated, published, broadcast, rewritten or reproduced without
                      express, written consent from STPNS

                                 April 1, 2010

Workshop attracts big crowd to learn about cover crops

BYLINE: The Leopold Center

LENGTH: 629  words


The Leopold Center If turnout at the annual workshop of the Midwest Cover Crops
Council is any indication, the use of cover crops could be on the rise. More
than 120 people from 13 states and provinces attended the March 3 event and
nearly half were farmers, some who had never used cover crops in their
operation. The workshop was hosted by the Leopold Center for Sustainable
Agriculture, the USDA's National Laboratory for Agriculture and the Environment
in Ames, Practical Farmers of Iowa and the USDA's Sustainable Agriculture and
Research Education (SARE) program.

Participants were as varied as the practices used in cover cropping. They
included large cash-grain farmers, livestock producers and graziers, as well as
farmers growing vegetables on very small farms. So it was with keen interest
that they listened to both researchers present some of the latest findings on
these practices, and farmers share their practical experiences with managing
cover crops, which included mixing cover crop seed with manure slurry applied to
fields, modifying equipment, and tracking the many benefits of using cover
crops.

Southeast Iowa farmer Steve Berger planted 1,000 acres of rye on his farm in
2007, and says that it works well with no-till operations to prevent soil
erosion and encourage root growth.

"We get a tremendous root system out of rye and the corn roots follow them
down," Berger said. "If you get those corn roots to go down just one foot more,
that's two inches more of available moisture and in some years two inches is a
big deal."

In western Iowa, Ron Ros-mann of Harlan uses cover crops for organic
certification in his 600-acre diversified operation. Most recently, cover crops
such as buckwheat provide additional forage for his livestock herd, half of
which is pasture-fed. Besides providing ground cover, Rosmann said cover crops
sequester carbon, provide nutrients for the next crop and have increased soil
organic matter and soil quality since he started planting cover crops in 1984.

Another convincing recommendation came from Gary Guthrie, who converted two
acres of his family's corn-soybean farm in Story County into a garden that
supplies a 74-member Community Supported Agriculture operation. "When I started
farming in 1998, I could not have imagined how productive my soil could be," he
said. "Cover crops have been the key to soil building, and disease and weed
control."

Guthrie said at first he could expect a 300 square-foot bed to produce about 100
pounds of carrots. However, as soil quality increases he also has increased
production, and under the right conditions some beds have produced more than 450
pounds of carrots.

USDA plant physiologist Tom Kaspar helped organize the workshop and said he was
pleased with the interest. He says that the most valuable part was the
opportunity for farmers, extension educators, researchers and agency personnel
to discuss cover crops and ask questions. "Cover crops are a long-term
investment and require a different approach in an operation," he said. "People
are

more at ease asking questions and there's a lot we can learn from one another."

The Midwest Cover Crops Council has been gathering research-based information
and experiential data from farmers over the past two growing seasons for a new
web-based Cover Crop Decision Tool. The tool, to be launched later this year,
will help users determine appropriate crops, planting times and other practices
based on their needs and geographic area. Information from the workshop will be
available on the council's web site: www.mccc.msu. edu

The Leopold Center, PFI and USDA-ARS coordinate the Iowa Cover Crops Working
Group, which works with the Midwest Cover Crops Council and the Green Lands,
Blue Water initiative to improve water and soil quality

                          China Daily European Edition

                             April 28, 2014 Monday

Stop pork from becoming easy meat

BYLINE: Shenggen Fant

SECTION: OPINION

LENGTH: 466 words


Pork is an important part of the Chinese diet and economy and is likely to
remain so in the foreseeable future given the increasing demand for meat because
of rising incomes and urbanization. As the largest producer and consumer of
pork, China accounts for half of the world's pork production and consumption.

In the coming decade, China's total pork production and consumption is projected
to increase by a little over 20 percent based on new figures from the United
States Department of Agriculture. While the increasing appetite for other meats,
especially poultry, in China is expected to slow down the growth in pork
consumption, its dominant position in the Chinese diet will remain intact for
some time to come. In per person terms, the consumption of pork is projected to
rise three times more than that of poultry and seven times more than that of
beef.

The structure of pig farming in China has been changing rapidly as part of the
larger transformation of agriculture. There is a growing shift away from
small-scale backyard farming to specialized and large-scale commercial farming.
Rising production costs (due mainly to higher feed costs), greater demand for
food safety (due to more outbreaks of animal disease and use of unsafe feed
additives), shrinking farm workforce (due to faster rural-urban migration) and
government policies to promote large commercial farms are some of the key
factors responsible for the rapidly vanishing small pig farms.

Since 2007, government policy has favored large-scale pig production as a way of
improving food safety and quality by providing grants and subsidies to large pig
farms. These policies need to be re-evaluated. Many of these changes have led to
increasing volatility of supply and prices in China's pork industry.

In the last few years, rising pork prices have been a major driver of food
inflation in the country. But now a declining price trend has begun to emerge.
Based on official data, pork prices in March 2014 fell by close to 7 percent
year-on-year, though food price inflation rose by about 4 percent. The recent
fall in prices has been widely attributed to consolidation in China's pork
industry leading to cycles of rapid expansion in pork production. This periodic
excess supply of pork can lead to a vicious cycle of reduced employment,
production and profitability in the industry.

The transition from small to large pig farms should be a natural economic
process. Small farms still have an important role to play in stabilizing China's
pork production, and equally importantly in providing employment and income for
many poor people in rural areas who will not be able to move out of the
agricultural sector, at least not in the near future. This is especially true of
farms in the central and western regions of China.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper
