                        Contra Costa Times (California)

                           September 17, 2006 Sunday

Definition of 'specialty crops' grows;
Rules clarify that canned, frozen and bottled products will now be eligible for
millions of dollars in federal funds

BYLINE: Michael Doyle, THE FRESNO BEE

SECTION: Pg. F4

LENGTH: 587 words


Score one for California wineries and Central Valley food processors.

Their canned, frozen and bottled products will now be eligible for millions of
dollars in federal funds devoted to promoting "specialty crops." That's a
bottom-line victory, following a peculiar bureaucratic battle whose origins
remain a tad murky.

Earlier this month, the Agriculture Department spelled out the rules for how the
specialty crop block grant funds can be spent. Some $7 million will be provided
in 2006 with California taking the largest share.

It's a relatively small amount, compared with the traditional crop subsidies
spanning hundreds of millions of dollars annually for cotton, rice, wheat and
corn growers.

Nonetheless, the new specialty crop block grant program has been treasured by
fruit and vegetable growers who complain they've been shortchanged in federal
farm bills.

"California specialty crop growers compete daily against foreign growers who are
heavily subsidized and face comparatively less environmental regulation,"
California Women for Agriculture President Mary Ann Graff advised the
Agriculture Department.

Urged on by then-Rep. Doug Ose, R-Sacramento, Congress approved the new
specialty crop block grant program in 2004.

Up to $44.5 million in annual funding is supposed to help increase fruit,
vegetable and nut consumption and improve the "competitiveness" of U.S.
producers.

"Significant federal investment ... is absolutely essential to fostering the
future of American agriculture," Rep. Dennis Cardoza, D-Merced, and 17 other
House members advised the Agriculture Department.

To spread the political benefits, lawmakers ensured that each state receives at
least $100,000. The rest of the money is divided according to a state's share of
specialty crop production, which is golden for California.

Last April, though, the Agriculture Department threatened to split the
agriculture industry by proposing that "fresh specialty crop projects" enjoy
priority in funding. That stunned some.

"The department's emphasis should be promoting a well-rounded nutritious diet
for all Americans and not singling out one category of fruits and vegetables,"
urged Dennis Balint, chief executive officer of the California Walnut
Commission.

Seventy other farm organizations, ranging from the Valley Fig Growers to the
California Tomato Growers Association, submitted similar public comments
opposing the proposal. Many of the written comments carried identical wording, a
sign of an orchestrated campaign.

"These comments have merit," the Agriculture Department now concedes.

"The (2004 law) does not restrict the term specialty crops to only fresh
commodities and, as such, both fresh and processed specialty crop producers
would benefit from the block grants provided for in this program."

That original proposal prompted worries among farm groups hoping to maintain a
united political front going into the 2007 farm bill debate; it was never really
clear whose fingerprints were on the original proposal.

In the rules made final this week, the Agriculture Department emphasized that
the grants are supposed to aid only crops grown in the United States.

Officials also offered a broad definition of eligible programs, including
everything from consumer ad campaigns to research and environmental
conservation.

Some organizations, for instance, had hoped the rules would specify that
products including lavender, ginger root, coffee and seaweed are all eligible
for funding. Department officials said they would leave those details to later.

LOAD-DATE: September 17, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                     Copyright 2006 Contra Costa Newspapers
                              All Rights Reserved

                             891 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                         The Land (Mankato, Minnesota)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            January 19, 2010 Tuesday

MFBF President Kevin Paap talks modern ag, promotes a positive message

BYLINE: Dick Hagen, The Land, Mankato, Minn.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 1084 words


Jan. 19--"The No. 1 issue of agriculture is our shrinking margins. Profitability
keeps declining. The livestock sector has endured negative margins for two
years."

That's Kevin Paap talking. As president of the Minnesota Farm Bureau Federation,
he's on the banquet circuit much of the winter season speaking up for
agriculture.

Interviewed at the December meeting of the Minnesota Lamb and Wool Growers in
Alexandria, close behind in his assessment of agricultural challenges is the
growing impact of rules and regulations. "Unfortunately we're seeing more
regulations, more controls thrown into the hopper. This cap and trade talk very
definitely will boost the costs of farming, and even the costs of living for
virtually everyone."

He sees more permit requirements facing farmers and more challenges against
pesticides relevant to clean water issues. Right along with these concerns is
the growing "voice" of the People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals and
Humane Society of the United States in more states.

"We've got to let science rule the day rather than emotion. And we need to put a
stronger, more recognizable face on agriculture. We have the science to support
us but we've got to reconnect with the consumers," Paap said, pointing out that
more and more consumers are getting further removed from agriculture and where
the food chain originates.

How food is produced, how animals are cared for before food gets on the dinner
plate is a growing disconnect for agriculture, Paap believes, proclaiming that
farmers and farm organization such as the Minnesota Farm Bureau and Minnesota
Farmers Union need to both educate and engage consumers.

"We need to understand why they (consumers) think like they think. We need to
understand their concerns. And then we need to address those issues with science
to back up our actions," he said.

How does agriculture get positive attention? Anyway we can, Paap said.

Often that can mean expensive promotion and education campaigns on television
and other media outlets. But it can also be personalized. Farmers making class
visits to local schools to talk about agriculture is education at its best. He
even suggested the holiday mailing of Christmas cards by farm families to their
"city cousins" should carry special messages about farming and what's going on
in agriculture.

"But face-to-face is the very best way. People don't often take advice from
people they don't know but they will and do appreciate listening to farmers
telling their story of where and how the food chain starts in America," Paap
said. His point being that all producers need to truly become advocates for
agriculture saying that is a primary mission statement of the Farm Bureau.

"Just producing the product whether it be a bushel of corn, a gallon of milk or
a pound of bacon doesn't cut it. If we produce it, it should be our inherent
responsibility to speak up for agriculture. We need to be more positive and more
proactive and less reactive."

He recognizes the impact the global recession is having on American agriculture,
especially the slow down in exports of agricultural products.

"We grow more than we can use thus export markets are key to economic well
being. We need to remember that 95 percent of the world's people don't live in
the United States. Over 1 billion people go to bed hungry every night."

But it's a competitive market out there. "I know Minnesota is in competition
with other states and countries to build trade. When ag commissioner Gene
Hugoson returned from a recent trade mission to Brazil and Chile he commented
how eager these two countries also are to claim a bigger portion of global
commodity markets."

Paap emphasizes that the last thing agriculture needs is being divisive. "There
simply aren't enough of us left in agriculture to get it done unless we're all
working together. That means getting all stakeholders at the table so that
everyone understands that we can produce both food and fuel while providing feed
for our livestock industry too. Today we're producing more corn on fewer acres
with less inputs than we were 20 years ago and I see that trend continuing."

He also sees a growing spirit of cooperation between the Farm Bureau and the
Farmer's Union. "In my opinion probably 80 percent of the issues we work on
we're there hand-in-hand. Granted there likely will always be certain issues we
won't agree upon simply because these are policy driven by our membership."

Acknowledging that membership is the lifeblood of Farm Bureau, Paap said there
has been positive membership growth for the Minnesota Farm Bureau the past two
years. He refers to membership as the "eyes and the ears" of the pulse of
agriculture. With a shrinking base (fewer farmers) he points out that
agriculture needs voice from more than just farmers who produce but also
processors, food manufacturers, transportation firms and others.

"I've heard Gov. Pawlenty talk of the 367,000 jobs represented by Minnesota's
agriculture and food industry. That's one of every five Minnesota jobs so policy
makers at both the state and national level need to understand the competitive
pressure of policy decisions that affect how we run our businesses."

Explaining the importance of speaking up, Paap often says, "If you're not on the
table, you'll be on the menu." That's one reason why he endorses the efforts of
the Minnesota Farm & Food Coalition sharing the total story of the various
participants that make up America's amazing food chain industry.

He gives tremendous credit to farmers for their productive capacity and their
willingness to adopt new science, new technologies helping them do even better.
"However, we can't say we're doing a perfect job now because down the road we
know we can do even better. GPS technologies are helping us tremendously in
doing a better job of farming. If someone just a few years ago would have told
me I would be in the field with my tractor that is steering itself while I'm on
my Blackberry sharing a message with an elected official in Washington, D.C., I
would have said you're nuts. But that's agriculture today," Paap said.

To see more of The Land or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.thelandonline.com. Copyright (c) 2010, The Land, Mankato, Minn.

                                The Toronto Star

              February 11, 1995, Saturday, SATURDAY SECOND EDITION

Sugar-products dispute spurs call for trade talks

BYLINE: (CP)

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. C9

LENGTH: 266 words

DATELINE: OTTAWA


   OTTAWA (CP) - Worried about U.S. measures to keep out many Canadian sugar
products, the federal government is seeking formal consultations with the United
States under the North American Free Trade Agreement.

"We have concerns with a number of measures taken by the United States which
have reduced Canada's access to the U.S. market for sugar and sugar-containing
products," Agriculture Minister Ralph Goodale said in a news release.

"We are therefore availing ourselves of the NAFTA provisions to consult with the
United States in this regard."

Goodale was joined by International Trade Minister Roy McLaren in the
announcement, underscoring the high-level interest in the issue.

Canadian and U.S. officials held fruitless talks earlier over the dispute, which
involves refined sugar and sugar-containing products such as crystal drink
mixes, iced tea and sweetened cocoa mixes.

The U.S. government imposed new definitions and classifications for
sugar-containing products Jan. 1, creating barriers for items previously
unaffected by restrictions. New quotas for refined sugar are also slated to be
implemented Oct. 1.

The Canadian sugar industry has said the U.S. restrictions could affect 1,700
jobs in the Canadian production of sugar-containing products.

New quotas on Canadian refined sugar would mean a cut of 150,000 tonnes or 14
per cent in production, costing an estimated $135 million in annual exports.

The closing of just one refinery would eliminate about 700 jobs.

Canada buys raw cane sugar on the world market to make refined sugar products.

                          The Tampa Tribune (Florida)

                            April 20, 2006 Thursday
                                 FINAL EDITION

Some Florida Farms Turn Over New Leaf

BYLINE: WILL RODGERS, wjrodgers@tampatrib.com

SECTION: MONEYSENSE; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 992 words

DATELINE: WIMAUMA


Organic farming isn't a big piece of Florida agriculture, but it's growing
rapidly to meet consumer demand.

By WILL RODGERS

wjrodgers@tampatrib.com

WIMAUMA - Kathy Oliver reaches down and plucks the flower off a basil plant
growing at My Mother's Garden Inc., a certified organic farm she operates with
her sister and husband.

"The herbs actually do better if you pinch them back," she said.

Pinching flowers is just a small part of the intensive manual labor Oliver and
her family put into growing organic herbs, spices, flowers and vegetables.
Growing food without artificial pesticides, fungicides and herbicides requires
more hands-on work - watering by hand, pulling weeds and picking off bugs - than
conventional farming.

It's labor Oliver, 45, loves.

"I think I will always be growing something out here," she said. "I don't know
if I'll always be doing it as a business. I like growing my own food."

My Mother's Garden received its first certification as organic in 2001. Six of
the family's 90 acres, at 3819 County Road 579 S., Wimauma, are certified, she
said. Much of the rest is open land or has homes on it.

Oliver is one of an increasing number of Florida growers turning to organic
farming. It is the fastest-growing sector, by percentage, of the state's
agriculture industry. Organic farming has increased in revenue about 20 percent
each year, although no agency officially tracks organic agribusiness sales in
Florida, said Mickie Swisher, an associate professor and director of the Center
for Organic Agriculture at the University of Florida.

Nearly 13,000 acres in Florida were devoted to organic operations in 2003, the
latest year available from the U.S. Department of Agriculture.

The annual market in the United States for organic products is about $15
billion, accounting for much of the total international demand of $23 billion,
said Holly Givens, communications director of the Organic Trade Association.

Swisher and other agriculture experts think organic farming will continue
expanding in Florida because the demand is growing and already outstrips supply.

Organic generally refers to food grown without man-made pesticides and
herbicides. That's different from natural food, which has no artificial
additives, preservatives or coloring but could be grown by more conventional
farming methods.

The expansion is breathing life into agriculture's future in Florida, where
farming has taken hits from weak pricing and other hardships.

Organic farming, however, commands an average 25 percent premium on products
because of the amount of work that goes into producing it. Still, there's no
guarantee of making a fortune. Oliver said her organic business is growing
slower than the family expected.

"We've learned to live a lot more simply than we used to," said Oliver, who did
not disclose the operation's annual revenue. "But it's not just the money."

Protecting the ecosystem from man-made chemicals is important to Oliver, who
holds a degree in wildlife ecology from the University of Florida.

Experts say the switch to organic farming might slow the pace of farm acreage
being turned into subdivisions and shopping centers. But it won't stop it.

"If you have a farmer who really wants to hang on to that land and keep it in
agriculture and not just sell, organic farming is one way they can make it,"
Swisher said. "But on pen and paper, I'm sure you come out ahead with
development every time."

For some, the bottom line is keeping man-made chemicals out of the state's soil
and water. They think organic is better for the environment and the health of
Florida residents and visitors.

That point of view is held by Marty Mesh, executive director of Florida Organic
Growers, the Gainesville-based nonprofit group that certifies Florida farms and
processes as organic.

Mesh encourages farmers to switch to organic to help meet consumer demand. He
also advocates to have Florida public schools buy from local organic farms for
student lunches.

"We're restoring the Everglades. Certainly part of the problem was dredging,
etc., but part of the problem also was nutrient overload," Mesh said. "If we
were farming more organically, then we wouldn't have that problem.

Ray Gilmer, a spokesman for the Florida Fruit and Vegetable Association, said
organic farming is a tough sell to growers. Florida is crawling with bugs, and
the land is arid. He said fewer than 10 of his association's 500 members have
full or partial organic operations.

Land is relatively cheap, and chemicals are readily available to manage crops,
he said. That has made it a losing proposition for farmers to switch to the more
labor-intensive organic farming.

But with the labor pool dwindling and the spread of diseases such as citrus
canker and citrus greening, some citrus nurseries are considering moving their
operations into greenhouses, which might make going organic more likely, Gilmer
said.

(CHART) IT'S A GROWING THING

The number of Certified Organic Operations in Florida has increased:

2000: 68

2001: 90

2002: 81

2003: 99

Source: U.S. Department of Agriculture

Information from Tribune archives was used in this report. Reporter Will Rodgers
can be reached at (813) 259-7870.

in 2003.

fastest-growing sector, by percentage, of the state's agriculture industry.

                     Belfast News Letter (Northern Ireland)

                            April 24, 2004, Saturday

PRICES GLOOM IN US

SECTION: 1st Edition; NEWS; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 159 words


THE United States Department of Agriculture paints a bullish picture for US beef
prices in the third and fourth quarter of 2004, according to the latest report
on corn production and usage.

Corn prices are forecast to range between US$ 2.35-US$ 2.55/bushel (pounds
1.32-pounds 1.43/bushel) for the 2003/04 marketing year (October 2003 to
September 2004), up from US$ 2.32 (pounds 1.30) from the 2002/03 marketing year.

Corn prices are expected to continue to increase in 2004.

The price rise forecast by the USDA estimates US corn yields of 142.2
bushels/acre for 2004/05, in line with the record yields from 2003/04.

In an environment where world corn stocks are at 30-year lows, small changes in
yields could push prices up further.

Corn is the primary feed for cattle in US feedlots with increases in the corn
price having a direct impact on the costs of US beef production.

* A bushel is equal to eight Imperial gallons.

                             895 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                                  China Daily

                              May 26, 2015 Tuesday

Empower farmers with full land rights

BYLINE: Zheng Yangpeng

LENGTH: 730  words


Reform of ownership is needed to unleash all the benefits of agriculture

The rural land issue in China rarely makes the headlines, but although it is
largely out of sight, it is a bitterly contested area.

Every suggestion on further liberalizing the rigid system is quickly dismissed
as basically a knee-jerk reaction.

Thus, 37 years after the major reform that allowed Chinese farmers to work the
land on a household basis, progress is limited.

Zou Lixing, vice-president of the research institute under the China Development
Bank, was reluctant to take a stand on the issue. But he has some bold ideas, at
least by the standards of Chinese bureaucracy.

Like most of his peers, he believes that agriculture and farmers are still the
backbone of the economy and society, even though the sector generates just 5.5
percent of GDP.

The country's modernization is unsustainable without the concurrent
modernization of the agricultural sector, he said.

For that reason, he gave his new English-language book the title of China Base:
County-Level Economy and Society.

He forecast that even at the end of this century, agriculture will remain the
economy's pillar by some measures, with this sector employing 20 to 30 percent
of the working population.

"China is not going to be like the United States, where agriculture sector
workers account for just 2 percent of the population. China, with its land
constraints, will not be like the US where large-scale farming prevails," he
said.

That long-term projection leads to his foundational argument: land rights should
belong to the tillers. The "tillers" are not necessarily individual farmers but
also professional planters, farming cooperatives and agricultural corporations.
Whatever they are, they should focus on farming, not real estate development,
for instance.

But while those views seem self-evident elsewhere in the world, they are not the
reality in China. The constitution still defines rural land as "collectively
owned", which in reality, according to Zou, equates to "township government
owned".

Farmers, though having a 30-year contract to plow the small plots assigned by
the government, are not able to transfer, collateralize or sell those plots
freely. In Zou's words, farmers' "usage rights" to the land are hollow. Local
governments retain real control over the land, which they can "expropriate" as
"State-owned construction land" and sell to developers at an astonishing
premium.

The long-term solution, he said, is the "actualization" of tillers' usage
rights. Privatization of the "collectively owned" land remains a political taboo
in this socialist country, but the "usage rights" could be separated from the
"ownership", with its legal status fully enshrined in the laws.

The status, he argued, should at least be equal to "ownership", so that under
this protection farmers can transfer rights to other "tillers" as they wish, as
long as the land is used for farming.

"After getting clearly defined rights to exploit the land, is there somewhere
they can take it?" Zou asked, suggesting that the government has nothing to
fear.

The problem with the "land expropriation" system, he argued, is that land is
sold on a one-off basis, while the State loses the ensuing added-value
permanently.

He said that to better exercise the "ownership" of the State, the central
government should transfer or rent the "usage rights" of the land to developers,
and use the compensation to set up a "national land provision fund".

Meanwhile, a certain portion of land could be demarcated as provincial-and
county-owned land, just like in the United States where federal, state and
county land coexists with private land.

Local governments in China can rely on these lands to set up their own "land
funds", which could openly trade options with the national fund.

"In the old system, all local governments covet State-owned land and they
expropriate the land as much as they can. The new design would allow local
governments to treasure their own land while the national fund serves to ensure
ensuing benefits of the land and also balance regional disparities," he said.

In summary, policymakers should have a long-term vision when making short-term
policy. To modernize the rural sector, empowering the 620 million farmers with
"actual usage rights" is a prerequisite.

Contact the writer at zhengyangpeng@chinadaily.com.cn

(China Daily 05/26/2015 page17)

                             July 8, 1987 Wednesday

SOURCE: QNP

BYLINE: WOCKNER C

LENGTH: 569 words


corrections Maize hybrid released THE Department of Primary Industries last week
released a new maize hybrid which promises higher returns for growers on the
Atherton Tableland. The new hybrid, Sloan, had 8 percent better grain yield than
QK 958 and 19 percent better than QK 657 in DPI trials. Sloan was developed at
the Kairi Research Station by DPI supervising agronomist, Mr Ian Martin and
district experimentalist, Mr Terry McCarthy. US announces sale THE United States
Department of Agriculture has announced a sale of 10,000 tonnes of steer and
heifer bone-in beef quarters to Venezuela through the US Commodity Credit
Corporation. At a reported sale price of $1500 per tonne, it is a subsidised
sale under the mandate given the USDA by Congress as part of the 1985 Farm Bill.
Herbicide developed RESEARCH scientists at the Alan Fletcher Research Station at
Sherwood have developed a special formulation of Atrazine and 2-4-D sodium salt
as a flowable herbicide. The new formulation known as AF-420 has been registered
for control of parthenium weed and giant sensitive plant in non-crop situations
and for giant sensitive plant control in sugar cane. It is available in 20 litre
drums. Freight charges slammed PEOPLE living in Queensland's rural areas are
unhappy about the new rail freight charges, according to the United Graziers'
Association. The UGA president, Mr Gordon Magoffin, said the new categories in
the schedules were creating major problems for graziers and small business
people. He said the effects of the charges were being felt by those using the
rail services. Donkey seminar THE Donkey Society of Queensland will hold a
seminar at Gatton Agricultural College on Saturday and Sunday. The weekend of
lectures and practical work will cover all aspects of owning and training a
donkey. Lecturers include Dr Terry McEvoy, an authority on conformation and the
mechanics of equine efficiency, and QAC Department of Animal Science head, Dr
Alex Kondos. Inquiries: (071) 460 920. Export film produced A FILM on
horticultural exports has been produced by the Department of Primary Industries.
It is to encourage awareness of the importance of exports in boosting the
national economy. The film, The Bottom Line, was funded partly by the
Commonwealth Innovative Agricultural Marketing Program. Meat production up
AUSTRALIAN Bureau of Statistics figures for May show that 65,096 tonnes of meat
was produced, 2 percent more than April this year and 11 percent more than May
1986. Veal production in May this year was 23 percent less than in April and 24
percent less than May last year. Lamb production was only 1 percent more for May
this year than April and 38 percent more than May 1986. Correct pH "important'
EVERY Queensland grower should understand the importance of pH in producing high
quality plants according to the Department of Primary Industries. It is a
measure of acidity and alkalinity in the soil. The DPI advisor in horticulture,
Mr Dick Franklin, said it was important to maintain the correct pH levels to
ensure healthy plant growth. Rural Youth show camp THE Rural Youth organisation
will hold a Show Camp '87 for young people interested in participating in the
Brisbane Exhibition. The camp will go from August 4-14 and participants will
stay at a motel. They will be involved in the exhibition as judges, stewards,
exhibitors and spectators. Inquiries: 831 4709.

                            The Press (Christchurch)

                            November 5, 2001, Monday

Live spider found in grapes

SECTION: NEWS; NATIONAL; Pg. 3; NEWS

LENGTH: 110 words


California table grapes may be off the shelves for good after another live black
widow spider was found.

The potentially deadly spider, spotted in a Nelson supermarket, was the fourth
found in a bunch of the grapes this year.

Ministry of Agriculture international operations adviser Justin Downs said the
latest black widow spider find was being taken very seriously.

"We are working with the United States Department of Agriculture to clarify
whether this finding is the result of a system failure," he said.

"Clearly if Import Health Standards protocols have not been followed, we will
need to close the trade in California table grapes."

LOAD-DATE: November 5, 2001

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                       Copyright 2001 Fairfax New Zealand

                             898 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                            The Press (Christchurch)

                             May 3, 2001, Thursday

Orange imports worry MP

SECTION: FARMING Pg. 18

LENGTH: 383 words


BLENHEIM-- Green Party MP Ian Ewen- Street says agricultural officials should be
questioning the import of Californian oranges and other American fruit,
including citrus and melons.

The American fruit potentially posed similar risks of carrying a devastating
disease -- and the insect that spreads it -- as the American table grapes which
the Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry had blocked from import this winter, he
said.

MAF officials are carrying out a risk analysis for both the grapevine sickness
Pierce's disease and the pest that spreads it, the glassy-winged sharpshooter.

They have suspended imports of Californian table grapes, which would normally
have started later this month.

The wine industry had complained that its $ 2 billion sector was at risk from
the disease and the pest.

An outbreak of Pierce's disease last year wiped out much of the Californian
grape harvest, even though the United States government spent $ US40 million ($
NZ93 million) on eradication and control.

But Mr Ewen-Street, who has just returned from California, said MAF now should
check imports of citrus and watermelons, in which the glassy-winged sharp
shooter could also lay eggs.

He said the sharpshooter was a voracious feeder and could die of starvation
within hours, and its eggs would live only 10-14 days under favourable
conditions.

"Importation by sea should be safe, but air freighting would still constitute a
huge risk," he said.

The Marlborough-based list MP spent time in Temecula, a grapegrowing area
utterly devastated by the disease and insect.

Feeding off the sap of the vines, the insect injects the disease organism, which
spreads through the plant, blocking sap flow and killing it.

There is no known preventative or cure.

Mr Ewen-Street said the Temecula winegrowing region was similar in size to
Marlborough and also boasted thriving citrus orchards. But everywhere he looked
he saw piles of dead grapevines waiting to be burnt.

"As a farmer, it was heartbreaking to see the land like that -- to see them
having to dig up the ground and bulldoze the vines out."

He feared the same thing could happen in New Zealand, if any insects that could
transfer the disease were accidentally imported. --NZPA

Supplied by New Zealand Press Association

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

                   October 10, 1990, Wednesday, DAILY EDITION

Give Soviets credit on grain, U.S. is urged

BYLINE: Financial Times of London

SECTION: SECTION 1, NEWS; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 188 words

DATELINE: Washington,DC


U.S. farming organizations are intensifying pressure on the U.S. government to
grant credits for Soviet grain purchases following reports that Canada has given
Moscow credits on the sale of five million metric tons of wheat and barley.

In a letter to President George Bush, 16 major farm groups warned that ''the
Soviets will not purchase signficant amounts of U.S. grain and other
agricultural products except on credit terms, which the U.S. government
currently is unwilling to grant.''

The Canadian Wheat Board has refused to confirm reports of a major sale and the
U.S. Department of Agriculture has been unable to get confirmation. But traders
in the U.S. report that Moscow last week bought four million metric tons of
Canadian wheat, including feed wheat and Durum, and a million tons of barley.

One U.S. Agriculture official said a team of Soviet agricultural officials
recently visited Washington and then went on to Winnipeg and Ottawa for ''a
courtesy call.'' According to the farm groups, the Soviet officials who visited
Washington threatened to halt purchases unless credit is granted.

                              The Financial Daily

                            January 31, 2014 Friday

Pak can benefit from Canadian experience in agriculture: High Comm.

LENGTH: 773  words


Canadian High  Commissioner  to Pakistan Greg Giokas, said Pakistan  is
agricultural super power in many ways but the yield is very low.

Pakistan has a lot of natural resources including vast agricultural and mineral
base.  However,  it needs structural reforms that is, in education, skill
development and taxation, he said.

The   Canadian   High Commissioner was addressing the members of English
Speaking Union of Pakistan here.

He said that Pakistan is considered as a middle income   country   and Canada
wants to see it peaceful, prosperous and progressive.

He said: "Under WTO, we must focus on developing    its    competency through
trainings and skill development of the manpower especially in agriculture. We
would have to improve our quality, yield and certification of our produce".

He noted that Pakistan government  needs  due consultations with agriculturists,
businessmen and other stakeholders including the donor agencies to come with
practical policies for developing and putting agriculture sector on modern line
assuring high yield for the benefit of the country and its large farming
community.

It needs a comprehensive agriculture policy and its true implementation.
Pakistani  businessmen should invest in various sectors mainly in agriculture
and in the associated businesses    for    the improvement of these sectors
along with making their profits. Investment in agriculture generates more
employment  than  other sectors.

He underlined the need for women empowerment in Pakistan as they had a great
contribution here in agriculture and dairy farming.

Canadian High Commissioner  said  that his country has focused on tariff regime.

It had initiated tariff reforms leading to preferential tariffs since 2010 which
will be completed in 2015.

He shared his country's experiences    regarding opening of economy and trade
especially with its neighboring countries.

He informed that majority  of  Canadian  people showed  strong  negative
reaction  and  became  a controversial issue when Canada signed free trade
agreement  (FTA)  with United States.

However, the result came totally different. It helped generate a great economic
activity in Canada  and  now  we have also huge trade with US.

He   advocated   that Pakistan should open its economy particularly for the
neighbors.

"We should find deficiencies and fundamentally review our structural policies to
benefit from the emerging changes on global economic scenario," He   suggested
that Pakistan should not hesitate in going forward with the Most Favored Nation
status  to  India  as  this would be in the interest of both  the  people.  The
regional  trade  is  being focused in the world and it has proved very
beneficial for all the trading partners.

He said agricultural sector is the most protected sector   under   WTO.

Pakistan has great potential in agriculture, dairy farming and poultry which can
be used for the development  of  the  farming communities.

"We want to share our experiences  to  support Pakistan's agriculture," he said
adding that his country had agriculture exports of dollars 47 billion which is
expected to reach dollars fifty billion soon. All this because of reducing
subsidies, rationalization of tariffs  and  research  and development,
involvement of businessmen and consultations with the stakeholders  in  this
sector besides providing a level playing field to our agriculturists", he said.
Canada exported 14million tonnes of cannula last year, he informed.

The Canadian diplomat said he had discussions with Pakistan Government
functionaries especially on agriculture trade between the two countries.

That, the response from Pakistan Government was very positive.

He said Pakistan is agricultural super power in many ways but the yield is very
low. Pakistan should also focus on the development of quality seeds and
genetically modified products. You people should have a seed policy.

"It is not possible to feed 18 million through naturally grown crops. Diversity
is needed," he remarked.

He acknowledged that good research has been done in Pakistan under Pakistan's
Agriculture Coalition Programme.

He noted that it is very positive that in Pakistan a chain of fast foods was
growing very fast which would help promote its agriculture.

He said trade between Canada and Pakistan has been fluctuating. It was dollars
700million  last year and is in favor of his country. Canada has trade with
India up to $6billion and with China it was $70 billion.

Earlier, President English Speaking Union in Pakistan  Aziz  Memon spoke  of
the  economic issues of Pakistan especially of trade and sought Canadian support
in different sectors.

                             901 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                  The State Journal-Register (Springfield, IL)

                            August 13, 2002 Tuesday

High prices maybe, but no crop to sell

BYLINE: CHARLYN FARGO AGRIBUSINESS EDITOR

SECTION: MARKETPLACE; Pg. 19

LENGTH: 538 words


Illinois farmers are viewing the August U.S. Department of Agriculture Crop
Report as a mixed blessing.

For livestock producers, it's likely to result in higher corn and soybean
prices, which means they'll be paying more for feed and have increased costs of
production. For grain farmers who were lucky enough to get rain when they needed
it, the higher prices will come as welcome news. Gordeon Bidner, a farmer from
Carlisle, has gotten the rains he needs for a good crop.

"Our corn crop looks really good this year," Bidner said. "But my son, who farms
in Champaign, is really hurting for rain.

"The good news is the fact that USDA recognizes the real stress on crops. Most
farmers have had pollination problems, drought stress, ponding and emergence
problems. On the other hand, crop prices are likely to be higher, but if you
don't have the crop to sell it's a Catch-22."

The Illinois corn crop is forecast to yield 140 bushels per acre, 12 bushels
below last year and 11 bushels below 2000. That would put the state corn crop at
1.582 billion bushels, 4 percent less than 2001 and 5 percent less than 2000.

Soybean production in the state is expected to reach 414 million bushels, 13
percent below last year and the lowest production since 1996. The yield is
forecast at 40 bushels per acre, five bushels below last year and the lowest
yield since 1995 when the yield was 39 bushels per acre.

"It seems we have a great deal of disparity in terms of rainfall and how the
crop looks," Bidner said. "Some places are going to have a good crop, and some
places won't make 100 bushels (per acre). It's all over the board. In some
areas, I'm not sure a rain would even help the corn, maybe the beans."

Steve Main is a grain and hog producer from Altona in Knox County. If corn
prices go higher, he'll likely reduce the size of his hog operation.

"If corn goes to $3, and I think it's headed that way, we'll have a higher cost
of production and further depressed prices for hogs," Main said. "I think you're
going to see an exodus in the hog market. Marginal producers are already pretty
much gone. Even the big companies producing hogs are going to be hurting."

Main farms about 1,200 acres and sells 15,000 hogs a year. He has to buy about
25 percent of the corn he uses as feed.

"This will probably mean I raise more corn next year and get rid of a few hogs,"
he said.

In this week's Illinois Crop Report, released Monday by the Illinois
Agricultural Statistics Service, the corn crop was rated as 10 percent very
poor, 18 percent poor, 40 percent fair and 29 percent good. The soybean crop was
rated 8 percent very poor, 16 percent poor, 39 percent fair and 34 percent good.

The crop is still behind schedule in maturity. Only 60 percent of the corn is in
the dough stage, having completed pollination. That compares to 75 percent last
year. Corn dented was at 16 percent this week compared to 29 percent last year
and a 22 percent average. Soybeans setting pods were at 71 percent this week
compared to 86 percent last year and an 80 percent average.

Rain is needed across most of the state, and the dry conditions continue to take
a toll on crops and negatively affect yields, officials said.

LOAD-DATE: August 23, 2002

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Drought-stricken corn grows in a field near Gordonville, Mo.

TYPE: LOCAL

                   Copyright 2002 The State Journal-Register

                             902 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                                  Farming Life

                             April 21, 2015 Tuesday

MEPs have their say on trade with the US

LENGTH: 431  words


A position on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) will be
voted on by the European Parliament's agriculture committee this week.

Agriculture MEPs are taking a keen interest in ensuring that any trade agreement
does not jeopardise the current quality standards of European agricultural
products while preserving the European agricultural model and ensuring its
economic and social viability'.

Although just one of a number of committees that will feed into the parliament's
overall position, proposed amendments include warnings that agriculture must not
be used as a bargaining chip in efforts to secure access to the US market for
other sectors'.

One amendment calls for the commission to more clearly outline what impact a
TTIP agreement could have on EU agriculture by conducting a sector by sector
study as soon as possible.

World cereal supply

predictions

The Food and Agriculture Organisation of the United Nations (FAO) has published
their latest forecasts for the 2015 cereal production year.

Global wheat production is expected to reach 722 million tonnes in 2015, 2
million tonnes higher than the FAO's first production forecast in March 2015.

Improved weather conditions have raised the prospects of increased plantings in
China, India and Pakistan. Anticipated increases in growing costs in Russia and
the Ukraine could result in a reduction of both plantings and yield.

In the United States the forecast is set to rise by 2% and in Canada where
spring planting is still yet to take place there is expected to be a 3% increase
in production.

On the demand side, forecasts for world cereal utilization in 2014/15 are now
2493 million tonnes. Predictions of increased demand in China and India are
largely responsible for this increased figure.

Food focus for World Health Day

The safety of food in Europe was the focus of World Health Day last week, a
joint initiative between the World Health Organisation (WHO) and the European
Food Safety Authority (EFSA).

EFSA is the EU scientific body which provides risk assessments for policymakers
on the safety of food and feed.

The work of EFSA is important from a farming perspective, most notably because
of their work on plant protection products but also because of the wide range of
scientific issues which affect farming and the food supply chain.

Bernhard Url, EFSA's Executive Director noted that "the role of EFSA is to
ensure food safety for 500 million European consumers and we can only do that in
partnership with other organisations. By pooling these resources we can make
sure that food in Europe is safe".

LOAD-DATE: April 21, 2015

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: INFL


                       Copyright 2015 Johnston Press Plc
                              All Rights Reserved

                             903 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                          September 17, 2008 Wednesday

PH&N duo dig farming stocks that are off the beaten path;
Phillips Hager & North Vintage Fund managers bullish on 'agriculture
reinvestment story'

BYLINE: ANDY GEORGIADES, Dow Jones Newswires

SECTION: REPORT ON BUSINESS: GLOBE INVESTOR MARKETS; MUTUAL FUNDS; Pg. B13

LENGTH: 552 words

DATELINE: TORONTO


The agriculture sector may be going through a major correction, but in the
context of a secular trend, it should look like a blip on a graph one day.

That's the view of Don Anderson and Andrew MacDonald, managers of the
$100-million Phillips Hager & North Vintage Fund, who say they've been
"fortunate" to have had an overweight position in the agriculture space.

"Our view is that there is a secular agriculture reinvestment story," Mr.
Anderson said. "[Farming] has not been a high-return business for a long time.
That's led to a lack of investment in farming and agri in general."

But times are changing. People are improving their diets and the world is
consuming more grain than it produces. That makes agriculture an area of focus
for the fund, and the managers have been adding to positions rather than taking
profits amid the pullback.

The fund has made an effort to find agriculture companies that are a little more
interesting - and less known - than staples Potash Corp. and Agrium Inc., though
the fund holds both. One that stands out is Alliance Grain Traders Income Fund,
which sources and processes specialty crops, such as lentils, peas and
chickpeas.

Mr. Anderson said he sees plenty of "long-term upside" for Alliance without the
same "hype" priced into a company like Potash. Outside of Canada, Mr. Anderson
likes ABB Grain in Australia and LSB Industries Inc. in the United States.

In assessing potential investments for the fund, which was recently opened to
investors for the first time since 1993, the managers pay particular attention
to free cash flow and the prospects for future free cash flow. They also look at
return on equity, both historical and prospective.

Mr. Anderson and Mr. MacDonald have been running the fund for almost two years.
According to Globefund, the two-year average annual return is 14 per cent
compared to a loss of 0.2 per cent for the group average; the five-year return
is 11 per cent compared to 8 per cent for the group average.

The fund, which has a bias to small- and mid-capitalization stocks, will
sometimes take a contrarian approach, as it has with its position in
International Forest Products Ltd., which represents 5 per cent of the fund.

Another materials holding is Gold Wheaton Gold Corp., which Mr. Anderson
described as a "specialty financier" to the gold industry. The company purchases
gold production from mines in Ontario and British Columbia.

Energy is another area in which the fund has significant holdings, but the
recent liquidation by hedge funds hasn't dampened their overall outlook.

For instance, Mr. MacDonald called Petro Andina Resources Inc., which operates
in Argentina, a "very cheap" stock. Natural gas prices have been hit especially
hard, which isn't good for a company like Orleans Energy Ltd. in the short term.
Mr. MacDonald acknowledged it will be a "tough winter" for gas producers, but
the resulting slower drilling activity should also lead to a recovery in the
medium term.

A "bottom-up-driven" pick is Futuremed Healthcare Income Fund, a distributor of
consumable nursing-home supplies. On the other hand, it recently sold MacDonald
Dettwiler & Associates Ltd. at a loss. While the managers think it has a great
business, they are content to wait until the housing cycle turns around and buy
it back.

LOAD-DATE: September 17, 2008

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


 Copyright 2008 The Globe and Mail, a division of CTVglobemedia Publishing Inc.
                              All Rights Reserved

                             904 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                              Western Daily Press

                                 July 20, 2004

Brighter future for grain

SECTION: Sport; Rugby; AmateurUnion; Pg. 38

LENGTH: 201 words


World grain stocks look set to rise, with experts announcing positive forecasts
for the first time this year.  While the UK harvest has got off to a poor start,
with heavy rain throwing a spanner in the works, good growing conditions
globally over the past month have led the US Department of Agriculture to
estimate a global wheat stocks rise of 5.8million to 132m tonnes.

Coarse grain stocks have been increased by almost 10million tonnes, although at
115.3million tonnes they would still be the lowest since the mid-1970s.

USDA raised its world wheat production estimate by 4.6million to 598million
tonnes, and its coarse grain output figure to 939million, up 6.9million tonnes.

But next month will be critical to both corn yields in the US and wheat quality
across Europe as the rain of the past weeks in the UK has also been experienced
across most of Europe and has delayed harvest.

This has boosted demand and prices for old crop wheat to about £73 to £78 a
tonne, depending on the region, and early harvest prices have also risen to £72
to £77 a tonne ex-farm. But concerns over quality have caused later harvest
markets to drop back to about £58 to £61 a tonne.


LOAD-DATE: July 21, 2004 2007WESTDP1C1brigh

LANGUAGE: English

PUB-TYPE: News

                      Copyright 2004 Bristol United Press

                             905 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                              May 17, 1991, Friday

Farm subsidies make federal budget come a cropper

BYLINE: Donald Lambrounited/states; agriculture; research; finances; budgets

SECTION: EDITORIAL; SECTION A; PAGE 10

LENGTH: 483 words


WASHINGTON - Congress is pretending to reorder spending priorities as it
legislates a record $ 1.4 trillion budget, but the truth is that relatively
little will actually be changed in this year's appropriations.

Sadly, most of the fat, waste and abuse will continue because Congress refuses
to conduct a hard-nosed re-evaluation of the outdated and ineffective programs
it has created over many decades. Nowhere is this more evident than in the U.S.
Department of Agriculture, a cobwebbed, cluttered collection of bureaucratic
boondoggles that cries out for a thorough housecleaning.

This department is a perfect example of a program whose budget has been
mushrooming while its clientele has been shrinking. Since fiscal 1990, USDA's
budget has jumped from $ 46 billion to an estimated $ 55.7 billion. Yet the
number of farms has steadily declined: 70 years ago 35 percent of the nation's
population were farmers. Today the number has shrunk to 2 percent.

In truth, billions are being poured year after year into research programs
benefiting the same rich agribusiness industries that are capable of paying for
this research themselves. Here are some examples of where our farm dollars are
going:

- $ 67,000 for Belgian endive research. Such federally funded studies have
helped "to produce maximum yields of high quality Belgian endives." Who
benefits? The endive growers and the chic restaurants that offer them on their
high-priced menus.

- $ 1.8 million for cranberry and blueberry research into variety development,
and increased yields. Who benefits? Highly profitable fruit and fruit juice
corporations.

- $ 2.3 million for peach and pecan research to help develop new varieties of
peaches. Who benefits? "My presence here today is on behalf of the fruit and nut
industry," said Georgia Rep. Richard Ray, who testified on behalf of this
expenditure.

- $ 6.3 million for peanut research. There has been a $ 300,000 increase for
peanut studies that will focus "on the major factors affecting market quality
and cost efficiency of production," according to the Georgia Peanut Research
Committee. Beneficiaries? The wealthy peanut processing industry.

- $ 1.7 million for research to improve potato chips, french fries and other
potato products. a $ 100,000 increase over last year. This is a giveaway to the
multibillion dollar potato industry that can't seem to get enough tax subsidies.
"We need funding for everything," testified Bob Walther, vice president of the
National Potato Council.

And so it goes. Not only is USDA's research benefiting highly profitable
industries that can easily finance their own research programs, Congress has
been increasing funding in the midst of the worst deficits in American history.

But this is only a very small portion of USDA's wasteful spending. I'll reveal
more in an upcoming column.-(c1991.)

LOAD-DATE: February 10, 1992

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                    Copyright 1991 The Atlanta Constitution

                             906 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                                The Toronto Star

                    February 7, 1989, Tuesday, FINAL EDITION

U.S.-Europe war over cattle hormone spreads to Texas

BYLINE: By Steven H. Lee Special to The Star (Dallas Morning News)

SECTION: BUSINESS TODAY; Pg. B10

LENGTH: 651 words


   The Europeans say they want beef not treated with growth hormones, so they
place a ban on imports of American beef into their countries - a move expected
to cost U.S. producers in excess of $100 million (U.S.).

U.S. trade representatives call the move a trade ploy, aimed at reducing the
Europeans' surplus of beef at home. So, the United States retaliates with more
than $100 million (U.S.) in excess tariffs on imports of certain commodities
from Europe.

What has developed, predictably, is an intensified trade conflict between the
United States and the European Economic Community (EEC), the 12-nation bloc
that, ironically, represents the best customer for all U.S. farm exports, in
total dollar value.

State capital

But what some officials didn't foresee was a verbal range war right here at
home, pitting Austin, Texas, and Washington. And today, once again, the eyes of
more than just Texas will be on the state capital.

For the past month, Texas Agriculture Commissioner Jim Hightower has been
directing talks with EEC representatives to send Texas beef free of growth
hormones to Europe - over the objections of U.S. trade representatives, cattle
industry groups and the American Farm Bureau Federation.

U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) officials say the federal government would
need to certify hormone-free beef for export, but that there's no way of
verifying whether the carcasses are indeed absent of growth stimulants.

But Hightower, in a news conference scheduled for later today, is expected to
announce details of a verification system developed in conjunction with EEC
officials that will be submitted for USDA approval.

Opposition cattle industry groups already are skeptical.

"We don't disagree with what (Hightower's) intent is in opening new markets, but
in this particular case, we disagree with his method," said Wes Bonner,
president of the Texas Cattle Feeders Association, and owner of Veribest Cattle
Feeders Inc. in San Angelo.

An EEC spokeswoman, however, said the Europeans are viewing today's announcement
with hope.

"There's no question that we're interested because we would like to maintain the
trade," said Ella Krucoff, the EEC spokeswoman in Washington. "We think it's
unfortunate that our health standards are being labeled protectionist. We have
to enforce those standards.

American cattle producers implant growth stimulants, or mix them with feed, to
produce leaner meat - and more of it. The National Cattlemen's Association
estimates that up to 65 per cent of all cattle is treated with growth hormones.

Hightower's stance has drawn the ire also of public officials in Washington.
Agriculture Secretary designate Clayton Yeutter, in confirmation hearings last
week, said Hightower has been "singularly unhelpful" in preparations for
upcoming trade talks, accusing the commissioner of siding with the Europeans.

Texas Farm Bureau president S.M. True last month called for Hightower's
resignation. Jimmie Powell, president of the Texas and Southwestern Cattle
Raisers Association, lashed out at Hightower's "uneducated, uninformed
statements," and said that the commissioner had damaged the Texas cattle
industry.

Consumer groups

The cattle groups also maintain that there's not enough cattle produced free of
growth hormones to supply the EEC request. Hightower has said about 35,000 head
of cattle would be required, while the cattle groups say the actual number is
5.7 million.

Still, Hightower - who has garnered support from several consumer groups and
some cattle producers who produce so-called "natural" beef - is pressing on.

"We're taking a states' rights position," he has said. "If Ollie North can go
run a private war with the applause of the administration, why are they getting
in the way of a few cattlemen who want to make a sale to our very best
customers?"

DALLAS MORNING NEWS

LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1999

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                  Copyright 1989 Toronto Star Newspapers, Ltd.

                             907 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                 Sampson Independent (Clinton, North Carolina)

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                             October 2, 2016 Sunday

Farm leaders rally for eastern North Carolina agriculture

BYLINE: Chase Jordan, The Sampson Independent, Clinton, N.C.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 1453 words


Oct. 02--KENANSVILLE -- When it comes to agriculture in eastern North Carolina,
farmers have a lot to smile about. One of those proud farmers is Sen. Brent
Jackson and, while facing a large audience Thursday night, he showed it to
people from west of Interstate 95.

"For all of those who live west of 95, I want to welcome you to God's country,"
Jackson said while drawing chuckles and applause during the Agriculture Rally at
the Duplin County Events Center.

The first generation farmer from Sampson County was one of many supporters who
addressed the successes and needs for agriculture in the region and throughout
North Carolina.

While showing support, Jackson continued and spoke about the labor of farmers
and making ends meet.

"We created the term 'Get 'Er Done" before it was ever popular, because you have
to make it work," Jackson said. "That's what we have done as a legislative
team."

Jackson added that agriculture is the lifeblood of the region, state and the
United States and encouraged the audience to support lawmakers who support it.
Before Jackson took the stage, Ed Emory, chairman of NC Farm Families, talked
about the state's biggest industry, which accounts for one-sixths of the income,
$84 billion of the state's gross product and 700,000 employees who work in food,
forestry and fiber industries. He also mentioned that seven of the top 10
producers are in the eastern region, which affects the quality of life.

"It's important that we gather tonight and celebrate that fact," Emory said.
"But we also need to remember that we produce a safe, good, quality, food supply
that feeds not only the United States -- we feed the world."

To express a point about support, Emory recited a quote from President Ronald
Reagan, who once said "We're nothing without our farmers. They're the backbone
of this country and everything we do to help them helps our country and its
future."

Rep. John Bell also stressed how agriculture feeds the world while encouraging
the audience to cheer and celebrate it. The legislator also talked about
improvements such as the unemployment rate dropping, road improvements and
salary increases for teachers.

"We have a wonderful story to tell," Bell said. "We inherited a broken car on
the side of the road, but we fixed it. We're not done yet, we still have a lot
to do. Our state is currently in great fiscal shape and we're continuing to move
forward."

Like Jackson and other state leaders present, he believes it's important to
elect people who support agriculture.

"We need to elect people who understand that food does not come from a grocery
store," Bell said.

N.C. House Speaker Tim Moore said agriculture plays a big part in employing
people and improving infrastructure in rural areas.

"We see great growth in the cities, but we see sometimes in rural areas we have
to keep being innovative with how we keep up, bring new jobs and do things,"
Moore said. "Agriculture has been a very key part of that -- transportation
infrastructure, water and sewer infrastructure. These are all things that we
fund and we want to make sure that rural North Carolina is able to be just as
competitive as urban and suburban North Carolina."

While sharing stories related to farming, Harry Brown, N.C. Senate Majority
Leader, and others also expressed feelings about the work ethic of farmers
throughout the state.

"Again, I can't thank you enough for what you do," Brown said. "In eastern North
Carolina and rural North Carolina in particular, agriculture is what it's all
about. That's where the jobs are at. You provide something that this whole state
has to have. That need is going to continue to grow and get bigger and bigger.
It's a rural problem that you're going to have to be a part of the solution
for."

Brown told local farmers and supporters that they'll meet the challenge. Later,
organizer Rep. Jimmy Dixon expressed gratitude for farm families who were
pioneers in the area.

"All of us have benefited from the hard work and innovation of some true
pioneers in agriculture fields," Dixon said while quoting Abraham Lincoln words,
"Every blade of grass is a study; and to produce two, where there was but one,
is both a profit and a pleasure."

N.C. Agriculture Commissioner Steve Troxler presented a few facts about
agricultural profits. His goal is to grow the industry by $100 billion by 2020,
which is an increase of $16 billion. One of the ideas is to improve food
manufacturing to supplement the products which are grown in the state.

"Something that is an anomaly to me is that we're the number one sweet potato
state in the nation, by a long shot," Troxler said. "We grow about 50 percent of
the sweet potatoes in the nation. But do you know how many sweet potato cannings
we have in North Carolina? None."

The sweet potato example was just one example of how the state can profit from
what it produces from the ground. He also mentioned how a can of raw beans is
really worth 10 cents, but by the time it gets to the grocery store, the value
is worth a few bucks.

"Look at what we're missing by not having that manufacturing here in the state,"
Troxler said.

He also mentioned the Connect NC Bond, introduced by Gov. Pat McCrory and $94
million which is being spent to build a Agriculture and Consumer Sciences Lab
for veterinary, food, drug and motor fuel testing. While discussing the
livestock industry, Troxler mentioned the importance of plant production.

"Our livestock actually eats plants," Troxler said. "So keeping North Carolina
at the very forefront of being able to produce the plants that we need, not only
for human consumption, but for animal protein, is going to be vital."

Like other supports, Troxler said it's an exciting time to be involved in
agriculture. McCrory and Lt. Gov. Dan Forest felt the same way.

"You guys are really the heart and soul of North Carolina," Forest said. "You
guys are what makes North Carolina great."

Forest said 100 years ago, 40 percent of Americans made their living in
agriculture. Today, that number has dwindled to 2 percent or less.

"We're now feeding more people here in America and more people around the world
than we ever fed, in the history of the United States," Forest said. "You're
doing it with less and less people. You guys really know what hard work is
about. You know what sacrifice is about. You know what risk is about. You are
what makes North Carolina great."

Forest said the farmers will have to do more with less and fight problems such
as environmental terrorism.

McCrory praised the culture of the farming community.

"The culture of the farming community is second to no culture in the United
States of America," McCrory said. "The farming community understands resiliency
more than anything else."

McCrory told a story about peanut farmers who struggled with too much rain and
their willingness not to give up, his example of resiliency.

"They're resilient," he said about agriculture producers dealing with challenges
such as the weather. "They're more resilient than any people in any industry in
the United States of America. Because there are things that are out of your
control that are in God's hands and they accept it."

He said it's something he respects. Another trait was independence and alluded
to farmers not wanting to be held back because of government regulations.
McCrory also mentioned the entrepreneurial opportunities of farming.

"I read about all of these Wall Street geniuses up in New York, San Francisco
and even Charlotte," McCrory said. "But the people who are really business
geniuses are the farmers. They're the ones who have to trade when it's up, when
it's down. Do I hold? Do I fold? Do I sell? Do I give it away? Every single day.
And I tell you what, your track record is a whole lot better than Wall Street.
There's no doubt about it."

Many attendees responded to the messages of presenters with applause. Ben
Aydlett was one of many who attended Thursday night.

"Being from a small town, I think that agriculture is the backbone of this
country," Aydlett said. "I feel like some of these politicians really appreciate
that and giving it the value it deserves."

Coming from a military Thomas Ritchie enjoyed McCrory's message about
patriotism. His farther served in the military and its one of the reasons his
family moved to the state.

"The state is very friendly to its veterans and takes good care of its
veterans," he said. "The culture here, like the governor said is very respectful
and reverent towards its veterans."

Reach Chase Jordan at 910-249-4617. Follow us on Twitter at @SampsonInd and like
us on Facebook.

Independent (Clinton, N.C.) at www.clintonnc.com Distributed by Tribune Content
Agency, LLC.

JOURNAL-CODE: 1SM

                             908 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                            The Statesman (AsiaNet)

                           January 30, 2014 Thursday

Pakistan can benefit from Canadian experience in agriculture: Greg Giokas

SECTION: Vol. 16 No. 29

LENGTH: 763  words


Canadian High Commissioner to Pakistan Greg Giokas on Wednesday said Pakistan is
agricultural super power in many ways but the yield is very low.

Pakistan has a lot of natural resources including vast agricultural and mineral
base. However, it needs structural reforms that is, in education, skill
development and taxation, he said.

The Canadian High Commissioner was addressing the members of English Speaking
Union in Pakistan here.

He said that Pakistan is considered as a middle income country and Canada wants
to see it peaceful, prosperous and progressive.

He said: "Under WTO, we must focus on developing its competency through
trainings and skill development of the manpower especially in agriculture. We
would have to improve our quality , yield and certification of our produce".

He noted that Pakistan government needs due consultations with agriculturists ,
businessmen and other stakeholders including the donor agencies to come with
practical policies for developing and putting agriculture sector on  modern line
assuring high yield for the benefit of the country and its large farming
community.  It needs a comprehensive agriculture policy and its true
implementation.

Pakistani businessmen should invest in various sectors mainly in agriculture and
in the associated businesses for the improvement of these sectors along with
making their profits. Investment in agriculture generates more employment than
other sectors.

He underlined the need for women empowerment in Pakistan as they had a great
contribution here in agriculture and dairy farming.

Canadian High Commissioner said that his country has focused on tariff regime.
It had initiated tariff reforms leading to preferential tariffs since 2010 which
will be completed in 2015.

He shared his country's experiences regarding opening of economy and trade
especially with its neighbouring countries.

He informed that majority of Canadian people showed strong negative reaction and
became a controversial issue when Canada signed free trade agreement (FTA) with
United States. However, the result came totally different. It helped generate a
great economic activity in Canada and now we have also huge trade with US.

He  advocated that Pakistan should open its economy particularly for the
neighbours. " We should find deficiencies and fundamentally review our
structural policies to benefit from the emerging changes on global economic
scenario ," He suggested that Pakistan should not hesitate in going forward with
the Most Favoured Nation status to India as this would be in the interest of
both the people. The regional trade is being focused in the world and it has
proved very beneficial for all the trading partners.

He said agricultural sector is the most protected sector under WTO. Pakistan has
great potential in agriculture , dairy farming and poultry which can be used for
the development of the farming communities.

" We want to share our experiences to support Pakistan's agriculture," he said
adding that his country had agriculture exports of dollars 47 billion which is
expected to reach dollars fifty billion soon. All this because of reducing
subsidies , rationalization of tariffs and research and development ,
involvement of businessmen and consultations with the stakeholders in this
sector besides providing a level playing field to our agriculturists", he said.

Canada exported 14 million tonnes of canola last year, he informed. The Canadian
diplomat said he had discussions with Pakistan Government functionaries
especially on agriculture trade between the two countries. That, the response
from Pakistan Government was very positive.

He said Pakistan is agricultural super power in many ways but the yield is very
low. Pakistan should also focus on the development of quality seeds and
genetically modified products. You people should have a seed policy.

" It is not possible to feed 18 million through naturally grown crops. Diversity
is needed," he remarked.

He acknowledged that good research has been done in Pakistan under Pakistan's
Agriculture Coalition Programme.

He noted that it is very positive that in Pakistan a chain of fast foods was
growing very fast which would help promote its agriculture.

He said trade between Canada and Pakistan has been fluctuating.  It was dollars
700million last year and is in favour of his country. Canada has trade with
India up to $6billion and with China it was $70 billion.

Earlier, President English Speaking Union in Pakistan Aziz Memon spoke of the
economic issues of Pakistan especially of trade and sought Canadian support in
different sectors.

LOAD-DATE: January 30, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                   Copyright 2014 Mashriq Group of Newspapers
                              All Rights Reserved

                             909 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                            The Statesman (AsiaNet)

                           January 30, 2014 Thursday

Pakistan can benefit from Canadian experience in agriculture: Greg Giokas

expected to reach dollars fifty billion soon. All this because of reducing
subsidies , rationalization of tariffs and research and development ,
involvement of businessmen and consultations with the stakeholders in this
sector besides providing a level playing field to our agriculturists", he said.

Canada exported 14 million tonnes of canola last year, he informed. The Canadian
diplomat said he had discussions with Pakistan Government functionaries
especially on agriculture trade between the two countries. That, the response
from Pakistan Government was very positive.

He said Pakistan is agricultural super power in many ways but the yield is very
low. Pakistan should also focus on the development of quality seeds and
genetically modified products. You people should have a seed policy.

" It is not possible to feed 18 million through naturally grown crops. Diversity
is needed," he remarked.

He acknowledged that good research has been done in Pakistan under Pakistan's
Agriculture Coalition Programme.

He noted that it is very positive that in Pakistan a chain of fast foods was
growing very fast which would help promote its agriculture.

He said trade between Canada and Pakistan has been fluctuating.  It was dollars
700million last year and is in favour of his country. Canada has trade with
India up to $6billion and with China it was $70 billion.

Earlier, President English Speaking Union in Pakistan Aziz Memon spoke of the
economic issues of Pakistan especially of trade and sought Canadian support in
different sectors.

                             910 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                     Belfast News Letter (Northern Ireland)

                            April 3, 2002, Wednesday

FARMING LIFE: WORLD-CLASS CONGRESS TO FOCUS ON FARMING'S FUTURE

BYLINE: David Mccoy

SECTION: FARMING LIFE; Pg. 12

LENGTH: 809 words


A WORLD-class annual congress at which international leaders in food and
agriculture will examine the challenges facing global agriculture, debate their
effects and predict the impact on world farming, food and trade, has been
launched in London.

Differing in both style and content from existing national and international
food and farming conferences, The World Food and Farming Congress will take
place in London every other year, alternating with other major venues throughout
the world.

The inaugural congress, 'Meeting the needs of a changing world', will take place
at Olympia, London, on Monday and Tuesday, November 25 and 26, 2002, being
associated with The Royal Smithfield Show. Organised by Clarion Events, and with
the support of the Washington-based International Policy Council (IPC) on
Agriculture, Food and Trade, the congress will be chaired by Lord Plumb, until
recently chairman of IPC.

Attracting speakers of the highest calibre, the congress will highlight
practical developments in world farming and food production, establish a link
between world policy issues, and examine practical advances in production
techniques and new technologies. The event will also provide scientists and
opinion-formers with an opportunity to comment on significant issues related to
food and agriculture, such as the use of biotechnology, climate change and the
form of the CAP.

Given its fundamental message, the congress will attract a high calibre
audience, including politicians, agricultural policy-makers, representatives
from the food and supply industries, international traders, academics,
scientists, environmentalists, consumer organisations and the media.

The opening day's programme will include two sessions, chaired by Lord Plumb.

The first, entitled 'Future world demand and supply', will consider the effects
of growing global prosperiy on consumer demand and tastes in the context of
constraints on water, land, environmental and health demands. Eminent speakers
will include Ke Bingsheng, director general, Research Centre for Rural
Economics, Ministry of Agriculture, China.

In the afternoon, 'Trade issues and the globalisation of farming', will question
whether free trade is a realistic proposition, investigate its limitations, and
consider the implications of the 11th of September on food security issues.

The session will also evaluate whether agriculture in the developed world can
compete with the low wage structures and differing standards of animal welfare
in developing countries.

Among the speakers will be Robert Thompson, chairman of the International Policy
Council and senior adviser, Agricultural Trade Policy at the World Bank.

'The balance and transfer of knowledge and experience', subject of the morning
session on day two, will consider the implications of science, in particular
biotechnology, on world agriculture and human health. Chaired by Lord Selborne,
former chairman of the House of Lords Select Committee on Science and
Technology, the session will examine how the developed world can assist
developing countries to deliver tangible benefits to their populations. It will
include a paper by Margaret Karembu, Director, Agricentre International Service
for the Acquisition of Agri-Biotech Application in Kenya.

During the afternoon, the speakers, who include Dennis Avery, Global Food Issues
at the Hudson Institute, will address 'The conflict between the affluent
consumer and the needs of the majority'. In doing so, they will ask whether
Western standards should apply to less affluent countries and question whether
developing countries should be denied certain advances in science on the grounds
of emotion rather than fact.

Speaking at the launch of the congress, James Brooks-Ward, group director of
Clarion Events, said: "Global agriculture is undergoing a period of significant
and rapid change. Never before have so many factors, such as economic and
environmental pressures, population growth, changing consumer attitudes,
increased affluence and new technologies, come together to create such an impact
on world food production. The World Food and Farming Congress has been designed
to provide an overview of agriculture's role in this fast-changing world, answer
the plethora of questions surrounding its future and highlights the
opportunities that change presents."

Lord Plumb commented: "The World Food and Farming Congress is a significant and
welcomed addition to the annual calendar of events. The fact that the
International Policy Council has lent its support highlights the quality of the
event and underlines its depth and credibility, both in terms of the quality of
speakers and the audience it will attract."

The next World Food and Farming Congress is scheduled to take place in Central
America during November 2003

LOAD-DATE: April 3, 2002

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUB-TYPE: PAPER

                                February 5, 2009

USDA calls on lamb producers

BYLINE: The Goldendale Sentinel staff

LENGTH: 167  words


The United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) has put out a call for
opinions from sheep producers and handlers.

Officials want to know whether producers should continue to pay an assessment to
fund marketing and research efforts of the American Lamb Board.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture will conduct a nationwide referendum on the
Lamb, Promotion, Research and Information Act of 1996, which expires the end of
this month.

USDA's Agricultural Marketing Service will conduct the referendum with the
assistance of USDA's Farm Service Agency. Eligible sheep producers and handlers
may vote by mail, fax, Internet or in person in the county where their farm
records are maintained with the Farm Service Agency

If they do not participate in FSA programs, they may vote at the county FSA
office where they own or rent land.

Persons eligible to vote may obtain form LS-86 from their county FSA office or
online at http://www.ams.usda.gov/lsmar-ketingprograms.

For more information, call 773-5822 ext 105.
