                               The New York Times

                            October 31, 2004 Sunday
                              Late Edition - Final

American Dirt, Mexican Grit: New York's Newest Farmers

BYLINE: By JENNIFER MEDINA

SECTION: Section 1; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk; Pg. 38

LENGTH: 1058 words

DATELINE: PINE ISLAND, N.Y., Oct. 24


It was the end of harvest season and Martin Rodriguez had plenty of work to do.
There were chilies to pick, rows of crops to clean and soil to turn over.

First, though, the farmer had to get to his farm.

So just as he had done every day for the last six months, Mr. Rodriguez began
the drive from his apartment in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, for the two-hour trip to
the six-acre farm he runs in Orange County.

Like other farms in the Hudson Valley, Mr. Rodriguez's produces lettuce,
brussels sprouts and tomatoes. But alongside stand neat rows of four kinds of
tomatillos and Mexican herbs with names like ''tlalpanche,'' ''alache'' and
''pipicha'' -- none of which have an English translation.

The specialty produce earned Mr. Rodriguez near-celebrity status at farmers'
markets in East Harlem, Jackson Heights and Sunset Park, where on good days he
sold as much as $1,500 in produce.

Mr. Rodriguez has become a success story for the New Farmer Development Project,
a program run by New York City's Greenmarket program to encourage Hispanic
immigrants to farm in the region. The program, which started in 2000, runs a
training course to teach immigrants who have agricultural experience how to
navigate the farming industry.

Although 85 people have completed the course, only eight, including Mr.
Rodriguez, are running farms in the region. About a dozen others are working on
training farms on Staten Island and in Brooklyn or helping on other farms in the
area.

The city's program is tapping into a demographic shift taking place across the
country as a growing number of immigrant farmers change the face of agriculture,
experts say. The number of Hispanic workers who rely on farming for their
livelihood has nearly doubled to 29,050 in the last decade, according to the
United States Department of Agriculture. Almost all of the increase can be
attributed to immigrants, said Rachel Dannefer, the Brooklyn-based coordinator
of the National Immigrant Farming Initiative, which collects information from
some 20 programs nationwide that promote farming by immigrants.

Still, trying to succeed as a farmer has not been easy for Mr. Rodriguez.

The commute, usually done in the dark hours before sunrise, has taken a toll.
''There's never enough sleep,'' Mr. Rodriguez said as he drove in his van to the
farm recently.

He is unlikely to make much of a profit this year. Each trip to the farm has
meant spending $50 on gas, and there is a stack of bills in his apartment yet to
be paid. He is not sure how much money he will have left after he pays his
bills.

The list of uncertainties is long. Will he have to find another job for the
winter? Will he rent the same land next year? Will he be able to rent or buy a
tractor? Will he be able to find a place to live closer to the farm?

''We only need two things to make it better,'' Mr. Rodriguez said. ''A machine
and a house.''

Just a few days after completing the city's 12-week training program in April,
Mr. Rodriguez told Kate Granger, the program's director, that he wanted to start
a 10-acre farm on the land in Pine Island. The program maintains a list of
farmers in the region willing to rent part of their land. Mr. Rodriguez pays
$250 an acre in rent for the season.

''I really wasn't sure it was possible,'' Ms. Granger said. ''It's an incredibly
tough business that needs so much planning.''

She persuaded him to limit the farm to six acres, and Mr. Rodriguez heeded
advice about laying down black plastic sheeting to protect the crops, but he
ignored warnings that he was planting seedlings too early.

By the time Mr. Rodriguez began selling his produce at the markets, Ms. Granger
was convinced that his determination was paying off. Customers at farmers'
markets would start lining up at his booth, called RodriMex, by 7 a.m., two
hours before he would arrive with the freshest produce. ''There was no other
place for them to go,'' said Garencia, Mr. Rodriguez's wife, who often sold some
produce before Mr. Rodriguez arrived with the day's latest pickings.

The crops her husband and his brother, Pedro Rodriguez, were growing were the
same vegetables and herbs that she had cooked with before she immigrated from
Puebla, Mexico, about 16 years ago.

At the markets, Ms. Rodriguez would arrange the produce and explain to customers
how to use the products. Three of her daughters and some of her nieces, who
range from 7 to 12 years old, would help translate.

It was not difficult for Mr. Rodriguez to decide what kind of crops to plant.
John Ameroso, an educator from Cornell University's cooperative extension
service who teaches the 12-week training class, told him that familiar crops
would start a customer base. The additions were a matter of pride.

''I grew them because I'm Mexican,'' he said with a proud grin. ''I knew the
other Mexicans would buy them. But I didn't think the 'gringos' would like them
so much.''

On nights when they had to water the crops at 2 a.m., the Rodriguez brothers
would sleep in the van on blankets spread out on black rubber mats. They would
awaken before dawn to gather the crops that must be sold the same day they were
harvested.

In Sunset Park, Ms. Rodriguez would worry that her husband might fall asleep on
the road. ''I'd tell him just to sleep for a few hours, that it would make him
feel better, but he doesn't always do that,'' she said.

This year there were no other options. There are no houses for rent in the area,
and the family cannot afford to buy one.

In addition to the agricultural challenges that all farmers face, immigrant
farmers, many of whom do not speak English, can find it difficult to get loans
to purchase land or a home. Several have illegally crossed the border from
Mexico and drive without a license.

Mr. Rodriguez seems certain that he will farm again next year, even if he must
continue the grueling commute.

''How can you stop when there are all these people who believe in you?'' he
said. As Martin and Pedro Rodriguez picked the last of the jalapenos, two of
their daughters trailed behind them, collecting green and red peppers in their
own baskets. Martin Rodriguez took off his white cowboy hat and fanned himself.

''That's it, the season is over,'' Pedro Rodriguez said. Martin filled the van
with bushels of chiles and a few carrots, then started the engine for the
two-hour drive.


URL: http://www.nytimes.com

LOAD-DATE: October 31, 2004

farmland in Orange County, and facing the two-hour commute back home to
Brooklyn.

Mexican chili peppers, right, for sale in farmers' markets. (Photographs by John
Marshall Mantel for The New York Times)

                               The New York Times

              January 14, 1981, Wednesday, Late City Final Edition

Farm Policies Draw Warning

BYLINE: Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section D; Page 16, Column 4; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 172 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13


This country's farm policies and laws, originally conceived to combat crop
surpluses and low farm prices and basically unchanged in the past 50 years, are
out of date, the Agriculture Department said today.

Unless these are changed, American farms will continue to grow larger and
control of food resources will be concentrated in the hands of fewer persons,
the department's farm structure study, 22 months in preparation, asserts.

Secretary of Agriculture Bob Bergland said the study showed that current
programs designed to protect family farming were actually pushing families out
of farming and keeping new farmers from entering it.

The study, Mr. Bergland said, was the most important internal activity the
department had undertaken in the last four years. He had hoped to use it as a
guide in formulating a new farm law, which the Reagan administration and the new
Congress must do this year, he said.

                             941 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                              Journal of Commerce

                            June 25, 1998, Thursday

Florida drought socks farmers

BYLINE: BY LESTER ALDRICH

SECTION: COMMODITIES/CHEMICALS/ENERGY; Pg. 8A

LENGTH: 514 words

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Mo.


Florida's worst drought since possibly 1952 is hurting the state's economy, but
no one knows how badly yet.

The worst areas for drought are the 40 counties north of Ocala, which leaves out
the state's critical concentrations of vegetable and citrus producers, said Bob
Blankenship, economic researcher for the state Department of Agriculture.

About 18 percent of Florida's total agriculture is in the affected area, Mr.
Blankenship said. But because of wildfires in other areas, all but two of
Florida's counties are federal disaster areas.

        In 1997, Florida had about $4.0 billion worth of crops, with about $250
million in the drought-affected area, he said.

State agriculture officials are sure that some farmers are going out of business
or are about to get out, he said. And many of those about to leave are good
farmers. They've just been hit with their third consecutive year of reduced
crops. The past two years have had yields reduced by hurricanes or other storms.

Fortunately for the state's economy, Florida's main citrus and winter vegetable
crop seasons are past, Mr. Blankenship said. And their main locations are south
of the hardest-hit north.

        The crops grown in the northern areas are corn, peanuts, cotton and hay,
with hay and corn the hardest hit. But in the area, all 600,000 acres of major
cropland are affected by drought. Part of the state's cattle and dairy and most
of its chicken production is there as well.

Area farmers have lost an estimated $100 million in 1998 sales because of the
drought, Mr. Blankenship said.

        Corn and hay each have lost $20 million, he said. This represents about
90 percent of the annual corn sales from 95,000 planted acres and 30 percent of
annual hay production from 200,000 planted acres.

The northern counties of Florida have about 90,000 acres of peanuts this year,
and officials are estimating 25 to 30 percent is lost if it starts raining now.
Similar percentage losses are estimated in the area's 103,000 planted cotton
acres, its 17,000 acres of watermelons and 35,000 acres of soybeans.

About 30 percent of Florida's cattle are in the hardest-hit northern area, Mr.
Blankenship said. Many cattlemen are selling their livestock because they have
run out of options, he said. Hay prices for shipped-in product have nearly
doubled in the past month to about $60.00 to $65.00 a short ton from $30.00 to
$35.00.

Milk production also has declined 25 percent across the state during the past
month, he said.

      In addition, wildfires have cut timber harvest values by $10 million this
year, Mr. Blankenship said.

        As farmers try to deal with the losses and try to cut expenses, they are
trimming or halting fertilizer, pesticide and herbicide applications, he said.
This is having a ripple effect on allied industries.

There also have been some concerns about chicken production, he said.

However, chicken houses are built to minimize heat stress losses, and he had
heard of no particular increased losses over the normal 5 percent.

LOAD-DATE: June 26, 1998

                               The New York Times

              November 22, 1984, Thursday, Late City Final Edition

Soviet Grain Purchases

SECTION: Section D; Page 11, Column 6; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 228 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21


A Soviet grain negotiating team indicated to Agriculture Department officials
today that the 22 million metric tons of corn, wheat and soybeans the United
States has offered to sell them this year would be sufficient. They did not ask
for permission to buy any more than that in the coming 10 months.

The Soviet team was here for the semiannual consultations provided for in the
five-year grain trade agreement the United States signed with the Soviet Union
last year.

Under Secretary of Agriculture Daniel G. Amstutz, who was the host for the
two-day meeting, said that the talks had been candid and cordial.

The Agriculture Department has already estimated a smaller than usual Russian
grain harvest and has been expecting the Soviet Union to have to import a record
50 million metric tons of grain this year to sustain expanding milk and meat
production.

Under the agreement, the Soviet Union is obligated to buy annually a minimum of
9 million metric tons of wheat, corn, and soybeans and a maximum of 12 million
tons from United States grain dealers. If the Russians want to buy more than the
maximum, they must ask the Agriculture Department for permission.

In the first two months of the current agreement year, the Russians have already
purchased and shipped 3.4 million tons of United States wheat and 8.1 million
tons of corn, Mr. Amstutz said.

                             943 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                        The Atlanta Journal-Constitution

                        May 3, 2004 Monday Home Edition

OUR OPINIONS: Reducing farm subsidies would spark competition

SOURCE: AJC

SECTION: Editorial; Pg. 8A

LENGTH: 662 words


It struck like a clap of thunder on a summer day, the kind that usually
announces rough weather. Such was the surprise announcement last week that a
ruling at the World Trade Organization could force the United States to lower
crop subsidies to cotton farmers.

And if cotton subsidies come under fire for destroying trade, can other crop
subsidies be far behind? The successful Brazilian complaint could embolden
others who suffer on the wrong end of crop supports paid by wealthy countries,
including sugar subsidies by the European Union and rice subsidies by Japan. (As
it happens, fairer trade in rice could even benefit the United States, which has
long wanted to tap into the protected Japanese rice market.) The ruling, which
is preliminary, could be a harbinger of a new era where poorer nations with
small farmers can gain in the world market.

U.S. trade officials and members of Congress winced at the ruling and pledged to
fight it, much as they did months ago when the domestic steel industry was
flagged for unfair competition. In that instance, after much grumbling by the
Bush administration, Washington relented before trade sanctions could be
imposed.

As with the steel issue, the cotton ruling is a political problem for President
Bush. He and his strategists are depending on Farm Belt voters, who benefit
heavily from the government's $19 billion in annual subsidies. That's why the
administration responded with a pledge to appeal.

The farm subsidy issue hits home. Georgia, according to statistics from the U.S.
Department of Agriculture, has enjoyed more than $796 million in cotton
subsidies between 1995 and 2002. In 2002 alone, the state's cotton subsidies
amounted to nearly $105 million. But the cotton figure looks modest compared to
the $483 million in peanut subsidies showered on Georgia in 2002.

Fiscal conservatives have railed against subsidies for decades, but the WTO
ruling possibly creates a new opportunity to promote change. In the past, farm
subsidies and crop supports were defended as a way to save "the family farm."

But today, subsidies flow heaviest toward agribusiness, including producers and
financiers. For instance, in 2002, the biggest recipient of subsidies in Georgia
listed by the USDA was John Hancock Mutual Insurance, a big investor in both
timber and agriculture, which received $2 million.

Under pressure to change this and other forms of protectionism, the United
States could begin to write trade policy on a more level playing field. It could
bring an end to the old game of government picking winners in the economy and,
instead, let competition hold sway.

The sweeping finding by the WTO was not simply that subsidized American cotton
was unfair competition. It also held that the volume of subsidized cotton, which
now amounts to 40 percent of all cotton produced worldwide, drives world prices
so low that even subsistence farmers cannot compete.

One of the leading opponents of subsidies is the tiny, landlocked African nation
of Burkina Faso, without notable natural resources and 90 percent dependent on
small farms. Such nations struggle not for prosperity, but for mere survival
against economic powers like us who pay farmers to grow corn, soy and grain.

However much the United States may be rankled by the impertinence of Brazil's
challenging our system on behalf of its farmers, Americans must acknowledge that
this is a chance to contemplate reform and also to negotiate more openly with
Third World nations to fashion a path toward more equity and fairness and
broader opportunity.

Allen Johnson, chief agricultural negotiator for the U.S. Trade Representative,
said it well: "We think the immediate impact of the [Brazil case] should be that
we roll up our sleeves . . . All parties need to recognize that their policies
need to be on the table as well."

* EQUAL TIME: For another perspective on this issue, see the next page, A9

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                  January 2, 1992, THURSDAY, FIVE STAR Edition

FAMILY FARMS: SLIPSLIDING AWAY

SECTION: EDITORIAL; Pg. 2F

LENGTH: 371 words


The bucolic scene of the family farm - husband and wife and children, house,
barns, cows, hogs, horses and grain growing in the fields - becomes dimmer with
each passing decade. Replacing this image, which exists mostly in nostalgic
pictures and dairy farming states where holdings are relatively small and the
work labor intensive, is one of large corporate and family-owned spreads that
produce a handful of products, depending on the location and climate.  And for
the first time this century, the 2 million farms have more owners than
operators. This means that government agricultural policy will be influenced
more heavily by people who look to farming for income but may have little
contact with the land and may not be as interested in the well-being of the
land, as the ideal small farmer has been.  According to a new U.S. Department of
Agriculture study on the structure of American agriculture, the number of
farmers and the number of people directly involved in farming have reached their
lowest point in this century. Yet slightly more acres of privately owned land,
833 million, are devoted to farming than in 1900. This land is owned by 2.95
million people, with a small minority, a mere 124,000, owning 47 percent of the
land.  In general, these ownership statistics show that American agriculture
continues to be converted to ever-larger blocks of land, held by absentee
owners, who exert enormous influence over federal and state agricultural
policies through well-financed lobbying efforts. When Congress and the White
House look at farm programs in light of free-trade considerations and tight
budgets, they should recall that the pastoral image of the family farm is more
an ideal than a reality. Many of these changes are the direct result of earlier
department policies that encouraged large spreads and little variety in crops
and livestock.  The federal government should ensure that this concentration of
agricultural power is not needlessly accelerated, nor should it allow a select
few people who happen to own valuable farm land to attract a disproportionate
share of tax dollars through farm programs that purport to support an idea - the
romantic family farm - whose time has passed.

                               The New York Times

               October 25, 1983, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

SECTION: Section D; Page 16, Column 5; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 426 words


COMMODITIES Grain and Soybeans Off; Price Rises Expected


By The Associated Press

Grain and soybean futures prices languished in a narrow range and finished
mostly lower yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

Analysts said, however, that a report later in the day that corn supplies were
lower than expected was likely to raise prices today.

Trading was light yesterday in anticipation of the report, as most traders were
reluctant to open new contract positions and others were squaring the positions
they held.

The report, released by the Agriculture Department, disclosed stocks of corn and
wheat as of Oct. 1.

It said stocks of wheat totaled 2.95 billion bushels, which was about as
expected.

Corn stocks, however, totaled 3.14 billion bushels, about 300 million bushels
less than the most recent U.S.D.A. supply-demand report, and about 260 million
bushels less than most analysts expected.

If the figure is correct, said Mike Hinebaugh, a grain analyst in Chicago with
ContiCommodity Services Inc., the corn supplies will be insufficient to last the
year at current rates of consumption.  At any rate, he said, ''The bottom line
is 260 million bushels of corn less than the market expected.''

Analysts expected corn for delivery in December to open higher today in response
to the report.

Yesterday, sources said the early pressure came primarily from outside markets,
where financial instrument prices were sharply lower and the United States
dollar was stronger against major foreign currencies.

Prices failed to rally despite a lack of sales by farmers on cash markets and
weekend rain that delayed the harvest, threatening further damage to the corn
and soybean crops.

Cattle prices were lower and live hogs and frozen pork bellies were mixed on the
Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

Cattle prices were under pressure as the price of carcass beef fell 2 cents a
pound in early trading on cash markets.

Supplies are plentiful, said Robert Holbert, a livestock analyst with
ContiCommodity Services, and demand traditionally is light from October through
late November.

Hog prices also were lower early in the session as cash prices fell on wholesale
markets, Mr. Holbert said. But later in the day, the selling lightened up and
prices recoverd.

Mr. Holbert noted that hog prices have been steady despite exceptionally large
slaughters during the past two weeks, rousing ideas that grocery markets are
widely featuring specials on pork.

Pork bellies were under pressure from lower cash quotes as well, Mr. Holbert
said.

             National Post's Financial Post & FP Investing (Canada)

                           December 19, 2015 Saturday
                                 Early Edition

End of U.S. meat labelling law seen as 'great day for Canada'

BYLINE: Dan Healing, Calgary Herald, With Files From The Canadian Press

SECTION: FINANCIAL POST; Pg. B3

LENGTH: 618 words


A potential trade war between Canada and the United States was averted Friday
when Congress passed a massive spending bill that also repealed a controversial
meat labelling law.

The 2,000-plus pages of legislation contained a two-page rider that scrapped the
U.S. labelling law, known as COOL, which had become a major irritant among
Canada, Mexico and the U.S. U.S. President Barack Obama formally signed the bill
Friday to complete the legislative process.

The World Trade Organization granted Canada and Mexico the right to impose $1
billion in punitive tariffs on various U.S. products after finding that the
country-oforigin labelling provisions on beef and pork products violated
international trade rules.

Canada and Mexico argued the measure was nothing more than thinly disguised
protectionism. Supporters said consumers have a right to know where their meat
comes from.

International Trade Minister Chrystia Freeland and Agriculture Minister Lawrence
MacAulay both welcomed the passage of the legislation, calling Friday "a great
day for Canada."

"This is a real vindication of the power and significance of the WTO
dispute-resolution mechanism, which has secured a real win for Canada," Freeland
said in a teleconference call from Nairobi, where she and MacAulay were taking
part in a trade conference. "This is a decision that will have a real and
immediate benefit to the Canadian economy."

Freeland expects the labelling regime will disappear quickly.

"We'll be monitoring the situation to make sure there are no problems in this
area," MacAulay added.

The ministers thanked Canadian diplomats and some American politicians and
industries which supported doing away with the measure.

The Senate had been the last barrier because domestic political interests kept
some senators opposed to repealing the law.

Alberta Agriculture Minister Oneil Carlier said the province's beef and pork
industry will now have greater access to American markets.

"Alberta's agriculture products are the province's second-largest export sector,
and the United States is our most important trading partner," he said in a news
release.

"With COOL eliminated, livestock producers, workers and businesses will no
longer be saddled with unnecessary costs and have more opportunities to
strengthen agriculture trade between our two countries."

In 2014, Alberta exported about $1.7 billion in live cattle and beef products to
the U.S. and $189 million in live hogs and pork products, the province said.

Kansas Sen. Pat Roberts, the Republican chair of the Senate's powerful
agriculture committee, expressed relief Friday at the news. Roberts said the
retaliatory measures would have been damaging to various sectors of the U.S.
economy.

"From the ranchers in Kansas to the jewelry makers on the East Coast, every
state had something to lose from keeping mandatory COOL intact," Roberts said in
a statement.

The WTO ruling, the latest in a series that Canada won in the dispute, cleared
the way for widespread retaliation.

The targeted U.S. products included not only agricultural ones such as cattle,
pork, apples, rice, maple syrup and wine, but extended to non-agricultural
products, such as jewelry, office chairs, wooden furniture and mattresses.

Freeland said Canada still intends to obtain formal approval next week from the
WTO for retaliation, even though the tariffs won't be imposed.

"We think that it is prudent of us to take the legal process to its formal,
technical conclusion," she said.

On Friday, the Senate voted by a 65-33 margin to approve the massive bill that
included $1.14 trillion in new spending in 2016 and $680 billion in tax cuts in
the decade to come. !@COPYRIGHT=© 2015 Postmedia Network Inc. All rights
reserved.

                                 April 15, 2016

Rotarians hear about TVCC ag and rodeo activities

BYLINE: The Malakoff News staff

LENGTH: 236  words


ATHENS -- Trinity Valley Community College (TVCC) Agriculture and Rodeo
department representatives told Athens Rotarians about their activities at the
weekly meeting at the Athens Country Club April 7.

The Ag Department maintains a 60-head herd of Charlais cattle and wins the
Houston Herdsman Award every year.

At the lab, students participate in dehorning and deworming, vaccinating,
pregnancy testing, artificial inseminating and otherwise maintaining cattle.

TVCC Ranch Manager Mark Robinson spoke, as well as students Chad Tindel, Jake
Hughes and TVCC Rodeo Team Advisor Brent Bratton.

"The ag building consists of two classrooms, one computer lab, shop, lounge and
254 acres just west of Athens," Robinson said.

TVCC offers an Associates of Arts degree in Agriculture Sciences, Associate of
Applied Sciences and a certificate in Ranch and Beef Cattle Management.

"TVCC provides hands-on training. When you leave, you have the knowledge needed
for your career," Hughes said.

Hughes is part of the rodeo team but has yet to compete due to an injured knee.

"The program has brought many blessings into my life and makes a big impact to
everyone in it.

After graduation, Robinson said students have many career choices including
teaching, ranch management, selling insurance, working for the United States
Department of Agriculture and farming.

"As long as humans want to eat, there will be jobs in agriculture," Robinson
said.

                               The New York Times

                 March 15, 1994, Tuesday, Late Edition - Final

FUTURES MARKETS;
Coffee Hits 5-Month High; Latin Crop Estimates Cut

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

SECTION: Section D;  Page 18;  Column 1;  Financial Desk

LENGTH: 407 words


Coffee prices surged yesterday to their highest levels in about five months
after the Agriculture Department sharply reduced its crop estimates for Brazil,
the world's largest producer, and for Mexico and El Salvador.

On the New York Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange, coffee for May delivery jumped
2.60 cents, to 81.40 cents a pound.

Brazil's coffee crop, which farmers will begin harvesting next month, will
probably be about 18 percent smaller than last year's, the Agriculture
Department said. Brazil's crop is now estimated at 23.5 million 132-pound bags,
a million bags lower than the department's projection in December and down from
28.5 million bags last year.

"There's some trepidation about the new crop in Brazil following the U.S.D.A.
report," said Steve Platt, commodity analyst with Dean Witter in Chicago.
"Things are tight and they're going to get tighter."

Lower-than-normal rainfall and hot weather reduced the crop this year.

"Principally, it was the hot weather during the flowering season, coupled with
low moisture" that will cut Brazil's yields, said Frank Hokana, an analyst at
the Agriculture Department. Also, coffee is grown in a two-year cycle, and many
trees were producing less this year after last year's larger crop.

Cocoa prices also surged on concerns about supplies. Cocoa for May delivery rose
$50, to $1,250 a ton, a three-month high.

Traders are worried about the Ivory Coast's ability to meet its contracts.

"They may have oversold the old crop," Mr. Platt said. "They're having trouble
filling what contracts they have outstanding."

On other commodity markets, soybean and grain prices leaped amid speculation of
lower-than-expected plantings this summer by American farmers and weather
problems that may reduce crops being harvested in Brazil and Argentina.

At the Chicago Board of Trade, soybeans for May delivery soared 15 cents, to
$6.9025 a bushel; May corn added 5 cents, to $2.87, and May oats rose 3.75
cents, to $1.3175 a bushel. But May wheat edged down 0.75 cent, to $3.3475.

The Sparks Companies, a Memphis-based crop forecasting firm, estimated that
farmers would plant 78.8 million acres of corn, below what traders had expected.
Also, Sparks said farmers intended to plant 59.6 million acres of soybeans in
the 1994-95 crop year, traders said, just 200,000 acres more than last year at a
time when soybean stocks are at the lowest level in more than 20 years.

                               The New York Times

                June 25, 1985, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Cattle and Pork Bellies Move Sharply Lower

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

SECTION: Section D; Page 18, Column 5; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 400 words


Cattle futures prices were sharply lower yesterday on the Chicago Mercantile
Exchange as the market reacted to a Government report that the market is still
flooded with heavy cattle.

Cattle for delivery in August and October fell by the daily limit of 1.5 cents a
pound and, along with the December contract, fell to new low prices.

Pork bellies were also sharply lower, with most delivery months falling by the
daily limit of 2 cents a pound.

The move in cattle was primarily a reaction to the Agriculture Department's
report Friday that cattle marketings in May were 3 percent lower than a year
earlier, analysts said.

''There's just no good news to talk about,'' said Phil Stanley, a livestock
analyst in Chicago with Thomson McKinnon Securities Inc. ''The report reaffirmed
ideas that there are still plenty of cattle on feed,'' Mr. Stanley said. Prices
of live cattle on wholesale cash markets were also lower.

Pork bellies were also affected by an Agriculture Department report.

The Agriculture Department reported that frozen inventories were higher than
expected, but Ron Garrison, a livestock analyst in St. Louis with the Clayton
Brokerage Company, said the weakness in the cattle pit also encouraged selling
in the pork belly pit.

Live hogs were also under pressure, but the contract for delivery in July
recovered near the close of trading and finished slightly higher on conjecture
that a surplus of heavy hogs has been depleted this month, Mr. Garrison said.

Corn and soybean futures prices were mostly higher and wheat was lower on the
Chicago Board of Trade.

Corn for delivery in July was slightly lower, while the contracts for delivery
after the harvest were higher.

Victor Lespinasse, a grain analyst in Chicago with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.,
said the forecast for the next 6 to 10 days, which calls for hot and dry
conditions, was the major influence supporting prices.

Wheat prices were under pressure from continued good progress in the winter
wheat harvest, which saw only slight delays because of weekend rain, Mr.
Lespinasse said.

Cocoa futures continued under pressure and the contract for delivery in July
fell to a new low on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York.

Precious metals prices were slighly higher in quiet, featureless trading on the
Commodity Exchange in New York.

Petroleum futures were mixed on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

                        The International Herald Tribune

                            February 12, 2007 Monday

Ethanol's hunger for corn upsets global food chain;
MARKETPLACE by Bloomberg

BYLINE: Peter Robison - Bloomberg News

SECTION: FINANCE; Pg. 14

LENGTH: 934 words

DATELINE: SEATTLE


Arturo Esquivel shakes his head as he pays 10 pesos for tortillas in Mexico
City, two-thirds more than a year ago. He would be even angrier to learn that
some of Detroit's alternative fuel vehicles may be partly to blame.

They run on ethanol, a fuel made from the corn that also influences the cost of
Esquivel's tortilla, feeds the chickens, pigs and cows raised for consumption
worldwide and sweetens soft drinks.

Demand for corn as the raw material for an alternative vehicle fuel is creating
unintended consequences throughout the global food chain. Corn growers in the
Midwest of the United States are commanding prices not seen in a decade. Yet
farmers who raise livestock are seeing feed costs soar, and companies from Tyson
Foods to Coca-Cola are warning of higher prices. Even environmentalists say
using more corn will have drawbacks.

''We are seeing the most dramatic, fast-moving changes in Midwest agriculture in
at least half a century,'' said Robert Wisner, an economics professor at Iowa
State University, in Ames.

Hog farmers, cattle ranchers and poultry producers are among those in the $125
billion U.S. livestock industry losing money. The U.S. Department of Agriculture
says the cost of American staples like pork and chicken may increase 6 percent
based on current corn prices.

U.S. automakers say alternative-fuel cars are a way to support American farmers
and reduce the country's dependence on foreign oil. President George W. Bush
pledged in his State of the Union address last month to increase the use of
renewable fuels almost fivefold through 2017, primarily relying on ethanol.

Already, 113 ethanol distilleries are operating and an additional 77 are under
construction, with potential capacity of 11.8 billion gallons, or 44.7 billion
liters, according to the Renewable Fuels Association, a trade group in
Washington backed by ethanol producers.

Record output of 4.9 billion gallons of ethanol last year triple the 1.6 billion
gallons produced in 2000 accounted for 2.8 percent of the U.S. fuel supply.

New demand for ethanol is reshaping America's farmlands. Last year, 20 percent
of the U.S. corn harvest went to make ethanol a figure that may rise to half of
the harvest within two years if all the new distilleries are built, said Wisner
of Iowa State. The United States is the largest corn grower and exporter,
accounting for almost 40 percent of the world supply.

Gene Gourley, a pig farmer in Webster City, Iowa, is not happy about the extra
competition for his main feedstock. Feed makes up 60 percent of the costs at the
farm where he and his brothers raise 60,000 pigs a year. He said their typical
profit is $3.50 per pig, yet they are now spending $18 more to feed each one.

The chief executive of Tyson Foods, Richard Bond, said last month that
''significant'' price increases were on the way, without saying how much.

''As the food-versus-fuel debate unfolds, we must carefully consider the
negative unintended consequences of over-using grains,'' Bond said.

An ''epic contest'' is brewing between the world's 800 million motorists and the
2 billion poorest people, who spend as much as half their income on food, said
Lester Brown, director of the Earth Policy Institute, a nonprofit environmental
group in Washington.

Supporters of ethanol dismiss the idea of a tradeoff between gas tanks and
stomachs. ''We ultimately have the resources to continue to produce for food and
energy,'' said Bruce Rastetter, the chief executive of Hawkeye Holdings in Iowa
Falls, Iowa, one of the biggest U.S. ethanol processors.

The ethanol boom is transforming places like Heron Lake, Minnesota, a town of
773 once known for some of the state's best duck hunting.

The $97 million Heron Lake BioEnergy plant, backed by a group of local farmers,
is scheduled to start producing 50 million gallons of ethanol a year beginning
next month.

Heron Lake has not been this busy since the 1950s, said Mayor Bill Wurdeman.
''We're hoping this is the spark we need to start growing,'' said Wurdeman.

Other links in the food chain are also feeling the effects of rising demand for
corn-based ethanol. Corn syrup accounts for about 10 percent of the costs for
bottlers of soft drinks.

''We as an industry are facing unprecedented issues on cost,'' John Brock, chief
executive of Coca-Cola Enterprises, Coke's chief bottler, said at a conference
in New York in December.

For all the excitement, ethanol share prices have not taken off as expected. One
reason: After soaring to more than $77 a barrel in mid-July, oil prices have
dropped back to about $60 a barrel

Shares of Pacific Ethanol and Aventine Renewable Energy Holdings have sunk to
less than $20 from more than $40 in April

But the venture capitalist Vinod Khosla, who helped start the computer company
Sun Microsystems, remains bullish. His Khosla Ventures has invested an
undisclosed amount in two corn-based ethanol plants and seven other biofuel
projects.

''I'm not changing my plans at all,'' he said, predicting the eventual emergence
of as many as five major biofuel companies, each with annual sales of $10
billion compared with $12 billion for the entire industry in 2006.

Making ethanol with corn carries its own environmental drawbacks, according to a
June 2006 study by the University of Minnesota in Minneapolis.

The crops have to be irrigated, plowed with tractors, doused with nitrogen
fertilizers and transported to ethanol distilleries, which power their machinery
with natural gas or coal.

''There's an awful lot we need to know before we plunge headfirst into
biofuels,'' said Jason Hill, a University of Minnesota research associate.

LOAD-DATE: February 12, 2007

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                           Aberdeen Press and Journal

                               February 25, 1999

Compromise CAP plan before ministers today

SECTION: Farming, Pg.13

LENGTH: 302 words


TALKS on reforming Europe's Common Agricultural Policy were stalled in Brussels
last night after a delay in producing a new compromise paper.

The new set of proposals, which will for the first time formally include the
idea of a progressive decline in farm aid, will now be given to ministers from
Europe's 15 member states this morning.

Germany, which holds the rolling EU presidency, is still hopeful of a conclusion
being reached this week, although France is not so confident.

French Farm Minister Jean Glavany is sticking to his Government's line that no
deal on agriculture is possible until the question is resolved of how the policy
is funded post-2000.

The French Prime Minister, Lionel Jospin also entered the simmering row between
France and Germany.

The Germans earlier this week issued two compromise papers on cereals, beef and
milk, which slightly amended the European Commission's reform plans.

The majority of farm ministers back the new cereal reform plan, despite UK
reservations. It would cut EU cereal price support by 20% and progressively
reduce oilseed aid over three years to bring it in line with other arable
payments.

Today's key paper, the first full compromise, is likely to include the idea of
degressivity - trimming aid to farmers over time.

Meanwhile, American President Bill Clinton yesterday asked a
Government-appointed farm commission for advice on how to dig US farmers out of
the crisis that is threatening to drive many of them out of business.

He has urged the group to make whatever recommendations they had as quickly as
possible to help the country's farmers.

American farmers were on Tuesday warned to expect another year of crop surpluses
and low prices. In many cases, stockpiles will be the largest and prices the
lowest since the mid-1980s.

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                       July 9, 1995, Sunday, ALL EDITIONS

Around the South;
TALK OF THE SOUTH;
Farm bill debate casts long shadow in peanut country

BYLINE: TOM BAXTER

SECTION: NATIONAL NEWS, Pg. 8G, Tom Baxter

LENGTH: 568 words

DATELINE: Dothan, Ala.


If there were a Great State of Peanuts, this southeast Alabama city near the
borders of Georgia and Florida would be its capital, and James Earl Mobley might
be its governor.

Half the peanuts produced in the United States are grown within 100 miles of
here. This region has always known poverty. But thanks largely to the
partnership of growers, the government and land-grant universities, farmers such
as Mobley, who heads the National Peanut Growers Group, have prospered in recent
decades.

This partnership has driven the dreaded boll weevil from the cotton fields that
also dot the region, found new markets for peanuts, and provided a system of
price supports that has given farmers a stable basis for long-range planning.
But as Congress gets down to work on the 1995 farm bill, the peanut program -
and with it the very concept of a public- private partnership in American
agriculture - faces an uncertain future.

Agricultural subsidies have been targeted by consumer groups as well as by big
companies such as RJR-Nabisco, which would profit from cheaper peanut prices,
and Coca-Cola, which would like cheaper sugar. This year, they have powerful
friends in the new Republican Congress, including House Majority Leader Richard
Armey, a free market champion.

"Whether we can survive or not remains to be seen," Mobley says.

Mobley considers himself a "free enterprise man," but he says he can't
understand how people could let philosophy get in the way of the dollar. To his
mind the peanut program has more than paid for itself, giving American consumers
a safe, steady supply and farmers a decent living.

Mobley claims growers have made compromises already and are willing to go to a
"no-net-costs" approach in which growers would be assessed for the costs of the
program. But in an April field hearing in Albany, Ben Smith, president of the
American Peanut Product Manufacturers, branded the peanut program "a relic of
the past that has outlived its usefulness."

Whether reducing or eliminating the program would cause the economic ruin the
growers warn of, it would be felt most in this area. An Auburn University study
of the impact on the three states is due to be released this month.

Mobley predicts that if the program goes, within 25 years peanut country will go
to timber or cattle, which require much less labor, and his three sons will be
forced to leave the land his family has farmed since 1843.

Peanut country was at one time the domain of white Democrats. Now it is
represented mainly by white Republicans such as Rep. Saxby Chambliss in Georgia
and Rep. Terry Everett in Alabama, and black Democrats such as Rep. Sanford
Bishop in Georgia and Rep. Earl Hilliard in Alabama.

The Republicans find themselves caught between party principle and their
districts' interests. Unstintingly, they have opted for the latter. But the
peanut Republicans face a tough battle against their own party's free
marketeers.

Recently, a Democratic congressman advised a delegation of peanut men in
confidence to let the Republicans do their worst. That would bring the Democrats
back in the next election, he said, and they will put things back the way they
were.

But that is politics talking, and Mobley and other knowledgeable growers know
it. If the delicate web of relations supporting the peanut program, built up
over decades, is torn, it won't be coming back.

LOAD-DATE: July 10, 1995

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                    Copyright 1995 The Atlanta Constitution

                              Journal of Commerce

                             April 28, 1989, Friday

SIMON SAYS

BYLINE: Howard Simon

SECTION: COMMODITIES, Pg. 6A

LENGTH: 487 words


THE EASTERN REGIONAL BUSINESS CONDUCT COMMITTEE of the National Futures
Association has barred State Street Futures Corp. of Quincy, Mass., permanently
from NFA membership.

As a result of the strong action by the Chicago-based industry watchdog, State
Street's two principals, David Joseph Condon and David L. Westbook, agreed not
to act as principals for any NFA member for three years from the ate of the
decision.

The firm was a Futures Commission Merchant. As an FCM, it could solicit orders
to buy or sell futures contracts or options on futures for customers and accept
customer money or other assets.

The NFA decision follows a seven-count complaint filed by NFA against the
company in February. In the complaint, NFA charged State Street with failing to
maintain adequate books and records and failing to prepare complete, accurate
and timely daily and monthly trade settlements.

* * * * *

AS TEMPERATURES HEAT UP in the Midwest, so does the debate about whether the
nation's midsection will experience the same hot, dry weather conditions that
caused extensive grain damage last summer.

U.S. Department of Agriculture chief meteorologist Norton Strommen Wednesday
reiterated his view that the United States isn't entering into a widespread
drought similar to that of 1988 despite pockets of dryness (particularly this
spring in hard winter wheat growing ar eas).

Meanwhile, John Schnittker, head of the Washington, D.C.-based agriculture
consulting firm of Schnittker Associates, said he is alarmed for the crops
because of depleted soil moisture.

In either case, the dry weather for Midwest crops prompted the USDA this week to
announce new assistance to farmers and ranchers hit hard by drought conditions.
Acknowledging the serious weather problem, the USDA said its aid includes
allowing emergency haying and grazing on land set aside for conservation. It was
not until late July and August, the peak of last summer's drought, that the USDA
eased restrictions on using conservation land.

The aid also provides feed assistance to livestock and poultry producers.

* * * * *

THE CASE OF AUSTRALIAN BEEF found by South Korean authorities to be tainted may
be the fault of Korean importers and Australian exporters both.

As a result of the spoiled beef, South Korea has imposed an indefinite ban on
beef imports from Australia.

Knight-Ridder Financial News reported Thursday that the 2 million metric tons
found spoiled in Seoul showed signs of bone taint, and South Korea's Livestock
Products Marketing Organization will issue its report on the case as early as
today.

The cause of the bone taint, which is marked by a deterioration in the meat
around the bone, remains unknown, but the problem would have arisen either
during initial freezing of the beef in Australia or due to storage problems in
Seoul, an Australian Meat & Livestock Corp. official said.

                            Manchester Evening News

                               February 15, 2002

Genus hits the bullseye

BYLINE: By PATRICIA ROBERTS

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. 16

LENGTH: 248 words


A "DESIGNER" bull named Machoman created by experts in Cheshire has become one
of the world's most prized animal.

And suitors around the world are queuing up to be matched with the super-stud.

The supreme champion was genetically engineered by researchers at Crewe-based
Genus to beat 750 other prize bulls to the title of world leader and best in
breed, from the United States Department of Agriculture.

Machoman, currently in stud in Canada, is the latest product of Genus' £
8m-a-year research and development programme which is being used to improve the
quality of beef and dairy herds worldwide.

Machoman's pole position is based on tests which include the robustness of his
calves. He is expected to produce 120,000 doses of semen a year, each of which
will be priced at a premium rate, with world sales expected to exceed £3.5m.

Genus, a leader of technology and service in cattle breeding, agricultural
consulting and the distribution of products in the veterinary market, moved from
Ofex to AIM in July 2000. It now trades in more than 70 countries, with three
substantial divisions including Genus Breeding, now the global market leader in
cattle breeding.

Chief executive Richard Wood said of the US accolade: "To have been awarded this
highly prestigious international ranking proves that Genus' research programme
is unequalled in the area of practical genetic research. Machoman has joined our
stable of decorated bulls in three continents."

                              Journal of Commerce

                          January 10, 1990, Wednesday

USERS WANT QUOTAS HIKED

BYLINE: From Wire Reports

SECTION: COMMODITIES, Pg. 7A

LENGTH: 194 words

DATELINE: WASHIN


A leading association of sugar users asked the Agriculture Department Monday to
raise U.S. sugar import quotas by up to 350,000 tons to beat a growing shortage
and rising prices.

The United States imports sugar under a quota system because U.S. production
lone is not sufficient to meet domestic needs.

The Sweetener Users Association said the supply situation worsened last month
when the U.S. sugar beet harvest came in lower than expected and freezing
weather damaged cane crops in Florida and Texas.

The situation has been further exacerbated by Brazil's failure to fulfill
existing quota allocations.

"The pricing, delivery and forward purchasing of sugar is most difficult in the
current environment," association president Tom Hammer said. "Swift
administrative action in the form of a quota increase is needed to restore order
to the domestic sweetener market."

The USDA last raised the 1989-90 sugar import quota in November, by about
300,000 tons.

USDA officials were unavailable for comment.

Mr. Hammer said last month's freeze would probably cut this seasons's domestic
cane sugar output by between 150,000 and 250,000 tons.

                         The Gazette (Montreal, Quebec)

                    October 15, 1996, Tuesday, FINAL EDITION

Change the Wheat Board

BYLINE: EDMONTON JOURNAL

SECTION: EDITORIAL / OP-ED; OTHER VIEWS: EDITORIALS FROM AROUND CANADA; Pg. B2

LENGTH: 201 words


Oct. 11:

Federal Agriculture Minister Ralph Goodale is right to defend the Wheat Board. .
. . He is wrong, however, to shut his ears so totally to the calls for change
that are coming from hundreds of Western grain producers.

By giving all wheat and barley growers a pooled price, the Wheat Board reduces
risk to individual producers. The tradeoff, however, is a limitation of an
individual producer's right to make his own deal.

An increasing number of farmers want to take the risk and cash in on the high
wheat prices across the border in the United States.

What Mr. Goodale has offered . . . is a change in the way the Wheat Board is
governed, some loosening of the regulations that bind the board, and a vote
among farmers on barley. . . .

The change in governance is an important step away from the bureaucratic
paternalism of the Wheat Board that irks so many farmers. By 1998, Mr. Goodale
promises it will be run by a board with a majority of farmers on it. . . .

That farmer-dominated board will still, however, have to operate under the
strictures of federal legislation. It's vital that the federal government give
the board enough slack to make the changes necessary.

                          South Bend Tribune (Indiana)

                  December 29, 2001 Saturday Michigan Edition

Hog report leads to high hopes;
Pork producers encouraged by year-end news

BYLINE: By WAYNE FALDA; Tribune Farm Writer

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. B10; FOCUS ON FARMING

LENGTH: 615 words


A smaller hogs and pigs herd in the United States is expected to set the stage
for a rally next month in the hog market.

Local pork producers will be encouraged by a year-end hogs and pigs report
issued Friday afternoon by the United States Department of Agriculture, said
Mark Hari, manager of the United Producers terminal near Cassopolis.

The USDA put the national inventory of all hogs and pigs at 58.8 million head,
or 1 percent fewer than last year at this time.

The breeding inventory, at 6.21 million head, also was down 1 percent from last
year but 1 percent above last quarter. The market hog inventory, at 52.6 million
head, was 1 percent below both last year and last quarter.

"This report is on the bullish side," said Hari, who anticipates that in the
next few weeks prices could begin to cross the $40 per hundredweight level and
perhaps to around $45 per cwt. by February, he said.

Hari said the report represents "a good sign" that the days of hogs in the
mid-$30 per cwt. range are numbered.

But at the same time Hari is concerned about the accuracy of the government
report -- as are many other local producers.

"It's harder for the government to get an accurate report," Hari said. "The last
report wasn't very accurate. Hopefully, this one will be."

Decatur producer Ed Reed is among those who will receive the report with a
degree of skepticism.

Pork producers complained loudly that the USDA's last quarterly report in
October greatly underestimated the size of the U.S. hog herd by a million head,
thus contributing to a brief crash in prices as low as $29 per hundredweight in
November.

Market hogs are averaging two pounds heavier than a year ago. "We have been
killing over 2 million hogs for at least 8 weeks in row," he said. "Even during
these holiday-shortened weeks, we have killed a lot of pigs."

But Reed suspects that the flood of animals going to market is due to
under-reporting by large commercial hog producers who are either refusing to
take part of the voluntary government survey "or they are telling tall tales,"
he said.

"It's becoming more and more difficult to get a handle on how many hogs are out
there," Reed said.

But Hari thinks the recent glut of market hogs is over. "We should see a little
dry spell coming into January," he said.

Cass County producer Nate Robinson said 2001 was an opportunity for pork
producers to wipe out debts incurred three years ago in the big market plunge.

"We have had a great year actually," he said.

Recently prices have edged back up to mid to high $30 per cwt. range. Right
after the report came out Friday afternoon Reed shipped a load of 190 pigs to
the IPC plant in Delphi, Ind. that brought $37 a hundredweight.

"If I had held out today I could have gotten another dollar (per cwt.)," he
laughed.

The reason is that packers have lately been bidding up prices to keep slaughter
plants at capacity during the holiday period.

The break-even point for most hog producers ranges from $30 to $35 per cwt.

Robinson said smaller producers like himself have taken advantage of the
premiums offered by the packers during the holidays. "A lot of the big fellas
don't want to do that because that is their day off," he said.

Prices in the past month have been a far cry from the high water marks
established earlier this summer when pork producers enjoyed a brief spurt in
which prices soared into the mid $50s.

Reed, who only signs contracts on 20 percent of his market hogs, said the
combination of low feed costs and high prices at that time was the highlight of
the year.

Staff writer Wayne Falda: wfalda@sbtinfo.com (219) 235-6326



LOAD-DATE: January 11, 2002

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

ready for shipment ahead of Friday's hogs and pigs report by the U.S. Department
of Agriculture.  Tribune Photo/SHAYNA BRESLIN

                      Hamilton Spectator (Ontario, Canada)

                     March 22, 2001 Thursday Final Edition

Health threat destroys sheep; U.S. moves against mad cow disease

SOURCE: Spectator Wire Services

SECTION: CANADA & WORLD; Pg. B04

LENGTH: 652 words

DATELINE: GREENSBORO, VT.


Federal agents seized a Vermont farmer's flock of 234 sheep yesterday for fear
they are infected with a version of mad-cow disease. It was the first such
action ever taken against livestock in the United States.

The U.S. Agriculture Department "has no choice but to take this decisive action
based on the threat the sheep pose to the health of America's livestock
nationwide," said Craig Reed, administrator of USDA's animal and plant health
inspection service.

A team of federal agents and agriculture officials arrived at Houghton Freeman's
farm at daybreak. Two cattle trucks were loaded by 11 a.m. and will take the
sheep to Iowa, where they will be tested and destroyed.

Freeman and another farmer had waged a court battle to save their sheep after
the Agriculture Department ordered the flocks seized last July.

The flocks consisted of sheep that were either imported from Belgium in 1996 or
were descendants of those animals. USDA spokesman Ed Curlett said the seizure
was the first of any cow or sheep in the United States under suspicion of having
an illness related to mad-cow disease.

The USDA has said four sheep from Freeman's flock showed signs of transmissible
spongiform encephalopathy, a class of neurological diseases that includes both
bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE), or mad-cow disease, and scrapie, a sheep
disease not harmful to humans. The government said the sheep may have been
exposed through contaminated European feed.

However, the USDA tests could not confirm whether the sheep have BSE. The
animals will undergo further testing at a USDA lab in Ames, Iowa.

There have been no confirmed cases of mad-cow disease in the United States.
Scrapie has been in the United States since at least 1947.

Meanwhile, the Dutch government said yesterday it had confirmed the first cases
of foot-and-mouth disease in the Netherlands, making it the second country on
the European continent to detect the livestock ailment.

Tests concluded that four cows had contracted the disease on a farm near Olst,
in the eastern part of the country. All 60 head of cattle and 20 sheep were
being destroyed immediately.

The 15-member European Union quickly banned all livestock exports from the
Netherlands, as well as meat, dairy and other animal products from four Dutch
provinces unless they are treated to ensure they cannot be carrying the disease.

The move extends restrictions already imposed on Britain, where the outbreak
originated, and France, where it was first discovered on the continent.

The Dutch government swiftly reinstated a nationwide ban on transporting
livestock that had been lifted just two days earlier, and extended it to cover
chickens.

Authorities also said that about 500 goats on a neighbouring farm were
slaughtered after foot-and-mouth symptoms were found last weekend.

In Britain, the deaths of five people in a single English village from the human
form of mad cow disease have been linked to local butchering techniques in the
1980s that have since been banned.

The findings support the suspicion held by many experts that the incubation
period of the fatal brain-wasting disease, a variant of Creutzfeld Jakob
Disease, is between 10 and 20 years.

Scientists began investigating last July whether residents of Queniborough, in
northern England, had a genetic susceptibility to the disease or whether the
cluster of deaths could provide other clues about its cause and spread. A total
of 90 people have died of the disease in Britain since 1996.

In a report published yesterday, investigators said they discovered that
slaughterhouses used to provide butchers in Queniborough with whole carcasses,
including the animals' heads. When the skulls were split to remove the brains,
tainted brain material would sometimes ooze out and could have contaminated
knives and other meat on the butcher's block, the investigators said.

LOAD-DATE: November 5, 2001

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

U.S., fears of infection of mad cow disease prompted federal agents to seize a
flock of 234 sheep yesterday in Vermont.

                             960 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

               October 1, 1987, Thursday, Late City Final Edition

Prices Paid To Farmers Up by 1.6%

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section D; Page 3, Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 305 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30


The prices that farmers receive for raw products rose 1.6 percent in September,
recovering more than half of the losses of July and August, the Agriculture
Department said today.

The gain in the index followed a 2.3 percent drop in July and a revised decline
of eight-tenths of 1 percent in August. The index, which had climbed in each of
the first six months of the year, was up 5.7 percent from a year ago.

Higher prices for cattle, eggs, milk and wheat were said to be mostly
responsible for the September increase. Lower prices were reported for hogs,
broilers and potatoes.

Prices for cattle and calves in September were the highest in more than seven
years. However, hog prices dropped sharply in September from August, the largest
month-to-month decline for market hogs since March 1983.

As a group, prices for livestock and livestock products were reported unchanged
from August but were up 3.4 percent from a year ago.

Crop Prices Climb

The all-crops price index rose 2.9 percent in September and was 9.3 percent
higher than the level a year earlier. Commercial vegetables rose 14 percent
during the month, and were 11 percent higher than in September 1986. Fruit
prices rose 2.8 percent in September and were up 4.6 percent from the period a
year earlier.

The preliminary September figures were based mostly on midmonth averages and are
subject to revision.

The most recent figures on prices paid by farmers to meet expenses were compiled
in July, and showed that farm costs were 3.1 percent higher than a year earlier;
new figures are scheduled to be released in October.

September farm commodity prices averaged 129 percent of a 1977 base used for
comparison, according to the preliminary figures, up from a revised August
reading of 127 percent. A year ago, the September index was at 122 percent.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Graph of farm prices (April 1986-September 1987) (Source: Agriculture
Department)

                             961 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                                Dawn (Pakistan)

                            August 25, 2015 Tuesday

Investment in agriculture research urged to boost production

BYLINE: AMIN AHMED

SECTION: Vol. LXIX No. 234

LENGTH: 534  words


Federal Minister for National Food Security Sikandar Hayat Khan Bosan has
cautioned that the impact of low-productivity on hunger, malnutrition and
poverty could be severe with population growing unchecked and limited arable
land left to expand farming.

Speaking at the annual conference on the Agriculture Innovation Programme (AIP)
on Monday, he said the situation needed to be tackled with investment in
agriculture research and development.

Launched in 2013, the AIP is an initiative of USAID, the International Maize and
Wheat Improvement Center (CIMMYT) and Pakistan Agricultural Research Council
(PARC).

Take a look: Agriculture strategy being evolved

The minister said that investment in agricultural research and development was
the need of the hour, adding that a closer watch on the impact of emerging
global technologies and dissemination of suitable technologies to respective
farming communities was the key to success.

Mr Bosan asked the farming community to take part in the AIP interventions,
learn new practices, adopt new technologies and improve agricultural
productivity for a food secure Pakistan.

Halfway through the four-year programme, we are already witnessing remarkable
results, said USAID Mission Director John Groarke. This demonstrates that with
the United States and Pakistan working together, we can achieve agricultural
growth and prosperity in the country's agricultural sector and beyond.

Heat resistant maize, higher-yielding wheat crops, livestock vaccines and less
water-dependent rice harvesting techniques were among the leading innovations
stemming from the $30 million initiative.

According to the USAID official, over the next two years AIP will continue its
farmer-focused innovations by helping Pakistani farmers increase their profits
while addressing emerging resource challenges caused by climate change.

He said that since 2012, USAID's growth programme had created over 23,000 jobs
and introduced new technologies and management practices to more than 118,000
farmers across 60,000 hectares.

The change in the climate, according to Mr Bosan, had endangered the food
security. He said comprehensive strategies were required to adapt to these
changes and cope with the challenges.

He added that the application of emerging global technologies was imperative to
promote the farming sector and stressed the need for coordinated effort between
public and private sectors with the support of the farming community.

The director-general of CIMMYT, Dr Martin Kropff, said that since the population
had been growing, there was a need to grow more food. He spoke about challenges
in the shape of climate change, extensive weather conditions, temperature, water
shortage which also have impact on agriculture produce. Dr Kropff said that
there was a need to take steps to cope with these challenges and ensure
sufficient food for growing populations. He congratulated Pakistan for
introducing the new zinc-rich wheat which he claimed would go a long way in
promoting nutritious food security.

The minister also held a meeting with the CIMMYT team led by Dr Kropff. They
explored areas for future collaboration, including the establishment of the
Borlaug Institute for South Asia.

                                US Official News

                            March 22, 2014 Saturday

Georgia: USDA Seeks Nominees for the National Sheep Industry Improvement Center
Board of Directors

LENGTH: 332  words

DATELINE: Atlanta


Agricultural Marketing Service, The State of Georgia has issued the following
news release:

Department of Agriculture (USDA) is seeking nominations for individuals to serve
on the National Sheep Industry Improvement Center Board of Directors.


There are three vacant positions for the 2015 board. There are two vacancies for
sheep or goat producers and one vacancy for a person with expertise in
marketing.


Any sheep or goat producer within the United States may be nominated for the
producer member positions and anyone with expertise in finance and management
may be nominated for the other position. Nominations are due by June 1, 2014,
and must be submitted by a USDA Certified National sheep and goat industry
organization. All applicable forms must be completed in their entirety and can
be found at www.ams.usda.gov/NSIIC.


USDA encourages board membership that reflects the diversity of the individuals
served by its industry. Diversity includes gender, race, disability, length of
service, and size and type of operation.


The board is comprised of seven voting members and two non-voting members.
Voting members include four active producers of sheep or goats in the United
States; two members with expertise in finance and management; and one member
with expertise in lamb, wool, goat, or goat product marketing. Non-voting
members include USDA's Under Secretary for Marketing and Regulatory Programs and
the Under Secretary for Research, Education, and Economics.


The Secretary of Agriculture selects appointees nominated by any national
organization whose membership consists primarily of active sheep or goat
producers in the United States; and the primary interest of the organization is
the production of sheep or goats in the United States.


The Sheep Center was established as part of the 2008 Farm Bill and its board
administers a grant program designed to improve the competitiveness of the U.S.
sheep and goat industries.

For further information please visit: http://www.ams.usda.gov/

                             963 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                              May 15, 1987 Friday

World grain stockpiles seem likely to drop

BYLINE: JOHN KOHUT; GAM

LENGTH: 691 words


BY  JOHN KOHUT
 The Globe and Mail
  World grain stockpiles appear to be headed for a drop for the first time
in four years because of a slowdown in production and poor weather,
factors that have contributed to a rally in grain prices.

According to a U.S. Department of Agriculture report, 1987 global
production of wheat and coarse grains such as corn, oats and barley is
likely to fall short of consumption for the first time since 1983, a year
in which U.S. production was cut sharply by drought and government
programs.

The report says the fall in grain prices last year appears to have
encouraged consumption and led to a "less rapid expansion of production in
many countries."

The USDA expects countries outside of the United States will need 82
million metric tons more grain than they produce in 1987-88, compared with
a production shortfall in those countries of 52 million tons during the
current season. World inventories of wheat and coarse grains are forecast
to decline to 357 million tons from a record 368.4 million this season.

Meanwhile, weather conditions threaten to cut grain yields in several
countries. Although analysts say it is still too soon in the year to make
firm forecasts, prices and volumes are up sharply on commodity exchanges.

Katharina Zimmer, senior grain analyst at Merrill Lynch & Co. Inc. of
New York, said the forecast is for drier and warmer weather than normal in
the U.S. West for the next 10 to 30 days. While U.S. wheat is progressing
well, rain is needed for the corn crop, which has just been planted, and
soybean crop, 50 per cent of which is now in.

"The major factor so far is that it is just too hot and dry," Ms Zimmer
said.

Cool temperatures and heavy rain have delayed planting of grain crops
in the Soviet Union by as much as a month. Reports from Beijing say that
China will return to being a net grain importer this year after two years
as a net exporter because of drought.

In Canada, dry conditions have helped farmers get their crops planted
ahead of normal, according to John Morriss of the Canadian Wheat Board,
which is responsible for shipping 90 per cent of prairie wheat. But the
southern regions of Saskatchewan, Alberta and Manitoba have received less
rain than normal for this time of year. "We're starting to get concerned"
about rain, Mr. Morriss said.

The Chicago Board of Trade reports a strong rally in grain futures.
Soybeans for May delivery were quoted at $5.75 (U.S.) a bushel, up about
75 cents from a month ago, while December corn is up almost 30 cents at
$2.06 a bushel.

On the Winnipeg Commodity Exchange grain futures prices are up by 5 to
10 per cent, compared with a month ago, mainly because of concern about
the weather, according to Ken Emmond, a spokesman for the exchange.
"People are starting to smell a drought," he said.

Stan Casar of McLeod Young Weir Ltd. said the commodities market in
Winnipeg is "sitting on a pivot point. . . . The speculators are long in
the market and they are very, very nervous," with most having bet that
rainfall will be below normal.

David Champion of grain merchants James Richardson & Sons Ltd. of
Winnipeg said that Canada appears to be heading for record exports of 32
million tons of grain for the current year, which ends in July, and that
the outlook for next year's volumes remains good.

But prices in the coming year may be affected by a U.S. announcement it
will sell four million tons of wheat to the Soviet Union.

Mr. Champion said this is not expected to affect Canadian sales volumes
to the Soviet Union next year. But the U.S.-Soviet contract could hurt
prices because Canada's trade partners are likely to balk at paying more
than the price of $80 a ton Moscow is paying for the U.S. wheat.

Canada will have sold nine million to 10 million tons of grain to the
Soviet Union this year, most of it being wheat and barley, he said.

An Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development agreement in
principle this week to speed up the process of dismantling farm subsidies
was received by analysts with skepticism. They say that because of the
strength of farm lobbies, it could take several years for the agreement in
principle to be followed up with strong action.

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

                  November 27, 1993, Saturday, WEEKLY EDITION

French farmers fight losing battle to maintain prices

BYLINE: Gerry Aziakou

SECTION: SECTION 3, SPECIAL REPORT: FRANCE; Pg. 20

LENGTH: 789 words

DATELINE: Paris, France


French farmers are fighting a losing battle against the accelerating decline of
agriculture across the European Community.

''Our goal is to keep farmers who can stand on their own two feet, farmers
present on the entire territory and not pushed back in some privileged areas or
parked in reservations,'' says Luc Guyau, head of the 600,000-member FNSEA, the
farmers' main labor union.

In the 1980s, two million farmers, including 600,000 in France, were driven off
the land in the EC under the so-called Common Agricultural Policy, and the
movement is sure to accelerate in the 1990s.

Militant farmers, particularly members of the Co-ordination rurale, which
organized large-scale protests across France in September, have been up in arms
over the CAP reform.

Under the revised CAP, EC cereal production must fall by 29% over three years in
exchange for price supports of 1,500 francs to 1,800 francs ($335 to $400) a
hectare for farmers agreeing to freeze at least 15% of their land.

EC oilseed production is also limited to five million hectares, even though the
community imports half of its needs, mainly from the U.S. Beef prices are to
drop 15% by 1996, with production limited to the 1992 level. The price of butter
is being cut 2.5% a year until 1996, and milk quotas, which brought a 12% cut in
community output, are to be maintained at the 1992 level.

While only mainstream farmers' groups such as the FNSEA endorse the CAP reform,
most farmers' unions have joined hands to oppose last November's U.S.-EC
agreement, known as the Blair House accord, which calls for a 21% cut in the
volume of subsidized EC farm exports over six years and a 36% reduction in EC
price supports.

The community would thus be forced to slash cereal exports by 15 million-20
million tonnes in the next few years, with French farmers suffering half of this
burden. This would mean a US$3.5-billion sacrifice for France, the world's No. 2
agricultural exporter after the U.S.

The EC subsidies, which benefit mainly French farmers, encourage overproduction.
As of Sept. 1, according to EC figures, the community had a surplus of 29
million tonnes of grain, 908,000 tonnes of beef, 128,000 tonnes of cheese,
303,000 tonnes of butter, 85,000 tonnes of pork and 4.8 million litres of wine.

Under pressure from the farm lobby, Prime Minister Edouard Balladur's government
is threatening to veto the Blair House accord unless French farmers get a better
deal. It regards the accord as unacceptable in its present form, maintaining it
would hurt French farmers too much, cost them world markets and drive them off
the land. But the U.S. adamantly rejects any renegotiation.

Is France merely engaging in brinkmanship? Is the world's fourth-ranking
industrialized trading nation really prepared to jeopardize lucrative exports of
cars, commercial planes, high-speed trains and nuclear installations for the
sake of subsidies that benefit only a minority of French farmers? The
conventional wisdom is that the French stance is dictated by electoral
considerations.

The farm lobby wields great influence in Balladur's neo-Gaullist RPR
(Rassemblement pour la Republique) party, whose leader, Jacques Chirac, hopes to
win the 1995 presidential election.

''For internal political reasons, it is important for Balladur to appear
extremely pugnacious (in the GATT negotiations). One hopes that this is not
based on a miscalculation,'' says Bernard Godement, an analyst with the Nomura
Research Institute.

France initially found itself isolated on the international stage. Australian
Trade Minister Peter Cook, chairman of the Cairns Group of 14 leading farm
exporting nations (including Canada), warned in October that France would be
blamed if the Uruguay Round fails. He said a balanced GATT accord would boost
the wealth of France by 150 billion francs and would create 500,000 French jobs
by 2002.

In France itself, leading political and business figures including former prime
minister Raymond Barre and Francois Perigot, chairman of the French employers'
association CNPF, have spoken in favor of a GATT deal and warned against the
danger of creeping protectionism.

A report on free trade by RPR MP Patrick Devedjian also argued that it was in
France's interest to enhance the role of GATT as the best way to combat U.S.
hegemony. The report, which was censured by a parliamentary commission, also
pointed out that the farm subsidies benefit mainly a small group of French
farmers concentrated in the cereal sector.

EC foreign ministers, however, closed ranks at a meeting in Brusels this month
and blamed the U.S. and Japan for failing to reciprocate the EC's more generous
tariff concessions.
