                               The New York Times

                 August 13, 1991, Tuesday, Late Edition - Final

FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Fall in Soybeans and Cotton Expected After Crop Report

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

SECTION: Section D; Page 15; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 448 words


Crop analysts predicted lower prices for soybean futures after the Agriculture
Department yesterday projected a larger harvest than most experts had expected.

The department's crop report, issued after the market's close, was considered
neutral for corn prices but extremely bearish for the cotton market, where
futures prices were expected to open sharply lower today.

Grain and soybean futures rose yesterday ahead of the eagerly awaited report,
the first this year based on field surveys. Cotton futures retreated.

Wheat for delivery in September settled 3 cents higher, at $2.98 3/4 a bushel,
on the Chicago Board of Trade; September corn rose 2 1/4 cents, to $2.53 a
bushel; September oats finished 1 1/4 cents higher, at $1.32 3/4 a bushel;
August soybeans rose 2 1/2 cents, to $5.58 1/2 a bushel.

Analysts predicted that the soybean market would open at least 5 cents to 10
cents lower today, mostly in reaction to the Agriculture Department's prediction
that United States farmers would harvest 1.87 billion bushels of soybeans this
year, 3 percent below last year's 1.92 billion bushels.

The market had expected the Government to project a 5 percent drop in soybean
production, to 1.83 billion bushels, because of the scattered Midwestern
drought.

The Agriculture Department number was especially surprising because it did not
take into account the several days of rain last week that brought relief to some
of the driest parts of the region. Analysts said that the rain increased the
prospective harvest by 50 million bushels but that more rain was needed.

The Agriculture Department projected a corn harvest of 7.42 billion bushels, 6
percent below last year's 7.93 billion. The number was near market expectations.

The agency predicted a 1991 United States cotton harvest of 17.65 million bales,
14 percent more than last year, compared with market expectations for a 7
percent increase.

Ernest Simon, cotton specialist with Prudential Securities Inc. in New York,
said he expected cotton futures to fall the permitted daily limit of 2 cents a
pound when trading resumes today on the New York Cotton Exchange.

Cotton for October delivery settled at 65.80 cents a pound yesterday, down 1.35
cents.

Gasoline futures headed higher in moderate trading on the New York Mercantile
Exchange amid continuing reports of refinery problems.

Wholesale unleaded gasoline for September delivery rose 0.21 cent, to 69.69
cents a gallon; crude oil for September delivery settled at $21.69 a barrel, up
7 cents from late Friday; September home heaing oil rose 0.12 cent, to 60.12
cents a gallon; Sptember natural gas settled at $1.289 per 1,000 cubic feet, up
0.01 cent.

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

                    March 29, 1990, Thursday, DAILY EDITION

Grain report speculation stirs up futures trading

BYLINE: Farm Market News

SECTION: SECTION 3, THE MARKETS; Pg. 24, FARM COMMODITIES

LENGTH: 284 words


  There was active trading in soybean and grain futures yesterday as traders at
the Chicago Board of Trade tried to take advantage of speculation about what may
be in the U.S. Department of Agriculture's crucial prospective plantings and
quarterly grain stocks report.

Traders speculated that the report, to be published Friday, will show U.S.
soybean acreage at 58.5 million acres. Last spring soybean plantings totaled
60.7 million acres.

The U.S. corn crop is now being forecast to come in at 75.2 million acres, which
is well above the 72.3 million planted in the spring of 1989.

Total U.S. wheat seedings for 1990 were estimated at 78.6 million acres,
compared with 76.6 million last year.

CBOT soybean futures settled US9 cents to US11 3/4 cents a bushel lower. May,
the most actively traded contract, finished at US$5.88 3/4, down US11 1/2 cents.

Pressure in soybeans stemmed from speculation the South American soybean harvest
will be picking up steam in the next few days because of good weather
conditions.

Corn futures at the CBOT closed US2 cents to US3 1/2 cents lower. July, the most
sought after future, ended at US$2.61 3/4 a bushel, down US2 3/4 cents.

The expected increase in corn acreage prompted most of the selling, pushing CBOT
corn futures lower yesterday.

A lack of exports also pushed CBOT corn futures lower yesterday. Near ideal
growing conditions for the U.S. winter wheat crop also weighed heavily on CBOT
wheat futures. CBOT wheat closed US2 3/4 cents to US5 cents a bushel lower. May
ended down the US5 cents at US$3.50.

CME pork bellies closed US$1.10 to US$1.40 a hundredweight higher. May finished
at US$53.95, up US$1.35.

                           The Decorah Journal (Iowa)

  This content, including derivations, may not be stored or distributed in any
  manner, disseminated, published, broadcast, rewritten or reproduced without
                      express, written consent from STPNS

                                  July 3, 2014

Is modern farming misunderstood?;
Farming and Your Freedom

BYLINE: The Decorah Journal staff

LENGTH: 551  words


There was a time when "Old McDonald Had a Farm," though just a tune for kids,
sort of told the story of American farming. No more. Modern production
agriculture is radically different than in the days of 160 acres in the valley
and Old McDonald.

In fact, farm advocacy groups, including commodity associations, have banded
together to criticize a new television series produced by the Chipotle Mexican
Grill chain. The show, called "Farmed and Dangerous," on Hulu Plus, depicts
modern production agriculture as farming on steroids -- gone insane. The company
said it satirizes American corporate agribusiness as out of control.

According to The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel, the first episode focused on
farmers who feed petroleum pellets to their cattle to save money and boost
profits, causing a cow to explode. Other episodes, The Journal Sentinel said,
talked about issues such as antibiotics in meat and food, and libel laws that
makes it easier for Big Food to sue its critics, that according to The New York
Times.

The Times wrote: "Starring the actor Ray Wise, the series is a full-throated
attack on industrial agriculture, complete with a Dr. Strangelove-like scientist
inventing eight-winged chickens and cash bribes being delivered in gift boxes."
Chipotle said the series "underscores social values." Farming, apparently,
doesn't share those values. "The show," Chipotle chief marketing and development
officer, Mark Crum packer, told The Journal Sentinel, "addresses issues that we
think are important, albeit in a satirical way, without being explicitly about
Chipotle. This approach allows us to produce content that communicates our
values and entertains people at the same time."

Farm groups, you might not be surprised to know, view the series in quite a
different light. The Wisconsin Farm Bureau Federation, for example, said,
Chipotle's latest marketing ploy is simply divisive propaganda. "We hope that
consumers see through this smear campaign against America's farm families by a
corporate restaurant chain."

Wisconsin farmers are sensitive to criticism broadly brushed after the national
attention the state received recently when an undercover video shot by an animal
rights group showed cows being kicked, whipped and otherwise abused on a Brown
County farm, The Journal Sentinel reported. Farm groups said they were "sickened
by the actions, which don't represent typical livestock handling practices."

Groups said the exploding cow and other bizarre behavior depicted on "Farmed and
Dangerous" sends "the wrong message to the public about modern farming
practices." The Journal Sentinel quoted Mike North, a board member at Wisconsin
Dairy Business Association: "It's saddening. It really is. There is a basic
misunderstanding of what farming is and how it has progressed over time.
Humorous or not, it plays poorly to getting the right information out."

Okay, so Big Farming is, well, a big boy now. It will get criticized and will
learn how to take it. But, the worry is that TV viewers might get a truly
twisted view of where their food comes from -- and vote accordingly.

After all, a large percentage of people have told surveys that they get their
news from late night television monologues, and the latest incarnation of the
Farm Bill was not exactly a popularity contest. Nuff said.

                             968 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                           December 15, 1987 Tuesday

Grain farmers won't recover until '89, Wise says

BYLINE: OLIVER BERTIN; GAM

LENGTH: 561 words

DATELINE: Ottawa ONT


BY  OLIVER BERTIN
 The Globe and Mail
  OTTAWA
  There is light at the end of the tunnel for Canada's troubled grain
farmers, but the light won't come until 1989, says John Wise, federal
Agriculture Minister.

Cattlemen, however, are enjoying their best year yet, and can expect
another record year in 1988.

As for consumers, they will continue to have low-cost food for the
foreseeable future.

Federal economists told the 53rd annual Canadian Agricultural Outlook
Conference that retail food prices will remain relatively unchanged in
1988, while consumers will see a 3.3 per cent rise in their real personal
disposable income.

Canadians now spend about 16 per cent of their disposable income on
food, the lowest level in the Western world.

The retail price of pork is expected to drop by 15 per cent in 1988,
the price of chicken may fall by 3 to 5 per cent, and prices for apples
and winter vegetables are expected to decline slightly.

The savings may not be translated into larger bank accounts, however,
because consumers are expected to take advantage of their higher
disposable income and spend more on highly processed food. They are also
expected to eat more often in restaurants, where food prices are expected
to rise by between 2 and 4 per cent.

The federal economists said wheat prices are expected to bottom out in
1987-88 and start a slow recovery in the 1988-89 crop year.

The recovery will come because world wheat production is finally coming
into line with consumption.

Canadian wheat prices are expected to rise slightly in 1988-89 to about
$180 a metric ton from the current average of about $173.

Exports of wheat will likely reach 21 million tons - the same as last
year's record - by the time the current crop year ends on July 31, 1988,
but the economists warned that export sales would depend on the United
States.

The United States has been spending billions of dollars on export
subsidies, and lately has been directing the financing at Canada's
traditional trading partners, China and the Soviet Union.

The economists warned that Canada has difficulty selling grain in
competition with the United States when that country uses these subsidies.

The outlook for coarse grains - barley and corn - is also looking up,
but the turnaround is a little further away than it is for wheat.

Coarse grain stocks could decline by up to 20 per cent around the world
by mid-1989, because production is slowly coming down, while consumption
is rising sharply.

Canadian farmers are expected to grow less barley and corn in 1988, and
to receive about the same prices.

Cattlemen are ending their best year in recent memory, and can look
forward to another record year in 1988.

Record-high cattle prices will remain steady in the first half, as
cattlemen continue to rebuild their herds after the massive kill-offs
during the depression of recent years.

Steers should be selling for about $89 a hundredweight for the
remainder of 1987 and through 1988.

Cattlemen will also benefit from low feed prices, at least until the
price of corn and barley starts to rise in 1989 or 1990.

Pork producers, however, will find profits fall in late 1988 and into
1989.

In 1987, prices were good and the industry optimistic.

Hog farmers are building up their herds and this will lead to
overproduction by mid-1988, and a drop in prices.

Hog prices are expected to average about $135 a hundred kilograms
through 1988 and much of 1989.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              All Rights Reserved

                             969 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                           The Japan Economic Journal

                                 March 17, 1981

REBUTTAL BY NATIONAL CHAMBER OF AGRICULTURE;
Food security warrants protection

SECTION: Pg. 13

LENGTH: 1526 words




Basic Views on Japan-U.S. Agricultural Trade

Japan's agriculture and rural communities play a major role as a stable
foundation of the nation and its society -a role which will need to be given
greater attention in the future.

The sound growth of farming operations and the building of a dynamic rural
community are therefore essential to Japan's political, economic and social
stability and development. It is the basis for ensuring the favorable
development of Japan-U.S. political and economic relations in the long term.
Japan-U.S. agricultural trade must be based on a common understanding of these
facts on both sides.

Agriculture in Japan is entering a period of major transformation under stable
economic growth. In April 1980, the Japanese Diet (both Houses)unanimously
adopted a "Resolution concerning Improving Self-sufficiency in Food," and, in
October, the Agricultural Policy Council, an advisory organ to the Prime
Minister, submitted to him its report, "The Basic Directions of Agricultural
Policy for the 1980s."

It is common knowledge that Japan imports large quantities of grain and other
agricultural products from the United States. These imports have played an
important role in the development of our bilateral trade, the supply of
foodstuffs to the Japanese people, and the rapid growth of the food industry and
livestock farming. At the same time, however, large imports of low-priced
grains, etc., have been a major factor in lowering the farmland utilization
ratio and reducing the food self-sufficiency ratio to a level unparalleled in
any other country. Solution to this problem is an important task in the
formulation of Japan's agricultural policies.

The report of the JapanUnited States Economic Relations Group proposes a
reduction in Japan's level of agricuituralprotection, emphasizing three main
areas:(1)reassessment of policies on the pricing and importation of agricultural
products (that is, reflection of international prices and relaxation and
abolition of import restrictions); (2)expansion of the scale of farming
operations; (3)food security and reserves.

We cannot agree to seeking a quick realization of the proposals made in the
report$-for example, closing the gap between domestic and international prices,
easing quantitative restrictions on agricultural imports, and lowering the level
of protection -since this would impede the future development of Japanese
agriculture and have an adverse impact on the JapanU.S. relationship.

To expand the amount of agricultural imports in the future would lead to the
decline of Japan's agriculture. It would also bring about further deterioration
in the world food situation and would probably be criticized by the developing
countries and others for doing so. This, it should be added, would have an
adverse impact on solving the international problems that Japan and the United
States both face.

Reflection of International Prices and Easing of Quantitative Restrictions on
Imports

(1)The pattern of agriculture in any country is determined by its climate,
natural conditions and dietary habits. It is inappropriate -and possibly
destructive to Japanese agriculture -to immediately bring domestic support
prices in line with international prices and ease quantitative restrictions on
agricultural imports, ignoring the differences between the conditions prevailing
in Japanese agriculture and those in the United States and other agriculturally
advanced countries. This is one of the most emphasized aspects of agricultural
policy, not only in Japan, but also in the United States and other western
industrial countrmes.

Obviously, it is necessary to improve productivity and reduce costs, and Japan
is in fact considering what kind of pricing policies might keep in step with the
degree of achievement of restructuring to expand operating scales and boost
productivity. In the case of land-intensive farming, the goal of price policies
should be to keep the gap between domestic and international prices from
increasing any further for the time being, and in the long term efforts will
need to be made to reduce this gap by whatever degree is possible. However, it
must be understood that there is a limit to the degree to which it can be
reduced, now and in the future.

(2)If a policy of closing the gap between the producer prices of rice and
international price levels is immediately implemented in order to cut back rice
production, there will be disruption, not only in the rice crop -the key crop in
Japanese agriculture and the central crop in land-intensive agriculture -but
throughout Japanese agriculture. It is most realistic to promote a smooth
conversion from rice to other crops while maintaining the vitality of Japanese
agriculture through the paddy field reorganization measures currently being
implemented.

(3)As for the restrictions on agricultural imports, Japan has already
liberalized to levels that compare well with other countries, and reduction of
the number of non-liberalized items has reached its limit. Moreover the import
quantities of non-liberalized items have already been expanded substantially as
part of an all-out effort to expand agricultural trade.

The report also proposed that the present quota system be abolished (that is,
imports would be liberalized)and that study be initiated on the adoption of a
deficiency payment system as an alternative. This would entail problems in the
form of an increased fiscal burden and other related problems which would
require cautious consideration. It is inappropriate to view the adoption of a
deficiency payments system as an effective means of immediately making possible
the abolition of import quotas.

(4)Efforts are being made to expand as much as possible imports of citrus fruit
and beef -which have come to symbolize the items for which quantitative
restrictions apply. Any further expansion will be the last straw for the farmers
in these sectors who are making efforts to deal with the situation by improving
their operations. Citrus fruit and beef make up only a very small part of the
United States' exports to Japan, and it is meaningless and undesirable for the
development of Japan-U.S. trade relations to make too great an issue of import
restrictions on these.



Expansion of Farm Size and the Encouragement of a Land Rental Market

Japan's agriculture has recently been going through a period of transition in
which "core"farmingoperations (those where the male breadwinner is engaged
full-time in farming)and greater productivity are being encouraged by promoting
greater fluidity of farmland through rental, etc. The reorganization of Japan's
agriculture through the implementation of a restructuring policy is only just
under way and it is necessary to aid and assist this trend toward reorganization
with all due urgency.

The proposal concerning agricultural restructuring is by and large appropriate,
but given tne historical conditions that have led to the development of such
small-scale farms in Japan, reform is not something that can be achieved in a
short time; it will need to be tackled over a long period. During the interval a
number of difficult problems will require solution, including the land price
problems peculiar to Japan, preparation of the land base for mechanization,
collectivization of farmland, and reorganization of paddy field use. Assistance
to help solve these problems will be essential.

It must also be understood that even if productivity increases are promoted as
much as possible by carrying out such structural reorganization, Japanese
agriculture, especially the land-intensive sectors, will be unable to withstand
international competition without a certain level of continued protection.



Food Security and a Contingency Reserve

(1)The Group's proposals suggest that it is unrealistic to increase
self-sufficiency of food, that food security cannot be guaranteed by protection
of agriculture, and that imported reserves are cheaper.

However, the very existence of the nation depends on its food security, the
basis of which should be the increasing of domestic self-sufficiency, which
will, of course, entail a fiscal burden to that end.

European industrial countries are emphasizing the maintenance and strengthening
of their domestic self-sufficiency, and Japan should not rely on cheap imports.

Moreover, any fiscal burden would be an investment for the development of
Japanese agriculture.

(2)In fact, Japan is heavily dependent on imports of American agricultural
products and does face some very real difficulties in raising its domestic
self-sufficiency rate substantially. It will be necessary, however, to endeavor
in principle to supply future increases in demand ourselves.

(3)At the same time, our food security also requires that we promote the stable
import of feedgrains, etc. Such stability also has advantages for producers in
exporting countries in that they are guaranteed a stable market.

(4)Reserves should be expanded and bolstered on the basis of the strengthening
of domestic self-sufficiency and stable imparts as outlined above.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                    Copyright 1981 The Nihon Keizai Shimbun

                             970 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                           The Japan Economic Journal

                                 March 17, 1981

REBUTTAL BY NATIONAL CHAMBER OF AGRICULTURE;
Food security warrants protection

SECTION: Pg. 13

LENGTH: 1526 words




Basic Views on Japan-U.S. Agricultural Trade

Japan's agriculture and rural communities play a major role as a stable
foundation of the nation and its society -a role which will need to be given
greater attention in the future.

The sound growth of farming operations and the building of a dynamic rural
community are therefore essential to Japan's political, economic and social
stability and development. It is the basis for ensuring the favorable
development of Japan-U.S. political and economic relations in the long term.
Japan-U.S. agricultural trade must be based on a common understanding of these
facts on both sides.

Agriculture in Japan is entering a period of major transformation under stable
economic growth. In April 1980, the Japanese Diet (both Houses)unanimously
adopted a "Resolution concerning Improving Self-sufficiency in Food," and, in
October, the Agricultural Policy Council, an advisory organ to the Prime
Minister, submitted to him its report, "The Basic Directions of Agricultural
Policy for the 1980s."

It is common knowledge that Japan imports large quantities of grain and other
agricultural products from the United States. These imports have played an
important role in the development of our bilateral trade, the supply of
foodstuffs to the Japanese people, and the rapid growth of the food industry and
livestock farming. At the same time, however, large imports of low-priced
grains, etc., have been a major factor in lowering the farmland utilization
ratio and reducing the food self-sufficiency ratio to a level unparalleled in
any other country. Solution to this problem is an important task in the
formulation of Japan's agricultural policies.

The report of the JapanUnited States Economic Relations Group proposes a
reduction in Japan's level of agricuituralprotection, emphasizing three main
areas:(1)reassessment of policies on the pricing and importation of agricultural
products (that is, reflection of international prices and relaxation and
abolition of import restrictions); (2)expansion of the scale of farming
operations; (3)food security and reserves.

We cannot agree to seeking a quick realization of the proposals made in the
report$-for example, closing the gap between domestic and international prices,
easing quantitative restrictions on agricultural imports, and lowering the level
of protection -since this would impede the future development of Japanese
agriculture and have an adverse impact on the JapanU.S. relationship.

To expand the amount of agricultural imports in the future would lead to the
decline of Japan's agriculture. It would also bring about further deterioration
in the world food situation and would probably be criticized by the developing
countries and others for doing so. This, it should be added, would have an
adverse impact on solving the international problems that Japan and the United
States both face.

Reflection of International Prices and Easing of Quantitative Restrictions on
Imports

(1)The pattern of agriculture in any country is determined by its climate,
natural conditions and dietary habits. It is inappropriate -and possibly
destructive to Japanese agriculture -to immediately bring domestic support
prices in line with international prices and ease quantitative restrictions on
agricultural imports, ignoring the differences between the conditions prevailing
in Japanese agriculture and those in the United States and other agriculturally
advanced countries. This is one of the most emphasized aspects of agricultural
policy, not only in Japan, but also in the United States and other western
industrial countrmes.

Obviously, it is necessary to improve productivity and reduce costs, and Japan
is in fact considering what kind of pricing policies might keep in step with the
degree of achievement of restructuring to expand operating scales and boost
productivity. In the case of land-intensive farming, the goal of price policies
should be to keep the gap between domestic and international prices from
increasing any further for the time being, and in the long term efforts will
need to be made to reduce this gap by whatever degree is possible. However, it
must be understood that there is a limit to the degree to which it can be
reduced, now and in the future.

(2)If a policy of closing the gap between the producer prices of rice and
international price levels is immediately implemented in order to cut back rice
production, there will be disruption, not only in the rice crop -the key crop in
Japanese agriculture and the central crop in land-intensive agriculture -but
throughout Japanese agriculture. It is most realistic to promote a smooth
conversion from rice to other crops while maintaining the vitality of Japanese
agriculture through the paddy field reorganization measures currently being
implemented.

(3)As for the restrictions on agricultural imports, Japan has already
liberalized to levels that compare well with other countries, and reduction of
the number of non-liberalized items has reached its limit. Moreover the import
quantities of non-liberalized items have already been expanded substantially as
part of an all-out effort to expand agricultural trade.

The report also proposed that the present quota system be abolished (that is,
imports would be liberalized)and that study be initiated on the adoption of a
deficiency payment system as an alternative. This would entail problems in the
form of an increased fiscal burden and other related problems which would
require cautious consideration. It is inappropriate to view the adoption of a
deficiency payments system as an effective means of immediately making possible
the abolition of import quotas.

(4)Efforts are being made to expand as much as possible imports of citrus fruit
and beef -which have come to symbolize the items for which quantitative
restrictions apply. Any further expansion will be the last straw for the farmers
in these sectors who are making efforts to deal with the situation by improving
their operations. Citrus fruit and beef make up only a very small part of the
United States' exports to Japan, and it is meaningless and undesirable for the
development of Japan-U.S. trade relations to make too great an issue of import
restrictions on these.



Expansion of Farm Size and the Encouragement of a Land Rental Market

Japan's agriculture has recently been going through a period of transition in
which "core"farmingoperations (those where the male breadwinner is engaged
full-time in farming)and greater productivity are being encouraged by promoting
greater fluidity of farmland through rental, etc. The reorganization of Japan's
agriculture through the implementation of a restructuring policy is only just
under way and it is necessary to aid and assist this trend toward reorganization
with all due urgency.

The proposal concerning agricultural restructuring is by and large appropriate,
but given tne historical conditions that have led to the development of such
small-scale farms in Japan, reform is not something that can be achieved in a
short time; it will need to be tackled over a long period. During the interval a
number of difficult problems will require solution, including the land price
problems peculiar to Japan, preparation of the land base for mechanization,
collectivization of farmland, and reorganization of paddy field use. Assistance
to help solve these problems will be essential.

It must also be understood that even if productivity increases are promoted as
much as possible by carrying out such structural reorganization, Japanese
agriculture, especially the land-intensive sectors, will be unable to withstand
international competition without a certain level of continued protection.



Food Security and a Contingency Reserve

(1)The Group's proposals suggest that it is unrealistic to increase
self-sufficiency of food, that food security cannot be guaranteed by protection
of agriculture, and that imported reserves are cheaper.

However, the very existence of the nation depends on its food security, the
basis of which should be the increasing of domestic self-sufficiency, which
will, of course, entail a fiscal burden to that end.

European industrial countries are emphasizing the maintenance and strengthening
of their domestic self-sufficiency, and Japan should not rely on cheap imports.

Moreover, any fiscal burden would be an investment for the development of
Japanese agriculture.

(2)In fact, Japan is heavily dependent on imports of American agricultural
products and does face some very real difficulties in raising its domestic
self-sufficiency rate substantially. It will be necessary, however, to endeavor
in principle to supply future increases in demand ourselves.

(3)At the same time, our food security also requires that we promote the stable
import of feedgrains, etc. Such stability also has advantages for producers in
exporting countries in that they are guaranteed a stable market.

(4)Reserves should be expanded and bolstered on the basis of the strengthening
of domestic self-sufficiency and stable imparts as outlined above.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                 Stone County Enterprise (Wiggins, Mississippi)

  This content, including derivations, may not be stored or distributed in any
  manner, disseminated, published, broadcast, rewritten or reproduced without
                      express, written consent from STPNS

                                 July 29, 2015

Heat not helping states corn crop

BYLINE: Stone County Enterprise staff

LENGTH: 589  words


Wet spring weather prevented Mississippi farmers from planting as many corn
acres as they intended, but despite the heat, the crop is mostly looking good in
fields across the state.

"We should have a good crop this year, but it won't be a record," said Erick
Larson, Mississippi State University Extension Service corn specialist. "The
planted acreage is down from what was intended because it was terribly rainy
during spring planting, which delayed planting and restricted corn acreage."

The U.S. Department of Agriculture estimates that 70 percent of the state's
overall corn crop is in good or excellent condition. One-quarter of the crop is
estimated in fair condition, while 5 percent is rated as very poor or poor.

"The primary issues we've had recently are the heat and a lack of rainfall,"
Larson said. "Nighttime temperatures have been 2 degrees hotter than normal,
with night temperatures 75 degrees or higher for the last two weeks."

Larson said this summer has been the fourth warmest in the last 20 years. The
only hotter years in that period were 1998, 2010 and 2011. The heat will likely
have the greatest negative impact on the late-planted acres.

Dennis Reginelli, Extension agronomic regional specialist, works with corn
producers in east Mississippi.

"In the Black Prairie region, the ground was wet up until about May 1. Most of
our corn was planted in a 10-day period in early May," Reginelli said. "However,
we decided in some situations to stop planting corn, and the growers changed
gears. Those who were also planting cotton did that instead, and those who were
also growing soybeans planted it instead."

Reginelli said much of the farmland in Noxubee County is irrigated, but not all
corn-growing areas are irrigated. Without irrigation, producing corn is a risky
proposition, so those growing it on dryland acres were careful to quit planting
the crop when the ideal window closed.

"Although much of the crop was planted late, we did a good job of accumulating
heat units, and the crop is progressing pretty rapidly," he said. "I would say
90 percent of the corn is 20 days from physiological maturity."

The heat that is helping the corn mature rapidly is also driving up the daily
water demand.

"We're using the maximum amount of moisture per day as the corn is trying mature
and cool," Reginelli said. "Because it's so hot at night, the corn isn't able to
recoup after a hot day."

Late-planted corn is also susceptible to windblown diseases. Reginelli said some
corn in east Mississippi is dealing with Southern corn rust, and there is the
potential for other diseases to become a threat before harvest.

Brian Williams, Extension agricultural economist, said corn prices are slightly
better this year but have fluctuated with the weather. Greenville cash corn
traded at $4.44 in mid-July and $4.13 a year ago.

Earlier this summer, wet weather kept producers out of the field, and many were
concerned about a large drop in acres," Williams said. "Going forward, traders
are watching crop conditions and how they will respond to the forecasted heat
wave through the last week of August."

Thirty-nine percent of the corn produced in the U.S. is used as feed; 39
percent, ethanol; 14 percent, exports; and 10 percent, food. Imported corn is
used to make up the difference between what is produced and what is used.

"For the most part, these proportions remain relatively constant," Williams
said. "We are expected to use slightly more corn for ethanol production this
year but slightly less for livestock feed than a year ago."

LOAD-DATE: June 19, 2016

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                     April 13, 2000, Thursday, Home Edition

Healthy Eating;
 In Season;
 Beans have plenty of flava;
 Pick of the Week: Fava Beans

BYLINE: Cynthia Hizer, For the Journal-Constitution

SOURCE: AJC

SECTION: Food; Pg. 10H

LENGTH: 1003 words


Now's the time to stock up on onions. Prices are so low, in fact, that farmers
are plowing them under. Warm winter weather has sped up Texas onion harvests,
and melons could start almost two weeks early.

Here are more highlights from the produce bins this week:

BEST BUYS: California navel oranges, through April; yellow and bicolor sweet
corn and green snap beans from Florida; jumbo onions; Washington state storage
Red Delicious apples, especially smaller sizes; smaller California avocados.
Also look for giant bundles of dill at local farmers' markets.

JUST IN: We're seeing the first shipments of Florida cucumbers and Texas sweet
1015 onions. Local organic farmers are bringing to specialty stores asparagus,
White Icicle radishes, flowering pea pods and baby lettuces.

LOOKING GOOD: California artichokes, green cabbage, broccoli; California
cauliflower supplies will be increasing and prices are fair; seedless
watermelon, sweet potatoes, Mexican raspberries. Table grapes are coming in from
Argentina and South Africa and the flavor is superior for nondomestic grapes.

EXPENSIVE: Eggplant supplies are moving from Mexico and Arizona to Northern
California and may create a gap; McIntosh apples will be winding down their
season, and the last of the supplies will be higher. Don't look for deals in
baby lettuces and lettuce mixes; Atlanta has some of the highest prices in the
country on these items. All varieties of tomato continue to rise in price while
Florida has the market to itself. White sweet corn is slightly higher in some
stores than yellow corn.

BUYER BEWARE: Onions and potatoes are sprouting because that is what they do
this time of year. Onions may be soft; green sprouting potatoes may taste bitter
and could be toxic. Chilean blueberry harvests are ending; if you see price
deals, they will likely be on marginal fruit.

FADING FAST: You'll see a few blood oranges, but they are puffy and less juicy.
We're seeing the end of Chilean raspberries; you may see appearance and quality
problems.

SEAFOOD DEPARTMENT: Red snapper catches have ended for this year. Soft shell
crabs get larger as the season progresses.

Alaskan halibut season has started. It's a white, meaty fish. Even kids love it.
You can cook it any way. Look for center-cut 1- to 1 1/2-pound steaks or
boneless fillets, skin-on, cut to portion size --- 6 to 8 ounces. The fish will
average $ 7.99 a pound, regardless of form. Serve it with a citrus-butter sauce
and capers. Sea bass is hard to find and the price has gone through the roof.
Lobster is high; don't look for any price relief until after Easter.

ETC.: Spring fromage blanc, fresh goat cheese, is available at specialty cheese
stores and counters.
MENU
Aunt Deborah's Pasta With Fava BeansSalad with sliced cucumbers, sweet onions
and dill vinaigretteRoasted Strawberries
MENU

MAIN DISH
Aunt Deborah's Pasta With Fava Beans

Deborah Geering, an editor at the Journal-Constitution, shared this fresh and
simple main dish that showcases fava beans. It was devised by her aunt, Deborah
McMillan.
Makes 4 servings
Preparation time: 20 minutes
Cooking time: 15-20 minutes

2 pounds fava beans, in their pods (about 1 cup shelled)

1/2 cup bread crumbs
1 tablespoon butter

1/2 pound linguine or other pasta
4 tablespoons olive oil
2 tablespoons minced shallot
2 to 4 cloves garlic, minced
2 tablespoons fresh sage leaves, sliced into ribbons

Salt and pepper

Grated Parmesan or Asiago cheese

Shell the fava beans and remove from casing (see preparation tip in Pick of the
Week); set aside. In a small frying pan over medium heat, brown the bread
crumbs, stirring regularly. Add the butter and stir until melted and absorbed by
the crumbs. Set bread crumbs aside. In a large pot of boiling water, cook pasta
according to package directions. Meanwhile, return frying pan to heat and add
the olive oil. Cook the shallots and garlic until shallots are translucent; add
the shelled fava beans. Cook for 2 minutes, then add the sage, and salt and
pepper to taste. Cook a few seconds longer until sage wilts. Toss the fava
mixture into the pasta, then divide the pasta among 4 dishes. Top each serving
with 1/4 of the bread crumbs; sprinkle with cheese.

Per serving: 522 calories, 17 grams protein, 18 grams fat (percent calories from
fat, 31), 74 grams carbohydrates, 8 milligrams cholesterol, 69 milligrams
sodium, 10 grams fiber.

DESSERT
Roasted Strawberries
Makes 4 servings
Preparation time: 10 minutes
Cooking time: 8 minutes

This is a great way to spiff up the mundane flavor of supermarket fruit.
1 tablespoon unsalted butter
3 tablespoons granulated sugar
16 large, beautiful strawberries, preferably with stems
1 cup heavy cream, chilled
2 tablespoons amaretto or orange liqueur
4 fresh mint sprigs (optional)

Preheat oven to 450 degrees. In an ovenproof skillet just large enough to hold
the strawberries in one layer, melt the butter in the oven, 2 or 3 minutes.
Watch carefully so it does not burn. Remove the skillet from the oven and stir
in 2 tablespoons of the sugar; the mixture will be grainy. Add the berries,
tossing to coat them. Spread in a single layer. Roast, stirring and turning once
or twice, until the berries just begin to soften and the sugar melts, about 5
minutes. Gently roll the berries in the pan syrup to coat, then let them cool
for about 5 minutes in the skillet.

Meanwhile, whip the cream with the liqueur and the remaining 1 tablespoon sugar
just until soft peaks form. Divide the cream among four dessert bowls. Arrange
the lukewarm berries in the cream, pointed ends up. Using a teaspoon, dribble
the pan syrup over the cream. Garnish with mint springs if desired. Serve
immediately. --- From "Short and Sweet" by Melanie Barnard (Houghton Mifflin, $
25)

Per serving: 213 calories, 1 gram protein, 14 grams fat (percent calories from
fat, 61), 20 grams carbohydrates, 49 milligrams cholesterol, 13 milligrams
sodium, 3 grams fiber.

LOAD-DATE: April 13, 2000

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Graphic
Photos by LOUIE FAVORITE/ Staff
This is how to shell Fava beans and put them in a pot to soak (below).
Photo
The Italian answer to butter beans, these giant and delicious beans mature in
early spring instead of summer. They have nourished China for 5,000 years and
Italy, France and England for who knows how long (where they are called broad
beans or simply, common beans). Yet they are hardly known in the United States.
Elizabeth Schneider, author of "Uncommon Fruits and Vegetables" (Harper & Row, $
16.95), has two theories why. First, Americans have always been in a hurry, and
favas take time to shell. Second, their flavor has a slightly bitter cast --- a
flavor Americans have been lukewarm about until they discovered arugula a few
years ago.
If you've never tried them, check them out for yourself and find out why they
are so prized by top chefs all over. Look for them in local farmers markets and
some supermarkets and specialty markets through early June.
Price: About $ 1.29 a pound, unshelled.
Nutrition: Rich in protein, iron, potassium dietary fiber, vitamins A and C,
flavonoids (which can defend cells against carcinogens) and protease inhibitors
(plant proteins that may aid DNA repair and slow cancer cell division).
Selection: For sure, favas are big, but the look is deceptive. Much of their
weight is pod and casing; 2 pounds of unshelled favas will yield only about a
cup. While the beans can grow a foot in length, most I have found in Atlanta
markets are less than half that size.
Storage: For all their toughness, favas don't have a long shelf life. If you
need to store them more than a few days, shell and freeze them.
Uses: Favas can be cooked as you would cook butter beans or limas, or simply
stew them a few minutes in butter, olive oil or cream. Their bitter- edged
flavor marries well with sage, spring onions, chives or even mint. The more
mature ones can be baked in a casserole, layered with leeks, artichokes and
cheese (even strong ones such as feta).
Preparation: After you remove the beans from the pod, you have one more step ---
to remove the bean from the tough casing covering it. Blanch the beans first,
for only 20 seconds, and then the bean will pop out of the casing. Some people
like to eat the casing, too --- they think it adds to the flavor and texture.
But others are allergic to the casing. Check with your dinner guests before you
decide to leave the casing on.
Photo
Once fava beans are out of the pod, blanching will help them pop out of the
casing (below) / Louie Favorite / Staff
Photo
 Putting Fava into the pot

                             974 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

               April 9, 1986, Wednesday, Late City Final Edition

CATTLE RANCHERS SUE TO STOP GOVERNMENT SLAUGHTER OF DAIRY COWS

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section A; Page 17, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 551 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 8


The National Cattlemen's Association filed a suit today in an effort to stop an
Agriculture Department program to slaughter nearly a million dairy cows, saying
the influx of beef was seriously depressing the cattle markets.

A hearing on the suit has been set for April 22 in Lubbock, Tex., before Federal
District Judge Halbert Woodward.

The suit by the association is the second that questions the Government program
in which entire herds of dairy cows are slaughtered or exported in an effort to
end the overproduction of milk.

Earlier this month, a Federal judge in Rochester temporarily blocked the program
after the Humane Society of Rochester and Monroe County complained about the
Federal requirement that an X be branded on the face of each cow.

Temporary Order Extended

The judge in that case, Michael Telesca, today extended his temporary order
barring enforcement of the face branding through April 21. He also set a hearing
for Monday to decide if the injunction should be made permanent.

Representative Frank Horton, Republican of upstate New York, and 19 other
members of the House have introduced a resolution calling on the Agriculture
Department to end the branding requirement. Mr. Horton said the resolution had
been introduced because dairy farmers were not experienced at branding and
risked their own safety as well as that of the animals.

In its suit, the cattlemen's association said the department's decision not to
spread the slaughtering of dairy herds over the 18-month life of the program had
resulted in an oversupply of beef and falling prices in both the live cattle and
futures markets. The beef could be sold in the United States and foreign
countries.

The Agriculture Department, which began the program April 1, will spend about
$1.8 billion over the next 18 months to pay dairy farmers to slaughter their
herds.

Dairy Farmers Need Money

While not commenting on the suit, Daniel Amstutz, Under Secretary of Agriculture
for commodity programs, said cow sales were heavily loaded into the early phase
of the program because many of the dairy farmers needed cash.

Mr. Amstutz said bid levels and cost determined over what period the department
would have the cows slaughtered or exported. ''Had we forced bids into
farther-out programs and forced acceptance of those, we'd have paid more,'' he
said. The department is also buying beef in the early period to offset the glut,
he said.

But Chuck Ball, a spokesman for the cattlemen's association, said the beef
cattle producers who sold animals in the last week lost about $25 million
because of price drops averaging $2 to $3 per 100 pounds.

''Unless the buyout is halted and precisely scheduled marketings are ordered,
losses will mount even higher in the coming weeks,'' the association said in a
statement.

Mr. Ball said the buyout ''has totally disrupted normal cattle marketing,''
adding ''It's just falling apart on us.''

The suit by the association seeks an immediate end to the marketing of dairy
cattle under the program and asks that the department be forced to withdraw its
regulations and rewrite them to lessen the impact on beef markets. The
cattlemen's group was joined in the suit by the Texas Cattle Feeders Association
and the Texas and Southwestern Cattle Raisers Association.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1986 The New York Times Company

                             975 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                                    The Land

                            March 20, 2014 Thursday

Looking after soils pays dividends

BYLINE: Shan Goodwin

SECTION: EARLY GENERAL NEWS; Pg. 38

LENGTH: 398 words


VEGETABLE growers from across the Cudgen Plateau on the Far North Coast are
moving to align their region and industry with sustainable agriculture for
production benefits and, longer term, as a point of difference in the market
place.

Developing whole-of-farm, natural resource management plans, underpinned by
biological practices, is their latest initiative and funding has been secured
for training for a group of 15 vegetable growers and one herb farmer.

Driven by Tweed Fruit and Vegetable Growers Association and Tweed Shire
Council's Sustainable Agriculture Strategy, the course will be delivered by TAFE
NSW thanks to North Coast Local Lands Service and Tweed Shire Council's
Water-ways Program funding.

The producers represent more than 160 hectares of State agricultural land and
are also the "new generation" of the region's farmers with none aged above 40.

They will attend sessions run by soil health guru Gary Zimmer and Bob Shaffer, a
sustainable agricultural consultant from the United States who has worked
extensively with the US sweet potato industry.

Challenges for the Cudgen vegetable producers include soil loss and degradation
and crop losses from plant parasitic nematodes.

Conventional soil management practices and chemical-based controls are proving
costly and ineffective long-term methods of addressing those issues.

Tweed Shire Council's Sustainable Agriculture program leader Eli Szandala said
the training would help farmers resist nematodes, increase profits and sustain
soil health.

"Farmers will be trained in best practice soil and pest management and, by
identifying specific production issues and natural resource assets on their
land, will be able to tailor farm management plans to fit the unique situations
they each face," he said.

The project builds on the success of a number of recent natural resource
management initiatives in the region, including federally-funded projects to
increase carbon levels in agricultural soils and revegetation of waterways on
farming country.

According to Mr Szandala, farmers in the area shared a desire to use natural
processes in food production to keep farming enterprises viable while protecting
the area's natural resources.

Producers said farming in a sustainable "clean, green" way may also, down the
track, underpin a branding program that would set them apart in the marketplace
and allow them to target premiums.

LOAD-DATE: March 19, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


             Copyright 2014 Fairfax Media Publications Pty Limited
                              All Rights Reserved

                             976 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                                    The Land

                                 March 19, 2014

SECTION: CROPPING

LENGTH: 398  words


VEGETABLE growers from across the Cudgen Plateau on the Far North Coast are
moving to align their region and industry with sustainable agriculture for
production benefits and, longer term, as a point of difference in the market
place.

Developing whole-of-farm, natural resource management plans, underpinned by
biological practices, is their latest initiative and funding has been secured
for training for a group of 15 vegetable growers and one herb farmer.

Driven by Tweed Fruit and Vegetable Growers Association and Tweed Shire
Council's Sustainable Agriculture Strategy, the course will be delivered by TAFE
NSW thanks to North Coast Local Lands Service and Tweed Shire Council's
Water-ways Program funding.

The producers represent more than 160 hectares of State agricultural land and
are also the "new generation" of the region's farmers - with none aged above 40.

They will attend sessions run by soil health guru Gary Zimmer and Bob Shaffer, a
sustainable agricultural consultant from the United States who has worked
extensively with the US sweet potato industry.

Challenges for the Cudgen vegetable producers include soil loss and degradation
and crop losses from plant parasitic nematodes.

Conventional soil management practices and chemical-based controls are proving
costly and ineffective long-term methods of addressing those issues.

Tweed Shire Council's Sustainable Agriculture program leader Eli Szandala said
the training would help farmers resist nematodes, increase profits and sustain
soil health.

"Farmers will be trained in best practice soil and pest management and, by
identifying specific production issues and natural resource assets on their
land, will be able to tailor farm management plans to fit the unique situations
they each face," he said.

The project builds on the success of a number of recent natural resource
management initiatives in the region, including federally-funded projects to
increase carbon levels in agricultural soils and revegetation of waterways on
farming country.

According to Mr Szandala, farmers in the area shared a desire to use natural
processes in food production to keep farming enterprises viable while protecting
the area's natural resources.

Producers said farming in a sustainable "clean, green" way may also, down the
track, underpin a branding program that would set them apart in the marketplace
and allow them to target premiums.

                     The Press (Christchurch, New Zealand)

                             April 15, 2005, Friday

Apple war grows

BYLINE: MURDOCH Helen

SECTION: FARMING Pg. 8; FARMING; C

LENGTH: 277 words


Pipfruit growers are asking Agriculture Minister Jim Sutton to back their calls
to take Australia to the World Trade Organisation.

They are also demanding that New Zealand ban the importation of Australian fruit
and vegetables because of the risks from unwanted pests and insects found on
produce.

The calls were made at a recent meeting of Hawkes Bay growers and are backed by
Nelson growers and Pipfruit New Zealand.

PNZ chairman Ian Palmer, of Tasman, said Australia's 80-year ban on New Zealand
apples, because of the supposed risk of fire blight, equated to a non-tariff
trade ban.

In a similar case between the United States and Japan, the WTO ruled mature
apples did not carry any risk, which entitled the US to $ 143 million of
sanctions.

Growers expected the New Zealand Government to seek similar compensation, he
said.

Australia ignores the WTO case between the US and Japan because it suits it, he
said.

"If Australia does not take note of science they are flying in the face of free
trade."

The industry and the Government had spent many years trying to work through the
fireblight issue with Australia, but to no avail, he said.

Growers were becoming increasingly frustrated and angry with Australia's stance,
he said.

PNZ also supported the call to ban Australian fruit and vegetables because of
the risk of pests.

The Hawkes Bay meeting was told that since 2000, more than 4000 interceptions of
unwanted organisms had been made on Australian produce.

"The data is solid; there have been a high number of interceptions which are
putting New Zealand's multibillion-dollar horticultural industry at extreme
risk."

LOAD-DATE: April 15, 2005

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                       Copyright 2005 Fairfax New Zealand

                             978 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                                   USA TODAY

                     July 24, 1990, Tuesday, FINAL EDITION

Portrait of farming a surprising picture

BYLINE: Tracy Walmer

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 427 words


Quick, name the nation's top farm state. Did you guess Iowa? Texas? California?

Whether you're right depends largely on the kind of yardstick you use, according
to a new portrait of farming released Monday by the U.S. Department of
Agriculture.

Though states like Texas, California and Iowa are predictably near the top in
some categories, there are some surprises. Farmland in Rhode Island, for
example, has the most value per acre.

''It's a bittersweet message,'' says Mike Annarummo, director of Rhode Island's
Department of Environmental Management. ''It's very encouraging that Rhode
Island has managed to be a very popular place to live, but for farmers it's a
very fragile existence.''

Other highlights:

- Texas has more farms and more farm acres than any other state. ''It signs the
paychecks of about one out of every five Texans,'' says Heather Ball, a state
economist.

- Iowa leads three categories, including direct government payments to farmers.

- Arizona, better known for its deserts and cacti, is actually an oasis for
cotton and a multitude of fruits and vegetables. It has the USA's biggest farms,
with an average of 4,444 acres.

''It's a surprise because people think of it as a desert. When I first moved to
Arizona 16 years ago friends and family kept sending me all these desert
survival tips from newspapers,'' laughs Roger Huber, assistant director for the
Cooperative Extension Service in Tucson.

The report comes amid congressional efforts to write the 1990 farm bill - a $
50-plus billion piece of legislation that will shape the fortunes of the
nation's 2 million farmers for the next five years.

                       The Southland Times (New Zealand)

                           February 14, 2006 Tuesday

NZ reliant on foreign trade, farmer tells Japan forum

BYLINE: HOLLAND Natasha

SECTION: FARMING; NATIONAL; Briefly; Pg. 13

LENGTH: 280 words


SOUTHLAND farmer Don Nicolson has returned from promoting New Zealand farming
and its rural sector to the Japanese.

Mr Nicolson, the Federated Farmers national vice-president, and president
Charlie Pedersen were invited to speak to the Japan Agricultural Exchange
Council last month.

Mr Nicolson told the council about his own farming operation in Southland and
highlighted New Zealand's economy was heavily dependent on overseas trade and
the importance of agriculture to the country's economy.

Back in Southland, Mr Nicolson said he found it odd that the Japanese bought in
stock food to feed animals that produced meat and milk from countries such as
Australia and the United States, when they could buy the same finished food
products on world open markets at a much lower price.

"Agriculture is not the significant provider to the national good as occurs in
New Zealand.

"Certain foods are very expensive compared to here.

Milk is over $NZ4 per litre ...

Japan is nowhere near self-sufficient in food and again I found it odd that they
may export some food products such as apples as high cost into, say China, at
the same time they have considerable tariff barriers to imports for the same
fruit," Mr Nicolson said.

The Japan Agricultural Exchange Council was established in 1988. It is
administered by Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Consular and Migration Policy
Division and the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries, Agricultural
Extension and Education Division. The council has 15 staff with offices in
Tokyo, Seattle and Bonn.

The council's objectives are to offer Japanese youth opportunities to cultivate
their international awareness within the agricultural arena.

                             980 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                  The State Journal-Register(Springfield, IL)

                            April 12, 2000 Wednesday

IFB urged to promote conservation ;
 Prairie Rivers wants farm group to do more

BYLINE: CHARLYN FARGO AGRIBUSINESS EDITOR

SECTION: BUSINESS, Pg. 29

LENGTH: 597 words


The Prairie Rivers Network called on the Illinois Farm Bureau Tuesday to put the
profits from its affiliate companies into helping farmers become more
conservation-minded.

The pro-environment network, based in Champaign, wants the IFB to provide direct
financial assistance to farmers who are trying to make a transition to more
sustainable, conservation-friendly farming practices, and to turn over to the
government information about agriculture chemical sales from IFB-owned
companies.

Prairie Rivers asked that the chemical information be turned over to the
Illinois Environmental Protection Agency, the U.S. Geological Survey and the
Illinois State Water Survey so the agencies can better estimate the impact of
agriculture- generated pollution on the state's waterways.

"With 27 million acres dedicated to agriculture in Illinois, farmers are the
single most important natural resource managers in the state," said Rob Moore,
executive director of Prairie Rivers. "If Illinois Farm Bureau was a leader, it
would help farmers become more effective stewards of the resources they manage
and contribute to the search for solutions. But promoting stewardship of family
farms and promoting agribusiness are not always compatible goals."

Moore held a press conference Tuesday at the state Capitol to again accuse the
IFB of siding with corporate interests and ignoring the plight of the small
farmer.

"For years, the Illinois Farm Bureau has represented the interests of
agribusiness, not the Illinois farmer," Moore alleged. "To many, this is not
surprising, given the small percentage of Farm Bureau members that are farmers
and the vast financial stake the Illinois Farm Bureau holds in agribusiness."

Karen Hudson, president of Families Against Rural Messes, joined Moore in
calling for a "spring cleaning" of the Farm Bureau.

Another press conference participant, Keith Bolin, a Bureau County farmer and
member of the IFB, thinks the Farm Bureau should fight for more equitable
pricing of agricultural products through elimination of contract farming.

"Our salvation as farmers is getting a share of the dollar that's deserved us,"
said Bolin, who farms 460 acres and raises 3,000 head of hogs in a non-
confinement operation. "We know farming, and we're good at it, but we want to
survive. "

Bolin said those who contracted with large companies to market hogs in his area
received $30 a head more, but he doesn't like the idea of being part of a large
conglomerate.

Dennis Vercler, director of news and communication for IFB, said complaints
about the bureau are misdirected.

" People make Farm Bureau the issue," said Vercler, who also attended Tuesday's
press conference. "When agriculture is under stress, established agriculture
groups become the target, not just Farm Bureau, but checkoffs and other
traditional farm groups."

Vercler said the IFB doesn't have the funds for the conservation sharing Prairie
Rivers wants.

"We just don't have that kind of money," he said. "We have a small amount of
reserves, but we lobby Congress for cost-share money for conservation for
farmers. What you're talking about is millions and millions of dollars."

In addition, he said the IFB has a 10-page action plan concerning agriculture
concentration.

" I'm baffled with why these folks are criticizing Farm Bureau," Vercler said. "
It's one way that farmers can get some conditions changed. What they said has
been said before. They should spend the same amount of effort that they've put
into fighting Farm Bureau into finding solutions."

                               The New York Times

              January 7, 1981, Wednesday, Late City Final Edition

BEST BUYS;
SUGAR PRICES ARE EXPECTED TO RISE FURTHER

SECTION: Section C; Page 9, Column 1; Living Desk

LENGTH: 674 words


THE United States Department of Agriculture estimates that sugar prices will
rise further this year. Recently the average price of a five-pound sack of
granulated sugar at the store dropped 10 cents to $3.08 - still 107 percent more
than last year at this time. Some experts believe that a decrease in consumption
is responsible for the small dip in price, plus the fact that on freezing winter
days soft drinks and ice cream do not have the allure they manifest at the
height of summer.

Sugar and drought were leading factors in the nearly 15 percent rise in grocery
bills last year. But there was some good news. During the two-week period of
Dec. 22-Jan. 2 the average cost of feeding a family of four in New York City
actually fell 37 cents to $101.37, according to the City of New York Department
of Consumer Affairs.

''This past month shoppers have had a breather from food price inflation,''
commented Commissioner Bruce C. Ratner. ''But even the usually conservative
Department of Agriculture is warning us that 1981 will be another year of
double-digit food price rises.''

Meanwhile, there are some bargain items to be found. Many store brands of frozen
orange juice are selling for 59 cents a 12-ounce can. Coffee is down to $1.99 a
pound in some supermarkets, and large eggs are 79 cents a dozen.

Last year drought caused higher meat prices because of increased feed grain
costs. Hot, dry weather also heavily damaged the nation's peanut crop and raw
peanut prices have more than doubled, with the result that peanut butter has
gone up too.

Recent cold weather has slowed down potato packing and brought about a slight
increase in price. Potato prices rose to an average of $1.20 for five pounds, 52
percent above year ago.

There are, however, some good buys in fruit and vegetables with the advent of
crops from California, Florida and Mexico. Broccoli is arriving in good supply
from California and Texas and going down in price. A sharp decline in the cost
of green peppers is expected as the Florida and Mexican harvest gets under way.

Citrus fruits are plentiful from Florida: juice oranges 10 for 89 cents, pink
and white grapefruits and tangerines 15 for 99 cents in some shops. California
small navel oranges are down to 10 for 89 cents. Red Delicious and McIntosh
apples from New York and Washington states are selling at 89 cents a three-pound
bag, French Granny Smiths at 49 cents a pound. Anjou pears are now two pounds
for 89 cents, bananas four pounds for $1.

Western cauliflower is 99 cents a head, and makes a satisfying winter vegetable.
Cabbage is in good supply from Florida and Texas at 25 cents a pound, with
prices declining.

The startling drop this week is in the price of cucumbers, newly arrived from
Mexico and the Bahamas selling at four for $1. For a salad, slice them very thin
and sprinkle them with Japanese vinegar and chopped dill, or bake them and coat
them with hollandaise, bechamel or Mornay sauce. The following recipe goes
particularly well with fish or chicken.

Cucumbers With Dill

4 cucumbers 2 tablespoons white vinegar 1/4 cup butter 4 tablespoons dill,
chopped Coarse salt and freshly ground pepper

1. Peel, seed and cut the cucumbers into 1/2-inch pieces. Soak in vinegar for 1
hour.  2.  Pre-heat oven to 350 degrees. Drain the cucumbers and pat dry with
paper towels.  3. Arrange cucumbers in a buttered ovenproof dish. Sprinkle with
pieces of butter, dill, salt and pepper.  4. Cover and bake for 30-45 minutes,
or until tender.  Yield: 4 servings.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1981 The New York Times Company

                             982 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                     Belfast News Letter (Northern Ireland)

                           October 4, 2003, Saturday

BEEF EMBRYOS GIVEN THE GREEN LIGHT

SECTION: FARMING LIFE; Pg. 17

LENGTH: 113 words


EXPORTS of British beef embryos to South Africa are to re-start after a
seven-year ban.

Based on the latest scientific evidence, an export certificate was issued this
month by the South African authorities following the ban which was triggered by
the BSE outbreak.

Meanwhile, lamb and mutton production in the United States dropped to a record
low in August, falling six per cent compared to 2002 levels to 7,080 tonnes.

The United States Department of Agriculture said that the three per cent rise in
average weights failed to offset the nine per cent decline in sheep slaughter.

There were 241,200 sheep slaughtered in August, averaging 129lb liveweight.

BEEF EMBRYOS GIVEN THE GREEN LIGHT

SECTION: FARMING LIFE; Pg. 17

LENGTH: 113 words


EXPORTS of British beef embryos to South Africa are to re-start after a
seven-year ban.

Based on the latest scientific evidence, an export certificate was issued this
month by the South African authorities following the ban which was triggered by
the BSE outbreak.

Meanwhile, lamb and mutton production in the United States dropped to a record
low in August, falling six per cent compared to 2002 levels to 7,080 tonnes.

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

                      June 29, 1990, Friday, DAILY EDITION

Report will be bullish for Chicago soybean prices

BYLINE: Farm Market News

SECTION: SECTION 2, INVESTMENT AND FINANCE; Pg. 18, FARM COMMODITIES

LENGTH: 283 words

DATELINE: Winnipeg,Man.


Traders at the Chicago Board of Trade and Winnipeg Commodity Exchange were
sidelined for the better part of yesterday awaiting the publication of the U.S.
Department of Agriculture's planted acreage and grain stocks reports.

The report, made public after the close of trading, was termed bullish for CBOT
soybean prices today, and bearish for both corn and wheat prices.

The department estimated U.S. farmers seeded 58.045 million acres of land to
soybeans in 1990. This is at the low end of pre-report estimates and could
ultimately create a soybean shortage. Total U.S. soybean stocks as of June 1,
1990 were pegged at 595.91 million bushels.

Corn plantings were at the higher end of pre-report guesses while the corn
stocks forecast was within market expectations.

U.S. wheat stocks as of June 1 totaled 535 million bushels, well above the
highest guess of what the trade had anticipated.

CBOT corn prices closed US2 1/2 cents to US8 1/4 cents a bushel higher. The most
active contract, September, settled at US$2.89 1/4, up US4 3/4 cents.

Continued concerns about the impact of intense heat on the U.S. corn crop drove
futures higher.

Wheat prices at the CBOT ended US1 1/2 cents to US3 cents lower. September
closed at US$3.35 1/4 a bushel, down US2 1/4 cents.

Sluggish export demand and an active harvest pace pressured wheat futures.

Poor exporter demand as well as the lack of fresh buying incentives pushed
flaxseed prices at the Winnipeg Commodity Exchange lower.

WCE flaxseed closed $2 to $10 a metric ton lower. The most active contract,
October, settled at $314.20, down $2. The most the flax contract can move in a
single day is $10.




LOAD-DATE: November 6, 1997

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: NEWS

                       Copyright 1990 Financial Post Ltd.

                             985 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                               The Washington Post

                   November 14, 2000, Tuesday, Final Edition

Smithfield Bids For Nation's Top Meat Producer

Kenneth Bredemeier , Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: FINANCIAL; Pg. E01

LENGTH: 767 words


Smithfield Foods Inc., the nation's largest pork producer, yesterday bid $ 4.1
billion in stock and assumed debt to take over IBP Inc., the country's No. 1
beef processor, in a deal immediately questioned by the Agriculture Department
and two U.S. senators.

The Smithfield, Va.-based firm with 20 percent of the U.S. pork market said its
offer for IBP trumped last month's leveraged buyout proposed by IBP managers by
$ 290 million. Smithfield said the deal would be good for shareholders by
increasing stock value and for food retailers and consumers by providing a wider
variety of meat products.

But IBP had no immediate reaction to the offer, saying only that it would
examine the proposed deal "with the help of outside counsel and its financial
adviser."

IBP, already the largest meat producer in the United States, with 30 percent of
the beef market and 18 percent of pork production, is based in Dakota Dunes,
S.D., but it has operations in China, Ireland and Russia and more than 60
production sites in North America.

As a result, the merger would create an even bigger meat-producing giant at the
top of the U.S. food chain. The proposed deal immediately drew the attention of
the Agriculture and Justice departments, which have reviewed other Smithfield
acquisitions over the past decade for antitrust considerations. Smithfield
notified Justice of its offer and said it might have to sell off a couple of its
pork-processing plants for the deal to be approved.

Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman said the proposal "highlights the continuing
troublesome trend of consolidation in American agriculture." Glickman said that
while he does not want to "prejudge the outcome," he will "work closely" with
the Justice Department "to ensure a close and serious review" of the deal.

Meanwhile, two Democratic senators from the Midwest, Paul D. Wellstone of
Minnesota and Tom Harkin of Iowa, voiced concern over the prospect of yet
another merger in the consolidating ranks of agribusiness.

"Wall Street may be cheering today," Wellstone said, "but hard-pressed family
farmers and ranchers are not cheering one bit. How much more concentrated do
these agriculture markets have to become before we demand strong antitrust
action? A Smithfield-IBP merger would represent an unprecedented case of
horizontal concentration, and I will continue to push federal antitrust
officials to scrutinize mergers involving IBP."

Harkin, in letters to Attorney General Janet Reno and Glickman, wrote: "In a
time of rapid consolidation and concentration in agriculture, any proposed
consolidation should raise the specter of concern. But when the largest pork
processor wants to acquire the largest beef processor and the second largest
pork processor, sirens should be sounding."

Joseph W. Luter III, Smithfield's chairman and chief executive, said in a letter
to IBP that "we view a combination with IBP as an opportunity to create
significant value for both of our stockholder bases by continuing to expand the
movement into [grocery store] case-ready products, by creating a national brand
and by building a strong stable of value-added meat products."

The Smithfield offer includes $ 2.7 billion in Smithfield stock ($ 25 a share)
and assumption of $ 1.4 billion in IBP debt. The Virginia firm said its
per-share price represents a 19.8 percent premium over IBP's closing price
Friday, a 36.5 percent premium over IBP's closing price on Sept. 29 (the day
before the managers' buyout proposal was announced) and a 12.4 percent premium
over the $ 3.8 billion offer ($ 22.25 a share) from the managers.

IBP's stock closed up 6.6 percent yesterday, increasing $ 1.38, to $ 22.25,
while Smithfield's fell 11.5 percent, dropping $ 3.63, to $ 28.

Christine L. McCracken, an analyst with Midwest Research in Cleveland, and Jaine
Mehring, an analyst with Salomon Smith Barney, both said that Smithfield could
pay as much as $ 30 a share to buy IBP and not hurt its earnings. "It's a great
deal from a marketplace and shareholder standpoint," McCracken said, because it
is tax-free for shareholders, whereas the management buyout offer is not. The
merger will create "a much more solid company," she added. "So I think the only
obstacle will be the sale of these [Smithfield] assets and how long that might
take. I would expect things to go forward."

But Mehring cautioned that it is "very unresolved" whether agribusiness mergers
"harm the farmer or consumer."

"What's good for the shareholder might be different from what's good for the
farmer or consumer," Mehring said.

LOAD-DATE: November 17, 2000

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                       Copyright 2000 The Washington Post

                             986 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                         Star Tribune (Minneapolis, MN)

                             August 13, 2010 Friday
                                 METRO EDITION

Crops may help farmers rebound;
With strong production expected, farm incomes should recover after a big drop
last year.

BYLINE: MIKE HUGHLETT; STAFF WRITER, STAR TRIBUNE (Mpls.-St. Paul)

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. 1D

LENGTH: 525 words


From corn to soybeans to sugar beets, Minnesota farmers are looking at bumper
crops this year.

They've benefited from good weather and a particularly mild spring that allowed
for early planting. And wheat growers are particularly in the green, as prices
for that grain have rocketed over the past several weeks.

Meanwhile, livestock and dairy farmers -- who mostly lost money last year -- are
back in the black in 2010.

The upshot: "Farm income trends should be very good this year," said Michael
Swanson, an agricultural economist at Wells Fargo in Minneapolis. "It's a very
positive outlook right now."

U.S. corn production is forecast to hit record highs this year, including in
Minnesota. The state's corn crop is expected to be 1.25 billion bushels, up
slightly over last year, with a yield of 178 bushels per acre, an increase of
four bushels over 2009, according to data released Thursday by the United States
Department of Agriculture's Minnesota field office.

The state's soybean production is forecast at a record 326 million bushels, up
14 percent from last year. Soybean yields are expected to be 44 bushels per
acre, up four bushels from last year, according to the USDA.

"Minnesota's corn and soybean crops look really good," said Dale Durchholz,
senior market analyst at AgriVisor LLC in Bloomington, Ill. Minnesota is the
nation's fourth-largest corn grower and third-biggest soybean producer.

The state is also the nation's second-largest producer of spring wheat, and
while that crop isn't forecast to break records, it's quite healthy. Spring
wheat production is expected to be up 10 percent from last year, with a yield
estimated at 55 bushels per acre, up two bushels from 2009, according to the
USDA.

Wheat prices have jumped about 70 percent this summer, as about one-third of
Russia's wheat crop shriveled during the hottest summer there in about 130
years. Bad weather in Ukraine and Kazakhstan -- both big wheat producers -- has
also put upward pressure on prices. Russia is the world's third-largest wheat
exporter after the United States and Canada.

Wheat prices particularly shot up in late July and early August, so farmers who
earlier this year sold their crops forward through futures contracts -- a common
practice -- missed out on some of the windfall.

Still, the majority of Minnesota growers are going to benefit from these high
prices, said Dave Torgerson, executive director of the Minnesota Association of
Wheat Growers.

Hog and cattle prices have also been on the upswing this year, as have dairy
prices -- welcome news after a miserable 2009.

A grim year in livestock and dairy farming, coupled with a decline in crop
farmers' earnings, led to a 63 percent drop in median net farm income in 2009 to
$33,417, the lowest mark since 2001, according to an annual study by the
Minnesota State Colleges and Universities system and University of Minnesota
Extension.

But in 2010, with big crops and decent grain prices coupled with "reasonable
profits" in the livestock and dairy sectors, Minnesota farm income could set
records, said Wells Fargo's Swanson.

The Associated Press contributed to this report. Mike Hughlett - 612-673-7003

LOAD-DATE: August 18, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper
