DELAY IN EXPORTS

SECTION: FARMING LIFE; Pg. 11

LENGTH: 112 words


IN spite of the soyabean harvest being well under way in South America,
logistical problems in Brazil are causing some export issues.

Meanwhile, in the US, the first United States Department of Agriculture planting
estimate for 2003 is above many trade estimates.

l FRENCH research has confirmed a link between somatic cell count (SCC) levels
recorded within six weeks of heifers calving down and animals future
predisposition to clinical mastitis problems.

The work was undertaken by staff at the Institute National de la Recherce
Agronomique (INRA)and involved the close scrutiny of the milk quality data
produced by over 20,000 Holstein heifers.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUB-TYPE: PAPER

                   Copyright 2003 Century Newspapers Limited

                             988 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                                The Toronto Star

                  November 12, 1986, Wednesday, FINAL EDITION

Ottawa eying ways to dispense aid to farmers

BYLINE: CP

SECTION: BUSINESS TODAY; Pg. E8

LENGTH: 548 words

DATELINE: OTTAWA


   OTTAWA (CP) - A formula is being drawn up by federal officials to determine
individual farmer shares of the $1 billion farm assistance program, Agriculture
Minister John Wise says.

The key ingredients to be included in the formula were worked out in meetings
with farm leaders and should ensure equal treatment for farmers across the
country, Wise said in an interview.

But the minister still doesn't know when federal cheques will be mailed, or
whether provincial governments will match or make supplementary payments based
on its formula.

Wise will meet provincial agriculture ministers Nov. 17 to put the final touches
to a national agriculture development strategy for presentation at the first
minister's meetings the week after.

Spokesman Lisa Hardey said there could be discussion at next week's meeting
about the formula and possible provincial payments.

The payment is supposed to help grain, oilseed and corn growers cope with the
lower prices for their crops caused by the agriculture subsidies battle between
the United States and the European Community and the large world grain surplus
caused by those subsidies.

Canada exports about three-quarters of its crop. The drop in grain and other
prices has hit Canadian farmers hard. Farm incomes have fallen in the past few
years to where they were in the early 1970s. In terms of purchasing power, some
economists say farm income has been reduced to the same level as during the
Depression.

Some farm organizations have argued that $3 billion to $4 billion is needed to
counter the impact of lower prices.

Jack Penner, president of Manitoba's Keystone Agricultural Producers, said the
formula is an "equitable and fair way to use as a distribution system and I
think we'll find that most people and most regions will be very equitably
treated under that system."

He said it was too early to tell how much of the payout will go to western
farmers. Last month Penner was urging Prairie farm organizations to lobby hard
for up to $900 million.

Bill Hamilton, executive-secretary of the Canadian Federation of Agriculture,
said the shape of the formula is still very vague.

He said it will take into account the financial burden on farmers, the amount of
land they seeded and the general productivity of their farms.

Less certain is the time period that will be looked at and whether there will be
a cap on the amount an individual farmer can collect, Hamilton said.

Wise said there appears to be general support to paying farmers who grow grain
to feed their own livestock.

Future payments

Wise said the formula will be shown to farm leaders to make sure it has their
support, but he has no plans to hold more meetings with them until January or
February, when he will discuss the agriculture development strategy and how to
make future payments to farmers.

It is expected to be at least several years before financial health is restored
to the agriculture industry. Wise wants federal assistance to help farmers
without encouraging them to expand production.

The payment formula now being developed probably won't be used again because
Ottawa will want different factors included when farmers know ahead of time they
will be getting federal money, Hamilton said.

LOAD-DATE: May 13, 1999

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Photo John Wise

                  Copyright 1986 Toronto Star Newspapers, Ltd.

                             989 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                               Business Recorder

                           February 18, 2016 Thursday

USAID launches biofortified maize hybrid seed

SECTION: Vol. 52 No. 49

LENGTH: 441  words


United States is committed to working with Pakistan to increase productivity and
income in the agriculture sector in order to improve the livelihood of the
farmers. John Groarke, Mission Director United States Agency for International
Development (USAID), said this while speaking at launching ceremony of
Biofortified Maize hybrid seed in Pakistan and handover of Maize parental seed
at National Agricultural Research Center (NARC) on Wednesday.

Groarke said that for the last 50 years, US and Pakistan have been working
together to strengthen Pakistan's agriculture and improve the productivity of
crops including wheat, rice and maize. "Due to joint efforts of US and Pakistan,
the production of wheat crop has increased by 25 percent during last few years,"
he added.

He handed over new varieties of maize seed to Pakistani research organisations
and private sector seed companies. The new varieties of maize were identified
and provided by USAID agriculture innovation program in co-ordination with the
NARC, in an effort to improve the production of quality hybrid maize seed in
Pakistan. The USAID Mission Director said that maize seeds will benefit farmers
and increase access to nutritious food to million of Pakistanis.

In addition to partnering together in the field, he said, "we are also
collaborating in the classroom, so the next generation of scientists can find
new ways to improve the lives of Pakistani farmers." Through the Agricultural
Innovation Program, USAID is providing graduate school fellowships to Pakistani
scientists and researchers at leading US agricultural universities, he said.

Dr Muhammad Hashim Popalzai, Additional Secretary, Ministry of National Food
Security and Research said that the new varieties seed would play pivotal role
in increasing productivity of maize, wheat and rice as quality seed is one of
the major challenge for Pakistan's agriculture.

He said that the government is committed to strengthening agriculture sector in
order to improve livelihood of farmers. Muhammad Sadiq Tahir, a farmer from
Rawalakot, Azad Jammu and Kashmir, speaking on the occasion said that seeds will
improve the quality of his harvest for years to come. USAID Agricultural
Innovation Program is a four-year $30 million initiative designed to increase
productivity and incomes in the agriculture sector through the promotion and
dissemination of modern production practices for wheat maize, rice, livestock ,
fruit and vegetable. The varieties of maize distributed are bred to resist
drought and heat stress and have enhanced nutritional quality. They also have
increased tolerance to insect attack and low soil nitrogen.

                              All Rights Reserved

                             990 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                March 27, 1984, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

FUTURES/OPTIONS ;
Planting Report Lifts Grains and Soybeans



BYLINE:
By The Associated Press

SECTION: Section D; Page 22, Column 5; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 376 words


Grain and soybean futures prices generally rose yesterday on the Chicago Board
of Trade. Prices advanced early in the session, then traded in a narrow range.

Prices were supported by an Agriculture Department report on Friday that
indicated that the enrollment in wheat and corn acreage-reduction programs was
greater than the market had expected, according to Bob Lekberg, a grain analyst
in Chicago with Shearson/American Express.

In addition, a Brazilian agency lowered its estimate for this year's soybean
crop in Brazil to 15.2 million metric tons, from 15.9 million, Mr. Lekberg said.

Commercial concerns have been taking delivery of large amounts of wheat,
possibly for export, sources said, and that has helped support soybean prices.

Live hogs and frozen pork bellies were mixed on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.
A report on cattle inventories released by the Agriculture Department last
Tuesday continued to affect the price of pork bellies and hogs. Contracts for
delivery in the fall and in 1985 continued to advance. Pork bellies for delivery
next February posted their fourth consecutive 2-cent advance and reached a
life-of- contract high.

John Ginzel, a livestock analyst in Chicago with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.,
said the report indicated that breeding herds of hogs on farms in the major
pork-producing states were 10 percent below a year ago, a development that will
lead to reduced supplies in the fall and later.

Hogs and pork bellies for delivery in the next few months were weaker, under
pressure from wholesale markets and technical factors.



Cattle Supplies Tight

Cattle prices also rose to life-of-contract highs early in the session and then
declined. Mr. Ginzel said a tug- of-war appeared to be developing in the cattle
market. Supplies appear tight, he said, as a major storm was moving into the
high plains and southern Corn Belt states, but demand for red meats typically
declines during Lent.

Orange juice and coffee prices also advanced to life-of-contract highs. Orange
juice was supported by concern about supplies, which has brought the price to
its highest level in seven years. Coffee was supported by the International
Coffee Organization's success in controlling supplies, analysts said.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1984 The New York Times Company

                             991 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                                 Stock Journal

                            January 5, 2012 Thursday

FARM industry groups worried by a growing lack of c

BYLINE: ANDREW MARSHALL

SECTION: EGN; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 537 words


FARM industry groups worried by a growing lack of consumer empathy with food
production and modern agriculture may adopt a United States' initiative to help
build public trust in farming. The work of the non-profit Centre for Food
Integrity in Missouri has attracted increasing attention in Australia because of
its success in building consumer understanding of farmers while also
highlighting environmental, productivity and food safety gains achieved by
today's farm enterprises. CFI chief executive officer Charlie Arnot is due back
in Australia in February to talk to dairyfarmers after two tours in 2011. His
message that farmers and food companies have to put more strategic effort into
promoting public trust and establishing their own strict self-regulated
standards has been keenly absorbed by industry leaders and farmer groups.

"The CFI model has certainly had a lot of success. It's now a case of trying to
determine if and how it might work in Australia," said New South Wales
Department of Primary Industries livestock officer at Moree Greg Mills, one of
the hosts of Mr Arnot's earlier visit. The CFI, established by US soybean
producers in 2007, is funded by farmers, farm and food organisations and private
companies. It researches food issues and develops messages that build consumer
trust in the food system. The centre has a big social media presence and helps
train qualified people to deliver positive and accurate information in public
forums and the media. National Farmers Federation chief executive officer Matt
Linegar said there was no doubt "agriculture's social licences to operate" were
under increasing pressure as the urban-rural divide widened and consumers had
less exposure to agriculture. "We're examining the CFI's activities as part of
our greater aim of keeping agriculture's true value recognised by governments
and the public," he said. "I'm sure the issue of building consumer trust will
emerge as an important theme in the NFF's blueprint for agriculture in the
coming year." While visiting Australia in November, organisations as diverse as
Horticulture Australia Limited, the Australian Rural Leadership Foundation,
Animal Welfare Science Centre and the Australian Egg Corporation discussed the
CFI's activities and sought Mr Arnot's views on consumer attitudes. Consumer
reaction to the northern Australian beef industry's perceived abdication of its
"social licence" in the Indonesian live cattle trade and the Federal
Government's snap decision to ban exports last year were topical discussion
themes. "Farmers often feel like the victims which they may or may not be but
the fact is consumers aren't willing to put your farm's profit concerns ahead of
their current principles," Mr Arnot said in Sydney. "We have to help consumers
understand their principles are actually the same as today's farmers. "Animal
welfare, environmental stewardship, food safety and a passion for doing the food
production job well are all basic principals of farming." He said if farmers
stayed quiet and shied from talking about their farms and farming activities,
they would never redefine the way urbanised consumers understood agriculture,
nor build public trust in what happens on the farm.

LOAD-DATE: January 4, 2012

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              All Rights Reserved

                             992 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                      Abbotsford Times (British Columbia)

                            December 31, 2004 Friday
                                 Final Edition

Young cattle allowed back

BYLINE: Christina Toth, The Times

SECTION: UPFRONT; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 139  words


Canadian cattle ranchers got a late Christmas gift Dec. 29, when the United
States Department of Agriculture said it will allow live cattle under 30 months
old across the border. The cattle must be slaughtered before 30 months and can't
be moved between feed lots, said the USDA release.

John van Dongen, Minister of Agriculture, Food and Fisheries, said the
announcement was good news for everyone in the cattle sector, but the border
remains closed to breeding stock and cull cattle, significant issues for Fraser
Valley dairy farmers who historically sold breeding animals to U.S. farms. U.S.
Agriculture Secretary Ann Veneman said after conducting an extensive review,
Canada is recognized as a minimal-risk region. Cattle must include permanent
marking of the animals as to their origin, and be moved in sealed containers to
feedlots.

LOAD-DATE: February 27, 2006

                             993 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                             August 30, 2013 Friday

Washington: NCGA Promotes Importance of Modern Farming to International Visitors

LENGTH: 347  words

DATELINE: Washington


National Corn Grower Association has issued the following Nomination:

This week, the National Corn Growers Association brought the corn farmers
perspective on American agriculture to an international group of an agronomists
and soil scientists hosted by the International Fertilizer Development Center in
St. Louis. Addressing participants from 10 nations, NCGA Vice President of
Production and Utilization Paul Bertels and Director of Biotechnology and
Economic Analysis Nathan Fields shared an overview of American agriculture
focusing on production techniques, crop conditions and biotechnology as part of
an effort to help participants find farming advances which might be useful in
their home countries.

"NCGA helps not only farmers abroad but also those here in the United States by
engaging in dialogues such as this," said Bertels. "As international
agricultural leaders come to understand how modern techniques and technologies
benefit our country and see the broad public acceptance of them, we foster
greater acceptance internationally. These visitors come away with a clearer
picture of U.S. farming that has a ripple effect, opening markets and dispelling
misperceptions across the globe."

The participants included thought leaders from Angola, Bangladesh, Brazil,
China, Croatia, Ethiopia, Morocco, Nigeria, South Africa and Zambia. Given the
magnitude of confusion surrounding biotechnology abroad, the discussion provided
an important opportunity to spread accurate, science-based information on this
subject to an audience with broad influence.

"The story of biotechnology is truly amazing, and it is one that must be told if
we are to meet the challenges a growing global population places upon farmers,"
Fields said. "When scientist such as these have an opportunity to see how
biotechnology works in America, providing a valuable tool that produces a safe,
abundant crop, they can act as advocates that help shape policies and
perceptions. Together, we can all ensure farmers have access to the tools they
need."

For more information please visit: http://www.ncga.com

LOAD-DATE: August 31, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire

Washington: NCGA Promotes Importance of Modern Farming to International Visitors

LENGTH: 347  words

This week, the National Corn Growers Association brought the corn farmers
perspective on American agriculture to an international group of an agronomists
and soil scientists hosted by the International Fertilizer Development Center in
St. Louis. Addressing participants from 10 nations, NCGA Vice President of
Production and Utilization Paul Bertels and Director of Biotechnology and
Economic Analysis Nathan Fields shared an overview of American agriculture
focusing on production techniques, crop conditions and biotechnology as part of
an effort to help participants find farming advances which might be useful in
their home countries.

"NCGA helps not only farmers abroad but also those here in the United States by
engaging in dialogues such as this," said Bertels. "As international

benefit our country and see the broad public acceptance of them, we foster

                       The Oklahoman (Oklahoma City, OK)

                              July 28, 2006 Friday
                                  City Edition

Organic farming a good step

SECTION: OPINION; YOUR VIEWS; Pg. 12A

LENGTH: 594 words


Regarding "Local farmers provide quality produce" (feature, July 19): It's great
to see that organic farming is becoming so popular in Oklahoma. As Americans
become aware of the animal welfare and environmental problems associated with
factory farming, concern about the way our food is produced increases. Factory
farming has become big business in this country -- the majority of all the eggs,
meat and dairy Americans consume comes from sprawling industrial sites that
reduce animals to units of production in order to drive up profits.

Inside vast sunless sheds, tens of thousands of egg-laying hens are routinely
confined to cages so small they can't spread their wings. Veal calves are
tethered by their necks to barren crates so small they can't turn around. And
for nearly their entire lives, mother pigs are confined in metal cages barely
larger than their own bodies. For too long, factory farming has been responsible
for an untold amount of animal suffering. Moving toward organic farming is a
step in the right direction. Katie Carrus Washington, D.C. Carrus is coordinator
of the Factory Farming Campaign for The Humane Society of the United States.

Laughable argument

I was appalled at the inaccuracy of Dan Thomasson's column Tuesday on subsidies
received by farmers. His description of an Oklahoma relative who was "paid" not
to produce while amassing a fortune is so far off base it's laughable. I'm
involved in financing production agriculture and know firsthand the cash flow of
Oklahoma producers. Producers are paid for various commodity programs, but being
paid not to produce isn't one of them. This theory is ancient and a holdover
from many years ago.

Today's producers are fighting financially for their farms and their livelihood.
The policies aimed at production agriculture would take a library to explain,
but the only thing Oklahomans need to know is that our producers are the best,
the food is the cheapest and, I hope, we'll never have to stand in line for
food. Doug Tippens Yukon Tippens is president and CEO of Canadian State Bank.

No justification

As a lifelong atheist, I do not lie and pronounce "under God" when reciting the
Pledge of Allegiance. I object to the government not stating "in God some of us
trust" on my currency. I refuse to swear to "God" in courts of law. I and
millions of other atheists have the courage to admit the obvious: There is no
"God" and no conceivable test to prove us wrong. There is no justification for
the majority to impose their beliefs on the minority. Bert Rackett Oklahoma City

Their own fault

Tim O'Connor (Your Views, July 21) is wrong when he blames the government for
Dayton Tire's closing. He needs to look at the union he's in charge of. The
members have priced themselves out of work. They've pushed these companies into
closing. Unions have used their power to negotiate contracts that these
companies can't afford. General Motors has a responsibility to its shareholders
also.

Nowadays no one is satisfied with a good-paying job. They want more and more.
Unions have the ability to extort money by the threat of striking. The leaders
of these unions are fat cats. O'Connor will go on enjoying his union perks, but
the employees will suffer. The unions don't give in to the demand of GM or
Dayton until they find out they will close. Only then they are willing to take
less money and offer to help pay for their health care. K.S. Jones Midwest City


LOAD-DATE: July 31, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


               Copyright 2006 The Oklahoman, All Rights Reserved

                               The New York Times

                             June 21, 2014 Saturday
                              Late Edition - Final

Agricultural Output Climbed in 2013, Recovering From Drought

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

SECTION: Section B; Column 0; Business/Financial Desk; OFF THE CHARTS; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 492 words


AGRICULTURE is a small part of the United States economy, but last year it was
the best part.

The output of the agriculture sector grew 16.4 percent after inflation last
year, the fastest rise for the sector since at least 1998 and far faster than
any other part of the economy. The nation's gross domestic product grew just 1.8
percent, while the second-fastest growing sector, the information industry, rose
3.2 percent.

Last week, the government released its estimates of state economic growth in
2013. North Dakota led the pack with a growth rate of 9.7 percent. Alaska was
the only state whose economy declined, shrinking by 2.1 percent, largely because
of declining oil production.

The economy of the District of Columbia also declined, but that was because of
cuts in government spending.

North Dakota benefited from its rising production of shale oil, but it was also
helped by the fact that its agriculture sector amounts to 12.9 percent of the
state's economy, more than that of any other state except South Dakota.

By contrast, agriculture accounted for just 1.6 percent of the country's overall
output in 2013. But that was the largest share in recent years, up from a recent
low of 0.9 percent in 2006. The agriculture sector includes forestry, fishing
and hunting as well as farming, but farming is much larger than the other
categories.

Last year, the government changed the way it calculated G.D.P. figures,
including counting research and development spending as investments rather than
as consumption. It revised historical figures only back to 1997, so earlier
years' output and growth figures for agriculture are not comparable.

Mitch Morehart, an economist with the Agriculture Department, said the strong
growth in agriculture reflected a recovery in production for some crops after a
drought in 2012, as well as strong production and rising prices for livestock.
This year, he said, it appears that agriculture is not doing nearly as well.

Over all, the economies of the 10 states that are most dependent on agriculture
grew at an average annual rate of 3.4 percent in 2013, while the 10 states that
are least dependent on the farm economy grew at an average rate of 1.3 percent.

California is by far the largest agricultural producer, accounting for $46.7
billion, or 17 percent, of the total national agricultural output of $269.1
billion. But the state is so large that agriculture makes up only 2.1 percent of
its output, less than 16 other states. Iowa, which ranks second in dollar value
at $16.1 billion, depends on agriculture for almost 10 percent of its total
economic output.

The 2013 surge in agriculture ended a string of three years in which that sector
did not do as well as the overall United States economy. But since 1998,
agriculture outperformed the rest of the economy in nine of the 15 years. During
that stretch, agriculture grew at an annual rate of 4 percent, double the 2
percent average for the national economy.

URL: http://www.nytimes.com/2014/06/21/business/economy/after-a-drought-
agriculture-climbs.html

LOAD-DATE: June 21, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: CHARTS: Booming Agriculture: The agriculture sector of the United
States economy grew far more rapidly than any other sector in 2013, and
outperformed all but one sector over  the last 15 years. It remains a small part
of the overall economy, but its share is the largest it has been in at least the
last 16 years. States most  dependent on agriculture generally grew more rapidly
in 2013 than did states with smaller agricultural sectors. (Source: Bureau of
Economic Analysis)

                             997 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                                 Pakistan Today

                              May 9, 2013 Thursday

US supports Pakistan's small farmers: Olsen

SECTION: Vol. III No. 310

LENGTH: 550  words


US Ambassador Richard Olson on Wednesday reaffirmed the United States (US)
government's long-term support to farming communities in Pakistan.

"Since the 1950s, the US has been working to support agriculture in Pakistan,
introducing the Kinnu and helping to double Pakistan's wheat production. Today,
we continue our support because improving crop yields, protecting food sources
from disease, and boosting milk production will increase the farmers' incomes,
improve nutrition, and ultimately strengthen Pakistan's prosperity," he said.

Addressing a gathering of government officials, researchers, and farmers during
his visit to the National Agriculture Research Center (NARC), Olson said, "The
US is committed to helping Pakistan's small farmers through projects that
enhance agricultural productivity."

The Ambassador lauded the Wheat Productivity Enhancement Project (WPEP)'s
progress, a United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) program managed in
collaboration with national and provincial research partners which has
successfully introduced the UG 99-resistant wheat variety.

This wheat variety helps protect against UG 99, a virulent wheat disease in the
region that poses a threat to Pakistan's farming community.

"Wheat constitutes approximately 60 percent of the daily caloric intake of the
average Pakistani, so our joint efforts to combat this disease are critical,"
the ambassador said. "The Wheat Productivity Enhancement Project team and
Pakistani scientists at national and provincial research stations have made
great progress in the fight against wheat rust, and I encourage them to continue
our work together."

Apart from the Wheat Productivity Enhancement Project, the US has also provided
new harvesting machines and funded improvements to research stations across
Pakistan to develop more disease-resistant wheat varieties. The country also
provides specialized training opportunities to Pakistani wheat scientists.

International Maize and Wheat Improvement Center Country Liaison Officer Dr.
Muhammad Imtiaz noted that without disease-resistant varieties of wheat, like
the one being harvested at NARC, experts estimate that Pakistan's annual wheat
harvest could be reduced by as much as 50 percent if and when UG 99 arrives.

"Agriculture contributes 21 percent to the Pakistan's GDP and employs 45 percent
of the labor force, making it among the most significant economic engines of
Pakistan," Dr. Imtiaz said. "Pakistani farmers grew about 24 million tons of
wheat on eight million hectares last year, accounting for about 2.4 percent of
the GDP," he added.

"The US and Pakistan have similar agricultural systems, and sowe have been
effective agricultural partners for more than 50 years, working together to
improve agricultural yields and to combat disease," said Ambassador Olson.

"Since the 1950s, American and Pakistani scientists have collaborated to
increase wheat production. At that time, Dr. Manzoor Bajwa and Dr. Norman
Borlaug collaborated to develop 'Mexi-Pak,' the wheat variety behind the Green
Revolution in Pakistan and helped to double Pakistan's wheat production between
1965 and 1970."

Ministry of National Food Security and Research Secretary Mr. Taimur Azmat Osman
and Pakistan Agriculture Research Centre (PARC) Chairman Dr. Iftikar Ahmed were
also present.s

LOAD-DATE: May 9, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                             998 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                   May 21, 2000, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

Rallying Round the China Bill, Hungrily: Agriculture;
Poised to Become A Big Winner

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA

SECTION: Section 3; Page 19; Column 4; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 384 words


American agriculture could be one of the biggest beneficiaries of the trade
bill.

After suffering through nearly three years of depressed commodity prices,
American farmers hope that improved trade relations will let them sell millions
of bushels of surplus corn, soybeans and other crops to China over the next few
years.

Last year, the United States had more than $50 billion in agricultural exports;
only about $1 billion of that went to China. Agriculture officials say that if
relations are normalized, exports could double in five years.

Farm equipment makers like Caterpillar, Deere and CNH project strong exports of
farm tractors and combines. Cargill and Archer Daniels Midland expect to sell
more processed goods, like soybean meal and vegetable oil. And the prices that
farmers get for beef, poultry and pork could also get a lift.

Nearly all agriculture officials see a win-win situation that could only
increase exports and raise commodity prices. "Everybody except for a few
splinter groups wants this to happen," said Bob Callanan, a spokesman at the
American Soybean Association. "China needs so much. Their people want to eat
better."

Soybeans are the leading American farm export to China. Although little corn
reaches the country, China has already made concessions that would include
importing 4.5 million metric tons of corn.

"It's not going to be easy to get China to implement this agreement," said Susan
Keith, an official at the National Corn Growers Association in St. Louis. "But
if they're denied access, they will do nothing to accommodate the U.S."

China has already said that if it receives trading privileges, it would lower
its tariffs on most American agricultural goods. Most everything from apples to
wine would have a better chance of getting in. Tariffs could fall from 31
percent today, on average, to 14 percent in 2004.

If China, as promised, also cuts subsidies to its own farmers, American corn
growers could have a better chance of selling their crops.

"China is the largest consumer market in the world," said Tamara White, director
of commodities at the Illinois Farm Bureau. "To get in on the ground level would
be great. You want American beef and American corn there, so you can get your
flavor on their taste buds."   DAVID BARBOZA


http://www.nytimes.com

LOAD-DATE: May 21, 2000

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 2000 The New York Times Company
